instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: ITG14 Shift To Ransomware With New TTPs
IBM X-Force Threat Intelligence has published a report on ITG14 and their shift from Point-of-Sale (POS) systems to ransomware and the emergence of new TTPs for the group.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware, Ransomware, Phishing, VBS, PowerShell, Backdoor




# Overview

IBM X-Force Threat Intelligence has published a report on ITG14, which shares overlap with FIN7 and CARBON SPIDER, and its latest shift from Point-of-Sale (POS) systems to ransomware with new TTPs. X-Force analysts have concluded ITG14 has worked as an affiliate of the Sodinokibi (aka REvil) ransomware-as-a-service (RaaS) group as well as possibly Ryuk. Additionally, ITG14 is reportedly behind the DarkSide RaaS operation. In this change of focus, the group has shifted from highly targeted, to more indiscriminate targeting of victims. Since March 2020, the group has been using VBS loaders to download the GRIFFON JScript backdoor, the JSSLoader .NET backdoor, and PowerShell loaders called TAKEOUT, SCRAMBLELOADER, and CLEARLOADER. The change in TTPs indicates the probable use of a new underground infrastructure, malware suppliers, and cooperation with other threat groups. The switch from POS attacks to ransomware indicates a decrease in revenue from POS attacks and the opportunity for more revenue through ransomware. The full story and analysis is available to IBM X-Force Premier Threat Intelligence clients at the link below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Indicators of compromise are available to IBM X-Force Premier Threat Intelligence clients at the link below.




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * Premier Threat Intelligence clients can read more at: <https://station.trustar.co/constellation/reports/e9dc890b-33ee-47eb-b1c4-3f30a16a5918>

  * To learn more about X-Force Premier Threat Intelligence, visit: <https://www.ibm.com/security/services/threat-intelligence>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Operation TooHash
Operation TooHash, discovered and reported on by G DATA, is a spearphishing campaign. While the majority of samples located by G DATA come from Taiwan, the use of Simplified Chinese in lure documents suggests the campaign could have targeted Greater China.
output:
, discovered and reported on by G DATA, is a spearphishing campaign. While the majority of samples located by G DATA come from Taiwan, the use of Simplified Chinese in lure documents suggests the campaign could have targeted Greater China.

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Spearphishing




# Overview

 is a spearphishing campaign that uses lure documents in the Simplified Chinese language. While the sample documents used in the campaign and identified by G DATA were mostly from Taiwan, the use of Simplified Chinese means the campaign documents could be used to target Greater China. The companies known to have been targeted in the campaign are involved in public research, telecommunications, and space research. The lure documents are used to exploit an old vulnerability, CVE-2012-0158. The exploit crashes Word but spawns another instance of Word, presumably to allay suspicion of malicious activity. If exploitation was successful, variants of the Cohhoc RAT and a rootkit named DirectsX were installed. The objective of the campaign is to steal information from the victims. Further information is available from G DATA's report which is linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://public.gdatasoftware.com/Presse/Publikationen/Whitepaper/EN/GDATA_TooHash_CaseStudy_102014_EN_v1.pdf>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Evolving Cryptominer Lucifer
Check Point researchers report on Lucifer which was originally just a Windows cryptominer and DDoS hybrid malware. They indicate that now it is not only multi-platform, but multi-architecture as well, bringing Linux and IoT devices into its sights.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Evolving Cryptominer Lucifer
Check Point researchers report on Lucifer which was originally just a Windows cryptominer and DDoS hybrid malware. They indicate that now it is not only multi-platform, but multi-architecture as well, bringing Linux and IoT devices into its sights.

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Cryptominer, DDoS



# Overview

Check Point researchers have published a paper on Lucifer. Going back as far as 2018, this cryptominer and DDoS malware hybrid targeted Windows systems. Current observations, though, show that Lucifer is now also targeting Linux and IoT systems. Data was collected from attacks in twenty-five companies in the US, Ireland, Netherlands, Turkey, and India. Industries targeted included manufacturing, legal, insurance, and financial. Self-propagation in the Windows version uses outdated and publicly-available exploits as well as brute-force attacks. The Linux and IoT versions do not have the self-propagation ability. Based on the Monero wallets used by Lucifer, Check Point suggested a possible campaign overlap from Lucifer to two malware packages called Rudeminer/Spreadminer and Blacksquid, based on two common wallets in play. The current version of Lucifer can carry out multiple forms of DDoS attacks, has full command and control capability to download and execute files, remote command execution, and Monero mining. For full technical details, including how this campaign was linked to others, please refer to the URL in the Reference section.

# CVEs

  * A complete list of CVEs can be found here: [ CVEs.txt](/download/attachments/30769362/Evolving%20Cryptominer%20Lucifer%20CVEs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1600195431255&api=v2)



# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/30769362/Evolving%20Cryptominer%20Lucifer%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1600195447139&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://research.checkpoint.com/2020/rudeminer-blacksquid-and-lucifer-walk-into-a-bar/>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Magniber Ransomware Evolving To Infect Chrome and Edge
The ransomware Magniber has historically only infected Internet Explorer. A report by the ASEC analysis team details how the ransomware is now infecting users of Google Chrome and Microsoft Edge.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Magniber Ransomware Evolving To Infect Chrome and Edge
The ransomware Magniber has historically only infected Internet Explorer. A report by the ASEC analysis team details how the ransomware is now infecting users of Google Chrome and Microsoft Edge.

# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Ransomware
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Unknown
  *  **Associated Payloads:** Magniber
  *  **Targets:** Users of Chrome, Edge, and IE.
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Phishing Sites
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Data Encyrption and Extortion



# Overview

The ASEC analysis team has been tracking the ransomware known as Magniber and its distribution methods. This ransomware is traditionally spread by exploiting Internet Explorer vulnerabilities and continues to be spread in this way. However, Magniber has recently been seen on both Microsoft Edge and Google Chrome. When the distribution pages are navigated to on these browsers, the user is asked to install an APPX file which is supposed to update the browser. Interestingly, the APPX file for both browsers contains a valid certificate, so the installation is allowed to go ahead. The result of this operation is a malicious executable and DLL file, which work together to download the ransomware and execute it in memory. Further information is available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/74056966/Magniber%20Ransomware%20Evolving%20To%20Infect%20Chrome%20and%20Edge%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1642174506730&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Ensure extensions that are installed are the intended ones as many malicious extensions will masquerade as legitimate ones (M1047).
  * Application control may be able to prevent the running of executables masquerading as other files (M1038).



# References

  * <https://asec.ahnlab.com/en/30645/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1189 - Drive-by Compromise  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1203 - Exploitation for Client Execution  
T1204 - User Execution  
T1204.002 - Malicious File  
  
 **Privilege Escalation - TA0004**  
T1548 - Abuse Elevation Control Mechanism  
T1548.002 - Bypass User Account Control  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1027 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
T1553 - Subvert Trust Controls  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1083 - File and Directory Discovery  
  
 **Impact - TA0040**  
T1486 - Data Encrypted for Impact

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: IBM X-Force Threat Activity Report - Nimar Backdoor
Throughout 2020 IBM X-Force saw a proliferation of malware created using the Go programming language, now some of that focus seems to be shifting onto the Nim programming language, with the latest addition being the Nimar Backdoor.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

Throughout 2020 IBM X-Force saw a proliferation of malware created using the Go programming language, now some of that focus seems to be shifting onto Nim. Nim is a flexible, statically typed programming language which is notable for having a straightforward, Python-like syntax, along with the ability to be compiled directly to C, C++, Objective-C or JavaScript. A number of Nim based malware samples have made their way into public repositories such as VirusTotal. These include loaders for Cobalt Strike and Meterpreter, shellcode loaders, process injectors, and cryptominers. The latest addition being the Nimar Backdoor.

# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * Premier Threat Intelligence clients can read more and see the indicators at: <https://station.trustar.co/constellation/reports/4113f4bc-b479-4116-a427-6165c84576f4>

  * To learn more about X-Force Premier Threat Intelligence, visit: <https://www.ibm.com/security/services/ibm-x-force-incident-response-and-intelligence>

IBM X-Force Threat Activity Report - Nimar Backdoor

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Apple Security Updates April 26 2021 - Exploitation in the Wild Reported
Apple has published security updates for iCloud for Windows, Xcode, Safari, iOS and iPadOS, watchOS, tvOS, and macOS: Big Sur, Catalina, and Mojave. One of the vulnerabilities (CVE-2021-30657) addressed in the updates for macOS Big Sur, and Catalina, has been reported independently as being exploited in the wild.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Apple Security Updates April 26 2021 - Exploitation in the Wild Reported
Apple has published security updates for iCloud for Windows, Xcode, Safari, iOS and iPadOS, watchOS, tvOS, and macOS: Big Sur, Catalina, and Mojave. One of the vulnerabilities (CVE-2021-30657) addressed in the updates for macOS Big Sur, and Catalina, has been reported independently as being exploited in the wild.

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

Apple has published security updates for iCloud for Windows, Xcode, Safari, iOS and iPadOS, watchOS, tvOS, and macOS: Big Sur, Catalina, and Mojave. Collectively, the updates address eighty-two CVE-numbered vulnerabilities. The potential impact from successful exploitation of the most serious vulnerabilities are privilege escalation and the remote execution of arbitrary code. One of the vulnerabilities (CVE-2021-30657) addressed in the updates for macOS Big Sur and Catalina has been independently reported as being exploited in the wild. Apple notes in their release details that the vulnerability may allow malicious applications to bypass Gatekeeper checks. A report from Jamf notes that a variant of the Shlayer malware is being spread through a malicious application. The application comes as a DMG file, which, when mounted and the contained application executed, will install Shlayer without any quarantine, signature, or notarization verification. Further details are available from the links in the Reference section below.

# CVEs

  * A complete list of CVEs can be found here: [ CVEs.txt](/download/attachments/48038071/Apple%20Security%20Updates%20April%2026%202021%20-%20Exploitation%20in%20the%20Wild%20Reported%20CVEs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1619583375177&api=v2)




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://support.apple.com/en-us/HT201222>

  * <https://support.apple.com/en-us/HT212321>

  * <https://support.apple.com/en-us/HT212320>

  * <https://support.apple.com/en-us/HT212318>

  * <https://support.apple.com/en-us/HT212325>

  * <https://support.apple.com/en-us/HT212326>

  * <https://support.apple.com/en-us/HT212327>

  * <https://support.apple.com/en-us/HT212317>

  * <https://support.apple.com/en-us/HT212324>

  * <https://support.apple.com/en-us/HT212323>

  * <https://objective-see.com/blog/blog_0x64.html>

  * <https://www.jamf.com/blog/shlayer-malware-abusing-gatekeeper-bypass-on-macos/>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: AvosLocker Ransomware Disables Anti-Virus
Trend Micro recently released a report on the AvosLocker ransomware. This is a newly scripted variant of ransomware that TrendMico has been tracking and is reported to have the ability to disable anti-virus solutions and in addition, is capable of scanning for the Log4Shell vulnerability.
output:
# Threat Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Ransomware ****
  * **Initial Infection Vector:** Suspected exploitation of a Zoho ManageEngine ADSelfService Plus vulnerability.
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Disabling Anti-Virus, Scanning for Log4Shell vulnerability.
  *  **Targets:** Critical Infrastructure in the U.S.



# Overview

Trend Micro is reporting on ransomware that is disabling anti-virus solutions. Specifically, the AvosLocker ransomware achieves this by utilizing legitimate drivers. The analyzed version also has the capability to scan for hosts running vulnerable instances of Log4j. While previous AvosLocker infections employ similar tactics, this is the first sample that Trend Micro has encountered with the capability to disable a defense solution using a legitimate Avast Anti-Rootkit Driver. Due to the lack of network traffic details, Trend Micro was unable to identify the exact CVE identifier of the security gap the attacker used. During monitoring, analysts observed that a new user account was created, added to the current domain, and included in the administrator group. Further information can be found in the article located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * For a list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.




# References

  * <https://www.trendmicro.com/en_us/research/22/e/avoslocker-ransomware-variant-abuses-driver-file-to-disable-anti-Virus-scans-log4shell.html>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Tactics and Techniques:**

 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1195.002 - Compromise Software Supply Chain  
  
 **Privilege Escalation - TA0004**  
T1068 - Exploitation for Privilege Escalation  
T1078.002 - Domain Accounts  
T1548 - Abuse Elevation Control Mechanism  
T1548.004 - Elevated Execution with Prompt  
  
 **Credential Access - TA0006**  
T1003 - OS Credential Dumping  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1007 - System Service Discovery  
T1057 - Process Discovery  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1219 - Remote Access Software

  
 **Mitigations:**

 **M1013:** Application Developer Guidance: This mitigation describes any guidance or training given to developers of applications to avoid introducing security weaknesses that an adversary may be able to take advantage of.  
 **M1015:** Active Directory Configuration - Configure Active Directory to prevent use of certain techniques; use SID Filtering, etc.  
 **M1016:** Vulnerability Scanning - Vulnerability scanning is used to find potentially exploitable software vulnerabilities to remediate them.  
 **M1017:** User Training - Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction.  
 **M1018:** User Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.  
 **M1019:** Threat Intelligence Program - A threat intelligence program helps an organization generate their own threat intelligence information and track trends to inform defensive priorities to mitigate risk.  
 **M1022:** Restrict File and Directory Permissions - Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.  
 **M1025:** Privileged Process Integrity - Protect processes with high privileges that can be used to interact with critical system components through use of protected process light, anti-process injection defenses, or other process integrity enforcement measures.  
 **M1026:** Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.  
 **M1027:** Password Policies - Set and enforce secure password policies for accounts.  
 **M1028:** Operating System Configuration - Make configuration changes related to the operating system or a common feature of the operating system that result in system hardening against techniques.  
 **M1031:** Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  
 **M1032:** Multi-factor Authentication - Use two or more pieces of evidence to authenticate to a system; such as username and password in addition to a token from a physical smart card or token generator.  
 **M1037:** Filter Network Traffic - Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic.  
 **M1038:** Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
 **M1040:** Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
 **M1041:** Encrypt Sensitive Information - Protect sensitive information with strong encryption.  
 **M1043:** Credential Access Protection - Use capabilities to prevent successful credential access by adversaries; including blocking forms of credential dumping.  
 **M1046:** Boot Integrity - Use secure methods to boot a system and verify the integrity of the operating system and loading mechanisms.  
 **M1047:** Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
 **M1048:** Application Isolation and Sandboxing - Restrict execution of code to a virtual environment on or in transit to an endpoint system.  
 **M1050:** Exploit Protection - Use capabilities to detect and block conditions that may lead to or be indicative of a software exploit occurring.  
 **M1051:** Update Software - Perform regular software updates to mitigate exploitation risk.  
 **M1052:** User Account Control - Configure Windows User Account Control to mitigate risk of adversaries obtaining elevated process access.

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Webex Invite Themed Phish
Providing further examples of their previous Webex-themed phish findings, Cofense reports on a Webex invite themed lure being used in a recent phishing campaign.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Webex Invite Themed Phish
Providing further examples of their previous Webex-themed phish findings, Cofense reports on a Webex invite themed lure being used in a recent phishing campaign.

# Threat Type

  * Phishing




# Overview

Cofense has discovered a new phishing campaign pivoting away from the previous Webex vulnerability and SSL certificate fix lure to a more subtle Webex invite theme. The phishing email claims an "Online Leader" has invited the recipient to attend a Webex event and provides a link to join the meeting. The link points to a lookalike domain name attempting to appear to be the legitimate site. The phishing page content itself is almost identical to the legitimate Webex login page. After entering login credentials, victims are redirected to a form attempting to gather even more personal information. Submitting this secondary form shows a registration confirmation page that claims a follow up email will be sent to the user. Meanwhile, the attacker has obtained all entered data for future use. For more information, see the Cofense blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://cofense.com/online-leader-invites-you-to-this-webex-phish/>

Tell me about the following threat: SAP Security Patch Day - January 2021
The SAP Product Security Response Team has issued an advisory detailing the security vulnerabilities patched its latest release.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: SAP Security Patch Day - January 2021
The SAP Product Security Response Team has issued an advisory detailing the security vulnerabilities patched its latest release.

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability



# Overview

 A total of thirty-two vulnerabilities were patched in this release. Issues resolved include code injection, privilege escalation, denial of service, missing authorization check, information disclosure, header manipulation, cross-site scripting, missing encryption, improper input validation, and XML external entity vulnerabilities. We recommend reviewing the advisory linked in the Reference section for further details and allocating testing time prior to updating production systems.

# CVEs

  * A complete list of CVEs can be found here: [SAP Security Patch DAy - January 2021 CVEs.txt](/download/attachments/35720108/SAP%20Security%20Patch%20DAy%20-%20January%202021%20CVEs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1610638060866&api=v2)

  * CVE-2021-21445: SQL_Injection
  * CVE-2021-21447: Cross_Site_Scripting
  * CVE-2021-21465: SQL_Injection



# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * https://wiki.scn.sap.com/wiki/pages/viewpage.action?pageId=564760476

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Crytominer and DDoS Bot Malware Loaded Onto Docker Image
Trend Micro is reporting that Alpine Linux Docker images are being attacked and loaded with crytominer and DDoS bot code. A similar attack in May of this year was also reported by Trend Micro.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Crytominer and DDoS Bot Malware Loaded Onto Docker Image
Trend Micro is reporting that Alpine Linux Docker images are being attacked and loaded with crytominer and DDoS bot code. A similar attack in May of this year was also reported by Trend Micro.

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Cryptominer, Bot, DDoS



# Overview

Reminiscent of an attack Trend Micro reported on in May of this year, they are now reporting on a similar attack. Docker images, based on Alpine Linux, are being attacked. Should the attack be successful, the server is infected with a cryptominer and DDoS bot malware. Infection begins on an exposed Docker server by creating a Docker container and running a script that retrieves an XMI file, which is really a bash script inside the container. This script then attempts to move laterally across the network, targeting hosts listed in the known_hosts file in the .ssh directory. Hosts listed in this file are systems this host / user has connected to in the past over an SSH connection. In some cases, the remote host might have this system's public key in their authorized_keys file, thus a connection could be made without knowing login credentials. The XMI script also downloads and executes other commands, such as those needed to set up cron jobs and services for persistence. Other commands in the script were commented out, such as one that appears to attempt to connect to SSH servers through brute-forcing the password. Trend Micro noted that the cryptocurrency wallet was the same one seen in campaigns that attempted to exploit a Confluence vulnerability (CVE-2019-3396) and an Apache Struts vulnerability (CVE-2017-5638). The XMI script then drops a cryptominer malware package and the DDoS bot. For more technical details, please see the Trend Micro article in the Reference section.

# CVEs

  * A complete list of CVEs can be found here: [ CVEs.txt](/download/attachments/29431538/Crytominer%20and%20DDoS%20Bot%20Malware%20Loaded%20Onto%20Docker%20Image%20CVEs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1599672212428&api=v2)



# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/29431538/Crytominer%20and%20DDoS%20Bot%20Malware%20Loaded%20Onto%20Docker%20Image%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1599672176075&api=v2)



# Protection

  * CVE-2019-3396: HTTP_Confluence_JSON_Injection
  * CVE-2017-5638: HTTP_Apache_Jakarta_Multipart_Exec



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.trendmicro.com/en_us/research/20/i/exposed-docker-server-abused-to-drop-cryptominer-ddos-bot-.html>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Grandoreiro Banking Trojan Impersonates Spain's Tax Agency
Despite tax season being mostly over, ESET has observed a Grandoreiro campaign impersonating Agencia Tributaria in phishing emails to distribute its payload.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware, Banking Trojan




# Overview

ESET has published a blog post analyzing a Grandoreiro campaign impersonating Agencia Tributaria to send tax-themed emails. The email claims that a linked ZIP file contains tax documents that need to be viewed by the recipient. Visiting the link downloads a ZIP archive containing an MSI file and GIF image. The researchers note that the domain the archive is downloaded from a domain that was registered on the same day of the campaign with a registrant country of Brazil. The name of the ZIP file includes a country code of "ES" and ESET was able to identify other files hosted on Dropbox that appear to be related but have other country codes, indicating that the campaign is targeting other countries also, not just Spain. If a victim runs the MSI installer contained inside the ZIP archive, the Grandoreiro banking trojan is installed and begins stealing data, which will later be exfiltrated to the attacker. For more information, see the WeLiveSecurity blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.welivesecurity.com/2020/08/21/grandoreiro-banking-trojan-impersonates-spain-tax-agency/>

I have encountered the following information: ETERBASE Exchange Hot Wallets Compromised
Breach / Leak Notifications: Hot wallets belonging to ETERBASE Exchange were compromised, and approximately $5.4 million was stolen.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

Breach, Compromise

# Overview

ETERBASE Exchange's hot wallets were compromised, they announced. Approximately 5.4 million dollars in assets were stolen as a result. As such, they have created new wallets and their addresses can be found in the links in the Reference section. The appropriate law enforcement agencies have been notified and a security audit begun. Upon completion of the audit, they will resume operations.

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: IBM Publishes Eight Security Guardium Security Bulletins
IBM has published eight security bulletins covering Security Guardium. The bulletins cover issues such as OS command injection, kernel vulnerabilities, Java vulnerabilities, third-party vulnerabilities, cross-site scripting issues, and hard-coded credentials.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Vulnerabilities



# Overview

IBM has published eight security bulletins covering fifty-nine vulnerabilities patched in the current version of Security Guardium.   
  
Two bulletins deal with OS command injection vulnerabilities (CVE-2020-4180 and CVE-2020-4183). In the first bulletin, a remote authenticated attacker could potentially send a specially crafted request to the system that exploits this vulnerability. If successful, the execution of arbitrary commands may be possible. The second bulletin describes a cross-site scripting issue that could allow the attacker to embed arbitrary JavaScript code into the Web UI. This could potentially lead to credential disclosure.   
  
Guardium is also vulnerable to a kernel vulnerability that could lead to a denial of service condition. This is due to a race condition between mmget_not_zero()/get_task_mm() and core dumping. A specially crafted system call could lead to a system crash or sensitive information being leaked.   
  
Eleven vulnerabilities were patched in the IBM Java SDK. Results from successful exploitation includes low confidentiality impact, low integrity impact, no availability, or leaking of sensitive information.   
  
Forty-three vulnerabilities were disclosed in two bulletins identifying third-party product vulnerabilities. These products include Jackson Library, Jackson-databind, FasterXML Jackson-databind, Oracle products, Huawei products, and Apache Log4j.   
  
The next bulletin describes a cross-site scripting vulnerability that could potentially lead to credential disclosure if successfully exploited.   
  
The last bulletin describes a hard-coded credential use that was fixed.   
  
IBM has provided updates that address all of the issues listed above.

# CVEs

  * For a complete list of CVEs, click here: [ CVEs.txt](/download/attachments/29428709/IBM%20Publishes%20Eight%20Security%20Guardium%20Security%20Bulletins%20CVEs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1599080547172&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Review bulletins carefully for vulnerable systems versions and technical details

  * Apply update as soon as possible

If successful, the execution of arbitrary commands may be possible. Forty-three vulnerabilities were disclosed in two bulletins identifying third-party product vulnerabilities. These products include Jackson Library, Jackson-databind, FasterXML Jackson-databind, Oracle products, Huawei products, and Apache Log4j.   
  
The next bulletin describes a cross-site scripting vulnerability that could potentially lead to credential disclosure if successfully exploited.   
  
The last bulletin describes a hard-coded credential use that was fixed.

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: ICS-CERT Advisories March 02 2021
The ICS-CERT has published 3 advisories that affect Hitachi ABB Power Grids Ellipse EAM, Rockwell Automation CompactLogix 5370 and ControlLogix 5570 Controllers, and MB connect line mbCONNECT24, mymbCONNECT24.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: ICS-CERT Advisories March 02 2021
The ICS-CERT has published 3 advisories that affect Hitachi ABB Power Grids Ellipse EAM, Rockwell Automation CompactLogix 5370 and ControlLogix 5570 Controllers, and MB connect line mbCONNECT24, mymbCONNECT24.

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

 Further information is available from the advisories which are summarized below.

 **ICS Advisory ICSA-21-061-01 - Hitachi ABB Power Grids Ellipse EAM**  
CVE-2021-27416 - An attacker could exploit this vulnerability by tricking a user to click on a link containing malicious code that would then be run by the web browser. This can result in the compromise of confidential information, or even the takeover of the user’s session.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 5.5 - CVSS Vector String: AV:N/AC:L/PR:L/UI:R/S:U/C:L/I:L/A:L).

CVE-2021-27414 - An attacker could trick a user into visiting a malicious website posing as a login page for the Ellipse application and gather authentication credentials.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 5.5 - CVSS Vector String: AV:N/AC:L/PR:L/UI:R/S:U/C:L/I:L/A:L).  
<https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ics/advisories/icsa-21-061-01>

 **ICS Advisory ICSA-21-061-02 - Rockwell Automation CompactLogix 5370 and ControlLogix 5570 Controllers**  
CVE-2020-6998 - The connection establishment algorithm found in CompactLogix 5370 and ControlLogix 5570 does not sufficiently manage its control flow during execution, creating an infinite loop. This may allow an attacker to send specially crafted CIP packet requests to a controller, which may cause denial-of-service conditions in communications with other products.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 5.8 - assigned; the CVSS vector string is (AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:C/C:N/I:N/A:L).  
<https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ics/advisories/icsa-21-061-02>

 **ICS Advisory ICSA-21-061-03 - MB connect line mbCONNECT24, mymbCONNECT24**  
CVE-2020-12527 - Improper access validation may allow a logged-in user to see devices in an account to which they should not have access.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 6.5 - CVSS Vector String: AV:N/AC:L/PR:L/UI:N/S:U/C:H/I:N/A:N).

CVE-2020-12528 - Improper access validation may allow a logged-in user to kill web2go sessions in an account to which they should not have access.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 6.5 - CVSS Vector String: AV:N/AC:L/PR:L/UI:N/S:U/C:H/I:N/A:N).

CVE-2020-12529 - There is a SSRF issue in the LDAP access check, allowing an attacker to scan for open ports.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 5.8 - CVSS Vector String: AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:C/C:L/I:N/A:N).

CVE-2020-12530 - There is an XSS issue in the redirect.php, allowing an attacker to inject code via a get parameter.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 4.3 - CVSS Vector String: AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:R/S:U/C:N/I:L/A:N).

CVE-2020-35557 - Improper access validation may allow a logged-in user to see devices in the account to which they should not have access.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 6.5 - CVSS Vector String: AV:N/AC:L/PR:L/UI:N/S:U/C:H/I:N/A:N).

CVE-2020-35558 - There is a SSRF issue in the MySQL access check, allowing an attacker to scan for open ports and gain information about credentials.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 5.8 - CVSS Vector String: AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:C/C:L/I:N/A:N).

CVE-2020-35559 - There is an unused function that allows an authenticated attacker to use up all available IPs of an account, preventing the creation of new devices and users.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 4.3 - CVSS Vector String: AV:N/AC:L/PR:L/UI:N/S:U/C:N/I:N/A:L).

CVE-2020-35560 - There is an unauthenticated open redirect in the redirect.php.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 4.3 - CVSS Vector String: AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:R/S:U/C:N/I:L/A:N).

CVE-2020-35561 - There is a SSRF issue in the HA module allowing an unauthenticated attacker to scan for open ports.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 5.8 - CVSS Vector String: AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:C/C:L/I:N/A:N).

CVE-2020-35563 - There is an incomplete XSS filter allowing an attacker to inject specially crafted malicious code into the page.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 3.5 - CVSS Vector String: AV:N/AC:L/PR:L/UI:R/S:U/C:N/I:L/A:N).

CVE-2020-35564 - There is an outdated and unused component, which may allow malicious input of active code.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 4.3 - CVSS Vector String: AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:R/S:U/C:N/I:L/A:N).

CVE-2020-35565 - Brute force detection is disabled by default on the login page.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 5.9 - CVSS Vector String: AV:N/AC:H/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:H/I:N/A:N).

CVE-2020-35566 - An attacker can read arbitrary JSON files via local file inclusion.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 5.3 - CVSS Vector String: AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:L/I:N/A:N).

CVE-2020-35567 - The software uses a secure password for database access, but this password is shared between instances.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 7.8 - CVSS Vector String: AV:L/AC:L/PR:L/UI:N/S:U/C:H/I:H/A:H).

CVE-2020-35568 - An incomplete filter applied to a database response allows an authenticated attacker to gain non-public information about other users and devices in the account.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 4.3 - CVSS Vector String: AV:N/AC:L/PR:L/UI:N/S:U/C:N/I:N/A:L).

CVE-2020-35569 - There is a self XSS issue with a crafted cookie in the login page.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 3.3 - CVSS Vector String: AV:L/AC:L/PR:N/UI:R/S:U/C:N/I:L/A:N).

CVE-2020-35570 - Improper access validation may allow a logged-in user to kill web2go sessions in the account to which they should not have access.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 5.3 - CVSS Vector String: AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:L/I:N/A:N).

CVE-2020-10384 - There is a local privilege escalation from the www-data account to the root account.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 7.8 - CVSS Vector String: AV:L/AC:L/PR:L/UI:N/S:U/C:H/I:H/A:H).  
<https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ics/advisories/icsa-21-061-03>

# CVEs

  * A complete list of CVEs can be found here: [ CVEs.txt](/download/attachments/42434956/ICS-CERT%20Advisories%20March%2002%202021%20CVEs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1614738874435&api=v2)




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ics/advisories>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Further NOBELIUM Information From Microsoft
In a follow-on from its prior blog postings on NOBELIUM activity, Microsoft has published another blog post on NOBELIUM. This post focuses on the toolset used by NOBELIUM in the early stages of an attack.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware




# Overview

In a blog post, Microsoft reference four tools, BoomBox, EnvyScout, NativeZone, and VaporRage, used by NOBELIUM during the early stages of gaining a foothold in a target entity. The tools have been observed in use since February 2021. BoomBox is a downloader that downloads components from Dropbox. It also uploads reconnaissance information to Dropbox. EnvyScout is also a dropper typically delivered to the victim as an attachment to a spearphishing email. It has multiple components including an obfuscated ISO, and others the carry out functions such as credential-harvesting, tracking, and deobfuscating files and writing them to disk. Multiple variants of EnvyScout are detailed in the blog post. NativeZone is a loader that uses rundll32.exe to load components. VaporRage is described as a shellcode downloader that contacts a legitimate, but compromised, Wordpess site, and registers the system as compromised. If the system is of interest to the attackers, it downloads a shellcode blob from the same site, decodes, and executes it in memory. In addition, Microsoft notes that NOBELIUM use a number of custom Cobalt Strike Beacon loaders which Microsoft will track under the name NativeZone. Further information is available from the blog post linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.microsoft.com/security/blog/2021/05/28/breaking-down-nobeliums-latest-early-stage-toolset/>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: iTunes 12.11 for Windows
Apple has released a security update for iTunes for Windows, bringing the version up to 12.11. This release patches six security vulnerabilities.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability



# Overview

In a security update for iTunes for Windows, the updated version 12.11 corrects six security vulnerabilities. Issues include the ability to read arbitrary files, arbitrary code execution, unexpected application termination, or access the user's Apple IDs. For full details, please refer to the Apple link in the Reference section.

# CVEs

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary.

  * <https://support.apple.com/en-us/HT211933>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Hackers Target Hiring Managers with More_Eggs Malware
eSentire's Threat Response Unit (TRU) has discovered a phishing campaign that is targeting corporate hiring managers. The hackers behind this campaign, pose as job applicants and forward resumes to these hiring managers. The resumes contain the more_eggs malware that is then downloaded for network exploitation.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Infostealer
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** FIN6, Evilnum, Cobalt Group, Golden Chickens, Venom Spider
  *  **Associated Payloads:** VenomLNK, TerraLoader, TerraPreter, TerraTV, TerraCrypt 
  * **Targets:** Corporate Hiring Managers
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Phishing 
  * **Post-Compromise Actions:** Unknown
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below



# Overview

eSentire’s security team recently discovered a campaign that is targeting hiring managers. The campaign involves hackers sending out resumes to corporate hiring managers and posing as interested candidates. The campaign appears to be targeted as the resumes that were sent out responded to job postings connected to specific organizations. Once the resume is received and opened, the malware known as more_eggs is downloaded. More_eggs targets usernames and passwords, corporate bank accounts, email accounts, and IT administrator accounts. More_eggs contains a suite of malware with the capabilities to target a number of processes. This malware includes VenomLNK which targets Windows LNK files to automate program delivery and TerraStealer which seeks sensitive data to exfiltrate. Additionally, more_eggs utilizes TerraTV which allows the attacker to take control of TeamViewer for possible lateral movement in the network and includes TerraCrypt to download PureLocker ransomware. More_eggs is a file-less malware that evades anti-virus and is a particular concern for employees working remotely. 

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Full mitigative measures are located below the MITRE ATT&CK matrix.



# References

  * <https://www.esentire.com/blog/hackers-spearphish-corporate-hiring-managers-with-poisoned-resumes-infecting-them-with-the-more-eggs-malware>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

####  **Tactics and Techniques:**

####  **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
T1059.003 - Windows Command Shell  
  
 **Privilege Escalation - TA0004**  
T1546.003 - Windows Management Instrumentation Event Subscription  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1027 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
T1070 - Indicator Removal on Host  
T1070.004 - File Deletion  
T1140 - Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information  
T1218 - Signed Binary Proxy Execution  
T1218.010 - Regsvr32  
T1220 - XSL Script Processing  
T1553 - Subvert Trust Controls  
T1553.002 - Code Signing  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1016 - System Network Configuration Discovery  
T1016.001 - Internet Connection Discovery  
T1033 - System Owner/User Discovery  
T1069 - Permission Groups Discovery  
T1082 - System Information Discovery  
T1518 - Software Discovery  
T1518.001 - Security Software Discovery  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
T1071.001 - Web Protocols  
T1105 - Ingress Tool Transfer  
T1132 - Data Encoding  
T1132.001 - Standard Encoding  
T1573 - Encrypted Channel  
T1573.001 - Symmetric Cryptography

####  **Mitigations:**

####  **M1018:** User Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.  
 **M1020:** SSL/TLS Inspection - Break and inspect SSL/TLS sessions to look at encrypted web traffic for adversary activity.  
 **M1021:** Restrict Web-Based Content - Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc.  
 **M1022:** Restrict File and Directory Permissions - Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.  
 **M1024:** Restrict Registry Permissions - Restrict the ability to modify certain hives or keys in the Windows Registry.  
 **M1026:** Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.  
 **M1028:** Operating System Configuration - Make configuration changes related to the operating system or a common feature of the operating system that result in system hardening against techniques.  
 **M1029:** Remote Data Storage - Use remote security log and sensitive file storage where access can be controlled better to prevent exposure of intrusion detection log data or sensitive information.  
 **M1031:** Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  
 **M1033:** Limit Software Installation - Block users or groups from installing unapproved software.  
 **M1035:** Limit Access to Resource Over Network - Prevent access to file shares, remote access to systems, unnecessary services. Mechanisms to limit access may include use of network concentrators, RDP gateways, etc.  
 **M1037:** Filter Network Traffic - Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic.  
 **M1038:** Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
 **M1039:** Environment Variable Permissions - Prevent modification of environment variables by unauthorized users and groups.  
 **M1040:** Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
 **M1041:** Encrypt Sensitive Information - Protect sensitive information with strong encryption.  
 **M1042:** Disable or Remove Feature or Program - Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.  
 **M1045:** Code Signing - Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.  
 **M1046:** Boot Integrity - Use secure methods to boot a system and verify the integrity of the operating system and loading mechanisms.  
 **M1047:** Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
 **M1049:** Antivirus/Antimalware - Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software.  
 **M1050:** Exploit Protection - Use capabilities to detect and block conditions that may lead to or be indicative of a software exploit occurring.  
 **M1051:** Update Software - Perform regular software updates to mitigate exploitation risk.  
 **M1052:** User Account Control - Configure Windows User Account Control to mitigate risk of adversaries obtaining elevated process access.  
 **M1054:** Software Configuration - Implement configuration changes to software (other than the operating system) to mitigate security risks associated to how the software operates.

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Unattributed Threat Actor Targeting the Finance and Investment Sectors
A report from Red Alert provides insight on a campaign that has been targeting the finance and investment sectors for at least a year.
output:
# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Unspecified though likely an infostealer.
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Unattributed, though has similarities to a known state-sponsored group.
  *  **Associated Payloads:** Unspecified
  *  **Targets:** Finance and Investment sectors.
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Word documents and template injection.
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Unspecified, though likely stealing financial related information.
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

A campaign that has been targeting the finance and investment sectors for at least a year had its beginnings around August 2020. Users within an organization are sent spear-phishing emails with an attached Word document. Various lure documents have been used, mostly purporting to be financial information from various legitimate companies. At least some of the documents, if opened by a victim, popup a notification that the document has been "secured by Kaspersky" and the victim is asked to click "Enable Content" to view it. Clicking Enable Content enables macros and results in a remote template being downloaded and injected into the document. No information on the actual payloads is provided in the report. The campaign's C&C servers use domain names that relate to businesses such as those involved in blockchain, coin exchanges, energy innovation, investment, and software. The C&C traffic is secured using SSL and free multi-domain certificates that are valid for 90 days. Once a certificate has expired the actors obtain new certificates and make any required changes to the included domains. While the actor behind the campaign is not attributed to any known entity, the report does note that the actor shows similarities with a known state-sponsored group. The objective of the campaign is believed to be stealing financial information or transaction details. Further information is available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/70222121/Unattributed%20Threat%20Actor%20Targeting%20the%20Finance%20and%20Investment%20Sectors%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1636432249461&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques and phishing emails (M1017).



# References

  * <https://redalert.nshc.net/2021/11/04/threat-actor-targeted-attack-against-finance-and-investment-industry/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1566 - Phishing  
T1566.001 - Spearphishing Attachment  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
T1059.003 - Windows Command Shell  
T1059.005 - Visual Basic  
T1106 - Native API  
T1204 - User Execution  
T1204.001 - Malicious Link  
T1204.002 - Malicious File  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1036 - Masquerading  
T1221 - Template Injection  
T1564.003 - Hidden Window  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1049 - System Network Connections Discovery  
T1082 - System Information Discovery  
T1083 - File and Directory Discovery  
  
 **Collection - TA0009**  
T1005 - Data from Local System  
T1119 - Automated Collection  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0010**  
T1020 - Automated Exfiltration  
T1041 - Exfiltration Over C2 Channel  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
T1071.001 - Web Protocols  
T1102 - Web Service  
T1105 - Ingress Tool Transfer  
T1571 - Non-Standard Port

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Dridex Affiliate Using COVID and Job Termination Lures
Researchers at Malwarebytes uncovered a Dridex affiliate leveraging job termination and COVID test result lures to deliver their payload.
output:
# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Loader
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Dridex affiliate
  *  **Associated Payloads:** Dridex
  *  **Targets:** Unknown 
  * **Initial Infection Vector:** Malicious email attachment
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Install additional malware



# Overview

Malwarebytes published a blog post analyzing a recent Dridex campaign. The affiliate behind this activity had two different lures attempting to get victims to open a malicious attachment. The first version claims that the attached file is a termination letter, while the other uses fake COVID Omicron variant test results as a lure. In either case, users are enticed to open the attached Excel file using a provided password. The use of password protection on the file allows for sandbox evasion. If the user opens the file and enables macros, an RTF file is written and executed, ultimately leading to the Dridex payload being downloaded from a Discord server. When running on the system, Dridex allows its operator to install secondary malicious payloads, such as ransomware. For more information, see the Malwarebytes blog post in the References section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/74056498/Dridex%20Affiliate%20Using%20COVID%20and%20Job%20Termination%20Lures%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1640893643480&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Restrict Web-Based Content (M1021).
  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques and phishing emails (M1017).



# References

  * <https://blog.malwarebytes.com/threat-intelligence/2021/12/dridex-affiliate-dresses-up-as-scrooge/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Resource Development - TA0042**

T1059.005 - Visual Basic

T1204.002 - Malicious File  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**

T1218.005 - Mshta

T1071.001 - Web Protocols

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Latest Attack Techniques From Qbot
Check Point published their latest findings on a ten year old banking Trojan called Qbot. They indicated that, despite its age, Qbot is still being improved and is still a threat.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Trojan, Campaigns



# Overview

Check Point examines the new techniques that a decade old banking Trojan called Qbot (aka Qakbot and Pinkslipbot) is exhibiting. The malware is capable of stealing information such as passwords, emails, credit card information, and more. It can also be used as a downloader for other malware, including ransomware packages. Commands from the bot controller can cause Qbot, on the infected system, to connect and make financial transactions with the victim's credentials. Additionally, Qbot can use stolen emails to send replies to other potential victims, making such replies appear legitimate. In July, Check Point observed an Emotet campaign that dropped a newer copy of Qbot on victims' systems. August saw a new malspam campaign distributing Qbot. The majority of the victims in this campaign resided in the US and Europe, with government, military, and manufacturing industries being the most targeted. The infection vector is an email, possibly an email thread stolen from a previous victim, with a malicious attachment or URL. A Visual Basic Script (VBS) stored in a malicious archive is used to start the infection process. Using VBS as a standalone script is relatively new (since April 2020) for malware. Normally, VBS is used as the macro in a weaponized Word document for installation. The VBS file is padded with NULL bytes to make it larger than 35 megabytes, a figure most sandboxes ignore. Once activated, the script sleeps for a period of time, also in an attempt to bypass sandbox environments. Obfuscation is used, as well as a number of anti-virtual machine and anti-debugging techniques, to avoid detection. Persistence is gained through registry keys and a scheduled task. For full technical details, please visit the link in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/28379390/Latest%20Attack%20Techniques%20From%20Qbot%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1598562243434&api=v2)



# Protection

  * Yara Rules can be found here: [ Yara.txt](/download/attachments/28379390/Latest%20Attack%20Techniques%20From%20Qbot%20Yara.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1598562282998&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://research.checkpoint.com/2020/exploring-qbots-latest-attack-methods/>

  * Malware, Trojan, Campaigns



# Overview

Check Point examines the new techniques that a decade old banking Trojan called Qbot (aka Qakbot and Pinkslipbot) is exhibiting. The malware is capable of stealing information such as passwords, emails, credit card information, and more. It can also be used as a downloader for other malware, including ransomware packages. Commands from the bot controller can cause Qbot, on the infected system, to connect and make financial transactions with the victim's credentials. Additionally, Qbot can use stolen emails to send replies to other potential victims, making such replies appear legitimate. In July, Check Point observed an Emotet campaign that dropped a newer copy of Qbot on victims' systems. August saw a new malspam campaign distributing Qbot. The majority of the victims in this campaign resided in the US and Europe, with government, military, and manufacturing industries being the most targeted. The infection vector is an email, possibly an email thread stolen from a previous victim, with a malicious attachment or URL. A Visual Basic Script (VBS) stored in a malicious archive is used to start the infection process. Using VBS as a standalone script is relatively new (since April 2020) for malware. Normally, VBS is used as the macro in a weaponized Word document for installation. The VBS file is padded with NULL bytes to make it larger than 35 megabytes, a figure most sandboxes ignore. Once activated, the script sleeps for a period of time, also in an attempt to bypass sandbox environments. Obfuscation is used, as well as a number of anti-virtual machine and anti-debugging techniques, to avoid detection. Persistence is gained through registry keys and a scheduled task. For full technical details, please visit the link in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/28379390/Latest%20Attack%20Techniques%20From%20Qbot%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1598562243434&api=v2)



# Protection

  * Yara Rules can be found here: [ Yara.txt](/download/attachments/28379390/Latest%20Attack%20Techniques%20From%20Qbot%20Yara.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1598562282998&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://research.checkpoint.com/2020/exploring-qbots-latest-attack-methods/>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Silently Running Facebook Ads with Exploits
At this year's Virus Bulletin international conference, which was virtual, researchers from FaceBook presented the findings of their research into a malware family they’ve named "SilentFade". The name is short for "Silently running Facebook ADs with Exploits".
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware




# Overview

Facebook researchers believe that malware named SilentFade, and the creators and operators of it, came onto the scene in early 2016. Since then, the SilentFade malware has been consistently improved with additional features and has been expanded to target other social networks and services. SilentFade is typically installed through a downloader that is bundled with pirated software. There are usually three or four components, including the downloader, that make up the SilentFade package. The downloader installs the payload as either a standalone component, or as a Windows service. Successfully installed, SilentFade will obtain the victim's Facebook credentials along with cookies from various browsers. As the name says, the objective of SilentFade is to run ads and pay for them using the stolen account credentials. Facebook attributes SilentFade to a Chinese company and filed a lawsuit against the company in December 2019. SilentFade has so far resulted in payment and ad fraud worth more than 4 million USD. See the report linked in the Reference section below for further details.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://vblocalhost.com/uploads/VB2020-Karve-Urgilez.pdf>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Haskers Gang Gives Away Ginzo Stealer For Free
G DATA Software has identified more than 400 samples for Ginzo stealer within a 10 day period at the end of March. The stealer is obfuscated with ConfuserEx making it difficult to decompile. The Haskers Gang has released Ginzo for free and it has gained traction.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Infostealer
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Haskers Gang
  *  **Associated Payloads:** antivm.exe coinminer, generation.exe stealer
  *  **Targets:** Unspecified
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Unspecified
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Collection and exfiltration of information.
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

The Ginzo stealer, released by the Haskers Gang for free, has been gaining traction as more than 400 samples were identified in the short timespan of 10 days. The stealer obtains general system data, telegram sessions, browser stored cookies and passwords, all desktop files, discord tokens, and cryptocurrency wallets. The stealer downloads a configuration file from the C&C server which contains additional download locations for executables. The downloaded files may include additional stealers, coinminers, and other malware. Further information is available from the link in the Reference section below. 

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * For a full list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.




# References

  * <https://www.gdatasoftware.com/blog/2022/03/ginzo-free-malware>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

#### Tactics and Techniques:

  
 **Credential Access - TA0006**  
T1528 - Steal Application Access Token  
T1539 - Steal Web Session Cookie  
T1552 - Unsecured Credentials  
T1552.001 - Credentials In Files  
T1555 - Credentials from Password Stores  
T1555.003 - Credentials from Web Browsers  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1082 - System Information Discovery  
T1087 - Account Discovery  
T1087.001 - Local Account  
T1124 - System Time Discovery  
  
 **Collection - TA0009**  
T1005 - Data from Local System  
T1074 - Data Staged  
T1074.001 - Local Data Staging  
T1119 - Automated Collection  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0010**  
T1020 - Automated Exfiltration  
T1041 - Exfiltration Over C2 Channel  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1102 - Web Service  
T1102.003 - One-Way Communication  
  


#### Mitigations:

  
 **M1015:** Active Directory Configuration - Configure Active Directory to prevent use of certain techniques; use SID Filtering, etc.  
 **M1017:** User Training - Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction.  
 **M1018:** User Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.  
 **M1021:** Restrict Web-Based Content - Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc.  
 **M1022:** Restrict File and Directory Permissions - Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.  
 **M1026:** Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.  
 **M1027:** Password Policies - Set and enforce secure password policies for accounts.  
 **M1028:** Operating System Configuration - Make configuration changes related to the operating system or a common feature of the operating system that result in system hardening against techniques.  
 **M1029:** Remote Data Storage - Use remote security log and sensitive file storage where access can be controlled better to prevent exposure of intrusion detection log data or sensitive information.  
 **M1030:** Network Segmentation - Architect sections of the network to isolate critical systems, functions, or resources. Use physical and logical segmentation to prevent access to potentially sensitive systems and information. Use a DMZ to contain any internet-facing services that should not be exposed from the internal network. Configure separate virtual private cloud (VPC) instances to isolate critical cloud systems.  
 **M1031:** Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  
 **M1032:** Multi-factor Authentication - Use two or more pieces of evidence to authenticate to a system; such as username and password in addition to a token from a physical smart card or token generator.  
 **M1035:** Limit Access to Resource Over Network - Prevent access to file shares, remote access to systems, unnecessary services. Mechanisms to limit access may include use of network concentrators, RDP gateways, etc.  
 **M1037:** Filter Network Traffic - Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic.  
 **M1041:** Encrypt Sensitive Information - Protect sensitive information with strong encryption.  
 **M1042:** Disable or Remove Feature or Program - Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.  
 **M1047:** Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
 **M1051:** Update Software - Perform regular software updates to mitigate exploitation risk.  
 **M1054:** Software Configuration - Implement configuration changes to software (other than the operating system) to mitigate security risks associated to how the software operates.  
 **M1057:** Data Loss Prevention - Use a data loss prevention (DLP) strategy to categorize sensitive data, identify data formats indicative of personal identifiable information (PII), and restrict exfiltration of sensitive data.

 **Exfiltration - TA0010**  
T1020 - Automated Exfiltration  
T1041 - Exfiltration Over C2 Channel  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1102 - Web Service  
T1102.003 - One-Way Communication  
  


#### Mitigations:

  
 **M1015:** Active Directory Configuration - Configure Active Directory to prevent use of certain techniques; use SID Filtering, etc.  
 **M1017:** User Training - Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction.  
 **M1018:** User Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.  
 **M1021:** Restrict Web-Based Content - Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc.  
 **M1022:** Restrict File and Directory Permissions - Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.  
 **M1026:** Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.  
 **M1027:** Password Policies - Set and enforce secure password policies for accounts.  
 **M1028:** Operating System Configuration - Make configuration changes related to the operating system or a common feature of the operating system that result in system hardening against techniques.  
 **M1029:** Remote Data Storage - Use remote security log and sensitive file storage where access can be controlled better to prevent exposure of intrusion detection log data or sensitive information.  
 **M1030:** Network Segmentation - Architect sections of the network to isolate critical systems, functions, or resources. Use physical and logical segmentation to prevent access to potentially sensitive systems and information. Use a DMZ to contain any internet-facing services that should not be exposed from the internal network. Configure separate virtual private cloud (VPC) instances to isolate critical cloud systems.  
 **M1031:** Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  
 **M1032:** Multi-factor Authentication - Use two or more pieces of evidence to authenticate to a system; such as username and password in addition to a token from a physical smart card or token generator.  
 **M1035:** Limit Access to Resource Over Network - Prevent access to file shares, remote access to systems, unnecessary services. Mechanisms to limit access may include use of network concentrators, RDP gateways, etc.  
 **M1037:** Filter Network Traffic - Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic.  
 **M1041:** Encrypt Sensitive Information - Protect sensitive information with strong encryption.  
 **M1042:** Disable or Remove Feature or Program - Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.  
 **M1047:** Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
 **M1051:** Update Software - Perform regular software updates to mitigate exploitation risk.  
 **M1054:** Software Configuration - Implement configuration changes to software (other than the operating system) to mitigate security risks associated to how the software operates.  
 **M1057:** Data Loss Prevention - Use a data loss prevention (DLP) strategy to categorize sensitive data, identify data formats indicative of personal identifiable information (PII), and restrict exfiltration of sensitive data.

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Amazon Vishing Attacks
Vishing allow attackers to perform phishing attacks without the need for malicious links or payloads. Armorblox has published details of two such campaigns impersonating Amazon.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

Armorblox published a blog post analyzing two Amazon-themed vishing campaigns. The attack begins with an email claiming to be from Amazon regarding an order, typically valued at hundreds of dollars. The emails leveraged Amazon branding or spoofed email addresses in an attempt to convince users it was legitimate. Rather than providing a link or attachment to visit in order to review/cancel the order, as a typical phishing email would, these emails instead provide a phone number to call in order to speak to a customer service representative. Armorblox researchers called these phone numbers to validate the intent of the campaign. As expected, calling the first number led to the operator requesting credit card details and other sensitive information. While the second number was disconnected, it is likely those operators had similar intentions. For more information, see the Armorblox blog post in the Reference section.

# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Always be suspicious of unexpected requests for sensitive information.




# Reference

  * <https://www.armorblox.com/blog/amazon-vishing-voice-phishing-attacks/>
