instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: LuminousMoth APT Group Targeting South Asia
LuminousMoth is a Chinese-speaking actor that Kaspersky observed using large-scale campaigns, but likely targeting a much smaller subset of victims, across South East Asia.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware, Campaign




# Overview

A Chinese-speaking actor using large-scale campaigns across South East Asia since October 2020, has been named LuminousMoth by Kaspersky. The great majority of victims are in the Philippines with Myanmar being the second most affected country. The actual targets of the campaign are likely government entities. In its report, Kaspersky notes two infection vectors. An email sent to victims contains a Dropbox link which leads to an RAR archive. To disguise the archive as a Word document, the “file_subpath” parameter is set to that of a file with a DOCX extension. Inside the archive were two malicious DLLs along with two legitimate executables files which were used to sideload the DLLs. If the first stage is successful, the second stage consists of installing a Cobalt Strike beacon and achieving persistence using a registry entry. The report notes that in the Philippines, there may have been another infection vector involved. The malware attempts to spread itself by copying malicious files to removable storage devices. In some cases, on systems located in Myanmar, an information stealer impersonated the Zoom video-conferencing application. It scanned the infected systems for files with specific extensions and exfiltrated those found to its C&C server. On some other systems, a tool to steal cookies from the Chrome web browser was deployed. Kaspersky notes a number of similarities in LuminousMoth's TTPs and targeting with another group named HoneyMyte (aka Mustang Panda), and finds with medium to high confidence that the LuminousMoth activity is connected to HoneyMyte.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://securelist.com/apt-luminousmoth/103332/>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: XAMPP Servers Hosting Agent Tesla and Formbook
A report from RiskIQ provides information on the use of Internet-facing XAMPP servers to host malware such as Agent Tesla and Formbook.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Malware
  *  **Malware Family/Families:**[Agent Tesla](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0331/), Formbook
  *  **Additional TTPs:** Servers running XAMPP are being used to host malware.



# Overview

XAMPP is an Apache distribution containing MariaDB, PHP, and Perl that is intended to make installation simple but is not intended to be used for production deployments. A report from RiskIQ provides information on the use of Internet-facing XAMPP servers that are being used to host malware such as Agent Tesla and Formbook. It is not clear from the report if the XAMPP servers have been set up by the actors behind the malware, or whether the servers have been compromised by the actors. A number of the hosts observed distributing the malware used dynamic DNS names. Further information is available from the report linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/59539651/XAMPP%20Servers%20Hosting%20Agent%20Tesla%20and%20Formbook%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1628643059745&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date ([M1049](https://attack.mitre.org/mitigations/M1049/)).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs ([M1031](https://attack.mitre.org/mitigations/M1031/), [M1035](https://attack.mitre.org/mitigations/M1035/), [M1037](https://attack.mitre.org/mitigations/M1037/)).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level ([M1051](https://attack.mitre.org/mitigations/M1051/)).



# References

  * <https://community.riskiq.com/article/40000d46/description>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: macOS Malware Hides in Named Resource Fork
Analysis of a new Bundlore adware sample by SentinelOne revealed the use of named resource forks to hide its payload, a previously unobserved technique.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Adware




# Overview

SentintelOne has published their analysis of a recent Bundlore adware sample using new techniques for hiding its payload. The payload was discovered on a site claiming to offer a free copy of Office 365. Proceeding with the download leads to a DMG file with a guided installer similar to that used by other Bundlore droppers. The interesting aspect of this sample comes with the discovery of the Install.command file having a hidden attribute. Specifically, a resource fork (historically used for storing data such as thumbnail images) was discovered. Combined with the contents of the command file, it was determined that during installation, part of this resource fork is parsed resulting in an archive that is subsequently decompressed and executed. The decompressed Mach-O file is the Bundlore adware payload. While manual analysis quickly leads to evidence of this activity, it is likely implemented to avoid certain security systems that focus on dynamic or AI-based detection. For more information, see the SentinelOne blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.



# Reference

  * <https://labs.sentinelone.com/resourceful-macos-malware-hides-in-named-fork/>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: HermeticWiper Is New Destructive Malware Affecting Ukraine
A new destructive piece of malware has been observed during the recent Ukraine crisis. Reports from Sentinel Labs and Symantec explore the malware's capabilities and the threat actor's tools and techniques. The malware is being called HermeticWiper by the security community.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Wiper
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Unknown
  *  **Associated Payloads:** HermeticWiper
  *  **Targets:** Ukraine, Lithuania, Latvia
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Exploitation of Public-Facing Systems
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Data Destruction



# Overview

A new piece of malware has been discovered during the ongoing Ukraine crisis. This malware is being called HermeticWiper because of the stolen certificate used. It has been seen mainly in businesses in Ukraine but has also been reported in Lithuania and Latvia. In a report by Symantec, it is speculated that the malware is dropped onto victim systems via exploitation of public-facing vulnerable systems, such as a Microsoft Exchange server. The researchers also note that in some attacks, the threat actors deployed ransomware to distract from the ongoing wiper attack. Sentinel Labs has analyzed the wiper malware and published some of the technical details they found. The malware is a custom-written application and uses a benign partition management driver to carry out the destructive attack. It enumerates the hard disks available in the system and proceeds to corrupt the master boot record for each one. Once the wiper process is complete, the victim machine would be unable to boot and all data would be destroyed. For more information, please see the links in the reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/81133569/HermeticWiper%20Is%20New%20Destructive%20Malware%20Affecting%20Ukraine%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1645742502295&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior (M1040). 



# References

  * <https://www.sentinelone.com/labs/hermetic-wiper-ukraine-under-attack/>
  * <https://symantec-enterprise-blogs.security.com/blogs/threat-intelligence/ukraine-wiper-malware-russia>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1569 - System Services  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1553 - Subvert Trust Controls  
T1553.002 - Code Signing  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1083 - File and Directory Discovery  
  
 **Lateral Movement - TA0008**  
T1021 - Remote Services  
T1021.002 - SMB/Windows Admin Shares  
  
 **Impact - TA0040**  
T1485 - Data Destruction

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Owowa Malicious IIS Module
A campaign targeting South East Asian government organizations is leveraging IIS modules to install malware. Kaspersky has published their analysis of the payload, which they have named Owowa.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Stealer, RAT
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Unknown
  *  **Associated Payloads:** Owowa
  *  **Targets:** Asian government organizations
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Unknown
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Credential theft, remote command execution



# Overview

Kaspersky published a blog post analyzing a malicious IIS module dubbed "Owowa." Not much is known about the infection chain or post-compromise actions, but a sample of the payload was found for analysis by researchers. The malicious module is capable of running on IIS servers that expose Exchange's Outlook Web Access (OWA). When loaded, it is capable of stealing credentials from the OWA login page as well as run commands issued by the attacker. It hooks an ISS event to inspect the content of HTTP requests, and when a successful OWA authentication attempt is observed, the credentials are encrypted and logged to a file on the system. This file can later be retrieved by the attacker. To issue commands, the attacker submits specific usernames to the OWA authentication page. Depending on what username is submitted, the malware will either exfiltrate the log file, delete the contents of the log file, or execute the contents of the password field via PowerShell, the results of which is sent back to the attacker. Victimology includes government organizations in Malaysia, Mongolia, Indonesia and the Philippines. The researchers were unable to attribute the activity to a known threat actor but provide their analysis of potential related personas and payloads based on PDB paths observed. For more information, see the Securelist blog post in the References section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/74056224/Owowa%20Malicious%20IIS%20Module%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1639670484269&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).



# References

  * <https://securelist.com/owowa-credential-stealer-and-remote-access/105219/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1587 - Develop Capabilities  
T1587.001 - Malware  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
T1059.001 - PowerShell  
T1129 - Shared Modules  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
T1071.001 - Web Protocols

parsed_raw_data.xfe_q:
Owowa Malicious IIS Module
A campaign targeting South East Asian government organizations is leveraging IIS modules to install malware. Kaspersky has published their analysis of the payload, which they have named Owowa.
parsed_raw_data.xfe_report:
# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Stealer, RAT
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Unknown
  *  **Associated Payloads:** Owowa
  *  **Targets:** Asian government organizations
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Unknown
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Credential theft, remote command execution



# Overview

Kaspersky published a blog post analyzing a malicious IIS module dubbed "Owowa." Not much is known about the infection chain or post-compromise actions, but a sample of the payload was found for analysis by researchers. The malicious module is capable of running on IIS servers that expose Exchange's Outlook Web Access (OWA). When loaded, it is capable of stealing credentials from the OWA login page as well as run commands issued by the attacker. It hooks an ISS event to inspect the content of HTTP requests, and when a successful OWA authentication attempt is observed, the credentials are encrypted and logged to a file on the system. This file can later be retrieved by the attacker. To issue commands, the attacker submits specific usernames to the OWA authentication page. Depending on what username is submitted, the malware will either exfiltrate the log file, delete the contents of the log file, or execute the contents of the password field via PowerShell, the results of which is sent back to the attacker. Victimology includes government organizations in Malaysia, Mongolia, Indonesia and the Philippines. The researchers were unable to attribute the activity to a known threat actor but provide their analysis of potential related personas and payloads based on PDB paths observed. For more information, see the Securelist blog post in the References section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/74056224/Owowa%20Malicious%20IIS%20Module%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1639670484269&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).



# References

  * <https://securelist.com/owowa-credential-stealer-and-remote-access/105219/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1587 - Develop Capabilities  
T1587.001 - Malware  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
T1059.001 - PowerShell  
T1129 - Shared Modules  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
T1071.001 - Web Protocols

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Shuckworm Group Continues To Carry Out Cyber-Espionage Attacks Against Ukraine
The Russia-linked Shuckworm group (aka Gamaredon, Armageddon, and tracked by IBM as hive0051) has continued to conduct targeted cyberintelligence operations against state bodies of Ukraine. Symantec observed Shuckworm activity between July 14, 2021, and August 18, 2021, on an organization in Ukraine. In their blog, Symantec shares a breakdown of the attacker's activity.
output:
# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Espionage
  *  **Targets:** State Bodies of Ukraine
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** Pterodo/Pteranodon 
  * **Initial Infection Vector:** Phishing Maldocs
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Unknown
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

Symantec’s Threat Hunter Team, a part of Broadcom Software, observed activity coming out of the Shuckworm group between July 14, 2021, and August 18, 2021. Symantec has provided a breakdown of the attacker's activity which includes the use of freely available remote access tools such as UltraVNC or Remote Manipulator System (RMS), as well as customized malware called Pterodo/Pteranodon. The group is known to send malicious documents via phishing emails. In the observed activity, the Shuckworm group utilized a number of malicious VBS script files. The Security Service of Ukraine (SSU) noted the use of living-off-the-land tools to steal credentials and move laterally on victim networks. Recent activity seen by Symantec is consistent with that documented by SSU. Further information is available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/74058219/Shuckworm%20Group%20Continues%20To%20Carry%20Out%20Cyber-Espionage%20Attacks%20Against%20Ukraine%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1644019370477&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques and phishing emails (M1017).
  * Application control may be able to prevent the running of executables masquerading as other files (M1038).
  * Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking (M1038). 
  * Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing (M1045). 
  * Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior (M1040). 
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).



# References

  * <https://symantec-enterprise-blogs.security.com/blogs/threat-intelligence/shuckworm-gamaredon-espionage-ukraine>
  * <https://www.broadcom.com/support/security-center/protection-bulletin>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1583.002 - DNS Server  
  
 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1566 - Phishing  
T1566.001 - Spearphishing Attachment  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1053 - Scheduled Task/Job  
T1053.005 - Scheduled Task  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
T1059.003 - Windows Command Shell  
T1059.005 - Visual Basic  
T1204 - User Execution  
T1204.002 - Malicious File  
  
 **Persistence - TA0003**  
T1053 - Scheduled Task/Job  
T1053.005 - Scheduled Task  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1218.005 - Mshta  
  
 **Credential Access - TA0006**  
T1003 - OS Credential Dumping  
  
 **Lateral Movement - TA0008**  
T1021 - Remote Services  
T1021.005 - VNC  
T1570 - Lateral Tool Transfer  
  
 **Collection - TA0009**  
T1005 - Data from Local System  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0010**  
T1041 - Exfiltration Over C2 Channel

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: The Gelsemium Cyberespionage Group
Gelsemium is believed to be a cyberespionage group that has been operating since 2014, and possibly earlier. An ESET report provides information on the TTPs associated with Gelsemium.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Cyberespionage




# Overview

A report from ESET provides information on the Gelsemium group, believed to be involved in cyberespionage. The group has been operating since at least 2014. The group's targets include electronics manufacturers, governments, religious organizations, and universities, located in East Asia and the Middle East, and in the past, Taiwan. The group has only attacked a small number of victims. Gelsemium's toolkit includes its own malware which ESET has named Gelsemine, Gelsenicine, and Gelsevirine. Other malware known to have been used by the group includes Chrommme and OwlProxy. Gelsemine is a first-stage dropper that contains multiple binaries used in further stages. Gelsenicine is a loader that retrieves and executes the next stage, Gelsevirine, which is the last stage of the chain. ESET notes that recently, Gelsemium exploited an Exchange server vulnerability to install the ChinaChopper webshell, which was later used to execute the first stage dropper, Gelsemine. It is unclear which Exchange server vulnerability was exploited but ESET believes it may be CVE-2020-0688. A notable tactic employed by Gelsemium is the use of Dynamic DNS (DDNS) domain names for its C&C servers. Further details are available from the report linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.welivesecurity.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/06/eset_gelsemium.pdf>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Intezer discovers New Linux Backdoor Named RedXOR
A new Linux backdoor has been discovered by Intezer and has been named RedXOR. It's likely to have been developed by Chinese nation-state actors.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Intezer discovers New Linux Backdoor Named RedXOR
A new Linux backdoor has been discovered by Intezer and has been named RedXOR. It's likely to have been developed by Chinese nation-state actors.

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Backdoor, RAT, APT




# Overview

Intezer discovered a new, sophisticated backdoor targeting Linux systems. It's likely to have been developed by Chinese nation-state actors based on the TTPs observed. Intezer has named the backdoor RedXOR due to it's encoding scheme based on XOR. RedXOR masquerades itself as polkit daemon. Intezer compares the similarities between RedXOR and malware PWNLNX backoodr, XOR.DDOR and Groundhog botnet, all attributed to Winnti. The backdoor is capable of a reverse shell, updating itself, file operations, remote command execution, and running as a proxy. Further information can be found in the article located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.intezer.com/blog/malware-analysis/new-linux-backdoor-redxor-likely-operated-by-chinese-nation-state-actor/>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Cisco Security Advisory - March 24th, 2021
Cisco published a security advisory addressing three vulnerabilities in the Cisco Jabber desktop and mobile client software.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview



CVE-2021-1411 and CVE-2021-1469 are arbitrary program execution vulnerabilities in Cisco Jabber for Windows. They results from improper validation of message content and, if successfully exploited, could allow an authenticated attacker to execute programs on the target system. CVE-2021-1417 is a information disclosure vulnerability in Cisco Jabber for Windows. It results from improper validation of message content and, if successfully exploited, could allow an authenticated attacker to access sensitive authentication information. CVE-2021-1471 is a certificate validation vulnerability in Cisco Jabber for Windows, Cisco Jabber for MacOS, and Cisco Jabber for mobile platforms that could allow an unauthenticated, remote attacker to intercept protected network traffic. CVE-2021-1418 is a denial of service (DoS)vulnerability in Cisco Jabber for Windows, Cisco Jabber for MacOS, and Cisco Jabber for mobile platforms that could allow an authenticated, remote attacker to cause a DoS condition.

Cisco has released patches to fix all of these vulnerabilities. We recommend reviewing the security advisory in the Reference section and applying any applicable patches as soon as possible.

# CVEs

  * CVE-2021-1411

  * CVE-2021-1417

  * CVE-2021-1418

  * CVE-2021-1469

  * CVE-2021-1471




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityAdvisory/cisco-sa-cisco-jabber-PWrTATTC>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: WooCommerce Skimmer Spoofs Checkout Page
A compromise of a client website led Sucuri to uncover a WooCommerce skimmer spoofing a checkout page to steal credit card details.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Skimmer
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Unknown
  *  **Associated Payloads:** Malicious JavaScript code
  *  **Targets:** E-commerce customers
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Compromised admin credentials
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Data theft



# Overview

Sucuri published a blog post analyzing a WooCommerce skimmer spoofing a checkout page for the purpose of credit card detail theft. Interestingly, the victim site was not an e-commerce platform; however, due to the skimmer looking for a "my-account" keyword which was present on the site, it successfully loaded. When the keyword condition is met, JavaScript code inserted into the themes header.php file is executed and loads malicious JavaScript from a remote server. The domain hosting this malicious code masquerades as a jquery resource to evade detection. The JavaScript is responsible for rendering a fake checkout form that exfiltrates entered credit card details to the remote server. The incident investigation determined the likely infection vector was brute-forcing of a WordPress admin account. Additionally, a malicious user was found logged into the WordPress database at the time of investigation. For more information, see the Sucuri blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/70222180/WooCommerce%20Skimmer%20Spoofs%20Checkout%20Page%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1636473577897&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Use multi-factor authentication wherever possible. (M1032)
  * Restrict Web-Based Content (M1021)



# References

  * <https://blog.sucuri.net/2021/11/woocommerce-skimmer-spoofs-checkout-page.html>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1583 - Acquire Infrastructure  
T1583.001 - Domains  
T1608 - Stage Capabilities  
T1608.001 - Upload Malware  
  
 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1078 - Valid Accounts  
T1078.003 - Local Accounts  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
T1059.007 - JavaScript  
  
 **Persistence - TA0003**  
T1136 - Create Account  
T1136.001 - Local Account  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1027 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
  
 **Credential Access - TA0006**  
T1056 - Input Capture  
T1110 - Brute Force  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0010**  
T1041 - Exfiltration Over C2 Channel  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
T1071.001 - Web Protocols

Tell me everything you know the following threat: Commercial Spyware Operation Uncovered
A Citizen Lab report delves into a commercial spyware product that can infect devices running Android, iOS, macOS, Windows, and also monitor cloud accounts.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware, Spyware




# Overview

A report from Citizen Lab looks into a commercial spyware operation. The spyware can infect devices running Android, iOS, macOS, Windows, and also monitor cloud accounts. Leaked documentation suggests the spyware can be installed in a number of different ways including through malicious links, man-in-the-middle attacks, and physical attacks. There is another vector offered which claims to be able to install the spyware on Android, iOS, and Windows, which Citizen Lab speculates may be a browser-based zero-click vector. The documentation notes that the spyware can steal and exfiltrate data from a variety of applications and accounts including Facebook, Gmail, Skype, Telegram, and web browsers. It also has the ability to take screenshots and turn on an infected device's microphone and webcam. Additional modules are offered for sale, including a remote shell that allows the operator access to the infected device. Fees for the spyware and additional modules, based on the number of devices infected and monitored, can run into tens of millions of Euros. A notable feature of the operation's infrastructure is the use of domain names that often impersonate media and advocacy organizations. Further details are available from the Citizen Lab report linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://citizenlab.ca/2021/07/hooking-candiru-another-mercenary-spyware-vendor-comes-into-focus/>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: A Technical Look at DreamBus Botnet
Zscaler's ThreatLabz has provided a technical analysis of the DreamBus Botnet. The malware, which exhibits worm-like behavior, has been in use since 2019.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Botnet




# Overview

Exhibiting worm-like behavior, DreamBus is a Linux-based botnet. The botnet can spread by scanning private IP address ranges for vulnerable systems. The botnet uses implicit trust, application exploits, and weak passwords to gain a foothold into databases, cloud-based applications, and IT admin tools. The botnet is using XMRig to mine for Monero currency and appears to be operating out of Russia or Eastern Europe. The botnet uses an ELF binary to set up the environment, infecting systems, downloading new modules, and deploying XMRig. The ELF binary is packed using UPX and a modified header and footer. This obfuscation reduces file sizes and hides the malware code. Most of the C2 components are hosted through TOR or anonymous file sharing services that use HTTP as its transport protocol. The main component spreads through SSH and is downloaded over HTTP when the exploit is successful. The module contains seven shell scripts with each performing a different action. Persistence is achieved via x() functionality in the creation of a cron job. This script will download the latest version of the malware. Each time the exploit is successful, the malware attempts to authenticate with the username of the compromised system. The SSH module is a brute force shell script used to download and extract a TAR file. Further details on this malware and its associated modules can be found in the Reference section below. 

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 

# Recommendations

    * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
    * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
    * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
    * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
    * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.

# Reference

    * <https://www.zscaler.com/blogs/security-research/dreambus-botnet-technical-analysis>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: BazarLoader to Domain Wide Encryption with Conti
An article on the DFIR Report website provides the details of a BazarLoader campaign that resulted in a victim suffering domain-wide encryption after the Conti ransomware was deployed.
output:
# Attack Details

  *  **Ransomware Family:** Conti
  *  **Targets:** Unspecified
  *  **Ransom Demand:** Unspecified
  *  **Intrusion Vector:** Most probably a malicious attachment in a phishing email
  *  **Data Exfiltrated:** Yes
  *  **Data Encrypted:** Yes
  *  **Data Published:** Unknown **.**
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

According to the DFIR Report, a BazarLoader campaign that resulted in a victim suffering domain-wide encryption began with a malicious attachment to a phishing email. Around 1.5 hours after the initial foothold was attained, and some host discovery tasks were carried out, a Cobalt Strike beacon DLL was downloaded and executed. After a period of time during which lateral movement to other systems was attained, data was exfiltrated from the domain using WinSCP. In total, less than 32 hours elapsed before the attackers ran an encryption test on several hosts and when that proved successful, the domain-wide encryption took place. Further details are available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/64127538/BazarLoader%20to%20Domain%20Wide%20Encryption%20with%20Conti%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1631506021108&api=v2)



# Detection

  * A list of Yara rules can be found here: [ Yara Rules.txt](/download/attachments/64127538/BazarLoader%20to%20Domain%20Wide%20Encryption%20with%20Conti%20Yara%20Rules.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1631506032135&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Restrict Web-Based Content (M1021).



# References

  * <https://thedfirreport.com/2021/09/13/bazarloader-to-conti-ransomware-in-32-hours/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1566 - Phishing  
T1566.001 - Spearphishing Attachment  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1047 - Windows Management Instrumentation  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
T1059.001 - PowerShell  
T1059.003 - Windows Command Shell  
T1569 - System Services  
  
 **Privilege Escalation - TA0004**  
T1078 - Valid Accounts  
T1078.002 - Domain Accounts  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1055 - Process Injection  
  
 **Credential Access - TA0006**  
T1003 - OS Credential Dumping  
T1003.001 - LSASS Memory  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1012 - Query Registry  
T1018 - Remote System Discovery  
T1069 - Permission Groups Discovery  
T1069.001 - Local Groups  
T1069.002 - Domain Groups  
T1082 - System Information Discovery  
T1087 - Account Discovery  
T1087.002 - Domain Account  
T1124 - System Time Discovery  
T1135 - Network Share Discovery  
T1482 - Domain Trust Discovery  
T1518 - Software Discovery  
T1518.001 - Security Software Discovery  
  
 **Lateral Movement - TA0008**  
T1021 - Remote Services  
T1021.001 - Remote Desktop Protocol  
T1021.002 - SMB/Windows Admin Shares  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0010**  
T1048 - Exfiltration Over Alternative Protocol  
  
 **Impact - TA0040**  
T1486 - Data Encrypted for Impact

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Docker Images Used To Target Russian Websites With Denial Of Service
Crowdstrike has published a report describing how Docker Engine images are being used to stage a DoS attack on Russian websites. The target list implies that this is a pro-Ukrainian attack.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Denial Of Service
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Unknown
  *  **Associated Payloads:** Unknown
  *  **Targets:** Russia, Lithuania, Belarus
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Compromise of Exposed Docker API
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** DoS Attack



# Overview

Crowdstrike has been tracking a DoS threat being spread using Docker Engine images. This was originally discovered as the researcher's honeypot was compromised using the exposed Docker Engine API. The first malicious image deployed contained a Go-based HTTP benchmarking tool that can be used to stress-test a website. This was used to stage a DoS attack which starts automatically when a new container based on the image is created. The target is randomly picked from a hard-coded list. This image was updated in March to include a much wider target list across Russia, Belarus, and Lithuania. The second image works similarly, but uses a different DoS program named 'stoppropoganda' and is custom-made. Both images are hosted on Docker Hub and have over one hundred thousand downloads - although the number of downloads to compromised infrastructure is unknown. For more information, please see the link in the reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * For a full list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.




# References

  * <https://www.crowdstrike.com/blog/compromised-docker-honeypots-used-for-pro-ukrainian-dos-attack/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1608.001 - Upload Malware  
  
 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1610 - Deploy Container  
  
 **Impact - TA0040**  
T1498 - Network Denial of Service  
  


#### Mitigations:

  
 **M1016:** Vulnerability Scanning - Vulnerability scanning is used to find potentially exploitable software vulnerabilities to remediate them.  
 **M1018:** User Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.  
 **M1026:** Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.  
 **M1030:** Network Segmentation - Architect sections of the network to isolate critical systems, functions, or resources. Use physical and logical segmentation to prevent access to potentially sensitive systems and information. Use a DMZ to contain any internet-facing services that should not be exposed from the internal network. Configure separate virtual private cloud (VPC) instances to isolate critical cloud systems.  
 **M1035:** Limit Access to Resource Over Network - Prevent access to file shares, remote access to systems, unnecessary services. Mechanisms to limit access may include use of network concentrators, RDP gateways, etc.  
 **M1037:** Filter Network Traffic - Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic.  
 **M1048:** Application Isolation and Sandboxing - Restrict execution of code to a virtual environment on or in transit to an endpoint system.  
 **M1050:** Exploit Protection - Use capabilities to detect and block conditions that may lead to or be indicative of a software exploit occurring.  
 **M1051:** Update Software - Perform regular software updates to mitigate exploitation risk.  
 **M1056:** Pre-compromise - This category is used for any applicable mitigation activities that apply to techniques occurring before an adversary gains Initial Access, such as Reconnaissance and Resource Development techniques.

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Magnitude Exploit Kit Distributing Magniber Ransomware
Avast has published a report on current activity involving the Magnitude exploit kit that targets Internet Explorer users in South Korea and results in the deployment of the Magniber ransomware.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Magnitude Exploit Kit Distributing Magniber Ransomware
Avast has published a report on current activity involving the Magnitude exploit kit that targets Internet Explorer users in South Korea and results in the deployment of the Magniber ransomware.

# Threat Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Ransomware
  *  **Targets:** Internet Explorer Users
  *  **Ransomware Family:** Magniber
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** CVE-2021-26411 **,** Initial Access (TA0001, T1189), Execution(TA0002, T1059.007, T1203, T1204, T1204.001)
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Privilege Escalation (TA0004, T1068, T1055), Defense Evasion (T1140, T1574, T1027, T1027.002, T1055), Impact (TA0040, T1486)
  *  **Additional TTPs:** Resource Development (TA0042, T1583.001, T1583, T1587, T1587.001, T1588, T1588.005, T1608, T1608.005)



# Overview

Due to past laws in South Korea which mandated the use of ActiveX controls for government and e-commerce sites, there remains a significant number of Internet Explorer users. The Magnitude exploit kit used to target Internet Explorer has been around for many years. To take advantage of the significant number of Internet Explorer users in South Korea, its operators are buying popunder ads on adult sites and pay only for those displayed to South Korean visitors to the sites. If a visitor to the site clicks on one of the ads, they are first redirected to a page that provides a legitimate-looking ad. The next redirection takes the victim to a second domain that is hosting an obfuscated JavaScript exploit for CVE-2021-26411. The second domain is short-lived, being rotated every thirty minutes, and domains are not reused. The JavaScript exploit used is one that is publicly available but includes custom shellcode, three versions of shellcode are used depending on the version of Windows the victim is using. If the exploit is successful, another vulnerability, CVE-2020-0986, is exploited to elevate privileges, and if successful, the Magniber ransomware is then injected into another process. Unlike the high profile big game hunting ransomware, Magniber does not employ the double extortion model of exfiltrating data to publish if the ransom is not paid. A ransom note is left in each directory in which files were encrypted. The ransom note contains a .onion URL that includes a subdomain that is generated dynamically, for each victim. Further information is available from the report linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/59540312/Magnitude%20Exploit%20Kit%20Distributing%20Magniber%20Ransomware%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1628222547230&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date ([M1049](https://attack.mitre.org/mitigations/M1049/)).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs ([M1031](https://attack.mitre.org/mitigations/M1031/), [M1035](https://attack.mitre.org/mitigations/M1035/), [M1037](https://attack.mitre.org/mitigations/M1037/)).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level ([M1051](https://attack.mitre.org/mitigations/M1051/)).



# References

  * <https://decoded.avast.io/janvojtesek/magnitude-exploit-kit-still-alive-and-kicking/>

Magnitude Exploit Kit Distributing Magniber Ransomware
Avast has published a report on current activity involving the Magnitude exploit kit that targets Internet Explorer users in South Korea and results in the deployment of the Magniber ransomware.

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/59540312/Magnitude%20Exploit%20Kit%20Distributing%20Magniber%20Ransomware%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1628222547230&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date ([M1049](https://attack.mitre.org/mitigations/M1049/)).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs ([M1031](https://attack.mitre.org/mitigations/M1031/), [M1035](https://attack.mitre.org/mitigations/M1035/), [M1037](https://attack.mitre.org/mitigations/M1037/)).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level ([M1051](https://attack.mitre.org/mitigations/M1051/)).



# References

  * <https://decoded.avast.io/janvojtesek/magnitude-exploit-kit-still-alive-and-kicking/>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Credit Card Skimmer Targets Virtual Conference Platform
Playback Now is a company providing an online conference platform. Malwarebytes researchers uncovered a campaign infecting sites leveraging Playback Now's services with the Inter skimmer.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Skimmer




# Overview

Malwarebytes discovered a campaign targeting sites using Playback Now's services. Playback Now is a video conferencing platform that, as part of its services, allows a customer to host websites on their own server. All the victim sites reside on the same IP address and all were running a vulnerable version of Magento CMS, which is a likely infection vector. These sites provide payment pages allowing visitors to purchase access to conference content. Injected into the victim sites is a script loaded from a remote site. The remote domain was registered recently and is a lookalike of the legitimate Playback Now domain. The loaded script identifies payment related fields and exfiltrates submitted data to another page on the same lookalike domain. Malwarebytes identified this skimmer to be part of the Inter skimmer family. For more information, see the Malwarebytes blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.



# Reference

  * <https://blog.malwarebytes.com/malwarebytes-news/2020/10/credit-card-skimmer-targets-virtual-conference-platform/>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Multiple Vulnerabilities in Exim Disclosed
Twenty-one vulnerabilities in Exim have been disclosed by Qualys. Three of the vulnerabilities could allow for remote code execution.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

Twenty-one vulnerabilities in Exim have been disclosed by Qualys. Of the most serious vulnerabilities, three could allow for remote code execution, and four could allow for escalation of privileges to those of root. In total, ten of the vulnerabilities are exploitable remotely and eleven are exploitable locally. Qualys has not provided working exploits but has provided proof-of-concept code for some of the vulnerabilities. The vulnerabilities, in many cases, affect all versions of Exim released since 2004. An updated version of Exim, 4.94.2, has been released and is described as rendering all prior versions of Exim as obsolete. Further details are available from the links in the Reference section below.

# CVEs

  * A complete list of CVEs can be found here: [ CVEs.txt](/download/attachments/48038303/Multiple%20Vulnerabilities%20in%20Exim%20Disclosed%20CVEs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1620190098839&api=v2)




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://www.exim.org/>

  * <https://www.exim.org/static/doc/security/CVE-2020-qualys/>

  * <https://www.qualys.com/2021/05/04/21nails/21nails.txt>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Credit Card Stealer Masquerading as Sucuri
In order to evade detection, skimmers often try to masquerade as legitimate software. Sucuri discovered one such case in which their own brand was leveraged in a skimming campaign.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware, Skimmer




# Overview

Sucuri published a blog post analyzing a skimmer using their brand name in order to evade detection. This skimmer is a base64-encoded JavaScript blob injected into target webpages. The web skimmer is typical of other skimmers, executing when a checkout button is clicked or a web page is unloaded. Upon execution, credit card and billing details are gathered from form fields and exfiltrated to a remote gateway using a GET request with plaintext parameters containing the stolen data. This gateway is hosted on Veeble, a Dutch hosting provider, and, before being disabled, operated under the account name "sucurrin." Visiting the account page of this user redirects to the legitimate Sucuri website, adding to their attempts to masquerade as the company. Further details can be found in Sucuri's blog post in the Reference section.

X-Force Threat Intelligence researchers identified at least three victims based on files uploaded to VirusTotal publically that indicate the presence of this skimmer. These victims include Harley-Davidson Military, Nappy Land National Childcare Supplier, and Soccer4All. It is unknown whether the skimmers are still active on this site, so caution should be maintained.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.



# Reference

  * <https://blog.sucuri.net/2020/11/another-credit-card-stealer-that-pretends-to-be-sucuri.html>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: OceanLotus Extending Cyber Espionage Operations Through Fake Websites
Expanding on their previous research into the OceanLotus threat group, Volexity reports on recent campaigns using fake news websites built to target victims in Southeast Asia.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware




# Overview

Volexity has published a blog post analyzing recent OceanLotus campaigns targeting victims in Southeast Asia. As with previous campaigns, the initial infection source was websites' relation to news in the targeted regions; however, instead of leveraging compromised, legitimate news sites, OceanLotus stood up their own websites. The content on the website appears to have been obtained via legitimate news sources, which Volexity believes is automatically done through a WordPress plugin. Some websites include malicious content on the majority of pages while others include the code only on specific pages, the latter of which are likely used in more targeted attacks where the link is sent via spear phishing messages. The infected pages executed two scripts, one to capture and store information and the other to display a malicious download link. Depending on the type of device the victim is visiting the page from, different links may be displayed. On mobile devices, a link that is currently offline is provided, but Volexity believes that at one point a phishing page was hosted there. On Windows systems, a fake Flash Player download is provided. On all other systems, an error message is displayed. In the case of Windows hosts, the sample analyzed by the researchers led to the download of a RAR archive containing a legitimate copy of Google's Update utility (masquerading as the Adobe Flash installer) and a malicious DLL. DLL side-loading is used to execute the malicious code when the legitimate executable is opened. The DLL loads a Cobalt Strike stager into memory that, in turn, downloads a Cobalt Strike Beacon from a C2 server. For more information, see the Volexity blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.volexity.com/blog/2020/11/06/oceanlotus-extending-cyber-espionage-operations-through-fake-websites/>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Renewable Energy Sector Targeted
A new blog post from Bushidotoken Threat Intel reports that the renewable energy sector is the target of an intelligence information gathering campaign.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Phishing Email
  *  **Target:** Renewable Energy, Industrial Control Systems Companies and Industries
  *  **Lure:** Password expired email
  *  **Payload:** Malicious link
  *  **Compromised Data:** Usernames and Passwords
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

According to a blog post from Bushidotoken, a campaign is underway that targets renewable energy and industrial tech organizations focusing mainly on Bulgaria. Organizations offering operational technology and industrial control systems from vendors such as Schneider Electric and Honeywell have been noted in the blog. Other companies and universities are also named as targets in the blog. The use of a custom ‘Mail Box’ phishing kit is used to collect the passwords of victims who visit the site. The kits are generic in nature and lead to a second stage of the kit. This stage consists of a "Your Mail Box storage is full" phishing email. This activity is purportedly connected to two APT groups: APT28 (FancyBear) and Konni. Several discovered hostnames and infrastructure similarities led researchers to the conclusion these activities could be related to the above-noted threat groups. For example, APT28 Konni both used Zetta Hosting for the phishing domains as well for C2 domains. At present, there is no hard evidence pointing to a definitive crossover of campaigns with previously noted campaigns. Further information can be found in the blog post located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/74057285/Renewable%20Energy%20Sector%20Targeted%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1642707777195&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction. (M1017)
  * Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc. (M1021)
  * Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries. (M1031)
  * Use a data loss prevention (DLP) strategy to categorize sensitive data, identify data formats indicative of personally identifiable information (PII), and restrict the exfiltration of sensitive data. (M1057)



# References

  * <https://blog.bushidotoken.net/2022/01/tracking-renewable-energy-intelligence.html>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Reconnaissance - TA0043**  
T1589 - Gather Victim Identity Information  
T1589.001 - Credentials  
T1589.002 - Email Addresses  
  
 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1566 - Phishing  
T1566.002 - Spearphishing Link  
  
 **Credential Access - TA0006**  
T1056 - Input Capture  
T1056.001 - Keylogging  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0010**  
T1567 - Exfiltration Over Web Service

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: New RaaS Offering - LokiLocker
A report from BlackBerry's Research & Intelligence team provides an analysis of a Ransomware-as-a-Service (Raas) offering that first appeared in the wild in mid-August 2021.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Ransomware
  *  **Targets:** Windows systems.
  *  **Ransomware Family:** LokiLocker
  *  **RaaS Operation:** Yes
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Trojanized brute-forcing tools.
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** File encryption, disk wiping if ransom not paid.
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

LokiLocker is a Ransomware-as-a-Service (Raas) offering that first appeared in the wild in mid-August 2021. According to a report from BlackBerry's Research & Intelligence team who named it LokiLocker, it targets Windows systems and has some similarities to the LockBit ransomware. The origin of LokiLocker isn't clear but there are some indicators that suggest it could be of Iranian origin, it's also possible that the developers may simply be trying to distract from its actual originating location. Early versions of LokiLocker were distributed inside Trojanized hacking tools used for brute-forcing credentials. Files are encrypted using AES and LokiLocker also provides wiper functionality that deletes files and overwrites the MBR. The wiper is used if the victim doesn't pay the demanded ransom by the due date. Further information is available from the report linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * For a full list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.



# References

  * <https://blogs.blackberry.com/en/2022/03/lokilocker-ransomware>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Tactics and Techniques:**

 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1587 - Develop Capabilities  
T1587.001 - Malware  
T1608 - Stage Capabilities  
T1608.001 - Upload Malware  
T1608.005 - Link Target  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1204 - User Execution  
T1204.002 - Malicious File  
  
 **Persistence - TA0003**  
T1547 - Boot or Logon Autostart Execution  
T1547.001 - Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1027 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
T1027.002 - Software Packing  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1049 - System Network Connections Discovery  
T1083 - File and Directory Discovery  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
T1071.001 - Web Protocols  
  
 **Impact - TA0040**  
T1485 - Data Destruction  
T1486 - Data Encrypted for Impact  
  


 **Mitigations:**

 **M1013:** Application Developer Guidance: This mitigation describes any guidance or training given to developers of applications to avoid introducing security weaknesses that an adversary may be able to take advantage of.  
 **M1017:** User Training - Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction.  
 **M1018:** User Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.  
 **M1021:** Restrict Web-Based Content - Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc.  
 **M1022:** Restrict File and Directory Permissions - Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.  
 **M1024:** Restrict Registry Permissions - Restrict the ability to modify certain hives or keys in the Windows Registry.  
 **M1025:** Privileged Process Integrity - Protect processes with high privileges that can be used to interact with critical system components through use of protected process light, anti-process injection defenses, or other process integrity enforcement measures.  
 **M1026:** Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.  
 **M1031:** Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  
 **M1033:** Limit Software Installation - Block users or groups from installing unapproved software.  
 **M1037:** Filter Network Traffic - Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic.  
 **M1038:** Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
 **M1040:** Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
 **M1042:** Disable or Remove Feature or Program - Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.  
 **M1043:** Credential Access Protection - Use capabilities to prevent successful credential access by adversaries; including blocking forms of credential dumping.  
 **M1044:** Restrict Library Loading - Prevent abuse of library loading mechanisms in the operating system and software to load untrusted code by configuring appropriate library loading mechanisms and investigating potential vulnerable software.  
 **M1045:** Code Signing - Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.  
 **M1047:** Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
 **M1049:** Antivirus/Antimalware - Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software.  
 **M1053:** Data Backup - Take and store data backups from end user systems and critical servers. Ensure backup and storage systems are hardened and kept separate from the corporate network to prevent compromise.  
 **M1056:** Pre-compromise - This category is used for any applicable mitigation activities that apply to techniques occurring before an adversary gains Initial Access, such as Reconnaissance and Resource Development techniques.

parsed_raw_data.xfe_q:
New RaaS Offering - LokiLocker
A report from BlackBerry's Research & Intelligence team provides an analysis of a Ransomware-as-a-Service (Raas) offering that first appeared in the wild in mid-August 2021.
parsed_raw_data.xfe_report:
# Threat Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Ransomware
  *  **Targets:** Windows systems.
  *  **Ransomware Family:** LokiLocker
  *  **RaaS Operation:** Yes
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Trojanized brute-forcing tools.
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** File encryption, disk wiping if ransom not paid.
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

LokiLocker is a Ransomware-as-a-Service (Raas) offering that first appeared in the wild in mid-August 2021. According to a report from BlackBerry's Research & Intelligence team who named it LokiLocker, it targets Windows systems and has some similarities to the LockBit ransomware. The origin of LokiLocker isn't clear but there are some indicators that suggest it could be of Iranian origin, it's also possible that the developers may simply be trying to distract from its actual originating location. Early versions of LokiLocker were distributed inside Trojanized hacking tools used for brute-forcing credentials. Files are encrypted using AES and LokiLocker also provides wiper functionality that deletes files and overwrites the MBR. The wiper is used if the victim doesn't pay the demanded ransom by the due date. Further information is available from the report linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * For a full list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.



# References

  * <https://blogs.blackberry.com/en/2022/03/lokilocker-ransomware>

T1608.001 - Upload Malware  
T1608.005 - Link Target  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1204 - User Execution  
T1204.002 - Malicious File  
  
 **Persistence - TA0003**  
T1547 - Boot or Logon Autostart Execution  
T1547.001 - Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1027 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
T1027.002 - Software Packing  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1049 - System Network Connections Discovery  
T1083 - File and Directory Discovery  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
T1071.001 - Web Protocols  
  
 **Impact - TA0040**  
T1485 - Data Destruction  
T1486 - Data Encrypted for Impact  
  


 **Mitigations:**

 **M1013:** Application Developer Guidance: This mitigation describes any guidance or training given to developers of applications to avoid introducing security weaknesses that an adversary may be able to take advantage of.  
 **M1017:** User Training - Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction.  
 **M1018:** User Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.  
 **M1021:** Restrict Web-Based Content - Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc.  
 **M1022:** Restrict File and Directory Permissions - Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.  
 **M1024:** Restrict Registry Permissions - Restrict the ability to modify certain hives or keys in the Windows Registry.  
 **M1025:** Privileged Process Integrity - Protect processes with high privileges that can be used to interact with critical system components through use of protected process light, anti-process injection defenses, or other process integrity enforcement measures.  
 **M1026:** Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.  
 **M1031:** Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  
 **M1033:** Limit Software Installation - Block users or groups from installing unapproved software.  
 **M1037:** Filter Network Traffic - Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic.  
 **M1038:** Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
 **M1040:** Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
 **M1042:** Disable or Remove Feature or Program - Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.  
 **M1043:** Credential Access Protection - Use capabilities to prevent successful credential access by adversaries; including blocking forms of credential dumping.  
 **M1044:** Restrict Library Loading - Prevent abuse of library loading mechanisms in the operating system and software to load untrusted code by configuring appropriate library loading mechanisms and investigating potential vulnerable software.  
 **M1045:** Code Signing - Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.  
 **M1047:** Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
 **M1049:** Antivirus/Antimalware - Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software.  
 **M1053:** Data Backup - Take and store data backups from end user systems and critical servers. Ensure backup and storage systems are hardened and kept separate from the corporate network to prevent compromise.  
 **M1056:** Pre-compromise - This category is used for any applicable mitigation activities that apply to techniques occurring before an adversary gains Initial Access, such as Reconnaissance and Resource Development techniques.

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: TA456 Targets Defense Contractor with Alluring Social Media Persona
TA456 (aka Tortoiseshell) is an Iranian-state aligned threat actor that targets U.S. defense contractors. A blog post from Proofpoint details a recent years-long, targeted malware campaign by the actor.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type** : Espionage

  *  **Associated Threat Actors** : TA456

  *  **Associated Payloads** : LEMPO

  *  **Targets:** U.S. Defense Contractors

  *  **Initial Infection Vector** : Link in phishing email to download malicious file ([T1566.002](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1566/002/))

  *  **Post-Compromise Actions** : Perform reconnaissance ([T1552.001](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1552/001/), [T1135](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1135/), [T1082](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1082/), [T1016](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1016/), [T1049](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1049/), [T1033](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1033/)), exfiltrate data via SMTPS ([T1048](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1048/))

  *  **Additional TTPs:** Visual Basic Scripts ([T1059.005](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/005/)), Persistence via Registry Run Key ([T1547.001](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1547/001/))




# Overview

Proofpoint published a blog post analyzing a recent TA456 campaign. This threat actor is aligned with Iranian-state interests and typically targets U.S. defense contractors. In this specific campaign, the actor created a social media persona and established a relationship with the target, an employee of a small subsidiary of an aerospace defense contractor, over an extensive period of time. With trust established, the attacker ultimately sent the target a Microsoft OneDrive link that led to the download of a RAR file. Inside the RAR archive was an XSLM file responsible for dropping and executing a Visual Basic script (VBS). This VBS file is simple stealer dubbed "LEMPO." A Registry Run key is created to establish persistence. Various built-in Windows commands are leveraged to gather system, user, and network information. Files potentially containing credentials are also stolen. All gathered data is exfiltrated over SMTPS using Microsoft's Collaboration Data Objects (CDO). No additional payloads or follow-on activities were observed during this specific incident. For more information, see the Proofpoint blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date ([M1049](https://attack.mitre.org/mitigations/M1049/)).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level ([M1051](https://attack.mitre.org/mitigations/M1051/)).
  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques and phishing emails ([M1017](https://attack.mitre.org/mitigations/M1017/)).
  * Restrict Web-Based Content ([M1021](https://attack.mitre.org/mitigations/M1021)).



# Reference

  * <https://www.proofpoint.com/us/blog/threat-insight/i-knew-you-were-trouble-ta456-targets-defense-contractor-alluring-social-media>
