instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Mirai Malware Variants Continue to Target Linux
The Crowdstrike research team assesses that Mirai malware variants targeting Linux are increasing. According to Crowdstrike, these Mirai variants continue to compromise systems to populate their botnets.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Details

  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Unknown
  *  **Targets:** Linux Devices
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Brute Force, vulnerability exploitation.
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Various ****
  * **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below



# Overview

The Crowdstrike report details a number of capabilities of Mirai variants, but focuses on instances that are targeting 32-bit x86 Linux systems. There is a significant increase in Mirai variants that target Linux systems that enterprise environments use as servers and networking endpoints. Crowdstrike research indicates that threat actors are targeting the Linux x86 monoculture because it is easier to target these devices as the Mirai code does not have to be continually updated. Additionally, the targeting and compromise of Linux servers provide more computing “power” for the botnet. The researchers at Crowdstrike go on to point out that the Mirai variants still utilize brute force attacks to gain initial access, but also exploit new vulnerabilities like the recent vulnerability in Log4j. Further information can be found in the article located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * For a list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.




# References

  * [https://www.crowdstrike.com/blog/linux-mirai-malware-double-on-stronger-chips/?&web_view=true](https://www.crowdstrike.com/blog/linux-mirai-malware-double-on-stronger-chips/?&web_view=true "Follow link")



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Tactics and Techniques:**

 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application

 **Credential Access - TA0006**  
T1110 - Brute Force  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1001 - Data Obfuscation  
T1090 - Proxy

  
 **Mitigations:**

 **M1018:** User Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.  
 **M1020:** SSL/TLS Inspection - Break and inspect SSL/TLS sessions to look at encrypted web traffic for adversary activity.  
 **M1027:** Password Policies - Set and enforce secure password policies for accounts.  
 **M1031:** Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  
 **M1032:** Multi-factor Authentication - Use two or more pieces of evidence to authenticate to a system; such as username and password in addition to a token from a physical smart card or token generator.  
 **M1036:** Account Use Policies - Configure features related to account use like login attempt lockouts, specific login times, etc.  
 **M1037:** Filter Network Traffic - Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic.

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: CoinHelper - A Family of AutoIt Droppers
A report from Avast looks at a family of AutoIt droppers that they have named CoinHelper. One of the main objectives of CoinHelper is delivering a cryptominer to infected systems.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: CoinHelper - A Family of AutoIt Droppers
A report from Avast looks at a family of AutoIt droppers that they have named CoinHelper. One of the main objectives of CoinHelper is delivering a cryptominer to infected systems.

# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Dropper
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Unspecified
  *  **Associated Payloads:** CoinHelper, Cryptominers, and others.
  *  **Targets:** Users downloading torrent files.
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Trojanized software, Dropped by other malware.
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Cryptomining
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

According to a report from Avast, they have observed in excess of 220,000 attempts to infect users with CoinHelper since the beginning of 2020. Russia has been the most targeted country followed by Ukraine and collectively account for well over 50% of the attempts. The most common distribution method is through Trojanized software packages ranging from games and game cheats to security-related software, downloaded in torrent files. In at least one case, an unofficial, Trojanized ISO image of Windows 11 was used. In some cases, CoinHelper has been deployed using the MyKings clipboard stealer by replacing a URL on the victim's clipboard with a malicious one. CoinHelper itself consists of multiple compiled AutoIt binaries that carry out a number of functions including gathering information about the victim system that is used for profiling and installing a Tor binary that is used to download payloads from .onion URLs. The main cryptominer deployed is XMRig with the most frequently mined currency being Monero. CoinHelper will also do some checks for competing cryptominers and if found, terminate them. It also checks system utilization and after a certain number of minutes idle will devote 100% of the CPU to mining. If the user is active on the system, utilization is held down to 50%. Further information is available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/74056131/CoinHelper%20-%20A%20Family%20of%20AutoIt%20Droppers%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1639546374523&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Restrict Web-Based Content (M1021).



# References

  * <https://decoded.avast.io/janrubin/toss-a-coin-to-your-helper/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework (Payload dependant)

 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1587 - Develop Capabilities  
T1587.001 - Malware  
T1608 - Stage Capabilities  
T1608.001 - Upload Malware  
  
 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1195 - Supply Chain Compromise  
T1195.002 - Compromise Software Supply Chain  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
T1204 - User Execution  
T1204.001 - Malicious Link  
T1204.002 - Malicious File  
T1204.003 - Malicious Image  
  
 **Persistence - TA0003**  
T1037 - Boot or Logon Initialization Scripts  
T1037.005 - Startup Items  
T1053 - Scheduled Task/Job  
T1547 - Boot or Logon Autostart Execution  
T1547.001 - Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder  
T1547.009 - Shortcut Modification  
  
 **Privilege Escalation - TA0004**  
T1548 - Abuse Elevation Control Mechanism  
T1548.002 - Bypass User Account Control  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1027 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
T1027.002 - Software Packing  
T1036 - Masquerading  
T1055 - Process Injection  
T1070 - Indicator Removal on Host  
T1070.004 - File Deletion  
T1140 - Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information  
T1562 - Impair Defenses  
T1562.001 - Disable or Modify Tools  
  
 **Credential Access - TA0006**  
T1552 - Unsecured Credentials  
T1552.001 - Credentials In Files  
T1552.002 - Credentials in Registry  
T1555 - Credentials from Password Stores  
T1555.003 - Credentials from Web Browsers  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1057 - Process Discovery  
T1082 - System Information Discovery  
T1083 - File and Directory Discovery  
T1518 - Software Discovery  
T1518.001 - Security Software Discovery  
T1614 - System Location Discovery  
T1614.001 - System Language Discovery  
  
 **Collection - TA0009**  
T1113 - Screen Capture  
T1123 - Audio Capture  
T1125 - Video Capture  
T1213 - Data from Information Repositories  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1090 - Proxy  
T1090.003 - Multi-hop Proxy  
T1132 - Data Encoding  
T1571 - Non-Standard Port

 **Impact - TA0040**  
T1496 - Resource Hijacking

CoinHelper itself consists of multiple compiled AutoIt binaries that carry out a number of functions including gathering information about the victim system that is used for profiling and installing a Tor binary that is used to download payloads from .onion URLs. The main cryptominer deployed is XMRig with the most frequently mined currency being Monero. CoinHelper will also do some checks for competing cryptominers and if found, terminate them. It also checks system utilization and after a certain number of minutes idle will devote 100% of the CPU to mining. If the user is active on the system, utilization is held down to 50%. Further information is available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/74056131/CoinHelper%20-%20A%20Family%20of%20AutoIt%20Droppers%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1639546374523&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Restrict Web-Based Content (M1021).



# References

  * <https://decoded.avast.io/janrubin/toss-a-coin-to-your-helper/>

 **Resource Development - TA0042**

T1608.001 - Upload Malware  
  
 **Initial Access - TA0001**

 **Execution - TA0002**

T1204.003 - Malicious Image  
  
 **Persistence - TA0003**

T1037.005 - Startup Items  
T1053 - Scheduled Task/Job  
T1547 - Boot or Logon Autostart Execution

 **Privilege Escalation - TA0004**  
T1548 - Abuse Elevation Control Mechanism  
T1548.002 - Bypass User Account Control  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1027 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
T1027.002 - Software Packing  
T1036 - Masquerading  
T1055 - Process Injection  
T1070 - Indicator Removal on Host  
T1070.004 - File Deletion  
T1140 - Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information  
T1562 - Impair Defenses  
T1562.001 - Disable or Modify Tools  
  
 **Credential Access - TA0006**  
T1552 - Unsecured Credentials  
T1552.001 - Credentials In Files  
T1552.002 - Credentials in Registry

T1555.003 - Credentials from Web Browsers  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: New PlugX Variant
In mid-March, Palo Alto's Unit 42 observed a new PlugX variant being deployed after an Exchange server was successfully compromised through the exploitation of the ProxyLogon vulnerabilities.
output:
# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Malware
  *  **Targets:** Unspecified
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** PlugX ([S0013](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0013/))
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Microsoft Exchange ProxyLogon vulnerabilities CVE-2021-26855, and CVE-2021-27065 ([T1190](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1190/))
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Collection ([T1113](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1113/)), Command and Control ([T1071](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1071/), [T1105](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1105/), [T1095](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1095/), [T1102](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1102/)), Persistence ([T1547](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1547/), [T1543](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1543/), [T1574](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1574/)), Execution ([T1574.002](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1574/002/)), Evasion ([T1140](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1140/), [T1036](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1036/), [T1112](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1112/), [T1127](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1127/), [T1497](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1497/)), Discovery ([T1083](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1083/), [T1135](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1135/), [T1057](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1057/), [T1012](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1012/), [T1049](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1049/)), Credential Access ([T1056](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1056/))
  *  **Additional TTPs:** Signature magic value, THOR



# Overview

Plugx has been around since 2008 and has been used by a number of threat actors. After an Exchange server was successfully compromised by exploiting the ProxyLogon vulnerabilities (CVE-2021-26855, and CVE-2021-27065) in mid-March, Palo Alto's Unit 42 observed a webshell being uploaded to the compromised server. The webshell was used to execute the Windows binary bitsadmin.exe which downloaded a file named Aro.dat which is an encrypted and compressed PlugX payload that requires a specific loader. Three files, aro.dat, aross.dll, aro.exe (a legitimate signed binary) are extracted and aro.exe is executed and sideloads aross.dll. The PlugX configuration file is aro.dat. One of the most obvious changes in the new variant is the change from the well-known signature magic value, PLUG, to THOR. Further details are available from the Palo Alto report linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/59539467/New%20PlugX%20Variant%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1627614800915&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date ([M1049](https://attack.mitre.org/mitigations/M1049/)).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs ([M1031](https://attack.mitre.org/mitigations/M1031/), [M1035](https://attack.mitre.org/mitigations/M1035/), [M1037](https://attack.mitre.org/mitigations/M1037/)).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level ([M1051](https://attack.mitre.org/mitigations/M1051/)).



# References

  * <https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/thor-plugx-variant/>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Digital-Only Banks Targeted In New Phishing Campaign
Digital-only banks are becoming more prevalent, and with this, they are becoming targets for scams and fraud. This blog post on Bushido Token Threat Intel explores one campaign targeting a bank in the UK.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Digital-Only Banks Targeted In New Phishing Campaign
Digital-only banks are becoming more prevalent, and with this, they are becoming targets for scams and fraud. This blog post on Bushido Token Threat Intel explores one campaign targeting a bank in the UK.

# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Phishing
  *  **Target:** Monzo Customers
  *  **Lure:** Monzo Login Page
  *  **Compromised Data:** Banking Credentials
  *  **Post-compromise Actions:** Unknown



# Overview

Threat actors are targeting digital only banks as they are becoming more and more common. Bushido Token Threat Intel has published a blog post exploring one campaign targeting the online bank Monzo. The attack targets the mechanism by which a customer verifies their device for use with the bank - using a "golden link" which allows for the first login. The attack follows common phishing patterns, with the page copying Monzo's pages to get the users to enter their credentials and PIN. Along with the victim's name and phone number, the attacker will be able to access the compromised account. Upon exploration of the infrastructure behind the phishing site, the researcher discovered sites also targeting the bank Revolut. There was evidence that this attack was orchestrated by the threat actor "Cazanova", who offers phishing as a service. For more information, please see the link in the reference section

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/74058973/Digital-Only%20Banks%20Targeted%20In%20New%20Phishing%20Campaign%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1645111572603&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques and phishing emails (M1017).
  * Proactively reset accounts that are known to be part of breached credentials either immediately, or after detecting bruteforce attempts (M1018).



# References

  * <https://blog.bushidotoken.net/2022/02/mobile-banking-phishing-campaign.html>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1583 - Acquire Infrastructure  
T1583.001 - Domains  
T1588 - Obtain Capabilities  
  
 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1566 - Phishing  
  
 **Credential Access - TA0006**  
T1056 - Input Capture  
T1056.002 - GUI Input Capture

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Ragnarok Shuts Down and Releases Master Decryptor
The Ragnarok ransomware gang appears to have shut down operations and, with the shutdown, have released a master decryptor, according to a report from Bleeping Computer.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Ransomware




# Overview

In a sudden move by the Ragnarok ransomware gang, all of the information on their specific leak site has been replaced with a master decryptor key as well as instructions on using the decryptor to remove the encryption placed on files. All visual elements of the site have been removed. According to the article, the group did not appear to intend on shutting down, however, the data was wiped and operations shuttered. A ransomware expert, Michael Gillespie, has confirmed the master decryption key is contained within the decryptor itself. He was able to confirm the successful decryption of a random file. There are reports that a master decryptor is in the process of development. Other ransomware gangs that have released decryption keys include Ziggy, Conti, Avaddon, and SynAck/El_Cometa. Caution should be exercised in using the decryption tools for each group as the provenance of these tools is uncertain. **IBM HAS NOT TESTED THESE DECRYPTORS AND THE USE OF THE AFOREMENTIONED DECRYPTORS SHOULD BE EXECUTED AT YOUR OWN RISK.** Further details can be found in the article located within the Reference section below.

# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary.

  * Obtain the master decryptor if your organization was affected
  *  **IBM has not tested this decryptor and cannot confirm its validity. ***Use at your own risk.*****



#  Reference

  * <https://www.bleepingcomputer.com/news/security/ragnarok-ransomware-releases-master-decryptor-after-shutdown/>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: CISA ICS Advisories September 17 2020
Cybersecurity & Infrastructure Security Agency has issued two advisories covering two products with varying degrees of severity.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Vulnerabilities




# Overview

Two advisories issued by CISA address vulnerabilities in product lines from two different vendors. 

## Philips Clinical Collaboration Platform (ICSMA-20-261-01)

A vulnerability in the Philips Clinical Collaboration Platform exists wherein an attacker could perform cross-site request forgery, improper neutralization of script attributes in a web page, protection mechanism failure, algorithm downgrade, and configuration. This exploit contains a CVSS score of 6.8. The vulnerability affects Clinical Collaboration Platform versions 12.2.1 and prior. Philips has released version 12.2.5 which addresses three of the vulnerabilities. One vulnerability requires manual intervention, details of which can be found in the link located within the Reference section below.

## Advantech WebAccess Node (ICSA-20-261-01)

A vulnerability in the Advantech WebAccess Node exists in which an attacker could escalate privileges. An incorrect permission assignment for critical resources allows for this particular vulnerability to be exploited. This vulnerability contains a CVSS score of 7.8. Affected versions of Advantech WebAccess Node prior to 9.0.1 are included. Advantech has issued version 9.0.1 which addresses the vulnerability. Further details can be found in the advisory located within the Reference section below.

# CVEs

  * A list of CVEs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/30769616/CISA%20ICS%20Advisories%20September%2017%202020%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1600732311953&api=v2)




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ics/advisories/icsma-20-261-01>

  * <https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ics/advisories/icsa-20-261-01>
  * <https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ics/advisories>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Cisco Security Advisories April 7 2021
Cisco has published fifteen Security Advisories. Of the advisories, two are rated as Critical, four are rated as High, and nine are rated as Medium.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

 For all advisories listed below, it is noted that Cisco's Product Security Incident Response Team (PSIRT) is "not aware of any public announcements or malicious use of the vulnerabilities" that are described in the advisories.

## Advisories Rated Critical

 **Cisco SD-WAN vManage Software Vulnerabilities**  
cisco-sa-vmanage-YuTVWqy  
Multiple vulnerabilities in CiscoSD-WAN vManage Software could allow an unauthenticated, remote attacker to execute arbitrary code or allow an authenticated, local attacker to gain escalated privileges on an affected system.  
CVE-2021-1137 CVE-2021-1479 CVE-2021-1480  
Base 9.8 CVSS:3.1/AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:H/I:H/A:H  
<https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityAdvisory/cisco-sa-vmanage-YuTVWqy>

 **Cisco Small Business RV110W, RV130, RV130W, and RV215W Routers Management Interface Remote Command Execution Vulnerability**  
cisco-sa-rv-rce-q3rxHnvm  
A vulnerability in the web-based management interface of CiscoSmall Business RV110W, RV130, RV130W, and RV215W Routers could allow an unauthenticated, remote attacker to execute arbitrary code on an affected device.  
CVE-2021-1459  
Base 9.8 CVSS:3.1/AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:H/I:H/A:H  
<https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityAdvisory/cisco-sa-rv-rce-q3rxHnvm>

## Advisories Rated High

 **Cisco Advanced Malware Protection for Endpoints Windows Connector, ClamAV for Windows, and Immunet DLL Hijacking Vulnerability**  
cisco-sa-amp-imm-dll-tu79hvkO  
A vulnerability in the dynamic link library (DLL) loading mechanism in CiscoAdvanced Malware Protection (AMP) for Endpoints Windows Connector, ClamAV for Windows, and Immunet could allow an authenticated, local attacker to perform a DLL hijacking attack on an affected Windows system. To exploit this vulnerability, the attacker would need valid credentials on the system.  
CVE-2021-1386  
Base 7.0 CVSS:3.1/AV:L/AC:H/PR:L/UI:N/S:U/C:H/I:H/A:H  
<https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityAdvisory/cisco-sa-amp-imm-dll-tu79hvkO>

 **Cisco Small Business RV Series Routers Vulnerabilities**  
cisco-sa-sb-rv-bypass-inject-Rbhgvfdx  
Multiple vulnerabilities exist in the web-based management interface of CiscoSmall Business RV Series Routers. A remote attacker could execute arbitrary commands or bypass authentication and upload files on an affected device.  
CVE-2021-1472 CVE-2021-1473  
Base 7.3 CVSS:3.1/AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:L/I:L/A:L  
<https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityAdvisory/cisco-sa-sb-rv-bypass-inject-Rbhgvfdx>

 **Cisco Small Business RV Series Routers Link Layer Discovery Protocol Vulnerabilities**  
cisco-sa-rv-multi-lldp-u7e4chCe  
Multiple vulnerabilities exist in the Link Layer Discovery Protocol (LLDP) implementation for CiscoSmall Business RV Series Routers. An unauthenticated, adjacent attacker could execute arbitrary code or cause an affected router to leak system memory or reload. A memory leak or device reload would cause a denial of service (DoS) condition on an affected device.

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Stalkerware on Android Platform
Stalkerware apps are becoming increasingly more popular on Android platforms. WeLiveSecurity has published a white paper on the proliferation of these malicious apps.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Stalkerware on Android Platform
Stalkerware apps are becoming increasingly more popular on Android platforms. WeLiveSecurity has published a white paper on the proliferation of these malicious apps.

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Stalkerware




# Overview

WeLiveSecurity has analyze 86 apps from 86 different vendors classified as "stalkerware." In their report, researchers detail a multitude of security and privacy issues that exist with these applications. Actions such as controlling a victim device, taking over the account of the victim, intercepting data, framing the victim using fabricated evidence, and/or remote code execution on Android OS-based devices are all possible. Within their research, 58 applications had a total of 158 security and privacy issues. Only six of the vendors tested have fixed issues associated with the report, forty-four have failed to reply, seven promised fixes in upcoming releases, and one decided to ignore the problem and not address the security and privacy concerns. Infection typically is fast if the stalker has physical access to the victim's device(s). Speculation is that most of these threat actors are someone within the victim's family or social/work circles. The stalker must also have unlock capabilities or the device must have PINs or patterns disable. Finally, the stalker must deactivate the protection measures on the device in order to achieve their goal, whatever that may be. The stalker must configure the app and synchronize it with their monitoring service, and, presumably, root permissions must be obtained. It should be noted that there are actually three components to stalkerware. One is the attacker, another the stalker, and finally the victim. The attacker uses the stalker's account and obtained information to carry out further actions on the device. For more detailed information, please see the white paper located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.welivesecurity.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/05/eset_android_stalkerware.pdf>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: XLL Malware Techniques
After observing a spike in the use of Microsoft Excel add-in (XLL) files to drop malware on systems, HP has published a report detailing various techniques used to develop these droppers.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Dropper
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Non-specific
  *  **Associated Payloads:** Unknown
  *  **Targets:** Non-specific
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Malicious XLL file
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Install malware



# Overview

HP has published a blog post analyzing the use of Microsoft Excel add-in (XLL) files to install malware on victim systems. There are three methods they identify being used to develop such malware. The first method observed involved the sale of a builder on underground forums. Purchase of the builder allows its user to specify a payload to embed or download along with a decoy file to display. The second method and, most used in the analyzed samples, is the use of Excel-DNA, a legitimate software project. .NET-developed code is stored in a resource and used to download and execute a malicious payload. Lastly, some samples used custom-generated add-ins as opposed to a builder or the use of Excel-DNA. The details of how the custom code operates can be found in the blog post. Eventually, API functions are used to download and execute a remotely hosted payload. For more information, see the HP blog post in the References section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/74057160/XLL%20Malware%20Techniques%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1642609237073&api=v2)



# Protection

## Yara Rule
    
    
    {  
      meta:  
        description = "XLL Custom Builder"  
        author = "patrick.schlapfer@[hp.com](http://hp.com)"  
        date = "2022-01-07"  
      
      strings:  
        $str1 = "xlAutoOpen"  
        $str2 = "test"  
        $op1 = { 4D 6B C9 00 }  
        $op2 = { 4D 31 0E }  
        $op3 = { 49 83 C6 08 }  
        $op4 = { 49 39 C6 }  
      
      condition:  
        uint16(0) == 0x5A4D and all of ($str*) and all of ($op*) and filesize < 10KB  
    }

# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Restrict Web-Based Content (M1021).
  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques and phishing emails (M1017).
  * Perform endpoint scans using the provided Yara rules.



# References

  * <https://threatresearch.ext.hp.com/how-attackers-use-xll-malware-to-infect-systems/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1566 - Phishing  
T1566.001 - Spearphishing Attachment  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1204 - User Execution  
T1204.002 - Malicious File  
  
 **Persistence - TA0003**  
T1137 - Office Application Startup  
T1137.006 - Add-ins

  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Install malware



# Overview

HP has published a blog post analyzing the use of Microsoft Excel add-in (XLL) files to install malware on victim systems. There are three methods they identify being used to develop such malware. The first method observed involved the sale of a builder on underground forums. Purchase of the builder allows its user to specify a payload to embed or download along with a decoy file to display. The second method and, most used in the analyzed samples, is the use of Excel-DNA, a legitimate software project. .NET-developed code is stored in a resource and used to download and execute a malicious payload. Lastly, some samples used custom-generated add-ins as opposed to a builder or the use of Excel-DNA. The details of how the custom code operates can be found in the blog post. Eventually, API functions are used to download and execute a remotely hosted payload. For more information, see the HP blog post in the References section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/74057160/XLL%20Malware%20Techniques%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1642609237073&api=v2)



# Protection

## Yara Rule
    
    
    {  
      meta:  
        description = "XLL Custom Builder"  
        author = "patrick.schlapfer@[hp.com](http://hp.com)"  
        date = "2022-01-07"  
      
      strings:  
        $str1 = "xlAutoOpen"  
        $str2 = "test"  
        $op1 = { 4D 6B C9 00 }  
        $op2 = { 4D 31 0E }  
        $op3 = { 49 83 C6 08 }  
        $op4 = { 49 39 C6 }  
      
      condition:  
        uint16(0) == 0x5A4D and all of ($str*) and all of ($op*) and filesize < 10KB  
    }

# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Restrict Web-Based Content (M1021).
  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques and phishing emails (M1017).
  * Perform endpoint scans using the provided Yara rules.



# References

  * <https://threatresearch.ext.hp.com/how-attackers-use-xll-malware-to-infect-systems/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1566 - Phishing  
T1566.001 - Spearphishing Attachment  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1204 - User Execution  
T1204.002 - Malicious File  
  
 **Persistence - TA0003**  
T1137 - Office Application Startup  
T1137.006 - Add-ins

Tell me everything you know the following threat: ICS-CERT Advisories February 02 2021
The ICS-CERT has published two advisories that affect Rockwell Automation's MicroLogix 1400 and Siemens SIMATIC HMI Comfort Panels and SIMATIC HMI KTP Mobile Panels.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

 Further information is available from the advisories which are summarised below.

 **ICS Advisory ICSA-21-033-01 - Rockwell Automation MicroLogix 1400**  
CVE-2021-22659 - A remote unauthenticated attacker may be able to send a specially crafted Modbus packet allowing the attacker to retrieve or modify random values in the register. If successfully exploited, this may lead to a buffer overflow resulting in a denial-of-service condition. The FAULT LED will flash RED and communications may be lost. Recovery from denial-of-service condition requires the fault to be cleared by the user.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 8.1 - CVSS Vector String: AV:N/AC:H/PR:N/UI:N/S:C/C:L/I:L/A:H).  
<https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ics/advisories/icsa-21-033-01>

 **ICS Advisory ICSA-21-033-02 - Siemens SIMATIC HMI Comfort Panels & SIMATIC HMI KTP Mobile Panels**  
CVE-2020-15798 - Affected devices with enabled Telnet service do not require authentication for this service. This could allow a remote attacker to gain full access to the device.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 8.1 - CVSS Vector String: AV:N/AC:H/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:H/I:H/A:H).  
<https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ics/advisories/icsa-21-033-02>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Owlproxy Malware Used in Attacks Targeting Taiwanese Government
Continuing their discussion of the April 2020 attacks against the Taiwanese government, CyCraft has published an article on the Owlproxy malware and use of skeleton keys for authentication.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware, RAT




# Overview

CyCraft has expanded on their previous research into attacks against the Taiwanese government by delving into the Owlproxy malware and use of skeleton keys. The Owlproxy malware, its name based on a PDB file project name, acts as a tunnel to bridge the internet and intranet so that the threat actor could have backdoor functionality. It allows the attacker to send backdoor commands over HTTP (port 80). The second part of the blog posts discusses an interesting TTP - the use of skeleton keys to gain network-wide authentication. This technique starts with an executable that, in turn, drops three files. The first file is an DLL that installs itself and deletes the original executable. A custom version of Mimikatz is then executed and injects the Skeleton Key into lsass, leveraging a kernel driver install to unprotect lsass if necessary. With this technique, Active Directory authentication can be bypassed. For more information, see the CyCraft blog post in the Reference section.  


# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.



# Reference

  * <https://medium.com/cycraft/taiwan-government-targeted-by-multiple-cyberattacks-in-april-2020-3b20cea1dc20>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Home Buying Phish Scheme Underway
Threat actors are using the home buying process in an attempt to phish sensitive from prospective buyers. A report from Cofense provides information on this latest in a long line of opportunistic attempts to gather information on unsuspecting users.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Phishing




# Overview

A new targeted attack is being levied against prospective home buyers in an attempt to gather sensitive information. Utilizing two popular brands within the email lends credence to the ruse perpetrated by the threat actors. Microsoft's OneDrive is leveraged as the lure for recipients to retrieve a file from the service. This file is a dummy tax return PDF, which is enticing to a victim due to its sensitive nature. The link, when hovered over, reveals no true OneDrive address but a typeform.com link. Once the link is clicked, the second brand is a fake Adobe login screen that is hosted on TypeForm. TypeForm allows users to create a multitude of products such as forms, quizzes, surveys, and other products. TypeForm being a free service makes it attractive to threat actors to use as a phishing service. In order to make the form, the threat actor used a login screen with a W-2 tax form as the background image. The threat actor added a question to the form prior to opening that stated "Adobe Secure Document" and a description of "Sign in with your email address." Similarly, the tactic is used again when requesting the user's password. The user is requested to enter the password twice, a common requirement when opening secure documents in order to confirm the correct password. Once the password is collected, the user is presented with a "View Document" button. Should the user click this button, the responses to the questions previously asked are sent back to the threat actor for harvesting. Upon successful exfiltration, the user is informed their identity could not be verified, and they are redirected to the first step of entering their email. This repetition allows the actor to confirm the email and password. Utilization of the W-2 and the prior scouting of targeting users in the home loan process allows the perpetrator to add relevance to their campaign. More details can be found in the article located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://cofense.com/blog/typeform-tax-phish/>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: ICS Advisory SHUN HU Technology JUUKO Vulnerability
An ICS advisory (ICSA-20-301-01) has been issued for SHUN HU Technology's JUUKO Industrial Radio Remote Control.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: ICS Advisory SHUN HU Technology JUUKO Vulnerability
An ICS advisory (ICSA-20-301-01) has been issued for SHUN HU Technology's JUUKO Industrial Radio Remote Control.

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

The Cybersecurity & Infrastructure Security Agency has published an advisory addressing vulnerabilities that exist in SHUN HU Technology's JUUKO Industrial Radio Remote Control. The most serious of the vulnerabilities has a CVSS score of 8.3, with low skill level needed to exploit it. If attackers on an adjacent network are able to successfully exploit the most serious vulnerability, they could potentially take control of an affected device. Affected products include the JUUKO K-800 and K-808. Vulnerable versions of firmware are those prior to versions ending with numbers 9A, 9B, 9C, etc. New firmware is available from the manufacturer to mitigate these vulnerabilities. We recommend patching the firmware as soon as possible. Further details can be found in the advisory located within the Reference section below.

# CVEs

  * A complete list of CVEs can be found here: [ CVEs.txt](/download/attachments/32146701/ICS%20Advisory%20SHUN%20HU%20Technology%20JUUKO%20Vulnerability%20CVEs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1603834575263&api=v2)




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ics/advisories/icsa-20-301-01>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: TA505 Using SolarWinds Vulnerability for Deployment of Clop
NCC Group's global Cyber Incident Response Team (CIRT) have seen an increase in Clop ransomware being deployed against vulnerable servers running SolarWinds Serv-U software.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: TA505 Using SolarWinds Vulnerability for Deployment of Clop
NCC Group's global Cyber Incident Response Team (CIRT) have seen an increase in Clop ransomware being deployed against vulnerable servers running SolarWinds Serv-U software.

# Threat Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Ransomware
  *  **Threat Actor:** TA505
  *  **Targets:** SolarWinds Serv-U Users
  *  **Ransomware Family:** Clop
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** SolarWinds Serv-U vulnerability (CVE-2021-35211)
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Deployment of Cobalt Strike Beacons and Persistence
  *  **Leak Site:** Unknown



# Overview

TA505 is exploiting the SolarWinds Serv-U vulnerability (CVE-2021-35211) to infiltrate victim networks, according to a blog post by NCC Group's CIRT. Initial access is obtained through the aforementioned vulnerability and is followed by the deployment of Cobalt Strike beacons and the Clop ransomware. Although SolarWinds patched the vulnerable OS, some vulnerable servers still exist, thus allowing for further exploitation opportunities. Using a base64-encoded PowerShell command structure, beacons were deployed on observed victim machines. The threat actor used a scheduled task to maintain persistence in the victim network, as well as a Registry entry as a backup. Further information can be found in the blog post located within the References section below. 

# CVEs

  * CVE-2021-35211



# Recommendations

  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Use application control where appropriate (M1026)(M1038)
  * Configure settings for scheduled tasks to force tasks to run under the context of the authenticated account instead of allowing them to run as SYSTEM (M1028).
  * Limit privileges of user accounts and remediate Privilege Escalation vectors so only authorized administrators can create scheduled tasks on remote systems (M1018).
  * Ensure proper permissions are set for Registry hives to prevent users from modifying keys for system components that may lead to privilege escalation (M1024).



# References

  * <https://research.nccgroup.com/2021/11/08/ta505-exploits-solarwinds-serv-u-vulnerability-cve-2021-35211-for-initial-access/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059.001 - PowerShell  
  
 **Persistence - TA0003**  
T1053.005 - Scheduled Task  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1112 - Modify Registry

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Threat Actor Targeting Huawei Cloud
A report from Trend Micro analyses Linux malware that is being used by a threat actor to disable services in the Huawei Cloud and install a cryptominer.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Cryptominer, Backdoor
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Unspecified
  *  **Associated Payloads:** linux64_shell, xlinux, Tor proxy service, cryptominer
  *  **Targets:** Huawei Cloud and other cloud instances.
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Unspecified vulnerability
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Removes infections from other actors, Adds users with administrative privileges, Installs shell and vulnerability scanner, Cryptomining
  *  **Additional TTPs: See MITRE ATT &CK Framework below.**



# Overview

Trend Micro has identified Linux malware that is being used by a threat actor to disable services in the Huawei Cloud and target other cloud instances. Code deployed by the actor can disable Huawei's hostguard service and includes open-source code named cloudResetPwdUpdateAgent that can be used to reset a password for an Elastic Cloud Service instance. The actors pay special attention to disabling infections from other competing actors. The actor creates users with administrative privileges, typically with benign-sounding names like "system" and "logging", and installs an ssh-rsa key. A binary named "xlinux" that is dropped on the system is a scanner that is used to scan the host for an Oracle WebLogic Server vulnerability (CVE-2020-14882) and weak passwords in SSH, Redis, PostgreSQL, SQL Server, MongoDB, and FTP. The actor's objective is to utilize infected hosts for cryptomining. Further information is available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/64130047/Threat%20Actor%20Targeting%20Huawei%20Cloud%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1634019396222&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).



# References

parsed_raw_data.xfe_q:
Threat Actor Targeting Huawei Cloud
A report from Trend Micro analyses Linux malware that is being used by a threat actor to disable services in the Huawei Cloud and install a cryptominer.
parsed_raw_data.xfe_report:
# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Cryptominer, Backdoor
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Unspecified
  *  **Associated Payloads:** linux64_shell, xlinux, Tor proxy service, cryptominer
  *  **Targets:** Huawei Cloud and other cloud instances.
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Unspecified vulnerability
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Removes infections from other actors, Adds users with administrative privileges, Installs shell and vulnerability scanner, Cryptomining
  *  **Additional TTPs: See MITRE ATT &CK Framework below.**



# Overview

Trend Micro has identified Linux malware that is being used by a threat actor to disable services in the Huawei Cloud and target other cloud instances. Code deployed by the actor can disable Huawei's hostguard service and includes open-source code named cloudResetPwdUpdateAgent that can be used to reset a password for an Elastic Cloud Service instance. The actors pay special attention to disabling infections from other competing actors. The actor creates users with administrative privileges, typically with benign-sounding names like "system" and "logging", and installs an ssh-rsa key. A binary named "xlinux" that is dropped on the system is a scanner that is used to scan the host for an Oracle WebLogic Server vulnerability (CVE-2020-14882) and weak passwords in SSH, Redis, PostgreSQL, SQL Server, MongoDB, and FTP. The actor's objective is to utilize infected hosts for cryptomining. Further information is available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/64130047/Threat%20Actor%20Targeting%20Huawei%20Cloud%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1634019396222&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).



# References

  * <https://www.trendmicro.com/en_us/research/21/j/actors-target-huawei-cloud-using-upgraded-linux-malware-.html>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Reconnaissance - TA0043**  
T1590 - Gather Victim Network Information  
T1592 - Gather Victim Host Information  
T1595 - Active Scanning  
  
 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1584 - Compromise Infrastructure  
T1585 - Establish Accounts  
T1586 - Compromise Accounts  
  
 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1053 - Scheduled Task/Job  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
T1072 - Software Deployment Tools  
T1129 - Shared Modules  
T1559 - Inter-Process Communication  
T1569 - System Services  
  
 **Persistence - TA0003**  
T1098 - Account Manipulation  
T1554 - Compromise Client Software Binary  
  
 **Privilege Escalation - TA0004**  
T1068 - Exploitation for Privilege Escalation  
  
 **Credential Access - TA0006**  
T1552 - Unsecured Credentials  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1007 - System Service Discovery  
T1018 - Remote System Discovery  
T1046 - Network Service Scanning  
T1057 - Process Discovery  
T1083 - File and Directory Discovery  
T1087 - Account Discovery  
T1518 - Software Discovery  
T1580 - Cloud Infrastructure Discovery  
  
 **Lateral Movement - TA0008**  
T1210 - Exploitation of Remote Services  
T1550 - Use Alternate Authentication Material  
  
 **Collection - TA0009**  
T1005 - Data from Local System  
T1119 - Automated Collection  
T1560 - Archive Collected Data  
T1602 - Data from Configuration Repository  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0010**  
T1020 - Automated Exfiltration  
T1041 - Exfiltration Over C2 Channel  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
T1104 - Multi-Stage Channels  
T1105 - Ingress Tool Transfer  
  
 **Impact - TA0040**  
T1489 - Service Stop

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: ICS Advisory ICSA-21-091-01
The ICS-CERT has published an advisory that affects Rockwell Automation's FactoryTalk AssetCentre.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

 Further information is available from the advisory which is summarized below.

 - Rockwell Automation FactoryTalk AssetCentre  
CVE-2021-27462 - A deserialization vulnerability exists in how the AosService.rem service in FactoryTalk AssetCentre verifies serialized data. This vulnerability may allow a remote, unauthenticated attacker to execute arbitrary commands in FactoryTalk AssetCentre.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 10.0 - CVSS Vector String: AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:C/C:H/I:H/A:H).

CVE-2021-27466 - A deserialization vulnerability exists in how the ArchiveService.rem service in FactoryTalk AssetCentre verifies serialized data. This vulnerability may allow a remote, unauthenticated attacker to execute arbitrary commands in FactoryTalk AssetCentre.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 10.0 - CVSS Vector String: AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:C/C:H/I:H/A:H).

CVE-2021-27470 - A deserialization vulnerability exists in how the LogService.rem service in FactoryTalk AssetCentre verifies serialized data. This vulnerability may allow a remote, unauthenticated attacker to execute arbitrary commands in FactoryTalk AssetCentre.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 10.0 - CVSS Vector String: AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:C/C:H/I:H/A:H).

CVE-2021-27474 - FactoryTalk AssetCentre does not properly restrict all functions relating to IIS remoting services. This vulnerability may allow a remote, unauthenticated attacker to modify sensitive data in FactoryTalk AssetCentre.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 10.0 - CVSS Vector String: AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:C/C:H/I:H/A:H).

CVE-2021-27476 - A vulnerability exists in the SaveConfigFile function of the RACompare Service, which may allow for OS command injection. This vulnerability may allow a remote, unauthenticated attacker to execute arbitrary commands in FactoryTalk AssetCentre.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 10.0 - CVSS Vector String: AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:C/C:H/I:H/A:H).

CVE-2021-27472 - A vulnerability exists in the RunSearch function of SearchService service, which may allow for the execution of remote unauthenticated arbitrary SQL statements.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 10.0 - CVSS Vector String: AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:C/C:H/I:H/A:H).

CVE-2021-27468 - The AosService.rem service exposes functions lacking proper authentication. This vulnerability may allow a remote, unauthenticated attacker to execute arbitrary SQL statements.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 10.0 - CVSS Vector String: AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:C/C:H/I:H/A:H).

CVE-2021-27464 - The ArchiveService.rem service exposes functions lacking proper authentication. This vulnerability may allow a remote, unauthenticated attacker to execute arbitrary SQL statements.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 10.0 - CVSS Vector String: AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:C/C:H/I:H/A:H).

CVE-2021-27460 - FactoryTalk AssetCentre components contain .NET remoting endpoints that deserialize untrusted data without sufficiently verifying that the resulting data will be valid. This vulnerability may allow a remote, unauthenticated attacker to gain full access to the FactoryTalk AssetCentre main server and all agent machines.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 10.0 - CVSS Vector String: AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:C/C:H/I:H/A:H).  
<https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ics/advisories/icsa-21-091-01>

# CVEs

  * A complete list of CVEs can be found here: [ CVEs.txt](/download/attachments/44827306/ICS%20Advisory%20ICSA-21-091-01%20CVEs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1617686582754&api=v2)




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ics/advisories>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Active QNAP NAS Exploitation
Attackers have been cautiously exploiting an unpublicized vulnerability in QNAP NAS devices. 360 Netlab provides their analysis of this activity in a recent blog post.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Active QNAP NAS Exploitation
Attackers have been cautiously exploiting an unpublicized vulnerability in QNAP NAS devices. 360 Netlab provides their analysis of this activity in a recent blog post.

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Exploit




# Overview

360 Netlab reports on an in the wild exploitation of a vulnerability in QNAP NAS devices. This vulnerability was not publicly reported on prior to these findings. The vulnerability exploited exists in the CGI program used when users log out of the QNAP NAS device. By exploiting the vulnerability, attackers are able to gain unauthenticated remote code execution capabilities. In this campaign, the remote code execution capabilities are used to download a payload using wget. Based on current observations, the researchers have been unable to identify the ultimate goal of the attackers as further malware is not installed at this time. Two additional files were discovered on the server hosting the payload currently being downloaded. Specifically, they are two text files, one containing 2 lines of seemingly random text and the other being a bash reverse shell script. The server was found to be running SSH, Metasploit, Apache httpd, and other services. When 360 Netlab reported this vulnerability to QNAP, they were informed that this vulnerability was patched in 2017; however, plenty of QNAP NAS devices are still running on the Internet without updated firmware. For more information, see the 360 Netlab blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.



# Reference

  * <https://blog.netlab.360.com/in-the-wild-qnap-nas-attacks-en/>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Active CVE-2020-0688 Exploit Affects Over 247,000 Microsoft Exchange Servers
A vulnerability, CVE-2020-0688, patched in February of 2020, is being actively exploited. This Microsoft Exchange Server remote code execution vulnerability could affect more than 247,000 unpatched systems on the Internet, BleepingComputer warns.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability



# Overview

BleepingComputer warns that over 247,000 Microsoft Exchange Servers on the Internet have not had the February update to address a remote code execution vulnerability, CVE-2020-0688. The issues resides in the Exchange Control Panel code, which is enabled by default, and could allow an attacker to gain control of the server if successfully exploited. In a survey of Exchange servers on the Internet, Rapid7 found 405,873 Exchange servers with 61% (247,986) still vulnerable to CVE-2020-0688. They also discovered 16,577 Exchange 2007 servers, which are no longer being supported by Microsoft, that were vulnerable as well. For more details, refer to the links in the Reference section.

# CVEs

  * A complete list of CVEs can be found here: [ CVEs.txt](/download/attachments/30771017/Active%20CVE-2020-0688%20Exploit%20Affects%20Over%20247%2C000%20Microsoft%20Exchange%20Servers%20CVEs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1601476091435&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://www.bleepingcomputer.com/news/security/over-247k-exchange-servers-unpatched-for-actively-exploited-flaw/>   
<https://www.bleepingcomputer.com/news/security/us-govt-china-sponsored-hackers-targeting-exchange-citrix-f5-flaws/>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: BazarBackdoor’s Stealthy Infiltration
A BazarBackdoor campaign discovered by Cofense aims to lure victims into downloading a payload using an invoice theme.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware, Backdoor




# Overview

Cofense has published a blog post analyzing a recent BazarBackdoor campaign. This campaign begins with an email claiming that an order is set for delivery with an invoice attached and a phone number to call for assistance. The PDF provided contains fake order details, but no direct link to click in order to cancel. There is, however, a domain contained in the company details line, which a curious recipient looking to cancel the order may visit. If it is visited, a form requests an order number be provided. Providing an order number leads to a user being redirected to a page where they can download a supposed order cancellation form. With macros enabled, the cancellation form leads to the download and installation of a new variant of the first-stage BazarBackdoor payload. With the access provided by this payload and its subsequent stages, the operators can carry out a variety of attacks. For more information, see the Cofense blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://cofense.com/blog/bazarbackdoor-stealthy-infiltration>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Cisco Security Advisories May 5 2021
Cisco has published twenty-nine security advisories. Of the advisories, two are rated as Critical, seven are rated as High, nineteen are rated as Medium, and one is rated as Informational.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

 Please note that one of the advisories summarized below (cisco-sa-anyconnect-profile-AggMUCDg) has a warning about public disclosure or exploitation of the vulnerability covered in the advisory.

## Advisories Rated Critical

 **Cisco SD-WAN vManage Software Vulnerabilities**  
cisco-sa-sd-wan-vmanage-4TbynnhZ  
Multiple vulnerabilities in CiscoSD-WAN vManage Software could allow an unauthenticated, remote attacker to execute arbitrary code or gain access to sensitive information, or allow an authenticated, local attacker to gain escalated privileges or gain unauthorized access to the application.  
CVE-2021-1275 CVE-2021-1468 CVE-2021-1505 CVE-2021-1506 CVE-2021-1508  
Base 9.8 CVSS:3.1/AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:H/I:H/A:H  
<https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityAdvisory/cisco-sa-sd-wan-vmanage-4TbynnhZ>

 **Cisco HyperFlex HX Command Injection Vulnerabilities**  
cisco-sa-hyperflex-rce-TjjNrkpR  
Multiple vulnerabilities in the web-based management interface of CiscoHyperFlex HX could allow an unauthenticated, remote attacker to perform command injection attacks against an affected device.  
CVE-2021-1497 CVE-2021-1498  
Base 9.8 CVSS:3.1/AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:H/I:H/A:H  
<https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityAdvisory/cisco-sa-hyperflex-rce-TjjNrkpR>

## Advisories Rated High

 **Cisco AnyConnect Secure Mobility Client for Windows DLL and Executable Hijacking Vulnerabilities**  
cisco-sa-anyconnect-code-exec-jR3tWTA6  
Multiple vulnerabilities in the install, uninstall, and upgrade processes of CiscoAnyConnect Secure Mobility Client for Windows could allow an authenticated, local attacker to hijack DLL or executable files that are used by the application. A successful exploit could allow the attacker to execute arbitrary code on an affected device with SYSTEM privileges. To exploit these vulnerabilities, the attacker must have valid credentials on the Windows system.  
CVE-2021-1426 CVE-2021-1427 CVE-2021-1428 CVE-2021-1429 CVE-2021-1430 CVE-2021-1496  
Base 7.0 CVSS:3.1/AV:L/AC:H/PR:L/UI:N/S:U/C:H/I:H/A:H  
<https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityAdvisory/cisco-sa-anyconnect-code-exec-jR3tWTA6>

 **Cisco SD-WAN Software vDaemon Denial of Service Vulnerability**  
cisco-sa-sdwan-dos-Ckn5cVqW  
A vulnerability in the vDaemon process of CiscoSD-WAN Software could allow an unauthenticated, remote attacker to cause a device to reload, resulting in a denial of service (DoS) condition.  
CVE-2021-1513  
Base 7.5 CVSS:3.1/AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:N/I:N/A:H  
<https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityAdvisory/cisco-sa-sdwan-dos-Ckn5cVqW>

 **Cisco SD-WAN vEdge Software Buffer Overflow Vulnerabilities**  
cisco-sa-sdwan-buffover-MWGucjtO  
Multiple vulnerabilities in CiscoSD-WAN vEdge Software could allow an attacker to execute arbitrary code as the root user or cause a denial of service (DoS) condition on an affected device.  
CVE-2021-1509 CVE-2021-1510 CVE-2021-1511  
Base 7.5 CVSS:3.1/AV:N/AC:H/PR:L/UI:N/S:U/C:H/I:H/A:H  
<https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/content/CiscoSecurityAdvisory/cisco-sa-sdwan-buffover-MWGucjtO>

 **Cisco SD-WAN vManage Software Authentication Bypass Vulnerability**  
cisco-sa-sdw-auth-bypass-65aYqcS2  
A vulnerability in the web-based messaging service interface of CiscoSD-WAN vManage Software could allow an unauthenticated, adjacent attacker to bypass authentication and authorization and modify the configuration of an affected system. To exploit this vulnerability, the attacker must be able to access an associated CiscoSD-WAN vEdge device.  
CVE-2021-1284

Cisco Security Advisories May 5 2021
Cisco has published twenty-nine security advisories. Of the advisories, two are rated as Critical, seven are rated as High, nineteen are rated as Medium, and one is rated as Informational.

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: New Variant of Buer Loader Written in Rust
A new variant of the Buer malware loader, dubbed "RustyBuer" by Proofpoint, has been completely rewritten in the Rust programming language.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware, Loader




# Overview

Proofpoint published a blog post analyzing a new variant of the Buer malware loader. The significant difference of this new variant, dubbed "RustyBuer," is that it has been completely rewritten to use the Rust programming language instead of C. Additionally, the threat actors are becoming more sophisticated by using more convincing lures. The new payload is being distributed via DHL shipping-themed phishing emails with either links to download a documents or a document directly attached to the email. The documents leverage malicious macros to extract an embedded payload and drop it on the system. Persistence is established via a LNK file that executes at startup. Base64 encoding, hex encoding, and RC4 encryption are used in order to encrypt C2 communications. The initial POST request to the C2 server provides system information. The response contains instructions related to downloading and executing a second-stage payload. In some cases, RustyBuer was used to distribute Cobalt Strike Beacon as a second-stage. In other cases, no second-stage payload was identified, potentially indicating access-as-a-service operations. The purpose of the rewrite is likely due to more efficient nature and broader feature set of Rust along with the ability to bypass existing detections of Buer that rely on C code detection. For more information, see the Proofpoint blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.proofpoint.com/us/blog/threat-insight/new-variant-buer-loader-written-rust>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: How Chinese Threat Actors Utilize BPFDoor
A recent report details processes used by a surveillance tool that is possibly connected to a Chinese threat actor group. BPFDoor has been utilized to target telecommunications, government, and education in the Middle East and Asia.
output:
# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Backdoor 
  * **Associated Threat Actors:** Red Manchin
  *  **Targets:** Telecommunications, Education, Government
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** RCE
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Surveillance 



# Overview

The report identifies the Chinese threat actor that is connected to BPFDoor as Red Manchin. This Chinese threat actor has been targeting sectors in the Middle East and Asia. Although primarily focusing on compromising telecommunication companies, they have also been targeting government and education. The threat actor is utilizing BPFDoor to target Linux for remote code execution. This is accomplished without utilizing network ports or alerting any firewall rules. BDFDoor utilizes web apps that are already running on ports. BDFDoor also obfuscates its activities by renaming its designed process on Linux and therefore does not utilize inbound ports or outbound command and control infrastructure. Further information can be found in the article located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * For a full list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.




# References

  * <https://doublepulsar.com/bpfdoor-an-active-chinese-global-surveillance-tool-54b078f1a896>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

####  **Tactics and Techniques:**

 **Privilege Escalation - TA0004**  
T1053.001 - At (Linux)  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1036.003 - Rename System Utilities  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1497 - Virtualization/Sandbox Evasion  
  
 **Lateral Movement - TA0008**  
T1210 - Exploitation of Remote Services  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1001 - Data Obfuscation

  
 **Mitigations:**

 **M1016:** Vulnerability Scanning - Vulnerability scanning is used to find potentially exploitable software vulnerabilities to remediate them.  
 **M1017:** User Training - Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction.  
 **M1018:** User Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.  
 **M1019:** Threat Intelligence Program - A threat intelligence program helps an organization generate their own threat intelligence information and track trends to inform defensive priorities to mitigate risk.  
 **M1022:** Restrict File and Directory Permissions - Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.  
 **M1026:** Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.  
 **M1028:** Operating System Configuration - Make configuration changes related to the operating system or a common feature of the operating system that result in system hardening against techniques.  
 **M1030:** Network Segmentation - Architect sections of the network to isolate critical systems, functions, or resources. Use physical and logical segmentation to prevent access to potentially sensitive systems and information. Use a DMZ to contain any internet-facing services that should not be exposed from the internal network. Configure separate virtual private cloud (VPC) instances to isolate critical cloud systems.  
 **M1031:** Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  
 **M1038:** Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
 **M1042:** Disable or Remove Feature or Program - Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.  
 **M1045:** Code Signing - Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.  
 **M1047:** Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
 **M1048:** Application Isolation and Sandboxing - Restrict execution of code to a virtual environment on or in transit to an endpoint system.  
 **M1050:** Exploit Protection - Use capabilities to detect and block conditions that may lead to or be indicative of a software exploit occurring.  
 **M1051:** Update Software - Perform regular software updates to mitigate exploitation risk.

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Amazon Japan Credential Phishing
A high-volume Amazon Japan themed phishing campaign was identified by Proofpoint researchers and reported on in a recent blog post.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Phishing




# Overview

Proofpoint has published their findings on an Amazon phishing campaign targeting Japanese users. In terms of the sender, the threat actors initially exploited randomly generated email addresses for distribution; but they have since pivoted to using lookalike domains and addresses, in order to increase legitimacy. The body and subject of the email are: written in Japanese, use legitimate Amazon logos, and request that the recipient provide information to update or unlock their account. In most cases, the URL is linked to an IP address, but in some cases, random domain names were used. The phishing page is also, geofenced and checks whether the user is in Japan before proceeding. If they are not, they are redirected to the legitimate Amazon Japan login page. If they are located in Japan, they are directed to a fake login page. Submitting credentials redirects users to, two additional forms, one requesting various pieces of personally identifiable information and another requesting credit card information. After the forms are complete, victims are redirected to the real Amazon Japan homepage, leaving the attackers with all of the provided information. Proofpoint gives credence to the fact that, this campaign is unique to other Amazon phishing campaigns. This is due to, the volume of emails sent, with an average of several hundred thousand distributed per day. Leading researchers to believe, a botnet is being used to automate the distribution of the emails based on the quantity. For more information, see the Proofpoint blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.proofpoint.com/us/blog/threat-insight/geofenced-amazon-japan-credential-phishing-volumes-rival-emotet>
