instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Seedworm: Continues to Target Organizations in the Middle East
The Threat Hunter Team from Symantec began probing a new hacking tool they believe Seedworm, the Iranian cyber-espionage group, also known as MuddyWater, has been utilizing in recent attacks, known as PowGoop. Furthermore, supporting Iranian strategic interest, with the end goal of smuggling key data from prime targets in the Middle East.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware




# Overview

Researchers at Symantec observed the latest addition to Seedworms attack arsenal, a new hacking tool called PowGoop. It was assessed, that Seedworm ulitizes the PowGoop malware as a downloader to reach out to other remote servers to download and execute additional PowerShell scripts. This has been highly effective for the group, due to PowGoops two components: a DLL loader and a PowerShell-based downloader. The PowGoop loader component is responsible for decrypting and running the PowerShell code that comprises the PowGoop downloader, allowing the threat group to siphon data off of networks. Analyst at Symantec also observed Seedworm exploiting several open-source tools like: Quarks PwDump, Chisel and Secure Sockets Funneling (SSF), to help with the movement and maneuverability of the data from one network to another. Furthermore, allowing the attackers to configure local and remote port forwarding as well as copy files to compromised machines. Although researchers are unable to assess a sustainable correlation between PowGoop and Seedworm, they’ve focused their rational on the presumption that; Seedworm is reconstructing their operational approach in terms of TTPs. For more details, please review the link in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://symantec-enterprise-blogs.security.com/blogs/threat-intelligence/seedworm-apt-iran-middle-east>

  * <https://symantec-enterprise-blogs.security.com/blogs/threat-intelligence/elfin-indictments-iran-espionage>

It was assessed, that Seedworm ulitizes the PowGoop malware as a downloader to reach out to other remote servers to download and execute additional PowerShell scripts. This has been highly effective for the group, due to PowGoops two components: a DLL loader and a PowerShell-based downloader. The PowGoop loader component is responsible for decrypting and running the PowerShell code that comprises the PowGoop downloader, allowing the threat group to siphon data off of networks. Analyst at Symantec also observed Seedworm exploiting several open-source tools like: Quarks PwDump, Chisel and Secure Sockets Funneling (SSF), to help with the movement and maneuverability of the data from one network to another. Furthermore, allowing the attackers to configure local and remote port forwarding as well as copy files to compromised machines. Although researchers are unable to assess a sustainable correlation between PowGoop and Seedworm, they’ve focused their rational on the presumption that; Seedworm is reconstructing their operational approach in terms of TTPs. For more details, please review the link in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://symantec-enterprise-blogs.security.com/blogs/threat-intelligence/seedworm-apt-iran-middle-east>

  * <https://symantec-enterprise-blogs.security.com/blogs/threat-intelligence/elfin-indictments-iran-espionage>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: North Korea Distributing BLINDINGCAN RAT
SentinelOne has published a paper regarding malicious North Korean activity and the distribution of a RAT labeled BLINDINGCAN.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware, RAT, Campaign



# Overview

Job offers are the subject of this particular phishing campaign and they carry BLINDINGCAN RAT as a payload, a SentinelOne paper states. The defense and aerospace industries in Europe and the United States are the primary targets of this campaign. An infected system in a key location can provide the attackers with valuable intelligence and key technologies, the article indicated. The attachment attempts to exploit CVE-2017-0199, a vulnerability in the processing of RTF files, which can result in the execution of arbitrary code if successful. Once infected, the malware contacts its command and control servers for additional components, such as a keylogger and clipboard monitor. Information about the system is sent back to the command and control servers. For more details, please refer to the links in the Reference section.

# CVEs

  * CVE-2017-0199



# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/29426391/North%20Korea%20Distributing%20BLINDINGCAN%20RAT%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1598905010014&api=v2)



# Protection

# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.sentinelone.com/blog/the-blindingcan-rat-and-malicious-north-korean-activity/>  
<https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ncas/analysis-reports/ar20-232a>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: The NetDooka Malware Framework
A report from Trend Micro documents a new malware framework they discovered and named NetDooka. This malware is being distributed through a pay-per-install service using a modular downloader named PrivateLoader.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: The NetDooka Malware Framework
A report from Trend Micro documents a new malware framework they discovered and named NetDooka. This malware is being distributed through a pay-per-install service using a modular downloader named PrivateLoader.

# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Malware
  *  **Targets:** Downloaders of pirated software.
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** NetDooka Malware Framework, PrivateLoader
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Pirated software that contains PrivateLoader.
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Typical RAT functions.
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

The NetDooka malware framework, discovered and named by Trend Micro, contains multiple elements including a dropper, a loader, a protection driver, and a remote access Trojan (RAT). Distribution of NetDooka is being carried out by a pay-per-install service using a modular downloader named PrivateLoader that is typically delivered to victims in pirated software. PrivateLoader executes the first of the NetDooka malware, a dropper that is used to download the next stage, NetDooka's loader. The loader carries out a number of tasks including checking that it isn't running in a virtual environment, creating a new virtual desktop that it uses to uninstall a number of anti-virus products, and may also install a kernel driver. The last stage is the deployment of the RAT which also carries out a number of system checks to detect analysis environments. The RAT provides features typical of many remote access Trojans though C&C communications are carried out using a custom protocol. Further information is available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * For a list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.




# References

  * <https://www.trendmicro.com/en_us/research/22/e/netdooka-framework-distributed-via-privateloader-ppi.html>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Tactics and Techniques:**

 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1583 - Acquire Infrastructure  
T1583.001 - Domains  
T1583.004 - Server  
T1587 - Develop Capabilities  
T1587.001 - Malware  
T1588 - Obtain Capabilities  
T1588.002 - Tool  
T1608 - Stage Capabilities  
T1608.002 - Upload Tool  
T1608.005 - Link Target  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
T1204 - User Execution  
T1204.002 - Malicious File  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1027 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
T1070 - Indicator Removal on Host  
T1070.004 - File Deletion  
T1140 - Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information  
T1197 - BITS Jobs  
T1497 - Virtualization/Sandbox Evasion  
T1497.001 - System Checks  
T1562 - Impair Defenses  
T1562.001 - Disable or Modify Tools  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1082 - System Information Discovery  
T1497 - Virtualization/Sandbox Evasion  
T1497.001 - System Checks  
T1518 - Software Discovery  
T1518.001 - Security Software Discovery  
  
 **Collection - TA0009**  
T1005 - Data from Local System  
T1123 - Audio Capture  
T1125 - Video Capture  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0010**  
T1041 - Exfiltration Over C2 Channel  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
  


####  **Mitigations:**

 **M1017:** User Training - Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction.  
 **M1018:** User Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.  
 **M1021:** Restrict Web-Based Content - Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc.  
 **M1022:** Restrict File and Directory Permissions - Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.  
 **M1024:** Restrict Registry Permissions - Restrict the ability to modify certain hives or keys in the Windows Registry.  
 **M1026:** Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.  
 **M1028:** Operating System Configuration - Make configuration changes related to the operating system or a common feature of the operating system that result in system hardening against techniques.  
 **M1029:** Remote Data Storage - Use remote security log and sensitive file storage where access can be controlled better to prevent exposure of intrusion detection log data or sensitive information.  
 **M1031:** Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  
 **M1033:** Limit Software Installation - Block users or groups from installing unapproved software.  
 **M1037:** Filter Network Traffic - Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic.  
 **M1038:** Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
 **M1039:** Environment Variable Permissions - Prevent modification of environment variables by unauthorized users and groups.  
 **M1040:** Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
 **M1041:** Encrypt Sensitive Information - Protect sensitive information with strong encryption.  
 **M1042:** Disable or Remove Feature or Program - Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.  
 **M1045:** Code Signing - Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.  
 **M1047:** Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
 **M1049:** Antivirus/Antimalware - Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software.  
 **M1054:** Software Configuration - Implement configuration changes to software (other than the operating system) to mitigate security risks associated to how the software operates.  
 **M1056:** Pre-compromise - This category is used for any applicable mitigation activities that apply to techniques occurring before an adversary gains Initial Access, such as Reconnaissance and Resource Development techniques.  
 **M1057:** Data Loss Prevention - Use a data loss prevention (DLP) strategy to categorize sensitive data, identify data formats indicative of personal identifiable information (PII), and restrict exfiltration of sensitive data.

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: White Rabbit Evasion Techniques Analyzed
The new ransomware family White Rabbit was first seen in December of 2021. A report by Trend Micro explores some of the evasion tactics used by this new malware.
output:
# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Ransomware
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Fin8 (G0061)
  *  **Associated Payloads:** White Rabbit
  *  **Targets:** Unknown
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Unknown **  
**
  * **Post-Compromise Actions:** Data Encryption, Double Extortion



# Overview

White Rabbit is a new ransomware family discovered by Trend Micro with a potential connection to the threat group Fin8. It looks like it could be loaded onto systems using systems already compromised and infected with Cobalt Strike. Trend Micro has published details of the evasion tactics used by the malware. The payload is a small file with no notable strings or activity. The way to activate the ransomware and decrypt the internal configuration is via a command-line password - a technique also used by the ransomware family Egregor. Upon execution, White Rabbit will terminate several processes, including processes related to antivirus. Once complete, the ransomware drops a ransom note which threatens to leak the victim's stolen data if the ransom is not paid. Further information is available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/74057151/White%20Rabbit%20Evasion%20Techniques%20Analyzed%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1642589352360&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior (M1040). 



# References

  * <https://www.trendmicro.com/en_us/research/22/a/new-ransomware-spotted-white-rabbit-and-its-evasion-tactics.html>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1027 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
T1070 - Indicator Removal on Host  
T1562 - Impair Defenses  
T1562.001 - Disable or Modify Tools  
  
 **Impact - TA0040**  
T1486 - Data Encrypted for Impact

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: El Salvador and Pegasus Spyware
A report has been published that is the result of an investigation by Citizen Lab and a number of collaborators that details attacks that infected the phones of journalists and members of civil society in El Salvador with NSO’s Pegasus spyware.
output:
# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Malware
  *  **Targets:** Journalists and members of civil society in El Salvador.
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** Pegasus
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** KISMET, and FORCEDENTRY.
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Data collection and exfiltration.
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

A series of attacks that ran from July 2020 through to November 2021 targeted the phones of a number of journalists and members of civil society in El Salvador. The malware delivered in these attacks was the Pegasus spyware from NSO. Citizen Lab reports that the timing of the attacks coincided with media organizations reporting on sensitive issues related to the Salvadoran government. In total, thirty-seven devices were found to be infected. The report notes that at least two zero-click exploits, KISMET and FORCEDENTRY, were used as the infection vector and were delivered in messages which contain either an attachment or a one-click malicious link. Citizen Lab identified one actor they have named TOROGOZ whose activities strongly suggest that they are a Pegasus customer located in El Salvador. Further information can be found in the report linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/74057202/El%20Salvador%20and%20Pegasus%20Spyware%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1642643420711&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Implement an enterprise mobility management (EMM), also known as mobile device management (MDM) (M1012).

  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques (M1017).

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).



# References

  * <https://citizenlab.ca/2022/01/project-torogoz-extensive-hacking-media-civil-society-el-salvador-pegasus-spyware/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Initial Access - TA0027**  
T1456 - Drive-by Compromise  
T1477 - Exploit via Radio Interfaces  
  
 **Persistence - TA0028**  
T1400 - Modify System Partition  
  
 **Privilege Escalation - TA0029**  
T1404 - Exploit OS Vulnerability  
  
 **Discovery - TA0032**  
T1422 - System Network Configuration Discovery  
T1426 - System Information Discovery  
  
 **Collection - TA0035**  
T1409 - Access Stored Application Data  
T1412 - Capture SMS Messages  
T1429 - Capture Audio  
T1430 - Location Tracking  
T1432 - Access Contact List  
T1433 - Access Call Log  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0037**  
T1438 - Alternate Network Mediums

# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Persistence - TA0028**  
T1400 - Modify System Partition  
  
 **Privilege Escalation - TA0029**  
T1404 - Exploit OS Vulnerability  
  
 **Discovery - TA0032**  
T1422 - System Network Configuration Discovery  
T1426 - System Information Discovery  
  
 **Collection - TA0035**  
T1409 - Access Stored Application Data  
T1412 - Capture SMS Messages  
T1429 - Capture Audio  
T1430 - Location Tracking  
T1432 - Access Contact List  
T1433 - Access Call Log  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0037**  
T1438 - Alternate Network Mediums

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Mount Locker Ransomware In The Mix
A new ransomware campaign is underway and stealing files, encrypting them, and demanding ransom in exchange for the return of files. Mount Locker is the subject of a report from Bleeping Computer.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Mount Locker Ransomware In The Mix
A new ransomware campaign is underway and stealing files, encrypting them, and demanding ransom in exchange for the return of files. Mount Locker is the subject of a report from Bleeping Computer.

# Threat Type

  * Ransomware




# Overview

Around July 2020, Mount Locker was discovered invading corporate networks in order to steal files and deploy its ransomware. The group doesn't follow typical protocol with regard to other ransomware actors. Mount Locker first steals a victim's files, then they encrypt those files, and finally leave a ransom note demanding millions of dollars to decrypt those files. This is key because the group threatens to release the unencrypted version of the files to the victim's competitors, the media, and others should the ransom not be paid. In fact, one company received such demands but refused to pay. Subsequently, the files were released to a ransomware data leak site. At present, the site lists four victim companies with only one's files being leaked. A sample of the malware was analyzed, and it was found the ransomware uses ChaCha 20 to perform encryption as well as an RSA-2048 public key to encrypt the encryption key. As with other ransomware, the Mount Locker ransomware appends a custom extension to the files. The ransomware registers the extension in the Registry so if a file is clicked, the ransom note is loaded automatically. The ransom note contains instructions on how to access a Tor site in order to communicate with the threat actors. This site is merely a chat service to negotiate ransom or inquire as to how to pay. Recovery of files for free is not an option at this time. For more information, please see the article located within the Reference section below.

# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * [https://www.bleepingcomputer.com/news/security/mount-locker-ransomware-joins-the-multi-million-dollar-ransom-game/](https://www.bleepingcomputer.com/news/security/mount-locker-ransomware-joins-the-multi-million-dollar-ransom-game/?&web_view=true)

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Debian Redis Servers Being Exploited to Deploy Muhstik Bot
Threat actors are exploiting a remote code execution vulnerability in Redis servers used in certain versions of Debian Linux and deploying the Muhstik bot, according to a report from Juniper Threat Labs.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Malware
  *  **Targets:** Debian Redis servers.
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** Muhstik
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Remote exploitation of CVE-2022-0543.
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Unspecified
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

Beginning on March 11th, Juniper Threat Labs observed an attack targeting a remote code execution vulnerability (CVE-2022-0543) in Redis servers used in certain versions of Debian Linux. According to Juniper's report, the actors behind the attack have previously exploited vulnerabilities in Confluence and Log4j. If exploitation is successful, wget or curl are used to download a file named "russia.sh" which is then executed. The file downloads and executes binaries that Juniper identifies as variants of the Muhstik bot. Muhstik is a bot that connects to an IRC server and has the ability to download files, execute shell commands, brute force SSH, and participate in DoS attacks. Further information is available from the links in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * For a full list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.



# References

  * <https://blogs.juniper.net/en-us/security/muhstik-gang-targets-redis-servers>
  * <https://www.ubercomp.com/posts/2022-01-20_redis_on_debian_rce>
  * <https://security-tracker.debian.org/tracker/CVE-2022-0543>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Tactics and Techniques:**

 **Reconnaissance - TA0043**  
T1595 - Active Scanning  
T1595.001 - Scanning IP Blocks  
T1595.002 - Vulnerability Scanning  
  
 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1583 - Acquire Infrastructure  
T1583.004 - Server  
T1587 - Develop Capabilities  
T1587.004 - Exploits  
T1588 - Obtain Capabilities  
T1588.001 - Malware  
T1608 - Stage Capabilities  
T1608.001 - Upload Malware  
  
 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
T1059.004 - Unix Shell  
  
 **Credential Access - TA0006**  
T1110 - Brute Force  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
  


 **Mitigations:**

 **M1016:** Vulnerability Scanning - Vulnerability scanning is used to find potentially exploitable software vulnerabilities to remediate them.  
 **M1018:** User Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.  
 **M1021:** Restrict Web-Based Content - Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc.  
 **M1026:** Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.  
 **M1027:** Password Policies - Set and enforce secure password policies for accounts.  
 **M1030:** Network Segmentation - Architect sections of the network to isolate critical systems, functions, or resources. Use physical and logical segmentation to prevent access to potentially sensitive systems and information. Use a DMZ to contain any internet-facing services that should not be exposed from the internal network. Configure separate virtual private cloud (VPC) instances to isolate critical cloud systems.  
 **M1031:** Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  
 **M1032:** Multi-factor Authentication - Use two or more pieces of evidence to authenticate to a system; such as username and password in addition to a token from a physical smart card or token generator.  
 **M1033:** Limit Software Installation - Block users or groups from installing unapproved software.  
 **M1036:** Account Use Policies - Configure features related to account use like login attempt lockouts, specific login times, etc.  
 **M1037:** Filter Network Traffic - Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic.  
 **M1038:** Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
 **M1040:** Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
 **M1042:** Disable or Remove Feature or Program - Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.  
 **M1045:** Code Signing - Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.  
 **M1047:** Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
 **M1048:** Application Isolation and Sandboxing - Restrict execution of code to a virtual environment on or in transit to an endpoint system.  
 **M1049:** Antivirus/Antimalware - Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software.  
 **M1050:** Exploit Protection - Use capabilities to detect and block conditions that may lead to or be indicative of a software exploit occurring.  
 **M1051:** Update Software - Perform regular software updates to mitigate exploitation risk.  
 **M1056:** Pre-compromise - This category is used for any applicable mitigation activities that apply to techniques occurring before an adversary gains Initial Access, such as Reconnaissance and Resource Development techniques.

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Gafgyt Using Pulse Secure Vulnerability
A vulnerability in Pulse Secure's Connect VPN framework is allowing for exploitation by Gafgyt. Avira details how this exploit works in a new blog.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Gafgyt Using Pulse Secure Vulnerability
A vulnerability in Pulse Secure's Connect VPN framework is allowing for exploitation by Gafgyt. Avira details how this exploit works in a new blog.

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Vulnerability




# Overview

Avira Labs has observed an increase in IoT malware binaries. These binaries have the capability to exploit CVE-2020-8218. This increase led to the discovery of a new variant of Gafgyt. Its functionality is mostly the same as the original Gafgyt with some inclusion of functionality from other malware families. One such family is Tsunami and its use of DNS amplification, which is incorporated into this new variant. The threat actors have included multiple architectures in an effort to deploy this malware to as many different types of processors as possible, thus widening their potential footprint and success rate. The malware attempts to print "bigB04t" using an API call. Gafgyt then attempts to prevent the affected device from restarting by manipulating the watchdog. The payload of the malware is downloaded from the IP addresses located in the IoC section below. The vulnerability itself allows an unauthenticated user to run arbitrary code remotely. This requires administrative privileges but can be accomplished through a malicious link clicked by an administrator. Further details can be found in the blog located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://prod-blog.avira.com/a-gafgyt-variant-that-exploits-pulse-secure-cve-2020-8218>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Avos Ransomware Group Expands Capabilities
Cisco Talos has posted an advisory that details the recent activities of the Avos Ransomware group. This threat actor is utilizing several vulnerabilities to gain a foothold in targeted networks.
output:
Summary
=======



Threat Details
==============

* **Malware Type:** Ransomware
* **Associated Threat Actors:** Avos
* **Associated Payloads:** AvosLocker
* **Targets:** Unknown
* **Initial Infection Vector:** Spam Email
* **Additional TTPs:**See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below

Overview
========

The team at Talos was recently asked to assist a Cisco customer. When they responded to the request their analysis revealed that the customer was targeted by the Avos ransomware group. This threat group goes back to 2021 when they initially targeted Windows instances. Recently a new variant of their ransomware known as AvosLocker is targeting Linux environments. Avos ransomware is known as ransomware-as-a-service. In past campaigns, Avos used spam emails to compromise victims. During the investigation of this incident, Talos researchers found that the threat actor had utilized an ESXi server that was exposed as the initial vector. This particular server was exposed because of the VMWare Horizon Unified Gateways that were vulnerable to the Log4Shell. Further information is available from the link in the References section below.

Indicators of Compromise
========================

Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.

Recommendations
===============

* For a list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.

References
==========

* [https://blog.talosintelligence.com/2022/06/avoslocker-new-arsenal.html](https://blog.talosintelligence.com/2022/06/avoslocker-new-arsenal.html "Follow link")

MITRE ATT&CK Framework
======================

#### Tactics and Techniques:

**Initial Access - TA0001**  
 T1566 - Phishing  
   T1566.001 - Spearphishing Attachment  

**Execution - TA0002**  
 T1047 - Windows Management Instrumentation  
   T1059.001 - PowerShell  

**Persistence - TA0003**  
   T1546.003 - Windows Management Instrumentation Event Subscription  

#### Mitigations:

**M1017:**  User Training - Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction.  
**M1018:**  User Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.  
**M1021:**  Restrict Web-Based Content - Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc.  
**M1022:**  Restrict File and Directory Permissions - Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.  
**M1026:**  Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.  
**M1028:**  Operating System Configuration - Make configuration changes related to the operating system or a common feature of the operating system that result in system hardening against techniques.  
**M1031:**  Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  
**M1033:**  Limit Software Installation - Block users or groups from installing unapproved software.  
**M1035:**  Limit Access to Resource Over Network - Prevent access to file shares, remote access to systems, unnecessary services. Mechanisms to limit access may include use of network concentrators, RDP gateways, etc.  
**M1038:**  Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
**M1040:**  Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
**M1042:**  Disable or Remove Feature or Program - Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.  
**M1045:**  Code Signing - Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.  
**M1047:**  Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
**M1049:**  Antivirus/Antimalware - Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software.  
**M1051:**  Update Software - Perform regular software updates to mitigate exploitation risk.  
**M1052:**  User Account Control - Configure Windows User Account Control to mitigate risk of adversaries obtaining elevated process access.  
**M1054:**  Software Configuration - Implement configuration changes to software (other than the operating system) to mitigate security risks associated to how the software operates.

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Service NSW Breach Report
Breach / Leak Notification: A breach report from Service NSW (Australia) discloses that an attack on Service NSW email accounts resulted in attackers obtaining 3.8 million documents, in total, 738 gigabytes of data.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Service NSW Breach Report
Breach / Leak Notification: A breach report from Service NSW (Australia) discloses that an attack on Service NSW email accounts resulted in attackers obtaining 3.8 million documents, in total, 738 gigabytes of data.

# Threat Type

  * Breach/Leak 




# Overview

  
"Service NSW is in the final stages of analysis into the cyber attack earlier this year on 47 staff email accounts and we're now working to notify customers who had personal information in the breach. The investigation has taken 4 months and required a highly technical approach to identify the exact amount of customer information in the 3.8 million documents (738 gigabytes of data) stolen from the email accounts. This rigorous first step surfaced about 500,000 documents which referenced personal information."

# Reference

  * <https://www.service.nsw.gov.au/cyber-incident>

parsed_raw_data.xfe_q:
Service NSW Breach Report
Breach / Leak Notification: A breach report from Service NSW (Australia) discloses that an attack on Service NSW email accounts resulted in attackers obtaining 3.8 million documents, in total, 738 gigabytes of data.
parsed_raw_data.xfe_report:

  * Breach/Leak 




# Overview

  
"Service NSW is in the final stages of analysis into the cyber attack earlier this year on 47 staff email accounts and we're now working to notify customers who had personal information in the breach. The investigation has taken 4 months and required a highly technical approach to identify the exact amount of customer information in the 3.8 million documents (738 gigabytes of data) stolen from the email accounts. This rigorous first step surfaced about 500,000 documents which referenced personal information."

# Reference

  * <https://www.service.nsw.gov.au/cyber-incident>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: HTML Attachment Phishing Email
A phishing email containing no content except an HTML attachment was detected and analyzed by Cofense researchers.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Phishing



# Overview

Cofense published a blog post analyzing a phishing email using only an HTML attachment as a lure. The email was sent free a SendGrid SMTP relay, which decreases its chances of being blocked by secure email gateways due to legitimate uses of the service. The email body contains no content with only an HTML file attached. Opening the HTML file displays a page using both Sharepoint and OneDrive branding. Links to view or download a business-related PDF file are provided. Both links lead to a pop-ip login page requesting an email and password. If credentials are entered, the data is exfiltrated to the attacker; meanwhile, the victim is redirected to a legitimate PDF with a name matching the one listed on the phishing page. For more information, see the Cofense blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://cofense.com/blog/html-phishing-email/>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Cracked Software Being Used as Victim Bait
A report from Sophos looks at the techniques used by some Malware as a Service (MaaS) offerings that provide droppers capable of delivering multiple different payloads.
output:
# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Malware
  *  **Targets:** Users searching for cracked software
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** Multiple
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** User execution of downloaded dropper
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Multiple
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See Mitre Attack Framework below.



# Overview

Users searching for cracked software are the targets of some Malware as a Service (MaaS) offerings that provide droppers that deliver multiple payloads. SEO techniques are used to promote links in search results that point to a bait page, the bait pages have typically been hosted on WordPress sites. The bait pages have a download button for the cracked software the victim was seeking. If the button is clicked, the request is passed through intermediary sites which carry out a number of checks such as operating system and geolocation are carried out, with the victim finally being provided a download link which leads to the dropper. The dropper is usually contained in a password-protected .zip file which is contained in another .zip file along with a text file that contains the password to decrypt the dropper .zip file. The droppers can deliver multiple payloads which Sophos have observed to include clickfraud bots, cryptomminers, information stealers, and the Conti and STOP ransomware. Further information is available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/64127095/Cracked%20Software%20Being%20Used%20as%20Victim%20Bait%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1630551629183&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Restrict Web-Based Content (M1021).



# References

  * <https://news.sophos.com/en-us/2021/09/01/fake-pirated-software-sites-serve-up-malware-droppers-as-a-service/>



# Mitre ATT&CK Framework

 **Credential Access - TA0006**  
T1539 - Steal Web Session Cookie  
T1555 - Credentials from Password Stores  
T1555.003 - Credentials from Web Browsers  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1027 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
  
 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1583 - Acquire Infrastructure  
T1583.004 - Server  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1204 - User Execution  
T1204.001 - Malicious Link  
T1204.002 - Malicious File

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: New Version of Stantinko’s Linux Proxy
Santinko has been tied to a Linux Trojan proxy primarily used to build adware and coin-miner botnets. Intezer has identified a new version of this malware that contains minor improvements.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Proxy




# Overview

Intezer has published their analysis of the most recent Santinko Linux proxy malware. This proxy malware is installed on Linux servers and masquerades as httpd. Once on the system, a configuration file delivered with the malware is used to install the malware. It is then daemonized in order to establish persistence. A socket and listener are created for the incoming connections. It is believed that the proxy hosts communicating with the victim host are previous victims of the same malware. A GET request to the C2 address will result in an HTTP redirect, misleading researchers by sending them to a benign URL. A POST or NOTIFY request, however, will result in sent data being proxied to the C2 server. Several possible C2 paths can be contacted, likely each delivering a different payload. The C2 server's response is also proxied through the designated proxy host before being sent to the victim host. Compared to the previous version of the malware, this version uses a configuration file instead of hardcoding the C2 address, uses dynamic linking, and solely functions as a proxy. For more information, see the Intezer blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.



# Reference

  * <https://www.intezer.com/blog/research/stantinkos-proxy-after-your-apache-server/>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Electric Company in Texas Being Used by Scammers
In an effort to intimidate customers of Austin Energy, scammers are using threatening phone calls to intimidate the customers into paying a non-existent bill with payment cards. Bleeping Computer and Austin Energy have both reported on these efforts.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Phishing




# Overview

A Texas utility company's customers are being targeted by scammers in an effort to obtain money. The scammers telephone customers and warn them their utilities will be disconnected unless they make an immediate payment using reloadable debit cards or other non-traceable forms of payment. This type of request is common amongst scammers seeking quick financial gain. A large winter storm across the state seems to be the catalyst behind this scam. The Austin Energy company released a statement via Twitter advising customers on policy and protective measures. For more information, see the links located within the Reference section below. 

# CVEs

  * N/A




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.

  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.

  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.

  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.

  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.




# Reference

  * <https://www.bleepingcomputer.com/news/security/texas-electric-company-warns-of-scammers-threatening-to-cut-power/>

  * [https://twitter.com/austinenergy/status/1363918887646019584](https://twitter\[.\]com/austinenergy/status/1363918887646019584)
  * <https://austinenergy.com/ae/residential/report-a-problem/report-telephone-scams>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Exploiting COVID-19: Using Multiple Email Providers
The exploitation of the current COVID–19 health crisis continues across all sectors, according to the Cofense Phishing Defense Center team.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Exploiting COVID-19: Using Multiple Email Providers
The exploitation of the current COVID–19 health crisis continues across all sectors, according to the Cofense Phishing Defense Center team.

# Threat Type

  * Phishing




# Overview

According to the Cofense Phishing Defense Center (PDC) team, threat actors continue to exploit the current COVID-19 pandemic in order to initiate phishing attacks. Researchers assessed these key components, amongst others, allowing success for threat actors: the exploitation of the pandemic and cogent aesthetics to bait targets. A tactic often seen is the use of duplicate Dropbox landing pages that require victims to login in order to view crucial documentation relating to COVID–19. The threat actors provide fake login pages to the victim for a number of popular email services. The harvested credentials are stored in a database via HTTP POST to a PHP script, victims are redirected to a legitimate webpage unconnected to COVID-19. For more information, see the Cofense blog post in the Reference section.  


# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://cofense.com/exploiting-the-current-covid-19-health-crisis-through-multiple-email-providers/>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Credential Stealing Malware Uses AHK
A credential stealing campaign that mainly uses AHK, an open-source scripting language, has been reported by Trend Micro. The campaign began in early 2020 and has mainly targeted the customers of Canadian and U.S. banks.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware




# Overview

Trend Micro discovered a credential stealing campaign that began in early 2020. The campaign has mainly targeted the customers of Canadian and U.S. banks. A malicious Excel file is used to kick off the infection chain by using a VBA AutoOpen macro to drop an AHK script compiler and an AHK script file. AHK is an open-source scripting language that runs on Windows. When the compiler is executed, it runs the script which is a client for downloading and executing further AHK payloads. It is also used for creating persistence by creating an autorun link in the startup folder and profiling the victim system. Commands issued to the malware by its C&C server are downloaded as individual scripts for each task. This means there is no single, large payload on the victim system and allows the operator to create custom commands for victims as required. The malware's primary function is to steal credentials from victims' browsers. The browsers it targets include Edge, Internet Explorer, Chrome, Firefox, and Opera. Further information is available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.trendmicro.com/en_us/research/20/l/stealth-credential-stealer-targets-us-canadian-bank-customers.html>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Android Trojan Targets Banking Users In Malaysia
A blog post from Cyble analyzes a banking Trojan specifically targeting users in Malaysia in an attempt to steal SMS messages and online banking credentials.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Android banking Trojan 
  * **Associated Threat Actors:** Unknown
  *  **Associated Payloads:** Malicious APK
  *  **Targets:** Malaysian banking users
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Fake "Cleaning Service Malaysia" app
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Credential theft, SMS stealing



# Overview

Cyble published a blog post analyzing a banking Trojan targeting Malaysian users. The malware masquerades as an Android booking application for a Malaysian cleaning company. Once on the device various intrusive permissions are requested, with the RECEIVE_SMS permissions being heavily abused in particular. The payload abuses this permission to listen for incoming messages and upload any that are received to a C2 server. Additionally, the fake application is designed to steal victim data. It uses the cleaner booking application theme to request payment details, specifically via online banking. Navigating to the payment screen provides victims with a list of Malaysian banks to choose from. Selecting a bank then leads to a fake version of its login page. Any entered credentials are subsequently exfiltrated to the attacker. For more information, see the Cyble blog post in the References section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/74055785/Android%20Trojan%20Targets%20Banking%20Users%20In%20Malaysia%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1638820789074&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Install security updates (M1001).
  * Users should be encouraged to only install apps from authorized app stores, which are less likely to contain malicious repackaged apps (M1011).
  * Implement an enterprise mobility management (EMM), also known as mobile device management (MDM) (M1012).
  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques (M1017).
  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.



# References

  * <https://blog.cyble.com/2021/12/01/banking-trojan-targets-banking-users-in-malaysia/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Initial Access - TA0027**  
T1444 - Masquerade as Legitimate Application  
T1476 - Deliver Malicious App via Other Means  
  
 **Execution - TA0041**  
T1575 - Native Code  
  
 **Persistence - TA0028**  
T1402 - Broadcast Receivers  
  
 **Credential Access - TA0031**  
T1411 - Input Prompt  
  
 **Collection - TA0035**  
T1412 - Capture SMS Messages  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0036**  
T1437 - Standard Application Layer Protocol  
  
 **Impact - TA0034**  
T1400 - Modify System Partition

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: WatchDog Mimicking TeamTNT TTPs
The WatchDog group appears to be expanding its cryptojacking operations while mimicking tactics, techniques, and procedures (TTPs) associated with TeamTNT. Palo Alto published a blog post detailing their findings on these TTPs and indicator overlap.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Cryptojacking
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** WatchDog
  *  **Associated Payloads:** Mining scripts
  *  **Targets:** Unknown
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Unknown
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Cryptomining



# Overview

Palo Alto published a blog post analyzing WatchDog's cryptojacking campaigns and their ties to TeamTNT. Their analysis begins with new WatchDog scripts that replace known WatchDog C2 addresses with new infrastructure. Notably, one of these samples also includes a TeamTNT email address alongside known WatchDog wallet addresses. The mining pools leveraged have been used by WatchDog in previous campaigns, whereas TeamTNT has used a different mining pool historically. Several other ties to TeamTNT were discovered, such as shared hosting infrastructure and lookalike domains. One of the scripts used by WatchDog was also discovered within a known TeamTNT malware repository. While some TTPs were mimicked, newer TeamTNT TTPs were not observed in use in the WatchDog scripts, such as container targeting, credential exfiltration, and network scanning using zgrab. Another notable change is WatchDog is no longer using their GoLang binaries in these scripts. The Palo Alto researchers believe that WatchDog is purposely mimicking TeamTNT in these new operations to avoid attribution. For more information, see the Palo Alto blog post in the References section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/68617152/WatchDog%20Mimicking%20TeamTNT%20TTPs%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1635781955558&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).



# References

  * <https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/teamtnt-cryptojacking-watchdog-operations/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
T1059.004 - Unix Shell  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1057 - Process Discovery  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
T1071.001 - Web Protocols  
  
 **Impact - TA0040**  
T1496 - Resource Hijacking

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Mac Malware Bypassing Security Checks
Protective measures put into place by Apple have been circumvented by threat actors. In a blog post, researcher Patrick Wardle of Objective-See reports on the ability for threat actors to bypass notary functionality on the Mac OSX operating system.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Mac Malware Bypassing Security Checks
Protective measures put into place by Apple have been circumvented by threat actors. In a blog post, researcher Patrick Wardle of Objective-See reports on the ability for threat actors to bypass notary functionality on the Mac OSX operating system.

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Adware




# Overview

What was formerly a problem not likely to rear its head in an Apple environment has become more and more common. Threats to macOS have begun an uptick in activity as threat actors look to expand their footprint into the Apple arena. Apple has responded, in kind, by introducing protective measures for its operating system. One such protective measure is the notarization of code by Apple after scanning software for malicious content. If software is not notarized by Apple, the OS will not allow the software to be installed on the system. The latest development in this "good vs. evil" cat and mouse game is the successful circumvention of the notarization process. Using an URL closely resembling the legitimate brew.sh, an active adware campaign is being employed. The website homebrew.sh is the culprit of this adware campaign and could easily be mistaken for the legitimate website due to the name "homebrew.sh" identifying the name of the brew service, thus making it likely to be mistakenly visited. Should a visitor connect to the "homebrew.sh" site, the user is redirected to an update for Adobe Flash Player. In this instance, the adware payloads were fully notarized. Containing the spctl command indicates the code has passed the notarization process. By submitting the application to Apple, they were scanned, approved, and notarized. These payloads are now able to run on macOS versions as recent as "Big Sur." The malware being employed in this campaign is the OSX.Shlayer malware. Although exceedingly common, the malware poses a significant risk to macOS users. This malware has the ability to download and install, with persistence, various macOS adware, including the Bundlore adware. Once the malicious payloads were identified and reported to Apple, the certificates were revoked and notarization status was rescinded. However, on August 28, 2020, the campaign was still live and serving new adware, which is still notarized. Further details can be found in the blog located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.

  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.

  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.

  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.

  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.




# Reference

  * <https://objective-see.com/blog/blog_0x4E.html>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Skimmers Being Spread By Cloud Video Platform
Palo Alto has published a report analyzing a skimmer that is being hosted by a cloud video platform. When the video is used by a site, it becomes infected with the skimmer. The skimmer is currently affecting over 100 real estate websites.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Skimmers Being Spread By Cloud Video Platform
Palo Alto has published a report analyzing a skimmer that is being hosted by a cloud video platform. When the video is used by a site, it becomes infected with the skimmer. The skimmer is currently affecting over 100 real estate websites.

# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Skimmer
  *  **Targets:** Real Estate Sites
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** Unknown **  
**
  * **Initial Infection Vector:** Supply Chain Attack
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Personal Information Theft
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

Palo Alto researchers have discovered a skimmer attack that is affecting over 100 real estate sites. They have determined that the source of this attack was a supply chain attack, where the attackers have leveraged a cloud video platform to allow them to reach a greater number of victims. The attackers injected malicious JavaScript into a specific video hosted on the cloud platform. Any site importing this video will also be infected, without the attackers having to perform any further attacks. The researchers also observed the attackers modify the script and re-upload it, which was then propagated to all previously infected sites. This is far more efficient than manually updating the skimmer on each site. The researchers retrieved the code from a compromised site and found that it was highly obfuscated to deter manual code analysis. Furthermore, the script includes code to detect if the code is being debugged and stops if the browser console is open. The end goal of this script is to steal any entered personal details such as names, emails, phone numbers, and credit card details and send them to a collection server. Further information is available from the report linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/74056799/Skimmers%20Being%20Spread%20By%20Cloud%20Video%20Platform%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1641899384488&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Restrict Web-Based Content (M1021)
  * Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior (M1040). 
  * Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking (M1038). 



# References

  * <https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/web-skimmer-video-distribution/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1584 - Compromise Infrastructure  
T1584.006 - Web Services  
T1587 - Develop Capabilities  
T1587.001 - Malware  
  
 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1195 - Supply Chain Compromise  
T1195.002 - Compromise Software Supply Chain  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
T1059.007 - JavaScript  
  
 **Credential Access - TA0006**  
T1056 - Input Capture  
T1056.003 - Web Portal Capture

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: New NOBELIUM Backdoor - FoggyWeb
A report from Microsoft provides an analysis of a newly discovered backdoor used by NOBELIUM that Microsoft has named FoggyWeb.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: New NOBELIUM Backdoor - FoggyWeb
A report from Microsoft provides an analysis of a newly discovered backdoor used by NOBELIUM that Microsoft has named FoggyWeb.

# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Backdoor
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** NOBELIUM, ITG11
  *  **Associated Payloads:** FoggyWeb
  *  **Targets:** Compromised Active Directory Federation Services (AD FS) servers.
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** FoggyWeb is a post-exploitation tool.
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Deploy FoggyWeb, Collect and Exfiltrate data.
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

NOBELIUM is a threat actor known by many names including APT29, Cozy Bear, CozyDuke, Cozys, Dark Halo, Duke Group, Hammertoss, Minis, Office Monkeys, Pitty Tiger, Spikerrush, StellarParticle, TEMP.Monkey, TEMP.Noble, The Dukes, TG-4127, UNC2452, and Yttrium. IBM X-Force tracks NOBELIUM as Hive0099. A report from Microsoft provides an analysis of a new backdoor which Microsoft has named FoggyWeb that has been used by NOBELIUM since at least April 2021. It is a passive backdoor that is specifically targeted to Active Directory Federation Services (AD FS) servers. FoggyWeb is installed deployed on compromised AD FS servers by dropping two files onto the system. One file, a DLL is a loader that is executed by Microsoft.IdentityServer.ServiceHost.exe through search order hijacking. In turn, the loader is responsible for decrypting and loading the second of the two files which is the FoggyWeb backdoor. Once active, FoggyWeb configures HTTP listeners that listen for specific URIs defined by the actor. These specific URIs are what provide instructions to the backdoor. FoggyWeb is used to collect and exfiltrate data from the infected server and can install additional payloads. 

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/64129463/New%20NOBELIUM%20Backdoor%20-%20FoggyWeb%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1633403936443&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Restrict Web-Based Content (M1021).



# References

  * <https://www.microsoft.com/security/blog/2021/09/27/foggyweb-targeted-nobelium-malware-leads-to-persistent-backdoor/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Persistence - TA0003**  
T1574 - Hijack Execution Flow  
T1574.001 - DLL Search Order Hijacking  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1027 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
T1140 - Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information  
T1574 - Hijack Execution Flow  
T1574.001 - DLL Search Order Hijacking  
  
 **Collection - TA0009**  
T1005 - Data from Local System  
T1074 - Data Staged  
T1074.001 - Local Data Staging  
T1560 - Archive Collected Data  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0010**  
T1041 - Exfiltration Over C2 Channel  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1001 - Data Obfuscation  
T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
T1071.001 - Web Protocols

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: IBM Security Family PAM Content Update 4009.22112
PAM update 4009.22112 contains 1 new events, 0 new moderate event responses, and 0 new aggressive event responses.

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability, XPU



# Overview

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Mirai Variant Exploiting Realtek SDK Vulnerability
A posting on the SAM blog reports that a Mirai variant is exploiting a recently disclosed vulnerability in the Realtek SDK that is used in devices from more than sixty-five vendors.
output:
# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Malware, Botnet
  *  **Targets:** Mainly domestic devices such as routers
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** Mirai
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Vulnerability in the device web interface
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Unknown
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See Mitre ATT&CK Framework below



# Overview

According to SAM, within two days of vulnerabilities in a Realtek SDK being disclosed, an attacker had created a Mirai variant that exploited one of the vulnerabilities. The vulnerability (CVE-2021-35395) can be exploited, without authentication, through the web interface of an affected device. Successfully exploited, an attacker can execute arbitrary code with the highest level of privilege. The SAM report notes that two weeks prior, the same attacker weaponised another vulnerability (CVE-2021-20090) within two days of disclosure. Further information is available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/62358010/Mirai%20Variant%20Exploiting%20Realtek%20SDK%20Vulnerability%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1629956853387&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Restrict Web-Based Content (M1021).



# References

  * <https://securingsam.com/realtek-vulnerabilities-weaponized/>



# Mitre ATT&CK Framework

 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1587 - Develop Capabilities  
T1587.001 - Malware  
  
 **Reconnaissance - TA0043**  
T1595 - Active Scanning  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
T1059.004 - Unix Shell  
  
 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Unsecured AWS Bucket Reveals 39 Million Records
Breach/Leak Notification: An online marketing company's database was left unsecured on an AWS server. CyberNews reveals the discovery of the records and the potential implications of the unsecured data.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Unsecured AWS Bucket Reveals 39 Million Records
Breach/Leak Notification: An online marketing company's database was left unsecured on an AWS server. CyberNews reveals the discovery of the records and the potential implications of the unsecured data.

# Threat Type

  * Leak




# Overview

The CyberNews research team uncovered an unsecured data bucket containing a database within an AWS server. The database belongs to a marketing firm, View Media. On July 29, Amazon closed the bucket and the data is no longer visible. Within the bucket were 700 statements of work for email and direct mail campaigns, along with 59 CSV and XLS files containing nearly 39 million records of U.S. citizens. About 2/3 of those records were unique. This information could later be used for targeting of potential victims in later scam attempts such as phishing, spam attacks, and identity fraud. "On August 24, we contacted View Media for an official comment regarding the leak. However, we received no response from the company." Further details can be found in the article located within the Reference section below.

# CVEs

  * N/A




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://cybernews.com/security/online-marketing-company-exposes-data-of-millions-americans/>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Ransomware Drove Public Data Breaches in 2020
IBM X-force Threat Intelligence has published a brief report following up on findings from the 2020 Threat Index related to public data breaches.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Ransomware Drove Public Data Breaches in 2020
IBM X-force Threat Intelligence has published a brief report following up on findings from the 2020 Threat Index related to public data breaches.

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

 Public breach data reveals several telling trends for 2020. First, ransomware attacks drove data breaches, making up 36% of data breaches as ransomware attackers incorporate data theft and leaks into their arsenal. In addition, manufacturing, government, and media/telecommunications appeared to be hit hardest by data breaches in 2020. Lastly, data breaches in 2020 appeared to peak in March, suggesting that breach trends may be loosely connected to COVID-19 pandemic trends as many organizations made abrupt changes to operations in March 2020. The full story and analysis is available to IBM X-Force Premier Threat Intelligence clients at the link below.

# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.




# Reference

  * Premier Threat Intelligence clients can read more at: <https://station.trustar.co/constellation/reports/f62b5b9d-bddf-4a29-9fd9-864bc8f289b8>

  * To learn more about X-Force Premier Threat Intelligence, visit: <https://www.ibm.com/security/services/threat-intelligence>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: BazarBackdoor to Ryuk Ransomware to Cobalt Strike
Continuing its targeting of the healthcare system, Ryuk ransomware group "one" has been analyzed by AdvIntel in a blog post.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Ransomware




# Overview

AdvIntel has provided an exact attack kill-chain by Ryuk ransomware "one" group in a new report. Using BazarBackdoor and Cobalt Strike, the group behind this Ryuk ransomware distribution is mainly targeting the healthcare industry. The typical M.O. of this particular group is a ransom of an average of 48 Bitcoin but has been as high as 2,200 Bitcoin. Recent targets also include technology, energy, financial services, and government. The group favors pen testing tools such as Cobalt Strike beacons as an intermediary payload. Additionally, they employs Mimikatz, PowerShell PowerSploit, LaZagne, AdFind, Bloodhound, and PsExec. A 15-step attack profile is used after having pivoted from BazarBackdoor using Cobalt Strike. The group uses various tools to examine the domain, collect passwords, create tokens for administrative work, view the network, portscan, list accessible hosts, employ AdFind, search for A/V, password recovery, and other actions in order to more efficiently infect and encrypt the target. Further details can be found in the report located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * [https://www.advanced-intel.com/post/anatomy-of-attack-inside-bazarbackdoor-to-ryuk-ransomware-one-group-via-cobalt-strike](https://www.advanced-intel.com/post/anatomy-of-attack-inside-bazarbackdoor-to-ryuk-ransomware-one-group-via-cobalt-strike?s=09)
