instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Emotet Chronicles
Kaspersky has published a report chronicling what is known about Emotet malware.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Emotet Chronicles
Kaspersky has published a report chronicling what is known about Emotet malware.

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Trojan



# Overview

According to Kaspersky, Emotet was first discovered in June 2014 by Trend Micro. Emotet is a malware package designed to steal banking credentials. Initial targets were German and Austrian bank users. At that time, the infection vector was bank-related spam with either weaponized attachments or links to ZIP files with the loader install. November of that year saw additional modules added that could modify HTTP(s) traffic, collect Outlook email addresses, and steal credentials in Mail PassView, among others. December saw unresponsive command and control servers as attacks dropped off. The following January saw a public RSA key and encrypted embedded strings. Swiss bank clients were also added to the victim list. June 2015 saw the beginning of another shutdown of the command and control servers. December of 2016 saw a new outlook for Emotet with the ability to infect victims using the RIG-E and RIG-V exploit kits. In February 2017, it was discovered that Emotet had included a spam module in its tool set. Banking clients in Poland were added in April's spam emails. May saw a change in the spam attachment used in the attack. This was the first time a weaponized Microsoft Word document (or a link to one) required the victim to enable macros. It was also the first time that Emotet began installing the banking Trojan Qbot (or QakBot), although the number of installs were not numerous. June saw Emotet begin to use a network spreading technique to infect other systems on the local network. In July, Emotet changed from using GET requests to using POST requests. The list of brute-force passwords used significantly increased in August. IBM X-Force announced in November that Emotet was now spreading IcedID. In January of 2018, Emotet began installing the banking Trojan Panda (also known as Zeus Panda). In April, Emotet added a module to spread laterally over wireless networks. In June, Emotet began a relationship with Trickbot (also known as Trickster). The ability to access computers behind NAT and convert them into command and control proxies was added in July. Installing Ryuk by Emotet began in August. October saw a brief suspension of command and control servers as well as an update to the Outlook exfiltration module. Another suspension of command and control servers began in November with a resumption beginning in January of 2019. March saw modifications to the HTTP protocol used in command and control communication. In April, data exfiltration (topics, mailing lists, message contents) began showing up in Emotet spam emails. From May until August, command and control servers went down once more. In November and February, additional minor changes were made to the headers in the HTTP protocol. Infections declined in February, not to resume until July. After starting back up in July, public reports indicated that the links in the spam emails were replaced with benign images and memes instead of the malicious Emotet payload. In a few days, this issue was corrected and Emotet began flowing again. For full details on the Emotet history, please refer to the link in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/35717728/Emotet%20Chronicles%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1607375773201&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://securelist.com/the-chronicles-of-emotet/99660/>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: More Joker Infected Apps in Google Play Store
Given the continued infection of legitimate apps and inclusion of malware within malicious apps, Zscaler has provided further updates on apps available or formerly available on the Google Play store.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: More Joker Infected Apps in Google Play Store
Given the continued infection of legitimate apps and inclusion of malware within malicious apps, Zscaler has provided further updates on apps available or formerly available on the Google Play store.

# Threat Type

  * Malware




# Overview

The Google Play store continues to be inundated with malicious apps infected with Joker. Google Security has taken necessary steps to remove any identified malicious apps from its store. With its latest update, Zscaler has identified 17 different samples uploaded in September 2020. These apps, according to the researchers, have been downloaded about 120,000 times. The subject of the report centers around how Joker-infected apps are able to circumvent the vetting processes in place for the Play Store. In some instances, the payload is delivered by direct URL from the C2 server. The string containing the URL is obfuscated and hidden, thus giving the actors a leg up in the vetting process. Upon installation, the app contacts the C2 server and receives the URL for final payload. The JSON file has class name information needed to be executed from the payload for malicious activity execution. Other apps use a stager payload that is encoded into the app's code using AES encryption. The stager payload is delivered rather than the final payload and then downloads the final payload from a URL within the stager and executes it. In a few cases, the final payload URL is seen in plaintext. The last method involves a two-stage download. These apps used an infected app to contact a C2 for a stage one payload URL hidden within the response to the request. This URL then downloads stage two, which loads the end result of the Joker malware. In each of these differing types of download, the final result is the Joker infection of the target device. With the Joker installed, the operator has the ability to harvest SMS and WAP fraud, as seen with previous Joker infections. Further information can be found in the report located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.zscaler.com/blogs/security-research/joker-playing-hide-and-seek-google-play>

  * <https://www.anquanke.com/post/id/211978>
  * [https://twitter.com/ReBensk](https://twitter\[.\]com/ReBensk)

# Overview

The Google Play store continues to be inundated with malicious apps infected with Joker. Google Security has taken necessary steps to remove any identified malicious apps from its store. With its latest update, Zscaler has identified 17 different samples uploaded in September 2020. These apps, according to the researchers, have been downloaded about 120,000 times. The subject of the report centers around how Joker-infected apps are able to circumvent the vetting processes in place for the Play Store. In some instances, the payload is delivered by direct URL from the C2 server. The string containing the URL is obfuscated and hidden, thus giving the actors a leg up in the vetting process. Upon installation, the app contacts the C2 server and receives the URL for final payload. The JSON file has class name information needed to be executed from the payload for malicious activity execution. Other apps use a stager payload that is encoded into the app's code using AES encryption. The stager payload is delivered rather than the final payload and then downloads the final payload from a URL within the stager and executes it. In a few cases, the final payload URL is seen in plaintext. The last method involves a two-stage download. These apps used an infected app to contact a C2 for a stage one payload URL hidden within the response to the request. This URL then downloads stage two, which loads the end result of the Joker malware. In each of these differing types of download, the final result is the Joker infection of the target device. With the Joker installed, the operator has the ability to harvest SMS and WAP fraud, as seen with previous Joker infections. Further information can be found in the report located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.zscaler.com/blogs/security-research/joker-playing-hide-and-seek-google-play>

  * <https://www.anquanke.com/post/id/211978>
  * [https://twitter.com/ReBensk](https://twitter\[.\]com/ReBensk)

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Android Flubot Smishing Campaigns
A posting to the Deutsche Telekom blog provides information on how Android Flubot smishing campaigns operate.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Android Flubot Smishing Campaigns
A posting to the Deutsche Telekom blog provides information on how Android Flubot smishing campaigns operate.

# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Smishing
  *  **Target:** Android devices
  *  **Lure:** Various missed calls or notifications from carriers and well-recognized services.
  *  **Payload:** Fluebot or Teabot
  *  **TTPs:** See MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.
  *  **Post-compromise Actions:** Data exfiltration, Spreading of malware.



# Overview

Flubot is Android malware that emerged in 2020. A posting to the Deutsche Telekom blog provides an analysis of a Flubot smishing campaign. Flubot is spread using SMS messages sent to contacts obtained from infected devices. A victim receives an SMS message from someone they know and provides a link. In the recent cases observed by Deutsche Telekom, the SMS messages claimed to be a missed call notification or a notification from DHL. In the past, Flubot campaigns are known to have used other brands such as FedEx and Correos in their SMS messages. Through compromised sites (frequently WordPress blogs) that host redirects, the link in the message leads to a site themed to the service or brand being used in the lure which tells the need victim they need to download and install an app to access the missed call or notification, etc. The theme and lure changed every month or so. The names of the APK files are also changed at certain intervals and hashes of the APK's change frequently. The links are generated per victim and a number of techniques are used to bypass a carrier's SMS content filters. One interesting technique used by Flubot to spread to other countries is having infected devices in one country and sending SMS messages to a neighboring country, in the neighboring countries language. In some cases, the payload distributed in the campaigns is Teabot. Further information is available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/64128051/Android%20Flubot%20Smishing%20Campaigns%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1632111685736&api=v2)



# Detection

  * A Yara rule can be found here: [ Yara Rule.txt](/download/attachments/64128051/Android%20Flubot%20Smishing%20Campaigns%20Yara%20Rule.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1632111698618&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Exercise caution with links in SMS messages.



# References

  * <https://www.telekom.com/en/blog/group/article/flubot-under-the-microscope-636368>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework (Mobile)

 **Initial Access TA0027**  
Deliver Malicious App via Other Means T1476

 **Defense Evasion TA0030**  
Evade Analysis Environment T1523  
Geofencing T1581  
Masquerade as Legitimate Application T1444  
Obfuscated Files or Information T1406

 **Credential Access TA0031**  
Capture SMS Messages T1412  
  
**Discovery TA0032**  
Application Discovery T1418

 **Collection TA0035**  
Access Contact List T1432  
Capture SMS Messages T1412

 **Command and Control TA0037**  
Alternate Network Mediums T1438  
Standard Application Layer Protocol T1437  
Standard Cryptographic Protocol T1521

 **Exfiltration TA0036**  
Alternate Network Mediums T1438  
Commonly Used Port T1436  
Data Encrypted T1532  
Standard Application Layer Protocol T1437

 **Impact TA0034**  
SMS Control T1582

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: The Warzone RAT and Confucius Campaign
Quickheal has published a report on the infection chain and malware used in a campaign attributed to the South Asian APT group named Confucius.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware




# Overview

A campaign that Quickheal attributes to the South Asian APT group named Confucius has been distributing the Warzone RAT. A weaponized Word .docx file that uses template injection to download the next stage which attempts to exploit an older Office vulnerability, CVE-2017-11882. If exploitation is successful, the Warzone RAT is installed. Warzone RAT was discovered being distributed as a malware-as-a-service offering in 2018. Quickheal notes in its report that a 'cracked' version of Warzone is available from a GitHub repository. Warzone is advertised as being able to bypass UAC to elevate privileges, bypass Windows Defender, log keystrokes, execute a remote shell, achieve persistence, provide an RDP connection, access a device's webcam, and download and execute files. While the Quickheal report does not specifically state the weaponized .docx file is delivered via email, it does note that this is a typical delivery mechanism. Further details are available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://blogs.quickheal.com/warzone-rat-beware-of-the-trojan-malware-stealing-data-triggering-from-various-office-documents/>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Malicious Actors Target Crypto Wallets of Coinbase Users in New Phishing Campaign
A phishing campaign detected by Bitdefender is targeting Coinbase users in order to empty cryptocurrency wallets.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Malicious Actors Target Crypto Wallets of Coinbase Users in New Phishing Campaign
A phishing campaign detected by Bitdefender is targeting Coinbase users in order to empty cryptocurrency wallets.

# Threat Type

  * Phishing




# Overview

Bitdefender published a brief blog post on a recent phishing campaign targeting Coinbase users. The source and destination of the emails varies, but the majority originated from India with the largest destination being South Korea. The body and subject of the email claim that the recipient's Coinbase account was suspended due to suspicious activity and that they need to sign in to verify their account. The email and landing page use Coinbase branding in order to increase the legitimacy of the content. If the user provides their credentials, the data is exfiltrated to the attacker who can then use the information to steal their cryptocurrency. For more information, see the Bitdefender blog post in the Reference section.

# Recommendations

  * Review source article for full details.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://hotforsecurity.bitdefender.com/blog/malicious-actors-target-crypto-wallets-of-coinbase-users-in-new-phishing-campaign-25445.html>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: New BotenaGo Variant Threatening IoT Camera Devices
Nozomi Networks Labs has discovered a new variant of the BotenaGo Malware. This malware puts millions of IoT devices at risk of potential cyberattacks, and the new variant specifically targets Lilin security camera DVR devices.
output:
# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Botnet
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Unknown
  *  **Associated Payloads:** Mirai, BotenaGo, Lillin Scanner
  *  **Targets:** Lilin Security Camera DVR Devices
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Default Accounts
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Botnet Download



# Overview

Nozomi Networks Labs has published details on a new variant of BotenaGo. This variant is built to specifically target Lilin security camera DVR devices and has been named "Lillin Scanner". This sample was not detected as malware by any detection engines as the portion of the malicious code is quite small and focuses on a single task. Current reporting indicates that the original code containing over 30 exploits had been removed. The scanner receives IP addresses to scan and attempts to use hardcoded user-password pairs to try and authenticate with the target in order to exploit for remote code execution. The vulnerability used was discovered in 2020 and has since been patched by the vendor. The attack downloads a malicious file and executes it to download several executables for multiple architectures. The executables are part of the Mirai malware family, which appears to be the goal of the attack. For more details, please see the link in the reference section

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

For a full list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.

# References

  * <https://securityboulevard.com/2022/04/new-botenago-variant-discovered-by-nozomi-networks-labs/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1587.001 - Malware  
T1608.001 - Upload Malware  
  
 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1078.001 - Default Accounts  
T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059.004 - Unix Shell  
  
 **Privilege Escalation - TA0004**  
T1068 - Exploitation for Privilege Escalation  
T1078.001 - Default Accounts  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1082 - System Information Discovery  
T1518 - Software Discovery  
  
 **Collection - TA0009**  
T1005 - Data from Local System  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0010**  
T1041 - Exfiltration Over C2 Channel  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
  


#### Mitigations:

  
 **M1013:** Application Developer Guidance: This mitigation describes any guidance or training given to developers of applications to avoid introducing security weaknesses that an adversary may be able to take advantage of.  
 **M1016:** Vulnerability Scanning - Vulnerability scanning is used to find potentially exploitable software vulnerabilities to remediate them.  
 **M1017:** User Training - Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction.  
 **M1018:** User Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.  
 **M1019:** Threat Intelligence Program - A threat intelligence program helps an organization generate their own threat intelligence information and track trends to inform defensive priorities to mitigate risk.  
 **M1021:** Restrict Web-Based Content - Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc.  
 **M1026:** Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.  
 **M1027:** Password Policies - Set and enforce secure password policies for accounts.  
 **M1030:** Network Segmentation - Architect sections of the network to isolate critical systems, functions, or resources. Use physical and logical segmentation to prevent access to potentially sensitive systems and information. Use a DMZ to contain any internet-facing services that should not be exposed from the internal network. Configure separate virtual private cloud (VPC) instances to isolate critical cloud systems.  
 **M1031:** Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  
 **M1032:** Multi-factor Authentication - Use two or more pieces of evidence to authenticate to a system; such as username and password in addition to a token from a physical smart card or token generator.  
 **M1033:** Limit Software Installation - Block users or groups from installing unapproved software.  
 **M1037:** Filter Network Traffic - Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic.  
 **M1038:** Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
 **M1040:** Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
 **M1042:** Disable or Remove Feature or Program - Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.  
 **M1045:** Code Signing - Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.  
 **M1047:** Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
 **M1048:** Application Isolation and Sandboxing - Restrict execution of code to a virtual environment on or in transit to an endpoint system.  
 **M1049:** Antivirus/Antimalware - Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software.  
 **M1050:** Exploit Protection - Use capabilities to detect and block conditions that may lead to or be indicative of a software exploit occurring.  
 **M1051:** Update Software - Perform regular software updates to mitigate exploitation risk.  
 **M1056:** Pre-compromise - This category is used for any applicable mitigation activities that apply to techniques occurring before an adversary gains Initial Access, such as Reconnaissance and Resource Development techniques.  
 **M1057:** Data Loss Prevention - Use a data loss prevention (DLP) strategy to categorize sensitive data, identify data formats indicative of personal identifiable information (PII), and restrict exfiltration of sensitive data.

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: QNAPCrypt and SunCrypt Ransomware Connection
A report from Intezer provides an analysis of the connections between the QNAPCrypt and SunCrypt ransomware.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Ransomware




# Overview

Intezer has published a blog posting that provides an analysis of the connections between the QNAPCrypt and SunCrypt ransomware. SunCrypt is affiliate ransomware service while QNAPCrypt surfaced in 2019 and was used to target devices from QNAP and Synology. The analysis concludes that the current SunCrypt ransomware shares many similarities with QNAP. However, it appears that there are different, unrelated actors, behind the two ransomwares. Further information is available from the report linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.intezer.com/blog/malware-analysis/when-viruses-mutate-did-suncrypt-ransomware-evolve-from-qnapcrypt/>

parsed_raw_data.xfe_q:
QNAPCrypt and SunCrypt Ransomware Connection
A report from Intezer provides an analysis of the connections between the QNAPCrypt and SunCrypt ransomware.
parsed_raw_data.xfe_report:
# Threat Type

  * Malware, Ransomware




# Overview

Intezer has published a blog posting that provides an analysis of the connections between the QNAPCrypt and SunCrypt ransomware. SunCrypt is affiliate ransomware service while QNAPCrypt surfaced in 2019 and was used to target devices from QNAP and Synology. The analysis concludes that the current SunCrypt ransomware shares many similarities with QNAP. However, it appears that there are different, unrelated actors, behind the two ransomwares. Further information is available from the report linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.intezer.com/blog/malware-analysis/when-viruses-mutate-did-suncrypt-ransomware-evolve-from-qnapcrypt/>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Amnesty Report on FinSpy Activity
A report from Amnesty’s Security Lab provides an analysis of FinSpy samples that were located during investigations. The samples include FinSpy variants for Windows, Mac, Linux, and Android. The report also provides information on the capabilities of the NilePhish group who are known to distribute FinSpy.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware




# Overview

Amnesty’s Security Lab has been tracking FinSpy usage due to its use in a number of operations to spy on what Amnesty describe as Human Rights Defenders. FinSpy is commercial spyware developed by the German company FinFisher Gmbh. Amnesty has observed variants of FinSpy for Windows, Mac, Linux, and Android. In its report, Amnesty looks at the NilePhish group who developed several droppers which include a fake Flash Player updater, macro enabled Word documents, and a .NET application. Early in 2020, NilePhish began testing Cobalt Strike, using an obfuscated VB script for installation. The versions of FinSpy for Mac and Linux share very similar modules which Amnesty notes could indicate a shared codebase, the launchers and infection chain are modified for Linux. All versions are configurable and employ various techniques to hinder detection and analysis. Further information is available from Amnesty's report which is linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.amnesty.org/en/latest/research/2020/09/german-made-finspy-spyware-found-in-egypt-and-mac-and-linux-versions-revealed/>

  * <https://www.sentinelone.com/blog/how-to-catch-a-spy-detecting-finfisher-spyware-on-macos/>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Recent Sandworm Activity
Following up on ANSSI's research into recent Sandworm activity, DomainTools reports on their findings related to the infrastructure used by this threat actor.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware, APT




# Overview

DomainTools has published a report identifying Sandworm infrastructure discovered during their investigation into ANSSI's recent report on the threat group. ANSSI's report discussed the exploitation of Centreon to deliver Exaramel, a known Sandworm tool. The report, however, did not detail any network indicators associated with this activity, causing DomainTools to dig further. They began by looking at the Exim exploitation campaign that the NSA reported on as occurring during an overlapping time period with the Centreon activity. The NSA report provided a few network indicators, specifically two IP addresses and a domain. Pivoting to related domains and IP address resolutions led to several new addresses and domains used by the group. They also discovered a couple bash scripts leveraging this infrastructure for communication. These scripts created a new user and associated SSH configuration, executed Python code, and established persistence. Eventually a secondary payload could be executed, but researchers were unable to retrieve a sample. Subdomains tied to the discovered domains indicate that the infrastructure was also used to host credential phishing pages for mail and social media services. Ultimately, DomainTools was unable to identify infrastructure specifically associated with the Centreon activity described by ANSSI, but they we able to find previously unreported on Sandworm network indicators. For more information, see the DomainTools blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.



# Reference

  * <https://www.domaintools.com/resources/blog/centreon-to-exim-and-back-on-the-trail-of-sandworm>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: APT41 Back as Earth Baku and New Campaign
APT41 is back with a new name and cyberespionage campaign, according to a report from Trend Micro. Tracked by IBM as hive0088, this group is also known as Barium, Winnti, Wicked Panda, as well as other suspected names.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Cyberespionage




# Overview

APT41 has resurfaced as Earth Baku along with a new cyberespionage campaign. The campaign can be traced back as far as July 2020. Using attack vectors designed to exploit different infrastructures, the group is using SQL injection to upload malicious files, installing through InstallUtil.exe using a scheduled task, a possible malicious link file in an email attachment, and exploiting the ProxyLogon vulnerability (CVE-2021-26855) to upload the China Chopper web shell. In addition to the above, the campaign is using unidentified shellcode loaders named StealthVector and StealthMutant, as well as a backdoor called ScrambleCross. These tools, developed by Earth Baku, are used to facilitate targeted attacks on entities in specific industries within the Indo-Pacific region. Countries affected include India, Indonesia, Malaysia, the Philippines, Taiwan, and Vietnam. StealthVector is a shellcode loader designed to be configurable for the threat actor's needs including disabling Event Tracing for Windows allowing for stealth mode execution. StealthMutant uses AES-256-ECB for decryption, whereas an earlier version uses XOR. This allows StealthMutant to perform process hollowing for execution remotely. ScrambleCross is a newly discovered backdoor. Instructions are received from a C2 server that allows it to receive and change plug-ins. The researchers have yet to obtain a plug-in to study. In addition to the tools mentioned, both StealthVector and StealthMutant contain a payload for Cobalt Strike beacons. Further details can be found in the links located within the Reference section below as well as a MITRE ATT&CK framework table. 

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Restrict Web-Based Content (M1021).



# Reference

  * <https://www.trendmicro.com/en_us/research/21/h/apt41-resurfaces-as-earth-baku-with-new-cyberespionage-campaign.html>

  * <https://documents.trendmicro.com/assets/white_papers/wp-earth-baku-an-apt-group-targeting-indo-pacific-countries.pdf>



# Mitre ATT&CK Framework

 **Privilege Escalation - TA0004**  
T1053.005 - Scheduled Task  
T1055.012 - Process Hollowing  
T1574.002 - DLL Side-Loading  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1027 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
T1027.002 - Software Packing  
T1036.003 - Rename System Utilities  
T1218.004 - InstallUtil  
T1562.006 - Indicator Blocking  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059.003 - Windows Command Shell  
T1059.005 - Visual Basic  
T1569.002 - Service Execution  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1071.001 - Web Protocols  
T1071.004 - DNS  
T1090.004 - Domain Fronting  
T1105 - Ingress Tool Transfer  
T1573.001 - Symmetric Cryptography  
  
 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application  
T1566.001 - Spearphishing Attachment

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: New TrickBot Infection Chain
TrickBot is constantly evolving its techniques in order to evade detection. Most recently, Cofense observed the use of three new components to distribute its payload.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware




# Overview

Cofense published a blog post analyzing TrickBot's most recent infection chain. The campaign uses the common method of a Word document attachment to a generic email. However, instead of using macros to execute malicious code, the document exploits the CVE-2017-0199 vulnerability. Exploiting this vulnerability causes the document to call out to a DOT payload, which leverages a macro to save and execute a VBS script. After performing checks for analysis tools, the VBS script will download and execute the final payload, TrickBot, from a remote server. From this point, a typical TrickBot routine is carried out. C2 communication is established and additional modules to expand its functionality are downloaded. For more information, see the Cofense blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://cofense.com/blog/trickbot-june-debut/>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Targeted Phishing Attack against Ukrainian Government Expands to Georgia
Following up on previous reporting from Fortinet and Malwarebytes, Intezer details updates to malware used in a campaign targeting government agencies in the Ukraine and Georgia.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Infostealer




# Overview

Intezer published a blog post analyzing updates to a targeted phishing attack against the Ukrainian and Georgian governments. Government-related topics are used in emails with shortened links to entice victims into downloading malware. The shortened URLs redirect to a C2 server hosting a ZIP archive. Inside the ZIP archive was either an RTF, DOC, PDF, JS, LNK or EXE. The methodology for dropping the final payload depended on the file type leveraged. For example, the PDF leveraged an action object alongside a Google redirect, while the Word documents used malicious macros in combination with PowerShell and a Batch script to download the final payload. Regardless of the intermediary step, ultimately an AutoIt payload is executed in memory. Its purpose is search for specific file types and exfiltrate discovered files to a C2 server. Analysis of the tactics, techniques, and procedures (TTPs) along with the targeting leads Intezer to assess with high confidence that the activity can be attributed to the Russian government. For more information, see the Intezer blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.intezer.com/blog/malware-analysis/targeted-phishing-attack-against-ukrainian-government-expands-to-georgia/>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: QRAT Distributed via Sex Scandal Video Spam
A spam campaign observed by Trustwave is using an investment scam theme with a "Trump Scandal" video attachment to distribute a new variant of QRAT.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware, RAT




# Overview

Trustwave has published a report detailing a spam campaign using a political lure to entice users to open a malicious attachment. Although the body of the spam emails appears to be an investment scam, the attached file name is “TRUMP_SEX_SCANDAL_VIDEO.jar," capitalizing off of recent political events. Opening the JAR file, kicks off the infection chain beginning with a variant of the QNODE downloader. Within the JAR file are multiple data streams containing malicious code. Additionally, this new variant of the Qnode downloader contains junk data, increasing its file size. A second change with this variant is the addition of a pop up window warning the user that this is remote access software used for pentesting. References to the string "qnode" have mostly been removed from the malware. The second-stage is downloaded from a C2 server in the form of a JavaScript file. The JavaScript file is the Node.JS QRAT payload. Available commands allow attackers to remotely perform file operations, steal passwords, and gather system information. For more information, see the Trustwave blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.trustwave.com/en-us/resources/blogs/spiderlabs-blog/updated-qnode-rat-downloader-distributed-as-trump-video-scandal/>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: ESPecter - A Persistant UEFI Bootkit
A report from ESET provides their analysis of a UEFI bootkit they've named ESPecter that is able to persist on the EFI System Partition.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: ESPecter - A Persistant UEFI Bootkit
A report from ESET provides their analysis of a UEFI bootkit they've named ESPecter that is able to persist on the EFI System Partition.

# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** UEFI Bootkit
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Unknown
  *  **Associated Payloads:** ESPecter
  *  **Targets:** Unspecified
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Unknown
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Persistence, Data collection, and exfiltration.
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

ESPecter, named by ESET who discovered it, is a UEFI bootkit that traces its roots back to 2012 when it was a legacy BIOS bootkit. According to ESET the major change in the bootkit was the move to targeting UEFI systems with little other change in ESPecter's components. The sample analyzed by ESET was found on a compromised system. Also found was a user-mode client component that has the ability to log keystrokes and steal documents. ESET believes that ESPecter is primarily used for espionage. The method used to distribute ESPecter remains unknown. To achieve the infection of a system, a legitimate Windows Boot Manager binary is modified to allow the attacker to execute ESPecter early in the boot process and provides the ability to bypass Windows Driver Signature Enforcement allowing ESPecter to load its unsigned driver. However, Secure Boot must be disabled for this to work on Windows 8 and later. Secure Boot is not supported on versions of Windows prior to Windows 8. ESET has been unable to determine how the attackers were able to disable Secure Boot but note that they could have achieved it through having physical access to the system, Secure Boot may have already been disabled, or by exploiting a vulnerability in the UEFI firmware. The driver is used to load two user-mode payloads, WinSys.dll and Client.dll, which are used to log keystrokes, take screenshots, collect and exfiltrate documents, handle C&C communications, and can download further payloads. ESET was not able to attribute ESPecter to a known threat actor but given that there are debug messages in Chinese in the user-mode client component, it is possibly the work of an unknown Chinese-speaking actor. Further information is available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/64129821/ESPecter%20-%20A%20Persistant%20UEFI%20Bootkit%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1633658531914&api=v2)



# Recommendations

parsed_raw_data.xfe_q:
ESPecter - A Persistant UEFI Bootkit
A report from ESET provides their analysis of a UEFI bootkit they've named ESPecter that is able to persist on the EFI System Partition.
parsed_raw_data.xfe_report:
# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** UEFI Bootkit
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Unknown
  *  **Associated Payloads:** ESPecter
  *  **Targets:** Unspecified
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Unknown
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Persistence, Data collection, and exfiltration.
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

ESPecter, named by ESET who discovered it, is a UEFI bootkit that traces its roots back to 2012 when it was a legacy BIOS bootkit. According to ESET the major change in the bootkit was the move to targeting UEFI systems with little other change in ESPecter's components. The sample analyzed by ESET was found on a compromised system. Also found was a user-mode client component that has the ability to log keystrokes and steal documents. ESET believes that ESPecter is primarily used for espionage. The method used to distribute ESPecter remains unknown. To achieve the infection of a system, a legitimate Windows Boot Manager binary is modified to allow the attacker to execute ESPecter early in the boot process and provides the ability to bypass Windows Driver Signature Enforcement allowing ESPecter to load its unsigned driver. However, Secure Boot must be disabled for this to work on Windows 8 and later. Secure Boot is not supported on versions of Windows prior to Windows 8. ESET has been unable to determine how the attackers were able to disable Secure Boot but note that they could have achieved it through having physical access to the system, Secure Boot may have already been disabled, or by exploiting a vulnerability in the UEFI firmware. The driver is used to load two user-mode payloads, WinSys.dll and Client.dll, which are used to log keystrokes, take screenshots, collect and exfiltrate documents, handle C&C communications, and can download further payloads. ESET was not able to attribute ESPecter to a known threat actor but given that there are debug messages in Chinese in the user-mode client component, it is possibly the work of an unknown Chinese-speaking actor. Further information is available from the link in the Reference section below.

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Rana Android Malware
Rana is an Android malware believed to be used by APT39 for cyber espionage purposes. ReversingLabs has identified old samples of the malware and published their analysis of the payloads.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Rana Android Malware
Rana is an Android malware believed to be used by APT39 for cyber espionage purposes. ReversingLabs has identified old samples of the malware and published their analysis of the payloads.

# Threat Type

  * Malware, APT




# Overview

ReversingLabs published a blog post analyzing samples of the Rana Android malware. A sample of this malware was previously reported on by the FBI and tied to the Iranian threat group APT39. While the YARA rule provided in the FBI's report did not lead to the identification of further samples, ReversingLabs was able to find additional Rana malware based on the signing certificate associated with the initial sample. Specifically, they uncovered three previously unidentified samples. One of these did not include the obfuscation seen in the majority of the samples, making analysis of the malware family simple. ReversingLabs highlighted a few commands specific to surveillance purposes that had not previously been mentioned. First is the ability to take camera photos at login success or failure, giving the attackers the ability to identify who is attempting to access a device. Second is advanced recording capabilities allowing for detailed configurations regarding when and for how long the device should record. Finally, the malware schedules a device boot to ensure the malware will re-activate even if the user turns off the device. Most commands included with the malware are common to Android backdoors, but a couple relatively unique commands were identified. These include the ability to add and connect to a custom WiFi point, and a capability allowing calls from specific phone numbers to be answered, which provides a backup method for audio tapping. The newest function that has been added is the use of accessibility services to steal contents of messages from instant messaging apps, some of which are specific to Iran. All of these commands are issued with intercepted SMS messages. ReversingLabs also investigated the C2 infrastructure in an attempt to identify related domains tied to the threat actor. For more information, see the ReversingLabs blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://blog.reversinglabs.com/blog/rana-android-malware>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: BazarLoader Using LoLBins through Office Documents to Deliver Payloads
Researchers at Netskope uncovered a BazarLoader sample using a Microsoft Office XML Flat file and living-off-the-land binaries for execution.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: BazarLoader Using LoLBins through Office Documents to Deliver Payloads
Researchers at Netskope uncovered a BazarLoader sample using a Microsoft Office XML Flat file and living-off-the-land binaries for execution.

# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Loader
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** TrickBot
  *  **Associated Payloads:** BazarLoader
  *  **Targets:** Unknown
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Malicious Word document
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Unknown



# Overview

Netskope published a blog post analyzing a recent BazarLoader sample leveraging a Microsoft Office XML Flat file and living-off-the-land binaries. The infection chain begins with a Microsoft Office XML Flat File Format Word Document, likely delivered to victims via phishing emails. If macros are enabled, embedded HTA data is saved to a new file on the system and executed using MSHTML.exe. The HTA file subsequently executes JavaScript code responsible for downloading a DLL disguised as a PNG file from a remote server and executing it with regsvr32.exe. At the time of analysis, the remote server was offline, so the DLL payload could not be retrieved. BazarLoader typically downloads a final payload, such as ransomware or a backdoor. For more information, see the Netskope blog post in the References section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/64128785/BazarLoader%20Using%20LoLBins%20through%20Office%20Documents%20to%20Deliver%20Payloads%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1632837753315&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques and phishing emails (M1017).
  * Restrict Web-Based Content (M1021).



# References

  * <https://www.netskope.com/blog/bazarloader-using-lolbins-through-office-documents-to-deliver-payloads>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1566 - Phishing  
T1566.001 - Spearphishing Attachment  
T1566.002 - Spearphishing Link

 **Execution - TA0002**

T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
T1059.005 - Visual Basic  
T1059.007 - JavaScript  
  
T1204 - User Execution  
T1204.002 - Malicious File

 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1218 - Signed Binary Proxy Execution  
T1218.005 - Mshta  
T1218.010 - Regsvr32

 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
T1071.001 - Web Protocols

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Lazarus Using BMP Files With Malicious HTA Objects
A report from Malwarebytes Labs provides details of an attack that occurred in early April that they attribute to the Lazarus APT group. In the attack, a BMP image that contained embedded HTA objects was used to drop a loader.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Lazarus Using BMP Files With Malicious HTA Objects
A report from Malwarebytes Labs provides details of an attack that occurred in early April that they attribute to the Lazarus APT group. In the attack, a BMP image that contained embedded HTA objects was used to drop a loader.

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Phishing




# Overview

The first stage of an attack, attributed to the Lazarus APT group by Malwarebytes Labs, probably began with phishing emails. Lazarus is known by many names including Guardians of Peace, Hidden Cobra, Nickel Academy, and Zinc. A malicious document attached to the emails contained macros that would kick off the infection process by dropping a loader. The loader was contained in a PNG file present in the document, which was then converted to a BMP file. During the conversion from PNG into the uncompressed BMP format, the malicious HTA objects are also decompressed. The HTA objects provide a JavaScript file that creates an executable file, in this case, "AppStore.exe". In turn, AppStore.exe loads a base64-encrypted payload into memory. The second stage payload initiates communication with the C&C servers. Further details are available from the Malwarebytes Labs report linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://blog.malwarebytes.com/malwarebytes-news/2021/04/lazarus-apt-conceals-malicious-code-within-bmp-file-to-drop-its-rat/>

I have encountered the following information: Apple Security Advisory - December 14th, 2020
Apple published a security advisory addressing eleven vulnerabilities affecting iOS and iPadOS.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

 These include information disclosure, out-of-bounds write, out-of-bounds read, memory corruption, and use after free vulnerabilities. The worst of these, if successfully exploited, may allow an attacker to perform arbitrary code execution. Apple has patched these vulnerabilities in iOS 14.3 and iPadOS 14.3. We recommend reviewing the advisory in the Reference section for further details and applying any applicable updates as soon as possible.

# CVEs

  * A complete list of CVEs can be found here: [ CVEs.txt](/download/attachments/35718310/Apple%20Security%20Advisory%20-%20December%2014th%2C%202020%20CVEs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1608046384943&api=v2)




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Blackrota - A Backdoor Written in Go
Netlab 360 reports on a backdoor written in Go that is been dubbed "Blackrota". It exploits an unauthorized access vulnerability in the Docker Remote API.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Blackrota - A Backdoor Written in Go
Netlab 360 reports on a backdoor written in Go that is been dubbed "Blackrota". It exploits an unauthorized access vulnerability in the Docker Remote API.

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Backdoor, Vulnerability



# Overview

Blackrota is a backdoor that exploits the Docker Remote API and its unauthorized access vulnerability according to a report by Netlab 360. At this time, Blackrota only works on Linux. Blackrota is compiled based on geacon. Geacon is a CobaltStrike Beacon written in Go. Using the CobalStrike Beacon, Blackrota can employ CobaltStrike to access and control infected hosts. The obfuscated code of BlackRota is compiled statically, meaning that all of the libraries and functions it uses are included in the final executable. This can potentially result in a very large binary file, which can be hard to reverse engineer. For more details review the link in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/33983242/Blackrota%20-%20A%20Backdoor%20Written%20in%20Go%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1606255041532&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://blog.netlab.360.com/blackrota-an-obfuscated-backdoor-written-in-go-en/>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Threat Actors Leverage Asterisk Servers for Monetary Gain
Researchers at Check Point recently discovered one of the most intricate methods of exploitation conducted by threat actors. As surges of cyber fraud attacks worldwide surface, the targeting of VoIP and Session Initiation Protocol (SIP) servers to make outgoing phone calls and generate profits has also appeared.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Threat Actors Leverage Asterisk Servers for Monetary Gain
Researchers at Check Point recently discovered one of the most intricate methods of exploitation conducted by threat actors. As surges of cyber fraud attacks worldwide surface, the targeting of VoIP and Session Initiation Protocol (SIP) servers to make outgoing phone calls and generate profits has also appeared.

# Threat Type

  * Ransomware 




# Overview

Analysts at Check Point Research assessed a unique campaign operation being conducted in the Middle East originally and have seen the campaigns influence spread worldwide, with 60 countries falling victim.  According to analysts, they believe the threat actors are located in Gaza and exploit the open-source user interface Sangoma PB to gain C2 of Asterisk VoIP phone systems, specifically the Session Initiation Protocol (SIP) servers. Asterisk is a well-known VoIP PBX (private branch exchange) system provider used for telecommunication services. PBX is initially used to establish and control phone calls between telecommunication endpoints like standard telephone sets and services/devices on VoIP networks. Researchers at Check Point also discovered Pastebin being leveraged in the campaign Pastebin to download password-protected web shells, leading them to believe it could be the work of an uploader known as INJ3CTOR3. Furthermore, researchers uncovered how threat actors have been able to generate monetary gain for themselves. By exploiting the desired VoIP server, threat actors have the ability to make calls to International Premium Rate Numbers, numbers used by businesses to offer phone-based purchases or services. When an IPRN is called, the victims making the calls to IPRNs will pay a fee meaning, more calls, more money for the threat actor. It was also assessed that threat actors began selling and bidding the compromised VoIP services, which generated them hundreds of thousands of dollars in profit, along with the added benefit of eavesdropping on phone calls. For more information, see the blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://research.checkpoint.com/2020/inj3ctor3-operation-leveraging-asterisk-servers-for-monetization/>

  * <https://github.com/FreePBX/framework/commit/4e4675d9a8c0cb5ff8891aa1b51889a8b845502f>
  * <https://packetstormsecurity.com/files/author/12734/>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: COVID-19 Used to Deliver Zebrocy
COVID-19 phishing lures are nothing in a time of pandemic chaos. Intezer reports on the use of the pandemic to deliver the malware known as Zebrocy.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: COVID-19 Used to Deliver Zebrocy
COVID-19 phishing lures are nothing in a time of pandemic chaos. Intezer reports on the use of the pandemic to deliver the malware known as Zebrocy.

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Phishing




# Overview

Zebrocy, malware used against government and commercial organizations engaged in foreign efforts, has been seen being delivered via documents about a COVID-19 vaccine company. A Virtual Hard Drive is the delivery mechanism and requires the victims to use Windows 10 in order to access the malicious files. The malware is heavily obfuscated but attribution was made to the Sofacy threat actor through the use of forensics in samples obtained from prior campaigns. Sofacy, also known as APT28, FancyBear, and STRONTIUM, was responsible for the compromise of the Democratic National Committee. Originally written in Delphi, the malware has since been translated into several other programming languages, thus widening its footprint and possible targets. The malware works by having a user open a VHD which includes two files, a PDF and an executable masquerading as a Word document. The PDF is a copy of slides from a presentation about the Sinopharm International Corporation, a company based out of China and a manufacturer of pharmaceutical products. The company is currently working on a COVID-19 vaccination and presents an attractive lure to unsuspecting users. The second file is the actual malware, and only 9 of 70 anti-virus engines were able to detect it. The malware is obfuscated with gobfuscator and doesn't collect the same information as noted in prior campaigns. Instead, only the hostname and TEMP folder path are gathered. Screenshot code has been implemented by the author and does not use a third-party software to accomplish the task. Additionally, anti-debugging checks are performed through the use of the Windows API, IsDebuggerPresent. If present, the malware enters an infinite sleep. Screenshots are uploaded to a C2 server and, should the C2 return a second stage, the file is written to the target disk and executed. Further information can be found in the report located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.intezer.com/blog/research/russian-apt-uses-covid-19-lures-to-deliver-zebrocy/>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Credit Card Skimmer Evades Virtual Machines
It is not uncommon for credit card skimmers to check geolocation or user-agent strings to filter potential victims. In an interesting case, Malwarebytes observed a skimmer instead performing virtual machine detection via the browser for filtering.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Skimmer
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Magecart
  *  **Associated Payloads:** Magecart skimmer
  *  **Targets:** Online retail consumers
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Server-side compromise
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Credit card skimming
  *  **Additional TTPs:** Virtual machine detection



# Overview

Malwarebytes published a blog post analyzing a new Magecart skimmer that implements virtual machine detection. This is a feature not commonly seen being performed by browser-based malware. The skimming JavaScript code is loaded on a compromised checkout page, masquerading as an Angular library. The WebGL JavaScript API is used to identify the victim machine's graphics renderer. If a software renderer, which is a common fallback for virtualization software, is identified, the skimming activity will not take place. If the checks pace, any data provided in the checkout form, such as contact information and credit card details, is exfiltrated to the attacker via an HTTP POST request. For more information, see the Malwarebytes blog post in the References section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/70221868/Credit%20Card%20Skimmer%20Evades%20Virtual%20Machines%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1636038054341&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Restrict Web-Based Content (M1021).



# References

  * <https://blog.malwarebytes.com/threat-intelligence/2021/11/credit-card-skimmer-evades-virtual-machines/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1584 - Compromise Infrastructure  
T1584.004 - Server  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
T1059.007 - JavaScript  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1027 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
T1497 - Virtualization/Sandbox Evasion  
T1497.001 - System Checks  
  
 **Collection - TA0009**  
T1056 - Input Capture  
T1056.002 - GUI Input Capture  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0010**  
T1041 - Exfiltration Over C2 Channel  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
T1071.001 - Web Protocols  
T1132 - Data Encoding

Tell me about the following threat: VMware Security Advisory VMSA-2021-0003
VMWare published a security advisory, VMSA-2021-0003, that addresses a vulnerability in VMware View Planner.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: VMware Security Advisory VMSA-2021-0003
VMWare published a security advisory, VMSA-2021-0003, that addresses a vulnerability in VMware View Planner.

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

VMWare published a security advisory, VMSA-2021-0003, that addresses a single vulnerability (CVE-2021-21978) in VMware View Planner. The vulnerability is caused by a lack of authorization and a failure to properly validate user provided input. A remote attacker may be able to upload a malicious file and execute it within the logupload container. An update which addresses the vulnerability has been issued. We recommend reviewing the advisory, linked in the Reference section below, for further details.

# CVEs

  * CVE-2021-21978




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://www.vmware.com/security/advisories/VMSA-2021-0003.html>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Magento Phishing Leverages JavaScript For Exfiltration
A new Magento phishing page discovered by Sucuri highlights a change in tactics for credential exfiltration.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Magento Phishing Leverages JavaScript For Exfiltration
A new Magento phishing page discovered by Sucuri highlights a change in tactics for credential exfiltration.

# Threat Type

  * Phishing




# Overview

Sucuri has published a blog post analyzing a recently discovered Magento phishing page. The page mimics a legitimate Magento admin login panel, despite having a file name masquerading as a WordPress page. The CSS structure and other elements are loaded from a remote site controlled by the attacker. The interesting aspect of this phishing page as compared to most phishing pages is that it leverages JavaScript for exfiltration instead of PHP. Specifically, an EventListener method is used to send any text entered into the login fields when the user clicks outside of the boxes, regardless of whether they hit the submit button or not. The stolen credentials are base64-encoded and sent as a parameter in a GET request to the attacker's domain. Further information can be found in the Sucuri blog post in the Reference section.

X-Force Threat Intelligence researchers were able to identify one web page contacting the malicious domain and confirmed it was hosting the fake Magento admin login panel. This site was hosting the phishing page in early September 2020, over a month prior to the time of this publication. Details of this specific phishing page can be found at the urlscan link in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.



# Reference

  * <https://blog.sucuri.net/2020/10/magento-phishing-leverages-javascript-for-exfiltration.html>

  * <https://urlscan.io/result/ba462cfe-dd79-4312-a442-970cb9a04020/>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: NCAS Alert - FASTCash 2.0 - North Korean BeagleBoyz Robbing Banks
A Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) Alert, AA20-239A, has been published through the National Cyber Awareness System. The report is a joint publication from the Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency, Department of Homeland Security, the Federal Bureau of Investigation, the Department of the Treasury, and U.S. Cyber Command. The alert provides information on the North Korean targeting of banks in a number of countries which resumed in February 2020. The group carrying out the attacks have been named the "BeagleBoyz". The group compromises banking systems and initiate fraudulent international money transfers and ATM cash outs.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware, APT




# Overview

The Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) Alert, AA20-239A, provides information on the North Korean targeting of banks in a number of countries which resumed in February 2020. The report is a joint publication from CISA, Department of Homeland Security (DHS), the Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI), the Department of the Treasury (DOT), and U.S. Cyber Command (USCYBERCOM). The group who is carrying out the attacks have been named the "BeagleBoyz" and are reported to be an element of the North Korean government’s Reconnaissance General Bureau. This subset of HIDDEN COBRA activity has been active since 2014. The alert notes that since 2015, according to public estimates, the BeagleBoyz have attempted to steal almost $2 billion. The BeagleBoyz compromise a bank's systems using multiple techniques including spearphishing, employment application themed phishing emails, exploit vulnerabilities in Internet facing systems, breaching of third party systems who have access to the target, and watering hole attacks. Other groups, such as TA505, may be acting on behalf of the BeagleBoyz. Once an initial foothold has been gained, depending on the value of the target, and that sufficient privileges and access to the required systems have been attained, the BeagleBoyz may initiate fraudulent international money transfers using the victim's SWIFT terminals or use payment switch application servers to conduct fraudulent ATM cash outs. In some cases the BeagleBoyz have been known to render critical systems inoperable. Information from the victim's are also exfiltrated using a variety of methods. The BeagleBoyz also target cryptocurrency exchanges. Malware such as CROWDEDFLOUNDER and HOPLIGHT are mentioned in the alert. In addition, three Malware Analysis Reports, AR20-239A, AR20-239B, and AR20-239C, have been published. The reports provide information on malware associated with the attacks which are named, ECCENTRICBANDWAGON, VIVACIOUSGIFT, and FASTCASH. The alert also provides recommendations and mitigation information. Further details are available from the alert which is linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. for IoCs.  




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ncas/alerts/aa20-239a>

  * <https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ncas/analysis-reports/ar20-239a>
  * <https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ncas/analysis-reports/ar20-239b>
  * <https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ncas/analysis-reports/ar20-239c>

The alert also provides recommendations and mitigation information. Further details are available from the alert which is linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. for IoCs.  




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.

  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.
