instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Prometheus Ransomware Group
Prometheus is a relatively new ransomware group emerging on the threat landscape. A blog post by Cyble discusses their usage of the Thanos ransomware in its operations.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Prometheus Ransomware Group
Prometheus is a relatively new ransomware group emerging on the threat landscape. A blog post by Cyble discusses their usage of the Thanos ransomware in its operations.

# Threat Type

  * Ransomware




# Overview

Cyble published a blog post analyzing the new Prometheus ransomware group. The group was discovered when researchers found a leak site for the group on the dark web. The website claims that they are affiliated with the REvil ransomware-as-a-service group. The site lists data for sale from breached companies. The ransomware family used during this group's operations was identified as the Thanos ransomware. It operates similar to most ransomware: stopping certain services and processes, adjusting firewall rules, encrypting files, and dropping ransom notes. The specific variant of Thanos uses AES for encrypting files and, unlike most ransomware, appends an extension that is unique to the malicious payload. The ransom note directs users to visit a Tor site in order to start a chat with the operators to negotiate the ransom. Additionally, the note claims stolen sensitive data will be publicly released or sold if the victim does not cooperate. For more information, see the Cyble blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://cybleinc.com/2021/06/05/prometheus-an-emerging-apt-group-using-thanos-ransomware-to-target-organizations/>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Joomla ACL Vulnerability Mitigation
A vulnerability in the Joomla platform has given threat actors and non-superusers an opportunity to exploit the third most used CMS after WordPress and Shopify. SecureLayer7 has the particulars on this vulnerability in a new blog.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

A Joomla security advisory has been disclosed that shows a vulnerability in the ACL of versions from 1.7.0 to 3.9.22. The exploit has since been patched with version 3.9.23. The exploit used a missing parameter that allowed for the bypass of checking for a user's level of access. This missing parameter is included in the patched version of the software. The weakness in the platform could allow an attacker to replace an actual ACL with one specifically written by the actor using the 'save' function. The vulnerability works by creating users with different privileges. A new category is created and given permission to the site manager. All permissions, however, are set to 'denied' for administrators. With this technique employed, the administrator can perform any function on the created folder because permissions are missing. The manager can edit the created page and a new ACL is set allowing total access to administrators. An edited POST function can allow all of these actions to take place. Further information can be found in the blog located within the Reference section below.

# CVEs

  * CVE-2020-35616




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://blog.securelayer7.net/latest-joomla-exploit-cve-2020-35616-acl-security-vulnerabilities/>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: New Phishing Campaign Harvests Credentials with GDPR Lure
A phishing campaign using a GDPR lure to entice victims to provide credentials was discovered and reported on by Area 1 Security researchers.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Phishing, Credential Stealing




# Overview

Area 1 Security has published a blog post detailing a GDPR-themed phishing campaign targeting multiple organizations. Analysis of the emails revealed that some were being sent from a VPS while others were sent from compromised servers. The body of the email uses graphics and a mix of formatting to pass itself off as legitimate. It spoofs the victim organization, specifically claiming to come from the security department, and requests that the recipient login to their account in order to follow steps related to GDPR compliance. The provided link leads to a login form hosted on a compromised WordPress site. If a user falls victim and enters their credentials, the data is exfiltrated to the attacker using a script hosted on the same domain. The researchers note that the phishing page has since been removed from the site but it is likely the attackers will simply compromise another site to host their content and continue their campaign. For more information, see the Area 1 Security blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.area1security.com/blog/gdpr-compliance-phishing/>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: OMIGOD Vulnerabilities being exploited by Mirai
A group of new high severity vulnerabilities affecting Azure has been disclosed. Since these were made public, there has been an increasing number of IPs scanning and attempting to exploit them, including
output:
# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Malware
  *  **Targets:** Azure Customers **  
**
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** Mirai
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** OMIGOD Vulnerabilities on Azure
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Privilege Escalation



# Overview

The Mirai botnet has been observed exploiting a high severity vulnerability in the wild. Various researchers on Twitter have reported an increasing number of IPs opportunistically scanning and subsequently exploiting the recently reported vulnerabilities which are being collectively tracked as OMIGOD. These four vulnerabilities allow attackers to remotely execute code or escalate privileges on vulnerable virtual machines running on Azure. The vulnerabilities affect the Open Management Infrastructure (OMI) software agent, which runs as root, and is automatically run when certain services are deployed. It has been estimated that these vulnerabilities could affect thousands of Azure customers and expose millions of endpoints to attack. One researcher, Kevin Beaumont, has reported seeing the Mirai botnet actively exploiting these vulnerabilities, before closing port 5896 to prevent other actors from exploiting the same host. The OMIGOD collection of vulnerabilities has since been patched, and Microsoft is urging all customers to update vulnerable deployments. Further information can be found in the article located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/64128592/OMIGOD%20Vulnerabilities%20being%20exploited%20by%20Mirai%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1632751756249&api=v2)



# CVEs

  * A complete list of CVEs can be found here: [ CVEs.txt](/download/attachments/64128592/OMIGOD%20Vulnerabilities%20being%20exploited%20by%20Mirai%20CVEs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1632739729074&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).

  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.

  * Regularly scan externally facing systems for vulnerabilities and establish procedures to rapidly patch systems when critical vulnerabilities are discovered through scanning and through public disclosure (M1051).  


  * Segment externally facing servers and services from the rest of the network with a DMZ or on separate hosting infrastructure (M1030).
  * Efforts should focus on minimizing the amount and sensitivity of data available to external parties (M1056). _  
_
  * Develop a robust cyber threat intelligence capability to determine what types and levels of threat may use software exploits and 0-days against a particular organization (M1019 ).



# References

  * <https://securityaffairs.co/wordpress/122322/hacking/omigod-mirai-botnet.html>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Reconnaissance - TA0043**  
T1595.002 - Vulnerability Scanning  
  
 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1584 - Compromise Infrastructure  
T1587.001 - Malware  
  
 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application  
  
 **Privilege Escalation - TA0004**  
T1068 - Exploitation for Privilege Escalation

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Brazilian Bank Customers Target By Vizom
IBM Security Trusteer researchers have discovered a new malware package being used against banking customers in Brazil that has been dubbed "Vizom".

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Brazilian Bank Customers Target By Vizom
IBM Security Trusteer researchers have discovered a new malware package being used against banking customers in Brazil that has been dubbed "Vizom".

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Backdoor



# Overview

Information about a new malware package, Vizom, that is targeting banking customers in Brazil is the basis of a new report from IBM Security Trusteer researchers. The attack vector for the malware is DLL hijacking. It uses two legitimate applications delivered in the payload, a video conferencing software package and an Internet browser named Vivaldi, to side-load the malicious DLLs. The malware typically is delivered via spam emails, where the user must be tricked into downloading Vizom. Once installed, the malware copies its own malicious DLLs in the directories where the legitimate DLLs would be loaded. For a technical detail of how Vizom operates, please see the link in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Spike in BazarCall and IcedID Activity Detected in March
Both BazarCall and IcedID saw a spike in activity in March based on observations by Trend Micro researchers.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Spike in BazarCall and IcedID Activity Detected in March
Both BazarCall and IcedID saw a spike in activity in March based on observations by Trend Micro researchers.

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Banking Trojan




# Overview

Trend Micro published a blog post analyzing a spike in BazarCall and IcedID activity in March 2021. BazarCall is a malicious payload that is typically used to deliver the BazarLoader malware. Its name comes from its unique use of phone operators in the infection process. The infection chain begins with a spam email claiming that the recipient's credit card will be charged for a subscription unless they call a provided phone number. When the phone number is called, the operators direct the victim to a webpage that will download a macro-embedded Excel document. This document is leveraged to download a malicious binary that, in turn, connects to the C2 hosting BazarLoader. IcedID, a banking Trojan around since 2017, also saw a spike in activity in March. The spam emails used in this campaign are copies of legitimate email threads with ZIP archives attached. Inside the ZIP archive is an XLSM file that uses a malicious macro to download the IcedID payload as a 64-bit DLL file. For more information, see the Trend Micro blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.trendmicro.com/en_us/research/21/d/a-spike-in-bazarcall-and-icedid-activity.html>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: New Features Of Hive Ransomware VMware Encryptor
Bleeping Computer has reported on an analysis of the new Hive ransomware encryptor for VMware ESXi Linux. They have switched to the Rust programming language and have added features to make it more evasive.
output:
# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Ransomware
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Hive Ransomware
  *  **Associated Payloads:** Hive VMware ESXi Linux encryptor.
  *  **Targets:** Unknown
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Unknown
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Data Encryption and Extortion



# Overview

As Businesses become more reliant on virtual machines, threat actors have been targeting these in their ransomware operations. Bleeping Computer has reported on some developments in Hive ransomware's VMware ESXi Linux encryptor. Although this encryptor has been in use for some time, they have recently updated it with features seen previously in the BlackCat ransomware operation. The main change is the attempt to make ransom negotiations private. This works by making the negotiation URL something that is passed as a command-line argument when executed, meaning the URL is harder to discover by researchers who may be tracking ransomware on open source sandboxes such as VirusTotal. They have also switched to using the Rust programming language, making it more difficult to reverse engineer. For more information, please see the link in the reference section.

# Recommendations

For a full list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.

# References

  * <https://www.bleepingcomputer.com/news/security/hive-ransomware-ports-its-linux-vmware-esxi-encryptor-to-rust/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1587.001 - Malware  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1027 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
T1564 - Hide Artifacts  
  
 **Impact - TA0040**  
T1486 - Data Encrypted for Impact  
  


#### Mitigations:

  
 **M1013:** Application Developer Guidance: This mitigation describes any guidance or training given to developers of applications to avoid introducing security weaknesses that an adversary may be able to take advantage of.  
 **M1022:** Restrict File and Directory Permissions - Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.  
 **M1028:** Operating System Configuration - Make configuration changes related to the operating system or a common feature of the operating system that result in system hardening against techniques.  
 **M1038:** Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
 **M1040:** Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
 **M1042:** Disable or Remove Feature or Program - Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.  
 **M1049:** Antivirus/Antimalware - Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software.  
 **M1053:** Data Backup - Take and store data backups from end user systems and critical servers. Ensure backup and storage systems are hardened and kept separate from the corporate network to prevent compromise.  
 **M1056:** Pre-compromise - This category is used for any applicable mitigation activities that apply to techniques occurring before an adversary gains Initial Access, such as Reconnaissance and Resource Development techniques.

New Features Of Hive Ransomware VMware Encryptor
Bleeping Computer has reported on an analysis of the new Hive ransomware encryptor for VMware ESXi Linux. They have switched to the Rust programming language and have added features to make it more evasive.
parsed_raw_data.xfe_report:
# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Ransomware
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Hive Ransomware
  *  **Associated Payloads:** Hive VMware ESXi Linux encryptor.
  *  **Targets:** Unknown
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Unknown
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Data Encryption and Extortion



# Overview

As Businesses become more reliant on virtual machines, threat actors have been targeting these in their ransomware operations. Bleeping Computer has reported on some developments in Hive ransomware's VMware ESXi Linux encryptor. Although this encryptor has been in use for some time, they have recently updated it with features seen previously in the BlackCat ransomware operation. The main change is the attempt to make ransom negotiations private. This works by making the negotiation URL something that is passed as a command-line argument when executed, meaning the URL is harder to discover by researchers who may be tracking ransomware on open source sandboxes such as VirusTotal. They have also switched to using the Rust programming language, making it more difficult to reverse engineer. For more information, please see the link in the reference section.

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Fake COVID-19 Survey Hides Ransomware
The Threat Intelligence Team at MalwarebytesLabs recently observed phishing attacks conducted by the APT group, Silent Librarian; targeting universities and colleges worldwide. An attack against the University of British Columbia (UBC) by Silent Librarian, unusually, involved ransomware.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Fake COVID-19 Survey Hides Ransomware
The Threat Intelligence Team at MalwarebytesLabs recently observed phishing attacks conducted by the APT group, Silent Librarian; targeting universities and colleges worldwide. An attack against the University of British Columbia (UBC) by Silent Librarian, unusually, involved ransomware.

# Threat Type

  * Phishing




# Overview

The APT group, Silent Librarian are well known for targeting educational facilities with phishing campaigns used to obtain user credentials. In an attack against the University of British Columbia (UBC) which MalwarebytesLabs attributes to Silent Librarian, instead of attempting to obtain user credentials, the goal was to install the Vaggen ransomware. The attackers leveraged mailproof.com services to create legitimate email accounts that were then used to register accounts in Box.net and Dropbox. The emails sent to victims contained a link to a malicious document hosted on the free services. Analysis revealed that the malicious phishing document utilized template injection to download and execute a remote template that contained a malicious macro; as well as notified via the canarytokens.com website. The final payload was the Vaggen ransomware that encrypts user’s files and drops a ransom note on the Desktop, demanding a payment equivalent to $80 USD to be paid in Bitcoin. For more information, see the blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://blog.malwarebytes.com/cybercrime/2020/10/fake-covid-19-survey-hides-ransomware-in-canadian-university-attack/>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: APT‑C‑23 Group Evolves Its Android Spyware
APT‑C‑23 has used Android spyware as part of its operations in the Middle East for a few years now. ESET has discovered an updated version of this spyware that provides added capabilities.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Spyware




# Overview

ESET has published a report on the latest version of APT-C-23's Android spyware. One of the key infection vectors is a fake Android app store. Some of the apps listed in this store redirect users to another download page for the legitimate app, while several of the apps can be downloaded directly. These apps that can be downloaded directly contain both the spyware and the legitimate application. ESET notes that prior to downloading the malware a coupon code is requested, likely to limit who can download it. They discovered further samples of the spyware not hosted on this fake app store, indicating that there are likely other infection vectors being used. In the case of the applications downloaded from the store, the legitimate application is installed to distract the user while the malware installs itself in the background. Other samples do not include a legitimate file and solely install the malware. Once installed on the system, the spyware requests permissions required to carry out its intended functions. It then establishes communication with a C2 server, its address obtained from a hardcoded Google Sites URL, allowing the attacker to easily change it as required. Commands from previous versions of the spyware that continue to be available in the new version are those for taking pictures, recording audio, exfiltrating data, uninstalling apps, and more. The newer version also adds capabilities, such as recording the screen and calls, making calls, and dismissing notifications. For more information, see the WeLiveSecurity blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.



# Reference

  * <https://www.welivesecurity.com/2020/09/30/aptc23-group-evolves-its-android-spyware/>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: New Variant of Ursnif Continuously Targeting Italy
Ursnif is a well-known banking Trojan with a large number of variants providing a diverse set of capabilities. A report from Fortinet analyzes a new variant of the malware specifically targeting users in Italy.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Trojan




# Overview

Fortinet has published a blog post analyzing a new variant of Ursnif targeting users in Italy via phishing emails. The initial phishing email uses a payment reminder theme and has a macro-embedded Word document attached. The macro code is responsible for clicking a button in a hidden UserForm that, in turn, downloads and executes a DLL file that is protected by a packer. The unpack program extracts the Ursnif payload into memory and then is called. At this point, a secondary PE file stored in the .reloc section is loaded into memory. Stored in the .bss section of this PE is an encrypted configuration. With the payload installed and the configuration decrypted, system information is gathered from the victim device and exfiltrated to a C2 server. Unfortunately, the C2 server was shut down at the time of analysis. If it had been live, the server's response would include a module to be executed by Ursnif in order to perform further malicious activities. For more information, see the Fortinet blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.fortinet.com/blog/threat-research/new-variant-of-ursnif-continuously-targeting-italy>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Dark Caracal: Undisclosed IoCs Can Pose Risks
Researchers at WhoisXML API took keen interest in the risk Dark Caracal undisclosed targeted attack IoCs pose, after FinSpy, a malicious tool commonly leveraged by the group resurfaced, according to a recent report.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Dark Caracal: Undisclosed IoCs Can Pose Risks
Researchers at WhoisXML API took keen interest in the risk Dark Caracal undisclosed targeted attack IoCs pose, after FinSpy, a malicious tool commonly leveraged by the group resurfaced, according to a recent report.

# Threat Type

  * Malware




# Overview

Researchers at WhoisXML API, decided to analyze an old threat group dubbed Dark Caracal, to gain a better understanding of the risk their IoCs pose, after a recent report. According to researchers, Dark Caracal is a threat group operated by an unknown group of hackers, since 2012; suspected to be state-sponsored and linked to the Lebanese government. According to researchers, Dark Caracal utilizes various malicious tools such as Bandook, CrossRAT, FinSpy, and Pallas. What researchers found interesting was one of the tools, utilized by Dark Caracal, dubbed FinSpy, resurfaced in a recent report by Amnesty International. Researchers then began collecting a list of publicly available Dark Caracal-related IoCs via Lookout from which they were able to retrieve 6 email addresses, 13 IP addresses, and 36 domain names. Researchers then began utilizing Reverse WHOIS searches and DNS lookups to help identify other possible IoCs that weren’t included in Lookout's available list. Successful in their efforts and using the 36 domain names collected from the Lookout report; researchers were able to collect 12 IP addresses, 11 domain names, and 4 additional domain names not openly disclosed as Dark Caracal previously. For more information, see the CircleID article in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [Dark Caracal! Undisclosed IoCs Can Pose Risks_IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/35718033/Dark%20Caracal%21%20Undisclosed%20IoCs%20Can%20Pose%20Risks_IoCs.txt?version=2&modificationDate=1607651393694&api=v2)  




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Recent Zoom-Themed Phish
Cofense reports on yet another Zoom-themed phishing campaign using the video conferencing software as a ruse to steal Microsoft credentials.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Phishing




# Overview

Cofense has published a blog post detailing the most recent in an extensive list of Zoom-themed phishing campaigns. This one uses a highly customized email to create a sense of legitimacy. The sender is spoofed to match the company domain, and mentions of both the recipient's first and last name and the company name are found throughout the email. Recipients are requested to click a link in order to see more details regarding the supposed meeting invite. The final destination of the link is hidden behind a MailChimp redirector URL. The landing page is a fake Microsoft login page hosted on a compromised WordPress site. Submitting credentials will ultimately result in their exfiltration to the attacker. For more information, see the Cofense blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://cofense.com/blog/zoom-themed-phish-in-use>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: AR20-259A - Iranian Web Shells
CISA has published a malware analysis report, AR20-259A, describing recent samples of web shells tied to an Iranian-based threat actor.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: AR20-259A - Iranian Web Shells
CISA has published a malware analysis report, AR20-259A, describing recent samples of web shells tied to an Iranian-based threat actor.

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Web Shell, Backdoor




# Overview

CISA published AR20-259A, a malware analysis report of Iranian web shell samples. The threat actor targets information technology, government, healthcare, financial, and insurance organizations across the United States. The initial infection vector in their attacks is through the exploitation of vulnerabilities in Pulse Secure virtual private network (VPN), Citrix NetScaler, and F5 devices. After successfully exploiting one of these vulnerabilities, the attackers were observed deploying various webshells onto the system. These included the ChunkyTuna, Tiny, and China Chopper web shells. Capabilities provided with these web shells installed include the ability to execute commands, enumerate directories, download and execute additional payloads, and exfiltrate data. Two additional tools were also discovered in use, FRP and KeeThief. FRP is an open source project allowing tunneling of network connections, which the researchers believed was used by this threat actor to tunnel Remote Desktop Protocol (RDP) sessions. KeeThief is another open source tool that is used to decrypt and steal credentials stored in the KeePass password manager. These credentials could then be used to move laterally. For more information, see the CISA report in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.



# Reference

  * <https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ncas/analysis-reports/ar20-259a>

Tell me about the following threat: Recent Phishing Campaigns Abusing Mimecast Services
Cofense reports on an uptick in phishing campaigns abusing legitimate Mimecast services in order to create more convincing lures and avoid detection.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Recent Phishing Campaigns Abusing Mimecast Services
Cofense reports on an uptick in phishing campaigns abusing legitimate Mimecast services in order to create more convincing lures and avoid detection.

# Threat Type

  * Phishing




# Overview

Cofense has published a blog post analyzing a phishing campaign leveraging legitimate Mimecast services. The lure uses the common "Payment Order" theme but, uniquely, includes a statement at the top of the email claiming that Mimecast was used to share large files with the recipient. Opening the attachment, as requested in the body of the email, provides users with a legitimate Mimecast link. The Mimecast link both provides users with a sense of legitimacy and evades email security appliances performing URL scanning. If a user falls victim and downloads and opens the HTML file from Mimecast, they will be redirected to a phishing page. The page claims to require Microsoft login credentials, along with the recovery email or phone number, in order to view the purchase order. The phishing page is relatively simplistic and lacks any branding to legitimize its claims. Submitting credentials leads to their exfiltration to an attacker-controlled URL and refreshes the page with no further action for the victim. For more information, see the Cofense blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://cofense.com/purchase-order-phishing-the-everlasting-phishing-tactic/>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Security Researchers Being Targeted in New Campaign
Google's Threat Analysis Group has uncovered a campaign that is taking aim at security researchers. The blog post discusses details of the campaign and some targets.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Security Researchers Being Targeted in New Campaign
Google's Threat Analysis Group has uncovered a campaign that is taking aim at security researchers. The blog post discusses details of the campaign and some targets.

# Threat Type

  * Phishing




# Overview

Using a fake research blog and twitter accounts, a suspected government-backed North Korean threat entity has targeted security researchers who may be working on vulnerabilities. The actors use the Twitter profiles to interact with researchers in order to gain trust. The blog contains links to claimed exploits. Information contained within the blog are write-ups for publicly disclosed vulnerabilities. The exploits in the blog could not be authenticated as working. A fake video of a previously patched Windows Defender vulnerability (CVE-2021-1647) is shown. The video is faked and is called out by targeted researchers. The actors then use one of the faked Twitter accounts to claim the video is not, in fact, faked. The actors establish initial communications and ask if the targeted researcher would like to collaborate on research together. The actor provides the victim with a Visual Studio Project which contains a DLL that is custom malware. This malware immediately communicates with C2 server domains. Additionally, the actors use a blog with a malicious link via a link on Twitter to install a malicious service on the victim machine. In addition to Twitter, other services used are LinkedIn, Telegram, Discord, Keybase, and email. Further details can be found in the blog located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://blog.google/threat-analysis-group/new-campaign-targeting-security-researchers/>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: TA402 Campaigns
Proofpoint has published a report which provides an analysis of campaigns that began in late 2021 that they have attributed to TA402.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: TA402 Campaigns
Proofpoint has published a report which provides an analysis of campaigns that began in late 2021 that they have attributed to TA402.

# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Malware, Espionage.
  *  **Targets:** Governments, foreign policy think tanks, and a state-affiliated airline, all located in the Middle East.
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** NimbleMamba, BrittleBush.
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Phishing emails with links leading to malicious files.
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Collection and exfiltration of information.
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below for TA402 TTPs.



# Overview

Proofpoint has published an analysis of campaigns that began in late 2021 and targeted governments, foreign policy think tanks, and a state-affiliated airline located in the Middle East. Proofpoint attributes the campaigns to a threat group they refer to as TA402 who is also known as Molerats and the Gaza Cybergang. IBM X-Force tracks the activities of the group using the identifier Hive0022. The threat group is believed to be Arabic-speaking, politically motivated, and acting in the interests of the Palestinian Territories. The campaigns typically began with phishing emails that contained links that, in two of the three analyzed cases, led to a host that used geolocation to redirect connections that did not originate from the target countries to a news site. Of the two examples that used the redirection based on geolocation, one used a website masquerading as Quora on an attacker-controlled domain, and the other involved an actor-controlled domain and WordPress site that carried out the redirections. In the third case, the group was using Dropbox to host the malicious files but were unable to conduct the geolocation redirection due to not having control of the domain. Dropbox was also used for C&C services in some cases. If a connection originated from one of the targeted countries, the victim was led to an RAR file that contained malicious executables. The payload was a new Trojan developed by TA402 that Proofpoint has named NimbleMamba and has features typical of malware used in intelligence gathering and initial access. In some cases, a second payload, the BrittleBush Trojan, was also deployed. Further information is available from Proofpoint's report which is linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/74058570/TA402%20Campaigns%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1644815134743&api=v2)



# Detection

  * A Yara rule can be found here: [ Yara Rule.txt](/download/attachments/74058570/TA402%20Campaigns%20Yara%20Rule.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1644815148113&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques and phishing emails (M1017).
  * Restrict Web-Based Content (M1021).



# References

  * <https://www.proofpoint.com/us/blog/threat-insight/ugg-boots-4-sale-tale-palestinian-aligned-espionage>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1566 - Phishing  
T1566.001 - Spearphishing Attachment  
T1566.002 - Spearphishing Link  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
T1059.001 - PowerShell  
T1059.005 - Visual Basic  
T1059.007 - JavaScript  
T1204 - User Execution  
T1204.001 - Malicious Link  
T1204.002 - Malicious File  
  
 **Persistence - TA0003**  
T1547 - Boot or Logon Autostart Execution  
T1547.001 - Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1027 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
T1036 - Masquerading  
T1140 - Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information  
T1218 - Signed Binary Proxy Execution  
T1218.007 - Msiexec  
T1480 - Execution Guardrails  
T1480.001 - Environmental Keying  
T1497 - Virtualization/Sandbox Evasion  
T1497.001 - System Checks  
T1553 - Subvert Trust Controls  
T1553.002 - Code Signing  
  
 **Credential Access - TA0006**  
T1555 - Credentials from Password Stores  
T1555.003 - Credentials from Web Browsers  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1057 - Process Discovery  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
T1071.001 - Web Protocols  
T1102 - Web Service  
T1102.002 - Bidirectional Communication  
T1105 - Ingress Tool Transfer  
T1573 - Encrypted Channel  
T1573.001 - Symmetric Cryptography

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: LockBit Gang Has Their Own Data Exfiltration Tool
Researchers from Yoroi ZLAB take a deeper look at how the LockBit gang conducts their data exfiltration. In their blog post, they reveal more about the tool, YARA rules to find samples of it, and show a sampling of infrastructure that has been used.
output:
# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Data Theft
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** LockBit Ransomware Gang
  *  **Associated Payloads:** StealBit Data Exfiltration Tool
  *  **Targets:** Unspecified
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Unspecified
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:**
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

While many threat actors carry out data exfiltration using common or public tools such as FTP or RClone, LockBit gang has developed their own tool. Researchers from Yoroi ZLAB step through how a custom tool named StealBit is used by the LockBit gang. The tool utilizes some anti-analysis techniques. Additionally, it is used to conduct massive data theft and uses HTTP in a design that is to be as fast as possible. The data is not compressed or encrypted. In it's configuration is a listing of files, extensions, and registry hives that are excluded from being exfiltrated. The systems indicated by the IP addresses noted to be used by StealBit have also been seen to be used in different operations by different criminal organizations. Further information is available from the report linked in the Reference section below.

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: The WayBack Campaign
A report from Yoroi provides insights into a campaign they have named "WayBack" due to the campaign's use of the Wayback Machine Internet Archive to store malicious code.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: The WayBack Campaign
A report from Yoroi provides insights into a campaign they have named "WayBack" due to the campaign's use of the Wayback Machine Internet Archive to store malicious code.

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Malspam, Campaign




# Overview

, named by Yoroi for its use of the Wayback Machine Internet Archive to store malicious code, has been active since at least April 2021. The campaign uses malspam to deliver weaponized PowerPoint documents. The malspam emails have been sent in at least six waves, the most recent listed in Yoroi's report being sent in the second week of June. The malicious PowerPoint document uses shortened URLs that point to Blogspot pages that contain obfuscated JavaScript code executed using MSHTA. In turn, this leads to malicious PowerShell scripts that have been stored in the Wayback Machine's pages. The PowerShell scripts are used to deliver the final payload which is typically either Agent Tesla or Oski information stealers or the Cobian RAT. Persistence is achieved using registry keys and a scheduled task. A registry key is used to trigger the download of a PowerShell script which is used to disable system protection mechanisms including the Firewall, Windows Defender, UAC controls, and whitelisted processes needed by the malware. Yoroi attributes the campaign to a threat actor they refer to as Aggah that may be associated with the Gorgon group. Further details are available from the Yoroi report linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://yoroi.company/research/the-wayback-campaign-a-large-scale-operation-hiding-in-plain-sight/>

Tell me everything you know the following threat: Malicious Docker Image Used To Install Cryptominers
TeamTNT is known for attacking cloud deployments. Researchers at Uptycs have identified a campaign from TeamTNT whereby a malicious Docker image being publicly hosted and used in an attack that propagates itself and installs malicious software onto the victim's machine.
output:
# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Cryptojacking
  *  **Associated Threat Actors** : TeamTNT
  *  **Targets:** Unknown
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** Xmrig Miner, Tsunami IRC Bot, Diamorphine Rootkit
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Bash Script
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Lateral Movement, Cryptomining



# Overview

Researchers at Uptycs Threat Research have recently identified a campaign where the threat actor TeamTNT is using a malicious docker container image to infect their victims. This image is hosted in Docker Hub under the user 'alpineos', who joined the site in the May of 2021. They currently host 25 images, with the one being analyzed here having over 5000 downloads, but another image from the repository having over 100,000 downloads. This indicates that the malicious image is being actively used in attacks. The attack starts using a malicious bash script that claims to install a crypto-miner. This script includes a command to download and run the malicious docker image on the user's system. Within this image, there is a script called 'pause' which installs several utilities including masscan and zgrab, which are then used to scan for other docker nodes on the victim's subnet. If found, the script will install the image onto that node, and download the initial script to that node to begin the process again. Once this stage is complete, the script will then deploy a cryptominer and a backdoor which will then contact the C2 server. The bash script also includes a command to download a rootkit shell script. There is currently no information on who the victims are for this campaign or where they may be based, but the high download count of the malicious container image shows that many machines have been infected and could be spreading the malware. Further information can be found in the article located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/64130055/Malicious%20Docker%20Image%20Used%20To%20Install%20Cryptominers%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1634032623118&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.

  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.

  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.

  * Use read-only containers and minimal images when possible to prevent the execution of commands (M1038).
  * Ensure containers are not running as root by default (M1026).
  * Limit communications with the container service to local Unix sockets or remote access via SSH. Require secure port access to communicate with the APIs over TLS by disabling unauthenticated access to the Docker API and Kubernetes API Server (M1035).



# References

  * <https://www.uptycs.com/blog/team-tnt-deploys-malicious-docker-image-on-docker-hub-with-pentesting-tools>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059.004 - Unix Shell  
T1609 - Container Administration Command  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1027 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
T1027.002 - Software Packing  
T1036.005 - Match Legitimate Name or Location  
T1070.003 - Clear Command History  
T1070.004 - File Deletion  
T1140 - Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information  
  
 **Credential Access - TA0006**  
T1552.001 - Credentials In Files  
T1552.004 - Private Keys  
T1552.005 - Cloud Instance Metadata API  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1046 - Network Service Scanning  
T1082 - System Information Discovery  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
T1102 - Web Service  
T1105 - Ingress Tool Transfer  
T1219 - Remote Access Software  
  
 **Impact - TA0040**  
T1496 - Resource Hijacking

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Android QR Scanner App Distributes Joker Variant
An app named "QR Scanner Free" that was available on the Google Play store until early July, infected victims with a variant of the Joker malware according to a blog posting from Cyble.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware




# Overview

The Joker malware is capable of stealing information, and money from its victim's bank accounts, as well as being able to sign the victims up to paid services, without their consent, or knowing. An article on the Cyble blog reports that an app named "QR Scanner Free" that was available on the Google Play store until early July, infected victims with a variant of the Joker malware. At the time it was removed, it had been installed more than 500 times. The app's author used a number of techniques to avoid Google's malicious app detections. The payload files are downloaded and installed on the victim device when the app is launched. Further details, including an analysis of the app, are available from Cyble's blog posting which is linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://blog.cyble.com/2021/07/09/android-app-disguised-as-a-qr-scanner-spreads-joker-variant-trojan/>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: In the Wild Exploits for WordPress Vulnerability
An exploit has been observed by researchers with Unit 42 in the wake of the release of CVE-2020-25213, a vulnerability in a WordPress plugin named File Manager. The vulnerability, if exploited, could lead to remote code execution.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability, Malware




# Overview

An exploit in the wild against the WordPress plugin named File Manager has been observed by Palo Alto's Unit 42 researchers. The vulnerability in the File Manager plugin has been used by attackers to install webshells. These webshells have been used to then install Kinsing. Kinsing is a malware that runs a cryptominer from H2miner. The vulnerability, CVE-2020-25213, is a file upload vulnerability that allows an attacker to rename a library from a .dist extension to a .php extension. This change allows for direct access to the library. This access can be done through browsing the web server. The flaw allows for the upload of files, which attackers have made use of recently. The attacker uses an HTTP POST request to upload a webshell, named k.php and a command to execute was included in the POST request. The webshell is in plain text and unobfuscated. The curl command was used to download a file named wpf.sh. The shell script was obtained from the C2 server, which was included in the WGET request. Further details can be found in the report located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/cve-2020-25213/>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Samba Security Advisories - October 29th, 2020
Samba published three security advisories addressing vulnerabilities in their software.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Samba Security Advisories - October 29th, 2020
Samba published three security advisories addressing vulnerabilities in their software.

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

  




CVE-2020-14318 is a missing permission check vulnerability in the SMB ChangeNotify concept. If successfully exploited, an attacker with unprivileged access could obtain file name information. CVE-2020-14323 is an improper input validation vulnerability in winbind that, if successfully exploited, could cause a NULL pointer dereference, which would in turn cause a crash. CVE-2020-14383 addresses an error handling vulnerability with the Samba dnsserver RPC pipe that could allow an authenticated, non-admin user to crash a server by adding invalid DNS records.

Samba has released patches and mitigation advice alongside all three advisories. We recommend reviewing the advisories and implementing their guidance as soon as possible.

# CVEs

  * A complete list of CVEs can be found here: [ CVEs.txt](/download/attachments/32147079/Samba%20Security%20Advisories%20-%20October%2029th%2C%202020%20CVEs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1604072909884&api=v2)




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://www.samba.org/samba/security/CVE-2020-14318.html>

  * <https://www.samba.org/samba/security/CVE-2020-14323.html>

  * <https://www.samba.org/samba/security/CVE-2020-14383.html>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Torisma and LCPDot Malware
Operation Dream Job was a campaign carried out by Lazarus. In a recent article JPCERT/CC described two malware families discovered as part of this campaign, Torisma and LCPDot.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware, APT, Downloader




# Overview

JPCERT/CC has published a blog post analyzing the Torisma and LCPDot downloaders used by Lazarus in Operation Dream Job. Torisma is spread through malicious Word files and are delivered to the system as DLL files. Its configuration information, such as the C2 server, is loaded from a separate file. Initial communication with its C2 involves sending the victim system's information. If the server returns an acceptance message as the response, a VEST-32-encrypted and Base64-encoded module is downloaded to the victim system. Modules observed during JPCERT/CC's analysis included the capability to send information about the infected host and to execute specific files. LCPDot is very similar Torisma and is believed to be used in combination with Torisma to move laterally on victim networks. In the case of LCPDot, the configuration is included within the payload. With successful C2 communication established, an RC4-encrypted module is downloaded. The researchers were unable to obtain samples of the modules downloaded by LCPDot so the next-stage functionality of this malware is unknown. For more information, see the JPCERT/CC blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://blogs.jpcert.or.jp/en/2021/01/Lazarus_malware2.html>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: JobCrypter Ransomware Analysis
Focusing on a smaller ransomware family still active amongst the largerm double extortion ransomware groups, Yoroi has published a blog post analyzing the JobCrypter ransomware.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Ransomware




# Overview

Yoroi has recently observed the JobCrypter ransomware active in campaigns across Italy, despite its relative simplicity to the larger, double extortion ransomware groups widely discussed across the cyber landscape. This ransomware family often spreads via email attachments sent to victims enticing them to open the file in order to initiate the infection. The researchers' analysis begins with the JavaScript loader employed by the threat actors. Inside the script is a hex-obfuscated payload that is dropped into the user's %TEMP% folder and subsequently executed. The payload is packed using a .NET packers and employs anti-debugging checks before performing its primary malicious activities. If anti-debugging checks pass, a configuration file is decrypted for use by the malware. Persistence is then established via a JavaScript file in the Startup folder that simply launches the ransomware executable. Plaintext SMTP is used in order to send the decryption key to be used to the attacker's C2 server. This means that if an organization is capturing the contents of outbound emails, the decryption key could be obtained and used without paying the ransom. Finally, Triple DES encryption is performed and a ransom note requesting the victim email the attacker's to pay the ransomware is dropped on the system. For more information, see the Yoroi blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Protection

## Yara Rule
    
    
    rule JobCrypter_2104{  
      
    meta:   
    description = "Yara Rule for JobCrypter Ransomware - End of March 2021 "   
    author = "Yoroi Malware ZLab"   
    last_updated = "2021-04-13"   
    tlp = "white"   
    category = "informational"  
      
    strings:   
    $a1 = { 3B C2 8D A0 ?? 00 }   
    $a2 = { 2A 28 C5 00 00 06 20 03 }   
    $a3 = { 20 BC 01 00 00 FE 0E 04 00 38 }   
    $a4 = { AB 39 00 00 83 54 00 00 8C }   
    $a5 = { 69 44 F4 E8 B7 78 50 EF }   
    $a6 = { 0E 03 6F 4F 02 00 06 }   
    $a7 = { 71 70 F4 48 B9 68 18 65 }   
      
    condition:   
    uint16(0) == 0x5A4D and 4 of them  
      
    } 

# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.
  * Perform endpoint scans using the provided Yara Rule to detect existing infections.



# Reference

  * <https://yoroi.company/research/ransomware-micro-criminals-are-still-out-here-and-growing/>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Ares: Kronos Banking Trojan Evolved
Zscaler reports on a new variant of the Kronos Banking Trojan dubbed Ares. Though still in development, this addition to the trojan provides new capabilities as explained in the article.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Ares: Kronos Banking Trojan Evolved
Zscaler reports on a new variant of the Kronos Banking Trojan dubbed Ares. Though still in development, this addition to the trojan provides new capabilities as explained in the article.

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Trojan




# Overview

Kronos, around since 2014, has undergone changes throughout its history. Now word comes about the latest upgrade to the trojan, Ares. Ares is malware with new capabilities such as information exfiltration. Ares is used in conjunction with another variant dubbed Osiris. The two malwares utilize a packer written in C++ called DarkCrypter. This version of DarkCrypter should not be confused with the commercially available packer, also called DarkCrypter. In the new variant, the first 41 strings match older Kronos variants as well as the addition of eight new strings to detect analysis tools such as sandboxes. There are, at the time of this writing, two versions of the packer. The first decrypts using Blowfish. The key size for this decryption is not the standard Blowfish size - 4 through 56 bytes vs. 288 byte fixed length. The second variant uses an embedding technique that uses a compressed format rather than Blowfish encryption. This compression algorithm is identical to Ares. The packer shows itself to be a bitmap image header. This is an obvious ruse and can be seen in photos within the article. Additionally, the actor behind the malware uses BMPack, so named by Zscaler. This packer uses an XOR-based algorithm as well as RC4. Upon decryption, the file appears as a static bitmap. Each structure within the decompressed file holds a different section of a PE file that is stitched together by a custom loader and is, subsequently, executed. Ares itself is under development as evidenced by the constant testing of new plugins and web injects. An embedded DLL module is compressed and placed within the binary. An export is loaded and used to establish persistence by creating a scheduled task that executes every two hours. Though sharing most of the code with Kronos and Osiris, there are several differences. At present, most of the samples of Ares do not communicate with a C2 over TOR. The removal of the TOR component could be used to reduce the malware size. The Ares stealer attempts to extract information from FTP clients, VPN clients, web browsers, cryptocurrency wallets applications, instant messenger clients, and email clients. Ares supports the commands as Kronos and Osiris though some commands have been modified. Further technical details can be found in the article located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.zscaler.com/blogs/security-research/ares-malware-grandson-kronos-banking-trojan>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Malware Leveraging XMRig Miner
One method of turning a profit during attacks is to perform crypto-mining activities; Kaspersky analyzes three malware families leveraging the open-source XMRig miner for this purpose.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware, Cryptominer




# Overview

Kaspersky published a blog post detailing three malware families exploiting XMRig miner for monetary gain. The first malware family discussed is dubbed "ransominer" due to its combined use of ransomware and crypto-mining. The infection chain involves a common Trojan installed on a victim's machine with the purpose of installing administration programs, adding a new user, and opening RDP access. A ransomware payload is then executed, followed by the XMRig loader; at the same time the user is seeing the ransom note while Monero mining is being performed in the background. The second family discussed is the Prometei backdoor. After a few years in operation, it expanded its capabilities by also distributing XMRig. After brute-forcing MS SQL credentials and gaining access, PowerShell scripts are run and privileges are elevated. Purple Fox and Prometei are both installed on the host. Lastly, the XMRig miner is downloaded from the C2 server and executed. The third family is the Cliptomaner miner. This malware is similar to the other families but has the added functionality of replacing crypto-wallet addresses in the clipboard. Additionally, instead of being written in a compiled language, it is fully written in AutoIT. For more information, see the Kaspersky blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.



# Reference

  * <https://securelist.com/miner-xmrig/99151/>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: The BackdoorDiplomacy APT Group
ESET has published a report on an APT group they have named BackdoorDiplomacy. The group has been active since at least 2017 and primarily targets diplomatic organizations located in Africa and the Middle East.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware, APT




# Overview

According to a report published by ESET, BackdoorDiplomacy is an APT group that primarily targets diplomatic organizations located in Africa and the Middle East. The group is also known, to a lesser degree, to have targeted telecommunication companies in the aforementioned geographies. BackdoorDiplomacy typically exploits vulnerabilities in Internet-accessible web-based applications and the management interfaces of network equipment to gain initial access to an environment and install a webshell. Examples of the vulnerabilities exploited by the group include an F5 BIP-IP vulnerability (CVE-2020-5902), unspecified Microsoft Exchange server vulnerabilities, and a misconfigured Plesk server. The webshell is used to install the group's principle backdoor which ESET refers to as Turian. The group's preferred method for installing Turian is to hijack DLL search orders. There are Windows and Linux versions of Turian and ESET notes that Turian is likely to be an evolution of the Quarian backdoor which has been previously used in attacks against diplomatic entities. Another binary installed by the group is used to detect removable media and copy their contents to the recycle bin on the system's main drive. Once a foothold has been established, a number of well-known tools are used to facilitate reconnaissance and lateral movement. The toolset is known to include EarthWorm, Mimikatz, SafetyKatz, Nbtscan, NetCat, PortQry, SMBTouch, EternalBlue, DoublePulsar, EternalRocks, and EternalSynergy. There are noted similarities between the TTPs used by BackdoorDiplomacy and a number of other Asian groups. The technical details are available from the report linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.welivesecurity.com/2021/06/10/backdoordiplomacy-upgrading-quarian-turian/>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Increase in Travel-Themed Phishing
As the world reopens to travel, it is not surprising that Palo Alto has identified an increase in travel-themed phishing, which they detail in a recent blog post.
output:
# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Phishing
  *  **Target:** Travel industry and customers
  *  **Lure:** Travel notice or services
  *  **Payload:** Phishing link
  *  **Compromised Data:** Account credentials, payment information, customer data
  *  **Post-compromise Actions:** Varies



# Overview

Palo Alto published a blog post discussing an increase in travel-themed phishing campaigns, aligning with an increase in ability to travel again post-COVID. Their data specifically revealed an increase in travel-themed phishing URLs being created since early 2021. These URLs were likely related to numerous campaigns, with the blog post providing two specific examples. The first is the use of these travel-themed URLs to assist in the delivery of the Dridex malware. The URL is used by a macro in an Excel spreadsheet that is either attached to the email or hosted on Dropbox. The researchers also observed a campaign targeting travel industry organizations and customers with Firebase-hosted web applications. The type of data that may be accessed during these phishing attempts ranges from account credentials to customer data to payment information. For more information, see the Palo Alto blog post in the References section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/64127996/Increase%20in%20Travel-Themed%20Phishing%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1631893249357&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques and phishing emails (M1017).
  * Restrict Web-Based Content (M1021).



# References

  * <https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/travel-themed-phishing/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1204 - User Execution  
T1204.001 - Malicious Link  
T1204.002 - Malicious File

 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1566 - Phishing  
T1566.001 - Spearphishing Attachment  
T1566.002 - Spearphishing Link

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Oracle Security Alert Advisory - CVE-2020-14750
Oracle has published a security alert addressing a remote code execution vulnerability in Oracle WebLogic Server.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability, Exploit




# Overview

Oracle has published a security alert addressing a remote code execution vulnerability in Oracle WebLogic Server, CVE-2020-14750. This alert was published with an out-of-band update due to the fact exploit code as been publicly released. This, combined with its severity and impact, makes it likely to be exploited by threat actors. CVE-2020-14750 also allows for code execution by a remote, unauthenticated attacker and has been assigned a CVSS 3.1 score of 9.8. Versions 10.3.6.0.0, 12.1.3.0.0, 12.2.1.3.0, 12.2.1.4.0, 14.1.1.0.0 of Oracle WebLogic server are affected and a patch has been released to fix the vulnerability. The advisory notes that this vulnerability is also related to CVE-2020-14882, which was addressed in the October 2020 Critical Patch Update. We recommend reviewing the Oracle security advisory, linked to in the Reference section, and applying any applicable patches as soon as possible.

# CVEs

  * A complete list of CVEs can be found here: [ CVEs.txt](/download/attachments/32147227/Oracle%20Security%20Alert%20Advisory%20-%20CVE-2020-14750%20CVEs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1604347327763&api=v2)




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://www.oracle.com/security-alerts/alert-cve-2020-14750.html>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Yanluowang Ransomware Is Now Code-Signed
Trend Micro have investigated some samples of a new ransomware named Yanluowang. They discovered that these samples were code-signed, and included the ability to disable backup and database processes to increase the severity of the ransomware attack.
output:
# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Ransomware
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Unknown
  *  **Associated Payloads:** Yanluowang
  *  **Targets:** United States Corporations
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Unknown
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Encryption, Ransom



# Overview

Trend Micro has discovered samples of the new ransomware known as "Yanluowang", which are code-signed with a valid signature. This ransomware was recently discovered and seems to be targeting US corporations from at least August 2021. It is currently unknown how this ransomware initially infects systems, but Trend Micro speculates that it would be executed via RDP, due to the requirement for certain arguments upon execution. The fact that these samples are code-signed allows the ransomware to appear legitimate to the victim's machine, enabling it to bypass some security measures. Upon execution, the ransomware encrypts files in specified filepaths before dropping the ransomware note. It also terminates processes associated with managing and backing up databases using the Windows API. Finally, it forcefully terminates any virtual machines that are running on the host. For more information, please see the blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/74056215/Yanluowang%20Ransomware%20Is%20Now%20Code-Signed%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1639654165236&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior (M1040). 



# References

  * <https://www.trendmicro.com/en_us/research/21/l/yanluowang-ransomware-code-signed-terminates-database-processes.html>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1587.001 - Malware  
T1587.002 - Code Signing Certificates  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1036 - Masquerading  
T1070 - Indicator Removal on Host  
T1562 - Impair Defenses  
  
 **Impact - TA0040**  
T1486 - Data Encrypted for Impact
