instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Compromised Docker Hub Accounts Abused for TeamTNT Cryptomining
TeamTNT is known for targeting exposed Docker REST APIs in order to carry out cryptomining campaigns. Trend Micro published a blog post detailing a recent TeamTNT campaign using compromised Docker Hub accounts to spread host their malicious containers.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Compromised Docker Hub Accounts Abused for TeamTNT Cryptomining
TeamTNT is known for targeting exposed Docker REST APIs in order to carry out cryptomining campaigns. Trend Micro published a blog post detailing a recent TeamTNT campaign using compromised Docker Hub accounts to spread host their malicious containers.

# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Cryptominer
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** TeamTNT
  *  **Associated Payloads:** Malicious scripts, cryptominer
  *  **Targets:** Docker servers
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Exposed Docker REST API
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Cryptomining, lateral movement



# Overview

Trend Micro published a blog post analyzing a recent TeamTNT campaign abusing Docker Hub for their malicious activities. They begin by creating a container on a remote host via exposed Docker REST APIs. This container is retrieved from Docker Hub, via accounts either compromised or owned by TeamTNT. Upon deployment these Docker images execute a malicious script that installs various tools to be used for post-compromise activities. These include tools for lateral movement, such as masscan and zmap. Ultimately, TeamTNT will carry out their goal of installing a cryptocurrency miner in order to turn a profit. During these attacks, the threat actors carry out container escapes to gain access to the host system. Persistence is established by adding new SSH key pairs to the authorized_keys file. Trend Micro reported the abused accounts to Docker, who have since disabled them. For more information, see the Trend Micro blog post in the References section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/70222380/Compromised%20Docker%20Hub%20Accounts%20Abused%20for%20TeamTNT%20Cryptomining%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1636572784047&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Use multi-factor authentication wherever possible. (M1032)
  * Limit communications with the container service to local Unix sockets or remote access via SSH. Require secure port access to communicate with the APIs over TLS by disabling unauthenticated access to the Docker API and Kubernetes API Server (M1035).



# References

  * <https://www.trendmicro.com/en_us/research/21/k/compromised-docker-hub-accounts-abused-for-cryptomining-linked-t.html>

 **Persistence - TA0003**  
T1098 - Account Manipulation  
T1098.004 - SSH Authorized Keys  
  
 **Privilege Escalation - TA0004**  
T1611 - Escape to Host  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1027 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1018 - Remote System Discovery  
T1613 - Container and Resource Discovery  
  
 **Lateral Movement - TA0008**  
T1021 - Remote Services  
T1021.004 - SSH

T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
T1071.001 - Web Protocols  
  
 **Impact - TA0040**  
T1496 - Resource Hijacking

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: High Profile Egyptian Targets Victim of Predator Spyware
A high profile Egyptian politician and an unnamed TV presenter have both been victims of spyware called Predator. Further to this, the politician was found to also be infected with Pegasus spyware. This attack has been analyzed by Citizen Lab researchers.
output:
# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Spyware
  *  **Targets:** Egyptian Public Figures
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** Pegasus, Predator
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Phishing
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Data Theft



# Overview

Citizen Lab researchers have identified two high-profile targets who have been compromised by spyware. These targets are both Egyptian, with an exiled politician and a popular talk show host both being targeted. Both of these targets were infected with Predator spyware, which is developed by Cytrox, a low-profile developer. The politician's mobile device was simultaneously infected with Pegasus spyware, developed by the Israeli company NSO Group. Both malware samples were being operated by different threat actors, which the researchers speculate are governmental. The malware infected what was then the latest version of iOS, and was spread using phishing links sent via Whatsapp. Upon analysis, the Predator malware was found to be persistent after reboot using the iOS automation features. This works by triggering the automation when certain built-in apps are opened. This then checks the battery level and downloads malicious JavaScript code which presumably reinstalls the malware. The researchers were able to obtain both an Android and iOS version of the malware from the C2 domain observed in the attack. Further details can be found in the article located within the Reference section below. 

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/74056540/High%20Profile%20Egyptian%20Targets%20Victim%20of%20Predator%20Spyware%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1641310852598&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Users should be encouraged to only install apps from authorized app stores, which are less likely to contain malicious repackaged apps (M1011).

  * Implement an enterprise mobility management (EMM), also known as mobile device management (MDM) (M1012).

  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques (M1017).

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).



# References

  * <https://citizenlab.ca/2021/12/pegasus-vs-predator-dissidents-doubly-infected-iphone-reveals-cytrox-mercenary-spyware/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Initial Access - TA0027**  
T1476 - Deliver Malicious App via Other Means  
  
 **Execution - TA0041**  
T1605 - Command-Line Interface  
  
 **Persistence - TA0028**  
T1603 - Scheduled Task/Job  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0030**  
T1406 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
T1447 - Delete Device Data  
  
 **Discovery - TA0032**  
T1418 - Application Discovery  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0037**  
T1436 - Commonly Used Port  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0036**  
T1436 - Commonly Used Port

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: DTPacker - A Commodity .NET Packer
A report from Proofpoint provides an analysis of a two-stage commodity .NET packer Proofpoint has named DTPacker.
output:
# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Packer
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Various APT and cybercrime actors.
  *  **Associated Payloads:** DTPacker, Agent Tesla, AsyncRAT, Ave Maria, and FormBook.
  *  **Targets:** Unspecified.
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Email with malicious attachments.
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Unspecified.
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

DTPacker is a two-stage commodity .NET packer that Proofpoint analyzed and named. Since 2020, tt has been used in many campaigns conducted by APT actors such as TA2536 and TA2715 and other cybercriminals. Many of the campaigns used emails that typically had an attached document or an executable in a compressed form that are used to deploy DTPacker. When DTPacker is executed, it decodes data contained in the executable or downloads it from a remote host using HTTP requests. Once all the required data has been downloaded, the resulting DLL is used to extract and execute the payload. The payloads delivered in the campaigns are varied but are known to have included information stealers and RATs including Agent Tesla, AsyncRAT, Ave Maria, and FormBook. While the Proofpoint report is focused on the analysis of DTPacker rather than the campaigns it has been used in, it does provide some information on one campaign that used websites for soccer clubs and their fans and later used Liverpool football club themed download locations to host the final payloads. Further information is available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/74057831/DTPacker%20-%20A%20Commodity%20.NET%20Packer%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1643597376176&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques and phishing emails (M1017).
  * Restrict Web-Based Content (M1021).



# References

  * <https://www.proofpoint.com/us/blog/threat-insight/dtpacker-net-packer-curious-password-1>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: ShellX Backdoor Highlights ITG01’s Renewed Activity
X-Force Threat Intelligence (XFTI) analysts have discovered new malware samples belonging to ITG01, also known as APT10, including a new backdoor we have dubbed ShellX.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Backdoor, APT




# Overview

 These new malware samples, discovered by X-Force in VirusTotal, share the same DLL hijacking technique and bear many coding similarities to the HelloEx backdoor, leading us to also attribute these new samples to ITG01 (aka APT10, Stone Panda, and MenuPass). The discovery of these new samples bolsters our assessment that ITG01 has reactivated operations with new malware after maintaining a low profile in 2019 and 2020 following public revelations of their “Cloud Hopper” campaign against Managed Service Providers (MSPs). The full story, including indicators of compromise, is available to IBM X-Force Premier Threat Intelligence clients at the link below. 

# Indicators of Compromise

Indicators of compromise are available to IBM X-Force Premier Threat Intelligence clients at the link below.   


# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * Premier Threat Intelligence clients can read more and see the indicators at: <https://station.trustar.co/constellation/reports/8fdaea0d-68e6-43c3-9a91-eef6f2712725>

  * To learn more about X-Force Premier Threat Intelligence, visit: <https://www.ibm.com/security/services/threat-intelligence>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Pirate Bay Clones Serve Malicious Ads And Fake Torrents
CyberNews researchers have been monitoring sites impersonating the Pirate Bay. These sites use malicious advertising and false torrents to spread malicious javascript which can be used to spy on victims and steal data.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Pirate Bay Clones Serve Malicious Ads And Fake Torrents
CyberNews researchers have been monitoring sites impersonating the Pirate Bay. These sites use malicious advertising and false torrents to spread malicious javascript which can be used to spy on victims and steal data.

# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Malvertising
  *  **Targets:** Unknown
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** Unknown
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Malicious Ads
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Advertisement, Spying



# Overview

CyberNews security researchers have discovered a series of websites impersonating The Pirate Bay - a popular website for torrenting pirated media. These sites serve malicious adverts which are being used to distribute malicious files. The researchers discovered five of these impersonation domains, with one of these seeing more than six million monthly visitors. All of these sites have not been flagged in tools such as VirusTotal. All of these fake sites layer malicious adverts on the page meaning that if the user clicks anywhere on the page, they could trigger three or more. On top of these adverts, the torrent files being distributed were found to be potentially malicious JavaScript files. The site generates these files using the victim's query, automatically renaming them to fit whatever the user is searching for. The resulting download contains scripts that can spy on the user and serve them intrusive and potentially malicious adverts. For more information, please see the link in the reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/74058542/Pirate%20Bay%20Clones%20Serve%20Malicious%20Ads%20And%20Fake%20Torrents%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1644598060018&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques and phishing emails (M1017).
  * Restrict Web-Based Content (M1021)
  * Set PowerShell execution policy to execute only signed scripts (M1045).



# References

  * <https://cybernews.com/security/the-pirate-bay-clones-target-millions-of-users-with-malware-and-malicious-ads/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1583.001 - Domains  
  
 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1189 - Drive-by Compromise  
T1566.002 - Spearphishing Link  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059.007 - JavaScript  
T1204.001 - Malicious Link

These sites serve malicious adverts which are being used to distribute malicious files. The researchers discovered five of these impersonation domains, with one of these seeing more than six million monthly visitors. All of these sites have not been flagged in tools such as VirusTotal. All of these fake sites layer malicious adverts on the page meaning that if the user clicks anywhere on the page, they could trigger three or more. On top of these adverts, the torrent files being distributed were found to be potentially malicious JavaScript files. The site generates these files using the victim's query, automatically renaming them to fit whatever the user is searching for. The resulting download contains scripts that can spy on the user and serve them intrusive and potentially malicious adverts. For more information, please see the link in the reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/74058542/Pirate%20Bay%20Clones%20Serve%20Malicious%20Ads%20And%20Fake%20Torrents%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1644598060018&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques and phishing emails (M1017).
  * Restrict Web-Based Content (M1021)
  * Set PowerShell execution policy to execute only signed scripts (M1045).



# References

  * <https://cybernews.com/security/the-pirate-bay-clones-target-millions-of-users-with-malware-and-malicious-ads/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1583.001 - Domains  
  
 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1189 - Drive-by Compromise  
T1566.002 - Spearphishing Link  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059.007 - JavaScript  
T1204.001 - Malicious Link

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: LNKR Malware Spread Through Malicious Chrome Extensions
Netskope Threat Labs have published an analysis of the LNKR malware used to spy on victims and serve potentially malicious ads into their browsers.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: LNKR Malware Spread Through Malicious Chrome Extensions
Netskope Threat Labs have published an analysis of the LNKR malware used to spy on victims and serve potentially malicious ads into their browsers.

# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Adware
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Unknown
  *  **Associated Payloads:** LNKR
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Malicious Google Chrome Extension
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Exfiltrate data, Ad injection



# Overview

Netskope Threat Labs have discovered a campaign using malware known as LNKR. First seen in 2019, the malware allows the actors to inject adverts into the victim's browser. In 2021, this campaign is still active and is more malicious than other types of adware. In addition to ad injection, the malware allows the threat actors to exfiltrate search data, redirect the user to any other page, and inject javascript from external sources. This last function is particularly dangerous, as the attacker can inject any script into the page, such as a script to steal credit card data. The malware is normally distributed through malicious Google Chrome extensions. The malware is also able to self replicate by injecting itself into web pages where the user has write permissions. Once the user is infected, the malware collects data on the user's search and shopping habits and exfiltrates that to a C2 server. This information is used to inject ads and to monetize the user's browsing activity. Further details are available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/72155229/LNKR%20Malware%20Spread%20Through%20Malicious%20Chrome%20Extensions%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1637933733101&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc (M1021).
  * Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries (M1031).
  * Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking (M1038).
  * Limit Software Installation - Block users or groups from installing unapproved software (M1033).



# References

  * <https://www.netskope.com/blog/black-friday-is-coming-and-lnkr-malware-might-be-watching-you>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1189 - Drive-by Compromise  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
T1059.007 - JavaScript  
T1204 - User Execution  
  
 **Persistence - TA0003**  
T1176 - Browser Extensions  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1036 - Masquerading  
  
 **Collection - TA0009**  
T1056 - Input Capture  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0010**  
T1041 - Exfiltration Over C2 Channel  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
T1071.001 - Web Protocols

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Credential Phishing Using Attractive Lures
A Twitter thread from Microsoft Security Intelligence discusses an active credential phishing campaign. The campaign uses timely lures in an effort to obtain sensitive information from unsuspecting users.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Phishing




# Overview

Using attractive lures such as remote work, password resets, help desk tickets, and conferencing information, a phishing campaign has been uncovered by Microsoft's Security Intelligence team. On a Twitter feed, the team observed redirector sites with unique subdomains for each individual target. Typically, the subdomain contains the recipient name and organizational domain name. The subdomains are added to compromised domains and the actual phishing URLs contain an extra dot in the top-level domain. A Base64-encoded email address of the recipient is also included. The lure is successful typically because of the inclusion of the unique subdomain. With each subdomain being unique, this indicates a large number of URLs in play with this phishing campaign. Should the redirector be from a sandbox, the visitor is sent to the legitimate site in an effort to evade automated analysis. This campaign is considered sophisticated due to the use of heavy obfuscation in the HTML code. Further information can be found in the Twitter thread located within the Reference section below.

# CVEs

  * N/A




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * [https://twitter.com/MsftSecIntel/status/1328481017842212864](https://twitter\[.\]com/MsftSecIntel/status/1328481017842212864)

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Scans for Vulnerable Oracle WebLogic Servers
An entry in the InfoSec Handlers Diary reports unknown actors are scanning for Oracle WebLogic Servers that do not have the patch for the vulnerability CVE-2020-14882 applied.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

In Oracle's October Critical Patch Update (October 20th, 2020), one of the vulnerabilities addressed is CVE-2020-14882 in Oracle's WebLogic Server. Successfully exploited, the vulnerability could allow a remote attacker to execute code arbitrary code on a victim system.  The scans began after proof-of-concept code for the vulnerability was made public. The honeypots that detected the scans do not at the time report as vulnerable, so they received no follow on attempts to exploit the vulnerability. The scans have reportedly slowed, but this may be due to all IPv4 addresses having been scanned. A warning note in the diary entry states "If you find a vulnerable server in your network: Assume it has been compromised". Further details are available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://isc.sans.edu/diary/rss/26734>

  * <https://www.oracle.com/security-alerts/cpuoct2020.html>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: South Korean and Australian Users Targeted with Malicious Emails Disguised as Accounting Ledgers
A malspam campaign spotted by Bitdefender is leveraging tax season in South Korea as a phishing lure.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware, RAT




# Overview

Bitdefender published a brief blog post detailing a malspam campaign targeting users in South Korea and Australia. The body of the email simply claims an "account ledger" is attached for review, enticing the recipient to open the malicious file. This theme aligns with upcoming filing deadlines for income tax returns in South Korea, increasing the chances a user may believe these claims. Opening the attached file leads to the execution of malware on the victim system. Specifically, a remote access Trojan (RAT) is installed, allowing the attackers capabilities such as accessing sensitive information, taking screenshots, monitoring user activity, and downloading additional payloads. For more information, see the Bitdefender blog post in the Reference section.

# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://hotforsecurity.bitdefender.com/blog/threat-actors-target-south-korean-and-aussie-users-with-malicious-emails-disguised-as-accounting-ledgers-25835.html>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: NCAS Malware Analysis Report AR20-239A - ECCENTRICBANDWAGON
A Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency malware analysis report, AR20-239A, has been published through the National Cyber Awareness System. The report is a joint publication from Department of Homeland Security, the Federal Bureau of Investigation, and the Department of Defense. The report provides information on the North Korean RAT, ECCENTRICBANDWAGON.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware, APT




# Overview

 **From the Malware Analysis Report (AR20-239A)**  
 **MAR-10301706-1.v1 - North Korean Remote Access Tool: ECCENTRICBANDWAGON**  
  


This Malware Analysis Report (MAR) is the result of analytic efforts between the Department of Homeland Security (DHS), the Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI), and the Department of Defense (DoD). Working with U.S. Government partners, DHS, FBI, and DoD identified Remote Access Tool (RAT) malware variants used by the North Korean government. This malware variant has been identified as ECCENTRICBANDWAGON. The U.S. Government refers to malicious cyber activity by the North Korean government as HIDDEN COBRA. For more information on HIDDEN COBRA activity, visit https://www.us-cert.gov/hiddencobra.

FBI has high confidence that HIDDEN COBRA actors are using malware variants in conjunction with proxy servers to maintain a presence on victim networks and to further network exploitation. DHS, FBI, and DoD are distributing this MAR to enable network defense and reduce exposure to North Korean government malicious cyber activity.

This MAR includes malware descriptions related to HIDDEN COBRA, suggested response actions and recommended mitigation techniques. Users or administrators should flag activity associated with the malware and report the activity to the Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) or the FBI Cyber Watch (CyWatch), and give the activity the highest priority for enhanced mitigation.

This report looks at malware samples known as ECCENTRICBANDWAGON. This family of malware is used as a reconnaissance tool. The samples in this report are used for keylogging and screen capture functionality. The samples are very similar, but differ slightly in the location that they store the key logs and screenshots. Some variants have RC4 encrypted strings within the executable and conduct a simple, ineffective cleanup, whereas others do not.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. for Yara Rules.



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ncas/analysis-reports/ar20-239a>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Democratic Voters Under Threat From Hate Group
Registered voters of the Democratic Party in Florida are being sent emails from the right-wing hate group "The Proud Boys." Proofpoint reports on the threats made to voters in a clear case of voter intimidation.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Extortion




# Overview

On October 20, 2020, Democratic voters in Florida were purportedly sent intimidating emails from the right-wing hate group "The Proud Boys." The emails contain threats of "coming after you" if the recipient did not vote for Donald Trump on Election Day. The email continues to implore the victim to change their registration to Republican in a sign of compliance. The group further explains they have access to the entire voting infrastructure. Other emails contain a link to a Proud Boys video supposedly hacking the Alaska voter rolls and filling out absentee ballots. The emails are sent from a specific IP and email domain. The intended victims of this particular email both reside in Florida. A copy of the video was obtained and analyzed. It is not clear whether the video is showing any actual activity in the Alaska voter rolls, but the technique depicted is convincing enough and could lead to successful intimidation. A subsequent report from Reuters purports to have evidence that this threat actually originated from Iranian hackers. Due to errors in the video, government analysts were able to identify the actors as Iranian. Analysis of the incident showed the email address that was allegedly from the far-right group, The Proud Boys, was actually inauthentic. The video contained snippets of code, file paths, file names, and IP address that enabled the researchers to identify the actors as not of the Proud Boys faction. Particularly, the IP address seen was previously linked to Iranian hacker activity. Further information can be found in the article located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * N/A  




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.proofpoint.com/us/blog/threat-insight/media-coverage-doesnt-deter-actor-threatening-democratic-voters>

  * <https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-cyber-iran-exclusive/exclusive-dumb-mistake-exposed-iranian-hand-behind-fake-proud-boy-u-s-election-emails-sources-idUSKBN2772YL?il=0>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: BlackSoul Delivered By ReconHellcat
QuoIntelligence reports on a new malware package, BlackSoul, that is being distributed by a threat-actor called ReconHellcat. The targeted campaign appears be using spear-phishing as a delivery mechanism.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Threat-Actor, Spear-Phishing, RAT



# Overview

QuoIntelligence reports on what appears to be a targeted campaign, possibly spread through the use of spear-phishing emails with a weaponized CAB file attachment. The CAB's file name is patterned after the file names one would expect in a download from the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST). The threat-actor is attempting to gain access to victims by installing the remote access Trojan, BlackSoul, on the victim system. The attachment is actually a loader that uses obfuscation techniques previously used by ReconHellcat to deliver the BlackWater malware. The loader downloads an executable and a DLL from the C2 server and then displays a legitimate document from NIST as a decoy. BlackSoul is a minimalistic RAT that accepts only a few commands. Although QuoIntelligence was unable to determine the exact targets of this campaign, they suspect, from the NIST-themed lure, the intended targets may be government related. For full technical details, please refer to the link in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/35719522/BlackSoul%20Delivered%20By%20ReconHellcat%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1610048685752&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

parsed_raw_data.xfe_q:
BlackSoul Delivered By ReconHellcat
QuoIntelligence reports on a new malware package, BlackSoul, that is being distributed by a threat-actor called ReconHellcat. The targeted campaign appears be using spear-phishing as a delivery mechanism.
parsed_raw_data.xfe_report:
# Threat Type

  * Malware, Threat-Actor, Spear-Phishing, RAT



# Overview

QuoIntelligence reports on what appears to be a targeted campaign, possibly spread through the use of spear-phishing emails with a weaponized CAB file attachment. The CAB's file name is patterned after the file names one would expect in a download from the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST). The threat-actor is attempting to gain access to victims by installing the remote access Trojan, BlackSoul, on the victim system. The attachment is actually a loader that uses obfuscation techniques previously used by ReconHellcat to deliver the BlackWater malware. The loader downloads an executable and a DLL from the C2 server and then displays a legitimate document from NIST as a decoy. BlackSoul is a minimalistic RAT that accepts only a few commands. Although QuoIntelligence was unable to determine the exact targets of this campaign, they suspect, from the NIST-themed lure, the intended targets may be government related. For full technical details, please refer to the link in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/35719522/BlackSoul%20Delivered%20By%20ReconHellcat%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1610048685752&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://quointelligence.eu/2021/01/reconhellcat-uses-nist-theme-as-lure-to-deliver-new-blacksoul-malware/>

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.

CVE-2020-15795 - The DNS domain name label parsing functionality does not properly validate the names in DNS-responses. instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Adobe Security Updates March 2021
Adobe has released three security updates. The updates are for Framemaker, Creative Cloud Desktop Application, and Connect. Each of the updates address at least one vulnerability rated by Adobe as Critical.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

 The potential impact of successful exploitation of the most serious vulnerabilities is the remote execution of arbitrary code. Further details are available from the links below.

 **APSB21-14 Security Updates Available for Adobe Framemaker**  
Adobe has released a security update for Adobe Framemaker. This update addresses a critical vulnerability. Successful exploitation could lead to arbitrary code execution in the context of the current user.  
<https://helpx.adobe.com/security/products/framemaker/apsb21-14.html>

 **APSB21-18 Security update available for Adobe Creative Cloud Desktop Application**  
Adobe has released a security update for the Creative Cloud Desktop Application for Windows. This update resolves multiple critical vulnerabilities that could lead to arbitrary code execution in the context of current user.  
<https://helpx.adobe.com/security/products/creative-cloud/apsb21-18.html>

 **APSB21-19 Security updates available for Adobe Connect**  
Adobe has released a security update for Adobe Connect. This update resolves a critical and an important vulnerability. Successful exploitation could lead to arbitrary JavaScript execution within the context of the victim's browser.   
<https://helpx.adobe.com/security/products/connect/apsb21-19.html>

# CVEs

  * CVE-2021-21056, CVE-2021-21068, CVE-2021-21078, CVE-2021-21069, CVE-2021-21085, CVE-2021-21079, CVE-2021-21080, CVE-2021-21081 




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://helpx.adobe.com/security.html>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Atlassian Vulnerability Exploited To Spread Crypto-Miners
Check Point researchers have observed threat actors exploiting the recently disclosed Atlassian vulnerability. The threat actors are using this to target both Windows and Linux servers, with the intent to install crypto-mining malware.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

Summary
=======



Attack Details
==============

* **Threat Type:** Cryptominer
* **Targets:** Windows and Linux Machines Running Atlassian Confluence Server and Data Center application
* **Malware Family/Families:** Unknown
* **Initial Infection Vector:** Exploitation of CVE-2022-26134 vulnerability
* **Post-Compromise Actions:** Lateral movement, resource hijacking
* **Additional TTPs:**See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below

Overview
========

Check Point researchers have reported seeing the critical Atlassian vulnerability (CVE-2022-26134) first disclosed on 31 May 2022 being exploited in the wild. The vulnerability is in the Atlassian Confluence Server and Data Center application and allows a remote attacker to execute arbitrary code on the target machine. In the observed Linux attack, the vulnerability was used to inject a loading script that downloaded a bash file from a C2 folder and executed it. The script gains persistence and then attempts to move laterally using stolen SSH credentials, spreading itself throughout a network. The final payload is a crypto miner which steals system resources. The Windows attack worked similarly but did not automatically spread laterally. For more information, please see the link in the reference section.

Indicators of Compromise
========================

Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.

Recommendations
===============

* For a list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.

References
==========

* <https://blog.checkpoint.com/2022/06/09/crypto-miners-leveraging-atlassian-zero-day-vulnerability/>

MITRE ATT&CK Framework
======================

#### Tactics and Techniques:

**Resource Development - TA0042**  
   T1588.005 - Exploits  

**Initial Access - TA0001**  
 T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application  

**Execution - TA0002**  
   T1059.001 - PowerShell  
   T1059.004 - Unix Shell  

**Persistence - TA0003**  
 T1053 - Scheduled Task/Job  
   T1053.003 - Cron  
   T1053.005 - Scheduled Task  

**Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
 T1562 - Impair Defenses  

**Discovery - TA0007**  
   T1016.001 - Internet Connection Discovery  
 T1082 - System Information Discovery  

**Lateral Movement - TA0008**  
   T1021.004 - SSH  

**Command and Control - TA0011**  
 T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  

**Impact - TA0040**  
 T1496 - Resource Hijacking  

#### Mitigations:

**M1016:**  Vulnerability Scanning - Vulnerability scanning is used to find potentially exploitable software vulnerabilities to remediate them.  
**M1018:**  User Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.  
**M1021:**  Restrict Web-Based Content - Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc.  
**M1022:**  Restrict File and Directory Permissions - Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.  
**M1024:**  Restrict Registry Permissions - Restrict the ability to modify certain hives or keys in the Windows Registry.  
**M1026:**  Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.  
**M1027:**  Password Policies - Set and enforce secure password policies for accounts.  
**M1028:**  Operating System Configuration - Make configuration changes related to the operating system or a common feature of the operating system that result in system hardening against techniques.  
**M1030:**  Network Segmentation - Architect sections of the network to isolate critical systems, functions, or resources. Use physical and logical segmentation to prevent access to potentially sensitive systems and information. Use a DMZ to contain any internet-facing services that should not be exposed from the internal network. Configure separate virtual private cloud (VPC) instances to isolate critical cloud systems.  
**M1031:**  Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  
**M1032:**  Multi-factor Authentication - Use two or more pieces of evidence to authenticate to a system; such as username and password in addition to a token from a physical smart card or token generator.  
**M1033:**  Limit Software Installation - Block users or groups from installing unapproved software.  
**M1035:**  Limit Access to Resource Over Network - Prevent access to file shares, remote access to systems, unnecessary services. Mechanisms to limit access may include use of network concentrators, RDP gateways, etc.  
**M1037:**  Filter Network Traffic - Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic.  
**M1038:**  Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
**M1039:**  Environment Variable Permissions - Prevent modification of environment variables by unauthorized users and groups.  
**M1040:**  Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
**M1042:**  Disable or Remove Feature or Program - Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.  
**M1045:**  Code Signing - Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.  
**M1047:**  Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
**M1048:**  Application Isolation and Sandboxing - Restrict execution of code to a virtual environment on or in transit to an endpoint system.  
**M1049:**  Antivirus/Antimalware - Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software.  
**M1050:**  Exploit Protection - Use capabilities to detect and block conditions that may lead to or be indicative of a software exploit occurring.  
**M1051:**  Update Software - Perform regular software updates to mitigate exploitation risk.  
**M1054:**  Software Configuration - Implement configuration changes to software (other than the operating system) to mitigate security risks associated to how the software operates.  
**M1056:**  Pre-compromise - This category is used for any applicable mitigation activities that apply to techniques occurring before an adversary gains Initial Access, such as Reconnaissance and Resource Development techniques.

parsed_raw_data.xfe_q:
Atlassian Vulnerability Exploited To Spread Crypto-Miners
Check Point researchers have observed threat actors exploiting the recently disclosed Atlassian vulnerability. The threat actors are using this to target both Windows and Linux servers, with the intent to install crypto-mining malware.
parsed_raw_data.xfe_report:
Summary
=======



Attack Details
==============

* **Threat Type:** Cryptominer
* **Targets:** Windows and Linux Machines Running Atlassian Confluence Server and Data Center application
* **Malware Family/Families:** Unknown
* **Initial Infection Vector:** Exploitation of CVE-2022-26134 vulnerability
* **Post-Compromise Actions:** Lateral movement, resource hijacking
* **Additional TTPs:**See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below

Overview
========

Check Point researchers have reported seeing the critical Atlassian vulnerability (CVE-2022-26134) first disclosed on 31 May 2022 being exploited in the wild. The vulnerability is in the Atlassian Confluence Server and Data Center application and allows a remote attacker to execute arbitrary code on the target machine. In the observed Linux attack, the vulnerability was used to inject a loading script that downloaded a bash file from a C2 folder and executed it. The script gains persistence and then attempts to move laterally using stolen SSH credentials, spreading itself throughout a network. The final payload is a crypto miner which steals system resources. The Windows attack worked similarly but did not automatically spread laterally. For more information, please see the link in the reference section.

Indicators of Compromise
========================

Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.

Recommendations
===============

* For a list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.

==========

* <https://blog.checkpoint.com/2022/06/09/crypto-miners-leveraging-atlassian-zero-day-vulnerability/>

   T1059.004 - Unix Shell  

**Persistence - TA0003**  
 T1053 - Scheduled Task/Job  
   T1053.003 - Cron  
   T1053.005 - Scheduled Task  

**Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
 T1562 - Impair Defenses  

**Discovery - TA0007**  
   T1016.001 - Internet Connection Discovery  
 T1082 - System Information Discovery  

**Lateral Movement - TA0008**  
   T1021.004 - SSH  

**Command and Control - TA0011**  
 T1071 - Application Layer Protocol

 T1496 - Resource Hijacking

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: New Pastebin-like Service Used in Multiple Malware Campaigns
Attackers have begun using a new pastebin-like service, paste.nrecom.net, to store malware payloads. Loaders, which are delivered as attachments in phishing emails, are used to download the payloads. The attacks have targeted multiple industries sectors including banking, shipping, and supply chain.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Spear Phishing




# Overview

  
Threat actors have reconstructed the conventional tactic of using legitimate web services to host malware payloads by exploiting a new pastebin-like service, paste.nrecom.net. The service operates on the open-source package, [Stikked](https://github.com/claudehohl/Stikked). While the service allows only text pastes, binary data can be encoded and stored as plain text. According to Juniper Threat Labs, it is "the first time, we have seen threat actors use paste.nrecom.net". Juniper Threat Labs mentioned various malware that threat actors hosted on paste.nrecom.net including LimeRAT, W3Cryptolocker, and Redline Stealer. However, it was observed that AgentTesla is one of the more common malwares hosted on the service. Further details are available from the report linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.

  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.

  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.

  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.

  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.




# References

  * [https://blogs.juniper.net/en-us/threat-research/new-pastebin-like-service-used-in-multiple-malware-campaigns](https://blogs.juniper.net/en-us/threat-research/new-pastebin-like-service-used-in-multiple-malware-campaigns)

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: TA505 and CL0P
A posting on the Deutsche Telekom blog looks at the relationships between TA505 and the operators of the CL0P ransomware, along with some of their activities throughout the past year.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware, Ransomware, APT




# Overview

A posting on the Deutsche Telekom blog looks at some of the activities of TA505 and the operators of the CL0P ransomware throughout the past year. TA505 is also known as CHIMBORAZO, Evil Corp, GOLD TAHOE, Graceful Spider, Sector J04, and Temp.Warlock. The group known as FIN11 may also be TA505 or a subgroup of TA505. IBM X-Force tracks TA505 as ITG19. According to Deutsche Telekom, the operators of the CL0P ransomware may also be a subgroup of, or managed by, TA505. Another group known as Silence appears to have some form on relationship with TA505. These subgroups may also be simple clients of TA505 as TA505 tends to focus on gaining access to targets. They may then sell access to the victim's network or hand off to a subgroup or client who conducts further operations, such as the deployment of the CL0P ransomware. Deutsche Telekom noted three waves of spam from TA505 in 2020. The first wave ran January through February, the second June until September, and the last run in early December. TA505 spam is typically sent during weekdays, whereas the CL0P deployments more often occurred on a Friday or Saturday. The emails may contain a link or an HTML attachment, which lead the victim to a malicious document. If the document is opened and macros are enabled, the infection chain begins. CL0P ransoms tend to be based on the revenue of the victim company and a victim's sensitive data will have been exfiltrated prior to the ransomware being executed. The ransom notes are customized to the victim and the CL0P operators maintain a portal where victims can negotiate or pay ransoms. If a victim does not pay the ransom, their sensitive data will be made public on the portal. Further details are available from the Deutsche Telekom blog posting linked to in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.telekom.com/en/blog/group/article/inside-of-cl0p-s-ransomware-operation-615824>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: New Targeted RTM Attacks using Quoter Ransomware
The Russian-speaking RTM threat group has launched a new campaign against Russian transport and finance organizations. Kaspersky reports on their usage of new techniques to include ransomware and extortion.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: New Targeted RTM Attacks using Quoter Ransomware
The Russian-speaking RTM threat group has launched a new campaign against Russian transport and finance organizations. Kaspersky reports on their usage of new techniques to include ransomware and extortion.

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Ransomware




# Overview

Kaspersky has published a blog post analyzing a recent campaign carried out by the RTM threat group against Russian transport and finance organizations. The campaign, as with previous ones, begins with the distribution of a the RTM banker via business-themed phishing emails. With the banker installed, the attackers move laterally across the network with legitimate remote access tools, such as RMS, and custom malicious utilities. In the past, their ultimate goal was to access computers owned by accounting employees and use the banker payload to substitute banking details. However, in this campaign, if those attempts fail backup plans are in place to ensure they can still turn a profit. If the banker infection is unsuccessful, the first backup function is to install a ransomware payload dubbed "Quoter." The ransomware encrypts the files on all previously infected computers and leaves a ransom note. If, after a period of time, the ransom is not paid or the encryption fails, an extortion letter is then sent to the victims claiming that data has been stolen and that if a payment isn't made, the data will be posted publicly. Notably, organizations in Russia are not typically targeted with ransomware, so this is highly unusual behavior. For more information, see the SecureList blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://securelist.ru/new-targeted-attacks-rtm/100720/>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Analysis of Kinsing Malware's Use of Rootkit
The Kinsing malware has been evolving with capabilities added to increase the difficulty of detection. Trend Micro reports on the use of a rootkit in recent samples to carry out these objectives.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Analysis of Kinsing Malware's Use of Rootkit
The Kinsing malware has been evolving with capabilities added to increase the difficulty of detection. Trend Micro reports on the use of a rootkit in recent samples to carry out these objectives.

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Rootkit, Backdoor, Miner




# Overview

Trend Micro has published their analysis of a Kinsing malware sample using a rootkit to evade detection. As with most Kinsing infections, a series of shell scripts are used to install the malware. After downloading and installing the backdoor, miner, and rootkit payloads, along with disabling resource-intensive services and processes, the rootkit installation process begins. This process is only able to be performed if the malware has root privileges. First, the immutable file flag from /etc/ld.so.preload is removed. Then the rootkit is downloaded onto the system and a new /etc/[ld.so](http://ld.so).preload file is created with a link to the rootkit. Without root privileges, persistence is established via a system service. Additionally, a cron job is created so that the installation script is repeatedly downloaded and executed. The rootkit, once installed, provides a variety of functions to hide malicious activity, such as hiding files, running processes, and active network connections. With this in place, the attacker can carry out their backdoor and mining activities with a decreased risk of detection. For more information, see the Trend Micro blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.trendmicro.com/en_us/research/20/k/analysis-of-kinsing-malwares-use-of-rootkit.html>

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware, APT




# Overview

360 Core Security has published a blog post analyzing recent APT-C-35 (aka DoNot) activities. Many aspects of the recent campaign align with the TTPs seen in their April 2020 attacks researchers previously reported. The APK analyzed in this blog post is delivered via a fake version of LoveHabibi, a Pakistani dating website. Based on open graph source code within the webpage it appears one method of distribution was via Facebook. Furthermore, install paths seen associated with the malware indicate another infection vector was WhatsApp messages. In terms of the payload, its data stealing functionality remains largely the same. The code, however, has been modified in a couple of aspects. Firstly, it now uses Base64 encoding of strings in the code in order to evade detection. Secondly, it uses retrofit2 and FireBase for C2 communication instead of Socket. The researchers hypothesize there may be hundreds of victims, with the main targets located in Pakistan and the Kashmir region. From what little stolen data could be analyzed, it appears a number of the victims have a military background. Furthermore, the activity aligns with a report from the Pakistani government regarding cyber attacks against the Pakistan Armed Forces. For more information, see the 360 Core Security blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://blogs.360.cn/post/APT-C-35_target_at_armed_forces_in_Pakistan.html>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Black Basta Ransomware Now Targeting ESXi Systems
The Uptycs research team has published details on new behavior seen from Black Basta ransomware. In this article. they describe how the ransomware is now targeting ESXi servers.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Black Basta Ransomware Now Targeting ESXi Systems
The Uptycs research team has published details on new behavior seen from Black Basta ransomware. In this article. they describe how the ransomware is now targeting ESXi servers.

Summary
=======



Threat Details
==============

* **Malware Type:** Ransomware
* **Associated Threat Actors:** Black Basta
* **Associated Payloads:** Black Basta
* **Targets:** ESXi Servers
* **Initial Infection Vector:** Unknown
* **Post-Compromise Actions:** Data Encryption
* **Additional TTPs:**See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.

Overview
========

The Uptycs threat research team has been tracking the activities of the Black Basta ransomware group. The ransomware, which was first seen in April 2022, now appears to be infecting ESXi servers. Researchers were able to attribute this behavior to the group behind Black Basta due to the similarities in the encrypted file extension and the chat support link. In this example, the ransomware looks for the directory which stores the virtual machines on the server and encrypts the files present. Multithreading is used to speed up the encryption process, and the malware uses the fast 'chacha20' encryption algorithm. For more information, please see the link in the references section.

Indicators of Compromise
========================

Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.

Recommendations
===============

* For a list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.

References
==========

* <https://www.uptycs.com/blog/black-basta-ransomware-goes-cross-platform-now-targets-esxi-systems>

MITRE ATT&CK Framework
======================

**Execution - TA0002**  
 T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  

**Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
 T1027 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
 T1112 - Modify Registry  
   T1562.001 - Disable or Modify Tools  

**Discovery - TA0007**  
 T1082 - System Information Discovery  
 T1083 - File and Directory Discovery  

**Impact - TA0040**  
 T1486 - Data Encrypted for Impact  
 T1489 - Service Stop  
 T1490 - Inhibit System Recovery  

#### Mitigations:

**M1018:**  User Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.  
**M1021:**  Restrict Web-Based Content - Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc.  
**M1022:**  Restrict File and Directory Permissions - Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.  
**M1024:**  Restrict Registry Permissions - Restrict the ability to modify certain hives or keys in the Windows Registry.  
**M1026:**  Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.  
**M1028:**  Operating System Configuration - Make configuration changes related to the operating system or a common feature of the operating system that result in system hardening against techniques.  
**M1030:**  Network Segmentation - Architect sections of the network to isolate critical systems, functions, or resources. Use physical and logical segmentation to prevent access to potentially sensitive systems and information. Use a DMZ to contain any internet-facing services that should not be exposed from the internal network. Configure separate virtual private cloud (VPC) instances to isolate critical cloud systems.  
**M1033:**  Limit Software Installation - Block users or groups from installing unapproved software.  
**M1038:**  Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
**M1039:**  Environment Variable Permissions - Prevent modification of environment variables by unauthorized users and groups.  
**M1040:**  Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
**M1042:**  Disable or Remove Feature or Program - Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.  
**M1045:**  Code Signing - Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.  
**M1047:**  Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
**M1049:**  Antivirus/Antimalware - Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software.  
**M1053:**  Data Backup - Take and store data backups from end user systems and critical servers. Ensure backup and storage systems are hardened and kept separate from the corporate network to prevent compromise.  
**M1054:**  Software Configuration - Implement configuration changes to software (other than the operating system) to mitigate security risks associated to how the software operates.

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Microsoft Security Update for Edge
Microsoft released a security update for its Chromium-based Edge browser that addresses six CVE-numbered vulnerabilities.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Microsoft Security Update for Edge
Microsoft released a security update for its Chromium-based Edge browser that addresses six CVE-numbered vulnerabilities.

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

A security update for Microsoft's Chromium-based Edge browser has been released. Six CVE-numbered vulnerabilities are addressed in the update. The most serious of the vulnerabilities, if successfully exploited, could potentially allow a remote attacker to execute arbitrary code on an affected system. Further details are available from the links in the Reference section below.

# CVEs

  * CVE-2021-21194, CVE-2021-21195, CVE-2021-21196, CVE-2021-21197, CVE-2021-21198, CVE-2021-21199 




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://msrc.microsoft.com/update-guide/>

  * <https://msrc.microsoft.com/update-guide/releaseNote/2021-Apr>

  * <https://msrc.microsoft.com/update-guide/vulnerability/CVE-2021-21199>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Latest Version of IceXLoader Analyzed
The malware loader IceXLoader is now at version 3.0, and Fortinet has written an article discussing the technical details of its behaviors. It has been seen dropping cryptocurrency miner malware and infostealer malware.
output:
Summary
=======



Threat Details
==============

* **Malware Type:** Loader
* **Associated Threat Actors:** Unknown
* **Associated Payloads:** IceXLoader 3.0
* **Targets:** Windows Users
* **Initial Infection Vector:** Phishing
* **Post-Compromise Actions:** Load Malware
* **Additional TTPs:**See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below

Overview
========

Fortinet has analyzed the latest version of IceXLoader. Now in its third version, the loader has been previously spread using phishing emails with the malware in a zip attachment. The malware sets itself to run on startup to gain persistence and seems to have incomplete functionality. This allows IceXLoader to set up mutexes to ensure only one instance will load on startup, but this function is not yet working. IceXLoader attempts to evade detection by using in-memory patching of AMSI.DLL and uses PowerShell to disable Windows Defender. The malware is also added to the Windows Defender exclusion list. In the example studied by researchers, the Loader was observed dropping unknown malware that may have been a RAT or info stealer. This would additionally deploy a Monero crypto-miner. Further information is available from the link in the References section below.

Indicators of Compromise
========================

Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.

Recommendations
===============

* For a list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.

References
==========

* <https://www.fortinet.com/blog/threat-research/new-icexloader-3-0-developers-warm-up-to-nim>

MITRE ATT&CK Framework
======================

**Resource Development - TA0042**  
   T1587.001 - Malware  

**Initial Access - TA0001**  
   T1566.001 - Spearphishing Attachment  

**Execution - TA0002**  
   T1059.001 - PowerShell  
   T1204.002 - Malicious File  

**Persistence - TA0003**  
   T1053.005 - Scheduled Task  
   T1547.001 - Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder  

**Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
   T1562.001 - Disable or Modify Tools  

**Discovery - TA0007**  
   T1016.001 - Internet Connection Discovery  
 T1057 - Process Discovery  
 T1082 - System Information Discovery  

**Command and Control - TA0011**  
 T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  

#### Mitigations:

**M1013:**  Application Developer Guidance: This mitigation describes any guidance or training given to developers of applications to avoid introducing security weaknesses that an adversary may be able to take advantage of.  
**M1017:**  User Training - Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction.  
**M1018:**  User Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.  
**M1021:**  Restrict Web-Based Content - Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc.  
**M1022:**  Restrict File and Directory Permissions - Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.  
**M1024:**  Restrict Registry Permissions - Restrict the ability to modify certain hives or keys in the Windows Registry.  
**M1025:**  Privileged Process Integrity - Protect processes with high privileges that can be used to interact with critical system components through use of protected process light, anti-process injection defenses, or other process integrity enforcement measures.  
**M1026:**  Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.  
**M1028:**  Operating System Configuration - Make configuration changes related to the operating system or a common feature of the operating system that result in system hardening against techniques.  
**M1031:**  Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  
**M1033:**  Limit Software Installation - Block users or groups from installing unapproved software.  
**M1037:**  Filter Network Traffic - Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic.  
**M1038:**  Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
**M1039:**  Environment Variable Permissions - Prevent modification of environment variables by unauthorized users and groups.  
**M1040:**  Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
**M1042:**  Disable or Remove Feature or Program - Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.  
**M1043:**  Credential Access Protection - Use capabilities to prevent successful credential access by adversaries; including blocking forms of credential dumping.  
**M1044:**  Restrict Library Loading - Prevent abuse of library loading mechanisms in the operating system and software to load untrusted code by configuring appropriate library loading mechanisms and investigating potential vulnerable software.  
**M1045:**  Code Signing - Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.  
**M1047:**  Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
**M1049:**  Antivirus/Antimalware - Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software.  
**M1054:**  Software Configuration - Implement configuration changes to software (other than the operating system) to mitigate security risks associated to how the software operates.  
**M1056:**  Pre-compromise - This category is used for any applicable mitigation activities that apply to techniques occurring before an adversary gains Initial Access, such as Reconnaissance and Resource Development techniques.

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Attack Exploiting XSS Vulnerability in E-commerce Websites
Following up on previous reporting from Trend Micro, JPCERT/CC has published their findings regarding a campaign that exploited XSS vulnerabilities in EC-CUBE products to steal sensitive data.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Exploit, Webshell, Infostealer




# Overview

JPCERT/CC published a blog post detailing a campaign targeting XSS vulnerabilities in EC-CUBE products. The attacker begins by running an exploit script on a potentially vulnerable site. If successful, the script will steal administrator credentials. Using these credentials, the attacker is able to log into the victim site and set up a simple webshell. A further multi-function webshell will also be installed. The attacker's primary objective is to inject information stealing JavaScript into payment and login pages. Any captured data is saved to a file on the website's server. It is presumed the attacker eventually accesses this data via the installed webshell. The researchers also uncovered a tool called Adminer that would allow the attacker to obtain contents of various types of databases. For more information, see the JPCERT/CC blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.



# Reference

parsed_raw_data.xfe_q:
Attack Exploiting XSS Vulnerability in E-commerce Websites
Following up on previous reporting from Trend Micro, JPCERT/CC has published their findings regarding a campaign that exploited XSS vulnerabilities in EC-CUBE products to steal sensitive data.
parsed_raw_data.xfe_report:
# Threat Type

  * Malware, Exploit, Webshell, Infostealer




# Overview

JPCERT/CC published a blog post detailing a campaign targeting XSS vulnerabilities in EC-CUBE products. The attacker begins by running an exploit script on a potentially vulnerable site. If successful, the script will steal administrator credentials. Using these credentials, the attacker is able to log into the victim site and set up a simple webshell. A further multi-function webshell will also be installed. The attacker's primary objective is to inject information stealing JavaScript into payment and login pages. Any captured data is saved to a file on the website's server. It is presumed the attacker eventually accesses this data via the installed webshell. The researchers also uncovered a tool called Adminer that would allow the attacker to obtain contents of various types of databases. For more information, see the JPCERT/CC blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.



# Reference

  * <https://blogs.jpcert.or.jp/en/2021/07/water_pamola.html>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Drupal core - Critical - Remote code execution - SA-CORE-2020-012
Drupal has released a security advisory detailing a remote code execution vulnerability (CVE-2020-13671).
output:
# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability



# Overview

Drupal has released a security advisory (SA-CORE-2020-012) detailing a critical remote code execution vulnerability (CVE-2020-13671). The vulnerability is due to the improperly sanitization of file names for uploaded files. This could lead to files with the incorrect extension being served up as the wrong MIME type. In some hosting configurations the files could be executed as PHP. As Drupal has rated this issue as critical, it is advised to update as soon as possible. This update would be an excellent time to verify that additional plug-ins are also up to date. Versions affected and patched versions can be found in the link in the Reference section.

# CVEs

  * A complete list of CVEs can be found here: [ CVEs.txt](/download/attachments/33982875/Drupal%20core%20-%20Critical%20-%20Remote%20code%20execution%20-%20SA-CORE-2020-012%20CVEs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1605731731129&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://www.drupal.org/sa-core-2020-012>
