instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Apple Security Updates for macOS February 09 2021
Apple has published security updates for macOS Big Sur, Catalina, and Mojave.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Apple Security Updates for macOS February 09 2021
Apple has published security updates for macOS Big Sur, Catalina, and Mojave.

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

  
Apple has published security updates for macOS macOS Big Sur, Catalina, and Mojave. The updates address three vulnerabilities, only one of the vulnerabilities affects Mojave. The most serious potential impact from successful exploitation of the vulnerabilities addressed in Big Sur and Catalina is the remote execution of arbitrary code with kernel privileges. The vulnerability that affects Big Sur, Catalina, and Mojave is a privilege escalation vulnerability in sudo. Further details are available from the advisories linked in the Reference section below.

# CVEs

  * CVE-2021-1805, CVE-2021-1806, CVE-2021-3156




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://support.apple.com/en-us/HT212177>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: IBM Security Guardium Security Bulletins March 01 2020
Six Security Bulletins that address multiple vulnerabilities have been published for IBM Security Guardium Security.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

Six Security Bulletins, 6420115, 6420079, 6405952, 6408630, 6408632, and 6408634, that apply to IBM Security Guardium have been published. The bulletins address vulnerabilities in Guardium itself and the versions of Oracle MySQL, the Linux Kernel, and the IBM Java SDK distributed with Guardium. Collectively, the bulletins address ninety CVE-numbered vulnerabilities. If successfully exploited, the most serious of the vulnerabilities could potentially allow an attacker on an adjacent network to execute arbitrary code, or an authenticated attacker to obtain root privileges on an affected system. Further details, including affected versions and available updates, can be found in the bulletins linked in the Reference section below.

# CVEs

  * A complete list of CVEs can be found here: [IBM Security Guardium Security Bulletins CVEs.txt](/download/attachments/42434964/IBM%20Security%20Guardium%20Security%20Bulletins%20CVEs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1614750903649&api=v2)




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://www.ibm.com/support/pages/node/6408630>

  * <https://www.ibm.com/support/pages/node/6420079>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Mindware and SFile Ransomware Technical Breakdown
Sentinel One has posted an analysis of the ransomware used by a threat group that refers to themselves as Mindware. This group has beenactive since March of this year.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

Summary
=======



Threat Details
==============

* **Threat Type:** Ransomware
* **Targets:** Healthcare, Finance, Engineering, and Manufacturing
* **Ransomware Family:** Mindware
* **Initial Infection Vector:** Unknown
* **Post-Compromise Actions:** File encryption and exfiltration
* **Additional TTPs:** See MITRE ATT&CK Below

Overview
========

Sentinel One analyzed the ransomware used by the Mindware group. The group is known to gave targeted victims in the healthcare, finance, engineering, and manufacturing sectors. The Sentinel One analysis notes that there are similarities between the SFile ransomware and Mindware's ransomware. There are no indications in the analysis of how the ransomware gains access to victim networks. The Mindware ransomware uses a less common technique, Reflective DLL Injection, to obtain handles to API functions. For more information, please see the link in the References section below.

Indicators of Compromise
========================

Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.

Recommendations
===============

* For a list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.

References
==========

* [https://www.sentinelone.com/blog/from-the-front-lines-another-rebrand-mindware-and-sfile-ransomware-technical-breakdown/](https://www.sentinelone.com/blog/from-the-front-lines-another-rebrand-mindware-and-sfile-ransomware-technical-breakdown/ "Follow link")

MITRE ATT&CK Framework
======================

**Tactics and Techniques:**

**Execution - TA0002**  
 T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  

**Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
 T1027 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
   T1027.002 - Software Packing  
 T1112 - Modify Registry  

**Discovery - TA0007**  
 T1007 - System Service Discovery  
 T1018 - Remote System Discovery  
 T1082 - System Information Discovery  

**Impact - TA0040**  
 T1485 - Data Destruction  
 T1486 - Data Encrypted for Impact  

**Mitigations:**

**M1018:**  User Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.  
**M1021:**  Restrict Web-Based Content - Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc.  
**M1024:**  Restrict Registry Permissions - Restrict the ability to modify certain hives or keys in the Windows Registry.  
**M1026:**  Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.  
**M1033:**  Limit Software Installation - Block users or groups from installing unapproved software.  
**M1038:**  Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
**M1040:**  Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
**M1042:**  Disable or Remove Feature or Program - Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.  
**M1045:**  Code Signing - Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.  
**M1047:**  Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
**M1049:**  Antivirus/Antimalware - Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software.  
**M1053:**  Data Backup - Take and store data backups from end user systems and critical servers. Ensure backup and storage systems are hardened and kept separate from the corporate network to prevent compromise.

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Ngrok Convoluted Attack Chain
Trend Micro writes about an event discovered in one of their customer's networks involving Ngrok.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Ngrok Convoluted Attack Chain
Trend Micro writes about an event discovered in one of their customer's networks involving Ngrok.

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Keylogger



# Overview

In July, Trend Micro uncovered a suspicious event inside one of their customer's networks. A registry value had been created that was patterned after a well known security vendor, but there was a misspelling of the name. Also found was an executable, with a randomized name, in the System directory. This led the researchers to dig deeper into the situation. The executable turned out to be a keylogger that delivered the data it gathered to a Gmail account. Upon closer examination of the executable, they found hard-coded information that suggested it was created specifically for that customer. Other information found within the executable led Trend to suspect the attackers had pre-existing knowledge about their customer. Their analysis found that the keylogger had been installed by ntoskrnl.exe, suggesting that this was done either through a network share on the system or by a kernel vulnerability. After discovering a command in the system logs dealing with the SMB port 445, they concluded the tool in question was a copy of ngrok. Ngrok allows a system to be visible on the ngrok website by routing network traffic through the ngrok website. For more technical details of this attack, please refer to the link in the Reference section.

# CVEs

  * N/A



# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * https://www.trendmicro.com/en_us/research/20/i/analysis-of-a-convoluted-attack-chain-involving-ngrok.html

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Chaos Ransomware Variant Sides with Russia
Fortinet Labs is reporting on a new variant of ransomware that is being utilized as a part of the Russian/Ukraine conflict. The new variant of Chaos ransomware is being reported as “being on the side” as the attacker using this malware appears to be pro-Russian.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Details

  *  **Threat Type: Ransomware**
  *  **Targets: Unknown**
  *  **Ransomware Family: Chaos**
  *  **RaaS Operation: Unknown**
  *  **Initial Infection Vector: Phishing**
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions: Data Loss**



# Overview

Fortinet Labs has conducted research on how a new variant of Chaos ransomware is being utilized. Their assessment is that the ransomware may be distributed by email and forum posts that masquerade as updates on the Russian/Ukrainian conflict. Fortinet also assesses that there is a ransomware builder available that the latest version of Chaos came from. Indications are, based on reporting, that the perpetrator(s) of this ransomware have no intent on providing decryption keys. Fortinet believes that Chaos malware is being used to destroy information rather than for monetary gain. Further information can be found in the article located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * For a full list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.




# References

  * <https://www.fortinet.com/blog/threat-research/chaos-ransomware-variant-sides-with-russia>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

#### Tactics and Techniques:

  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1070.004 - File Deletion  
  
 **Credential Access - TA0006**  
T1552.001 - Credentials In Files  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1082 - System Information Discovery  
  
 **Collection - TA0009**  
T1005 - Data from Local System  
  
 **Impact - TA0040**  
T1490 - Inhibit System Recovery  
  


#### Mitigations:

  
 **M1015:** Active Directory Configuration - Configure Active Directory to prevent use of certain techniques; use SID Filtering, etc.  
 **M1017:** User Training - Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction.  
 **M1018:** User Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.  
 **M1021:** Restrict Web-Based Content - Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc.  
 **M1022:** Restrict File and Directory Permissions - Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.  
 **M1026:** Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.  
 **M1027:** Password Policies - Set and enforce secure password policies for accounts.  
 **M1028:** Operating System Configuration - Make configuration changes related to the operating system or a common feature of the operating system that result in system hardening against techniques.  
 **M1029:** Remote Data Storage - Use remote security log and sensitive file storage where access can be controlled better to prevent exposure of intrusion detection log data or sensitive information.  
 **M1030:** Network Segmentation - Architect sections of the network to isolate critical systems, functions, or resources. Use physical and logical segmentation to prevent access to potentially sensitive systems and information. Use a DMZ to contain any internet-facing services that should not be exposed from the internal network. Configure separate virtual private cloud (VPC) instances to isolate critical cloud systems.  
 **M1033:** Limit Software Installation - Block users or groups from installing unapproved software.  
 **M1035:** Limit Access to Resource Over Network - Prevent access to file shares, remote access to systems, unnecessary services. Mechanisms to limit access may include use of network concentrators, RDP gateways, etc.  
 **M1037:** Filter Network Traffic - Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic.  
 **M1038:** Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
 **M1039:** Environment Variable Permissions - Prevent modification of environment variables by unauthorized users and groups.  
 **M1040:** Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
 **M1041:** Encrypt Sensitive Information - Protect sensitive information with strong encryption.  
 **M1042:** Disable or Remove Feature or Program - Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.  
 **M1045:** Code Signing - Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.  
 **M1047:** Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
 **M1049:** Antivirus/Antimalware - Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software.  
 **M1051:** Update Software - Perform regular software updates to mitigate exploitation risk.  
 **M1053:** Data Backup - Take and store data backups from end user systems and critical servers. Ensure backup and storage systems are hardened and kept separate from the corporate network to prevent compromise.  
 **M1057:** Data Loss Prevention - Use a data loss prevention (DLP) strategy to categorize sensitive data, identify data formats indicative of personal identifiable information (PII), and restrict exfiltration of sensitive data.

 **M1018:** User Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.  
 **M1021:** Restrict Web-Based Content - Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc.  
 **M1022:** Restrict File and Directory Permissions - Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.  
 **M1026:** Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.  
 **M1027:** Password Policies - Set and enforce secure password policies for accounts.  
 **M1028:** Operating System Configuration - Make configuration changes related to the operating system or a common feature of the operating system that result in system hardening against techniques.  
 **M1029:** Remote Data Storage - Use remote security log and sensitive file storage where access can be controlled better to prevent exposure of intrusion detection log data or sensitive information.  
 **M1030:** Network Segmentation - Architect sections of the network to isolate critical systems, functions, or resources. Use physical and logical segmentation to prevent access to potentially sensitive systems and information. Use a DMZ to contain any internet-facing services that should not be exposed from the internal network. Configure separate virtual private cloud (VPC) instances to isolate critical cloud systems.  
 **M1033:** Limit Software Installation - Block users or groups from installing unapproved software.  
 **M1035:** Limit Access to Resource Over Network - Prevent access to file shares, remote access to systems, unnecessary services. Mechanisms to limit access may include use of network concentrators, RDP gateways, etc.  
 **M1037:** Filter Network Traffic - Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic.  
 **M1038:** Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
 **M1039:** Environment Variable Permissions - Prevent modification of environment variables by unauthorized users and groups.  
 **M1040:** Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
 **M1041:** Encrypt Sensitive Information - Protect sensitive information with strong encryption.  
 **M1042:** Disable or Remove Feature or Program - Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.  
 **M1045:** Code Signing - Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.  
 **M1047:** Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
 **M1049:** Antivirus/Antimalware - Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software.  
 **M1051:** Update Software - Perform regular software updates to mitigate exploitation risk.  
 **M1053:** Data Backup - Take and store data backups from end user systems and critical servers. Ensure backup and storage systems are hardened and kept separate from the corporate network to prevent compromise.  
 **M1057:** Data Loss Prevention - Use a data loss prevention (DLP) strategy to categorize sensitive data, identify data formats indicative of personal identifiable information (PII), and restrict exfiltration of sensitive data.

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Internet Being Actively Scanned for ZeroLogon Vulnerable Servers
In a post on DoublePulsar, Kevin Beaumont expands his personal honeypot, BluePot, to include systems vulnerable to the ZeroLogon vulnerability CVE-2020–1472. His post describes what he has found.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability, Honeypot, Scanning, Exploitation



# Overview

Kevin Beaumont has posted his findings on DoublePulsar regarding the expansion of his honeypot to include systems vulnerable to the ZeroLogon vulnerability. Microsoft patched this vulnerability in their August patch release. The Active Directory server he used was fully patched up to Microsoft's July release. Ports 135 (MS-RPC), 445 (SMB), and RPC high ports were left open to the Internet while all other ports were blocked. On September 26th, his server received hundreds of login attempts that closely matched the ZeroLogon exploit chain. These attempts were successful in resetting the domain controller's admin password to a blank password. All of the attempts were from the same IP address, listed in the IoCs section below. The successful exploitation of the ZeroLogon vulnerability was accomplished without any credentials and provided the attacker with full remote code execution ability. For more details, please refer to the URLs in the Reference section.

# CVEs

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ CVEs.txt](/download/attachments/30770622/Internet%20Being%20Actively%20Scanned%20for%20ZeroLogon%20Vulnerable%20Servers%20CVEs.txt?version=2&modificationDate=1601305723756&api=v2)



# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/30770622/Internet%20Being%20Actively%20Scanned%20for%20ZeroLogon%20Vulnerable%20Servers%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1601305089007&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://doublepulsar.com/in-the-wild-exploitation-of-zerologon-detected-over-the-internet-on-honeypot-f61e2700215b>
  * <https://exchange.xforce.ibmcloud.com/collection/Microsoft-Netlogon-Vulnerability-CVE-2020-1472-Potential-Exploit-974989e2263f1f3415c463388b84121a>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: OGNL Vulnerability in Confluence Disclosed
The National Vulnerability Database (NVD) has provided details on a vulnerability existing in versions of Confluence that could have impacts on a number of organizations.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Overview

Select versions of Atlassian Confluence are affected by a critical vulnerability, identified as CVE-2021-26084, and should be patched immediately according to various media sources as well as Atlassian. the vulnerability is an OGNL injection vulnerability that would allow an authenticated or unauthenticated (in certain instances) to execute arbitrary code on Confluence servers or Data Center instances. "The vulnerability endpoints can be accessed by a non-administrator user or unauthenticated user if 'Allow people to sign up to create their account' is enabled", quotes the NVD.

 **Affected versions:**

  * version < 6.13.23
  * 6.14.0 ≤ version < 7.4.11
  * 7.5.0 ≤ version < 7.11.5
  * 7.12.0 ≤ version < 7.12.5



The NVD has provided instructions on verifying whether the setting for user account creation is enabled. More information can be found in the links located within the Reference section below.

# Vulnerability Details

### Type of Vulnerability (OS, Software, Hardware)

  * OGNL Injection Vulnerability
  * Various



### CVE Details

  * CVE-2021-26084
  * Allow authenticated user and some unauthenticated users to execute arbitrary code on Confluence server and Data Center instances.



### Seen in the Wild

  * Yes, reproduced by researchers as well.
  * No attribution possible at this time.



### Proof of Concept

  * Publicly available since August 31, 2021.



# CVEs

  * CVE-2021-26084



# Protection

  * Check your instance of Confluence for affected versions.
  * Upgrade instances of Confluence to the most recent version of the software depending on your particular environment.



# References

  * <https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/CVE-2021-26084>
  * <https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFSERVER-67940>
  * <https://www.securityweek.com/recently-patched-confluence-vulnerability-exploited-wild>
  * <https://www.rapid7.com/blog/post/2021/09/02/active-exploitation-of-confluence-server-cve-2021-26084/>
  * <https://packetstormsecurity.com/files/164013/Confluence-Server-7.12.4-OGNL-Injection-Remote-Code-Execution.html>
  * [https://twitter.com/SwitHak/status/1433791273966657537](https://twitter.\[com\]/SwitHak/status/1433791273966657537)

  * [https://twitter.com/iamnoooob/status/1431739398782025728](https://twitter.\[com\]/iamnoooob/status/1431739398782025728)




# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1078 - Valid Accounts  
  
 **Persistence - TA0003**  
T1037 - Boot or Logon Initialization Scripts  
T1037.003 - Network Logon Script

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: TrickBot's New LightBot Malware Finds High-Value Targets
Bleeping Computer reports on a new malware from the TrickBot operators named, "LightBot", which is used as a reconnaissance tool to search for new high-value targets.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: TrickBot's New LightBot Malware Finds High-Value Targets
Bleeping Computer reports on a new malware from the TrickBot operators named, "LightBot", which is used as a reconnaissance tool to search for new high-value targets.

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Reconnaissance




# Overview

The TrickBot operators have released a new reconnaissance tool used to find additional high-value targets within an infected network. The tool, LightBot, was first seen in a phishing campaign normally used to distribute TrickBot's BazarLoader. The emails pretend to be from Human Resources or legal departments regarding any number of issues. One such email contained a link to a Google Drive document for which document previewing is disabled. This technique requires the user to download the document in order to see the contents. The download is a JavaScript file that that executes the LightBot PowerShell script. The tool gathers information about the victim network to determine its value to threat actors for further attacks. There is speculation the malware is used to choose Ryuk ransomware targets. Information is sent to C2 servers in order receive additional PowerShell scripts which will execute and send data collected previously. LightBot collects computer name, hardware info, user names, Windows version, and other salient information from the prospective target. Two files are created in the %Temp% folder. One is a text file containing an encrypted base64 encoded string, the second is a PowerShell script that decodes the aforementioned base64 string and executes it. A scheduled task is run at 7AM each day which launches the PowerShell script. It is speculated the task is the persistence method. LightBot continues to run in the background and checks for new C2 commands. Further information can be found in the article located within the Reference section below. 

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.bleepingcomputer.com/news/security/lightbot-trickbot-s-new-reconnaissance-malware-for-high-value-targets/>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Proxylogon Allows for New Malware Family Capabilities
The Proxylogon zero-day exploit has allowed for three new malware families to take advantage of the vulnerability. Trend Micro has published a blog post regarding these new capabilities and their usage.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Ransomware, Botnet




# Overview

The Proxylogon zero-day exploits have allowed for several malware families to take advantage of the vulnerability. Included in these malware families are LemonDuck, BlackKingdon, and Prometei botnet. The vulnerability allows the malwares to execute Chopper web shells that allow for the usage of the final payloads of the families. Activities deployable include dropping ExchDefender seen in both BlackKingdom and Prometei, and a WMI modifier allowing for LemonDuck infections. As seen in previous campaigns involving ExchDefender, a service made to impersonate a security measure for Exchange is created. This leads to the execution of a binary in a created folder which uses the command line "Dcomsvc." The directory is searched for web shells used in other attacks and deletes them. In the LemonDuck family, WMI is used to modify the OAB. A PowerShell process executes a Base64-encoded command. Once deobfuscated, it is revealed that it is capable of modifying the ExernalURL of an ASPX file. This, then, allows for remote command execution. Further information can be found in the blog located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.



# Reference

  * <https://www.trendmicro.com/en_us/research/21/e/proxylogon-a-coinminer--a-ransomware--and-a-botnet-join-the-part.html>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Russian Threat Group Attacking Russian Industry
A new Russian threat group, OldGremlin, is targeting Russian industries with ransomware, phishing attempts, and other malware. Group-IB details this group and its campaigns against those Russian industries.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Phishing, Ransomware




# Overview

A new Russian threat group is wreaking havoc on various Russian industries. Using a variety of techniques, the group seeks to phish credentials, implant malware, and deploy ransomware. The group is made up of Russian speakers who break the untold rule of not working within Russia and post-Soviet countries. Impersonating regulatory organizations, a metallurgical company, an industrial plant, a dental clinic, and media holdings company, the group uses a variety of techniques to infiltrate these and other industries within Russia. The first attack was against a large medical company using a phishing email claiming to be from the media holding company. Upon opening of the phishing email, a custom malware called TinyNode is installed. This malware is used as a backdoor and to load additional malware. The group performs reconnaissance, collection of data, and propagation. Additionally, the group uses Cobalt Strike to ensure post-exploitation is effective. The group moves laterally in an effort to obtain domain administrator credentials as well as creates a new account with privileges to perform administrative actions in case the original account is deleted or blocked. A backup of the data was unsuccessful as it was later revealed the attackers had deleted the organization's backups. Within hours, the ransomware TinyCryptor was spread throughout the network. A note of interest is each campaign uses a different email address. A demand of $50,000 worth of cryptocurrency was made in exchange for decrypting the encrypted files. The group was first observed between late-March and early-April. The group used a custom Trojan called TinyPosh. After a two week break, the group changed tactics and employed a fake email from a journalist to take part in research activities. The email used proper grammar as well as imitating the media's holding style. The fake journalist offered a 30-minute interview and uploaded questions to the cloud. Upon clicking the link, the TinyPosh Trojan was downloaded to a victim's computer. Persistence was set and the privileges of the account were obtained. Additionally, Cobalt Strike Beacon was launched and, in order to hide the actual C2 address, the group used a Cloudflare Workers server. The group took a hiatus until August 2020 when two large-scales campaigns were launched using the Russian media holding company as a front. Within days, the decoy email was edited to address protests in Belarus. Using several themes the group continued to launch TinyPosh backdoor attacks. These emails contained malicious emails with malicious ZIP files attached. Further details can be found in the article located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.group-ib.com/blog/oldgremlin>

Russian Threat Group Attacking Russian Industry
A new Russian threat group, OldGremlin, is targeting Russian industries with ransomware, phishing attempts, and other malware. Group-IB details this group and its campaigns against those Russian industries.

The first attack was against a large medical company using a phishing email claiming to be from the media holding company. Upon opening of the phishing email, a custom malware called TinyNode is installed. This malware is used as a backdoor and to load additional malware. The group performs reconnaissance, collection of data, and propagation. Additionally, the group uses Cobalt Strike to ensure post-exploitation is effective. The group moves laterally in an effort to obtain domain administrator credentials as well as creates a new account with privileges to perform administrative actions in case the original account is deleted or blocked. A backup of the data was unsuccessful as it was later revealed the attackers had deleted the organization's backups. Within hours, the ransomware TinyCryptor was spread throughout the network. A note of interest is each campaign uses a different email address. A demand of $50,000 worth of cryptocurrency was made in exchange for decrypting the encrypted files. The group was first observed between late-March and early-April. The group used a custom Trojan called TinyPosh. After a two week break, the group changed tactics and employed a fake email from a journalist to take part in research activities. The email used proper grammar as well as imitating the media's holding style. The fake journalist offered a 30-minute interview and uploaded questions to the cloud. Upon clicking the link, the TinyPosh Trojan was downloaded to a victim's computer. Persistence was set and the privileges of the account were obtained. Additionally, Cobalt Strike Beacon was launched and, in order to hide the actual C2 address, the group used a Cloudflare Workers server. The group took a hiatus until August 2020 when two large-scales campaigns were launched using the Russian media holding company as a front. Within days, the decoy email was edited to address protests in Belarus. Using several themes the group continued to launch TinyPosh backdoor attacks. These emails contained malicious emails with malicious ZIP files attached. Further details can be found in the article located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.group-ib.com/blog/oldgremlin>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: VMware Workspace ONE Access Exploited to Deploy New Backdoor
A report from Morphisec provides an analysis of a new attack that targets VMware Workspace ONE Access to exploit an RCE vulnerability (CVE-2022-22954) to deploy a backdoor.
output:
# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Malware
  *  **Targets:** Unpatched versions of VMware Workspace ONE Access.
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** PowerTrash, Core Impact Agent.
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** CVE-2022-22954
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Deployment of Core Impact Agent.
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

A remotely exploitable code execution vulnerability (CVE-2022-22954) in VMware Workspace ONE Access is being exploited to deploy a backdoor, according to a report from Morphisec. On successful exploitation, a PowerShell stager is deployed which in turn downloads a PowerShell loader named PowerTrash. The loader decompresses the final payload, a Core Impact Agent, and reflectively loads it into memory. This technique leaves no forensic evidence on the disk. Further information is available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * For a list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.




# References

  * <https://blog.morphisec.com/vmware-identity-manager-attack-backdoor>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Tactics and Techniques:**

 **Reconnaissance - TA0043**  
T1595 - Active Scanning  
T1595.002 - Vulnerability Scanning  
  
 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1583 - Acquire Infrastructure  
T1583.001 - Domains  
T1583.004 - Server  
T1587 - Develop Capabilities  
T1587.001 - Malware  
T1588 - Obtain Capabilities  
T1588.005 - Exploits  
T1608 - Stage Capabilities  
T1608.001 - Upload Malware  
T1608.002 - Upload Tool  
  
 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
T1059.001 - PowerShell  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1027 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
T1055 - Process Injection  
T1055.012 - Process Hollowing  
T1070 - Indicator Removal on Host  
  


 **Mitigations:**

 **M1016:** Vulnerability Scanning - Vulnerability scanning is used to find potentially exploitable software vulnerabilities to remediate them.  
 **M1018:** User Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.  
 **M1021:** Restrict Web-Based Content - Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc.  
 **M1022:** Restrict File and Directory Permissions - Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.  
 **M1026:** Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.  
 **M1029:** Remote Data Storage - Use remote security log and sensitive file storage where access can be controlled better to prevent exposure of intrusion detection log data or sensitive information.  
 **M1030:** Network Segmentation - Architect sections of the network to isolate critical systems, functions, or resources. Use physical and logical segmentation to prevent access to potentially sensitive systems and information. Use a DMZ to contain any internet-facing services that should not be exposed from the internal network. Configure separate virtual private cloud (VPC) instances to isolate critical cloud systems.  
 **M1033:** Limit Software Installation - Block users or groups from installing unapproved software.  
 **M1038:** Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
 **M1039:** Environment Variable Permissions - Prevent modification of environment variables by unauthorized users and groups.  
 **M1040:** Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
 **M1041:** Encrypt Sensitive Information - Protect sensitive information with strong encryption.  
 **M1042:** Disable or Remove Feature or Program - Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.  
 **M1045:** Code Signing - Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.  
 **M1047:** Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
 **M1048:** Application Isolation and Sandboxing - Restrict execution of code to a virtual environment on or in transit to an endpoint system.  
 **M1049:** Antivirus/Antimalware - Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software.  
 **M1050:** Exploit Protection - Use capabilities to detect and block conditions that may lead to or be indicative of a software exploit occurring.  
 **M1051:** Update Software - Perform regular software updates to mitigate exploitation risk.  
 **M1056:** Pre-compromise - This category is used for any applicable mitigation activities that apply to techniques occurring before an adversary gains Initial Access, such as Reconnaissance and Resource Development techniques.

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Additional Dark Caracal Indicators
Following Checkpoint's recent report on the Dark Caracal threat group, the Electronic Frontier Foundation (EFF) has published previously unreported indicators of compromise (IoCs) associated with the actor.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware, RAT, APT




# Overview

The Electronic Frontier Foundation (EFF) has published various indicators of compromise associated with the Dark Caracal threat group, which was recently reported on by Checkpoint. They provide a brief overview of the group, which is believed to be state-sponsored, supporting Kazakhstan and Lebanon government interests in particular. Although they were inactive for a period of time, they re-emerged in November of 2019 with new, signed versions of the Bandook malware. Checkpoint's report specifies a much broader list of target industries and countries than previously discussed. The Bandook malware used by the group is a commercially available, full-featured RAT that has been around since 2007. While monitoring the group, the EFF identified Bandook samples, command and control infrastructure, and other indicators of compromise associated with the group that were not provided in Checkpoint's reporting. For more information, see the Checkpoint blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.eff.org/deeplinks/2020/12/dark-caracal-you-missed-spot>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Mongolian CA Compromised and Installers Trojanized
The website of MonPass, a certification authority in Mongolia, was compromised. According to a report from Avast, eight different webshells were installed on the compromised server. Certain legitimate, downloadable, installers and executable files on the site, were Trojanized.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware




# Overview

MonPass is a certification authority in Mongolia. An investigation by Avast found the MonPass website was compromised with eight different webshells being found on the server. This could potentially mean the website was compromised eight separate times. The installer for the MonPass client was Trojanised and Cobalt Strike binaries. Other downloadable executable files on the site were also Trojanized. When the installer was executed, it functioned normally, however, malware was also installed. The malware downloaded a BMP file from a remote server that used Steganography to hide shellcode within the image file. The decrypted shellcode was a Cobalt-Strike beacon. The domains used for the C&C servers are crafted to appear to belong to Google, Microsoft, and jQuery. One of the C&C servers provided a website that was crafted to appear to be a legitimate jQuery site. One of the few obvious differences was the site's certificate. Further information is available from the report linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://decoded.avast.io/luigicamastra/backdoored-client-from-mongolian-ca-monpass/>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: ICS-CERT Advisories March 04 2021
The ICS-CERT has published 2 advisories that affect Rockwell Automation 1734-AENTR Series B and Series C, and Schneider Electric EcoStruxure Building Operation (EBO).

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: ICS-CERT Advisories March 04 2021
The ICS-CERT has published 2 advisories that affect Rockwell Automation 1734-AENTR Series B and Series C, and Schneider Electric EcoStruxure Building Operation (EBO).

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

 Further information is available from the advisories which are summarised below.

 **ICS Advisory ICSA-21-063-01 - Rockwell Automation 1734-AENTR Series B and Series C**  
CVE-2020-14504 - The web interface of the 1734-AENTR communication module mishandles authentication for HTTP POST requests. A remote, unauthenticated attacker can send a crafted request that may allow for modification of the configuration settings.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 7.5 - CVSS Vector String: AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:N/I:H/A:N).

CVE-2020-14502 - The web interface of the 1734-AENTR communication module is vulnerable to stored XSS. A remote, unauthenticated attacker could store a malicious script within the web interface that, when executed, could modify some string values on the homepage of the web interface.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 4.7 - CVSS Vector String: AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:R/S:C/C:N/I:L/A:N).  
<https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ics/advisories/icsa-21-063-01>

 **ICS Advisory ICSA-21-063-02 - Schneider Electric EcoStruxure Building Operation (EBO)**  
CVE-2020-7569 - An unrestricted upload of a file with dangerous type vulnerability could allow an authenticated remote user to upload arbitrary files due to incorrect verification of user supplied files and achieve remote code execution.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 4.6 - CVSS Vector String: AV:N/AC:H/PR:L/UI:R/S:U/C:L/I:L/A:L).

CVE-2020-7570 - An improper neutralization of an input during webpage generation vulnerability could allow an authenticated remote user to inject arbitrary web script or HTML due to incorrect sanitization of user-supplied data and achieve a stored cross-site scripting attack against other WebReport users.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 6.4 - CVSS Vector String: AV:N/AC:H/PR:L/UI:N/S:U/C:H/I:L/A:L).

CVE-2020-7571 - Multiple improper neutralizations of an input during webpage generation vulnerabilities could allow a remote attacker to inject arbitrary web script or HTML due to incorrect sanitization of user supplied data and achieve a reflected cross-site scripting attack against other WebReport users.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 6.1 - CVSS Vector String: AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:R/S:C/C:L/I:L/A:N).

CVE-2020-7572 - An improper restriction of XML external entity reference vulnerability could allow an authenticated remote user to inject arbitrary XML code and obtain disclosure of confidential data, cause a denial-of-service condition, or execute server-side request forgery due to improper configuration of the XML parser.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 6.7 - CVSS Vector String: AV:N/AC:H/PR:L/UI:R/S:U/C:H/I:L/A:H).

CVE-2020-7573 - An improper access control vulnerability could allow a remote attacker access to restricted web resources due to improper access control.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 5.0 - CVSS Vector String: AV:N/AC:H/PR:N/UI:R/S:U/C:L/I:L/A:L).

CVE-2020-28209 - An unquoted search path vulnerability could allow any local Windows user with write permissions on at least one of the subfolders of the connect agent service binary path to gain the privilege of the user who started the service.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 2.0 - CVSS Vector String: AV:L/AC:L/PR:H/UI:R/S:U/C:L/I:N/A:N).

CVE-2020-28210 - An improper neutralization of an input during webpage generation vulnerability could allow an attacker to inject HTML and JavaScript code into the user's browser.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 4.3 - CVSS Vector String: AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:R/S:U/C:N/I:L/A:N).  
<https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ics/advisories/icsa-21-063-02>

# CVEs

  * A complete list of CVEs can be found here: [ CVEs.txt](/download/attachments/42435070/ICS-CERT%20Advisories%20March%2004%202021%20CVEs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1614909857297&api=v2)




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ics/advisories>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Demise of Cerberus
ThreatFabric acknowledges the passing of Cerberus, an Android-based banking Trojan and one of the more successful services up until August of 2020.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Demise of Cerberus
ThreatFabric acknowledges the passing of Cerberus, an Android-based banking Trojan and one of the more successful services up until August of 2020.

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Trojan, MaaS



# Overview

ThreatFabric noted the demise of one of the more successful Android banking Trojan services, Cerberus, as taking place some time in August of 2020. Issues within the malware, both architectural and technical, went unsolved by the threat-actors long enough that Google Play Protect was able to find and remove all of the samples on the store and on infected devices. Unable to resolve the issues, ThreatFabric indicated that the threat-actor attempted to sell off the service and the customer list. By August, the threat-actor had released the source code and refunded active licenses owners their money. With the source code available, those that tried to use the code needed to learn how the back end and builder worked. Also, a number of test samples began showing up on Google Play, but were immediately taken down by Protect - the code base was similar enough to Cerberus it was recognized as malware. Further research lead ThreatFabric to a malware package called Alien that appeared to be a variant of a January version of Cerberus. Alien contains a number of capabilities, such as overlay attacks, control and steal SMS, harvest the contact list, keylogging, install / start / remove applications, notification sniffer, and a RAT. For technical details, please refer to the link in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/30770712/Demise%20of%20Cerberus%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1601326284197&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.threatfabric.com/blogs/alien_the_story_of_cerberus_demise.html>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Vidar Stealer Abuses Mastadon Social Network
The Vidar stealer has historically used the Thumbler and Faceit gaming platforms in order to obtain its C2 configuration. A new sample discovered by Cyberint researchers has moved to using the Mastadon social network for this purpose instead.
output:
# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Stealer
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Unknown
  *  **Associated Payloads:** Vidar stealer
  *  **Targets:** Non-specific
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Malspam, social engineering via social networks, fake advertisements
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Data theft



# Overview

Cyberint published a blog post analyzing the most recent version of the Vidar stealer. Vidar is sold on a underground forums and Telegram, meaning that various threat actors can leverage the malware, which may cause tactic, techniques, and procedures (TTPs) to vary across campaigns. The most common initial access vector is malicious spam campaigns, but the use of direct messaging on social networks and malvertising has also been observed. Once on a victim system, Vidar obtains its C2 configuration from a remote service. In the case of this new version, the C2 IP address is found in Mastadon profile descriptions. Prior to collection of data, several DLL dependencies are downloaded from the C2 server. Finally, data such as credentials, screenshots, and system information is gathered, staged, and exfiltrated as a ZIP archive in an HTTP POST request. For more information, see the Cyberint blog post in the References section. 

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/64129860/Vidar%20Stealer%20Abuses%20Mastadon%20Social%20Network%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1633707932622&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques and phishing emails (M1017).
  * Restrict Web-Based Content (M1021).



# References

  * <https://blog.cyberint.com/vidar-stealer-abuses-mastadon-social-network>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1566 - Phishing  
T1566.001 - Spearphishing Attachment  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1204 - User Execution  
T1204.002 - Malicious File  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1070 - Indicator Removal on Host  
T1070.004 - File Deletion  
  
 **Credential Access - TA0006**  
T1552 - Unsecured Credentials  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1082 - System Information Discovery  
T1083 - File and Directory Discovery  
  
 **Collection - TA0009**  
T1005 - Data from Local System  
T1074 - Data Staged  
T1074.001 - Local Data Staging  
T1113 - Screen Capture  
T1119 - Automated Collection  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0010**  
T1041 - Exfiltration Over C2 Channel  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
T1071.001 - Web Protocols

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Thalluim APT Leverages Malicious Cryptocurrency Wallet Apps
Thallium APT is performing a supply chain attack to inject their malicious code into cryptocurrency wallet apps. EST Security reports on this activity and their analysis of related samples.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Thalluim APT Leverages Malicious Cryptocurrency Wallet Apps
Thallium APT is performing a supply chain attack to inject their malicious code into cryptocurrency wallet apps. EST Security reports on this activity and their analysis of related samples.

# Threat Type

  * Malware




# Overview

EST Security has published a blog post analyzing Thallium malware samples disguised as cryptocurrency wallet apps. In order to distribute their malicious code, they injected it into legitimate applications, essentially performing a supply chain attack. Two different operating systems were targeted, Windows and Android. On Windows, the code is distributed via either the wallet installer or a firmware update program. Along with the legitimate code is the threat actor's code that ensures communication is established with a C2 server. In the same way, Android APKs for legitimate wallet apps were repackaged to include the actor's code that establishes C2 communication. It was reported that unauthorized withdrawal of coins were made in some cases. Credentials were also able to be stolen by the malware. The activity has been attributed to the Thallium APT based on code overlaps, such as the use of the same mutex and string encryption method. For more information, see the EST blog post linked to in the Reference section. 

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://blog.alyac.co.kr/3310>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Zerologon Exploit Live and In The Wild
A Windows vulnerability is being actively used in the wild on targets. Bleeping Computer reports on Zerologon and the available patch.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability, Exploit




# Overview

A vulnerability that results in the escalation of privilege in the Netlogon process is being used in the wild. CVE-2020-1472 was addressed as part of the August 2020 Patch Tuesday event. When exploited, attackers have the ability to elevate privileges to domain administrator and, effectively, take over a domain. A series of tweets from Microsoft confirms this exploit is being used and warns users to patch their systems immediately. According to Microsoft, "Microsoft is actively tracking threat actor activity using exploits for the CVE-2020-1472 Netlogon EoP vulnerability, dubbed Zerologon. We have observed attacks where public exploits have been incorporated into attacker playbooks." The tweets contained three samples used in the attack. The samples are written as .NET executables and can be found on VirusTotal. The attack will change the NTLM hash to 31d6cfe0d16ae931b73c59d7e0c089c0, an empty password. We urge users to apply the August 2020 patches as soon as possible to prevent this attack from occurring in vulnerable networks. IBM X-Force is actively tracking this threat in a related collection and further details can be found in the links located in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# CVEs

  * CVE-2020-1472




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://www.bleepingcomputer.com/news/microsoft/microsoft-hackers-using-zerologon-exploits-in-attacks-patch-now/>

  * [https://twitter.com/MsftSecIntel/status/1308941504707063808](https://twitter\[.\]com/MsftSecIntel/status/1308941504707063808)
  * <https://www.bleepingcomputer.com/news/microsoft/windows-zerologon-poc-exploits-allow-domain-takeover-patch-now/>
  * <https://exchange.xforce.ibmcloud.com/collection/Microsoft-Netlogon-Vulnerability-CVE-2020-1472-Potential-Exploit-974989e2263f1f3415c463388b84121a>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: z0Miner Exploiting ElasticSearch and Jenkins Vulnerabilities
While investigating active botnet mining attacks, 360 Netlab discovered a change in the vulnerabilities exploited by z0Miner for spreading.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Botnet, Cryptomining




# Overview

360 Netlab published a blog post about recent development in z0Miner, a malicious mining family that appeared on the scene last year. When it was initially discovered, the botnet was spreading by exploiting a WebLogic unauthorized remote command execution vulnerability. The most recent attacks, however, exploit remote command execution vulnerabilities in ElasticSearch and Jenkins, both vulnerabilities are from 2015. Regardless of the exact vulnerability exploited, it results in a .txt file being downloaded from a remote server and executed as a shell script. Once executed, competing mining processes are killed. Then cron tasks are created that will download and execute malicious scripts from Pastebin. Currently, the discovered Pastebin URLs point to a script with only an "exit" command, but these can easily be edited to include malicious commands. Lastly, the mining payloads are downloaded and executed. This includes a config file, the miner itself, and a shell script to execute the miner. Monero is the cryptocurrency being mined in this case. For more information, see the 360 Netlab blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://blog.netlab.360.com/threat-alert-z0miner-is-spreading-quickly-by-exploiting-elasticsearch-and-jenkins-vulnerabilities/>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: DoJ Allows FBI Login to Exchange Server WebShells
In a ruling on April 13, 2021, the U.S. Department of Justice (DoJ) allowed the Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) to log into exploited Microsoft Exchange Servers in order to disrupt and remove web shells providing backdoor access to the servers.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

According to multiple sources, including the DoJ, the FBI has been permitted to log into, copy, and remove malicious web shells from vulnerable Microsoft Exchange Servers. Throughout January and February 2021, threat actors have been exploiting a zero-day vulnerability in an effort to gain access to these servers. The vulnerability allowed for the installation of web shells for continued access. Although many owners of the vulnerable servers were able to remove the web shells, many more still appear to be vulnerable to this zero-day exploit. Some of the vulnerable server owners attempted to remove the web shells but were, ultimately, unsuccessful. The FBI then conducted the removal by issuing a command through the web shell to delete only the web shell itself as identified by its unique file path. This action did not include the patching of the servers in question but only the removal of the malicious web shells. Officials from the DoJ and FBI are urging owners to patch the affected systems immediately by reviewing Microsoft's remediation guide published in March in a Joint Advisory. Many security sources are urging owners to not only patch vulnerable systems but to remove any web shells left behind. Further details can be found in the links located within the Reference section below.

# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://www.justice.gov/usao-sdtx/pr/justice-department-announces-court-authorized-effort-disrupt-exploitation-microsoft>

  * <https://therecord.media/fbi-operation-removed-web-shells-from-hacked-exchange-servers-across-the-us/>
  * <https://www.bleepingcomputer.com/news/security/nsa-discovers-critical-exchange-server-vulnerabilities-patch-now/>

I have encountered the following information: Fourth District Court of Louisiana Affected by Ransomware
Breach / Leak Notification: The Fourth District Court of Louisiana has reportedly been the victim of a Conti ransomware attack. The Conti operators have published what are claimed to be court documents.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Breach/Leak 




# Overview

  
"The infrastructure of US criminal court has been hit by ransomware, with court documents published online in what is thought to be the first ransomware attack of its kind. Hacking group/ransomware strain Conti has claimed the attack on the Fourth District Court of Louisiana, and published apparent proof of the attack on its dark web page this week. It appears to have published documents obtained from the court relating to defendant pleas, witnesses and jurors."

# Reference

  * <https://www.cbronline.com/news/conti-ransomware-court>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Samba Advisory for ZeroLogon Vulnerability - CVE-2020-1472
An advisory that addresses the ZeroLogon, CVE-2020-1472, has been published by the Samba team. Successful exploitation of the vulnerability could allow an attacker to gain administrator access and takeover an active directory domain.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

  
Samba uses the netlogon protocol. The protocol contained a vulnerability known as ZeroLogon, CVE-2020-1472, which Microsoft patched in its September bulletins. Versions of Samba, 4.7 and prior, running as domain controller only, are vulnerable. Instances of Samba operating as file servers only, are not directly vulnerable. An authenticated attacker, on an active directory domain, could potentially change the domain password, thereby taking control of the domain. Versions of Samba, 4.8 and later, are only vulnerable if the "smb.conf" file contains the lines "server schannel = no" or "server schannel = auto". Further details are available from the Samba advisory linked in the Reference section below.

# CVEs

  * CVE-2020-1472 




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://www.samba.org/samba/security/CVE-2020-1472.html>

An advisory that addresses the ZeroLogon, CVE-2020-1472, has been published by the Samba team. Successful exploitation of the vulnerability could allow an attacker to gain administrator access and takeover an active directory domain.

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Ryuk Flips the Script in Five Hours
The threat actors behind Ryuk have updated tactics from phishing emails to a domain wide ransomware attack inside 5 hours. The DFIR Report posted an analysis and case summary regarding the sudden change in tactics.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware, Ransomware, Phishing




# Overview

Using tools such as Cobalt Strike, AdFind, WMI, and PowerShell, the actors behind Ryuk took their actions from a phishing email to a full-blown, domain-wide ransomware attack in just 5 hours. Using Bazar as an entry point via phishing email, the actors were able to accomplish their mission faster than previously observed. As with previous attacks, once Bazar was downloaded, it began injecting into explorer.exe or svchost.exe and spawning command shells. The domain was then mapped using a lower-level privileged user with a slow and methodical approach. It was from this point the Zerologon vulnerability (CVE-2020-1472) was used to reset the password of the primary domain controller. Lateral movement was done via SMB file transfers and WMI executions of Cobalt Strike beaconing. More domain discovery was accomplished and privilege escalation was completed. Additional Cobalt Strike beacons were deployed, and further domain recon was performed using AdFind. At just 4 hours into the attack, the actors were able to pivot from the primary domain controller to RDP into the backup server. This was the target for the deployment of ransomware, followed by servers and, finally, workstations. Execution of the ransomware occurred on the primary domain controller and completed their attack at the 5 hour mark. Further details can be found within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://thedfirreport.com/2020/10/18/ryuk-in-5-hours/>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: WildPressure Campaign Goes Cross Platform
In March, Kaspersky published a report on an operation they named WildPressure. The operation distributed C++ malware, which they have named Milum. New variants of Milum, written in Python and VBScript, have been discovered.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware




# Overview

Operation WildPressure is a campaign documented by Kaspersky in March 2020 that targeted organizations in the Middle East. The malware installed in the campaign is named Milum and was written in C++. A new report from Kaspersky provides an analysis of more recent variants of Milum that are written in Python and VBScript. The targets in this more recent phase of the campaign may be involved in the oil and gas sectors in the Middle East, although Kaspersky assesses this with low confidence. No information is provided on how the malware is being distributed. The Python version runs on Windows and macOS, which indicates a shift to cross-platform targeting. The C&C communication protocol is common across the three different language versions. In the original campaign, the C&C servers were located on rented infrastructure. The more recent phase of the operation also uses rented infrastructure but now also includes legitimate, but compromised WordPress and other sites. Further technical details are available from the report linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://securelist.com/wildpressure-targets-macos/103072/>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: COVID-19 Themed Phishing Attacks and the Fake Websites Created for Them
Palo Alto's Unit 42 revisits the phishing trends they observed over the past year, gaining deeper insight into the various COVID-related topics that attackers might try to exploit. Attackers continued to change their tactics to adapt to the latest pandemic trends.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: COVID-19 Themed Phishing Attacks and the Fake Websites Created for Them
Palo Alto's Unit 42 revisits the phishing trends they observed over the past year, gaining deeper insight into the various COVID-related topics that attackers might try to exploit. Attackers continued to change their tactics to adapt to the latest pandemic trends.

# Threat Type

  * Phishing




# Overview

Palo Alto's Unit 42 revisits the phishing trends they observed over the past year, gaining deeper insight into the various COVID-related topics that attackers might try to exploit.Attackers continued to change their tactics to adapt to the latest pandemic trends. They are constantly creating new websites to host their phishing campaigns. Topics in COVID-19-themed phishing included testing (including test kits and scheduling), personal protection equipment (PPE), government stimulus programs, treatment using pharmaceutical drugs, prevention via vaccines, and vaccine distribution. Some attacks were phishing for credentials from employees working in organizations such as Walgreens drug stores and pharmaceutical research, development, and production companies. Further information can be found in the article located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.

  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.
  * Enforcing multi-factor authentication on all business-related logins as an added layer of security.
  * Double-checking the URL and security certificate of each website before inputting your login credentials.

  * <https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/covid-19-themed-phishing-attacks/>
