instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Iranian Rail Systems Attack Malware Analysis
A report from SentinelLabs provides an analysis of the malware used in the attack against the Iranian rail systems in July.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Iranian Rail Systems Attack Malware Analysis
A report from SentinelLabs provides an analysis of the malware used in the attack against the Iranian rail systems in July.

# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Malware
  *  **Target:** The Islamic Republic of Iran Railways (IRIR)
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** MeteorExpress
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Unspecified
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Execution ([T1059](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/), [T1059.001](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/001/), [T1059.003](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/003/)), Defense Evasion ([TA0005](https://attack.mitre.org/tactics/TA0005/), [T1070](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1070/)), Impact ([T1485](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1485/), [T1561](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1561/)), Lateral Movement ([TA0008](https://attack.mitre.org/tactics/TA0008/), [T1570](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1570/))
  *  **Additional TTPs:** Develop Capabilities ([T1587](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1587/), [T1587.001](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1587/001/)), Gather Victim Network Information ([T1590](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1590/))



# Overview

On July 9th, 2021, a destructive attack was carried out on the computer systems of the Islamic Republic of Iran Railways (IRIR). A report from SentinelLabs provides an analysis of the malware used in the attack. Group Policy on an IRIR computer was used to distribute the malware, the form of a CAB file, to other computers on the internal network. The CAB file contained .bat files, an RAR file and a copy of WinRAR to unpack it, and an executable binary. The .bat files are the primary controllers of the attack which culminates in the wiping of the system's disk. The wiper has been named MeteorExpress by SentinelLabs. There is conjecture that the malware may be related to NotPetya due to the same sectors of the MBR being overwritten. SentinelLabs provides no attribution for the attack but the attackers were familiar with their target before commencing the destructive attack. The report further notes that the actors behind the malware have an intermediate skill level but the quality of code and design ranges from "clunky and rudimentary to slick and well-developed". While MeteorExpress has not been observed to have been used in any other attacks, it is configurable which suggests it could be used in other attacks. Further information is available from the report linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/59539664/Iranian%20Rail%20Systems%20Attack%20Malware%20Analysis%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1627970277495&api=v2)



Detection

  * A complete list of YARA rules can be found here: [ Yara Rules.txt](/download/attachments/59539664/Iranian%20Rail%20Systems%20Attack%20Malware%20Analysis%20Yara%20Rules.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1627970325993&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date ([M1049](https://attack.mitre.org/mitigations/M1049/)).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs ([M1031](https://attack.mitre.org/mitigations/M1031/), [M1035](https://attack.mitre.org/mitigations/M1035/), [M1037](https://attack.mitre.org/mitigations/M1037/)).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level ([M1051](https://attack.mitre.org/mitigations/M1051/)).



# References

  * <https://labs.sentinelone.com/meteorexpress-mysterious-wiper-paralyzes-iranian-trains-with-epic-troll/>

A report from SentinelLabs provides an analysis of the malware used in the attack against the Iranian rail systems in July.

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: UNC1945 - Threat Actor that Targets Solaris and Telecommunications Companies
UNC1945 is a threat actor that Mandiant has been tracking since 2018. UNC1945 has primarily targeted exposed Solaris servers in the networks of telecommunications entities. Mandiant has published a report on the activities of UNC1945 throughout the time period they have been tracking the threat actor.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: UNC1945 - Threat Actor that Targets Solaris and Telecommunications Companies
UNC1945 is a threat actor that Mandiant has been tracking since 2018. UNC1945 has primarily targeted exposed Solaris servers in the networks of telecommunications entities. Mandiant has published a report on the activities of UNC1945 throughout the time period they have been tracking the threat actor.

# Threat Type

  * Malware, APT




# Overview

A report from Mandiant tracks the activities of a threat actor Mandiant has named UNC1945 that has been targeting telecommunications entities. To gain access to a network, UNC1945 has exploited vulnerabilities in the Solaris operating system. The first compromise of a Solaris host by UNC1945 which is noted in the report occurred in late 2018. A backdoor named SLAPSTICK was installed on the compromised host. In mid 2020, Mandiant observed a remote exploitation tool named EVILSUN being deployed by UNC1945. EVILSUN contained an exploit, for what at the time, was a 0-day vulnerability in Solaris, which is now identified as CVE-2020-14871. Oracle provided a patch for this vulnerability in its October 2020 Critical Patch Update. An exploit for the vulnerability had been advertised for sale on black-market website in April 2020. Once the initial foothold was established, UNC1945 installed a number of tools, including a QEMU Virtual Machine that contained a version of Tiny Core Linux. A number of techniques and tools were used to facilitate lateral movement to HP-UX, Linux, and Windows hosts, and to third-party environments. UNC1945 takes a number of steps to evade detection including the scrubbing of log files. No data exfiltration was detected in the UNC1945 attacks but in one case, ransomware was deployed. Mandiant does not attribute the ransomware to UNC1945 and instead suggests that access to the compromised system may have been sold to a third-party. Tools and malware associated with UNC1945 includes LEMONSTICK, OKSOLO, PUPYRAT, SLAPSTICK, TINYSHELL which all provide some level of backdoor capabilities, STEELCORGI which is a packer for Linux ELF programs, the reconnaissance tool OPENSHACKLE, LOGBLEACH which is used for scrubbing log files, and ProxyChains. Further details are available from Mandiant's report linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.fireeye.com/blog/threat-research/2020/11/live-off-the-land-an-overview-of-unc1945.html>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: CISA Alert AA20-258A
Observations of the Chinese Ministry of State Security (MSS) cyber threat actors reveal the use of public information source and well-known TTPs, states CISA in a new alert (AA20-258A).

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: CISA Alert AA20-258A
Observations of the Chinese Ministry of State Security (MSS) cyber threat actors reveal the use of public information source and well-known TTPs, states CISA in a new alert (AA20-258A).

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability, Cyber Threat




# Overview

The Cybersecurity and Information Security Agency has issued an alert detailing the suspected actions of Chinese Ministry of State Security-affiliated cyber threat actors. These actors are using publicly available information and well-known TTPs in order to target U.S. government agencies. Additionally, the actors use easily obtained exploit kits to infiltrate target networks. In addition to the targeting of the U.S. Government, the actors have also been observed targeting various other industries including high-tech manufacturing, medical devices, civil and industrial engineering, business, education, gaming software, and others. Through the use of open-source tools, it is suspected the actors have low-complexity capabilities. The actors have been mostly successful in the infiltration of networks that are misconfigured or have a weak password management profile. Further information can be found in the alert listed within the Reference section below.

# CVEs

  * A list of CVEs can be found here: [ CVEs.txt](/download/attachments/30769168/CISA%20Alert%20AA20-258A%20CVEs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1600107390523&api=v2)




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ncas/alerts/aa20-258a>

parsed_raw_data.xfe_q:
CISA Alert AA20-258A
Observations of the Chinese Ministry of State Security (MSS) cyber threat actors reveal the use of public information source and well-known TTPs, states CISA in a new alert (AA20-258A).
parsed_raw_data.xfe_report:
# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability, Cyber Threat




# Overview

The Cybersecurity and Information Security Agency has issued an alert detailing the suspected actions of Chinese Ministry of State Security-affiliated cyber threat actors. These actors are using publicly available information and well-known TTPs in order to target U.S. government agencies. Additionally, the actors use easily obtained exploit kits to infiltrate target networks. In addition to the targeting of the U.S. Government, the actors have also been observed targeting various other industries including high-tech manufacturing, medical devices, civil and industrial engineering, business, education, gaming software, and others. Through the use of open-source tools, it is suspected the actors have low-complexity capabilities. The actors have been mostly successful in the infiltration of networks that are misconfigured or have a weak password management profile. Further information can be found in the alert listed within the Reference section below.

# CVEs

  * A list of CVEs can be found here: [ CVEs.txt](/download/attachments/30769168/CISA%20Alert%20AA20-258A%20CVEs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1600107390523&api=v2)




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ncas/alerts/aa20-258a>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Adobe February 2021 Updates - Exploit in the Wild
Adobe has released six security bulletins. Of note is that a vulnerability in Adobe Reader running on Windows has been exploited in the wild.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

 In all, fifty CVE numbered vulnerabilities are addressed in the bulletins. Further information is available from the links in the bulletin summaries below.

 **APSB21-09 Security update available for Adobe Acrobat and Reader**  
Adobe has released security updates for Adobe Acrobat and Reader for Windows and macOS. These updates address multiple critical and important vulnerabilities. Successful exploitation could lead to arbitrary code execution in the context of the current user. **Adobe has received a report that CVE-2021-21017 has been exploited in the wild in limited attacks targeting Adobe Reader users on Windows.**  
<https://helpx.adobe.com/security/products/acrobat/apsb21-09.html>

 **APSB21-13 Security update available for Adobe Dreamweaver**  
Adobe has released a security update for Adobe Dreamweaver. This update resolves a vulnerability rated important. Successful exploitation could lead to sensitive information disclosure in the context of the current user.   
<https://helpx.adobe.com/security/products/dreamweaver/apsb21-13.html>

**APSB21-12 Security update available for Adobe Illustrator**  
Adobe has released an update for Adobe Illustrator 2021. This update resolves multiple critical vulnerabilities that could lead to arbitrary code execution in the context of current user.   
<https://helpx.adobe.com/security/products/illustrator/apsb21-12.html>

**APSB21-11 Security update available for Adobe Animate**  
Adobe has released an update for Adobe Animate. This update resolves a critical vulnerability. Successful exploitation could lead to arbitrary code execution in the context of the current user.   
<https://helpx.adobe.com/security/products/animate/apsb21-11.html>

**APSB21-10 Security update available for Adobe Photoshop**  
Adobe has released updates for Photoshop for Windows and macOS. These updates resolve multiple critical vulnerabilities. Successful exploitation could lead to arbitrary code execution in the context of the current user.   
<https://helpx.adobe.com/security/products/photoshop/apsb21-10.html>

**APSB21-08 Security updates available for Magento**  
Magento has released updates for Magento Commerce and Magento Open Source editions. These updates resolve vulnerabilities rated important and critical. Successful exploitation could lead to arbitrary code execution.   
<https://helpx.adobe.com/security/products/magento/apsb21-08.html>

  


# CVEs

  * A complete list of CVEs can be found here: [ CVEs.txt](/download/attachments/40992848/Adobe%20February%202021%20Updates%20-%20Exploit%20in%20the%20Wild%20CVEs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1613003596846&api=v2)




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://helpx.adobe.com/security.html>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Increase in FakeClicky Skimmer Activity
An increase in activity involving the FakeClicky skimmer has been detected and reported by Zscaler ThreatLabz.
output:
# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Skimmer
  *  **Targets:** Users of compromised e-commerce sites
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** FakeClicky skimmer ****
  * **Initial Infection Vector:** Unspecified
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Extracting victim's details, Exfiltration to skimmer operator.
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See MITRE ATT&CK framework below.



# Overview

The FakeClicky skimmer has been in existence for two years or more and a number of variants have been observed. Zscaler ThreatLabz has reported a recent increase in activity involving the FakeClicky skimmer. In the activity observed by Zscaler, the skimmer is loaded onto compromised e-commerce sites using tags on the sites' pages that give the appearance of loading a legitimate Google Tag Manager script. No information regarding how the e-commerce sites have been compromised is provided in the report. The skimmer code is hosted on recently registered domains that have resolved to one of two IP addresses. The domains are named to appear to belong to legitimate services. When a victim uses a compromised site's checkout page, the skimmer extracts the page's data, encodes it using Base64 and exfiltrates the data to the skimmer operator's system. Further information is available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/64127968/Increase%20in%20FakeClicky%20Skimmer%20Activity%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1631861788013&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Restrict Web-Based Content (M1021).



# References

  * <https://www.zscaler.com/blogs/security-research/fakeclicky-activity-skimmers-hit-again>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1583 - Acquire Infrastructure  
T1583.001 - Domains  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
T1059.007 - JavaScript  
  
 **Persistence - TA0003**  
T1505 - Server Software Component  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1027 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
T1036 - Masquerading  
T1140 - Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1083 - File and Directory Discovery  
  
 **Collection - TA0009**  
T1056 - Input Capture  
T1119 - Automated Collection  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0010**  
T1048 - Exfiltration Over Alternative Protocol  
T1048.003 - Exfiltration Over Unencrypted/Obfuscated Non-C2 Protocol

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: RestyLink - New Campaign Targeting Japanese Companies
NTT Security has observed a new campaign targeting Japanese companies. This is an operation being run by an as-yet-unnamed APT, and the operation has been named RestyLink.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: RestyLink - New Campaign Targeting Japanese Companies
NTT Security has observed a new campaign targeting Japanese companies. This is an operation being run by an as-yet-unnamed APT, and the operation has been named RestyLink.

# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Espionage
  *  **Targets:** Japanese Companies
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** Unknown
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Spearphishing Link
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Unknown



# Overview

Beginning in April of 2022, the NTT Security SOC noticed some APT activity targeting their clients. The attack begins with a phishing email containing a malicious link that will download a zip file. This contains an LNK file, that will download a DOT file on execution and place it in the Microsoft Word startup folder. At this stage, the user will be distracted by a decoy PDF file that will be displayed. After this, every time the user opens a Word document, the DOT file will load and execute a macro to download a second file and execute it. At this point, the researchers were unable to retrieve the final payload from the server. The decoy PDF files seen in this attack were related to international relations between Japan and South Korea. The APT group appears to be based in East Asia and the researchers believe they are mainly targeting Japan. For more information, please see the link in the references section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * For a list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.




# References

  * <https://insight-jp.nttsecurity.com/post/102hojk/operation-restylink-apt-campaign-targeting-japanese-companies>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1566 - Phishing  
T1566.002 - Spearphishing Link  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1204 - User Execution  
T1204.002 - Malicious File  
  
 **Persistence - TA0003**  
T1037.005 - Startup Items  
T1574.002 - DLL Side-Loading  
  


#### Mitigations:

  
 **M1013:** Application Developer Guidance: This mitigation describes any guidance or training given to developers of applications to avoid introducing security weaknesses that an adversary may be able to take advantage of.  
 **M1017:** User Training - Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction.  
 **M1018:** User Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.  
 **M1021:** Restrict Web-Based Content - Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc.  
 **M1022:** Restrict File and Directory Permissions - Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.  
 **M1024:** Restrict Registry Permissions - Restrict the ability to modify certain hives or keys in the Windows Registry.  
 **M1028:** Operating System Configuration - Make configuration changes related to the operating system or a common feature of the operating system that result in system hardening against techniques.  
 **M1031:** Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  
 **M1038:** Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
 **M1040:** Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
 **M1044:** Restrict Library Loading - Prevent abuse of library loading mechanisms in the operating system and software to load untrusted code by configuring appropriate library loading mechanisms and investigating potential vulnerable software.  
 **M1045:** Code Signing - Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.  
 **M1047:** Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
 **M1049:** Antivirus/Antimalware - Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software.  
 **M1051:** Update Software - Perform regular software updates to mitigate exploitation risk.  
 **M1052:** User Account Control - Configure Windows User Account Control to mitigate risk of adversaries obtaining elevated process access.  
 **M1054:** Software Configuration - Implement configuration changes to software (other than the operating system) to mitigate security risks associated to how the software operates.

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Redline Stealer Distributed in Software Cracks
A report from AhnLab ASEC traces a corporate breach to a user's laptop which had cracked software installed on it.
output:
# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Malware
  *  **Targets:** Unspecified
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** Redline Infostealer.
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Weaponized software crack.
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Data collection, and exfiltration.
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

Pirated software and cracks for software have been a common method used to distribute malware for many years. A report from AhnLab ASEC looks at a case where a corporate laptop became infected with the Redline stealer. The laptop was being used by a work from home user who accessed the corporate network using a VPN. A family member used the laptop to search for the crack for a specific piece of software which they located, downloaded, and executed. This was the source of the Redline infection. The laptop's user had stored the VPN password in their web browser and the web browser's credentials were then stolen by Redline. Some months later, the stolen credentials were used to breach the corporate network. Further information is available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/74056576/Redline%20Stealer%20Distributed%20in%20Software%20Cracks%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1641360485854&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Restrict Web-Based Content (M1021).
  * Prevent users or groups from installing unapproved software (M1033).



# References

  * <https://asec.ahnlab.com/en/30445/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1588 - Obtain Capabilities  
T1588.001 - Malware  
T1608 - Stage Capabilities  
T1608.001 - Upload Malware  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1204 - User Execution  
T1204.002 - Malicious File  
  
 **Credential Access - TA0006**  
T1539 - Steal Web Session Cookie  
T1555 - Credentials from Password Stores  
T1555.003 - Credentials from Web Browsers  
  
 **Collection - TA0009**  
T1005 - Data from Local System  
T1113 - Screen Capture  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0010**  
T1041 - Exfiltration Over C2 Channel  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1095 - Non-Application Layer Protocol  
T1571 - Non-Standard Port

BlackCat is a new ransomware-as-a-service advertising its Rust-based payloads on popular underground forums. SentinelOne has published a blog post analyzing the ransomware payload.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: BlackCat Ransomware-as-a-Service
BlackCat is a new ransomware-as-a-service advertising its Rust-based payloads on popular underground forums. SentinelOne has published a blog post analyzing the ransomware payload.

# Threat Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Ransomware
  *  **Targets:** Unknown
  *  **Ransomware Family:** BlackCat
  *  **RaaS Operation:** Yes
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Cobalt Strike, exploitation of public-facing applications
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Data encryption, data theft



# Overview

SentinelOne published a blog post analyzing the BlackCat ransomware, which is being distributed via an affiliate model. The ransomware is written in Rust, allowing it to be executed on both Windows and Linux hosts. Common initial infection vectors used by the affiliates are via a 3rd party framework/toolset or exploitation of a public-facing application. The payload must be executed with an access token parameter, although the token provided is irrelevant. Various additional parameters and options can be provided to disable certain functionality or restrict the scope of encryption. Privilege escalation is performed at the beginning of the execution flow. Volume shadow copies are deleted on Windows and processes that may inhibit encryption are stopped. Files are then encrypted via either AES or ChaCha20. The desktop image is changed to direct victims to a ransom note. The ransom note demands payment via a TOR payment portal in exchange for the decryption key. Additionally, the attackers threaten to leak stolen data on the BlackCat leak site if the ransom is not paid. For more information, see the SentinelOne blog post in the References section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/74057252/BlackCat%20Ransomware-as-a-Service%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1642696109580&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Take and store data backups from end user systems and critical servers. Ensure backup and storage systems are hardened and kept separate from the corporate network to prevent compromise (M1053).



# References

  * <https://www.sentinelone.com/labs/blackcat-ransomware-highly-configurable-rust-driven-raas-on-the-prowl-for-victims/>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: REvil Group is Back
The REvil ransomware gang is back after a 2-month hiatus following its self-imposed shut down after the July 4th Kaseya attacks reports news outlets.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Ransomware Group




# Overview

A mere 2 months after a self-imposed shutdown, REvil is back on the ransomware scene and already wreaking havoc. According to its Happy Blog, the group has resumed attacking organizations and leaking exfiltrated data on the Dark Web. The group has reactivated its Tor payment/negotiation and data leak sites. According to Bleeping Computer, all victims previously attacked had their payment timers reset in order to pay the ransom or risk the sensitive data being leaked. The group has published screenshots of new victim data on its data leak site. Over the past year, the group has attacked at least 360 US-based organizations according to Emsisoft threat analyst Brett Callow. The group claimed, in a chat between what is believed to be a security researcher and a representative of the group, they simply took a break. The previous "leader" of REvil, "UNKN" or "UNK", has disappeared, according to the operator during the chat session. With the group being back in action, some of the victims previously attacked have a chance to get their data back after a leaked decryptor was found to be ineffective. For more information, please see the links located within the Reference section and the MITRE ATT&CK framework below.

# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.zdnet.com/article/revil-ransomware-group-resurfaces-after-brief-hiatus/>

  * <https://www.bleepingcomputer.com/news/security/revil-ransomware-is-back-in-full-attack-mode-and-leaking-data/>

 **Discovery - TA0007**

T1083 - File and Directory Discovery  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0010**

 **Command and Control - TA0011**

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Phishing Emails Targeting Naver Credentials
Spoofing a well-known Korean manufacturer, a phishing campaign caught by EST Security was determined to be attempting to obtain Naver credentials.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Phishing Emails Targeting Naver Credentials
Spoofing a well-known Korean manufacturer, a phishing campaign caught by EST Security was determined to be attempting to obtain Naver credentials.

# Threat Type

  * Phishing




# Overview

EST Security discovered a phishing campaign attempting to steal credentials for Naver, a Korean online platform. The initial phishing email spoofs a well-known Korean steel manufacturer and claims to have a quote attached. This attached HTM file, however, is used to redirect users to a phishing page. The phishing page is almost identical to the legitimate Naver login page and requests the user's credentials. Falling victim to this lure will lead to the entered credentials being exfiltrated back to the attacker. In order to increase the legitimacy of the attack, after entering the credentials the victim is redirected to a fake quote hosted on Google Drive in order to make them think the login was successful. For more information, see the EST Security blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://blog.alyac.co.kr/3325>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: SMAUG Ransomware as a Service
A relatively new Ransomware as a Service (RaaS) offering, SMAUG, is discussed in an analysis by SentinelOne researchers.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: SMAUG Ransomware as a Service
A relatively new Ransomware as a Service (RaaS) offering, SMAUG, is discussed in an analysis by SentinelOne researchers.

# Threat Type

  * Ransomware




# Overview

SentinelOne published their analysis of the SMAUG RaaS offering. It has some interesting characteristics not commonly seen with other RaaS offerings. It first appeared in the threat landscape at the end of April 2020. Similar to other ransomware services, a percentage of the profit made by the purchasers is provided to the operators in order to receive the payload and services. Additionally, the operators charge a registration fee, one that is quite a bit higher than those charged by competitors (.2 BTC or $1,800). One of the most unique features of SMAUG is its multi-platofrm support, allowing encryption of Windows, Linux and macOS systems. Additionally, when building the malicious payload, an option is provided to allow a single encryption key to be used across all victim hosts in a single company. Anti-analysis, offline execution, customizable campaigns are all features advertised in their forum posts. The payloads are generated via a web-based management interface as opposed to the more common offline builder. This web portal also allows victims to decrypt a single file for free. The generated payloads for Windows are obfuscated Go binaries. On Windows, persistence is established via the LoadAppInit_DLLs Registry key. A ransom note is dropped in all folders containing encrypted files. The researchers also note that the SMAUG portal provides detailed walkthroughs for victims and affiliates. For more information, see the SentinelOne blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.



# Reference

  * <https://labs.sentinelone.com/multi-platform-smaug-raas-aims-to-see-off-competitors/>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Fake Roblox Package Used to Install Ransomware
Sonatype researchers have uncovered fake Roblox packages are being used to install malware that, in turn, installs ransomware on victim machines.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Fake Roblox Package Used to Install Ransomware
Sonatype researchers have uncovered fake Roblox packages are being used to install malware that, in turn, installs ransomware on victim machines.

# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Typosquatting
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** DarkDev or DarkDev1
  *  **Associated Payloads:** Monster Ransomware
  *  **Targets:** Users of Roblox
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Typosquatted URL for installation of Roblox API
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Drops obfuscated Batch script, alter registry, drops trojan, and ransomware
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See MITRE ATT&CK Framework below



# Overview

Researchers from Sonatype have uncovered fake npm Roblox API packages being used to install malware and ransomware. Through the use of open source ecosystems, threat actors are able to deploy ransomware using PyPl, npm, and Rubygems. Noblox.js uses open-source JavaScript API for the creation of in-game scripts. At present, Noblox.js-proxy and Noblox.js-proxies have seen 387 total downloads of these malicious, typosquatted packages. The typosquats lead to Noblox's README page. The page appears normal but contains a section of obfuscated code that installs postinstall.js. This drops a Batch script that, in turn, is used to contact a C2 server for the download of the final payload, trojans and ransomware named Monster Ransomware. Attribution to DarkDev or DarkDev1 has been made at this point. Further technical details can be found within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/68616961/Fake%20Roblox%20Package%20Used%20to%20Install%20Ransomware%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1635430903028&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Restrict Web-Based Content (M1021)
  * Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking (M1038). 
  * Leave Safe Browsing warnings on.



# References

  * <https://blog.sonatype.com/fake-npm-roblox-api-package-installs-ransomware-spooky-surprise>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1189 - Drive-by Compromise  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059.007 - JavaScript  
  
 **Persistence - TA0003**  
T1547 - Boot or Logon Autostart Execution  
T1547.001 - Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder  
  
 **Credential Access - TA0006**  
T1056 - Input Capture  
T1056.004 - Credential API Hooking  
  
 **Collection - TA0009**  
T1056 - Input Capture  
T1056.004 - Credential API Hooking  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0010**  
T1041 - Exfiltration Over C2 Channel  
  
 **Impact - TA0040**  
T1485 - Data Destruction  
T1486 - Data Encrypted for Impact

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Updated XCSSET Malware Targets Telegram and Other Apps
XCSSET is a malware family that targets macOS devices in order to steal sensitive information. Trend Micro reports on the most recent updates to the XCSSET malware and its techniques.
output:
# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type** : Stealer

  *  **Associated Threat Actors** : Unknown

  *  **Associated Payloads** : XCSSET

  *  **Targets** : macOS users

  *  **Initial Infection Vector** : Infected Xcode Project ([T1204.002](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1204/002/))

  *  **Post-Compromise Actions** : Steal data from application files ([T1005](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1005/)), Exfiltrate app data ([T1041](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1041/))

  *  **Additional TTPs** : Archive collected data into ZIP ([T1560](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1560))




# Overview

Trend Micro published a blog post analyzing the most recent version of the XCSSET malware. As with before, the malware is delivered via infected Xcode projects and is used to steal information from various apps. Since previous reporting, analysts were able to identify the mechanism for stealing this information. The malware steals application files from the Application sandbox directory, which does not require admin privileges. The application files are archived in ZIP format and exfiltrated to a C2 server. Where administrator privileges are needed, a single command is used to prompt users to grant the permissions via a fake dialog box. The scripts leveraged by XCSSET show the capability to steal information from TElegram, Contacts, Evernote, Notes, Chrome, Opera, Skype, and WeChat. The researchers also provide a brief overview of recent C2 infrastructure changes. For more information, see the Trend Micro blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.



# Reference

  * <https://www.trendmicro.com/en_us/research/21/g/updated-xcsset-malware-targets-telegram--other-apps.html>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Jekyll Island Authority Ransomware Attack
Breach/Leak Notification: The Jekyll Island Authority was victim of a Ransomware attack during the week of 7-11 September 2020. News Break reports on steps taken to mitigate and eliminate the attack.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Ransomware Attack




# Overview

  
A ransomware attack on the Jekyll Island Authority in Georgia brought the computer systems of the authority to a halt. According to JIA Executive Director Jones Hooks, "JIA computer systems were infected by a ransomware attack designed to damage or gain unauthorized access to the system." Further, "all of our computer systems - this was not just within a department - were impacted, and it’s a very serious situation,” Hooks said. “It’s much more than just an interruption of the internet (sic) or anything like that.” The attackers were able to gain access through the authority's firewalls and encryption schemes. A third-party provider was able to identify and eliminate the threat. The restoration of the computer systems is still underway and communication with the attackers has yet to yield any type of demand for the recovery assistance of the affected files and computer systems. Further information can be found in the article located within the Reference section below.

# CVEs

  * N/A




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://www.newsbreak.com/news/2061662093944/jia-computer-system-infiltrated-in-ransomware-attack>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: A Brute-Force Attack Against a Linux Server
A report from JPCERT/CC provides insight into an attack on a publicly accessible Linux server and the attacker's actions subsequent to compromising the host.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware, Brute-force, Cryptominer




# Overview

An attack on a Linux server is the subject of a report from JPCERT/CC. In what appears to be a brute-force attack, an attacker attempted to log into a publicly accessible Linux server multiple times before successfully logging in as root. Once logged into the server, the attacker carried out brute-force attacks against other Linux servers located on the compromised host's Intranet. In cases where the servers were successfully compromised, the attacker installed an XMRig cryptominer and used a process hiding tool named h64, and the deletion of log files help to evade detection. The attacker also conducted scans of random Internet IP addresses from the initially compromised server. If the right combinations of open ports and banners from the scans were found, a brute-force attack was then carried out on the host. Further information can be found in the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://blogs.jpcert.or.jp/en/2021/05/xmrig.html>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Cyberpunk 2077 Release Hoax is Actually Data Theft Attempt
A joint analysis effort by Kaspersky and other researchers has revealed a scheme to steal information from users eagerly awaiting the release of a new game.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Cyberpunk 2077 Release Hoax is Actually Data Theft Attempt
A joint analysis effort by Kaspersky and other researchers has revealed a scheme to steal information from users eagerly awaiting the release of a new game.

# Threat Type

  * Malware




# Overview

With the much anticipated impending release of the PC game Cyberpunk 2077 comes a scam being perpetrated against impatient users. The scam involves the download of a fake installer, which is used to steal data through a series of redirects and phishing pages. When the user visits one of the fake sites, they are presented with the option to download a copy of the game, which, in actuality, is an executable that masquerades as the real game installer. This executable contains legitimate looking splash screens and buttons. Though some buttons are unusable, it's a convincing enough fake that users are clicking on the install link. Once the install link is clicked, a window is displayed that shows the "game" being downloaded and unpacked. The program doesn't actually perform an install action; instead, the program only emulates the install process. From here, the user is presented with the option of entering a license key. Since the game is not yet released, the actors decided to include a link in the installer, which will allow the victim to obtain a key. The link takes the victim to another site that leads to a survey or giveaway entry. A new prompt is displayed asking a set of questions, such as requests for phone number and email addresses. This information, it is hypothesized, is the target data set of the threat actors. The site does provide a key, which has been hard coded into the installer' however, the game will not start as a DLL is missing from the installation. The user would have to click the download button again. They are taken to a dead end site with another survey. More information can be found in the link in the Reference section below. 

# CVEs

  * N/A




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.




# Reference

  * <https://www.kaspersky.com/blog/cyberpunk-2077-scam/37907/>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Black KingDom Ransomware Using ProxyLogon Exploit
A variety of threat actors have been exploiting the ProxyLogon vulnerability in order to carry out malicious activities. Sophos identified the operators of the Black KingDom ransomware also taking advantage of this exploit in a recent campaign.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Ransomware




# Overview

Sophos published a blog post analyzing Black KingDom's use of the ProxyLogon exploit to distribute its ransomware payloads. After exploiting ProxyLogon (CVE-2021-27065) on vulnerable on-premise versions of Microsoft Exchange Server, the threat actor installed a webshell in order to allow further remote command execution. A PowerShell command was executed via this webshell to download and install the ransomware payload from a remote server. Analysis of the payload reveals that it is a Python script compiled into an executable using PyInstaller. It contains a list of folders to avoid encrypting and kills SQL services to unlock database files. The generated encryption key and ID are uploaded to a [mega.io](http://mega.io) account. Finally, encryption is performed by reading the original file, overwriting it with encrypted content, and renaming it. No indicators are added to the file to prevent the file from being encrypted again. After encryption completes, the mouse and keyboard are disabled and a full screen window displays a ransom note and a countdown timer. Sophos notes that review of the cryptocurrency transaction log reveals at least one victim has paid the ransom. For more information, see the Sophos blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.



# Reference

  * <https://news.sophos.com/en-us/2021/03/23/black-kingdom/>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Cryptojacking Malware Disabling Threat Detection Tools In Cloud Instances
Cryptojacking attacks succeed by being as stealthy as possible while the malware steals computer resources from the victim machine. This article from Trend Micro explores the common feature where malware will attempt to disable features inside cloud service providers.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Cryptojacking Malware Disabling Threat Detection Tools In Cloud Instances
Cryptojacking attacks succeed by being as stealthy as possible while the malware steals computer resources from the victim machine. This article from Trend Micro explores the common feature where malware will attempt to disable features inside cloud service providers.

# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Cryptojacking
  *  **Targets:** Unknown
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** Unknown
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Unknown
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Cryptomining



# Overview

Cryptojacking malware aims to sit on victim computers for as long as possible without being noticed, so they can utilize as many resources as they can. To achieve this, the malware employs techniques to reduce the possibility of detection and competition. Trend Micro has reported on functionality that appears in multiple samples - the ability to disable features of the cloud service provider. These particular attacks target the Alibaba Elastic Computing Service, which comes with a preinstalled security agent. Upon infection, many cryptojacking samples will attempt to uninstall this to avoid detection. This is not uncommon behavior for malware, but in this example, specific code was identified which creates firewall rules to drop packets coming from internal Alibaba zones and regions. Alibaba ECS also makes a good target as it provides root access to the instance, which many cloud providers do not. Since the threat actor can gain the highest possible privilege, the possibility of advanced payloads such as kernel module rootkits and system service persistence can be established. There is potential for a large financial impact for victims of this malware, as cloud autoscaling can mean victims get charged more for the increased resource usage. For more information, please see the link in the reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/74058339/Cryptojacking%20Malware%20Disabling%20Threat%20Detection%20Tools%20In%20Cloud%20Instances%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1644318133034&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Ensure containers are not running as root by default (M1026).



# References

  * <https://www.trendmicro.com/en_us/devops/22/b/cryptojacking-attacks-target-alibaba-ecs-instances.html>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Persistence - TA0003**  
T1543 - Create or Modify System Process  
  
 **Privilege Escalation - TA0004**  
T1543 - Create or Modify System Process  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1014 - Rootkit  
T1562 - Impair Defenses  
T1562.001 - Disable or Modify Tools  
T1562.007 - Disable or Modify Cloud Firewall  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1007 - System Service Discovery  
  
 **Impact - TA0040**  
T1496 - Resource Hijacking

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: ICS-CERT Advisories - September 22, 2020
ICS-CERT has published two security advisories addressing vulnerabilities in ICS-related systems.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

ICS-CERT has published two security advisories, ICSA-20-266-01 and ICSA-20-266-02, addressing vulnerabilities in ICS-related systems. ICSA-20-266-01 addresses two vulnerabilities in the GE Digital APM Classic tool. The first vulnerability, CVE-2020-16240, is an insecure direct object reference (IDOR) vulnerability that could allow an attacker to download sensitive data related to user accounts without having the proper privileges. The second vulnerability, CVE-2020-16244, is the result of unsalted passwords that could allow an authenticated user to obtain and decrypt password hashes. Both vulnerabilities are patched in recent versions of the software. ICSA-20-266-02 details two vulnerabilities in GE Reason S20 Ethernet Switches. CVE-2020-16242 and CVE-2020-16246 are both cross site scripting vulnerabilities, one of which could allow an attacker to perform critical application actions while the other could allow malicious JavaScript to be rendered. Both vulnerabilities have been patched by GE in recent firmware updates. We recommend reviewing the advisories, linked to in the References section, and applying any relevant updates as soon as possible.

# CVEs

A complete list of associated CVEs can be found here: 

# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ics/advisories/icsa-20-266-01>

  * <https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ics/advisories/icsa-20-266-02>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Colibri Loader Using New Persistence Technique
Malwarebytes Labs has been tracking the Colibri loader first seen in August 2021, which has recently been seen delivering the Mars Stealer. In this article, they discuss a new persistence mechanism it has been seen using.
output:
# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Loader
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Unknown
  *  **Associated Payloads:** Colibri Loader, Mars Stealer
  *  **Targets:** Unknown
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Malicious Word Doc **  
**
  * **Post-Compromise Actions:** Load Mars Stealer



# Overview

Colibri Loader was first seen in August 2021. Malwarebytes Labs researchers have been tracking a more recent campaign that has been seen delivering the Mars Stealer malware. One feature of note was the use of a brand new persistence mechanism. The infection starts with a malicious word document that deploys the loader using a remote template injection attack. For persistence, the malware creates a scheduled task to execute PowerShell with a hidden window. Earlier on in the process, the malware drops an executable (Get-Variable.exe) in the WindowsApps directory, which has the same name as a legitimate PowerShell command-let. When this command is executed, the system processes the malicious file rather than the proper command. Analysis shows that the earliest use of this technique matches when Colibri Loader was first seen on underground forums, showing that this could be the first use of this technique. For more information, please see the link in the References section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

For a full list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.

# References

  * <https://blog.malwarebytes.com/threat-intelligence/2022/04/colibri-loader-combines-task-scheduler-and-powershell-in-clever-persistence-technique/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059.001 - PowerShell  
  
 **Persistence - TA0003**  
T1053.005 - Scheduled Task  
T1574.001 - DLL Search Order Hijacking  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1027 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
T1564.003 - Hidden Window  
  


#### Mitigations:

  
 **M1013:** Application Developer Guidance: This mitigation describes any guidance or training given to developers of applications to avoid introducing security weaknesses that an adversary may be able to take advantage of.  
 **M1018:** User Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.  
 **M1021:** Restrict Web-Based Content - Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc.  
 **M1022:** Restrict File and Directory Permissions - Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.  
 **M1024:** Restrict Registry Permissions - Restrict the ability to modify certain hives or keys in the Windows Registry.  
 **M1026:** Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.  
 **M1028:** Operating System Configuration - Make configuration changes related to the operating system or a common feature of the operating system that result in system hardening against techniques.  
 **M1033:** Limit Software Installation - Block users or groups from installing unapproved software.  
 **M1038:** Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
 **M1040:** Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
 **M1042:** Disable or Remove Feature or Program - Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.  
 **M1044:** Restrict Library Loading - Prevent abuse of library loading mechanisms in the operating system and software to load untrusted code by configuring appropriate library loading mechanisms and investigating potential vulnerable software.  
 **M1045:** Code Signing - Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.  
 **M1047:** Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
 **M1049:** Antivirus/Antimalware - Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software.  
 **M1051:** Update Software - Perform regular software updates to mitigate exploitation risk.  
 **M1052:** User Account Control - Configure Windows User Account Control to mitigate risk of adversaries obtaining elevated process access.

parsed_raw_data.xfe_q:
Colibri Loader Using New Persistence Technique
Malwarebytes Labs has been tracking the Colibri loader first seen in August 2021, which has recently been seen delivering the Mars Stealer. In this article, they discuss a new persistence mechanism it has been seen using.
parsed_raw_data.xfe_report:
# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Loader
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Unknown
  *  **Associated Payloads:** Colibri Loader, Mars Stealer
  *  **Targets:** Unknown
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Malicious Word Doc **  
**
  * **Post-Compromise Actions:** Load Mars Stealer



# Overview

Colibri Loader was first seen in August 2021. Malwarebytes Labs researchers have been tracking a more recent campaign that has been seen delivering the Mars Stealer malware. One feature of note was the use of a brand new persistence mechanism. The infection starts with a malicious word document that deploys the loader using a remote template injection attack. For persistence, the malware creates a scheduled task to execute PowerShell with a hidden window. Earlier on in the process, the malware drops an executable (Get-Variable.exe) in the WindowsApps directory, which has the same name as a legitimate PowerShell command-let. When this command is executed, the system processes the malicious file rather than the proper command. Analysis shows that the earliest use of this technique matches when Colibri Loader was first seen on underground forums, showing that this could be the first use of this technique. For more information, please see the link in the References section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

For a full list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Linux and VMware ESXi Variant of LockBit Ransomware
After a public announcement by LockBit regarding a Linux and ESXi version of its ransomware, Trend Micro has published a blog post analyzing samples observed in the wild.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Ransomware
  *  **Targets:** Unknown
  *  **Ransomware Family:** LockBit
  *  **RaaS Operation:** Yes
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Unknown
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Data encryption, data theft



# Overview

Trend Micro published a blog post analyzing samples of a LockBit variant targeting Linux and ESXi hosts. The LockBit group announced the release of the variant on an underground forum back in October 2021 and shortly after samples appeared in the wild. When executing the payload, the operator can provide various parameters that will modify how the ransomware operates, such as how much of a file is encrypted and whether logging should occur. The commands necessary for encrypting VM images on ESXi servers are also included. These include those for gathering a list of VMs, shutting them down, and enabling SSH. The ransom note is similar to those observed in Windows variants. Along with demanding a ransom in exchange for the decryption key, it also threatens to release stolen data and attempts to recruit potential insiders. For more information, see the Trend Micro blog post in the References section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/74057430/Linux%20and%20VMware%20ESXi%20Variant%20of%20LockBit%20Ransomware%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1643045104751&api=v2)



# Protection

## Yara Rule
    
    
    rule Linux_Lockbit_Jan2022 {  
      
       meta:  
      
          description = "Detects a Linux version of Lockbit ransomware"  
          author = "TrendMicro Research"  
          date = "2022-01-24"  
          hash1 = "038ff8b2fef16f8ee9d70e6c219c5f380afe1a21761791e8cbda21fa4d09fdb4"  
      
         strings:  
      
            $xor_string_1 = "LockBit Linux/ESXi locker V:" xor(0x01-0xff)  
            $xor_string_2 = "LockBit 2.0 the world's fastest ransomware since 2019" xor(0x01-0xff)  
            $xor_string_3 = "Tox ID LockBitSupp" xor(0x01-0xff)  
      
        condition:  
      
          uint16(0) == 0x457f and filesize < 300KB and  
          filesize > 200KB and any of them  
      
    }

# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Perform endpoint scans using the provided Yara rules.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Take and store data backups from end user systems and critical servers. Ensure backup and storage systems are hardened and kept separate from the corporate network to prevent compromise (M1053).



# References

  * <https://www.akamai.com/blog/security/mirai-botnet-abusing-log4j-vulnerability>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Impact - TA0040**  
T1486 - Data Encrypted for Impact  
T1490 - Inhibit System Recovery

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: XML Vulnerabilities in Go's Standard Library
Mattermost has responsibly disclosed three XML vulnerabilities in Go's standard library.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability



# Overview

Mattermost, working with Go's security team, has responsibly disclosed three XML vulnerabilities in Go's standard library. These include an XML attribute instability (CVE-2020-29509), an XML directive instability (CVE_2020-29510), and an XML element instability (CVE-2020-29511). In essence, if your application is processing information that has already gone through Go's decoder and encoder functions at least one time before, the application may be processing invalid data, since Go's decoder and encoder does not preserve the semantics of the data. The lack of integrity is a major issue in applications that require absolute semantic integrity in order to be secure, such as SAML (Security Assertion Markup Language). The notification indicates that the Go team cannot, at this time, reliably and reasonably address the issues. Only one of the issues is on the Go roadmap to be addressed in the foreseeable future. Mattermost is releasing an XML validation library that can be used as a workaround until a full patch can be released. For more details, please refer to the disclosure notification in the Reference section.

# CVEs

  * A complete list of CVEs can be found here: [XML Vulnerabilities in Gos Standard Library CVEs.txt](/download/attachments/35718356/XML%20Vulnerabilities%20in%20Gos%20Standard%20Library%20CVEs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1608064748127&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * https://mattermost.com/blog/coordinated-disclosure-go-xml-vulnerabilities/

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: APT32 and Bangladesh-Based Threat Group Disruption
After discovering APT32 and a Bangladesh-based threat group performing malicious activity on their platform, Facebook implemented disruption techniques to prevent further abuse. They subsequently published a blog post sharing the details of this activity.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware, APT




# Overview

Facebook published a blog post detailing their attempts to disrupt activity carried out by two separate threat groups. The first group is an unnamed, Bangladesh-based threat actor targeting local and activists, journalists and religious minorities. Their purpose seemed to be to have target accounts and Pages disabled. Facebook researchers were able to tie this activity to Don’s Team (also known as Defense of Nation) and the Crime Research and Analysis Foundation (CRAF), two non-profit organizations in the region. In collaboration, they would report target pages and accounts to Facebook in an attempt to have Facebook block them. In other cases, hacked accounts were used to spread content related to their operational purposes. Finally, one occasion involved hacking a page admin's account, removing the rest of the admins, and disabling the page. The researchers believe that the hacking of the accounts took place through email/device compromise or abuse of account recovery processes. Facebook took action by disabling all accounts and pages found to be behind this activity. The second threat group reported on in this blog post is APT32, a Vietnamese APT. Their campaigns target Vietnamese human rights activists, foreign governments, and others. Research into their activity began with the discovery of fictitious personas created on Facebook in order to carry out social engineering campaigns. During the research, Facebook also discovered malicious Google Play Store apps with surveillance capabilities and custom-built malware being distributed through watering hole attacks. For more information, see the Facebook blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://about.fb.com/news/2020/12/taking-action-against-hackers-in-bangladesh-and-vietnam/>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Hive Ransomware Activity
A report from Netskope details the Hive ransomware group, which, unlike most other ransomware-as-a-service groups, has attacked healthcare organizations.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Hive Ransomware Activity
A report from Netskope details the Hive ransomware group, which, unlike most other ransomware-as-a-service groups, has attacked healthcare organizations.

# Threat Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Ransomware
  *  **Ransomware Family:** Hive
  *  **Targets:** Non-specific
  *  **RaaS Operation:** Unconfirmed
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Malicious email attachment
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Data encryption, Data theft
  *  **Leak Site:** hiveleakdbtnp76ulyhi52eag6c6tyc3xw7ez7iqy6wc34gd2nekazyd[.]onion



# Overview

Netskope published a blog post that details recent attacks by the Hive ransomware group and analyzes the ransomware payload. The recent attack against the Memorial Health System is significant because most ransomware-as-a-service groups have a code of ethics to avoid breaching hospitals, as it can cause life or death situations. Hive operates a double extortion model, stealing data and threatening to release it if the ransom is not paid. Their leak site is hosted on the dark web, provides victim information, and performs a countdown. If the ransom is not paid, the stolen data is shared via a file-sharing service. The initial infection vector is purportedly a phishing attachment that provides attackers access to the victim host and network. The ransomware payload is written in Go, providing the possibility for cross-platform execution. It can be executed via the command line with various optional parameters for killing processes, stopping services, skipping certain files, and more. One unique feature of this ransomware is that the encrypted key is stored in a file on the system. This means if the key file is deleted, file decryption will be impossible. The ransom note points users to a dark web portal where they can chat with the operators and receive the decryption software if the ransom is paid. For more information, see the Netskope blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/64127588/Hive%20Ransomware%20Activity%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1631547670436&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques and phishing emails (M1017).
  * Restrict Web-Based Content (M1021).



# References

  * <https://www.netskope.com/blog/hive-ransomware-actively-targeting-hospitals>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Impact - TA0040**  
T1486 - Data Encrypted for Impact

 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter

 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1566 - Phishing  
T1566.001 - Spearphishing Attachment

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Malicious Ads for Home Depot Being Used in Google Search
A familiar type of campaign has been seen by Bleeping Computer after a user reported having fallen for the scam. The scam involves using malicious ads in Google Search results for Home Depot.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Malicious Ads for Home Depot Being Used in Google Search
A familiar type of campaign has been seen by Bleeping Computer after a user reported having fallen for the scam. The scam involves using malicious ads in Google Search results for Home Depot.

# Threat Type

  * Malvertising




# Overview

A malvertising campaign has been underway using an ad for Home Depot as a redirect to tech support scams. These types of campaigns are nothing new. Previously, Amazon Prime, PayPal, and eBay have been observed being used in the same type of activity. Threat actors use malicious search ads to point users to a seemingly innocuous result for Home Depot in this case. Upon hovering over the link, the legitimate URL for Home Depot appears and provides the victim with a false sense of security. In their research, Bleeping Computer was able to find the malicious link on the first attempt at doing so. Upon clicking on the link, they were redirected through ad services until they reached a tech support scam website purporting to be "Windows Defender - Security Warning". The scam page opens the Print dialog box which makes closing the web page difficult. In an effort to deter diagnosis of the ads, the scam will only run once every 24 hours, per IP address. Any clicks after the first sends the victim to the legitimate web page. The scam web page contains a phone number the victim is to call to "remedy" the security issue. Further details can be found within the Reference section below. 

# CVEs

  * N/A




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

parsed_raw_data.xfe_q:
Malicious Ads for Home Depot Being Used in Google Search
A familiar type of campaign has been seen by Bleeping Computer after a user reported having fallen for the scam. The scam involves using malicious ads in Google Search results for Home Depot.
parsed_raw_data.xfe_report:
# Threat Type

  * Malvertising




# Overview

A malvertising campaign has been underway using an ad for Home Depot as a redirect to tech support scams. These types of campaigns are nothing new. Previously, Amazon Prime, PayPal, and eBay have been observed being used in the same type of activity. Threat actors use malicious search ads to point users to a seemingly innocuous result for Home Depot in this case. Upon hovering over the link, the legitimate URL for Home Depot appears and provides the victim with a false sense of security. In their research, Bleeping Computer was able to find the malicious link on the first attempt at doing so. Upon clicking on the link, they were redirected through ad services until they reached a tech support scam website purporting to be "Windows Defender - Security Warning". The scam page opens the Print dialog box which makes closing the web page difficult. In an effort to deter diagnosis of the ads, the scam will only run once every 24 hours, per IP address. Any clicks after the first sends the victim to the legitimate web page. The scam web page contains a phone number the victim is to call to "remedy" the security issue. Further details can be found within the Reference section below. 

# CVEs

  * N/A




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://www.bleepingcomputer.com/news/security/beware-malicious-home-depot-ad-gets-top-spot-in-google-search/>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Exposed Kubeflow Interfaces Used to Run Cryptomining Containers
A new campaign has been targeting exposed Kubeflow interfaces to install containers that carry out cryptocurrency mining according to a a report from a researcher at Cloud Security Research.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Cryptomining




# Overview

In late May, Cloud Security Research observed an increase in deployments of TensorFlow pods on a number Kubernetes clusters. The deployments were simultaneous, which according to Cloud Security Research, indicates the targets were scanned prior and the attacks staged to execute at the same time. To carry out the attack, the attackers targeted exposed instances of Kubeflow's centralized dashboard. Two cryptomining pods were installed on each cluster. One being the Ethminer which uses the GPU for mining, the other being XMRIG which uses the CPU. Prior to the commencement of cryptomining, a pod was installed which provided the attacker's information on the environment such as CPU and GPU information. Further details are available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.
