  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://techcommunity.microsoft.com/t5/azure-security-center/new-large-scale-campaign-targets-kubeflow/ba-p/2425750>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: macOS Adware in Rust
Using a new programming language, Rust, threat actors have turned their attention to the creation of adware. SecureList posted a blog detailing the language and its use in the creation of adware.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Adware




# Overview

A new adware program dubbed Convuster has been seen in the wild. The adware is written in a little known programming language called Rust. Analysts were able to identify the language through the use of Rust specific language and the file extension .rs. The malware works by checking for keys needed to run the adware. The program obtains a device ID, system version, fitness and forwards that data to a C2 server. A JSON file is sent and sends a request to the host specified within the JSON file. In response, a Bash script is sent and executed. After the script retrieves the Bash shell, it is removed from the system. Upon analysis of the C2 server, a DMG disk image with the Convuster executable written in Swift was found. The malware is stored in a macOS Gatekeeper security system. This helps to prevent analysis from security professionals. If certain checks are successful, the user is shown a window prompting the installation of FlashPlayer. If the checks fail, the program provides a window informing the victim to try later. The actual malware is run through LaunchAgents but does not write itself to run on startup. Based on the behavior of the malware, SecureList has classified it as malware. Further details can be found in the blog located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://securelist.com/convuster-macos-adware-in-rust/101258/>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: New Lyceum Group Malware Profiled
Kaspersky researchers have written an in-depth report on new malware they discovered being used by the Lyceum Group.
output:
# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Malware
  *  **Associated Threat Group:** Lyceum Group, APT34, Hexane (G0005)
  *  **Targets:** Telecommunications, Oil, Gas
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** DanBot
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Unknown
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Reconnaissance, Lateral Movement, Credential Harvesting



# Overview

Researchers at Kaspersky have profiled the threat group known as the Lyceum Group (or Hexane). They are a little-known threat actor who has been active since April 2018 and has become known for attacking telecommunications companies and critical systems in the Middle East. Since being originally discovered, researchers have noted that they have replaced their publicly documented payload known as 'DanBot', with new C++ backdoors and a PowerShell script that serve the same purpose. The script was discovered on VirusTotal in November 2020, and using the C2 server, the researchers were able to access the new C++ payloads. There are two main variants of the backdoor, named 'James' and 'Kevin', after the names of directories found with the variants. Both variants communicate with their C2 servers using DNS, but the 'James' variant also allows for communication over HTTP exfiltration. The domains used in the attack attempt to impersonate known services, by using keywords such as 'cloud', 'windows', or 'cdn'. The attackers also host their own nameservers, meaning they can decode the DNS queries received from the malware and respond using commands the malware can understand. Once a machine has been infected, the attackers use commands from the C2 server to perform local reconnaissance. They also drop a Mimikatz-based executable to harvest credentials from Google Chrome. Although this is an individual group, the researchers do comment on the similarities between Lyceum Group and APT34, so there could be a relationship between these groups. Further information can be found in the article located within the Reference section below.

  


# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/68616283/New%20Lyceum%20Group%20Malware%20Profiled%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1634812999338&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Set PowerShell execution policy to execute only signed scripts (M1045).
  * When PowerShell is necessary, restrict PowerShell execution policy to administrators. Be aware that there are methods of bypassing the PowerShell execution policy, depending on environment configuration (M1026).



# References

  * <https://vblocalhost.com/uploads/VB2021-Kayal-etal.pdf>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1583 - Acquire Infrastructure  
T1583.001 - Domains  
T1583.002 - DNS Server  
T1587 - Develop Capabilities  
T1587.001 - Malware  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
T1059.001 - PowerShell  
T1106 - Native API  
  
 **Persistence - TA0003**  
T1053 - Scheduled Task/Job  
  
 **Privilege Escalation - TA0004**  
T1078 - Valid Accounts  
  
 **Credential Access - TA0006**  
T1003 - OS Credential Dumping  
T1552 - Unsecured Credentials  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1007 - System Service Discovery  
T1012 - Query Registry  
T1046 - Network Service Scanning  
T1057 - Process Discovery  
T1083 - File and Directory Discovery  
T1087 - Account Discovery  
  
 **Collection - TA0009**  
T1056 - Input Capture  
T1056.001 - Keylogging  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
T1071.001 - Web Protocols  
T1071.004 - DNS  
T1132 - Data Encoding

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: New npm Malware With Bladabindi Trojan Spotted
Analysts at Sonatype recently unveiled updated malware within the npm registry, combining typosquatting packages with njRAT.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware




# Overview

Over the Thanksgiving holiday, Sonatype discovered two malicious npm packages named jdb.js and db-json.js. According to the analyst, jdb.js contains the credential stealing RAT, njRAT. The npm package contained three files and conducts multiple malicious activities such as: data gathering, reconnaissance, and launching patch.exe which is the njRAT dropper. Before C2 communication is initiated, the malicious executable edits Windows firewall rules to avoid connection and communication issues. The db-json.js package eludes malicious intention by appearing to be a safe and legitimate JSON DB creation package but works in conjunction with the jdb.js package. According to the analyst, what was even more interesting, was the effective implementation of the db-json.js package. After infecting the desired target, the end-user’s machine is then open to a multitude of nefarious acts, granting the attacker the ability to, log keystrokes, alter registry values, inaugurate system shutdown, initially granting a level of C2 to the attacker. Furthermore, putting developers at risk who may be unaware of the malware. Further information can be found in the article located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://blog.sonatype.com/bladabindi-njrat-rat-in-jdb.js-npm-malware>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Bandook Malware in Spanish Language Emails
A new and highly active threat group that is distributing the Bandook malware in Spanish language emails has been reported on by Proofpoint who refer to the group as TA2721.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware




# Overview

Proofpoint researchers have identified a new threat group that they refer to as TA2721. The group is using Spanish language emails to spread the Bandook malware. An earlier ESET report noted the malware in a campaign they named Bandidos. The Proofpoint report notes that TA2721 campaigns are low in the volume of emails, typically less than 300 per campaign, and target employees with Spanish-language surnames in less than 100 companies, at a time. The emails have a PDF file attached which contains a link to a password-protected RAR archive. The password is provided in the PDF. The archive contains an executable file which is the Bandook payload. Proofpoint has located two variants of Bandook used in the campaigns. Bandook achieves persistence through a Registry run key. C&C communications are encrypted using AES in CFB mode, a hardcoded key, and an initialization vector that differs from the publicly available versions of Bandook. Further information is available from the reports linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.proofpoint.com/us/blog/threat-insight/new-threat-actor-uses-spanish-language-lures-distribute-seldom-observed-bandook>

  * <https://www.welivesecurity.com/2021/07/07/bandidos-at-large-spying-campaign-latin-america/>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Evolution of Fake Alert and Technical Support Scams
Sophos has published an article on the various "scarevertising" methods in play today, including "fake alerts", technical support scams, and browser locks.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware, Scams, Browser Locks, Scarevertising



# Overview

As the Sophos article states, "For nearly as long there have been web advertising networks, there have been malicious web ads." A lot of work has been accomplished by browser vendors to protect the user, but there are still unscrupulous ad networks that do not monitor or restrict what is being sent to the user. Some ads use a "pop-under" technique to bypass any "pop-up" restrictions that the browser may have employed. These "pop-under" techniques may deploy JavaScript or Cascading Style Sheet (CSS) features to convince the user their system has a real problem that only the contents of the ad can resolve. Technical support calls of the past, where a potential victim was cold-called over the phone, have evolved to use web pages, maliciously designed, that pull the victim to the fake call center for "assistance with their problem". It isn't just the desktop being attacked, either. Mobile devices have similar attack patterns. Ads on mobile devices may lead to tech support scams or to PUAs (Potentially Unwanted Applications). The PUAs may even reside in Google's or Apple's app stores because there's no real malicious code within the app to trigger anti-malware detection software. For more technical details, please refer to the link in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/29432396/Evolution%20of%20Fake%20Alert%20and%20Technical%20Support%20Scams%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1599685244864&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://news.sophos.com/en-us/2020/09/09/faking-it-the-thriving-business-of-fake-alert-web-scams>

Tell me everything you know the following threat: Emotet Adopts Political and Elections Lures
Continuing their use of current events to social engineer victims, Emotet has pivoted to using political and elections lures. Proofpoint reports on samples from this recent campaign.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware




# Overview

Proofpoint identified an Emotet campaign using political and election themes to social engineer recipients. With the U.S. presidential election coming up, users may be more susceptible to this type of messaging. The email body contains text directly copied from the Democratic National Committee's website. Added to the end of the text is a request to open an attached Word document. As is common with Emotet infection chains, this Word document uses malicious macros to download and install Emotet. This campaign is distributing Qbot and Trickbot as secondary payloads. Along with the subject and filename of "Team Blue Take Action," researchers also observed volunteer-themed and other subject and filenames. For more information, see the Proofpoint blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.proofpoint.com/us/blog/threat-insight/emotet-makes-timely-adoption-political-and-elections-lures>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Ave_Maria and Packer Malware Analysis
In order to avoid heuristic-based detection, malware families will implement various forms of obfuscation. VMRay analyzed one such case where Ave_Maria has implemented a packer to obfuscate its code.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Ave_Maria and Packer Malware Analysis
In order to avoid heuristic-based detection, malware families will implement various forms of obfuscation. VMRay analyzed one such case where Ave_Maria has implemented a packer to obfuscate its code.

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Stealer




# Overview

VMRay has published a blog post analyzing Ave_Maria and a packer it leveraged for obfuscation. The infection chain begins with the packer, which is a .NET binary. It starts by establishing persistence via a scheduled task that executes at logon. A new process is created in a suspended state. Ave_Maria is then extracted and decoded from the packer's resource section and unpacked into the new process. The Ave_Maria payload is comprised of two executables. The first one is the stealer payload which performs the majority of the malicious activity. It establishes a secondary method of persistence by writing itself to a Registry Run key. The stealer payload also performs the main purpose of the malware, stealing credentials from various applications, such as browsers and email clients. The second executable that is injected into memory is simply a UAC bypass that leverages DLL hijacking. For more information, see the VMRay blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.vmray.com/cyber-security-blog/ave_maria-malware-analysis-spotlight/>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: New Ransomware - Vovalex
The new Vovalex ransomware may be the first known ransomware to be written in the D language. It was discovered by the MalwareHunterTeam and is the subject of a report from Bleeeping Computer.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware, Ransomware




# Overview

A report from Bleeping Computer looks at the new Vovalex ransomware that was discovered by the MalwareHunterTeam. Vovalex is unusual in that it may be the first known ransomware to be written in the D language. It was discovered being distributed in pirated software such as Windows utilities. The sample that is the subject of the article was distributed with a version of the CCleaner utility. When Vovalex encrypts files, it appends the extension .Vovalex to the encrypted files. The ransom note, left on the desktop, provides instructions and a demand for 0.5 XMR (Monero, about $70 USD) from the victim, to provide them with a decryptor. While more samples of Vovalex have been uploaded to Virus Total, at this time it does not appear that Vovalex has been widely distributed. Further information is available from the links in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Malicious npm Packages Targeting Major Companies
A new package in the npm ecosystem has been seen by Sonatype and appears to be targeting major corporations.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability, Malware




# Overview

New packages in the npm ecosystem are targeting major corporations such as Google, Zillow, Lyft, and Slack, by using names similar to their components, namespaces, or repositories. Some of the package names are amzn, zg-rentals, lyft-dataset-sdk, and serverless-slack-app. Sonatype has identified more than 700 copycat packages in the npm repository. Research carried out by an independent researcher led Sonatype to observe more than 700 copycat packages in the npm repository. Originally a bug bounty hunt, the malicious packages were identified as such and are now being reported on. A proof-of-concept package was used as the template for the packages. It appears as though this type of package crosses the line from security awareness bounty hunting into unethical areas. The lack of disclaimers and code comments are what led Sonatype to conclude this is not linked to any kind of bounty hunting. While these disclaimers may not always be what they appear, the lack of them indicates the author is not working in good faith with the targeted companies. The packages installed share a name with already installed dependencies, hence the ability to perform "dependency confusion." The packages exfiltrate the .bash_history, etc/shadow, and could, in some cases, spawn reverse shells. The author listed within the code (zappos) is a subsidiary company of one of the targets, Amazon. Amazon routinely uses amzn as shorthand for some of its packages. Inside the package are two files. Within the run.js file are the contents of the shadow file which is sent to the author's domain. In addition to the shadow file exfiltration, the attacker uses .bash_history to exfiltrate IP address, hostname, and current directory. Researchers indicate the increase in npm dependency confusion packages is on the rise and precautions should be taken to ensure use of non-malicious packages. Further information can be found within the article located in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.

  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.

  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.

  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.

  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.




# Reference

  * <https://blog.sonatype.com/malicious-dependency-confusion-copycats-exfiltrate-bash-history-and-etc-shadow-files>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Apache Struts 2 RCE Vulnerability
The Apache Software Foundation has published an advisory that addresses a vulnerability in Struts 2, which, in some cases, could allow for the remote execution of arbitrary code.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

An advisory from the Apache Software Foundation addresses a vulnerability in Struts 2 that could allow a remote attacker to execute arbitrary code. The vulnerability is caused by a failure to properly sanitize user-provided input in certain tags. The vulnerability can be exploited if forced Object-Graph Navigation Language (OGNL) evaluation using the %{...} syntax has been applied. A remote attacker could exploit the vulnerability by sending a maliciously crafted request to the application, potentially leading to arbitrary code execution. Versions of Strut 2 2.0.0 through 2.5.25 are affected. A workaround, and an update (version 2.5.26), have been published to address the vulnerability. Further details are available from the link in the Reference section below.

# CVEs

  * CVE-2020-17530




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/WW/S2-061#space-menu-link-content>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: P.A.S. Fork v. 1.0
A blog from Sucuri has an analysis of the P.A.S. Fork V. 1.0, a PHP web shell that originally appeared in 2013.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: P.A.S. Fork v. 1.0
A blog from Sucuri has an analysis of the P.A.S. Fork V. 1.0, a PHP web shell that originally appeared in 2013.

# Threat Type

  * Malware




# Overview

Sucuri has published a blog with information on P.A.S. Fork V 1.0. A version of the PHP web shell has been making the rounds since at least late 2016 when DHS and the FBI issued a joint report (linked below) on the malware with several IoCs for detection of the web shell. The initial version of the web shell was retired in 2013 due to accusations made against the authors of the shell. The latest variant was first seen in January 2020 in a new thread on a forum. Interest in the P.A.S. web shell was renewed after disclosure of new capabilities. These capabilities were mainly related to evasion tactics to avoid detection from web application firewalls and IDS systems. First verifiable usage of the new version came in March 2020 on a compromised website. Other changes included a different packer/obfuscator and the addition of random ASCII characters, which makes the PHP code difficult to read without proper editing tools. By removing the added strings, analysis could more easily be performed. Other modifications exist and can be seen by comparing older versions with the newest in a side-by-side editor. Backdoor commands are contained within the attacker's HTTP request as cookies. Hash values are set to facilitate obfuscation and are applied to a string containing the server IP and backdoor file. Hashed passwords can also be encoded. Further details can be found in the blog post located within the Reference section below.

# CVEs

  * N/A




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://blog.sucuri.net/2020/10/p-a-s-fork-v-1-0-a-web-shell-revival.html>

  * <https://us-cert.cisa.gov/sites/default/files/publications/JAR_16-20296A_GRIZZLY%20STEPPE-2016-1229.pdf>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: New DJVU Ransomware Variant
While monitoring dark web marketplaces, Cyble discovered a new version of the DJVU malware, a member of the STOP ransomware family.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Ransomware




# Overview

Cyble published a blog post analyzing a new variant of the DJVU ransomware. Active since 2018, DJVU is part of the STOP ransomware family. Its distribution method is via Trojanized software cracks or keygens. Once executed on the system, several common ransomware behaviors are initiated. These include modifying system files, changing Windows registry entries, and deleting Volume Shadow Copies in an attempt to reduce the chance of file recovery. The malware then retrieves additional payloads from a remote server and executes them. These stagers are used for AV evasion capabilities. Finally, the encryption process begins, specifically implementing custom AES or RSA algorithms. Encrypted files are appended with a defined extension. In most cases, the name of the virus is used as the extension, but the sample analyzed by Cyble used the extension ".QSCX". The malware checks in with a C2 server after encryption is complete. Additionally, a scheduled task is created to regularly encrypt any new files. The ransom note requests victims contact the operators via email to pay the ransom and receive the decryption tool. For more information, see the Cyble blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.



# Reference

  * <https://cybleinc.com/2021/06/21/djvu-malware-of-stop-ransomware-family-back-with-new-variant/>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: R_Evil WordPress Hacktool and Malicious JavaScript Injections
Discovered during a recent investigation, Sucuri researchers report on an interesting custom WordPress hacktool, dubbed "R_Evil," and JavaScript injection activity.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: R_Evil WordPress Hacktool and Malicious JavaScript Injections
Discovered during a recent investigation, Sucuri researchers report on an interesting custom WordPress hacktool, dubbed "R_Evil," and JavaScript injection activity.

# Threat Type

  * Malware




# Overview

Sucuri has published a blog post analyzing a recently discovered WordPress hacktool dubbed "R_Evil." Their analysis pertains to the main PHP file used to load secondary files making up the hacktool. They believe their inability to find samples of the secondary files is due to a self-destruct function in the tool that cleans up associated files. Many of the functions in the tool are similar to most PHP shells, such as those for file modifications, downloading, executing PHP, and scanning files. The researchers highlight several functions that are more unique, including those to update or debug WordPress, restore files, and scan for malware. The malware scanning function in particular is interesting as it appears to scan for a common website malware based on filenames and regex strings. It is possible this is used to remove existing infections in order to reduce the chance of detection. Another interesting aspect of the main PHP file was the presence of a modified version of the hello.php WordPress file. The modification is used to inject malicious JavaScript into the front end of the website. When loaded, this JavaScript redirects users to scam landing page. For more information, see the Sucuri blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.



# Reference

  * <https://blog.sucuri.net/2020/10/r_evil-wordpress-hacktool-malicious-javascript-injections.html>

  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.



# Reference

  * <https://blog.sucuri.net/2020/10/r_evil-wordpress-hacktool-malicious-javascript-injections.html>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Attacks on Industrial Enterprises Using RMS and TeamViewer
Expanding on their previous research into the use of RMS and TeamViewer in attacks on industrial enterprises, Kaspersky reports on the changes in techniques employed by the threat actors.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware




# Overview

Kaspersky has published a blog post analyzing changes in the campaigns abusing RMS and TeamViewer that they previously reported on. This activity has been occuring from 2018 until at least early fall 2020 with all the attacks starting with a phishing email. This phishing email is customized to the recipient in terms of the content of the body of the email and filenames, but the attackers have pivoted from using custom domain names to instead using public email services. Attached to these emails is a password-protected RAR archive containiing several malicious obfuscated JS scripts masquerading as normal documents. Executing one of these scripts opens a malicious program and a legitimate PDF file. The legitimate PDF file appears to be real documents stolen from previous attacks. While this document is distracting the user, a modified version of TeamViewer with a hidden GUI is installed. Previously, at this point the TeamViewer ID was sent to an attacker-controlled C2 server. However, they are now using legitimate RMS remote administration infrastructure to transport this information using its email notification functionality. Kaspersky notes that the RMS developers have implemented code to prevent this abuse in future. With TeamViewer access established, the attackers are granted full control over the system, which they have used to install spyware and Mimikatz in order to obtain credentials for lateral movement and eventually carry out their ultimate goal of stealing funds from financial software on the network. For more information, see the Securelist blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://securelist.com/attacks-on-industrial-enterprises-using-rms-and-teamviewer-new-data/99206/>  
<https://securelist.com/attacks-on-industrial-enterprises-using-rms-and-teamviewer/87104/>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: More_eggs Backdoor Delivered via LinkedIn with Fake Job Offers
More_eggs is a malware-as-a-service backdoor sold by Golden Chickens to other cybercriminals. eSentire reports on its recent usage in a spear phishing campaign targeting LinkedIn professionals with fake job offers to distribute the payload.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Backdoor




# Overview

eSentire discovered the more_eggs backdoor being distributed as part of a LinkedIn spear phishing campaign. Targets receive a ZIP file name based on their LinkedIn job title, attempting to lure them into opening the ZIP file. Opening the file leads to the execution of VenomLNK, the initial stage of a more_eggs infection. VenomLNK, in turn, displays a decoy job application document to distract the user while executing TerraLoader, more_eggs' plugin loader. Finally, Terraloader loads the TerraPreter payload via an ActiveX control file downloaded from AWS. The more_eggs operator is then able to interact with the victim host in order to carry out further activities, such as installing additional malware or exfiltrating data. Notably, this entire infection chain is performed by abusing legitimate Windows processes, decreasing the chances of detection. eSentire was unable to attribute this activity to a specific threat actor, but based on known more_eggs customers and previous threat activity, potential groups include FIN6, Evilnum, and Cobalt Group. For more information, see the eSentire blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.esentire.com/security-advisories/hackers-spearphish-professionals-on-linkedin-with-fake-job-offers-infecting-them-with-malware-warns-esentire>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Vulnerable WordPress Sites Used To DDoS Ukrainian Targets
BleepingComputer has reported on the discovery of several WordPress sites which contain a malicious script. When accessed by a user, the script is run and the browser is used to stage a DDoS attack. Details have been published in a report.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** DDoS
  *  **Targets:** Ukrainian Websites
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** Unknown
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** WordPress Vulnerabilities
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** DDoS Attack



# Overview

Browsers are being used as part of an ongoing DDoS attack, BleepingComputer has reported. The attackers have compromised several WordPress sites using known vulnerabilities. With this, they have implanted a JavaScript file that runs when the site is loaded. The script forces the browser to make many connections to a hardcoded website, intending to degrade the service of the website. The sites targeted by the script include Ukrainian government agencies, think tanks, financial sites, and other pro-Ukrainian sites. Upon further analysis, the researchers found the same script being used by a pro-Ukrainian site to target Russian websites. The difference in this use of the script is that the website is transparent about the use of the script whereas on the compromised WordPress sites the user wouldn't know the script is running in the background. The script uses a random query string in the request to avoid anti-DDoS services and get to the actual target server. For more information please see the link in the reference section.

# Recommendations

For a full list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.

# References

  * <https://www.bleepingcomputer.com/news/security/hacked-wordpress-sites-force-visitors-to-ddos-ukrainian-targets/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059.007 - JavaScript  
  
 **Impact - TA0040**  
T1489 - Service Stop  
T1498 - Network Denial of Service  
  


#### Mitigations:

  
 **M1016:** Vulnerability Scanning - Vulnerability scanning is used to find potentially exploitable software vulnerabilities to remediate them.  
 **M1018:** User Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.  
 **M1021:** Restrict Web-Based Content - Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc.  
 **M1022:** Restrict File and Directory Permissions - Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.  
 **M1024:** Restrict Registry Permissions - Restrict the ability to modify certain hives or keys in the Windows Registry.  
 **M1026:** Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.  
 **M1030:** Network Segmentation - Architect sections of the network to isolate critical systems, functions, or resources. Use physical and logical segmentation to prevent access to potentially sensitive systems and information. Use a DMZ to contain any internet-facing services that should not be exposed from the internal network. Configure separate virtual private cloud (VPC) instances to isolate critical cloud systems.  
 **M1033:** Limit Software Installation - Block users or groups from installing unapproved software.  
 **M1037:** Filter Network Traffic - Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic.  
 **M1038:** Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
 **M1040:** Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
 **M1042:** Disable or Remove Feature or Program - Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.  
 **M1045:** Code Signing - Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.  
 **M1047:** Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
 **M1048:** Application Isolation and Sandboxing - Restrict execution of code to a virtual environment on or in transit to an endpoint system.  
 **M1049:** Antivirus/Antimalware - Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software.  
 **M1050:** Exploit Protection - Use capabilities to detect and block conditions that may lead to or be indicative of a software exploit occurring.  
 **M1051:** Update Software - Perform regular software updates to mitigate exploitation risk.

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Remote Code Execution Vulnerabilities Affect Drupal Core
A Security Advisory for Drupal, SA-CORE-2020-013, addresses critical remote code execution vulnerabilities in the PEAR Archive_Tar library, which is used by the Drupal core.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

  
The Drupal Security Advisory, SA-CORE-2020-013, provides an update for various versions of Drupal core to address remotely exploitable code execution vulnerabilities in the Drupal core. The vulnerabilities are rated as critical by Drupal. The vulnerabilities exist in the PEAR Archive_Tar library and are caused by a failure to properly sanitize user provided input when processing URI handlers in filenames. A remote attacker who can upload maliciously crafted .tar, .tar.gz, .bz2, or .tlz files could potentially execute arbitrary PHP code on an affected system. The vulnerabilities are addressed in versions 7.75, 8.8.12, 8.9.10, 9.0.9. Further details are available from the advisory linked to in the Reference section below.

# CVEs

  * A complete list of CVEs can be found here: [Remote Code Execution Vulnerability Affects Drupal Core CVEs.txt](/download/attachments/33983867/Remote%20Code%20Execution%20Vulnerability%20Affects%20Drupal%20Core%20CVEs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1606446648437&api=v2)




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://www.drupal.org/sa-core-2020-013>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Cryptomining Campaign Targeting Docker Linux Systems
A cryptomining campaign targeting Docker Linux systems was detected, analyzed, and reported on by SentinelOne.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Cryptomining Campaign Targeting Docker Linux Systems
A cryptomining campaign targeting Docker Linux systems was detected, analyzed, and reported on by SentinelOne.

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Cryptomining




# Overview

SentinelOne has published a blog post detailing a cryptomining campaign they observed. The campaign specifically targeted a Docker container running Linux, although the initial access method to that container is not specified. Once on the system, the threat actor executed a shell script that, in turn, downloaded and executed a second-stage script. Performing similar actions, the second-stage attempts to download and execute the final shell script in the sequence. The final shell script is responsible for downloading and executing the final payload. Steganography is used to embed the ELF binary into a JPG image, reducing its detection rate. By extracting and analyzing the payload, the researchers identified the final executable as XMRig, providing the threat actor with a profit via Monero mining. For more information, see the SentintelOne blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.



# Reference

  * <https://labs.sentinelone.com/caught-in-the-cloud-how-a-monero-cryptominer-exploits-docker-containers/>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Hidden SEO Spam Threatens WorldPress Sites
Analysts at Sucuri observed threat actors utilizing black hat SEO tactics to enhance effectiveness and exploit WordPress sites.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware




# Overview

  
It was discovered by analysts at Sucuri that SEO spam, also known as spamdexing, was being utilized to exploit WordPress sites. According to the analysts, one notable technique commonly seen was attackers forcing the injected SEO spam links off the visible portion of the website, further eluding the spam from end-users but not from bots that can read the HTML.  The threat actors utilize the PHP function fsockopen() to connect to other malicious PHP functions containing the URL to the SEO spam infrastructure. In conclusion, SEO spam attacks can be dangerous and generate copious amounts of revenue for threat actors. The researchers highlight the usage of remote site scanning tools, such as SiteCheck, to help end-users detect security issues, malware, infected files and, blacklist status.

# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://blog.sucuri.net/2020/11/hidden-seo-spam-link-injections-on-wordpress-sites.html>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Two New IoT Vulnerabilities Identified with Mirai Payloads
Mirai is constantly evolving and adding new exploits to its infection chain. Palo Alto identified four variants across recent campaigns that have added previously unobserved IoT vulnerabilities.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware, Botnet




# Overview

Palo Alto published a blog post analyzing new Mirai variants leveraging exploits not previously observed. Across the four Mirai variants, two new vulnerabilities were identified. In both cases, remote code execution vulnerabilities in IoT devices were exploited to run a wget command that downloads a shell script. The shell script, in turn, downloads Mirai binaries for various architectures and executes each one. The first vulnerability is the result of an unsanitized HTTP parameter in IoT devices synchronizing time over HTTP. Palo Alto researchers are still analyzing IoT devices that use such NTP server handling routines to identify which specific devices are being targeted. The second exploit is also due to lack of sanitization of an HTTP parameter. In this case, limited context is provided so pinpointing the targeted device has been a challenge, but it is believe that it may be a remote process management tool based on the included parameters. This second exploit was only used for a matter of seconds based on Palo Altos observations and not been observed since. All four of the analyzed variants have the capability to launch DDoS attacks. Additionally, one of the variants contains an infection capability not present in the other three variants. For more information, see the Palo Alto blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.



# Reference

  * <https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/iot-vulnerabilities-mirai-payloads/>

parsed_raw_data.xfe_q:
Two New IoT Vulnerabilities Identified with Mirai Payloads
Mirai is constantly evolving and adding new exploits to its infection chain. Palo Alto identified four variants across recent campaigns that have added previously unobserved IoT vulnerabilities.
parsed_raw_data.xfe_report:
# Threat Type

  * Malware, Botnet




# Overview

Palo Alto published a blog post analyzing new Mirai variants leveraging exploits not previously observed. Across the four Mirai variants, two new vulnerabilities were identified. In both cases, remote code execution vulnerabilities in IoT devices were exploited to run a wget command that downloads a shell script. The shell script, in turn, downloads Mirai binaries for various architectures and executes each one. The first vulnerability is the result of an unsanitized HTTP parameter in IoT devices synchronizing time over HTTP. Palo Alto researchers are still analyzing IoT devices that use such NTP server handling routines to identify which specific devices are being targeted. The second exploit is also due to lack of sanitization of an HTTP parameter. In this case, limited context is provided so pinpointing the targeted device has been a challenge, but it is believe that it may be a remote process management tool based on the included parameters. This second exploit was only used for a matter of seconds based on Palo Altos observations and not been observed since. All four of the analyzed variants have the capability to launch DDoS attacks. Additionally, one of the variants contains an infection capability not present in the other three variants. For more information, see the Palo Alto blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.



# Reference

Tell me about the following threat: Western Digital My Cloud NAS Devices Security Vulnerabilities
Five security vulnerabilities were discovered by Comparitech researchers in Western Digital network-attached storage (NAS) devices. The vulnerabilities affect a large number of the devices globally.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Western Digital My Cloud NAS Devices Security Vulnerabilities
Five security vulnerabilities were discovered by Comparitech researchers in Western Digital network-attached storage (NAS) devices. The vulnerabilities affect a large number of the devices globally.

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability



# Overview

Comparitech researches have published a paper on five vulnerabilities found in Western Digital network-attached storage (NAS) devices. If successfully exploited, the exploitation of these vulnerabilities could lead to remote code execution. Also possible is the ability to compromise data and files on a vulnerable device or allow the installation of malware on the device. An update for the device has been available since late October. A process to automatically update vulnerable devices is not present, so owners must manually apply the firmware update. For affected devices and descriptions of the CVEs, please refer to the link in the Reference section.

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Symchanger Malware Installing Backdoor on Unsuspecting Users
Sucuri Labs reports on the Symchanger malware being peddled to bad actors under the guise of free malware for use in campaigns.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware




# Overview

Symchanger malware is a "free" malware being distributed by bad to other bad actors under the guise of free malware. In addition to the malware, the compromise tool is being promoted on a Facebook group along with a tutorial video. The malware, however, is distributed with a backdoor installer that allows the authors access to other bad actor's computer systems. The code is obfuscated using differing layers and code checks. Deobfuscation is not an easy feat as it's not just text that is encoded and compressed. Upon deobfuscation of the code, the symchanger.php name is seen. Cross-contamination is accomplished via a popular symlink method so long as the site is hosted by the same user as the compromised website. A tool is used to search for configuration files for various website publication platforms such as WordPress and others. If detected, a .txt file is generated so the file can be downloaded. If /etc/passwd is accessible, the file is read and a list of existing users is gathered. A loop is then used to run the list of users from passwd against the various publication system's configuration files to extract the matching credentials. The malware then reads SQL connection information and connects to the associated database, where it adds a malicious administrative user to any databases to which it can successfully connect. Once the script has finished, the results are displayed to the threat actor. Without deobfuscation, the malware appears to be what the attacker claims it to be. The malware sends five emails to multiple addresses which contain sensitive data for the compromised website(s). Further details can be found in the blog post located within the Reference section below.

# CVEs

  * N/A




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://blog.sucuri.net/2020/12/free-symchanger-malware-tricks-users-into-installing-backdoor.html>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: New Campaign Using Targeted Exploitation of Vulnerable Zoho Products
Palo Alto are tracking a campaign where multiple instances of ManageEngine ADSelfService Plus have been exploited to gain access into corporate networks. The researchers have reported on the tools and patterns seen in this campaign.
output:
# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Dropper
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** APT27
  *  **Associated Payloads:** Godzilla Webshell
  *  **Targets:** Unknown
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Exploitation of ManageEngine ADSelfService Plus
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Drop Webshell



# Overview

An as-yet-unknown APT actor has compromised 13 organizations after exploiting new vulnerabilities in the self-service password management and single sign-on solution known as ManageEngine ADSelfService Plus, according to a Palo Alto report. The threat actor conducting this campaign has shifted its focus to other vulnerable Zoho products, like ManageEngine ServiceDesk Plus. The campaign is being called TiltedTemple and its tactics and tooling appear to correspond with the APT27 group, but no group has been attributed with confidence yet. The actor has been observed to exploiting the vulnerabilities and uploading a new dropper which provides further access to and persistence in compromised systems. After successfully exploiting an internet-facing instance of ServiceDesk Plus, the actor uploaded a malicious file called msiexec.exe to the server. The dropper attempts to write a hardcoded java module to disk, which is a variant of the Godzilla webshell. The researchers have scanned for vulnerable instances of the ServiceDesk Plus, and have found over 4000 internet-exposed systems, with 62% being vulnerable to exploitation. Further details can be found in the article located within the Reference section below. 

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/74056487/New%20Campaign%20Using%20Targeted%20Exploitation%20of%20Vulnerable%20Zoho%20Products%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1640880345453&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior (M1040). 



# References

  * <https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tiltedtemple-manageengine-servicedesk-plus/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Reconnaissance - TA0043**  
T1595 - Active Scanning  
T1595.002 - Vulnerability Scanning  
  
 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1587 - Develop Capabilities  
T1587.001 - Malware  
T1587.004 - Exploits  
  
 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1203 - Exploitation for Client Execution  
  
 **Persistence - TA0003**  
T1546 - Event Triggered Execution  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1027 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1057 - Process Discovery  
T1082 - System Information Discovery  
T1083 - File and Directory Discovery  
T1518 - Software Discovery

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: BladeHawk Targets Ethnic Kurds with Android RATs
ESET has published a report on a campaign conducted by the BladeHawk group that used Facebook postings to target ethnic Kurds with the Android RATs 888 and SpyNote.
output:
# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Android Malware
  *  **Targets:** Ethnic Kurds and their supporters
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** 888 RAT, and SpyNote (S0305)
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Fake apps containing the malware.
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions and** **Additional TTPs:** See MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

According to ESET, the BladeHawk group created Facebook profiles that posted links to fake Android apps. The profiles gave the appearance of being news feeds, news about Android in Kurdish, and news that would interest supporters of the Kurds. The postings contained links to apps that, while appearing legitimate, contained commercial malware, the 888 and SpyNote RATs. The same profiles were also used to post links to malicious apps to certain public Facebook groups which have a combined number of followers in excess of 11,000. In some cases, phishing activities were also observed. Further information is available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/64127353/BladeHawk%20Targets%20Ethnic%20Kurds%20with%20Android%20RATs%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1631158059643&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Restrict Web-Based Content (M1021).



# References

  * <https://www.welivesecurity.com/2021/09/07/bladehawk-android-espionage-kurdish/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **For 888 RAT**

 **Initial Access TA0027**  
T1444 Masquerade as Legitimate Application

 **Persistence TA0028**  
T1402 Broadcast Receivers   
  
**Defense Evasion TA0030**  
T1508 Suppress Application Icon   
T1447 Delete Device Data  
  
 **Credential Access TA0031**  
T1411 Input Prompt  
  
 **Discovery TA0032**  
T1418 Application Discovery  
T1420 File and Directory Discovery  
  
 **Collection TA0035**  
T1433 Access Call Log   
T1430 Location Tracking  
T1432 Access Contact List  
T1429 Capture Audio  
T1512 Capture Camera  
T1412 Capture SMS Messages  
T1533 Data from Local System  
T1513 Screen Capture  
  
 **Command And Control TA0037**  
T1509 Uncommonly Used Port  
  
 **Impact TA0034**  
T1582 SMS Control  
T1447 Delete Device Data

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Citrix Vulnerability Exploited To Deliver Webshell
Crowdstrike recently investigated an incident in which the threat actor PROPHET SPIDER exploited a vulnerability in Citrix software to deliver a webshell. The technical details of this have been published in a report.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Citrix Vulnerability Exploited To Deliver Webshell
Crowdstrike recently investigated an incident in which the threat actor PROPHET SPIDER exploited a vulnerability in Citrix software to deliver a webshell. The technical details of this have been published in a report.

# Threat Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Vulnerability
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** PROPHET SPIDER
  *  **Associated Payloads:** Unknown
  *  **Targets:** Unknown
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Exploitation of Public Facing Infrastructure
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Further Tool Download



# Overview

Crowdstrike has published the details of an incident in which PROPHET SPIDER deployed a web shell. PROPHET SPIDER is a cybercriminal group that has been active since 2017. In this incident, they exploited a vulnerability in the Citrix ShareFile Storage Zones Controller service to upload code that will execute arbitrary commands. After infection, the actors tested the connection and then downloaded a reverse shell tool from GitHub. For more information, please see the link in the references section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

For a full list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.

# References

  * <https://www.crowdstrike.com/blog/prophet-spider-exploits-citrix-sharefile/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059.001 - PowerShell  
  
 **Persistence - TA0003**  
T1505.003 - Web Shell  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
T1105 - Ingress Tool Transfer  
  


#### Mitigations:

  
 **M1016:** Vulnerability Scanning - Vulnerability scanning is used to find potentially exploitable software vulnerabilities to remediate them.  
 **M1018:** User Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.  
 **M1021:** Restrict Web-Based Content - Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc.  
 **M1026:** Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.  
 **M1030:** Network Segmentation - Architect sections of the network to isolate critical systems, functions, or resources. Use physical and logical segmentation to prevent access to potentially sensitive systems and information. Use a DMZ to contain any internet-facing services that should not be exposed from the internal network. Configure separate virtual private cloud (VPC) instances to isolate critical cloud systems.  
 **M1031:** Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  
 **M1033:** Limit Software Installation - Block users or groups from installing unapproved software.  
 **M1037:** Filter Network Traffic - Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic.  
 **M1038:** Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
 **M1040:** Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
 **M1042:** Disable or Remove Feature or Program - Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.  
 **M1045:** Code Signing - Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.  
 **M1047:** Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
 **M1048:** Application Isolation and Sandboxing - Restrict execution of code to a virtual environment on or in transit to an endpoint system.  
 **M1049:** Antivirus/Antimalware - Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software.  
 **M1050:** Exploit Protection - Use capabilities to detect and block conditions that may lead to or be indicative of a software exploit occurring.  
 **M1051:** Update Software - Perform regular software updates to mitigate exploitation risk.

Citrix Vulnerability Exploited To Deliver Webshell
Crowdstrike recently investigated an incident in which the threat actor PROPHET SPIDER exploited a vulnerability in Citrix software to deliver a webshell. The technical details of this have been published in a report.

 **M1030:** Network Segmentation - Architect sections of the network to isolate critical systems, functions, or resources. Use physical and logical segmentation to prevent access to potentially sensitive systems and information. Use a DMZ to contain any internet-facing services that should not be exposed from the internal network. Configure separate virtual private cloud (VPC) instances to isolate critical cloud systems.  
 **M1031:** Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  
 **M1033:** Limit Software Installation - Block users or groups from installing unapproved software.  
 **M1037:** Filter Network Traffic - Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic.  
 **M1038:** Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
 **M1040:** Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
 **M1042:** Disable or Remove Feature or Program - Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.  
 **M1045:** Code Signing - Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.  
 **M1047:** Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
 **M1048:** Application Isolation and Sandboxing - Restrict execution of code to a virtual environment on or in transit to an endpoint system.  
 **M1049:** Antivirus/Antimalware - Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software.  
 **M1050:** Exploit Protection - Use capabilities to detect and block conditions that may lead to or be indicative of a software exploit occurring.  
 **M1051:** Update Software - Perform regular software updates to mitigate exploitation risk.

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: HabitsRAT Used to Target Linux and Windows Servers
HabitsRAT is a simple backdoor identified to be targeting Microsoft Exchange servers by exploiting the ProxyLogon vulnerability. Intezer has discovered newer Windows variants as well as a Linux variant.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware, RAT




Overview

Intezer published a blog post analyzing the HabitsRAT backdoor, which was previously observed exploiting the ProxyLogon vulnerability. With their discovery, they also found a Linux variant of the malware, although the exploit leveraged to deliver this version is unknown. The malware is written in Go, allowing the same main code base to be shared between the variants with separate files to handle operating system-specific code. Once on the system, it attempts to establish persistence via a systemd unit file on Linux or a scheduled task on Windows. C2 communication is rather sophisticated as it uses public-key cryptography for encryption and authentication. The C2 server is polled every 10 seconds to check whether a command should be executed. Along with version 11 of the malware, a version 12 was found for Windows, with a different C2 public key in use and support for multiple C2 addresses. For more information, see the Intezer blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.



# Reference

  * <https://www.intezer.com/blog/malware-analysis/habitsrat-used-to-target-linux-and-windows-servers/>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Samba Security Advisories - March 24th, 2021
Samba published two security advisories addressing vulnerabilities in their software.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview



The first advisory addresses CVE-2020-27840, a heap corruption vulnerability in all Samba versions since Samba 4.0.0. If successfully exploited, an easily crafted DN could be sent to the Samba AD DC LDAP server to crash it. The second advisory addresses CVE-2021-20277, an out of bound read vulnerability in AD DC LDAP server. If successfully exploited, user-controlled LDAP filter strings may be used to crash the LDAP server.

Samba has released patches and mitigation advice alongside both advisories. We recommend reviewing the advisories and implementing their guidance as soon as possible.

# CVEs

  * CVE-2020-27840

  * CVE-2021-20277




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://www.samba.org/samba/security/CVE-2020-27840.html>

  * <https://www.samba.org/samba/security/CVE-2021-20277.html>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: An Analysis of the LockFile Ransomware
Sophos has published an analysis of the LockFile ransomware which uses a novel approach to file encryption.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Ransomware
  *  **Targets:** Unspecified
  *  **Ransomware Family:** LockFile
  *  **RaaS Operation:** Unspecified
  *  ** **Initial Infection Vector:**** Microsoft Exchange ProxyShell vulnerabilities
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** PetitPotam NTLM relay attack, File encryption
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

Emerging in July 2021, and according to Sophos, LockFile implements a novel approach to encrypting files. Instead of encrypting the whole file, it only encrypts chunks of the file. This technique may help evade detection by some ransomware protection systems due to the encrypted files looking statistically similar to an unencrypted file. LockFile has been used in attacks that exploited vulnerabilities (CVE-2021-34473, CVE-2021-34523, and CVE-2021-31207) in on-premise Microsoft Exchange servers to gain access to a system. Next, the PetitPotam NTLM relay attack has been used to gain control of the domain. LockFile attacks are human-operated, rather than automated. Files encrypted by LockFile are renamed using lowercase and have the extension .lockfile added to them. The ransom note directs the user to a ToR website to pay the ransom and obtain a decrypter. Further information is available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/64127177/An%20Analysis%20of%20the%20LockFile%20Ransomware%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1630910608951&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).



# References

  * <https://news.sophos.com/en-us/2021/08/27/lockfile-ransomwares-box-of-tricks-intermittent-encryption-and-evasion/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1047 - Windows Management Instrumentation  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1027 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
T1055 - Process Injection  
T1140 - Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information  
T1553 - Subvert Trust Controls  
  
 **Credential Access - TA0006**  
T1187 - Forced Authentication  
T1557 - Man-in-the-Middle  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1090 - Proxy  
T1104 - Multi-Stage Channels

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Tech Support Scam Campaign Abuses XSS Vulnerability
While scammers typically use malvertising to lead users to their tech scam site, Malwarebytes has observed a new campaign that uses Facebook as a distribution point and cross-site scripting (XSS) for redirection.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Tech Support Scam Campaign Abuses XSS Vulnerability
While scammers typically use malvertising to lead users to their tech scam site, Malwarebytes has observed a new campaign that uses Facebook as a distribution point and cross-site scripting (XSS) for redirection.

# Threat Type

  * Scam




# Overview

Malwarebytes has published a report detailing a new tech support scam campaign leveraging a cross-site scripting (XSS) vulnerability to carry out their malicious actions. The first link is a bit.ly shortened URL that is being distributed via Facebook. This shortener then redirects users to a secondary website that contains an XSS vulnerability allowing for open redirects. In particular, the XSS vulnerability is used to load JavaScript from a remote attacker-controlled domain. The purpose of the JavaScript is to perform the malicious redirect to a browlock landing page. Assuming the IP address of the visitor is based in the US, the browlock landing page identifies the browser version and shows an animation indicating the victim's computer is infected and requests they call a tech support center to avoid data loss. While Malwarebytes did not investigate past this point, it is likely the fake call center will try to scam users out of money or personal data. For more information, see the Malwarebytes blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.



# Reference

  * <https://blog.malwarebytes.com/cybercrime/2020/10/xss-to-tss-tech-support-scam-campaign/>
