instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Maze Attackers Adopt Ragnar Locker Virtual Machine Technique
After their initial attempts at deploying the Maze ransomware failed, attackers switched to deploying their payload via a virtual machine. Sophos published a blog post analyzing this infection chain that was observed in a recent incident they responded to.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Ransomware




# Overview

Sophos has published a blog post analyzing a recent Maze ransomware attack that resulted in the use of a technique previously observed in use by Ragnar Locker. The technique was implemented after the first two attempts to deliver the payload directly to the victim host were blocked. At this point, the operators instead dropped a virtual machine and an 11 year old copy of VirtualBox onto the system via an MSI installer. Running as a headless device, the VM executed a series of files stored on its virtual hard drive. First, a batch file is used to rename the VM's computer name and join the VM to the victim's network. Furthermore, shared network drives are mapped to the host and a shared folder is created and shared with the rest of the network. Persistence is established via the Startup folder on infected hosts. This technique was originally observed in use by the Ragnar Locker ransomware operators. The key difference between the two campaigns is that Ragnar Locker used a Windows XP machine whereas Maze used a Windows 7 image. This meant the associated files in the Maze attack were much larger than the Ragnar Locker files. For more information, see the Sophos article in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://news.sophos.com/en-us/2020/09/17/maze-attackers-adopt-ragnar-locker-virtual-machine-technique/>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: XorDdos Malware Infections On The Rise
Microsoft has written a report on a sharp rise in infections of the Linux malware XorDdos. This malware is used as a botnet to perform DDoS attacks.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: XorDdos Malware Infections On The Rise
Microsoft has written a report on a sharp rise in infections of the Linux malware XorDdos. This malware is used as a botnet to perform DDoS attacks.

# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** DDoS
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Unknown
  *  **Associated Payloads:** XorDdos 
  * **Targets:** Linux Machines
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** SSH Bruteforcing
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** DDoS Attack



# Overview

Microsoft has published a detailed report on the Linux malware XorDdos, of which they have seen a 254% increase in infections this year. The malware uses SSH brute force attacks to gain control of a remote target. If successful, root access is used to run a script to install XorDdos on the victim machine. The payload contains a number of anti-detection capabilities, such as running as a daemon process, obfuscated data, and process name spoofing. Some samples also installed a kernel rootkit to hide the presence of malicious code. For persistence, the malware drops an 'init' script to run on system startup, as well as sets up a scheduled script to run every three minutes. To stage the DDoS attack, the malware uses multiple threads, with each one sending a significant amount of traffic to the target address. The target IP address is received from the C2 server, to which it sends relevant system information on startup. the malware can also download and upload files. For more information, please see the link in the references section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * For a full list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.




# References

  * <https://www.microsoft.com/security/blog/2022/05/19/rise-in-xorddos-a-deeper-look-at-the-stealthy-ddos-malware-targeting-linux-devices/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Reconnaissance - TA0043**  
T1590.005 - IP Addresses  
T1595 - Active Scanning  
  
 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1078 - Valid Accounts  
T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059.004 - Unix Shell  
  
 **Persistence - TA0003**  
T1037.005 - Startup Items  
T1053.003 - Cron  
  
 **Privilege Escalation - TA0004**  
T1078 - Valid Accounts  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1014 - Rootkit  
T1027 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
T1036.004 - Masquerade Task or Service  
T1070 - Indicator Removal on Host  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1082 - System Information Discovery  
  
 **Lateral Movement - TA0008**  
T1021.004 - SSH  
T1570 - Lateral Tool Transfer  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0010**  
T1041 - Exfiltration Over C2 Channel  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
  
 **Impact - TA0040**  
T1498.001 - Direct Network Flood  
  


#### Mitigations:

  
 **M1013:** Application Developer Guidance: This mitigation describes any guidance or training given to developers of applications to avoid introducing security weaknesses that an adversary may be able to take advantage of.  
 **M1016:** Vulnerability Scanning - Vulnerability scanning is used to find potentially exploitable software vulnerabilities to remediate them.  
 **M1017:** User Training - Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction.  
 **M1018:** User Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.  
 **M1021:** Restrict Web-Based Content - Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc.  
 **M1022:** Restrict File and Directory Permissions - Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.  
 **M1024:** Restrict Registry Permissions - Restrict the ability to modify certain hives or keys in the Windows Registry.  
 **M1026:** Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.  
 **M1027:** Password Policies - Set and enforce secure password policies for accounts.  
 **M1028:** Operating System Configuration - Make configuration changes related to the operating system or a common feature of the operating system that result in system hardening against techniques.  
 **M1029:** Remote Data Storage - Use remote security log and sensitive file storage where access can be controlled better to prevent exposure of intrusion detection log data or sensitive information.  
 **M1030:** Network Segmentation - Architect sections of the network to isolate critical systems, functions, or resources. Use physical and logical segmentation to prevent access to potentially sensitive systems and information. Use a DMZ to contain any internet-facing services that should not be exposed from the internal network. Configure separate virtual private cloud (VPC) instances to isolate critical cloud systems.  
 **M1031:** Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  
 **M1032:** Multi-factor Authentication - Use two or more pieces of evidence to authenticate to a system; such as username and password in addition to a token from a physical smart card or token generator.  
 **M1033:** Limit Software Installation - Block users or groups from installing unapproved software.  
 **M1035:** Limit Access to Resource Over Network - Prevent access to file shares, remote access to systems, unnecessary services. Mechanisms to limit access may include use of network concentrators, RDP gateways, etc.  
 **M1037:** Filter Network Traffic - Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic.  
 **M1038:** Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
 **M1039:** Environment Variable Permissions - Prevent modification of environment variables by unauthorized users and groups.  
 **M1040:** Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
 **M1041:** Encrypt Sensitive Information - Protect sensitive information with strong encryption.  
 **M1042:** Disable or Remove Feature or Program - Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.  
 **M1045:** Code Signing - Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.  
 **M1047:** Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
 **M1048:** Application Isolation and Sandboxing - Restrict execution of code to a virtual environment on or in transit to an endpoint system.  
 **M1049:** Antivirus/Antimalware - Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software.  
 **M1050:** Exploit Protection - Use capabilities to detect and block conditions that may lead to or be indicative of a software exploit occurring.  
 **M1051:** Update Software - Perform regular software updates to mitigate exploitation risk.  
 **M1056:** Pre-compromise - This category is used for any applicable mitigation activities that apply to techniques occurring before an adversary gains Initial Access, such as Reconnaissance and Resource Development techniques.  
 **M1057:** Data Loss Prevention - Use a data loss prevention (DLP) strategy to categorize sensitive data, identify data formats indicative of personal identifiable information (PII), and restrict exfiltration of sensitive data.

Microsoft has written a report on a sharp rise in infections of the Linux malware XorDdos. This malware is used as a botnet to perform DDoS attacks.

# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** DDoS
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Unknown
  *  **Associated Payloads:** XorDdos 
  * **Targets:** Linux Machines
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** SSH Bruteforcing
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** DDoS Attack



# Overview

Microsoft has published a detailed report on the Linux malware XorDdos, of which they have seen a 254% increase in infections this year. The malware uses SSH brute force attacks to gain control of a remote target. If successful, root access is used to run a script to install XorDdos on the victim machine. The payload contains a number of anti-detection capabilities, such as running as a daemon process, obfuscated data, and process name spoofing. Some samples also installed a kernel rootkit to hide the presence of malicious code. For persistence, the malware drops an 'init' script to run on system startup, as well as sets up a scheduled script to run every three minutes. To stage the DDoS attack, the malware uses multiple threads, with each one sending a significant amount of traffic to the target address. The target IP address is received from the C2 server, to which it sends relevant system information on startup. the malware can also download and upload files. For more information, please see the link in the references section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * For a full list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.




# References

  * <https://www.microsoft.com/security/blog/2022/05/19/rise-in-xorddos-a-deeper-look-at-the-stealthy-ddos-malware-targeting-linux-devices/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Reconnaissance - TA0043**  
T1590.005 - IP Addresses  
T1595 - Active Scanning  
  
 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1078 - Valid Accounts  
T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059.004 - Unix Shell  
  
 **Persistence - TA0003**  
T1037.005 - Startup Items  
T1053.003 - Cron  
  
 **Privilege Escalation - TA0004**  
T1078 - Valid Accounts  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1014 - Rootkit  
T1027 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
T1036.004 - Masquerade Task or Service  
T1070 - Indicator Removal on Host  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1082 - System Information Discovery  
  
 **Lateral Movement - TA0008**  
T1021.004 - SSH  
T1570 - Lateral Tool Transfer  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0010**  
T1041 - Exfiltration Over C2 Channel  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
  
 **Impact - TA0040**  
T1498.001 - Direct Network Flood  
  


#### Mitigations:

  
 **M1013:** Application Developer Guidance: This mitigation describes any guidance or training given to developers of applications to avoid introducing security weaknesses that an adversary may be able to take advantage of.  
 **M1016:** Vulnerability Scanning - Vulnerability scanning is used to find potentially exploitable software vulnerabilities to remediate them.  
 **M1017:** User Training - Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction.  
 **M1018:** User Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.  
 **M1021:** Restrict Web-Based Content - Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc.  
 **M1022:** Restrict File and Directory Permissions - Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.  
 **M1024:** Restrict Registry Permissions - Restrict the ability to modify certain hives or keys in the Windows Registry.  
 **M1026:** Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.  
 **M1027:** Password Policies - Set and enforce secure password policies for accounts.  
 **M1028:** Operating System Configuration - Make configuration changes related to the operating system or a common feature of the operating system that result in system hardening against techniques.  
 **M1029:** Remote Data Storage - Use remote security log and sensitive file storage where access can be controlled better to prevent exposure of intrusion detection log data or sensitive information.  
 **M1030:** Network Segmentation - Architect sections of the network to isolate critical systems, functions, or resources. Use physical and logical segmentation to prevent access to potentially sensitive systems and information. Use a DMZ to contain any internet-facing services that should not be exposed from the internal network. Configure separate virtual private cloud (VPC) instances to isolate critical cloud systems.  
 **M1031:** Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  
 **M1032:** Multi-factor Authentication - Use two or more pieces of evidence to authenticate to a system; such as username and password in addition to a token from a physical smart card or token generator.  
 **M1033:** Limit Software Installation - Block users or groups from installing unapproved software.  
 **M1035:** Limit Access to Resource Over Network - Prevent access to file shares, remote access to systems, unnecessary services. Mechanisms to limit access may include use of network concentrators, RDP gateways, etc.  
 **M1037:** Filter Network Traffic - Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic.  
 **M1038:** Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
 **M1039:** Environment Variable Permissions - Prevent modification of environment variables by unauthorized users and groups.  
 **M1040:** Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
 **M1041:** Encrypt Sensitive Information - Protect sensitive information with strong encryption.  
 **M1042:** Disable or Remove Feature or Program - Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.  
 **M1045:** Code Signing - Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.  
 **M1047:** Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
 **M1048:** Application Isolation and Sandboxing - Restrict execution of code to a virtual environment on or in transit to an endpoint system.  
 **M1049:** Antivirus/Antimalware - Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software.  
 **M1050:** Exploit Protection - Use capabilities to detect and block conditions that may lead to or be indicative of a software exploit occurring.  
 **M1051:** Update Software - Perform regular software updates to mitigate exploitation risk.  
 **M1056:** Pre-compromise - This category is used for any applicable mitigation activities that apply to techniques occurring before an adversary gains Initial Access, such as Reconnaissance and Resource Development techniques.  
 **M1057:** Data Loss Prevention - Use a data loss prevention (DLP) strategy to categorize sensitive data, identify data formats indicative of personal identifiable information (PII), and restrict exfiltration of sensitive data.

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Resurgence of The Emotet Botnet Malware
TrendMicro has recently posted an update of the Emotet botnet malware. This malware was thought to be “shut down” due to recent international law enforcement operations that took control of Emotet’s network infrastructure.
output:
# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Botnet
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Unknown
  *  **Associated Payloads:** Trickbot, Ryuk, Conti 
  * **Targets:** Asia-Pacific and EMEA Region
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Spam
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Botnet, Credentials Stolen



# Overview

Emotet is one of the most prolific malware types utilized by threat actors. Past reporting indicates that the Emotet botnet malware has been utilized by a number of threat actors to compromise endpoints and networks. Emotet has also been utilized to create a botnet that is marketed as malware as a service (MaaS). After the international law enforcement operation known as Ladybird, it was assessed that the botnet and the adjacent infrastructure had been taken down. TrendMicro now believes that the Emotet botnet malware returned and is once again operational. The newest version of Emotet now utilizes Excel 4.0 to execute downloads. Emotet malware has continued to change and uses several techniques to avoid detection. Two techniques employed by the latest version of Emotet include using .ocx on the file extension and deploying carets in URLs. Further information can be found in the article located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * For a full list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.




# References

  * <https://www.trendmicro.com/en_us/research/22/e/bruised-but-not-broken--the-resurgence-of-the-emotet-botnet-malw.html>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Tactics and Techniques:**

 **Reconnaissance - TA0043**  
T1591.004 - Identify Roles  
T1595 - Active Scanning  
T1598 - Phishing for Information  
  
 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1566 - Phishing  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059.001 - PowerShell  
T1204.002 - Malicious File  
  


 **Mitigations:**

 **M1017:** User Training - Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction.

 **M1026:** Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.  
 **M1031:** Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  
 **M1033:** Limit Software Installation - Block users or groups from installing unapproved software.  
 **M1038:** Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
 **M1040:** Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
 **M1042:** Disable or Remove Feature or Program - Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.  
 **M1045:** Code Signing - Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.  
 **M1047:** Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
 **M1049:** Antivirus/Antimalware - Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software.  
 **M1054:** Software Configuration - Implement configuration changes to software (other than the operating system) to mitigate security risks associated to how the software operates.  
 **M1056:** Pre-compromise - This category is used for any applicable mitigation activities that apply to techniques occurring before an adversary gains Initial Access, such as Reconnaissance and Resource Development techniques.

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Hundreds of URLs Inside Excel Spreadsheet Distribute New Dridex Trojan Variant
A recent Dridex campaign is leveraging malicious macros to distribute its payload. Fortinet analyzes the infection process associated with this campaign along with the malware itself.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware




# Overview

Fortinet has published a blog post analyzing a recent Dridex campaign and the infection process used by the malware. The initial infection vector is a Microsoft Excel document attached to a payment request themed email. Opening the attachment and enabling macros leads to the execution of malicious VBA code. This code is responsible for creating folders, downloading an executable from a remote URL, and executing it with regsvr32.exe. The remote URL is chosen at random from a list of hundreds of URLs hidden in the body of the spreadsheet. The downloaded payload was identified as Dridex. Upon execution, the embedded Dridex core module is decrypted, extracted, and then loaded into memory. The researchers note the use of hiding the API functions, encrypting strings, and identifying debuggers for anti-analysis purposes. Once running, Dridex first gathers system information and exfiltrates the RC4-encrypted data to its C2 server. This exfiltration process continues in a loop until a 200 response is received. At the time of analysis, researchers were unable to observe a 200 response from any of the C2 servers so the next stage of this Dridex activity is currently unknown. For more information, see the Fortinet blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.fortinet.com/blog/threat-research/hundreds-of-urls-inside-microsoft-excel-spreads-new-dridex-trojan-variant>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Roaming Mantis Targets European Countries
Kaspersky has published a report that indicates that the Roaming Mantis smishing campaign has added two European countries to its primary targets.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Roaming Mantis Targets European Countries
Kaspersky has published a report that indicates that the Roaming Mantis smishing campaign has added two European countries to its primary targets.

# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Malware
  *  **Targets:** Android users in China, France, Germany, India, Japan, and Korea.
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** Wroba
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Smishing
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Phishing, Data collection, and exfiltration.
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

The Roaming Mantis smishing campaign, which Kaspersky has tracked since 2018, has historically targeted Asian countries. A report from Kaspersky indicates that Roaming Mantis has now added two European countries, France and Germany, to its primary target list. The most affected countries in the last year have been China, France, Germany, India, Japan, and Korea. The current smishing campaign targets Android devices and deploys malware named Wroba. The smishing messages usually contain a brief description and a link to a landing page where iOS devices were redirected to the Apple website whereas Wroba would be downloaded onto Android devices. The code in the landing page is obfuscated, uses geolocation to reject IP addresses that are not in the targeted region and delivers them a fake 404 error page, and uses user-agent checks to differentiate between iOS and Android devices. Significant updates have been made to the loader used to deliver Wroba. It has been rewritten from Java to use the Kotlin language and uses multiple stages to deliver the payload. Additions to the Wroba payload include the ability to display phishing pages to victims in French or German and additional backdoor commands. Further information is available from the link in the Reference section below. 

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/74058567/Roaming%20Mantis%20Targets%20European%20Countries%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1644803618670&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Users should be encouraged to only install apps from authorized app stores, which are less likely to contain malicious repackaged apps (M1011).

  * Implement an enterprise mobility management (EMM), also known as mobile device management (MDM) (M1012).

  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques (M1017).

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).



# References

  * <https://securelist.com/roaming-mantis-reaches-europe/105596/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Initial Access - TA0027**  
T1476 - Deliver Malicious App via Other Means  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0030**  
T1406 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
T1523 - Evade Analysis Environment  
T1581 - Geofencing  
  
 **Credential Access - TA0031**  
T1417 - Input Capture  
  
 **Discovery - TA0032**  
T1418 - Application Discovery  
T1420 - File and Directory Discovery  
T1422 - System Network Configuration Discovery  
T1426 - System Information Discovery  
  
 **Collection - TA0035**  
T1409 - Access Stored Application Data  
T1417 - Input Capture  
T1533 - Data from Local System  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0037**  
T1437 - Standard Application Layer Protocol  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0036**  
T1437 - Standard Application Layer Protocol

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Mozilla Advisory Updates - 23 Sep 2020
Mozilla has issued two security advisories, updating Firefox to version 81 and Firefox ESR to version 78.3.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Mozilla Advisory Updates - 23 Sep 2020
Mozilla has issued two security advisories, updating Firefox to version 81 and Firefox ESR to version 78.3.

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability



# Overview

Mozilla has published two security advisories, mfsa2020-42 and mfsa2020-43. The mfsa2020-42 advisory brings Firefox's version up to 81 and addresses six vulnerabilities, three of these rated as High and three as Moderate. The most severe potential resulting from a successful exploitation could be the possible execution of arbitrary code. In advisory mfsa2020-43, four vulnerabilities are disclosed that have been patched in release 78.3. Of these, two were rated as High and two as Moderate. The most severe potential resulting from a successful exploitation could possibly be the execution of arbitrary code. For full details, please see the links in the Reference section.

# CVEs

  * A complete list of CVEs can be found here: [ CVEs.txt](/download/attachments/30769856/Mozilla%20Advisory%20Updates%20-%2023%20Sep%202020%20CVEs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1600874842942&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://www.mozilla.org/en-US/security/advisories/mfsa2020-42/>
  * <https://www.mozilla.org/en-US/security/advisories/mfsa2020-43/>

I have encountered the following information: Chrome Browser Update - May 10 2021
Google has released an update to its Chrome web browser for Windows, Mac, and Linux that provides fixes for nineteen vulnerabilities. Of the fifteen CVE-numbered vulnerabilities noted in the advisory, Google has rated thirteen of them as High, and two as Medium.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

Google has released an update, version 90.0.4430.212, to its Chrome web browser for Windows, Mac, and Linux that provides fixes for nineteen vulnerabilities. Of the fifteen CVE-numbered vulnerabilities noted in the advisory, Google has rated thirteen of them as High, and two as Medium. Successful exploitation of the most serious vulnerabilities could potentially allow for the remote execution of arbitrary code. Further information is available from the release notes which are linked in the Reference section below.

# CVEs

  * A complete list of CVEs can be found here: [ CVEs.txt](/download/attachments/49184870/Chrome%20Browser%20Update%20-%20May%2010%202021%20CVEs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1620709617563&api=v2)




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://chromereleases.googleblog.com/2021/05/stable-channel-update-for-desktop.html>

A new version of Joomla! CMS, 3.9.25, has been released and addresses ten vulnerabilities.
output:

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

Version 3.9.25 of the Joomla! CMS has been released. It addresses ten vulnerabilities, all of which have been rated as Low, but some with an impact described as Moderate by the Joomla! security team. An attacker who successfully exploited the vulnerabilities may be able to conduct cross-site scripting attacks, overwrite certain fields in postings, change the category of articles, and write files outside the intended paths or locations. instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: JavaScript Backdoor Exfiltrates Mailbox
Trend Micro reports on a campaign targeting organizations (governmental, research institutions, universities) located in Taiwan since May of 2019.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: JavaScript Backdoor Exfiltrates Mailbox
Trend Micro reports on a campaign targeting organizations (governmental, research institutions, universities) located in Taiwan since May of 2019.

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Threat-Group, Backdoor



# Overview

Trend Micro has published an article on a threat-group (dubbed Earth Wendigo) that is running campaigns against organizations in Taiwan. The organizations under attack include governmental, research institutions, and universities. The campaign attempts to install a JavaScript backdoor in order to exfiltrate mail on the system. Trend Micro could not attribute the attack to any known group so they dubbed the threat-actor Earth Wendigo. The infection vector appears to be via spear-phishing with malicious links in the body of the email. Targeted individuals have been supporters of Tibet, Uyghur, and Hong Kong, as well as Taiwan. Once opened, the embedded JavaScript in the email loads malicious scripts from a remote server to perform browser cookie and webmail session key theft, append a malicious script to the victim's signature file (for propagation), exploit the webmail's cross-site scripting vulnerability to inject malicious JavaScripts, and register malicious JavaScript code to the Service Worker. After this, the exfiltration of mailboxes begins. For technical details of the attack, please see the link in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/35719437/JavaScript%20Backdoor%20Exfiltrates%20Mailbox%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1609881643047&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.trendmicro.com/en_us/research/21/a/earth-wendigo-injects-javascript-backdoor-to-service-worker-for-.html>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Among Us Imposter on Google Play
With the growing popularity of the mobile game Among Us, Zscaler has discovered a fake version of the app used for intrusive advertising.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Adware




# Overview

Zscaler has published a blog post analyzing a fake Among Us app being distributed via the Google Play store. When first installed on a victim device, a video plays in an attempt to convince the user additional features are being downloaded and that is why the game cannot immediately be played. In the meantime, however, details about the user's device, such as SDK version, model, manufacturer, and more, are sent to the attacker's server. After this data has been sent, the device begins displaying highly intrusive advertisements. Notably, the app also contains a fake login/registration page, but at this time no functionality is implemented to send entered data to the attacker, indicating that this feature is likely still in development. Examining the developer profile behind this app reveals fake version of other games and social media apps, many of which are specific to Indian users. They all perform the same functionality as the Among Us app. For more information, see the Zscaler blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.



# Reference

  * <https://www.zscaler.com/blogs/security-research/among-us-imposter-google-play>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Grayfly and Blackfly Cyberespionage Activity
Stemming from the recent indictments of Chinese cyber criminals by the US, Symantec reports on activity tied to Blackfly and Grayfly (collectively known as APT41).
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware, Backdoor, APT




# Overview

Symantec has published a report on activity related to APT41 (referred to by IBM as Hive0088), which they break up into two groups named Grayfly and Blackfly. Grayfly is known to target a organizations in Asia, Europe, and North America across a variety of industries. The most common initial infection vector is exploitation of public facing websites. While they have been known to use POISONPLUG in the past, their most recent attacks leveraged Motnug in conjunction with Cobalt Strike to gain remote access to victim networks and create proxy connections. Furthermore, an internal tool used to interact with SMS databases was observed, indicating their motive of intelligence gathering. The second subgroup tracked by Symantec is Blackfly. This group leverages PlugX, Winnti, and Shadowpad during their attacks. They are known for their targeting of the computer gaming industry to steal in-game digital items to sell for profit. Recently though, they also targeted a telecoms organization in Taiwan using a modified version of Winnti. The groups appear to be connected based on two individuals, charged as part of the indictments, that appear to have worked with both groups on various operations. For more information, see Symantec's blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://symantec-enterprise-blogs.security.com/blogs/threat-intelligence/apt41-indictments-china-espionage>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: XLoader Botnet - Update
Check Point Research recently posted an assessment of the XLoader Botnet that covers new techniques utilized by this malware.
output:
# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Botnet
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Unknown
  *  **Associated Payloads:** XLoader
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

Researchers at Check Point have been tracking the XLoader malware and have published an assessment of the malware’s new capabilities. The most significant change to this malware is its ability to mask the command and control (C2) infrastructure that it utilizes. Check Point was able to identify how the newest version of XLoader was obfuscating its C2 communications. This version contains 64 domains in its configuration and from those, it chooses 16. As the malware randomly chooses domains, it overwrites eight of the previous selections. Further information can be found through the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.

# Recommendations

  * For a list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.




# References

  * <https://research.checkpoint.com/2022/xloader-botnet-find-me-if-you-can/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Tactics and Techniques:**

 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1583 - Acquire Infrastructure  
T1583.001 - Domains  
T1583.004 - Server  
T1587 - Develop Capabilities  
T1587.001 - Malware  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1036 - Masquerading  
T1140 - Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
T1071.001 - Web Protocols  
T1573 - Encrypted Channel  
T1573.002 - Asymmetric Cryptography  
  


####  **Mitigations:**

 **M1017:** User Training - Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction.  
 **M1020:** SSL/TLS Inspection - Break and inspect SSL/TLS sessions to look at encrypted web traffic for adversary activity.  
 **M1022:** Restrict File and Directory Permissions - Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.  
 **M1028:** Operating System Configuration - Make configuration changes related to the operating system or a common feature of the operating system that result in system hardening against techniques.  
 **M1031:** Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  
 **M1037:** Filter Network Traffic - Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic.  
 **M1038:** Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
 **M1045:** Code Signing - Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.  
 **M1056:** Pre-compromise - This category is used for any applicable mitigation activities that apply to techniques occurring before an adversary gains Initial Access, such as Reconnaissance and Resource Development techniques.

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Wslink Loader
Wslink is a unique loader that runs as a server in order to deliver its modules. ESET published a blog post analyzing the server and client components.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Wslink Loader
Wslink is a unique loader that runs as a server in order to deliver its modules. ESET published a blog post analyzing the server and client components.

# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Loader
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Unknown
  *  **Associated Payloads:** Wslink
  *  **Targets:** Central Europe, North America, and the Middle East
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Unknown
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Unknown



# Overview

ESET published a blog post analyzing Wslink, a loader that runs a a server and executes modules in memory. The initial infection vector used by the attackers to deliver the loader has not yet been identified, and the malware itself does not seem to be prevalent. Once on a system, Wslink is registered as a service via a currently unknown method and listens on a configured port. An encrypted communication channel between the client and server components of Wslink. Modules received by Wslink are decrypted and subsequently loaded into memory. The modules use the existing communication channel for exchanging messages. At this time, researchers have been unable to obtain samples of the modules being loaded. For more information, see the WeLiveSecurity blog post in the References section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/68616973/Wslink%20Loader%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1635435578007&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).



# References

  * <https://www.welivesecurity.com/2021/10/27/wslink-unique-undocumented-malicious-loader-runs-server/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1587 - Develop Capabilities  
T1587.001 - Malware  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1129 - Shared Modules  
T1569 - System Services  
T1569.002 - Service Execution  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1027 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
T1027.002 - Software Packing  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1573 - Encrypted Channel  
T1573.001 - Symmetric Cryptography  
T1573.002 - Asymmetric Cryptography

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Blogspot Serves as a COVID-19 Scamming Hotspot
While tracking COVID-19 related campaigns, Netskope identified a scam claiming to provide relief packages in order to obtain ad revenue from visitors to the sites, many of which were hosted on Blogspot.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Blogspot Serves as a COVID-19 Scamming Hotspot
While tracking COVID-19 related campaigns, Netskope identified a scam claiming to provide relief packages in order to obtain ad revenue from visitors to the sites, many of which were hosted on Blogspot.

# Threat Type

  * Scam




# Overview

Netskope reported on a COVID-19 scam campaign that has been active since April 2020 and is targeting a number of different countries. In a some cases, the operators of the campaign registered their own domains; however, most of the scam sites were hosted on Blogspot. Across all of the sites, the same template was used for the site design, allowing the operators to easily stand up new sites on other domains or cloud services as needed. Changes to the template were made in order to target different countries and currencies. Once the site was created, it was distributed to potential victims via Facebook and WhatsApp. Visiting the link leads to a questionnaire to identify eligibility. After completing the questionnaire, victims are asked to share a message with WhatsApp groups in order to receive the payment. The legitimacy of the campaign is reinforced by Facebook comments from fake users claiming they received their payment. After sharing the message 10 times, the victim is redirected to a page that requests their bank account number to finalize the transfer. The researchers note that the bank account numbers are neither stored nor exfiltrated. Instead, victims are redirected to a website serving unwanted ads, allowing the operators to collect ad revenue. Pivoting off the source code in the initially identified sites, Netskope was able to discover references to Blogspot profiles hosting multiple similar scams. For more information, see the Netskope blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.



# Reference

  * <https://www.netskope.com/blog/blogspot-serves-as-a-covid-19-scamming-hotspot>

parsed_raw_data.xfe_q:
Blogspot Serves as a COVID-19 Scamming Hotspot
While tracking COVID-19 related campaigns, Netskope identified a scam claiming to provide relief packages in order to obtain ad revenue from visitors to the sites, many of which were hosted on Blogspot.
parsed_raw_data.xfe_report:
# Threat Type

  * Scam




# Overview

Netskope reported on a COVID-19 scam campaign that has been active since April 2020 and is targeting a number of different countries. In a some cases, the operators of the campaign registered their own domains; however, most of the scam sites were hosted on Blogspot. Across all of the sites, the same template was used for the site design, allowing the operators to easily stand up new sites on other domains or cloud services as needed. Changes to the template were made in order to target different countries and currencies. Once the site was created, it was distributed to potential victims via Facebook and WhatsApp. Visiting the link leads to a questionnaire to identify eligibility. After completing the questionnaire, victims are asked to share a message with WhatsApp groups in order to receive the payment. The legitimacy of the campaign is reinforced by Facebook comments from fake users claiming they received their payment. After sharing the message 10 times, the victim is redirected to a page that requests their bank account number to finalize the transfer. The researchers note that the bank account numbers are neither stored nor exfiltrated. Instead, victims are redirected to a website serving unwanted ads, allowing the operators to collect ad revenue. Pivoting off the source code in the initially identified sites, Netskope was able to discover references to Blogspot profiles hosting multiple similar scams. For more information, see the Netskope blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.



# Reference

  * <https://www.netskope.com/blog/blogspot-serves-as-a-covid-19-scamming-hotspot>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: ICS-CERT Advisories March 09 2021
The ICS-CERT has published 10 advisories that affect the following Siemens products: SIMATIC S7-PLCSIM, SCALANCE and RUGGEDCOM Devices, SINEMA Remote Connect Server, LOGO! 8 BM, TCP Stack of SIMATIC MV400, Energy PLUSCONTROL 1st Gen, Solid Edge File Parsing, SCALANCE and SIMATIC libcurl, and TCP/IP Stack Vulnerabilities–AMNESIA:33 in SENTRON PAC / 3VA Devices.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

 Further information is available from the advisories which are summarised below.

 **ICS Advisory ICSA-21-068-01 - Siemens SIMATIC S7-PLCSIM**  
CVE-2021-25673 - An attacker with local access to the system could cause a denial-of-service condition in the application when it is used to open a specially crafted file. As a result, the application could enter an infinite loop, become unresponsive, and must be restarted to restore the service.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 5.5 - CVSS Vector String: AV:L/AC:L/PR:L/UI:N/S:U/C:N/I:N/A:H).

CVE-2021-25674 - An attacker with local access to the system could cause a denial-of-service condition in the application when it is used to open a specially crafted file. As a result, a NULL pointer deference condition could cause the application to terminate unexpectedly and must be restarted to restore the service.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 5.5 - CVSS Vector String: AV:L/AC:L/PR:L/UI:N/S:U/C:N/I:N/A:H).

CVE-2021-25675 - An attacker with local access to the system could cause a denial-f-service condition in the application when it is used to open a specially crafted file. As a result, a divide by zero operation could occur and cause the application to terminate unexpectedly and must be restarted to restore the service.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 5.5 - CVSS Vector String: AV:L/AC:L/PR:L/UI:N/S:U/C:N/I:N/A:H).  
<https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ics/advisories/icsa-21-068-01>

 **ICS Advisory ICSA-21-068-02 - Siemens SCALANCE and RUGGEDCOM Devices SSH**  
CVE-2021-25676 - Multiple failed SSH authentication attempts could trigger a temporary denial-of-service condition under certain conditions. When triggered, the device will reboot automatically.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 8.6 - CVSS Vector String: AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:C/C:N/I:N/A:H).  
<https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ics/advisories/icsa-21-068-02>

 **ICS Advisory ICSA-21-068-03 - Siemens SCALANCE and RUGGEDCOM Devices**  
CVE-2021-25667 - Affected devices contain a stack-based buffer overflow vulnerability in the handling of Spanning Tree Protocol (STP) Bridge Protocol Data Unit (BPDU) frames that could allow a remote attacker to trigger a denial-of-service condition or potential remote code execution. Successful exploitation requires the passive listening feature of the device to be active.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 8.8 - CVSS Vector String: AV:A/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:H/I:H/A:H).  
<https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ics/advisories/icsa-21-068-03>

 **ICS Advisory ICSA-21-068-04 - Siemens SINEMA Remote Connect Server**  
CVE-2020-25239 - The webserver could allow unauthorized actions via special URLs for unprivileged users. The settings of the Unified Management Component (UMC) authorization server could be changed to add a rogue server by an attacker authenticating with unprivileged user rights.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 8.8 - CVSS Vector String: AV:N/AC:L/PR:L/UI:N/S:U/C:H/I:H/A:H).

CVE-2020-25240 - Unprivileged users can access services when guessing the URL. An attacker could impact availability, integrity, and gain information from logs and templates of the service.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 6.3 - CVSS Vector String: AV:N/AC:L/PR:L/UI:N/S:U/C:L/I:L/A:L).  
<https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ics/advisories/icsa-21-068-04>

 **ICS Advisory ICSA-21-068-05 - Siemens LOGO! 8 BM**  
CVE-2020-25236 - Control logic (CL) the LOGO! 8 could be manipulated in a way to cause the device executing the CL to improperly handle the manipulation and crash, resulting in a denial-of-service condition. The device must then be manually reset.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 5.5 - CVSS Vector String: AV:L/AC:L/PR:N/UI:R/S:U/C:N/I:N/A:H).  
<https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ics/advisories/icsa-21-068-05>

 **ICS Advisory ICSA-21-068-07 - Siemens TCP Stack of SIMATIC MV400**  
CVE-2020-25241 - The underlying TCP stack of the affected products does not correctly validate the sequence number for incoming TCP RST packages. An attacker could exploit this vulnerability to terminate arbitrary TCP sessions.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 7.5 - CVSS Vector String: AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:N/I:N/A:H).

CVE-2020-27632 - ISN generator is initialized with a constant value and has constant increments. An attacker could exploit this vulnerability to predict and hijack TCP sessions.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 7.5 - CVSS Vector String: AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:N/I:H/A:N).  
<https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ics/advisories/icsa-21-068-07>

 **ICS Advisory ICSA-21-068-08 - Siemens Energy PLUSCONTROL 1st Gen**  
CVE-2020-28388 - Initial sequence numbers (ISNs) for TCP connections are derived from an insufficiently random source. As a result, the ISN of current and future TCP connections could be predictable. An attacker could hijack existing sessions or spoof future ones.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 6.5 - CVSS Vector String: AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:N/I:L/A:L).  
<https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ics/advisories/icsa-21-068-08>

 **ICS Advisory ICSA-21-068-09 - Siemens Solid Edge File Parsing**  
CVE-2020-28385 - Affected applications lack proper validation of user-supplied data when parsing DFT files. This could result in an out-of-bounds write past the end of an allocated structure. An attacker could leverage this vulnerability to execute code in the context of the current process.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 7.8 - CVSS Vector String: AV:L/AC:L/PR:N/UI:R/S:U/C:H/I:H/A:H).

CVE-2020-28387 - When opening a specially crafted SEECTC XML file, the application could disclose arbitrary files to remote attackers. This is because of the passing of specially crafted content to the underlying XML parser without taking proper restrictions such as prohibiting an external dtd.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 5.6 - CVSS Vector String: AV:L/AC:L/PR:L/UI:R/S:U/C:H/I:N/A:L).

CVE-2021-27380 - Affected applications lack proper validation of user-supplied data when parsing PAR files. This could result in an out-of-bounds write past the end of an allocated structure. An attacker could leverage this vulnerability to execute code in the context of the current process.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 7.8 - CVSS Vector String: AV:L/AC:L/PR:N/UI:R/S:U/C:H/I:H/A:H).

CVE-2021-27381 - Affected applications lack proper validation of user-supplied data when parsing PAR files. This could result in an out-of-bounds read past the end of an allocated structure. An attacker could leverage this vulnerability to execute code in the context of the current process.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 7.8 - CVSS Vector String: AV:L/AC:L/PR:N/UI:R/S:U/C:H/I:H/A:H).  
<https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ics/advisories/icsa-21-068-09>

 **ICS Advisory ICSA-21-068-10 - Siemens SCALANCE and SIMATIC libcurl**  
CVE-2019-3823 - The libcurl library Versions 7.34.0 through 7.63.0 are vulnerable to a heap out-of-bounds read condition in the code handling the end-of-response for SMTP. This vulnerability could allow an attacker to trigger a denial-of-service condition on the affected devices.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 7.5 - assigned; the CVSS vector string is (AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:N/I:N/A:H).  
<https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ics/advisories/icsa-20-068-10>

 **ICS Advisory ICSA-21-068-06 - TCP/IP Stack Vulnerabilities–AMNESIA:33 in SENTRON PAC / 3VA Devices**  
CVE-2020-13987 - An attacker located in the same network could trigger a denial-of-service condition on the device by sending a specially crafted IP packet.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 6.5 - CVSS Vector String: AV:A/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:N/I:N/A:H).

CVE-2020-17437 - An attacker located in the same network could trigger a denial-of-service condition on the device by sending a specially crafted IP packet.  
CVSS v3 Base score: 6.5 - CVSS Vector String: AV:A/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:N/I:N/A:H).  
<https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ics/advisories/icsa-21-068-06>

# CVEs

  * A complete list of CVEs can be found here: [ CVEs.txt](/download/attachments/43090175/ICS-CERT%20Advisories%20March%2009%202021%20CVEs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1615353601779&api=v2)




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ics/advisories>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: An Analysis of a Kingminer Attack
Trend Micro has published details on a Kingminer botnet attack they detected in their client's environment.
output:
# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Cryptominer
  *  **Targets:** Unknown
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** Kingminer
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Exploitation of Public Facing Infrastructure
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Cryptomining



# Overview

Trend Micro researchers detected unusual behavior in one of the client's systems. A VBScript file was seen executing from an unusual process, implying that the system had been exploited using a vulnerability that allowed remote code execution. The file in question was obfuscated, but the researchers decoded it to gain some insight into its function. Depending on the operating system version, the file downloads another payload, as well as a PowerShell scripts to check for certain hotfixes. The purpose of this is to see if the system is vulnerable to the BlueKeep vulnerabilitiy (CVE-2019-0708). If both scripts find that the system is not vulnerable, the script disables RDP and the cryptocurrency miner proceeds to its infection routine. In this instance, the researchers observed further attempts to drop malware onto the system, despite being unsuccessful at executing them. This stopped once the vulnerability was patched. For more information, please see the link in the references section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * For a full list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.




# References

  * <https://www.trendmicro.com/en_us/research/22/e/uncovering-a-kingminer-botnet-attack-using-trend-micro-managed-x.html>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059.001 - PowerShell  
T1059.005 - Visual Basic  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1027 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1082 - System Information Discovery  
  
 **Impact - TA0040**  
T1496 - Resource Hijacking  
  


#### Mitigations:

  
 **M1016:** Vulnerability Scanning - Vulnerability scanning is used to find potentially exploitable software vulnerabilities to remediate them.  
 **M1018:** User Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.  
 **M1021:** Restrict Web-Based Content - Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc.  
 **M1026:** Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.  
 **M1030:** Network Segmentation - Architect sections of the network to isolate critical systems, functions, or resources. Use physical and logical segmentation to prevent access to potentially sensitive systems and information. Use a DMZ to contain any internet-facing services that should not be exposed from the internal network. Configure separate virtual private cloud (VPC) instances to isolate critical cloud systems.  
 **M1033:** Limit Software Installation - Block users or groups from installing unapproved software.  
 **M1038:** Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
 **M1040:** Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
 **M1042:** Disable or Remove Feature or Program - Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.  
 **M1045:** Code Signing - Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.  
 **M1047:** Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
 **M1048:** Application Isolation and Sandboxing - Restrict execution of code to a virtual environment on or in transit to an endpoint system.  
 **M1049:** Antivirus/Antimalware - Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software.  
 **M1050:** Exploit Protection - Use capabilities to detect and block conditions that may lead to or be indicative of a software exploit occurring.  
 **M1051:** Update Software - Perform regular software updates to mitigate exploitation risk.

T1496 - Resource Hijacking  
  


#### Mitigations:

  
 **M1016:** Vulnerability Scanning - Vulnerability scanning is used to find potentially exploitable software vulnerabilities to remediate them.  
 **M1018:** User Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.  
 **M1021:** Restrict Web-Based Content - Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc.  
 **M1026:** Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.  
 **M1030:** Network Segmentation - Architect sections of the network to isolate critical systems, functions, or resources. Use physical and logical segmentation to prevent access to potentially sensitive systems and information. Use a DMZ to contain any internet-facing services that should not be exposed from the internal network. Configure separate virtual private cloud (VPC) instances to isolate critical cloud systems.  
 **M1033:** Limit Software Installation - Block users or groups from installing unapproved software.  
 **M1038:** Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
 **M1040:** Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
 **M1042:** Disable or Remove Feature or Program - Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.  
 **M1045:** Code Signing - Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.  
 **M1047:** Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
 **M1048:** Application Isolation and Sandboxing - Restrict execution of code to a virtual environment on or in transit to an endpoint system.  
 **M1049:** Antivirus/Antimalware - Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software.  
 **M1050:** Exploit Protection - Use capabilities to detect and block conditions that may lead to or be indicative of a software exploit occurring.  
 **M1051:** Update Software - Perform regular software updates to mitigate exploitation risk.

I have encountered the following information: ALERT: Hello Ransomware Advisory
A new ransomware is being observed in the wild. The .hello, or WickrMe, ransomware family is using Microsoft SharePoint with a vulnerability disclosed in 2019, according to Brucert.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Ransomware, Malware, Trojan




# Overview

A new ransomware variant dubbed .hello or WickrMe ransomware is using a SharePoint 2019 vulnerability has been observed infiltrating victim networks, according to a report from Brucert. Encryption is occurs when the files are encrypted and appended with a .hello extension. The vulnerability leveraged in Microsoft SharePoint is due to a failure to check the source markup of a package. If successfully exploited, the vulnerability could lead to the execution of arbitrary code in the SharePoint application pool and farm account. Along with the ransomware, trojans and malware can be installed. Further information can be found in the report located within the Reference section below. 

# CVEs

  * CVE-2019-0604




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary.

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Allcome Clipboard Banker
Allcome is a new clipboard banker being sold on underground forums as a malware-as-a-service. G DATA has published a blog post analyzing the malware's functionality.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Clipboard banker
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Unknown
  *  **Associated Payloads:** Allcome
  *  **Targets:** Unknown
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Unknown
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Clipboard hijacking



# Overview

G DATA published a blog post analyzing Allcome, a clipboard banker being sold on underground forums as a malware-as-a-service. The payload is a small executable capable of monitoring the clipboard and replacing its contents when certain conditions are meant. It attempts to replace cryptocurrency wallet addresses, PayPal email addresses, and Steam trade offers URLs present on the clipboard with those controlled by the attacker. The C2 URL and attacker's replacement data are encrypted and stored in the PE resources. Upon connecting to the C2 URL, the server confirms that the operator of the malware is a valid customer. Persistence is established via a scheduled task. The researchers note that there are minimal checks in place to avoid incorrect replacements, so the victim is likely to notice odd behavior early on. For more information, see the G DATA blog post in the References section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/74058986/Allcome%20Clipboard%20Banker%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1645115743655&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).



# References

  * <https://www.gdatasoftware.com/blog/2022/02/37239-allcome-clipbanker-is-a-newcomer-in-malware-underground-forums>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1588 - Obtain Capabilities  
T1588.001 - Malware  
  
 **Persistence - TA0003**  
T1053 - Scheduled Task/Job  
T1053.005 - Scheduled Task  
  
 **Collection - TA0009**  
T1115 - Clipboard Data  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
T1071.001 - Web Protocols

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Coinbase Phishing Attacks
Coinbase is a cryptocurrency exchange platform that is exponentially gaining users with the increased popularity in cryptocurrency. With this increased usage, Inky has discovered threat actors targeting Coinbase credentials in phishing attacks.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Coinbase Phishing Attacks
Coinbase is a cryptocurrency exchange platform that is exponentially gaining users with the increased popularity in cryptocurrency. With this increased usage, Inky has discovered threat actors targeting Coinbase credentials in phishing attacks.

# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Phishing
  *  **Target:** Coinbase users
  *  **Lure** : Email from claiming Coinbase account actions are required
  *  **Payload** : Link to compromised site hosting phishing page
  *  **TTPs:** Spoofed sender, phishing link ([T1566.002](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1566/002/)), hosting on compromised site
  *  **Compromised data:** Coinbase login credentials

  *  **Post-compromise actions:** Unknown



# Overview

Inky published a blog post analyzing a phishing campaign targeting users of Coinbase, a cryptocurrency exchange platform. The phishing email is sent from a compromised account and spoofs Coinbase, claiming that action is needed from the user to prevent their account from being disabled. The link contained in the body of the email leads to a hijacked website hosting a fake Coinbase login page. Submitting credentials via this page will exfiltrate the data to the attacker, giving them access to the Coinbase account, which may include cryptocurrency wallets, financial information, and other sensitive data. For more information, see the Inky blog post in the Reference section. 

# Recommendations

  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.
  * Enable multi-factor authentication (MFA) where possible.



# Reference

  * <https://www.inky.com/blog/rising-value-and-visibility-of-coinbase-attracts-impersonators>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: PsExec Privilege Escalation in Windows Fixed
Microsoft has finally fixed a vulnerability initially disclosed by a Tenable researcher back in January 2021.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

A component of Microsoft's Sysinternals utility was found in January 2021 to be vulnerable to privilege escalation. According to the release notes from Microsoft: "This update to PsExec mitigates named pipe squatting attacks that can be leveraged by an attacker to intercept credentials or elevate to System privilege. the -i command line switch is now necessary for running processes interactively, for example with redirected IO."  The local privilege escalation allows for the escalation to SYSTEM if PsExec is executed either locally or remotely. This vulnerability was shown to work from Windows 10 to Windows XP. This vulnerability was exploitable all the way back to v1.72. The researcher, upon disclosing the vulnerability, gave Microsoft ninety days in which to address it. The company did not release a patch within that window and, therefore, the researcher released the flaw as well as a fully working PoC. On March 23, 2021, Microsoft issued a micro patch to address the issue and has since been tested and confirmed as working. Further details can be found in the article located within the Reference section below.

# CVEs

  * N/A




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://www.bleepingcomputer.com/news/security/microsoft-fixes-windows-psexec-privilege-elevation-vulnerability/>

  * <https://techcommunity.microsoft.com/t5/sysinternals-blog/tcpview-v4-0-psexec-v2-33-winobj-v3-02-and-sysmon-v13-02/ba-p/2230549>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Qakbot Upgrade and Activity
According to SANS ISC, a security researcher from malware-traffic-analysis.net conducted a sample Qakbot/Qbot malware infection in order to observe new behaviors. The researcher provided a full report on his findings.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware




# Overview

During a short, sample infection test, security researcher Brad Duncan was able to capture interesting information about new behaviors in the Qakbot malware. It appears, according to his research, the malware underwent a version update. During his research, malspam was observed in December 2020 with fake replies to email chains. In some of his examples, he found these may have been Qakbot generated replies for unsolicited spam. In the email, a ZIP archive with an Excel macro-enabled spreadsheet was discovered. The macros were intended to infect vulnerable Windows hosts with the malware. The templates used were the same used in previous campaigns. The infection took place using a Qakbot-typical HTTP GET request. The request searched for a URL with a .jpg file. The file was actually a DLL disguised as a Windows binary. During Wireshark analysis, Duncan observed web traffic with a destination of wellsfargo.com. This traffic was not generated with a web browser, as none had been opened. The user-agent string indicated the traffic my have been caused by Google Chrome. There was also web traffic attributed to Firefox. The belief is this traffic was related to a Qakbot module, though no modules were found on the "infected" machine. Some notable changes for this version included the Qakbot binary was changed from EXE to DLL, the malware creates other Windows Registry updates, and the directory for Qakbot artifacts has fewer files than previously seen. Further details can be found in the report located within the Reference section below. 

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://isc.sans.edu/forums/diary/Recent+Qakbot+Qbot+activity/26862/>

  * <https://twitter.com/lazyactivist192/status/1332363179729575938>
  * <https://twitter.com/_alex_il_/status/1333737189990158337>
  * <https://twitter.com/0verfl0w_/status/1331598884431421441>
