instruction:
I have encountered the following information: New Distribution Techniques For Agent Tesla
Since 2014, Agent Tesla has been stealing information from infected systems. Morphisec indicates that it has seen a growth in use in the last two or three years, possibly because cracked versions of it have been leaked.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Infostealer, Vulnerability



# Overview

Morphisec has published a paper on Agent Tesla detailing its change and growth. Since at least 2014, Agent Tesla has seen a significant growth in use, possibly because cracked versions have been released. This year also marks a change in its delivery methods to include exploits, Covid-19 phishing campaigns, and advanced steganography. Additionally, innovative obfuscation techniques have been added to its arsenal. The spearphishing method is based on an RFQ (Request for Quote) order sent to employees who routinely process such requests. Even when the malicious email was quarantined by protection systems, some employees actually pulled it out of quarantine because they were convinced of its legitimacy. Such RFQ attachments are a known DDE exploit that pulls the next stage of infection from the malware's command and control server when opened. Two Equation Editor exploits, CVE-2017-11882 and CVE-2018-0802, are also part of the infection chain. Successfully exploited, a small, obfuscated loader is downloaded and executed. This loader makes use of steganography by hiding the next stage in a PNG image to execute a second loader. This second loader is injected into a legitimate RegAsm application. The final payload is the main Agent Tesla Dark Stealer module, which is also run from the RegAsm application. Persistence is achieved through a scheduled task. For full technical details, please refer to the URL in the Reference section.

# CVEs

  * A complete list of CVEs can be found here: [ CVEs.txt](/download/attachments/33982119/New%20Distribution%20Techniques%20For%20Agent%20Tesla%20CVEs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1605030159015&api=v2)



# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/33982119/New%20Distribution%20Techniques%20For%20Agent%20Tesla%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1605030179762&api=v2)



# Protection

## IBM

  * CVE-2017-11882: CompoundFile_OLE_Equation_Exec
  * CVE-2018-0802: CompoundFile_OLE_Equation_Size_Exec



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://blog.morphisec.com/agent-tesla-a-day-in-a-life-of-ir>

I have encountered the following information: Bangladesh Organizations Being Targeted
The Dhaka Tribune has published an article on 6 Bangladeshi organizations being targeted by hackers.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Phishing, Botnet




# Overview

Kasablanca is a threat group that is targeting 6 Bangladeshi organizations in a campaign to intercept sensitive data from either Android or Windows devices. The group was said to have deployed a new RAT in a previous campaign; however, there has been signs of that RAT being used in this campaign. The e-Gov CIRT, Bangladesh's e-Government Computer Incident Response Team, has identified several phishing sites set up for the purposes of obtaining sensitive information from the targeted organizations. The CIRT has not found a specific reason for the targeting but, as previously stated, phishing sites have been set up. The group is using the organizations as the backbone of the phishing websites. Additionally, 8 other sites have been setup using other organizations for phishing. The group's typical motives for campaign's targeting is to spread a botnet to as many computers and mobile devices as possible. The victims could be targeted due to their collection of National ID card numbers, financial information, and other information. In each instance, the targeted organizations have taken extra security measures to mitigate any current or future threats or infiltrations. Further details can be found in the article located within the Reference section below.

# CVEs

  * N/A




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://www.dhakatribune.com/business/2021/02/22/hackershave-eye-on-6-bangladeshi-organisations>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Malware Leveraging XML-RPC Vulnerability to Exploit WordPress Sites
XML-RPC is commonly abused by attackers to compromise WordPress sites. A recent campaign investigated by Zscaler researchers reveals a new malware using XML-RPC to fingerprint WordPress sites and perform brute-force attacks.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware




# Overview

Zscaler reports on a new campaign leveraging XML-RPC in an attack chain against WordPress websites. It begins with an executable masquerading as a legitimate Microsoft system file. While some of the metadata used matches that of real Microsoft executables, other fields indicate that the malware is still in development due to comments like "TODO" being present. Upon execution, the malware first decrypts the C2 URI to be leveraged and a domain name using an XOR loop. The domain that is decrypted is used to perform a blockchain DNS lookup in order to identify the C2 IP to be used by the malware. This IP, in combination with the aforementioned URI, is leveraged for the initial C2 communication. The C2 server, in turn, downloads an updated version of the malware. It then gathers system information to report back to the C2. Its final functionality is then implemented. Specifically, it performs a brute force attack against a list of targets provided by the C2 server. It uses XML-RPC in combination with a cURL script to attempt cookie-based authentication to WordPress login pages until valid credentials are identified. For more information, see the Zscaler blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.



# Reference

  * <https://www.zscaler.com/blogs/security-research/malware-leveraging-xml-rpc-vulnerability-exploit-wordpress-sites>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Updated Version of WordPress Addresses Ten Vulnerabilities
A new version of WordPress, 5.5.2, was released to address ten vulnerabilities, and other bugs, present in versions 5.5. In addition, a further update, 5.5.3, was released to address a bug introduced in the 5.5.2 release.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Updated Version of WordPress Addresses Ten Vulnerabilities
A new version of WordPress, 5.5.2, was released to address ten vulnerabilities, and other bugs, present in versions 5.5. In addition, a further update, 5.5.3, was released to address a bug introduced in the 5.5.2 release.

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

  
To address ten vulnerabilities, and general bugs, in versions 5.5, WordPress released version 5.5.3. No CVE numbers and few details about the vulnerabilities were provided in the release information. The descriptions of the vulnerabilities note potential impacts of arbitrary file deletion, cross-site scripting, privilege escalation, and a denial of service condition that could lead to the remote execution of arbitrary code. Version 5.5.2 also introduced a bug which was then addressed in version 5.5.3 which was released the following day. Further details are available from the links in the Reference section below.

# CVEs

  * No CVE numbers provided.




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://wordpress.org/support/wordpress-version/version-5-5-2/>

  * <https://wordpress.org/support/wordpress-version/version-5-5-3/>

Tell me everything you know the following threat: Praying Mantis Threat Group
A new threat group has been identified by the Sygnia Incident Response team. Sygnia refers to the group as Praying Mantis and TG1021. The group typically exploits Internet-facing Windows IIS servers and web applications.
output:
# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Threat Group, Malware
  *  **Targets:** Windows IIS Servers, Web Applications
  *  **Malware Family/Families:**
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** CVE-2017-11317, CVE-2019-18935, CVE-2021-27852, Initial Access ([T1190](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1190/)), Execution ([T1059.001](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/001/), [T1059.007](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/007/))
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Persistence ([T1505.003](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1505/003/)), Privilege Escalation ([T1055.001](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1055/001/), [T1068](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1068/)), Defense Evasion ([T1036.005](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1036/005/), [T1140](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1140/), [T1070.004](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1070/004/), [T1134.001](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1134/001/), [T1562.002](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1562/002/), [T1078.002](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1078/002/), [T1027.002](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1027/002/)), Credential Access ([T1056.003](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1056/003/)), Discovery ([T1135](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1135/), [T1083](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1083/)), Lateral Movement ([T1550.004](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1550/004/), [T1021.002](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1021/002/), [T1210](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1210/), [T1570](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1570/)), Collection ([T1005](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1005/)), Command and Control ([T1071.001](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1071/001/), [T1001](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1001/), [T1090.001](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1090/001/), [T1132.001](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1132/001/), [T1573.001](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1573/001/), [T1572](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1572/))
  *  **Additional TTPs:** Reconnaissance ([T1595.002](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1595/002/), [T1592](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1592/), [T1590](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1590/)), Resource Development ([T1587.001](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1587/001/), [T1587.004](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1587/004/))



# Overview

The Sygnia Incident Response team has published a report on their identification of a threat group they refer to as Praying Mantis or TG1021. The group's TTPs have similarities to the attacks described by the Australian government's Cyber Security Centre in 2020 that were known as the "Copy-Paste Compromises". The group has mainly exploited deserialization vulnerabilities in Windows IIS servers (CVE-2021-27852), and vulnerable web applications (CVE-2017-11317, and CVE-2019-18935) to gain their initial foothold. Post compromise activities include credential harvesting, lateral movement, reconnaissance, and the deployment of a custom toolset, including a webshell and malware. The toolset is reflectively loaded into a compromised system's memory and leaves few traces. Further details are available from the Sygnia report linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/59539531/Praying%20Mantis%20Threat%20Group%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1627875947006&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date ([M1049](https://attack.mitre.org/mitigations/M1049/)).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs ([M1031](https://attack.mitre.org/mitigations/M1031/), [M1035](https://attack.mitre.org/mitigations/M1035/), [M1037](https://attack.mitre.org/mitigations/M1037/)).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level ([M1051](https://attack.mitre.org/mitigations/M1051/)).



# References

  * <https://f.hubspotusercontent30.net/hubfs/8776530/TG1021%20-%20Praying%20Mantis%20Threat%20Actor.pdf>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: The Deployment of DirtyMoe Payload
DirtyMoe is a complex, modularized, malware, focused on carrying out cryptojacking and DDoS attacks. In this article, Avast focuses on DirtyMoe's deployment and how it does things differently based on the version of windows each victim is using.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Cryptojacker and DDoS
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Unknown
  *  **Associated Payloads:** PurpleFox Exploit Kit
  *  **Targets:** Unspecified
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Malicious Ads, Phishing, Network Exploits
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Cryptomining, DDoS botnet attacks
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

Avast has a series of articles regarding the DirtyMoe malware which is a complex and modularized malware. DirtyMoe focuses on carrying out cryptojacking and DDoS attacks. Most of the samples they captured were delivered onto victims' machines by the PurpleFox exploit kit. The article takes a deeper look at 2 MSI installer packages. The newest version consists of two parts where one is the MSI package itself and the other part is a separate CAB file that contains the malicious payloads. The registry is used to disable antispyware and file protection features. It's also used for a counter to track how many times the installer has run, a killswitch that will abort installation, and a flag to indicate a victim's computer has already been compromised. The malware will run on various versions of Windows including older versions such as NT, XP, and Vista. Further information is available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [TheDeploymentofDirtyMoePayload-IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/70221897/TheDeploymentofDirtyMoePayload-IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1636059404233&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Restrict Web-Based Content (M1021).



# References

  * <https://decoded.avast.io/martinchlumecky/dirtymoe-4/>

 **Execution - TA0002**

  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Malicious Ads, Phishing, Network Exploits
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Cryptomining, DDoS botnet attacks
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

Avast has a series of articles regarding the DirtyMoe malware which is a complex and modularized malware. DirtyMoe focuses on carrying out cryptojacking and DDoS attacks. Most of the samples they captured were delivered onto victims' machines by the PurpleFox exploit kit. The article takes a deeper look at 2 MSI installer packages. The newest version consists of two parts where one is the MSI package itself and the other part is a separate CAB file that contains the malicious payloads. The registry is used to disable antispyware and file protection features. It's also used for a counter to track how many times the installer has run, a killswitch that will abort installation, and a flag to indicate a victim's computer has already been compromised. The malware will run on various versions of Windows including older versions such as NT, XP, and Vista. Further information is available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [TheDeploymentofDirtyMoePayload-IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/70221897/TheDeploymentofDirtyMoePayload-IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1636059404233&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Restrict Web-Based Content (M1021).



# References

  * <https://decoded.avast.io/martinchlumecky/dirtymoe-4/>

 **Resource Development - TA0042**

T1608 - Stage Capabilities

T1608.005 - Link Target  
  
 **Initial Access - TA0001**

T1566 - Phishing

T1566.002 - Spearphishing Link  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**

T1204.002 - Malicious File

T1569.002 - Service Execution  
  
 **Persistence - TA0003**

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Egregor Infection Chain and Payload Analysis
Following the trend of ransomware operators also exfiltrating data is the Egregor ransomware family. Cybereason published their analysis of recent campaigns involving this ransomware.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Ransomware




# Overview

Cybereason has published their analysis of the Egregor ransomware and its infection chain. Campaigns begin with a phishing email with a malicious Word document attached. These maldocs deliver a commodity malware, such as Qbot, Ursnif or IcedID. The commodity malware is used for stealing sensitive data and lateral movement. Furthermore, CobaltStrike beacons are deployed for reconnaissance, privilege escalation, and lateral movement. Eventually the attacker compromises Active Directory and obtains domain admin privileges. With this access, scripts, DLLs, and additional files are downloaded from a C2 server. Included in these downloaded files are a batch file and a ZIP file. The batch file is used to download and execute the Egregor ransomware. The ZIP file contains the RClone client, masquerading as svchost, which is leveraged to exfiltrate files from the victim network. The Egregor ransomware can only be executed if it is passed a correct decryption key, otherwise execution will fail, increasing the difficulty of analysis. Victims are provided a short period of time to pay the ransomware, which is negotiated via chat. If the ransom goes unpaid, the stolen files are published on a Tor website operated by the attackers. For more information, see the Cybereason blog post in the Reference section. A link to a blog post by Group-IB regarding this ransomware family is also provided.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.cybereason.com/blog/cybereason-vs-egregor-ransomware>

  * <https://www.group-ib.com/blog/egregor>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Phishing for Cash(App)
A new campaign by actors using a phishing kit provided by the phishing kit provider group 16shop is making the rounds in an effort to bilk victims of money through the money transfer app, CashApp. ZeroFOX provides details on the campaign's TTPs.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Phishing




# Overview

A popular money transfer service's customers are under attack from threat actors using 16shop's phishing kit. CashApp users have been targeted in the newest campaign in an effort to steal as much money as possible. Normally, 16shop's modus operandi is to phish through computer means. The shift to mobile phone-based payment systems represents a change in kit's design and functionality. The developer of the kit has been documented as having been in the fraud scene for many years. This particular kit is being sold on the kit's storefront. This phishing kit has options for those who deploy it to make it customizable to the specific app the actors are attempting to impersonate, in this case, CashApp. Lures in this campaign come in the form of email or SMS messages informing potential victims their account has been locked for security purposes. The link on the phishing page listed in either the email or SMS message leads to the actual phishing page. Prior to sending the victim to the phishing page, checks are made against the IP address, User-Agent strings, and ISP info in an effort to prevent security technologies and web crawlers from accessing the page. If the checks pass, access is allowed to the page, and a request for the victim's CashApp email address is made. Upon population, a pop-up window confirms the account is "locked." As the victim delves deeper and deeper into the process, more and more sensitive data is requested. Items such as credit card numbers, usernames and passwords, addresses, social security numbers, and other identifying information. Further details can be found in the report located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.zerofox.com/blog/16shop-cash-app-phishing-kit/>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Scammers Leverage Personal Information of Targets in France
Trend Micro discovered that faked emails and webpages pretending to be the French retail company Darty were recently used in a peculiar phishing campaign aimed at stealing sensitive information.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Phishing, Spearphishing, Spoofing




# Overview

Threat actors took advantage of the current COVID-19 lockdown and online Black Friday sales to reactivate a phishing campaign using the branding of Darty, the French Retail company. Researchers at Trend Micro noticed tactics integrating social engineering and phishing techniques. Furthermore, researchers uncovered the compromise of another French company whose database provided the threat actors with home addresses and phone numbers which were used to target potential victims. It was assessed that threat actors were able to construct an artificial order billed to the target's physical home address. As planned, the target would then click the “Cancel Order” option and be redirected to a pre-filled page containing their first name, last name, phone number, and physical address. Once that is done by selecting “Validate” option, the victim is directed to another page and duped into providing their credit card information for reimbursement. For more information, see the Trend Micro blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.trendmicro.com/en_us/research/20/l/scammers-use-home-addresses-of-targets-in-france.html>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Bumble's API Reversing Analysis
Independent Security Evaluators has published a blog on their efforts to reverse engineer Bumble's API.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

  
Researchers from Independent Security Evaluators have published a blog on their efforts to reverse engineer the popular dating app Bumble. The research has shown that an unverified user can bypass paying for some premium features. The attacker could also have the ability to dump the entire user-base with pictures. Some of the techniques have been mitigated, while others remain. Part of a mitigated issue is the use of sequential user IDs by Bumble as well as updating its encryption scheme. Additionally, providing distance to other users is no longer possible, which eliminates the possibility of using triangulation to locate a specific user. One technique is using an endpoint to obtain Facebook likes, pictures, and other profile information. One limitation is the attack must have the encrypted user ID available to them or one which they own. It is suspected that Bumble will address this vulnerability in the coming days. Bypassing other premium features is still functional. The use of REST APIs for inter-application communication can allow client-side communication in a stateless form. Using the Burp Suite, the team was able to explore API calls and perform the necessary functions to trigger the unintentional data leak. 

## Unlimited Votes

Bumble's mobile app limits the number of "swipes" a non-premium user can use per day. The request is done through an action called SERVER_ENCOUNTERS_VOTE. If the options are manipulated, an attacker could receive unlimited votes during a 24-hour period. Since there is no check on the APIs, the web application user could achieve this rather easily. 

## Backtrack

Should a user accidentally swipe left (deny) a prospective match, the backtrack function allows for removing the parameter for exclusion. An API voting request directly would allow an attacker to change his vote from left to right (accept). 

## Beeline

One of the most useful functions to an attacker is the ability to see all those who've swiped right on them. Assigned user codes allow for the exploitation of this information and can be modified and used for other endpoints. 

## Enumeration

Finally, perhaps the most useful feature is the ability to find users by employing unlimited filters. This could allow an attacker to limit search results to a certain radius. The results would also include pictures and Facebook (if connected) interests and pages liked by the victim. 

Further technical information can be found in the blog post located within the Reference section below. 

# CVEs

  * N/A




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://blog.securityevaluators.com/reverse-engineering-bumbles-api-a2a0d39b3a87>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: MultiloginBot Stealer Campaign
A fake installer for Multilogin, an application for logging into multiple accounts on a single platform, is being distributed in a new phishing campaign. Analysis by Zscaler researchers revealed the installer ultimately installs a stealer on victim systems.
output:
# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Stealer
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Unknown
  *  **Associated Payloads:** MultiloginBot
  *  **Targets:** Multilogin Users
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Fake Multilogin installer
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Data theft



# Overview

Zscaler published a blog post analyzing a stealer, dubbed MultiloginBot, being distributed via a fake installer. The malicious installer is hosted on a lookalike domain and web page designed to match that of the legitimate Multilogin application. If a user falls for the lure and downloads the fake installer, a malicious executable is dropped onto the system and persistence is established via the startup folder. Files and folders are created to stage the data that will be stolen, and then the stealing activities begin. First, the victim's IP address is obtained and saved to a file. Then credentials, autofill data, and cookies are stolen from multiple browsers and saved into various text files. Finally, all created text files are archived into a ZIP file that is exfiltrated to the attacker via a Telegram bot. After the data has been successfully exfiltrated, a pop up redirects users to the legitimate Multilogin website and artifacts on the system are cleaned up. For more information, see the Zscaler blog post in the References section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/68616509/MultiloginBot%20Stealer%20Campaign%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1635166755508&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Restrict Web-Based Content (M1021).
  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques (M1017).



# References

  * <https://www.zscaler.com/blogs/security-research/new-multiloginbot-phishing-campaign>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1583 - Acquire Infrastructure  
T1583.001 - Domains  
  
 **Persistence - TA0003**  
T1547 - Boot or Logon Autostart Execution

 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**

T1070.004 - File Deletion  
  
 **Credential Access - TA0006**  
T1555 - Credentials from Password Stores  
T1555.003 - Credentials from Web Browsers  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1016 - System Network Configuration Discovery  
T1016.001 - Internet Connection Discovery  
  
 **Collection - TA0009**  
T1005 - Data from Local System  
T1074 - Data Staged  
T1074.001 - Local Data Staging  
T1119 - Automated Collection  
T1560 - Archive Collected Data  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0010**  
T1020 - Automated Exfiltration  
T1041 - Exfiltration Over C2 Channel  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
T1071.001 - Web Protocols  
T1102 - Web Service

A fake installer for Multilogin, an application for logging into multiple accounts on a single platform, is being distributed in a new phishing campaign. Analysis by Zscaler researchers revealed the installer ultimately installs a stealer on victim systems.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/68616509/MultiloginBot%20Stealer%20Campaign%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1635166755508&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Restrict Web-Based Content (M1021).
  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques (M1017).



# References

  * <https://www.zscaler.com/blogs/security-research/new-multiloginbot-phishing-campaign>

Tell me everything you know the following threat: Chrome Browser Update - February 04 2021 - Exploit in the Wild
Google has released an update to its Chrome web browser for Windows, Mac, and Linux that provides a fix for a single vulnerability, which Google has rated as High. An exploit for the vulnerability exists in the wild.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

Google has released an update, version 88.0.4324.150, to its Chrome web browser for Windows, Mac, and Linux that provides a fix for a single vulnerability. Google has rated the vulnerability (CVE-2021-21148) as High. An exploit for the vulnerability exists in the wild. If successfully exploited, the vulnerability could potentially allow for the remote execution of arbitrary code. Further information is available from the release notes which are linked in the Reference section below.

# CVEs

# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Malicious App Targets Turkish Ministry of Justice
Cyble Research Labs recently conducted research detailing malware that is configured to target specific programs and steal sensitive credentials. This malware is known as "Adalet" and was recently used to target the Turkish Ministry of Justice.
output:
# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type: Malicious App**
  *  **Targets: Turkish Ministry of Justice**
  *  **Initial Infection Vector: Intercept SMS**



# Overview

The team at Cyble Research Labs conducted open-source intelligence and discovered reporting on malware that was reported to be possibly targeting the Turkish Ministry of Justice. The research team conducted an analysis of the malware and found a number of malicious apps. Further analysis reported that they identified sophisticated capabilities that allowed the app to conduct keylogging, and steal data from Google Authenticator, TeamViewer, and Gmail accounts. The app also sends messages to infected devices that lure victims into responding and sending data to malicious websites. Further information can be found in the article located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * For a full list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.




# References

  * <https://blog.cyble.com/2022/04/22/malicious-app-targets-turkish-ministry-of-justice/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

####  **Tactics and Techniques:**

  
 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1189 - Drive-by Compromise  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1204.002 - Malicious File  
  
 **Collection - TA0009**  
T1056.001 - Keylogging  
T1123 - Audio Capture  
T1560 - Archive Collected Data  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1571 - Non-Standard Port

  
 **Mitigations:**

####  **M1017:** User Training - Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction.  
 **M1021:** Restrict Web-Based Content - Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc.  
 **M1026:** Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.  
 **M1030:** Network Segmentation - Architect sections of the network to isolate critical systems, functions, or resources. Use physical and logical segmentation to prevent access to potentially sensitive systems and information. Use a DMZ to contain any internet-facing services that should not be exposed from the internal network. Configure separate virtual private cloud (VPC) instances to isolate critical cloud systems.  
 **M1031:** Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  
 **M1038:** Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
 **M1040:** Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
 **M1045:** Code Signing - Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.  
 **M1047:** Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
 **M1048:** Application Isolation and Sandboxing - Restrict execution of code to a virtual environment on or in transit to an endpoint system.  
 **M1050:** Exploit Protection - Use capabilities to detect and block conditions that may lead to or be indicative of a software exploit occurring.  
 **M1051:** Update Software - Perform regular software updates to mitigate exploitation risk.

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Mirai's New Variant Called Katana
Avira's IoT research team has identified a developing botnet based on Mirai they have labeled "Katana."
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware, Botnet



# Overview

In 2016, the source code for the malware Mirai was released. Since then, a number of variants have emerged based on the work of enterprising hackers. Avira's IoT research team has identified a variant they have labeled "Katana". Functionality of this variant includes "layer 7 DDoS, different encryption keys for each source, fast self-replication, and secure C&C." Avira also indicates that a link to an HTTP banking botnet may be on the horizon. Exploitation attempts on LinkSkys and GPON routers are based on remote code execution and command injection vulnerabilities. Avira discovered that URLs that required authentication to access, the mere act of adding "?images" allowed the hacker to bypass authentication and gain control of the device. In some LinkSys attacks, a vulnerable CGI script, tmUnblock.cgi, that contains multiple security vulnerabilities that was the focus of the attack. In other cases, where the RealTek SDK was used to create the miniigd deamon, command injection attacks were used on the UPnP SOAP interface. For full technical details, please refer to the link in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/32146729/Mirai%27s%20New%20Variant%20Called%20Katana%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1603898736144&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.avira.com/en/blog/katana-a-new-variant-of-the-mirai-botnet>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Rook Ransomware
Researchers have uncovered a new ransomware variant, Rook, that is seemingly leveraging leaked Babuk ransomware source code. SentintelOne has published their analysis of the Rook payload and its overlap with Babuk.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Rook Ransomware
Researchers have uncovered a new ransomware variant, Rook, that is seemingly leveraging leaked Babuk ransomware source code. SentintelOne has published their analysis of the Rook payload and its overlap with Babuk.

# Threat Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Ransomware
  *  **Targets:** Non-specific
  *  **Ransomware Family:** Rook
  *  **RaaS Operation:** Unknown
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Delivered via Cobalt Strike or phishing email
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Data encryption, data theft



# Overview

SentinelOne published a blog post analyzing the Rook ransomware, a new ransomware family based on the Babuk source code. The connection to Babuk is based on significant code overlap, such as the use of specific APIs and functions. The Babuk source code, including its builder, was leaked several times throughout 2021, which is likely how these threat actors obtained it. The payload was seen being delivered by both Cobalt Strike and via phishing campaigns. The ransomware operates similar to most families. It begins by killing processes that may interfere with encryption or are related to security products. It then deletes volume shadow copies, performs encryption, and deletes itself. No persistence mechanisms were observed during SentintelOne's analysis. The threat actors operate on a double-extortion model, threatening to release stolen data on a TOR site if the ransom is not paid. It is unknown at this time whether an affiliate model exists. For more information, see the SentinelOne blog post in the References section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/74056481/Rook%20Ransomware%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1640810161750&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques and phishing emails (M1017).



# References

  * <https://www.sentinelone.com/labs/new-rook-ransomware-feeds-off-the-code-of-babuk/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1583 - Acquire Infrastructure  
T1587 - Develop Capabilities  
T1587.001 - Malware  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1027 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
T1027.002 - Software Packing  
T1070 - Indicator Removal on Host  
T1070.004 - File Deletion  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1007 - System Service Discovery  
T1057 - Process Discovery  
T1083 - File and Directory Discovery  
  
 **Impact - TA0040**  
T1486 - Data Encrypted for Impact  
T1490 - Inhibit System Recovery

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: UK Banks 2FA Being Bypassed
Akamai and Cyjax have published reports on a campaign that is bypassing 2FA in order to employ a multi-part phishing kit. Functionality of this kit does not behave as typically expected. This particular phishing kit uses a centralized control panel, a departure from typical phishing operations.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: UK Banks 2FA Being Bypassed
Akamai and Cyjax have published reports on a campaign that is bypassing 2FA in order to employ a multi-part phishing kit. Functionality of this kit does not behave as typically expected. This particular phishing kit uses a centralized control panel, a departure from typical phishing operations.

# Threat Type

  * Phishing




# Overview

A phishing kit is bypassing 2FA by intercepting 2FA tokens in real time. The kit allows anyone to develop lures for this campaign through the use of the control panel previously mentioned. Lures created by a variety of actors have the potential to be quite lucrative depending on the sophistication of the lures. The campaign uses a high-quality phishing page, an optional, masked gateway to the control panel, and the actual control panel to which the stolen credentials are exfiltrated. Lures for this campaign are split into two parts: an SMS message containing a link to a fake login page to the victim's bank. One of the more interesting aspects of the SMS message is that is a type-0 SMS, typically used to display emergency messages. The type-0 message displays over any open window or application making it particularly enticing to recipients. The link in the SMS leads to a cloned copy of the actual bank page in question and drops a cookie to advise the attacker of subsequent visits to the page. Attackers are able to organize the phishing kit to block or redirect victims who do not click on the link, or security professionals attempting to ascertain where the stolen information is exfiltrated. The masked gateway allows victims to only see the gateway should they attempt to find the actual control panel. Should anyone attempt to track the control panel, they are only able to see the masked gateway information. Once a victim visits a lure, a beacon is sent to the control panel, which triggers visual and audio alerts to the attacker allowing them to take actions to phish the intended victim. This particular kit allows for the creation of multiple lures for multiple banks, seemingly, to provide the widest net for trapping victims. If the lure or logs are removed by anyone other than the attacker, all credentials found during that session are lost. The kit contains a configured email address to which the kit will send obtained credentials. The 2FA bypass works by providing its own 2FA with fake information and a challenge screen in which victims are to enter specific pieces of information from the fake 2FA provided. Once the victim enters the information and clicks the "Next" button, all details are passed to the attacker's control panel. Further details can be found in the reports located within the Reference section below.

# CVEs

  * N/A




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.

  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.

  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.

  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.

  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://www.cyjax.com/2020/07/14/two-factor-fail-analysis-of-a-modern-phishing-kit/>

  * <https://blogs.akamai.com/sitr/2021/02/massive-campaign-targeting-uk-banks-bypassing-2fa.html>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: FBI Flash - Cuba Ransomware
The FBI has issued a Flash alert that provides information and IoCs related to the Cuba ransomware.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: FBI Flash - Cuba Ransomware
The FBI has issued a Flash alert that provides information and IoCs related to the Cuba ransomware.

# Threat Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Ransomware
  *  **Targets:** Unspecified
  *  **Ransomware Family:** Cuba (S0625)
  *  **Additional Payloads:** Cobalt Strike (S0154), Hancitor (S0499), Mimikatz (S0002).
  *  **RaaS Operation:** Unspecified
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Multiple
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Data collection, and exfiltration, File encryption.
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

The Cuba ransomware has been around since very late in 2019. According to the FBI's Flash alert, it has been involved in the compromising of some forty-nine entities as of early November 2021. The compromised entities exist mainly in five critical infrastructure sectors, financial, government, healthcare, information technology, and manufacturing. Cuba is typically deployed by the Hancitor malware which is a dropper used to deploy a variety of malware including RATs and other ransomware. Hancitor itself uses a number of infection vectors including exploiting Exchange vulnerabilities, compromised credentials, phishing, and RDP. Once Cuba is deployed, Cobalt Strike beacons are installed on compromised hosts and MimiKatz is used to obtain credentials that allow the attacker to connect to other hosts using RDP. Compromised hosts are able to communicate directly with the Cuba C&C servers to download and deploy files used in the next stage of the attack. When Cuba encrypts files it adds a .cuba extension to the filename. The Flash makes no mention of exfiltration of data although the sample ransom note shown in the alert mentions the downloading of data to attacker-controlled servers. The Flash notes that the Cuba operators have demanded ransoms that total at least $74 million USD, and have received a minimum, $43.9 million USD in payments. Further information is available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/74055873/FBI%20Flash%20-%20Cuba%20Ransomware%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1638938176371&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Restrict Web-Based Content (M1021).
  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques and phishing emails (M1017).



# References

  * <https://www.ic3.gov/Media/News/2021/211203-2.pdf>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: TeamTNT Adopt TTPs From WatchDog Group
TeamTNT have changed their TTPs, dropping some of their traditional TTPs and adopting some from the WatchDog cryptojacking group, according to a report from Palo Alto's Unit 42.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Cryptomining




# Overview

Palo Alto's Unit 42 has published a report on changes to the TTPs used by TeamTNT. The group has dropped the targeting of Kubernetes and Docker APIs, are no longer exfiltrating data from infected systems, and are not using the zgrab network scanner. Instead, TeamTNT has copied techniques used by the cryptojacking group, WatchDog. Among the changes are the use of additional Monero mining pools and a directory structure used by WatchDog. According to Unit 42, this is not the first time TeamTNT has adopted the TTPs of other groups. In the past, TeamTNT utilized TTPs from the Kinsing group. Unit 42 concludes that the changes to TTPs are to allow TeamTNT to increase its cryptomining operations while attempting to hide the operations by appearing to be those of the WatchDog group. Further details are available from the report linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/teamtnt-cryptojacking-watchdog-operations/>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Watering Hole Attack From Unknown Group Targets MacOS
Google's Threat Analysis Group has reported a new exploit chain targeting Mac devices, starting with a watering hole attack. This attack results in a new, sophisticated backdoor being installed on the victim's machine.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Watering Hole Attack From Unknown Group Targets MacOS
Google's Threat Analysis Group has reported a new exploit chain targeting Mac devices, starting with a watering hole attack. This attack results in a new, sophisticated backdoor being installed on the victim's machine.

# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Backdoor
  *  **Targets:** Mac/IOS Users
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** Unknown **  
**
  * **Initial Infection Vector:** Watering Hold Attack
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Input Capture, Exfiltration



# Overview

Google's Threat Analysis Group has reported a new exploit chain targeting Mac devices, starting with a watering hole attack. The attack targets unpatched MacOS Catalina, which leads to the installation of a previously unknown backdoor. It is speculated that the group behind this attack may be state-supported, as the malware is high quality and it appears they have a lot of resources with which to set up infrastructure and develop malware. The attack begins on malicious websites that contain iframes that serve the exploits. One targets ios, and the other targets MacOS, with both using a different framework. Once the user navigates to the malicious pages and the remote code execution completes, a heavily obfuscated embedded binary is loaded into memory, patched, and run. This binary then uses an exploit to escalate privilege, allowing the attacker to generate their own sec_token and audit_token. After gaining root, the payload is run in the background of the victim's machine. This payload appears to be highly sophisticated, suggesting that the threat actor has extensive software engineering capabilities. Further details can be found in the report located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/70222567/Watering%20Hole%20Attack%20From%20Unknown%20Group%20Targets%20MacOS%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1637069386478&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking (M1038). 



# References

  * <https://blog.google/threat-analysis-group/analyzing-watering-hole-campaign-using-macos-exploits/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1189 - Drive-by Compromise  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
  
 **Privilege Escalation - TA0004**  
T1068 - Exploitation for Privilege Escalation  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1027 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1007 - System Service Discovery  
T1016 - System Network Configuration Discovery  
T1040 - Network Sniffing  
T1083 - File and Directory Discovery  
  
 **Collection - TA0009**  
T1056 - Input Capture  
T1113 - Screen Capture  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0010**  
T1041 - Exfiltration Over C2 Channel  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1095 - Non-Application Layer Protocol  
T1571 - Non-Standard Port

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: GuLoader Delivering AZORult
The delivery chain examined by VMRay uses GuLoader to download and install an infostealer called AZORult.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Campaign, Infostealer



# Overview

VMRay examines the delivery chain used by a campaign that utilizes GuLoader to install AZORult on a victim system. GULoader is a downloader that employs advanced anti-analysis techniques that, in the past, has been used to deliver FormBook, NanoCore, LokiBot, and Remcos, as well as other malware. In this campaign, a weaponized RTF document is sent via a spam email. This attachment, if opened, exploits a vulnerability (CVE-2017-11882) in Microsoft Office products. The malware download process consisted of three steps and downloaded two payloads, GuLoader and AZORult. Once GuLoader runs, it uses advanced anti-analysis, sandbox detection, and evasion techniques to ensure a "safe" environment to download and execute its final AZORult payload. AZORult is an information stealer targeting login credentials, cookies, cryptocurrency wallets, and more. Information captured by AZORult is sent back to its command and control servers. For more details, examine the link in the Reference section.

# CVEs

  * A complete list of CVEs can be found here: [ CVEs.txt](/download/attachments/33983058/GuLoader%20Delivering%20AZORult%20CVEs.txt?version=3&modificationDate=1606178217355&api=v2)



# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/33983058/GuLoader%20Delivering%20AZORult%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1606149916650&api=v2)



# Protection

## IBM

  * [CVE-2017-11882](https://exchange.xforce.ibmcloud.com/vulnerabilities/134283): [CompoundFile_OLE_Equation_Exec](https://exchange.xforce.ibmcloud.com/signature/CompoundFile_OLE_Equation_Exec)



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.vmray.com/cyber-security-blog/azorult-delivered-by-guloader-malware-analysis-spotlight/>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Declassifying UNC1945
Yoroi has published a report declassifying some details about a group called UNC1945 in a paper presented by Mandiant. Yoroi uses TH-239 to identify the same group.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware, Threat-Group



# Overview

Based on a Mandiant report, Yoroi decided to declassify information about the group UNC1945 (Mandiant label) in their own report. Yoroi identifies the group with the term TH-239. UNC1945 uses a Linux QEMU virtual machine with all of the tools needed to achieve its goals. The version of Linux bundled for the attack is Tinycore Linux 7.2. This distribution is about four years old but was seen being used in attacks during 2020. Inside the disk image, three directories stand out - "deploy", "python", and "responder". The deploy directory contains a number of tools designed to attack various kinds of machines. The python directory contains various exploits written in the Python language. Some of the exploits include EternalBlue, EternalChampion, EternalSynergy, and EternalRomance. The responder directory contains a tool that listens on the network for NetBIOS Name Service and Link-Local Multicast Name Resolution broadcasts for hostnames. It is used to steal NTLMv1/v2 password hashes. For more technical details and more information on the tools used, please see the link in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ - IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/35717245/Declassifying%20UNC1945%20-%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1606771293055&api=v2)



# Yara Rule

  * Yara Rule protection can be found here: [ - Yara.txt](/download/attachments/35717245/Declassifying%20UNC1945%20-%20Yara.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1606771341207&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://yoroi.company/research/shadows-from-the-past-threaten-italian-enterprises/>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Baka JavaScript Skimmer
Baka is a new JavaScript skimmer identified by Visa Payment Fraud Disruption (PFD). It is relatively advanced for a skimmer and leverages unique loading and obfuscation techniques.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware, Skimmer




# Overview

Visa Payment Fraud Disruption (PFD) has published a report analyzing the Baka JavaScript skimmer. This skimmer has some advanced components making it relatively sophisticated for a credit card skimmer. Its loader is dynamically added to a victim site and is responsible for decrypting and executes remotely-hosted JavaScript code. The C2 URL from which is loads the JavaScript is encrypted and hardcoded in the loader code. Five scheduled functions are run by the skimming malware in order to carry out its purpose. First, it looks for target field names and, if identified, captures any data entered by the victim into those fields. If data has been captured, it calls an exfiltration function. To exfiltrate the data, it is encoded and stored in the GET parameters of the gateway URL, which masquerades as an image. The malicious code performing these functions runs only in memory on the victim's machine, and after data has been exfiltrated, the malware cleans itself up by removing the skimming code from memory. The researchers note that the use of an XOR cipher to encrypt the malicious code and avoid detection is unique and not previously seen in JavaScript skimming malware. For more information, see the Visa report in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.



# Reference

parsed_raw_data.xfe_q:
Baka JavaScript Skimmer
Baka is a new JavaScript skimmer identified by Visa Payment Fraud Disruption (PFD). It is relatively advanced for a skimmer and leverages unique loading and obfuscation techniques.
parsed_raw_data.xfe_report:
# Threat Type

  * Malware, Skimmer




# Overview

Visa Payment Fraud Disruption (PFD) has published a report analyzing the Baka JavaScript skimmer. This skimmer has some advanced components making it relatively sophisticated for a credit card skimmer. Its loader is dynamically added to a victim site and is responsible for decrypting and executes remotely-hosted JavaScript code. The C2 URL from which is loads the JavaScript is encrypted and hardcoded in the loader code. Five scheduled functions are run by the skimming malware in order to carry out its purpose. First, it looks for target field names and, if identified, captures any data entered by the victim into those fields. If data has been captured, it calls an exfiltration function. To exfiltrate the data, it is encoded and stored in the GET parameters of the gateway URL, which masquerades as an image. The malicious code performing these functions runs only in memory on the victim's machine, and after data has been exfiltrated, the malware cleans itself up by removing the skimming code from memory. The researchers note that the use of an XOR cipher to encrypt the malicious code and avoid detection is unique and not previously seen in JavaScript skimming malware. For more information, see the Visa report in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.



# Reference

  * <https://usa.visa.com/content/dam/VCOM/global/support-legal/documents/visa-security-alert-baka-javascript-skimmer.pdf>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Custom PowerShell RAT Targeting Germany in New Campaign
Malwarebytes Labs has published a report on a new campaign targeting Germans seeking information about the Ukraine crisis. The final payload of this campaign is a custom PowerShell RAT.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Custom PowerShell RAT Targeting Germany in New Campaign
Malwarebytes Labs has published a report on a new campaign targeting Germans seeking information about the Ukraine crisis. The final payload of this campaign is a custom PowerShell RAT.

# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Remote Access Trojan
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Unknown
  *  **Associated Payloads:** Unnamed PowerShell RAT
  *  **Targets:** German Citizens
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Phishing Site
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Unknown



# Overview

Malwarebytes Labs has analyzed a new custom PowerShell RAT being used to target German citizens. The attack starts on an expired Germain domain that was a legitimate collaboration platform. The attackers registered this domain and used it to host a fake version of the local government site. The site encourages the user to download a file that claims to contain information on the war in Ukraine but is really a Microsoft HTML help file. Upon execution, the users will receive an error message, but a Base64 encoded PowerShell command is executed in the background. It downloads two files which are executed as the final payload, which is the PowerShell RAT. This RAT can download and upload files, execute PowerShell scripts, and execute commands. The C2 domain is another Germain domain to avoid suspicion. For more information, please see the link in the references section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * For a full list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.




# References

  * <https://blog.malwarebytes.com/threat-intelligence/2022/05/custom-powershell-rat-targets-germans-seeking-information-about-the-ukraine-crisis/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
T1059.001 - PowerShell  
T1059.003 - Windows Command Shell  
  
 **Persistence - TA0003**  
T1053.005 - Scheduled Task  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1027 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
T1222 - File and Directory Permissions Modification  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0010**  
T1041 - Exfiltration Over C2 Channel  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1071.001 - Web Protocols  
  


#### Mitigations:

  
 **M1018:** User Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.  
 **M1021:** Restrict Web-Based Content - Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc.  
 **M1022:** Restrict File and Directory Permissions - Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.  
 **M1026:** Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.  
 **M1028:** Operating System Configuration - Make configuration changes related to the operating system or a common feature of the operating system that result in system hardening against techniques.  
 **M1031:** Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  
 **M1033:** Limit Software Installation - Block users or groups from installing unapproved software.  
 **M1037:** Filter Network Traffic - Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic.  
 **M1038:** Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
 **M1040:** Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
 **M1042:** Disable or Remove Feature or Program - Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.  
 **M1045:** Code Signing - Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.  
 **M1047:** Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
 **M1049:** Antivirus/Antimalware - Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software.  
 **M1057:** Data Loss Prevention - Use a data loss prevention (DLP) strategy to categorize sensitive data, identify data formats indicative of personal identifiable information (PII), and restrict exfiltration of sensitive data.

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: CrimsonIAS Backdoor
CrimsonIAS is a Windows backdoor that has been around since at least 2017. ThreatConnect has published an analysis of the malware and its potential ties to Mustang Panda.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Backdoor




# Overview

ThreatConnect published their analysis of the CrimsonIAS backdoor, including potential attribution. The backdoor operates on Windows hosts, is written in Delphi, and dates back to at least 2017. Upon execution, the malware points to the MZ header to run embedded shell code. The shell code is responsible for calling a reflective loader function that loads the binary and jumps to its entry point. Unlike most Windows backdoors that beacon to a C2 server to retrieve commands, CrimsonIAS simply opens a listener that waits to receive commands from the attacker. There are three available commands an attacker can pass to the backdoor: run a command, receive a file, or send a file. Researchers believe that this backdoor could potentially be attributed to the Mustang Panda APT due to a few key similarities. First, the payload is encrypted with an XOR key that is prepended to the binary. Additionally, it leverages the MZ header to store shell code. Lastly, an exported library named Loader is used to reflectively load the binary. This also means that existing Mustang Panda PlugX archives could be used to launch CrimsonIAS instead of a PlugX DLL. For more information, see the ThreatConnect blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://threatconnect.com/blog/crimsonias-listening-for-an-3v1l-user/>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: BendyBear is Sophisticated Shellcode
A report from Palo Alto's Unit 42 looks at shellcode that they've named BendyBear and have attributed to a cyber espionage group named BlackTech.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware, APT




# Overview

BendyBear is x64 shellcode that Palo Alto's Unit 42 has attributed to the APT group named BlackTech. The group are believed to have ties to the Chinese government and are involved in cyber espionage. BendyBear is used to download a payload from a C&C server. According to Unit 42's report, BendyBear has a number of unique features including transmitting payloads in modified RC4-encrypted chunks so that a single RC4 key cannot be used to decrypt the entire payload. In addition it employs several techniques to evade detection such as the use of polymorphic code to evade memory analysis, encrypting or decrypting code blocks at runtime, unique session keys for each C2 connection, and the use of position independent code. Unit 42 describe BendyBear as "one of the most sophisticated, well-engineered and difficult-to-detect samples of shellcode" used by an APT group. Further information, and a detailed analysis, is available from the report linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/bendybear-shellcode-blacktech/>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Threat Group Uses Voice Changing Software in Espionage Attempt
While investigating a server operated by APT-C-23, Cado Security identified an interesting tool in use by the group: voice changing software.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Espionage




# Overview

Cado Security published a blog post analyzing a server operated by APT-C-23, specifically focusing on a software program named Morph Vox Pro. APT-C-32 is a Middle Eastern cyber espionage group that typically targets government officials. Their main method of espionage is through the use of social engineering methods. One specific technique involves the use of fake social media profiles of attractive women used to strike up conversation with unsuspecting targets eventually luring them to open malicious files or to disclose sensitive information. The server used by the group includes a diverse set of tools, many of which have been reported on by other security researchers. Malware payloads communicating with the server include Palestinian-themed downloaders used to install the H-Worm backdoor. The server also hosts folders containing pictures of a female model used to build a fake Instagram account to lure victims. One of the most interesting discoveries was that of Morph Vox Pro installation files. It is believed that this tool is used to create audio messages from the fake Instagram models in order to increase legitimacy despite the group likely being made up of all males. A spear phishing delivery tool and router exploitation capabilities were also discovered. For more information, see the Cado Security blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.cadosecurity.com/post/threat-group-uses-voice-changing-software-in-espionage-attempt>
