instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Ransomware Ads Being Banned at a Rapid Pace
Hot on the heels of the Colonial Pipeline ransomware attack, cybercrime forums, threat groups, and others are reevaluating their business model. According to several reports of varying sources, even Darkside has claimed to have taken itself offline.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Ransomware Ads Being Banned at a Rapid Pace
Hot on the heels of the Colonial Pipeline ransomware attack, cybercrime forums, threat groups, and others are reevaluating their business model. According to several reports of varying sources, even Darkside has claimed to have taken itself offline.

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Ransomware




# Overview

Due to what is being described as indiscriminate targeting, many forums, repos, and even some threat groups are taking steps to ensure a "proper vetting" of targets occurs prior to attack. The forums and repos have gone so far as to ban any ransomware ads placed on the sites. Any type of ad touting ransomware is removed. Leading the way in this effort is the XSS Russian-speaking forum. RaaS gangs such as REvil, LockBit, DarkSide, Netwalker, Nefilim, Babuk, and others have been using these forums to recruit new members, partners, and affiliates. The owner of XSS feels that ransomware is bringing "unwanted attention to the site and has become dangerous and toxic," according to a quote obtained by Bleeping Computer. Many of the RaaS gangs are purportedly leaving the forums for others that are more welcoming of their type of activity, such as exploit.in. This move will, most likely, be a temporary one as more and more forums are banning these gangs/actors. Forum admins have also stated they will remove all ransomware-related topics as well as affiliate programs. 

In a surprise move, DarkSide has claimed to have ceased operations. This closure is a result of the attack on the Colonial Pipeline that caused major interruptions in the flow of petroleum to large sections of the eastern United States. DarkSide has released a "press release" stating they are apolitical and will vet targets before any future attacks. Colonial Pipeline reportedly paid nearly $5M in cryptocurrency to obtain a decryption key from the actors. One well-known threat actor, UNKN, stated the operations ceased due to the loss of access to the public data leak site, payment servers, and CDN servers "at the request of law enforcement agencies," and cryptocurrency being moved to an unknown wallet. DarkSide has confirmed UNKN's claims. DarkSide also announced the requirement of providing decryption keys to each target that have been attacked and would compensate all financial obligations by May 23, 2021. 

REvil has imposed new restrictions on the targeting of entities. Affiliates are now required to obtain permission in order to target an organization. According to the representative of REvil, health care, education, etc. are all prohibited targets as are government sectors of any country. Further information can be found in the links located within the Reference section below. 

# Reference

  * <https://www.bleepingcomputer.com/news/security/ransomware-ads-now-also-banned-on-exploit-cybercrime-forum/>

  * <https://www.bleepingcomputer.com/news/security/darkside-ransomware-servers-reportedly-seized-operation-shuts-down/>
  * <https://www.intel471.com/blog/darkside-ransomware-shut-down-revil-avaddon-cybercrime>
  * <https://www.bleepingcomputer.com/news/security/popular-russian-hacking-forum-xss-bans-all-ransomware-topics/>

REvil has imposed new restrictions on the targeting of entities. Affiliates are now required to obtain permission in order to target an organization. According to the representative of REvil, health care, education, etc. are all prohibited targets as are government sectors of any country. Further information can be found in the links located within the Reference section below. 

# Reference

  * <https://www.bleepingcomputer.com/news/security/ransomware-ads-now-also-banned-on-exploit-cybercrime-forum/>

  * <https://www.bleepingcomputer.com/news/security/darkside-ransomware-servers-reportedly-seized-operation-shuts-down/>
  * <https://www.intel471.com/blog/darkside-ransomware-shut-down-revil-avaddon-cybercrime>
  * <https://www.bleepingcomputer.com/news/security/popular-russian-hacking-forum-xss-bans-all-ransomware-topics/>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: NCAS Alert AA21-200A - TTPs of Indicted APT40 Actors
Alert AA21-200A has been published through the National Cyber Awareness System and provides information on APT40’s tactics, techniques, and procedures (TTPs) and indicators of compromise (IOCs).

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware




# Overview

 **From Alert AA21-200A**  
 **Tactics, Techniques, and Procedures of Indicted APT40 Actors Associated with China’s MSS Hainan State Security Department**

This Joint Cybersecurity Advisory was written by the Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) and the Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) to provide information on a Chinese Advanced Persistent Threat (APT) group known in open-source reporting as APT40. This advisory provides APT40’s tactics, techniques, and procedures (TTPs) and indicators of compromise (IOCs) to help cybersecurity practitioners identify and remediate APT40 intrusions and established footholds.

APT40—aka BRONZE MOHAWK, FEVERDREAM, G0065, Gadolinium, GreenCrash, Hellsing, Kryptonite Panda, Leviathan, MUDCARP, Periscope, Temp.Periscope, and Temp.Jumper—is located in Haikou, Hainan Province, People’s Republic of China (PRC), and has been active since at least 2009. APT40 has targeted governmental organizations, companies, and universities in a wide range of industries—including biomedical, robotics, and maritime research—across the United States, Canada, Europe, the Middle East, and the South China Sea area, as well as industries included in China’s Belt and Road Initiative.

On July 19, 2021, the U.S. Department of Justice (DOJ) unsealed an indictment against four APT40 cyber actors for their illicit computer network exploitation (CNE) activities via front company Hainan Xiandun Technology Development Company (Hainan Xiandun). Hainan Xiandun employee Wu Shurong cooperated with and carried out orders from PRC Ministry of State Security (MSS) Hainan State Security Department (HSSD) intelligence officers Ding Xiaoyang, Zhu Yunmin, and Cheng Qingmin to conduct CNE. Wu’s CNE activities resulted in the theft of trade secrets, intellectual property, and other high-value information from companies and organizations in the United States and abroad, as well as from multiple foreign governments. These MSS-affiliated actors targeted victims in the following industries: academia, aerospace/aviation, biomedical, defense industrial base, education, government, healthcare, manufacturing, maritime, research institutes, and transportation (rail and shipping).

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 
  * IoCs can also be download in STIX format from CISA: <https://us-cert.cisa.gov/sites/default/files/publications/AA21-200A.stix.xml>



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ncas/alerts/aa21-200a>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: TeamTNT Updates Scripts After Tool Leak
Talos Intelligence has written a report detailing TeamTNTs actions after their tools were leaked by security researchers. They are actively modifying their scripts which target AWS instances, but can also run in on-premise, container, or other forms of Linux instances.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: TeamTNT Updates Scripts After Tool Leak
Talos Intelligence has written a report detailing TeamTNTs actions after their tools were leaked by security researchers. They are actively modifying their scripts which target AWS instances, but can also run in on-premise, container, or other forms of Linux instances.

# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Cryptominer
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** TeamTNT
  *  **Associated Payloads:** Various Scripts
  *  **Targets:** Unknown
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Unknown
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Cryptomining



# Overview

Cisco Talos has been provided with recently modified versions of TeamTNT's malicious scripts. These have been modified because of a recent leak where security researchers published their tools and made their scripts public. These scripts include scripts that steal credentials, cryptocurrency mining scripts, and scripts for lateral movement and persistence. The majority of these scripts were targetting AWS instances, but there are scripts to affect on-premise, container, and other Linux instances. One factor which has not been reported on in the past was the ability of these scripts to disable cloud security tools. The majority of this functionality is targeting Alibaba Cloud Security's various agents. The scripts can hunt for the process and attempt to kill it by running Alibaba tools, as well as trying to unmount the default Alibaba aegis directory. For full details of each script and its functionality, please see the link in the reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

For a full list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.

# References

  * <https://blog.talosintelligence.com/2022/04/teamtnt-targeting-aws-alibaba.html>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Reconnaissance - TA0043**  
T1592.002 - Software  
  
 **Persistence - TA0003**  
T1098.004 - SSH Authorized Keys  
T1547 - Boot or Logon Autostart Execution  
  
 **Privilege Escalation - TA0004**  
T1547 - Boot or Logon Autostart Execution  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1480 - Execution Guardrails  
T1562 - Impair Defenses  
  
 **Impact - TA0040**  
T1496 - Resource Hijacking  
  


#### Mitigations:

  
 **M1013:** Application Developer Guidance: This mitigation describes any guidance or training given to developers of applications to avoid introducing security weaknesses that an adversary may be able to take advantage of.  
 **M1017:** User Training - Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction.  
 **M1018:** User Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.  
 **M1022:** Restrict File and Directory Permissions - Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.  
 **M1024:** Restrict Registry Permissions - Restrict the ability to modify certain hives or keys in the Windows Registry.  
 **M1025:** Privileged Process Integrity - Protect processes with high privileges that can be used to interact with critical system components through use of protected process light, anti-process injection defenses, or other process integrity enforcement measures.  
 **M1026:** Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.  
 **M1028:** Operating System Configuration - Make configuration changes related to the operating system or a common feature of the operating system that result in system hardening against techniques.  
 **M1030:** Network Segmentation - Architect sections of the network to isolate critical systems, functions, or resources. Use physical and logical segmentation to prevent access to potentially sensitive systems and information. Use a DMZ to contain any internet-facing services that should not be exposed from the internal network. Configure separate virtual private cloud (VPC) instances to isolate critical cloud systems.  
 **M1032:** Multi-factor Authentication - Use two or more pieces of evidence to authenticate to a system; such as username and password in addition to a token from a physical smart card or token generator.  
 **M1033:** Limit Software Installation - Block users or groups from installing unapproved software.  
 **M1038:** Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
 **M1039:** Environment Variable Permissions - Prevent modification of environment variables by unauthorized users and groups.  
 **M1042:** Disable or Remove Feature or Program - Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.  
 **M1043:** Credential Access Protection - Use capabilities to prevent successful credential access by adversaries; including blocking forms of credential dumping.  
 **M1044:** Restrict Library Loading - Prevent abuse of library loading mechanisms in the operating system and software to load untrusted code by configuring appropriate library loading mechanisms and investigating potential vulnerable software.  
 **M1047:** Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
 **M1049:** Antivirus/Antimalware - Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software.  
 **M1054:** Software Configuration - Implement configuration changes to software (other than the operating system) to mitigate security risks associated to how the software operates.  
 **M1055:** Do Not Mitigate - This category is to associate techniques that mitigation might increase risk of compromise and therefore mitigation is not recommended.  
 **M1056:** Pre-compromise - This category is used for any applicable mitigation activities that apply to techniques occurring before an adversary gains Initial Access, such as Reconnaissance and Resource Development techniques.

parsed_raw_data.xfe_q:
TeamTNT Updates Scripts After Tool Leak
Talos Intelligence has written a report detailing TeamTNTs actions after their tools were leaked by security researchers. They are actively modifying their scripts which target AWS instances, but can also run in on-premise, container, or other forms of Linux instances.
parsed_raw_data.xfe_report:
# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Cryptominer
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** TeamTNT
  *  **Associated Payloads:** Various Scripts
  *  **Targets:** Unknown
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Unknown
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Cryptomining



# Overview

Cisco Talos has been provided with recently modified versions of TeamTNT's malicious scripts. These have been modified because of a recent leak where security researchers published their tools and made their scripts public. These scripts include scripts that steal credentials, cryptocurrency mining scripts, and scripts for lateral movement and persistence. The majority of these scripts were targetting AWS instances, but there are scripts to affect on-premise, container, and other Linux instances. One factor which has not been reported on in the past was the ability of these scripts to disable cloud security tools. The majority of this functionality is targeting Alibaba Cloud Security's various agents. The scripts can hunt for the process and attempt to kill it by running Alibaba tools, as well as trying to unmount the default Alibaba aegis directory. For full details of each script and its functionality, please see the link in the reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: The TTPs of a Moses Staff Campaign
A report from FortiGuard Labs focuses on the TTPs used by the Iranian threat group Moses Staff in a campaign the group has been conducting.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: The TTPs of a Moses Staff Campaign
A report from FortiGuard Labs focuses on the TTPs used by the Iranian threat group Moses Staff in a campaign the group has been conducting.

# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Malware, Espionage.
  *  **Targets:** Israeli organizations across a range of industry sectors.
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** DriveGuard, Webshells.
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** ProxyShell vulnerabilities in Microsoft Exchange servers.
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Data collection and exfiltration.
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

MosesStaff is believed to be an Iranian threat actor that could have been active as early as 2020 but had remained undetected until more recently. The campaign analyzed by FortiGuard Labs specifically targeted Israeli organizations across a range of industry sectors. Initial access to the victims was obtained by exploiting the ProxyShell vulnerabilities in Microsoft Exchange servers. After successfully exploiting the vulnerabilities, two webshells were installed on the systems. The report notes that the attackers then spent several days exfiltrating PST files and other sensitive information before installing a backdoor. To install the backdoor, a loader installs itself as a service named DriveGuard and aside from executing the backdoor it also monitors it and restarts the backdoor if it stops. The loader also creates a watchdog mechanism to restart its service if it is stopped. The motive for the group's attack appears to be espionage. Further information is available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/74058940/The%20TTPs%20of%20a%20Moses%20Staff%20Campaign%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1645072083733&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).



# References

  * <https://www.fortinet.com/blog/threat-research/guard-your-drive-from-driveguard>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
T1059.003 - Windows Command Shell  
T1569 - System Services  
T1569.002 - Service Execution  
  
 **Persistence - TA0003**  
T1053 - Scheduled Task/Job  
T1053.005 - Scheduled Task  
T1505 - Server Software Component  
T1505.003 - Web Shell  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1055 - Process Injection  
T1134 - Access Token Manipulation  
T1134.004 - Parent PID Spoofing  
T1140 - Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information  
T1480 - Execution Guardrails  
  
 **Credential Access - TA0006**  
T1003 - OS Credential Dumping  
T1003.001 - LSASS Memory  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1033 - System Owner/User Discovery  
T1082 - System Information Discovery  
T1083 - File and Directory Discovery  
  
 **Collection - TA0009**  
T1005 - Data from Local System  
T1113 - Screen Capture  
T1114 - Email Collection  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0010**  
T1041 - Exfiltration Over C2 Channel  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1008 - Fallback Channels  
T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
T1071.001 - Web Protocols  
T1573 - Encrypted Channel  
T1573.001 - Symmetric Cryptography

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: TeamTnT Distributing New Variant of Black-T
A report from Palo Alto's Unit 42 provides an analysis of a new variant of TeamTNT's Black-T cryptojacking malware. The new variant has some additional features.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware, Cryptojacking




# Overview

The Black-T cryptojacking malware is a product of TeamTNT. A new variant has been analyzed by Unit 42 from Palo Alto. TeamTNT are well known for their targeting of exposed Docker daemon APIs which they use to install their malware. Additional features in the new variant include the terminating of some previously unknown cryptojacking worms including the Crux worm, ntpd miner, and a redis-backup. The new variant may install any or all of the network scanners, masscan, pnscan and zgrab. In addition, scans for exposed Docker APIs are now conducted on random CIDR 8 network ranges instead of just the local network. The malware will attempt to exploit any exposed Docker APIs it finds. A new port, TCP 5555, has been added to the network scans, its purpose is not yet known. The memory scraping tools, mimipy and mimipenguins, are also installed with the new variant, and function similar to Mimikatz. Any passwords that are obtained and exfiltrated to a C&C server. Further details are available from the report linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/black-t-cryptojacking-variant/>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: NCAS Alert AA21-042A - Compromise of U.S. Water Treatment Facility
Alert AA21-042A has been published through the National Cyber Awareness System and provides information on the compromise of a SCADA system at water treatment facility in the United States. The attackers attempted to to increase the amount of sodium hydroxide in the water by manipulating the compromised system.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: NCAS Alert AA21-042A - Compromise of U.S. Water Treatment Facility
Alert AA21-042A has been published through the National Cyber Awareness System and provides information on the compromise of a SCADA system at water treatment facility in the United States. The attackers attempted to to increase the amount of sodium hydroxide in the water by manipulating the compromised system.

# Threat Type

  * Breach




# Overview

From Alert (AA21-042A)  
Compromise of U.S. Water Treatment Facility

On February 5, 2021, unidentified cyber actors obtained unauthorized access to the supervisory control and data acquisition (SCADA) system at a U.S. drinking water treatment plant. The unidentified actors used the SCADA system’s software to increase the amount of sodium hydroxide, also known as lye, a caustic chemical, as part of the water treatment process. Water treatment plant personnel immediately noticed the change in dosing amounts and corrected the issue before the SCADA system’s software detected the manipulation and alarmed due to the unauthorized change. As a result, the water treatment process remained unaffected and continued to operate as normal. The cyber actors likely accessed the system by exploiting cybersecurity weaknesses, including poor password security, and an outdated operating system. Early information indicates it is possible that a desktop sharing software, such as TeamViewer, may have been used to gain unauthorized access to the system. Onsite response to the incident included Pinellas County Sheriff Office (PCSO), U.S. Secret Service (USSS), and the Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI).

The FBI, the Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA), the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA), and the Multi-State Information Sharing and Analysis Center (MS-ISAC) have observed cyber criminals targeting and exploiting desktop sharing software and computer networks running operating systems with end of life status to gain unauthorized access to systems. Desktop sharing software, which has multiple legitimate uses—such as enabling telework, remote technical support, and file transfers—can also be exploited through malicious actors’ use of social engineering tactics and other illicit measures. Windows 7 will become more susceptible to exploitation due to lack of security updates and the discovery of new vulnerabilities. Microsoft and other industry professionals strongly recommend upgrading computer systems to an actively supported operating system. Continuing to use any operating system within an enterprise beyond the end of life status may provide cyber criminals access into computer systems.

  
The complete alert, available from the link in the reference section below provides further information and mitigation and prevention strategies.

CVEs

  * None Provided




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ncas/alerts/aa21-042a>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Cryptominer Exploiting ProxyLogon
The ProxyLogon vulnerability affecting Microsoft Exchange has been exploited for a wide variety of purposes. A report by Sophos details the case of a cryptominer spreading via exploitation of this vulnerability.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Cryptominer, Exploit




# Overview

Sophos has published a blog post analyzing a cryptominer spreading via the ProxyLogon exploit. The payload being distributed is itself hosted on a vulnerable Microsoft Exchange server. The infection chain begins with the attackers exploiting ProxyLogon in order to execute a PowerShell command. This PowerShell command downloads and executes a batch script masquerading as a ZIP archive. The batch script, in turn, uses certutil to download two files hosted on the same server, a base64-encoded executable and a .dat file. The decoded executable extracts the miner and its configuration from the .dat file, injects it into a system process, and then deletes the downloaded files, leaving the miner running in memory only. The miner in use is xmr-stack and is capable of mining Monero. The Monero blockchain indicates that the wallet has been receiving funds with fluctuations due to patching of servers followed by further infections on other servers. For more information, see the Sophos blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.



# Reference

  * <https://news.sophos.com/en-us/2021/04/13/compromised-exchange-server-hosting-cryptojacker-targeting-other-exchange-servers/>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: SAP Security Patch Day - December 2020
SAP has released a security patch for December that fixes fourteen security vulnerabilities across their product line.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability



# Overview

SAP has released a security patch for December that fixes fourteen security vulnerabilities. Issues include a missing authentication check, a missing XML validation, code injection, path traversal, unrestricted file upload, formula injection, missing encryption, cross-site scripting, content spoofing, and an open redirect. Products affected include SAP AS ABAP, SAP BW4HANA, SAP Business Warehouse, SAP BusinessObjects BI Platform, SAP BusinessObjects Business Intelligence Platform, SAP Disclosure Management, SAP HANA Database, SAP NetWeaver, SAP NetWeaver AS, SAP NetWeaver AS ABAP, SAP NetWeaver Application Server, SAP S4 HANA, SAP Solution Manager, and SAP UI. Check to patch link in the Reference section for product versions and additional details.

# CVEs

  * A complete list of CVEs can be found here: [ CVEs.txt](/download/attachments/35717836/SAP%20Security%20Patch%20Day%20-%20December%202020%20CVEs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1607447951840&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

parsed_raw_data.xfe_report:
# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability



# Overview

SAP has released a security patch for December that fixes fourteen security vulnerabilities. Issues include a missing authentication check, a missing XML validation, code injection, path traversal, unrestricted file upload, formula injection, missing encryption, cross-site scripting, content spoofing, and an open redirect. Products affected include SAP AS ABAP, SAP BW4HANA, SAP Business Warehouse, SAP BusinessObjects BI Platform, SAP BusinessObjects Business Intelligence Platform, SAP Disclosure Management, SAP HANA Database, SAP NetWeaver, SAP NetWeaver AS, SAP NetWeaver AS ABAP, SAP NetWeaver Application Server, SAP S4 HANA, SAP Solution Manager, and SAP UI. Check to patch link in the Reference section for product versions and additional details.

# CVEs

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: UltimaSMS Scam Campaign
A large premium SMS scam campaign, dubbed "UltimaSMS," is being carried out via the Google Play Store. Avast reports on the fake applications and their functionality in a recent blog post.
output:
# Threat Details

  *  **Threat Type:** SMS Subscription Scam
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Unknown
  *  **Associated Payloads:** Unknown
  *  **Associated** **Campaign** : UltimaSMS
  *  **Targets:** Android users
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Fake apps in Google Play Store
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Premium SMS subscription enrollment



# Overview

Avast published a blog post analyzing a premium SMS scam campaign, dubbed "UltimaSMS," that has been active since at least May 2021. Google Play Store links to fake copies of legitimate applications are being shared via TikTok and Instagram. The types of applications vary and include custom keyboards, photo editors, games, and more. Once on the system, the fake app gathers system information to determine the location of the victim, which will determine the language and area code that should be used. Upon opening the app, users are presented with a location-specific prompt requesting a phone number. Entering this information results in the user being enrolled in monthly premium SMS services, with the charge maxed out to the limit of the country they are located in. The app either attempts to enroll them in further subscriptions or becomes non-functional. For more information, see the Avast blog post in the References section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/68616701/UltimaSMS%20Scam%20Campaign%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1635257639416&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Install security updates (M1001).
  * Users should be encouraged to only install apps from authorized app stores, which are less likely to contain malicious repackaged apps (M1011).
  * Implement an enterprise mobility management (EMM), also known as mobile device management (MDM) (M1012).
  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques (M1017).



# References

  * <https://blog.avast.com/premium-sms-scam-apps-on-play-store-avast>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Initial Access - TA0027**

T1444 - Masquerade as Legitimate Application

T1475 - Deliver Malicious App via Authorized App Store

 **Execution - TA0041**

T1204.002 – User Execution: Malicious File

 **Discovery - TA0032**

T1422 – System Network Configuration Discovery

 **Impact - TA0034**

T1448 – Carrier Billing Fraud

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: RATDispenser JavaScript Loader
Researchers with HP uncovered a JavaScript loader, dubbed "RATDispenser," being used to distribute various remote access Trojans (RATs).

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Loader
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Unknown
  *  **Associated Payloads:** RATDispenser
  *  **Targets:** Unknown
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Malicious email attachment
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Install remote access Trojan (RAT)



# Overview

HP published a blog post analyzing RATDispenser, a JavaScript loader being used to distribute multiple RATs. The initial infection vector is order-themed phishing email with a JS file attached. Opening the attachment leads to the obfuscated JavaScript code writing and executing a VBScript file. The VBScript will operate in one of two ways depending on the variant. In some cases, it operates as a dropper that decodes an embedded payload and writes it to the system. In other cases, it acts as a downloader, retrieving the secondary payload from a remote server. The encoding method also varied, with some samples using base64-encoding and others using hex arrays. Among the samples of RATDispenser analyzed by HP, eight different malware families were observed being dropped as the final payload, including FormBook, STRRAT, and WSHRAT. For more information, see the HP blog post in the References section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/72155243/RATDispenser%20JavaScript%20Loader%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1638196796787&api=v2)



# Protection

## Yara Rule
    
    
    rule js_RATDispenser : downloader  
    {  
      meta:  
        description = "JavaScript downloader resp. dropper delivering various RATs"  
        author = "HP Threat Research @HPSecurity"  
        filetype = "JavaScript"  
        maltype = "Downloader"  
        date = "2021-05-27"   
      
      strings:  
        $a = /{(\d)}/  
      
        $c1 = "/{(\\d+)}/g"  
        $c2 = "eval"  
        $c3 = "prototype"  
      
        $d1 = "\\x61\\x64\\x6F\\x64\\x62\\x2E"  
        $d2 = "\\x43\\x68\\x61\\x72\\x53\\x65\\x74"  
        $d3 = "\\x54\\x79\\x70\\x65"  
      
        $e1 = "adodb."  
        $e2 = "CharSet"  
        $e3 = "Type"  
      
        $f1 = "arguments"  
        $f2 = "this.replace"  
      
      condition:  
        #a > 50 and all of ($c*) and (any of ($d*) or any of ($e*)) and all of ($f*) and filesize < 2MB  
    }

# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques and phishing emails (M1017).
  * Perform endpoint scans using the provided Yara rules.
  * Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking (M1038). 



# References

  * <https://threatresearch.ext.hp.com/javascript-malware-dispensing-rats-into-the-wild/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1566 - Phishing  
T1566.001 - Spearphishing Attachment  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
T1059.001 - PowerShell  
T1059.007 - JavaScript  
T1204 - User Execution  
T1204.002 - Malicious File  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1027 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
T1070 - Indicator Removal on Host  
T1070.004 - File Deletion

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Phishing Campaigns and Their Evasion and Obfuscation Techniques
Four phishing campaigns that use new techniques for evasion and obfuscation, and the tools used to achieve them, are the subject of a report from Zscaler ThreatLabZ.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Phishing Campaigns and Their Evasion and Obfuscation Techniques
Four phishing campaigns that use new techniques for evasion and obfuscation, and the tools used to achieve them, are the subject of a report from Zscaler ThreatLabZ.

# Threat Type

  * Phishing




# Overview

Information about four phishing campaigns has been provided in a report from Zscaler ThreatLabZ. The campaigns are notable for their use of new techniques for obfuscation and evasion. The first campaign uses phishing pages in which most of the JavaScript is obfuscated, that are designed to closely mimic a Microsoft login page. The obfuscation is achieved using a version of a tool named JavaScript Obfuscator. The second campaign takes a different route and uses a combination of Eval Execution obfuscation, and, secondly, Base64 encoding, to obfuscate the entirety of the source code. JavaScript Obfuscator is also thought to be used in this campaign as well. The third campaign mainly uses imitations of Microsoft pages and obfuscates variable names in the code by hex-encoding them, and JavaScript Obfuscator is also used. The fourth campaign uses JavaScript obfuscation and embedded Base64 images. Common to all the pages is that victims are redirect to legitimate pages once they have entered credentials, and the credentials are sent to the campaigns C&C servers. Further details are available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.zscaler.com/blogs/security-research/new-phishing-trends-and-evasion-techniques>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: LATAM Banking Trojan – Numando
ESET has published another in its series of articles on Latin American banking Trojans. This time, the focus is Numando.
output:
# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Banking Trojan
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Unspecified
  *  **Associated Payloads:** Numando
  *  **Targets:** Bank customers in Brazil.
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Malspam
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions: Stealing and exfiltration of user information.**
  *  **Additional TTPs: See MITRE ATT &CK Framework below.**



# Overview

The Numando banking Trojan is used primarily to target bank users in Brazil. It has been known on rare occasions to have been used in campaigns targeting users in Mexico and Spain. According to ESET, The actor behind Numando has been active since 2018 however, Numando is not frequently updated and does not appear to be under continuous development. It provides features common to banking Trojans such as overlay windows and backdoor access to an infected system. Currently, Numando is distributed using malspam with a ZIP file containing an MSI installer attached to the emails. Inside the installer is a CAB archive that contains an injector, an encrypted DLL which is the Numando payload, and a legitimate application. The legitimate application is used to sideload the Numando DLL. One other infection chain that was used by Numando starts with a downloader that downloads a ZIP file but ignores its content. Instead, it extracts the ZIP file's comment which is a hex-encoded and encrypted string that when decrypted provides the URL of the actual ZIP file whose contents are used in the infection chain. Numando uses a remote configuration that is stored in either Pastebin or YouTube pages. Further information is available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/64128206/LATAM%20Banking%20Trojan%20%E2%80%93%20Numando%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1632197194015&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Restrict Web-Based Content (M1021).



# References

  * <https://www.welivesecurity.com/2021/09/17/numando-latam-banking-trojan/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1583 - Acquire Infrastructure  
T1583.001 - Domains  
T1587 - Develop Capabilities  
T1587.001 - Malware  
  
 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1566 - Phishing  
T1566.001 - Spearphishing Attachment  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1204 - User Execution  
T1204.002 - Malicious File  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1140 - Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information  
T1218 - Signed Binary Proxy Execution  
T1218.007 - Msiexec  
T1574 - Hijack Execution Flow  
T1574.002 - DLL Side-Loading  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1010 - Application Window Discovery  
T1082 - System Information Discovery  
  
 **Collection - TA0009**  
T1113 - Screen Capture  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0010**  
T1041 - Exfiltration Over C2 Channel  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1132 - Data Encoding  
T1132.002 - Non-Standard Encoding

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Widely-Used Node.js Package Code Injection Vulnerability
NPM has issued an advisory regarding a code injection vulnerability in a widely-used package, systeminformation.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

 The package provides functions to retrieve hardware, system, and OS information. The vulnerability, CVE-2021-21315, is due to unsanitized parameters. If successfully exploited, an attacker may be able to execute commands by injecting a payload within these vulnerable parameters. The developer has released an update to the code that patches this issue. Furthermore, guidance is provided for a workaround if updating the package is not possible. We recommend reviewing the advisory and applying any applicable workarounds or updates as soon as possible.

# CVEs

  * CVE-2021-21315




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://www.npmjs.com/advisories/1628>

  * <https://www.bleepingcomputer.com/news/security/heavily-used-nodejs-package-has-a-code-injection-vulnerability/>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Partner Phishing Compromise
An associate partner of a targeted company was the victim of an email infiltration attack. Abnormal Security reports on the attempted theft of credentials and company account information.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Partner Phishing Compromise
An associate partner of a targeted company was the victim of an email infiltration attack. Abnormal Security reports on the attempted theft of credentials and company account information.

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Phishing, etc... 




# Overview

A compromised partner was the victim of an attack in which the unwitting victim appeared to be sending encrypted messages to the partner company. The company, the actual target, received an email that could only be accessed by clicking on the encrypted text. Behind the text was a hyperlink that would redirect the victim to a landing page, which then urged the victim to download a file. The download button, however, did not retrieve a file; it instead redirected the victim again to the final landing page. This landing page seemingly was a fake Microsoft sign-in page with credential phishing as its primary function. Two malicious links were involved. The first was hidden under the retrieval message in the email. The second was on the download page itself from which the victim was redirected. By clicking on these links and entering information, the victim was compromised and any account information could be ascertained. This attack could result in further infiltration and exploitation of the targeted network. Because the sender is a known partner, it was assumed the email was legitimate making this attack all the more effective. Further information can be found in the link located in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://abnormalsecurity.com/blog/compromised-partner-phishing/>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: NCAS Malware Analysis Report AR21-039A - SUNBURST
A Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency malware analysis report, AR21-039A, has been published through the National Cyber Awareness System. The report provides information on the SUNBURST malware, which is associated with the supply chain compromise of Solar Winds.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware




# Overview

 **From the Malware Analysis Report (AR21-039A)**  
 **MAR-10318845-1.v1 - SUNBURST**

This report provides detailed analysis of several malicious artifacts associated with a sophisticated supply chain compromise of SolarWinds Orion network management software, identified by the security company FireEye as SUNBURST.

After being delivered as part of certain SolarWinds updates, a trojanized version of the “solarwinds.orion.core.businesslayer.dll” containing SUNBURST malware is installed by a legitimate SolarWinds installer application. The modified dynamic-link library (DLL) contains an obfuscated backdoor that allows a remote operator to execute various functions on the compromised system, as well as deploy additional payloads and exfiltrate data. The embedded SUNBURST code encrypts its outbound communications to the remote operator using XOR encryption and modified Base64 encoding. To maintain a low profile, the SUNBURST code will not run if it detects certain security software running on the target system.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ncas/analysis-reports/ar21-039a>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Exploit Kits Targeting of Chrome
The developers of the Magnitude and Underminer exploit kits created exploit chains targeting Google Chrome, according to a report from Avast.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Exploit Kits Targeting of Chrome
The developers of the Magnitude and Underminer exploit kits created exploit chains targeting Google Chrome, according to a report from Avast.

# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Exploit Kits.
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Magnitude, and Underminer.
  *  **Associated Payloads:** Various.
  *  **Targets:** Users of Google Chrome.
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Various vulnerabilities in Google Chrome.
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Unspecified.
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

Exploit kits, in terms of web browsers they exploit, have typically focused on Internet Explorer. Avast discovered that the developers of the Magnitude kit were testing exploits targeting Google Chrome. A month later, Avast observed the Underminer kit developers following suit. Both sets of developers were targeting the vulnerabilities CVE-2021-21224 and CVE-2021-31956 while the Underminer developers also targeted CVE-2019-0808, CVE-2020-1020, CVE-2020-1054, and CVE-2021-21224. The Magnitude developers appear to have discontinued the use of Chrome exploits while Underminer has continued though Avast notes that only around twenty percent of Underminer exploit attempts target Chrome. Considering Chrome appears to have sixty percent or more of the browser market share, this is a relatively low number. Avast notes that while both sets of developers were able to successfully create Chrome exploits, they were not very successful in the number of victims exploited. Perhaps one reason for this is the frequent and automatic updating of Chrome. Avast also notes that other Chromium-based browsers may be more at risk due to less frequent updating or the use of aged Chromium forks or vulnerabilities in their own codebases. Further information is available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/74057027/Exploit%20Kits%20Targeting%20of%20Chrome%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1642474148075&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Restrict Web-Based Content (M1021).



# References

  * <https://decoded.avast.io/janvojtesek/exploit-kits-vs-google-chrome/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1587 - Develop Capabilities  
T1587.001 - Malware  
T1588 - Obtain Capabilities  
T1588.001 - Malware  
T1608 - Stage Capabilities  
T1608.001 - Upload Malware  
T1608.004 - Drive-by Target  
T1608.005 - Link Target  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1204 - User Execution  
T1204.001 - Malicious Link

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Severe Vulnerabilities Patched in NextGen Gallery
Wordfence has published a blog post addressing two severe vulnerabilities in the NextGen Gallery WordPress plugin.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

Wordfence has published a blog addressing two severe vulnerabilities in the NextGen Gallery WordPress plugin. The first, CVE-2020-35942, is a cross-site request forgery (CSRF) vulnerability that could lead to XSS and RCE via file upload and local file inclusion. It has been rated with a CVSS score of 9.6. The second vulnerability, CVE-2020-35943, is also a CSRF issue. The impact, however, is the ability to upload an arbitrary image file. This file could potentially be used to carry a malicious payload though. In both cases, successful exploitation would require some degree of social engineering to get an admin to cluck a specially-crafted link. Imagely, the developer of the plugin, released a patched version (3.5.0) on December 17, 2020. For more information, see the Wordfence blog post in the Reference section.

# CVEs

  * CVE-2020-35942

  * CVE-2020-35943




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://www.wordfence.com/blog/2021/02/severe-vulnerabilities-patched-in-nextgen-gallery-affect-over-800000-wordpress-sites/>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Android  Credential Stealer - ERMAC
Cyble Research Labs has published a report on a new variant of the credential-stealing Android malware, ERMAC 2.0.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Android Malware
  *  **Targets:** Users of 467 various Android apps.
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** ERMAC
  *  **Initial Infection Vector: Fake app.**
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Credential stealing.
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

ERMAC is credential-stealing malware for Android devices. Version 1.0 of ERMAC was discovered in August 2021 with the actor behind ERMAC renting it out for $3,000 per month with version 2.0 becoming available around March 2022, now being rented for $5,000 per month. Cyble Research Labs have published a report of their analysis of ERMAC 2.0 which has increased the number of applications it targets from 378 in version 1.0 to 467 in 2.0. ERMAC is installed through third-party sites. In Cyble's analysis, it was found on fake sites impersonating a Polish food delivery platform. A link to download what is purported to be the legitimate site's app is provided. It has also been observed masquerading as browser updates. The fake app seeks 43 different permissions when installed. Once installed, it sends a list of the applications installed on the infected device to its C&C servers. The C&C server responds with a list of targeted applications and an encrypted HTML phishing page ERMAC will use to carry out overlay injections. When the victim interacts with a targeted application, the overlay injection is used to obtain the victim's credentials which are then sent to the C&C server. Further information is available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.

# Recommendations

  * For a list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.




# References

  * <https://blog.cyble.com/2022/05/25/ermac-back-in-action/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Tactics and Techniques:**

 **Initial Access - TA0027**  
T1444 - Masquerade as Legitimate Application  
T1476 - Deliver Malicious App via Other Means  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0030**  
T1406 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
  
 **Credential Access - TA0031**  
T1412 - Capture SMS Messages  
  
 **Discovery - TA0032**  
T1421 - System Network Connections Discovery  
  
 **Collection - TA0035**  
T1432 - Access Contact List  
T1507 - Network Information Discovery  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0037**  
T1571 - Non-Standard Port  
T1573 - Encrypted Channel

 **Mitigations:**

 **M1001:** Security Updates -Install security updates in response to discovered vulnerabilities. Purchase devices with a vendor and/or mobile carrier commitment to provide security updates in a prompt manner for a set period of time. Decommission devices that will no longer receive security updates. Limit or block access to enterprise resources from devices that have not installed recent security updates. On Android devices, access can be controlled based on each device's security patch level. On iOS devices, access can be controlled based on the iOS version.  
 **M1005:** Application Vetting - Enterprises can vet applications for exploitable vulnerabilities or unwanted (privacy-invasive or malicious) behaviors. Enterprises can inspect applications themselves or use a third-party service. Enterprises may impose policies to only allow pre-approved applications to be installed on their devices or may impose policies to block use of specific applications known to have issues. In Bring Your Own Device (BYOD) environments, enterprises may only be able to impose these policies over an enterprise-managed portion of the device. Application Vetting is not a complete mitigation. Techniques such as Evade Analysis Environment exist that can enable adversaries to bypass vetting.  
 **M1006:** Use Recent OS Version - New mobile operating system versions bring not only patches against discovered vulnerabilities but also often bring security architecture improvements that provide resilience against potential vulnerabilities or weaknesses that have not yet been discovered. They may also bring improvements that block use of observed adversary techniques.  
 **M1011:** User Guidance - Describes any guidance or training given to users to set particular configuration settings or avoid specific potentially risky behaviors.  
 **M1012:** Enterprise Policy - An enterprise mobility management (EMM), also known as mobile device management (MDM), system can be used to provision policies to mobile devices to control aspects of their allowed behavior.

Android  Credential Stealer - ERMAC
Cyble Research Labs has published a report on a new variant of the credential-stealing Android malware, ERMAC 2.0.

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Elephant Beetle Targets Latin America
A report from Sygnia's Incident Response team provides information on a financially motivated threat group they have named Elephant Beetle.
output:
# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Malware, Fraud.
  *  **Targets:** Organizations in Latin America involved in the commerce and finance sectors.
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** Unnamed.
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Compromise of public-facing applications.
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Persistence, discovery, lateral movement, carrying out fraudulent transactions.
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

For at least two years, the financially motivated threat group Elephant Beetle has been targeting organizations in Latin America that are involved in the commerce and finance sectors. According to a report from Sygnia's Incident Response Team, the group is highly proficient with Java-based attacks and typically exploits Java-based applications, such as webservers that have well-known, possibly unpatched vulnerabilities. The CVE numbered vulnerabilities cited in the Sygnia report as having been used to compromise systems are CVE-2017-1000486, CVE-2015-7450, and CVE-2010-5326. The initial payload deployed during the initial compromise is typically a webshell. Using the initial foothold, the group may spend up to three months conducting reconnaissance and moving laterally through the environment before carrying out any fraudulent transactions. If a transaction is discovered or blocked, the group will go silent for up to a few months before attempting another transaction using a different system. Further information is available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

Elephant Beetle Targets Latin America
A report from Sygnia's Incident Response team provides information on a financially motivated threat group they have named Elephant Beetle.
parsed_raw_data.xfe_report:
# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Malware, Fraud.
  *  **Targets:** Organizations in Latin America involved in the commerce and finance sectors.
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** Unnamed.
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Compromise of public-facing applications.
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Persistence, discovery, lateral movement, carrying out fraudulent transactions.
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

For at least two years, the financially motivated threat group Elephant Beetle has been targeting organizations in Latin America that are involved in the commerce and finance sectors. According to a report from Sygnia's Incident Response Team, the group is highly proficient with Java-based attacks and typically exploits Java-based applications, such as webservers that have well-known, possibly unpatched vulnerabilities. The CVE numbered vulnerabilities cited in the Sygnia report as having been used to compromise systems are CVE-2017-1000486, CVE-2015-7450, and CVE-2010-5326. The initial payload deployed during the initial compromise is typically a webshell. Using the initial foothold, the group may spend up to three months conducting reconnaissance and moving laterally through the environment before carrying out any fraudulent transactions. If a transaction is discovered or blocked, the group will go silent for up to a few months before attempting another transaction using a different system. Further information is available from the link in the Reference section below.

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Metamorfo/Mekotio Banking Trojan Uses AutoHotKey Scripting
The Cofense Phishing Defense Center (PDC) takes a brief look at Mekotio, also known as Metamorfo, a banking Trojan with Latin American origins that is now expanding its reach to victims across Europe. This trojan is one that makes use of a little known scripting language known as AutoHotKey (AHK).
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware, Phishing, Keylogger, Infostealer, Trojan




# Overview

 AHK was originally developed to create keyboard shortcuts (e.g. hot keys). Mekotio monitors browser activity looking for targeted banks. The targeted banks list include banks from Latin America, Spain, France, and Portugal. The malware captures the credentials with its keylogging capabilities. In addition to being a banking trojan, it can also monitor bitcoin addresses and replaces them with ones belonging to the attackers. Further information can be found in the article located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://cofense.com/blog/autohotkey-banking-trojan/>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: RansomEXX Linux Malware Analyzed
Researchers at Profero have detailed how the Linux version of the ransomware used by RansomEXX functions, and have developed their own decryption tool to avoid potential reinfection from the attacker's own tool. They have also provided guidance on what to do when the decryption fails due to file corruption.
output:
# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Ransomware
  *  **Associated Threat Actor:** RansomEXX
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** RansomEXX
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Unknown
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Unknown



# Overview

The Profero IR team has been witnessing a rise in ransomware attacks following the disappearance of the REvil ransomware operation. A large portion of these attacks are carried out by a group known as RansomEXX. This group is notable for using custom malware for each target, as well as leaking the identities of any victims who refuse to pay the ransom. The malware affects both Windows and Linux machines, and the Profero team has analyzed the Linux version and written their own decryption tool. The malware is hard to characterize, as each instance is specifically compiled for each attack. There is no persistence mechanism enabled and the tool runs as a standalone command-line tool executed on the victim's machine as part of a multi-stage attack. The ransomware works by recursively encrypting files in a given directory using symmetric encryption. The key used for this encryption is regenerated every 0.18 seconds to prevent a key from being taken from memory and used to decrypt all files. Each key is then appended to the relevant file and further encrypted with an RSA public key. Because of the risk of the decryption tool being malicious, the researchers have written their own decryption tool, which is able to extract the config file from the attacker-provided decryption tool and decrypt the files using this file. Further information can be found in the report located in the Reference section below.

# Recommendations

  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.

  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.

  * Where possible, only permit execution of signed scripts (M1045). 
  * Take and store data backups from end user systems and critical servers. Ensure backup and storage systems are hardened and kept separate from the corporate network to prevent compromise (M1053). 
  * Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking (M1038). 



# References

  * <https://medium.com/proferosec-osm/ransomexx-fixing-corrupted-ransom-8e379bcaf701>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1053 - Scheduled Task/Job  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
T1059.003 - Windows Command Shell  
T1059.004 - Unix Shell  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1070 - Indicator Removal on Host  
T1070.004 - File Deletion  
T1562 - Impair Defenses  
T1562.001 - Disable or Modify Tools  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1057 - Process Discovery  
T1082 - System Information Discovery  
T1083 - File and Directory Discovery  
T1518 - Software Discovery  
T1518.001 - Security Software Discovery  
  
 **Impact - TA0040**  
T1486 - Data Encrypted for Impact  
T1490 - Inhibit System Recovery

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Priority Threat Actors Using Mirai Code
Another threat group has taken to using Mirai source code in its actions against victims. Juniper has provided insight into this group and how it currently uses the source code.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware




# Overview

The Mirai botnet has become such an overused commodity in the world of cyber attacks that it seems as though every threat actor employs it in some form or fashion. A group known as "Priority" has taken the source code and repurposed it in its latest campaign. This particular threat actor has used several iterations of Mirai including DemonBot and the version of Mirai written by an actor named, "Scarface." Having been active since September 10, 2020 to the present, the activity curve has continued to rise. Attacking on ports 5500, 5501, 5502, 5050, and 60001, the group employs a simple GET request to leverage the MVPower DVR Shell Unauthenticated Command Execution, reported by Unit 42 as being part of the Omni Botnet variant. During most employments of Mirai, three to seven exploits are used. With Priority, the number of exploits employed is a singular with most of the targeting focusing on port 60001. Additionally, all attacks originate from a single IP address. A file downloaded contains a script with the IP address of the host machine containing the malware. Most files are packed with UPX while some are completely unpacked. These strings show this is a variant of Mirai. At first analysis, these strings contain "NeTiS and Thisity," as well as "FoReHeAd We BiG L33T Has." Future versions include significant references to "Priority." The group shows some sophistication in the understanding of code modification for its specific purposes. For more information, please see the analysis located in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://blogs.juniper.net/en-us/security/priority-threat-actors-adopt-mirai-source-code>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: APT37 Using Self Decoding to Inject RokRat
A malicious document examined by MalwareBytes Labs has shown the ability to use VBA self-decoding in order to inject RokRat into victim machines.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware




# Overview

A file with an embedded macro that uses a VBA self-decoding technique built in decodes itself in memory of Microsoft Office without actually writing the script to disk. After this step, a variant of RokRat is embedded into Notepad. Using new techniques for this APT has provided unique insight into the evolving TTPs of APT37. Previously, the APT has used Hangui Office documents as its targeting mechanism, which is commonly used in South Korea. First introduced in 2016, the self-decoding process uses a macro within a macro that is decoded and executed. The technique uses an IF/THEN series of instructions to decode and execute the payload. In order to check for the possibility of execution, the macro checks for bypass ability within VBOM. If an exception is triggered in the checks process, VBOM needs to be bypassed. This is the IF clause. If no exception exists, the ELSE clause kicks in and allows for dynamic macro execution. Once VBOM is bypassed, a mutex is created in the victim's machine. Speculation on this step centers around whether the victim is only infected once. A new application process is created and loaded in invisible mode. Deobfuscation is accomplished via a defined loop. This step provides the memory infiltration macro and makes a call to its main function. Within the infected notepad.exe is the payload download from an nefarious link which then links to a Google drive link. Anti-analysis techniques are employed, as with previous versions of the malware. Capturing screen shots, gathering system info, exfiltration, credential stealing, and file and directory management are the functions it performs once running. Further details can be found in the report located within the Reference section below. 

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://blog.malwarebytes.com/threat-analysis/2021/01/retrohunting-apt37-north-korean-apt-used-vba-self-decode-technique-to-inject-rokrat/>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Middle Eastern Oil and Gas Supply Chain Entities Targeted
An spear-phishing email campaign has been targeting entities in the Middle East involved in the oil and gas supply chain. According to a Zscaler report, the final payload is the information stealing Azorult malware.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware




# Overview

Zscaler has been tracking a campaign in which spear-phishing emails, purporting to be from the Abu Dhabi National Oil Company, were sent to a number of oil and gas supply chain companies and government entities in the Middle East. The campaign has been active since July 2020. The emails have a PDF attached that contains a link to an archive file hosted on a legitimate file sharing site. The archive file contains a .NET executable, which will kick off the multistage infection chain that results in the installation of the Azorult information stealing malware using the process hollowing technique. The third stage of the infection chain includes multiple checks for analysis or virtualized environments. Further information is available from the report linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.zscaler.com/blogs/security-research/targeted-attacks-oil-and-gas-supply-chain-industries-middle-east>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: New APT Targeting MENA
A new APT named FIREPLACE is targeting the Middle East and North Africa. Shells.Systems published a blog detailing the TTPs of this new group as well as its targeting profile.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Threat Group




# Overview

A new, possibly Iranian, APT named FIREPLACE has been seen targeting MENA using mostly off-the-shelf software and backdoors. Researchers observed the attackers using a modified, publicly available web shell called AspxSpy2014Final.aspx. This web shell is used after exploiting a web vulnerability within the web application. From there, attackers used tools such as Plink, Winrar, PsExec, and procdump for lateral movement. Persistence is gained through a VBS, Powershell, and C# developed back doors. This step is used to contact the C2 node. If the victim server is unable to contact the Internet, the attackers employ a new backdoor implanted in the OWA (Exchange web server) to hide. Typically, endpoint security does not monitor OWA directories. This provides attackers with a cover against detection. Backdoors, C2, data exfiltration, and SOCKS proxy use different servers. The attackers do not attempt to hide their tracks nor remove the tools used in the attack. Additionally, backdoors are not obfuscated. Despite this, attackers were able to remain in the target environment for an extended period of time. Because of similar tactics to APT34, there is speculation this group may be tied to Iran. For more information, see the Shells.System blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference
