instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Google's Project Zero In The Wild Series
Google's Project Zero has published part one of a six part series on vulnerabilities found in the wild by researchers.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Google's Project Zero In The Wild Series
Google's Project Zero has published part one of a six part series on vulnerabilities found in the wild by researchers.

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

In part one of a six part series, Google's Project Zero details some vulnerabilities found as part of a "make 0-day hard" goal. Part one focuses on the discovery of a watering hole attack in 2020. This attack, it is hypothesized, was carried out by a highly sophisticated threat actor. In the attack, two exploit servers were delivering exploit chains via this watering hole attack. One server was targeting Windows users and the other, Android users. Interestingly, both used Chrome exploits for remote code execution. Both used 0-day vulnerabilities. The Android exploit was known to the researchers. The researchers believe the actor had access to Android 0-days but discovered no new vulnerabilities. The researchers also discovered two sandbox escape exploits abusing three 0-day vulnerabilities within Windows. Another discovery was that of a privilege escalation kit composed of publicly known n-day exploits which can be employed against older versions of Android. Efficiency and flexibility are seemingly the order of the day for these exploit chains. In future parts of the series, the team will provide detailed analysis of the vulnerabilities, exploit techniques, deep dive into the bug class of the Chrome exploits, and an in-depth teardown of the post-exploitation code for Android. Parts two through six are linked within the Reference section below. All vulnerabilities discussed in this blog post series were patched as of April 2020.

# CVEs

  * A complete list of CVEs can be found here: [ CVEs.txt](/download/attachments/35720836/Google%27s%20Project%20Zero%20In%20The%20Wild%20Series%20CVEs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1611343213858&api=v2)  




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://googleprojectzero.blogspot.com/2021/01/introducing-in-wild-series.html>

  * <https://googleprojectzero.blogspot.com/p/rca.html>
  * <https://googleprojectzero.blogspot.com/2021/01/in-wild-series-chrome-infinity-bug.html>
  * <https://googleprojectzero.blogspot.com/2021/01/in-wild-series-chrome-exploits.html>
  * <https://googleprojectzero.blogspot.com/2021/01/in-wild-series-android-exploits.html>
  * <https://googleprojectzero.blogspot.com/2021/01/in-wild-series-android-post-exploitation.html>
  * <https://googleprojectzero.blogspot.com/2021/01/in-wild-series-windows-exploits.html>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Hancitor Downloader Still Installing Cobalt Strike
The DFIR Report has published an analysis of an intrusion which demonstrated that the Hancitor downloader continues to install Cobalt Strike.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Hancitor Downloader Still Installing Cobalt Strike
The DFIR Report has published an analysis of an intrusion which demonstrated that the Hancitor downloader continues to install Cobalt Strike.

# Threat Type

  * Malware




# Overview

The Hancitor downloader has been around since at least 2014 and is provided to threat actors through a Malware-as-a-Service operation. Over the years, Hancitor has been used to install a range of malware through either spam or phishing emails that had weaponized documents attached or links within the emails. Hancitor has, for some time, been installing Cobalt Strike to facilitate lateral movement and has become involved in ransomware attacks. The DFIR Report has published an analysis of a recent intrusion which demonstrated that the Hancitor downloader continues to install Cobalt Strike. Typically, the intrusion began with a malicious Word document which dropped the first stage Hancitor downloader DLL. The DLL was injected into multiple instances of svchost.exe which, in turn, injected a Cobalt Strike beacon into multiple instances of rundll32.exe. Attempts were made to download further malware, including Ficker Stealer, which is commonly installed by Hancitor. The attacker did manage to compromise another system on the network by using the SMB protocol to copy a batch script and DLL to the system. The batch file was then executed by a remote service and executed the Cobalt Strike shellcode embedded in the DLL. The attacker was discovered and evicted from the systems before their objective became clear. Further details are available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://thedfirreport.com/2021/06/28/hancitor-continues-to-push-cobalt-strike/>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: 'Lebanese Cedar' New Campaign
Lebanese Cedar APT has been operating since at least 2012 and has, recently, employed a new version of the "Explosive" V4 RAT or "Caterpillar" V2 WebShell. ClearSky has the latest on these developments in a new report.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware, APT




# Overview

Active since at least 2012 the APT Lebanese Cedar - also known as Volatile Cedar - has been engaging in campaigns using a low profile and maintaining an under the radar footprint. In conducting their latest research, ClearSky has found evidence of new versions of "Explosive"V4 RAT or "Caterpillar" V2 WebShell being used against targets. Researchers found at least 250 servers breached by the APT using known vulnerabilities such as CVE-2012-3152 and other 1-day vulnerabilities. Vulnerable Atlassian and Oracle servers were found to have been infiltrated. Target counties include: the U.S., U.K., Egypt, Jordan, Lebanon, Israel, and the Palestinian Authority. The countries have companies which have lost valuable information over a period of months and years. Check Point released a report stating the group is motivated by political and ideological interests, targeting individuals, companies, and institutions. In most of the research, "Caterpillar" WebShell was found in most instances, however, "Explosive" RAT was also found. At present, Lebanese Cedar is the only actor known to use this code. Further information can be found in the report PDF located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/39288977/%27Lebanese%20Cedar%27%20New%20Campaign%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1612296077085&api=v2)  




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Log4j Being Exploited By Threat Group AQUATIC PANDA
Crowdstrike has observed an attack where the attackers exploited Log4j for initial access before establishing persistence via a reverse shell. They have attributed this activity to the threat group AQUATIC PANDA by analyzing the attacker's infrastructure.
output:
# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Vulnerability
  *  **Targets:** Unknown
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** Unknown
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Exploitation of Log4j Vulnerability
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Installation of Reverse Shell, Internal Reconnaissance, Defense Impairment



# Overview

Crowdstrike has discovered evidence that the group known as AQUATIC PANDA is exploiting the recently disclosed Log4j vulnerability to gain access to victim systems. Crowdstrike threat hunters noticed multiple connections to a publicly accessible DNS logging service, which is an indicator that someone may be searching for vulnerabilities and using this service to confirm this. After this was seen, the attackers executed Linux commands in an attempt to execute an interactive shell and malicious tool retrieval from a hardcoded IP address. The attackers then attempted to assess the privilege levels and system details, whilst also attempting to stop any antivirus and EDR tools. The attackers retrieved PowerShell scripts and installed a reverse shell in the victim machine, and were also observed attempting credential harvesting by dumping the memory of the LSASS process. Further information can be found in the post located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/74056608/Log4j%20Being%20Exploited%20By%20Threat%20Group%20AQUATIC%20PANDA%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1641397221860&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior (M1040). 
  * Set PowerShell execution policy to execute only signed scripts (M1045).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).



# References

  * <https://www.crowdstrike.com/blog/overwatch-exposes-aquatic-panda-in-possession-of-log-4-shell-exploit-tools/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Reconnaissance - TA0043**  
T1595 - Active Scanning  
T1595.002 - Vulnerability Scanning  
  
 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
T1059.001 - PowerShell  
T1059.004 - Unix Shell  
  
 **Persistence - TA0003**  
T1574 - Hijack Execution Flow  
T1574.001 - DLL Search Order Hijacking  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1562 - Impair Defenses  
T1562.001 - Disable or Modify Tools  
  
 **Credential Access - TA0006**  
T1003 - OS Credential Dumping  
T1003.001 - LSASS Memory  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1007 - System Service Discovery  
T1087 - Account Discovery

# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Vulnerability
  *  **Targets:** Unknown
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** Unknown
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Exploitation of Log4j Vulnerability
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Installation of Reverse Shell, Internal Reconnaissance, Defense Impairment



# Overview

Crowdstrike has discovered evidence that the group known as AQUATIC PANDA is exploiting the recently disclosed Log4j vulnerability to gain access to victim systems. Crowdstrike threat hunters noticed multiple connections to a publicly accessible DNS logging service, which is an indicator that someone may be searching for vulnerabilities and using this service to confirm this. After this was seen, the attackers executed Linux commands in an attempt to execute an interactive shell and malicious tool retrieval from a hardcoded IP address. The attackers then attempted to assess the privilege levels and system details, whilst also attempting to stop any antivirus and EDR tools. The attackers retrieved PowerShell scripts and installed a reverse shell in the victim machine, and were also observed attempting credential harvesting by dumping the memory of the LSASS process. Further information can be found in the post located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/74056608/Log4j%20Being%20Exploited%20By%20Threat%20Group%20AQUATIC%20PANDA%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1641397221860&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior (M1040). 
  * Set PowerShell execution policy to execute only signed scripts (M1045).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).



# References

  * <https://www.crowdstrike.com/blog/overwatch-exposes-aquatic-panda-in-possession-of-log-4-shell-exploit-tools/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Reconnaissance - TA0043**  
T1595 - Active Scanning  
T1595.002 - Vulnerability Scanning  
  
 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
T1059.001 - PowerShell  
T1059.004 - Unix Shell  
  
 **Persistence - TA0003**  
T1574 - Hijack Execution Flow  
T1574.001 - DLL Search Order Hijacking  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1562 - Impair Defenses  
T1562.001 - Disable or Modify Tools  
  
 **Credential Access - TA0006**  
T1003 - OS Credential Dumping  
T1003.001 - LSASS Memory  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1007 - System Service Discovery  
T1087 - Account Discovery

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: IronNetInjector
A new loader in Turla's arsenal, dubbed IronNetInject, was analyzed by Palo Alto in a recent blog post.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Injector




# Overview

Palo Alto published a blog post analyzing , a new malware loading tool attributed to Turla.  is composed of IronPython scripts and an injector used to load a final payload. IronPython is an open-source project that allows Python code to use .NET framework APIs without compiling a .NET assembly. The IronPython script in this case executes the .NET injector. The injector and the malicious payloads are both Base64-encoded and Rijndael-encrypted. The injector is able to load either PE files or .NET assemblies into either its own process or a remote process. The main malware family being loaded by  samples identified by Palo Alto was ComRAT, however an RPC backdoor and unknown malware were also identified. The researchers were unable to determine the initial infection vector used to deliver this tool. For more information, see the Palo Alto blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/ironnetinjector/>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Hackers Scanning for Critical VMware Vulnerability
A critical arbitrary file upload vulnerability has been patched by VMware (CVE-2021-22005), with scanning activity for the vulnerability being detected within hours of the patch.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Hackers Scanning for Critical VMware Vulnerability
A critical arbitrary file upload vulnerability has been patched by VMware (CVE-2021-22005), with scanning activity for the vulnerability being detected within hours of the patch.

# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Vulnerability



# Overview

Threat intelligence company Bad Packets has reported that they are already seeing scanning for a new vulnerability (CVE-2021-22005) that affects VMware. It is reported that this scanning began just hours after a patch was released, and was detected using honeypot machines. It is thought that thousands of potentially vulnerable vCenter servers are reachable over the internet via port 443 and so could be exposed to attack. The vulnerability only requires the attacker to have network access to port 443, where they can upload a specially crafted file which would lead to remote code execution. This vulnerability already has a patch available, and VMware has released workarounds for users who are unable to patch immediately. At this time, there is no publicly available exploit, but VMWare has warned that it is only a matter of time before one becomes available and has encouraged urgency when patching this critical flaw. Further information can be found in the article located within the Reference section below.

# CVEs

  * A complete list of CVEs can be found here: [ CVEs.txt](/download/attachments/64129199/Hackers%20Scanning%20for%20Critical%20VMware%20Vulnerability%20CVEs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1633079290026&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.

  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.

  * Web Application Firewalls may be used to limit exposure of applications to prevent exploit traffic from reaching the application (M1050).
  * Segment externally facing servers and services from the rest of the network with a DMZ or on separate hosting infrastructure (M1030).
  * Regularly scan externally facing systems for vulnerabilities and establish procedures to rapidly patch systems when critical vulnerabilities are discovered through scanning and through public disclosure (M1051).



# References

  * <https://www.bleepingcomputer.com/news/security/hackers-are-scanning-for-vmware-cve-2021-22005-targets-patch-now/>
  * <https://kb.vmware.com/s/article/85717>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Reconnaissance - TA0043**  
T1595 - Active Scanning  
T1595.002 - Vulnerability Scanning  
  
 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application

Breach / Leak Notification: The CMA CGM Group, a transport and logistics company, has reported it is the victim of a malware attack. The attack has impacted peripheral servers. To prevent the spread of the malware, possibly ransomware, CMA CGM, shutdown external access to applications.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: CMA CGM Group Suffers Malware Attack
Breach / Leak Notification: The CMA CGM Group, a transport and logistics company, has reported it is the victim of a malware attack. The attack has impacted peripheral servers. To prevent the spread of the malware, possibly ransomware, CMA CGM, shutdown external access to applications.

# Threat Type

  * Breach/Leak 




# Overview

  
"The CMA CGM Group (excluding CEVA Logistics) is currently dealing with a cyber-attack impacting peripheral servers. As soon as the security breach was detected, external access to applications was interrupted to prevent the malware from spreading. Our teams are fully mobilized and access to our information systems is gradually resuming. The CMA CGM network remains available to the Group's customers for all booking and operation requests."

# Reference

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Scouts Victoria Hit with Data Breach
Breach/Leak Notification: Scouts Victoria in Australia was hit with a data breach in which vast amounts of personal data were accessed. ZDNet reports on the breach and the company's response.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Breach




# Overview

Scouts Victoria in Australia was hit with a data breach on September 24, 2020. The unauthorized access occurred through the company's email system via a phishing attack. The attack resulted in two staff email accounts and a shared file folder being compromised. Among the data compromised are names, email addresses, residential addresses, driver's licenses, Medicare information, tax file numbers, and signatures. This data could be potentially harmful to the victims affected as it introduces the possibility of identity theft or even personal attack. "The investigation found that correspondence relating to a number of individuals associated with Scouts Victoria is among the data potentially accessed by unauthorized third parties," a statement from a Scouts Victoria spokesperson said. More information can be found in the article located within the Reference section below.

# CVEs

  * N/A




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://www.zdnet.com/article/scouts-victoria-phished-for-data-treasure-trove-including-tfns-and-bank-account-history/>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Increased SideCopy Activity Targeting India
Cisco Talos is reporting an increase in activity by the SideCopy APT group. The target of the activity is Indian government personnel.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware




# Overview

The SideCopy APT group has been active since 2019 and has primarily targeted India. Cisco Talos is reporting an increase in SideCopy activity targeting Indian government personnel. While SideCopy's infection chain continues to start with emails containing a LNK file, the infection chain has become more convoluted with an increased number of stages and delivering a number of different payloads. Documents and LNK files used to lure victims are often presented as internal documents of the Indian Army. In some cases, the lures use a honeytrap technique, LNK files that display explicit images of women. The current infection chain is composed of the LNK file which leads to an HTA that in turn provides a loader DLL. The DLL loads another HTA leading to either a dropper or actual payload. The payloads, a variety of bespoke and commodity malware, includes CetaRAT, DetaRAT, ReverseRAT, MargulasRAT, Allakore, ActionRAT, Lilith RAT, EpicenterRAT, and Nodachi. Two keyloggers, Xeytan and Lavao, and a number of plugins, including browser credential stealers are also used. Further details are available from the report linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://blog.talosintelligence.com/2021/07/sidecopy.html>

  * <https://talosintelligence.com/resources/257>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: KryptoCibule Malware - Cryptominer and RAT
KryptoCibule is malware discovered by researchers from ESET that has the ability to mine cryptocurrency, hijack cryptocurrency transactions, and exfiltrate files from victim systems which are mainly related to cryptocurrency. It also has RAT functionality.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware, Cryptomining




# Overview

Researchers from ESET have discovered a piece of malware which they have named KryptoCibule. The malware appears to have first emerged in December 2018, but until now, was undocumented. The primary functions of the malware are related to cryptocurrency. It can mine currency, hijack cryptocurrency transactions, and exfiltrate files related to cryptocurrency, and provides RAT functionality. It uses XMRig to mine Monero, and kawpowminer to mine Ethereum. Other, legitimate applications are also installed by KryptoCibule, these include the Apache httpd server, Buru SFTP server, Tor, and the Transmission torrent client, which are either bundled with the installer or downloaded at runtime. KryptoCibule mainly targets users in the Czech Republic and Slovakia. It is distributed in torrent files that purport to be cracked or pirated games and software. The torrents deliver a ZIP file, inside which is an executable file that masquerades as a legitimate InstallShield application. A number of anti-analysis and anti-detection techniques are implemented in KryptoCibule and specifically checks for three anti-virus products, Avast, AVG, and ESET, all of which are headquartered in either the Czech Republic or Slovakia. Infected systems are used to seed the malicious torrents, and the BitTorrent protocol is used for downloading updates to KryptoCibule and installing additional applications. The Transmission client, transmission-daemon, is managed through RPC on port 9091 and used the hardcoded credentials "superman:krypton". The SFTP server is also used to download additional components, and additionally, run as an onion service using port 9187 for exfiltrating data. Persistence for the malware is achieved using a scheduled task. Further details are available from the ESET report linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.welivesecurity.com/2020/09/02/kryptocibule-multitasking-multicurrency-cryptostealer/>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: CISA ICS-CERT Advisories - September 08 2020
CISA has published nine ICS-CERT Advisories. Eight of the advisories deal with vulnerabilities in various Siemens products while the ninth applies to Wibu-Systems' CodeMeter.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

  


CISA has published nine ICS-CERT Advisories. Eight of the advisories deal with vulnerabilities in various Sieman's products while the ninth applies to Wibu-Systems' CodeMeter. See below for a summary of each advisory.

  
 **ICS Advisory ICSA-20-252-01 - Siemens SIMATIC RTLS Locating Manager**  
Potential Impact: Local privilege escalation.  
CVE-2020-10049 - CVSS v3 Base Score: 7.9 (AV:L/AC:L/PR:L/UI:R/S:C/C:H/I:H/A:N)  
CVE-2020-10050 - CVSS v3 Base Score: 8.4 (AV:L/AC:L/PR:L/UI:N/S:C/C:H/I:H/A:N)

 **CS Advisory ICSA-20-252-02 - Siemens SIMATIC S7-300 and S7-400 CPUs**

<https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ics/advisories/icsa-20-252-02>

<https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ics/advisories/icsa-20-252-04>

 **ICS Advisory ICSA-20-252-05 - Siemens Siveillance Video Client**  
Potential Impact: Disclosure of administrator credentials.  
CVE-2020-15785 - CVSS v3 Base Score: 5.3 (AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:L/I:N/A:N)  
<https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ics/advisories/icsa-20-252-05>

 **ICS Advisory ICSA-20-252-06 - Siemens SIMATIC HMI Products**  
Potential Impacts: Authentication bypass due to lack of restrictions.

<https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ics/advisories/icsa-20-252-06>

 **ICS Advisory ICSA-20-252-07 - Siemens Industrial Products**  
Potential Impacts: Local information disclosure.   
CVE-2020-0543 - CVSS v3 Base Score: 5.5 (AV:L/AC:L/PR:L/UI:N/S:U/C:H/I:N/A:N)  
<https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ics/advisories/icsa-20-252-07>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Sophisticated Android RAT Being Delivered in New Campaign
Cyble Researchers have discovered a new sophisticated Android RAT, which uses the names and icons of legitimate applications to remain hidden. Analysis of the code has been published in a new report.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Remote Access Trojan
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Unknown
  *  **Associated Payloads:** Unnamed Android RAT
  *  **Targets:** Android Users
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Masquerading As Legitimate Application **  
**
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Data theft, Surveillance



# Overview

Cyble researchers have come across a new RAT for Android devices with over 200 samples seen since March 2022. The malware uses the names and icons of legitimate applications to trick users into executing them. Upon installation, the malware requests 18 different permissions which are abuses to collect sensitive data from the device and control mobile features such as audio recording. Upon the first launch, the icon gets hidden from the menu and runs silently in the background. The malware then monitors the user's clipboard and steals any data found there, exfiltrating it to the C2 server. The malware also performs a number of data collection operations to collect device technical information, which is also exfiltrated. The RAT can receive commands from the C2 server, allowing it to capture audio, take pictures using the device camera, collect device location, and take screenshots. For more information, please see the link in the references section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * For a full list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.




# References

  * <https://blog.cyble.com/2022/05/26/new-malware-campaign-delivers-android-rat/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Initial Access - TA0027**  
T1444 - Masquerade as Legitimate Application  
T1476 - Deliver Malicious App via Other Means  
  
 **Execution - TA0041**  
T1575 - Native Code  
  
 **Collection - TA0035**  
T1412 - Capture SMS Messages  
T1414 - Capture Clipboard Data  
T1429 - Capture Audio  
T1430 - Location Tracking  
T1433 - Access Call Log  
T1512 - Capture Camera  
T1533 - Data from Local System  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0037**  
T1436 - Commonly Used Port  
  


#### Mitigations:

  
 **M1001:** Security Updates -Install security updates in response to discovered vulnerabilities. Purchase devices with a vendor and/or mobile carrier commitment to provide security updates in a prompt manner for a set period of time. Decommission devices that will no longer receive security updates. Limit or block access to enterprise resources from devices that have not installed recent security updates. On Android devices, access can be controlled based on each device's security patch level. On iOS devices, access can be controlled based on the iOS version.  
 **M1005:** Application Vetting - Enterprises can vet applications for exploitable vulnerabilities or unwanted (privacy-invasive or malicious) behaviors. Enterprises can inspect applications themselves or use a third-party service. Enterprises may impose policies to only allow pre-approved applications to be installed on their devices or may impose policies to block use of specific applications known to have issues. In Bring Your Own Device (BYOD) environments, enterprises may only be able to impose these policies over an enterprise-managed portion of the device. Application Vetting is not a complete mitigation. Techniques such as Evade Analysis Environment exist that can enable adversaries to bypass vetting.  
 **M1006:** Use Recent OS Version - New mobile operating system versions bring not only patches against discovered vulnerabilities but also often bring security architecture improvements that provide resilience against potential vulnerabilities or weaknesses that have not yet been discovered. They may also bring improvements that block use of observed adversary techniques.  
 **M1011:** User Guidance - Describes any guidance or training given to users to set particular configuration settings or avoid specific potentially risky behaviors.  
 **M1012:** Enterprise Policy - An enterprise mobility management (EMM), also known as mobile device management (MDM), system can be used to provision policies to mobile devices to control aspects of their allowed behavior.

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: DC Metro Police Hit With Ransomware Attack
About a week ago, the Infosecurity Group reported that Washington D.C.'s metro police department was hit by ransomware threat actors of Russian origins.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: DC Metro Police Hit With Ransomware Attack
About a week ago, the Infosecurity Group reported that Washington D.C.'s metro police department was hit by ransomware threat actors of Russian origins.

# Threat Type

  * Ransomware




# Overview

The Babuk group claimed to have information on confidential informants used by the district's police department. Metro police only acknowledged the breach but not whether or not they paid the ransom or even that there was an attack and that ransom was being sought. The information the group claimed to have included gang conflict information and a jail census. This information is extremely sensitive and could have deadly consequences should it be released. The Babuk group had given the department three days to pay the ransom or they would share the data with local gangs. The group did post screenshots of the stolen data on the dark web. This is not our first time hearing about the Babuk group. Previously the group had attempted to extort the NBA's Houston Rockets. That incident was described as attempting to disrupt operations using a ransomware attack. Reports on the attack indicate much of the damage was mitigated, although the group did claim to have more than 500GB of data. This group's non-discriminatory targeting shows they're looking for fast money, as most ransomware attackers are. Additionally, the group attacked Serco, the UK's Covid test and trace group. Further information on this group can be found in the Reference section below.

# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.infosecurity-magazine.com/news/ransomware-group-dc-cops-informant/>

  * <https://www.infosecurity-magazine.com/news/global-government-outsourcer-serco/>
  * <https://www.infosecurity-magazine.com/news/cyberattack-on-nba-team/>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Nibiru Ransomware and Decryptor
Focusing on their development of a decryptor, Cisco Talos researchers have published a brief overview of the Nibiru ransomware.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Nibiru Ransomware and Decryptor
Focusing on their development of a decryptor, Cisco Talos researchers have published a brief overview of the Nibiru ransomware.

# Threat Type

  * Ransomware




# Overview

Cisco Talos published a blog post providing an overview of the Nibiru ransomware and a decryptor they developed. Nibiru is a .NET ransomware family that operates similar to most ransomware, traversing directories to identify target files, encrypting them, and appending a custom extension (in this case .Nibiru). To encrypt the files, the Rijndael-256 encryption algorithm is used. Although this is a secure algorithm, this ransomware family made the mistake of hardcoding the string that is used for generating the key and IV values. With this string, "Nibiru," the researchers were able to create a decryption tool that uses the string to compute the required key and IV values and, in turn, use these values to decrypt files that were encrypted by the ransomware. Cisco has published this decryption tool on Github for open-source access. For more information, including a link to the decryptor, see the Cisco Talos blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.



# Reference

  * <https://blog.talosintelligence.com/2020/11/Nibiru-ransomware.html>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Confluence Vulnerability Being Exploited In-The-Wild
Fortinet researchers have been tracking scanning and exploitation activity for a vulnerability that affects Confluence instances - CVE-2021-26084. They have published a list of exploitation attempts they have observed, and described the steps different threat actors took to compromise their targets.
output:
# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Vulnerability
  *  **Targets:** Confluence Server
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** Mushtik, Setag
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Exploitation of Public-Facing Server
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Backdoor installation, C2 Communication



# Overview

Researchers at Fortinet have been tracking a new vulnerability affecting confluence instances. The vulnerability is being tracked as CVE-2021-26084 and enables threat actors to run arbitrary code on unpatched confluence servers and Data Center instances. Since the disclosure of this vulnerability, Fortinet has seen massive scanning across the internet, as well as POC, exploit code. Fortinet has observed several attack attempts using this vulnerability, including cryptojacking attacks, backdoor downloads, and fileless attacks leveraging PowerShell. It has also been seen in attacks spreading the Mushtik botnet. The exploit is used to download malware onto the hosts, and in one case, further reconnaissance tools are downloaded. In another attack, a PowerShell command was used to set up a reverse shell, allowing the attacked access to the machine. The patch has already been released, but public attacks are ongoing. Further information can be found in the article located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/68616634/Confluence%20Vulnerability%20Being%20Exploited%20In-The-Wild%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1635248121083&api=v2)



# CVEs

  * A complete list of CVEs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/68616634/Confluence%20Vulnerability%20Being%20Exploited%20In-The-Wild%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1635248121083&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Set PowerShell execution policy to execute only signed scripts (M1045).
  * When PowerShell is necessary, restrict PowerShell execution policy to administrators. Be aware that there are methods of bypassing the PowerShell execution policy, depending on environment configuration (M1026).



# References

  * <https://www.fortinet.com/blog/threat-research/recent-attack-uses-vulnerability-on-confluence-server>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
T1059.001 - PowerShell  
  
 **Credential Access - TA0006**  
T1003 - OS Credential Dumping  
T1110 - Brute Force  
T1552 - Unsecured Credentials  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1046 - Network Service Scanning  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
T1571 - Non-Standard Port

It has also been seen in attacks spreading the Mushtik botnet. The exploit is used to download malware onto the hosts, and in one case, further reconnaissance tools are downloaded. In another attack, a PowerShell command was used to set up a reverse shell, allowing the attacked access to the machine. The patch has already been released, but public attacks are ongoing. Further information can be found in the article located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/68616634/Confluence%20Vulnerability%20Being%20Exploited%20In-The-Wild%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1635248121083&api=v2)



# CVEs

  * A complete list of CVEs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/68616634/Confluence%20Vulnerability%20Being%20Exploited%20In-The-Wild%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1635248121083&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Set PowerShell execution policy to execute only signed scripts (M1045).
  * When PowerShell is necessary, restrict PowerShell execution policy to administrators. Be aware that there are methods of bypassing the PowerShell execution policy, depending on environment configuration (M1026).



# References

  * <https://www.fortinet.com/blog/threat-research/recent-attack-uses-vulnerability-on-confluence-server>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
T1059.001 - PowerShell  
  
 **Credential Access - TA0006**  
T1003 - OS Credential Dumping  
T1110 - Brute Force  
T1552 - Unsecured Credentials  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1046 - Network Service Scanning  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
T1571 - Non-Standard Port

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Ngioweb Botnet Targeting IoT Devices
A new version of the Ngioweb botnet malware was discovered and analyzed by Netlab 360 researchers. Their blog post details the changes observed in these newer samples.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware, Botnet




# Overview

Netlab 360 has published a blog post detailing changes to the Ngioweb botnet malware. This version, V2, provides the sample functionality as previous interactions, implementing a back-connect proxy on victim hosts and adding them to a pool. One of the most significant changes to the malware is that it now supports additional architectures and leverages CVEs targeting IoT devices, whereas before only x64 architectures were supported. Additionally, the authors have moved away from hardcoding the C2 address, DGA seed and count, and other configuration details and instead are storing it in an AES-encrypted configuration file. The researchers generated the list of possible C2 domains based on the DGA seed and count in order to proactively block them. For more information, see the Netlab blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.



# Reference

  * <https://blog.netlab.360.com/linux-ngioweb-v2-going-after-iot-devices-en/>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: South Eastern Asian Government Institutions Targeted By Chinese APT Group
Bitdefender has published a whitepaper on their monitoring of a Chinese APT group that has been targeting South Eastern Asian government institutions since late 2018.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware, APT, Backdoor



# Overview

In a recently published whitepaper, Bitdefender dissects the antics of a Chinese APT group's attacks on South Eastern Asian Government institutions. The paper indicates that these attacks have been going on since at least late 2018. Although proof was not found, Bitdefender suspects that social engineering via spam may be the source of infection. Chinoxy backdoor is first loaded and gains persistence on the infected system. Chinoxy then deploys additional modules, including in some cases, an open source Chinese RAT called PcShare. Lateral movement was also observed to some extent through the uses of credentials. How the credentials were obtained is unknown. System information is gathered through the use of a number of Windows command line tools such as tasklist.exe, ipconfig.exe, among others. Data gathered is sent back to the command and control servers on a daily basis. For a detailed timeline and tool description, please refer to the link in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.bitdefender.com/files/News/CaseStudies/study/379/Bitdefender-Whitepaper-Chinese-APT.pdf>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Recent Investigation of FinSpy Spyware RAT by Kaspersky
Kaspersky has been tracking deployments of FinSpy, a controversial Spyware RAT, marketed through law enforcement channels, since 2011. Kaspersky conducted a comprehensive investigation in several recent updates introduced into the spyware, which took eight months to complete, and first shared their results at the Security Analyst Summit (SAS) 2021.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Spyware RAT
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Unspecified
  *  **Associated Payloads:** FinSpy
  *  **Targets:** Unspecified
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Trojanized application installers, email attachments
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Records user activity and uploads to server
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

Detection of FinSpy, also known as FinFisher or Wingbird, has dropped since 2018 for Windows. In the middle of 2019, Kaspersky began investigating further after discovering a host serving backdoored FinSpy installers. The eight month investigation resulted in discovering new methods used by the spyware, particularly in the levels of obfuscation used to avoid detection and analysis. The installers found were trojanized application installers for popular software packages. Prior to the trojan being installed, there are layers of software run that will vet the environment to be safe from further detection before downloading the rest of the modules. Newer machines that are capable of using UEFI will have the windows boot manager replaced with a malicious one. Older machines that don't support UEFI can be infected through the MBR. For further details on FinSpy used on Windows, MacOS, and Linux, see the article located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [RecentInvestigationofFinSpySpywareRATbyKaspersky-IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/64129315/RecentInvestigationofFinSpySpywareRATbyKaspersky-IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1633305778146&api=v2)

I have encountered the following information: Some Sam's Club Customer Accounts Breached Through Credential Stuffing
Breach / Leak Notification: A media report notes that over the last two weeks, some Sam's Club customers have received password reset emails and security notifications due to their accounts having been compromised through credential stuffing attacks.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Breach/Leak 




# Overview

  
"In emails sent out to Sam's Club members, and seen by BleepingComputer, the company is alerting members that an unauthorized party may have gained access to their accounts. This activity, detected by Sam's Club in September, did not stem from a data breach. According to the company, it was likely a result of the attackers already knowing the user's credentials—for example, via credential stuffing, data breaches, or phishing."

# Reference

  * <https://www.bleepingcomputer.com/news/security/sams-club-customer-accounts-hacked-in-credential-stuffing-attacks/>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Xen Advisory - XSA-355
Xen has published an advisory, XSA-355, addressing a vulnerability that could allow an attacker to cause denial of service condition and possibly access data or elevate privileges.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Xen Advisory - XSA-355
Xen has published an advisory, XSA-355, addressing a vulnerability that could allow an attacker to cause denial of service condition and possibly access data or elevate privileges.

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

Xen has published an advisory, XSA-355, addressing a vulnerability (CVE-2020-29040) that could allow an attacker to cause denial of service condition and possibly access data or elevate privileges. The issues were introduced by a prior patch, XSA-346 (CVE-2020-27671). The vulnerability can only be exploited on x86 HVM or PVH guests that have physical devices passed through to them. Further details are available from the links in the Reference section below.

# CVEs

  * CVE-2020-29040




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://xenbits.xen.org/xsa/advisory-355.html>

  * <https://cve.mitre.org/cgi-bin/cvename.cgi?name=CVE-2020-29040>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: ITG14 Fielding VBS Loader for Victim Reconnaissance
IBM X-Force Threat Intelligence reports on an ITG14 (aka FIN7) campaign delivering VBS loaders designed to install the Griffon backdoor.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Backdoor




# Overview

  
IBM X-Force Threat Intelligence analysts, since March 2020, have been tracking malicious campaigns using phishing emails to deploy Visual Basic Script (VBS) files that fingerprint infected machines and download and execute the Griffon JScript backdoor. The Griffon backdoor, in use since early 2018, is custom malware that has been attributed to ITG14 (aka FIN7). This group is an advanced cybercriminal group known for conducting illegal operations since 2016 against organizations within the retail, restaurant, banking, and hospitality sectors worldwide. These campaigns demonstrate ITG14’s continued efforts, despite several arrests since 2018, to attack commercial organizations for financial gain using new methods and malware. The full story, including indicators of compromise, is available to IBM X-Force IRIS Premier Threat Intelligence clients at the link below. 

# Indicators of Compromise

Indicators of compromise are available to IBM X-Force IRIS Premier Threat Intelligence clients at the link below.   


# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.




# Reference

  * Premier Threat Intelligence clients can read more and see the indicators at: <https://station.trustar.co/constellation/reports/91d2a1ed-6884-4b74-89bf-d42bcf8ecc6e>

  * To learn more about X-Force IRIS Premier Threat Intelligence, visit: <https://www.ibm.com/security/services/threat-intelligence>

IBM has published eight security bulletins that apply to QRadar SIEM. In total, seventeen vulnerabilities are addressed in the bulletins.

output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

 The potential impacts from successful exploitation of the vulnerabilities includes a remote attacker being able to cause denial of service conditions, obtain sensitive data (including session credentials), and execute arbitrary commands or code. The vulnerabilities are present in QRadar versions 7.3.0 to 7.3.3 Patch 7, and 7.4.0 to 7.4.2 Patch 2. We recommend updating to the latest fixed versions at the earliest opportunity. Further information is available from the links to the bulletins contained in the Reference section below.

# CVEs

  * A complete list of CVEs can be found here: [ CVEs.txt](/download/attachments/48038297/IBM%20QRadar%20SIEM%20Security%20Bulletins%20-%20May%202021%20CVEs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1620183908684&api=v2)

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary.

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: OpenSSL Security Advisory March 2021
A Security Advisory for OpenSSL that addresses two vulnerabilities has been published by the OpenSSL Software Foundation. Both of the vulnerabilities have been rated as being of High severity.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

Two vulnerabilities have been addressed in a new version of OpenSSL, version 1.1.1k. Both the vulnerabilities have been rated as High by the OpenSSL Software Foundation. One of the vulnerabilities (CVE-2021-3449) could allow a remote attacker to cause a denial of service condition by sending a maliciously crafted renegotiation ClientHello message from a client. All versions of OpenSSL 1.1.1 are affected by the vulnerability. The other vulnerability (CVE-2021-3450) could allow for a failure to reject certain invalid certificates. OpenSSL versions from 1.1.1h onwards are affected by this issue. Further information is available from the OpenSSL security advisory linked in the Reference section below.

# CVEs

  * CVE-2021-344, CVE-2021-3450




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://www.openssl.org/news/secadv/20210325.txt>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: FiveSys - A Rootkit With a Microsoft-issued Digital Signature
Bitdefender has discovered a rootkit they have named FiveSys that has a valid WHQL digital signature from Microsoft. It is typically being used to target Chinese gamers.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: FiveSys - A Rootkit With a Microsoft-issued Digital Signature
Bitdefender has discovered a rootkit they have named FiveSys that has a valid WHQL digital signature from Microsoft. It is typically being used to target Chinese gamers.

Summary
=======



Threat Details
==============

* **Malware Type: Rootkit**
* **Associated Threat Actors: Multiple, Chinese-based actors.**
* **Associated Payloads: FiveSys rootkit.**
* **Targets: Gamers located in China**
* **Initial Infection Vector: Rootkit bundled with cracked software.**
* **Post-Compromise Actions: Stealing game credentials.**
* **Additional TTPs: See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.**

Overview
========

Bitdefender has discovered a rootkit they have named FiveSys that has a valid WHQL digital signature from Microsoft. Its components were first seen in late 2020. FiveSys shares some similarities with malware named Undead which was documented a few years ago. Bitdefender notes that there are several Chinese threat actors involved in distributing FiveSys and they target several domestic Chinese games. So far, the spread of FiveSys appears to be limited to China. The primary function of FiveSys is to redirect HTTP/S traffic to a proxy server and achieves this by acting as a local Proxy Autoconfguration Script. To avoid generating browser warnings, a custom root certificate is installed. FiveSys attempts to block other malicious drivers by maintaining a blocklist of digital signatures used by other malware groups. FiveSys also protects modifications it makes to the system registry. While not mentioned in the Bitdefender report, comments in a media article suggest that FiveSys is distributed by bundling it with cracked software downloads. The signature used by FiveSys was revoked after Bitdefender notified Microsoft. Further information is available from the links in the Reference section below.

Indicators of Compromise
========================

Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.

Recommendations
===============

* Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
* Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
* Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
* Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
* Restrict Web-Based Content (M1021).

References
==========

* <https://www.bitdefender.com/files/News/CaseStudies/study/405/Bitdefender-DT-Whitepaper-Fivesys-creat5699-en-EN.pdf>
* <https://www.zdnet.com/article/hackers-somehow-got-their-rootkit-a-microsoft-issued-digital-signature/>
* <https://cyberintelmag.com/malware-viruses/fivesys-a-new-malicious-microsoft-signed-rootkit/>

MITRE ATT&CK Framework
======================

**Resource Development - TA0042**  
 T1583 - Acquire Infrastructure  
   T1583.001 - Domains  
   T1583.004 - Server  
 T1587 - Develop Capabilities  
   T1587.001 - Malware  
   T1587.003 - Digital Certificates  
 T1608 - Stage Capabilities  
   T1608.001 - Upload Malware  

**Execution - TA0002**  
 T1204 - User Execution  
   T1204.002 - Malicious File  

**Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
 T1014 - Rootkit  
 T1027 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
 T1055 - Process Injection  
 T1112 - Modify Registry  
 T1140 - Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information  
 T1216 - Signed Script Proxy Execution  
 T1222 - File and Directory Permissions Modification  
 T1562 - Impair Defenses  
   T1562.001 - Disable or Modify Tools  

**Discovery - TA0007**  
 T1016 - System Network Configuration Discovery  
 T1057 - Process Discovery  
 T1087 - Account Discovery  
   T1087.001 - Local Account  

**Collection - TA0009**  
 T1005 - Data from Local System

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: GhostEmperor - A New Sophisticated Chinese Threat Group
Researchers at Securelist have identified repeated behaviors when investigating attacks on Exchange servers. This activity is sophisticated and has been going on for at least a year, with many high profile targets being breached. The activity is not thought to be associated with any known threat groups, and so the group is being tracked under the name GhostEmperor.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: GhostEmperor - A New Sophisticated Chinese Threat Group
Researchers at Securelist have identified repeated behaviors when investigating attacks on Exchange servers. This activity is sophisticated and has been going on for at least a year, with many high profile targets being breached. The activity is not thought to be associated with any known threat groups, and so the group is being tracked under the name GhostEmperor.

# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Malware
  *  **Targets:** Government Entities, Telecommunication Companies
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** Demodex
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Exploitation of Public-Facing Servers
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Data Collection, Internal Reconnaissance **  
**



# Overview

Whilst investigating attacks on Exchange servers, researchers at Securelist discovered a repeated cluster of behavior. This behavior involved highly sophisticated methods and hitherto unseen malware, suggesting that this is a very capable threat group. The researchers have traced this activity back to July 2020. As this is a long-standing operation, with advanced capabilities and no known affinity to existing threat groups, the researchers have named this group GhostEmperor. This group has been observed using several initial infection vectors, but most commonly, they exploit public-facing servers to gain initial access. They have recently been observed exploiting the ProxyLogon vulnerability. Once initial access is gained, the group deploys a series of malware starting with a PowerShell dropper, which installs the second stage as a service and executes it. This second stage then initiates a third stage payload as an in-memory implant. The third stage is in charge of facilitating a communication channel with a C2 server, where traffic can be masqueraded under the guise of legitimate communications with a benign service. The final stage is injected into the winlogon.exe process by the previous stage, which provides the attacker remote control over the system. In addition to the final stage, the implant also deploys a Windows kernel-mode driver which serves as a rootkit with the sole purpose of concealing malware artifacts. Analysts have named this rootkit Demodex, as it has not been seen before. Once this malware has been established, the attackers perform internal reconnaissance using public tools such as NBTscan, as well as tools from the Sysinternals suite such as PsExec and ProcDump. GhostEmperor mainly targets government entities and telecommunication companies in southeast Asia, with multiple high-profile entities targeted in Malaysia, Thailand, Vietnam, and Indonesia. Researchers have characterized the group as a Chinese-speaking group, thanks to some evidence found in the custom malware. Further information can be found in the article located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/64129608/GhostEmperor%20-%20A%20New%20Sophisticated%20Chinese%20Threat%20Group%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1633523506641&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.

  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.

  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.

  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.

  * Some endpoint security solutions can be configured to block some types of process injection based on common sequences of behavior that occur during the injection process (M1040). 
  * Set PowerShell execution policy to execute only signed scripts (M1045).
  * When PowerShell is necessary, restrict PowerShell execution policy to administrators. Be aware that there are methods of bypassing the PowerShell execution policy, depending on environment configuration (M1026).



# References

  * <https://securelist.com/ghostemperor-from-proxylogon-to-kernel-mode/104407/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1587.001 - Malware  
  
 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
T1059.001 - PowerShell  
  
 **Persistence - TA0003**  
T1053 - Scheduled Task/Job  
T1543 - Create or Modify System Process  
  
 **Privilege Escalation - TA0004**  
T1055 - Process Injection  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1014 - Rootkit  
T1036 - Masquerading  
T1055 - Process Injection  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1007 - System Service Discovery  
T1046 - Network Service Scanning  
T1057 - Process Discovery  
  
 **Collection - TA0009**  
T1005 - Data from Local System  
T1056 - Input Capture  
T1113 - Screen Capture  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0010**  
T1041 - Exfiltration Over C2 Channel  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
T1071.001 - Web Protocols  
  
 **Impact - TA0040**  
T1565 - Data Manipulation

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: The Evolution of the FIN7 JSSLoader
Given the lack of historical reporting on the FIN7 JSSLoader infection chain, Morphisec has published a whitepaper describing the malware and its evolution.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware, RAT




# Overview

Morphisec has published a whitepaper analyzing the JSSLoader malware, its infection chain, and its evolution over the past year. JSSLoader is a simple .NET RAT leveraged by FIN7, a financially motivated cybercrime group tracked by IBM as ITG14. The group's campaigns typically begin with a phishing email luring visitors to click a malicious link. Hosted at the destination link is a VBScript or WSF file that the user is enticed to download. This script, in turn, executes a second-stage VBScript in memory. Finally, the JSSLoader payload is downloaded and executed on the system. The remote access can then be used for a variety of purposes. In the specific case described by Morphisec, it is used to execute DiceLoader, which is responsible for installing a Cobalt beacon. The researchers note a resemblance between the scripts used in this campaign to load JSSLoader and those used in QBot campaigns. In terms of the evolution of the malware, most of the functionality has remained the same since October 2019. Persistence is still established via a LNK file in the Startup folder, system information is exfiltrated to the C2 server, and the RAT can receive commands from that server. The main changes have been the addition of new commands. For more information, see Morphisec's whitepaper in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.morphisec.com/hubfs/eBooks_and_Whitepapers/FIN7%20JSSLOADER%20FINAL%20WEB.pdf>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Largely Undetected PRISM Variants Used in Multiple Campaigns
A report from AT&T Alien Labs provides information on variants of the open-source PRISM backdoor that have remained largely undetected for at least 3.5 years.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Backdoor
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Multiple unnamed actors
  *  **Associated Payloads:** PRISM, WaterDrop
  *  **Targets:** Various
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Unspecified
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Detection evasion, Data Exfiltration
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See Mitre ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

A report from AT&T Alien Labs describes the open-source PRISM backdoor as simplistic and its binaries as being easy to detect. Additionally, PRISM's C&C communications are HTTP-based and clearly identifiable. Despite this, AT&T Alien Labs has discovered a number of PRISM variants that have been used in multiple smaller campaigns, by multiple actors, over a period of more than 3.5 years, which have remained largely undetected. They have named one of the variants WaterDrop, named for the string "waterdropx" which is used in the C&C domain name, and the User-Agent in its HTTP communications with its C&C server. The domain was registered in 2017 and remained online in August 2021. Other PRISM variants were also observed using the WaterDrop C&C server. Further information is available from the report linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

Largely Undetected PRISM Variants Used in Multiple Campaigns
A report from AT&T Alien Labs provides information on variants of the open-source PRISM backdoor that have remained largely undetected for at least 3.5 years.
parsed_raw_data.xfe_report:
# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Backdoor
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Multiple unnamed actors
  *  **Associated Payloads:** PRISM, WaterDrop
  *  **Targets:** Various
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Unspecified
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Detection evasion, Data Exfiltration
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See Mitre ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

A report from AT&T Alien Labs describes the open-source PRISM backdoor as simplistic and its binaries as being easy to detect. Additionally, PRISM's C&C communications are HTTP-based and clearly identifiable. Despite this, AT&T Alien Labs has discovered a number of PRISM variants that have been used in multiple smaller campaigns, by multiple actors, over a period of more than 3.5 years, which have remained largely undetected. They have named one of the variants WaterDrop, named for the string "waterdropx" which is used in the C&C domain name, and the User-Agent in its HTTP communications with its C&C server. The domain was registered in 2017 and remained online in August 2021. Other PRISM variants were also observed using the WaterDrop C&C server. Further information is available from the report linked in the Reference section below.

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Bazar, Anchor and Cobalt Strike
An article from the DFIR Report looks at an intrusion where Bazar was used to drop Anchor. Both of the malwares are thought to be related to related to the group behind Trickbot.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Bazar, Anchor and Cobalt Strike
An article from the DFIR Report looks at an intrusion where Bazar was used to drop Anchor. Both of the malwares are thought to be related to related to the group behind Trickbot.

# Threat Type

  * Malware




# Overview

The DFIR Report observed an intrusion that began with a malicious Excel file. Bazar was installed, and then around an hour later, a Cobalt Strike beacon was installed followed by Anchor. Anchor and Bazar are thought to be related to related to the group behind Trickbot. The attackers then began moving laterally and within a short period of time, the domain controller and other servers had been compromised. In all the attacks, the attackers had access for five days before they were cut off. The final objective of the compromise is believed to have been domain-wide ransomware; however due to being cut off, the attackers did not achieve their goal. The report provides an analysis of the attack including a detailed timeline of the events. Further details can be obtained from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://thedfirreport.com/2021/03/08/bazar-drops-the-anchor/>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: FIN7 Recruiting Unsuspecting IT Specialists Via New Fake Company
The cybercriminal group known as FIN7 has been discovered by Gemini Advisory as using a fake company named “Bastion Secure”. Using this company they have posed as a legitimate cybersecurity software company in order to recruit IT specialists and pay them a lower wage in post-Soviet states than they would pay them if they were knowingly participating in the cybercriminal activity that FIN7 has them doing.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Details

  *  **Threat Type:** APT, Ransomware, Malware
  *  **Targets:** Unspecified
  *  **Ransomware Family:** Unknown, REvil, Ryuk
  *  **RaaS Operation:** Unspecified
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Spearphishing Attachment (T1566.001)
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Ransomware Deployment
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.
  *  **Leak Site:** N/A



# Overview

Gemini Advisory, a Recorded Future Company, has discovered that the cybercriminal group known as FIN7 has created a fake company named “Bastion Secure”. Using this company they have posed as a legitimate cybersecurity software company in order to recruit IT specialists and pay them a lower wage in post-Soviet states than they would pay them if they were knowingly participating in the cybercriminal activity that FIN7 has them doing. A Gemini source who was offered a position as an IT specialist at Bastion Secure Ltd was able to analyze the tools provided by Bastion Secure and found they are components of the post-exploitation toolkits Carbanak and Lizar/Tirion, both having been previously attributed to the FIN7 group. Further information is available from the links in the Reference section below.

# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques and phishing emails (M1017).
  * Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking (M1038). 
  * Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing (M1045). 
  * Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior (M1040). 



# References

  * <https://geminiadvisory.io/fin7-ransomware-bastion-secure/>
