instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Zero Day Vulnerability  In FatPipe MPVPN Gives Root Access
FBI forensic research revealed the exploitation of a 0-day vulnerability in the FatPipe MPVPN device software allowing attackers to gain root access to the victim's system.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Vulnerability
  *  **Targets:** FatPipe MPVPN software
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Exploitation of External Server
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Unknown



# Overview

FBI forensic research revealed the exploitation of a 0-day vulnerability in the FatPipe MPVPN device software dating back to at least May 2021. The vulnerability allows APT actors to obtain access to an unrestricted file upload capability, allowing them to install a webshell for exploitation activity with root access. For the actors, abusing this vulnerability allowed them to use the system as a springboard into other infrastructure. This vulnerability does not yet have a CVE number but is being tracked as Pipe Security Advisory number FPSA006. Before the latest version releases 10.1.2r60p93 and 10.2.2r44p1, the vulnerability affects all FatPipe WARP, MPVPN, and IPVPN device software. Further details are available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Set execution policy to execute only signed scripts (M1045).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).



# References

  * <https://www.ic3.gov/Media/News/2021/211117-2.pdf>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1587 - Develop Capabilities  
T1587.003 - Digital Certificates  
T1587.004 - Exploits  
  
 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Web Skimming Attacks Using Google Tag Manager
Malicious code injected into compromised eCommerce sites often tries to hide under the guise of legitimate services. Avast published a blog post analyzing one such case where Google Tag Manager was abused for web skimming.
output:
# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Skimmer
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Unknown
  *  **Associated Payloads:** Web skimming code
  *  **Targets:** eCommerce customers
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Exploitation of eCommerce platform vulnerabilities
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Data theft



# Overview

Avast published a blog post analyzing a web skimming campaign that abuses Google Tag Manager to inject malicious code. Google Tag Manager provides a method of loading custom code. After a eCommerce site is compromised, often via CMS vulnerabilities, the attackers inject the Google Tag Manager reference into the site's checkout pages. Google Tag Manager, in turn, loads custom code into the page. In this case, the JavaScript code is responsible for rendering a fake payment form onto the legitimate checkout page. Any data entered into this form is base64-encoded and exfiltrated via WebSockets back to attacker. Avast observed two websites targeted by this threat actor, one in Argentina and one in Saudi Arabia. For more information, see the Avast blog post in the References section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/74057921/Web%20Skimming%20Attacks%20Using%20Google%20Tag%20Manager%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1643659398403&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Restrict Web-Based Content (M1021).



# References

  * <https://decoded.avast.io/pavlinakopecka/web-skimming-attacks-using-google-tag-manager/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1584 - Compromise Infrastructure  
T1584.001 - Domains  
T1608 - Stage Capabilities  
T1608.001 - Upload Malware  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
T1059.007 - JavaScript  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1027 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
T1036 - Masquerading  
  
 **Collection - TA0009**  
T1056 - Input Capture  
T1056.003 - Web Portal Capture  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0010**  
T1041 - Exfiltration Over C2 Channel  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
T1071.001 - Web Protocols  
T1132 - Data Encoding  
T1132.001 - Standard Encoding

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: QNAP Security Advisories - December 12th, 2020
QNAP published five security advisories addressing eight vulnerabilities affecting QNAP NAS devices.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview



QSA-20-12 and QSA-20-16 address cross-site scripting and command injection vulnerabilities in QTS and QuTS hero. If successfully exploited, remote attackers may be able to execute arbitrary code on vulnerable devices.

QSA-20-13, QSA-20-14, and QSA-20-15 address cross-site scripting vulnerabilities in Music Station, Multimedia Console, and Photo Station, respectively. If successfully exploited, remote attackers may be able to execute arbitrary code on vulnerable devices.

QNAP has issued updates that patch these vulnerabilities. We recommend reviewing the advisories in the Reference section for patches and mitigation advice.

# CVEs

  * A complete list of CVEs can be found here: [ CVEs.txt](/download/attachments/35717954/QNAP%20Security%20Advisories%20-%20December%2012th%2C%202020%20CVEs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1607532100903&api=v2)




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary.

QSA-20-12 and QSA-20-16 address cross-site scripting and command injection vulnerabilities in QTS and QuTS hero. If successfully exploited, remote attackers may be able to execute arbitrary code on vulnerable devices.

QSA-20-13, QSA-20-14, and QSA-20-15 address cross-site scripting vulnerabilities in Music Station, Multimedia Console, and Photo Station, respectively. If successfully exploited, remote attackers may be able to execute arbitrary code on vulnerable devices.

QNAP has issued updates that patch these vulnerabilities. We recommend reviewing the advisories in the Reference section for patches and mitigation advice.

# CVEs

  * A complete list of CVEs can be found here: [ CVEs.txt](/download/attachments/35717954/QNAP%20Security%20Advisories%20-%20December%2012th%2C%202020%20CVEs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1607532100903&api=v2)




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://www.bleepingcomputer.com/news/security/qnap-patches-qts-vulnerabilities-allowing-nas-device-takeover/>

  * <https://www.qnap.com/en/security-advisory/qsa-20-16>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Chinese APT Group Cicada Conducting Sustained Espionage Campaign
Symantec researchers have been tracking the activity of the Chinese APT group Cicada. They have been attacking multiple organizations around the world, which is broadening the scope from the initial targets of Japanese-linked companies. Details have been published in a report.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Chinese APT Group Cicada Conducting Sustained Espionage Campaign
Symantec researchers have been tracking the activity of the Chinese APT group Cicada. They have been attacking multiple organizations around the world, which is broadening the scope from the initial targets of Japanese-linked companies. Details have been published in a report.

# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Cyber-Espionage
  *  **Associated Threat Groups:** Cicada
  *  **Targets:** Governmental and NGOs across many countries
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** Sodamaster (S0627), Mimikatz
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Exploitation of exchange server
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Unknown



# Overview

Cicada, also known as APT10, has been linked to espionage operations dating back to 2009. Symantec has discovered a new campaign starting in mid-2021 targeting a much broader scope than the initial activity which targeted Japanese-linked companies. The new campaign targets a wide range of Government and non-governmental organizations in multiple countries. In a number of instances, initial access was gained on Microsoft Exchange servers, hinting that there may have been a zero-day vulnerability used in the attacks on Exchange servers. Once access was gained, the group used a custom loader and a backdoor called Sodamaster. This malware is believed to be used exclusively by Cicada, which allows for attribution. It is a fileless malware that can evade detection and collect system information, as well as download more malware. It can also obfuscate and encrypt C2 traffic. For more information, please see the link in the reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * For a list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.



# References

  * <https://symantec-enterprise-blogs.security.com/blogs/threat-intelligence/cicada-apt10-china-ngo-government-attacks>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Tactics and Techniques:**

 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1106 - Native API  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1027 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
T1497 - Virtualization/Sandbox Evasion  
T1497.001 - System Checks  
T1497.003 - Time Based Evasion  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1012 - Query Registry  
T1033 - System Owner/User Discovery  
T1057 - Process Discovery  
T1082 - System Information Discovery  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1105 - Ingress Tool Transfer  
T1573 - Encrypted Channel  
T1573.001 - Symmetric Cryptography  
T1573.002 - Asymmetric Cryptography  
  


 **Mitigations:**

 **M1016:** Vulnerability Scanning - Vulnerability scanning is used to find potentially exploitable software vulnerabilities to remediate them.  
 **M1020:** SSL/TLS Inspection - Break and inspect SSL/TLS sessions to look at encrypted web traffic for adversary activity.  
 **M1026:** Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.  
 **M1030:** Network Segmentation - Architect sections of the network to isolate critical systems, functions, or resources. Use physical and logical segmentation to prevent access to potentially sensitive systems and information. Use a DMZ to contain any internet-facing services that should not be exposed from the internal network. Configure separate virtual private cloud (VPC) instances to isolate critical cloud systems.  
 **M1031:** Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  
 **M1038:** Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
 **M1040:** Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
 **M1048:** Application Isolation and Sandboxing - Restrict execution of code to a virtual environment on or in transit to an endpoint system.  
 **M1049:** Antivirus/Antimalware - Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software.  
 **M1050:** Exploit Protection - Use capabilities to detect and block conditions that may lead to or be indicative of a software exploit occurring.  
 **M1051:** Update Software - Perform regular software updates to mitigate exploitation risk.

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: BlackTech Employing Flagpro in Campaign
A campaign using a new malware dubbed Flagpro and employed by BlackTech is targeting some Japanese companies and has been observed by NTTSecurity.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: BlackTech Employing Flagpro in Campaign
A campaign using a new malware dubbed Flagpro and employed by BlackTech is targeting some Japanese companies and has been observed by NTTSecurity.

# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Downloader, Dropper/Loader, Exfiltration
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** BlackTech
  *  **Associated Payloads:**
  *  **Targets:** Japanese Defense, Media, Communications
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Spearphishing Email Attachment
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Download and execute tools, execute OS commands, collect authentication information



# Overview

Since at least October 2020, NTTSecurity has observed a campaign by threat actor BlackTech using a malware dubbed Flagpro targeting various Japanese businesses. Using a phishing email as the delivery mechanism, the malware is used during the initial stages of the attack. During this phase, a second stage malware is downloaded and executed. Attached to the email is a password-protected archive file containing an XLSM file. The password is in the phishing email. The XLSM file is tailored to each victim, lending plausibility to the attacker researching its victims. If macros are enabled in the XLSM file, malware is dropped and an EXE file is written to the Startup directory. This file is the Flagpro malware. Communication takes place with a C2 server and commands are sent from the C2 to Flagpro. Checks are made for furtherance of malicious activity based on the environment being attacked. Should the environment meet the standard for additional manipulation, more malware is downloaded and executed. The main functions of the malware are to download and execute a tool, execute OS commands and report results, and to collect and send Windows authentication information. Further technical details can be found in the analysis located within the Reference section below. 

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/74056637/BlackTech%20Employing%20Flagpro%20in%20Campaign%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1641411311047&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction. (M1017)
  * Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc. (M1021)
  * Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts. (M1022)
  * Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries. (M1031)
  * Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking. (M1038)
  * Protect sensitive information with strong encryption. (M1041)
  * Use capabilities to prevent successful credential access by adversaries; including blocking forms of credential dumping. (M1043)
  * Use A/V and IDS/IPS signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software. (M1049)
  * Use a data loss prevention (DLP) strategy to categorize sensitive data, identify data formats indicative of personal identifiable information (PII), and restrict exfiltration of sensitive data. (M1057)



# References

  * <https://insight-jp.nttsecurity.com/post/102hf3q/flagpro-the-new-malware-used-by-blacktech>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

  
 **Reconnaissance - TA0043**  
T1589 - Gather Victim Identity Information  
T1591 - Gather Victim Org Information  
T1592 - Gather Victim Host Information  
T1592.002 - Software  
  
 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1566 - Phishing  
T1566.001 - Spearphishing Attachment  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1053 - Scheduled Task/Job  
T1053.002 - At (Windows)  
T1072 - Software Deployment Tools  
T1204 - User Execution  
T1204.002 - Malicious File  
  
 **Persistence - TA0003**  
T1037 - Boot or Logon Initialization Scripts  
T1037.005 - Startup Items  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1027 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
  
 **Credential Access - TA0006**  
T1003 - OS Credential Dumping  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1033 - System Owner/User Discovery  
  
 **Collection - TA0009**  
T1005 - Data from Local System  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0010**  
T1041 - Exfiltration Over C2 Channel

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Vidar Infostealer Spread Via Malicious Windows 11 ISO Files
ZScaler has published a report detailing a new campaign they have been tracking. This campaign uses malicious Windows 11 ISO files to infect the victim with the Vidar Infostealer.
output:
# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Infostealer
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Unknown
  *  **Associated Payloads:** Vidar
  *  **Targets:** Windows Users
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Phishing Site
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Data Theft



# Overview

ZScaler ThreatLabz has discovered a new campaign spreading the Vidar infostealer. The researchers found newly registered domains that were spoofing the official Microsoft Windows 11 OS download portal. From these sites, the victims could download fake Windows 11 ISO files which are very large, and so can evade network security products. These files are signed with an expired certificate that is likely stolen during the 2019 AVAST compromise. The Vidar samples seen in this campaign are all packed with Themida and are very large in size, as they have been artificially inflated with padding bytes. The malware uses hardcoded URLs as dead drop resolvers, which directs them to various social media accounts on Telegram and Mastadon that host legitimate binaries for credential and data harvesting. For more information, please see the link in the reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * For a full list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.




# References

  * <https://www.zscaler.com/blogs/security-research/vidar-distributed-through-backdoored-windows-11-downloads-and-abusing>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1583.001 - Domains  
T1585.001 - Social Media Accounts  
  
 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1566 - Phishing  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1204.002 - Malicious File  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1027.001 - Binary Padding  
T1027.002 - Software Packing  
T1036 - Masquerading  
  
 **Credential Access - TA0006**  
T1003 - OS Credential Dumping  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1082 - System Information Discovery  
  
 **Collection - TA0009**  
T1005 - Data from Local System  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0010**  
T1041 - Exfiltration Over C2 Channel  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1102 - Web Service  
T1102.001 - Dead Drop Resolver  
  


#### Mitigations:

  
 **M1015:** Active Directory Configuration - Configure Active Directory to prevent use of certain techniques; use SID Filtering, etc.  
 **M1017:** User Training - Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction.  
 **M1021:** Restrict Web-Based Content - Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc.  
 **M1022:** Restrict File and Directory Permissions - Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.  
 **M1025:** Privileged Process Integrity - Protect processes with high privileges that can be used to interact with critical system components through use of protected process light, anti-process injection defenses, or other process integrity enforcement measures.  
 **M1026:** Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.  
 **M1027:** Password Policies - Set and enforce secure password policies for accounts.  
 **M1028:** Operating System Configuration - Make configuration changes related to the operating system or a common feature of the operating system that result in system hardening against techniques.  
 **M1031:** Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  
 **M1038:** Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
 **M1040:** Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
 **M1041:** Encrypt Sensitive Information - Protect sensitive information with strong encryption.  
 **M1043:** Credential Access Protection - Use capabilities to prevent successful credential access by adversaries; including blocking forms of credential dumping.  
 **M1045:** Code Signing - Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.  
 **M1047:** Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
 **M1049:** Antivirus/Antimalware - Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software.  
 **M1054:** Software Configuration - Implement configuration changes to software (other than the operating system) to mitigate security risks associated to how the software operates.  
 **M1056:** Pre-compromise - This category is used for any applicable mitigation activities that apply to techniques occurring before an adversary gains Initial Access, such as Reconnaissance and Resource Development techniques.  
 **M1057:** Data Loss Prevention - Use a data loss prevention (DLP) strategy to categorize sensitive data, identify data formats indicative of personal identifiable information (PII), and restrict exfiltration of sensitive data.

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Server Side Data Exfiltration via Telegram API
In recent months, Sucuri has observed skimming code that uses the Telegram API to exfiltrate stolen data.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Server Side Data Exfiltration via Telegram API
In recent months, Sucuri has observed skimming code that uses the Telegram API to exfiltrate stolen data.

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Skimmer




# Overview

Sucuri published a blog post analyzing skimming code that uses the Telegram API to exfiltrate stolen data. The code was seen injected into the wp-login.php page of a compromised WordPress site. This means that any time a user logs into the WordPress side, the attacker is able to capture login credentials. These credentials are then formatted and URL encoded. The URL encoded data is sent as part of a request to Telegram's API. Analysis of the JSON response reveals that the request is being sent to a Telegram bot that has received messages in the past. Based on commented out code, the attacker behind this skimming code previously wrote the stolen data to a local file. This method provides the stolen data in real time without the need to visit the server and check the file. For more information, see the Sucuri blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.



# Reference

  * <https://blog.sucuri.net/2021/03/server-side-data-exfiltration-via-telegram-api.html>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: KAMACITE ICS Threat Activity Group
KAMACITE is an ICS threat activity group that obtains access to victim networks and enables other actors to carry out attacks. Dragos revealed their findings on this threat group in a recent blog post.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: KAMACITE ICS Threat Activity Group
KAMACITE is an ICS threat activity group that obtains access to victim networks and enables other actors to carry out attacks. Dragos revealed their findings on this threat group in a recent blog post.

# Threat Type

  * Malware




# Overview

Dragos has published a blog post detailing a newly identified threat activity group targeting electric utilities, oil and gas operations, and various manufacturing organizations since as early as 2014. The group has been tied to the BLACKENERGY2 campaign and both the 2015 and 2016 Ukraine power disruption attacks. They are behind custom malware families, such as BLACKENERGY2, BLACKENERGY3, GREYENERGY, and EXARAMEL. Their initial access vector is through the use of phishing lures associated with Ukrainian politics, finances, or technical conferences. Once on a network, credentials are captured and built-in system tools or administration frameworks are used for remote access. The C2 infrastructure for the malware uses direct IP address communication instead of registered domains. It is also composed of compromised third-party infrastructure in most cases. With the access obtained, KAMACITE typically acts as a Stage 2 ICS access enabling entity, meaning they hand over control of these victim networks for another group to carry out ICS-specific activities, such as disruption attempts. One such example is when the group handed over control to ELECTRUM for the CRASHOVERRIDE campaign. For more information, see the Dragos blog post in the Reference section.

# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.dragos.com/blog/industry-news/new-ics-threat-activity-group-kamacite/>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Brazilian Bank Users Targeted in Phishing Operation
Clients of Banco Itau Empresas who use Itaú Internet Banking are being targeted by a phishing operation that is set up to take advantage of the new PIX payment method.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Phishing




# Overview

PIX is a payment method implemented by Brazil's Central Bank that provides several benefits over the old systems, such as faster completion of transactions. A phishing operation is targeting business customers of Banco Itau Empresas online banking service, which uses an app. The lure is a fake diagnostic page for the app that informs the user their version of the app is out of date and provides a link to update the app. If the link is clicked, the victim is presented with a fake login page. The login page uses PHP sessions and AJAX calls to provide the attacker real time control over the responses and requests sent to the victim. While a victim awaits responses, the bank's legitimate loading GIF is presented to the victim. The aim of the attacker is to obtain the victim's credentials and QR code, which allows the attacker to then access and manipulate the victim's account. Further details, including a split screen animation showing the victim's screen and the attacker's dashboard, are available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * None provided.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://blog.sucuri.net/2021/01/real-time-phishing-kit-targets-brazilian-central-bank.html>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: New Threat Group - UNC3524
Mandiant has published a report that examines the TTPs of a newly discovered threat group they refer to as UNC3524.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Malware, Espionage.
  *  **Targets:** Employees involved in acquisitions, corporate development, mergers, IT security staff, or that deal with large corporate transactions.
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** QUIETEXIT
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Unknown
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Collection of emails.
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

UNC3524 is a newly discovered threat group that focuses on collecting the emails of its targets. According to a report from Mandiant, the group targets employees working in the fields of acquisitions, corporate development, mergers, IT security staff, or that deal with large corporate transactions. Mandiant notes that UNC3524's targeting suggests a financial motivation, the level of tradecraft displayed by the group is more suggestive of an espionage actor. How UNC3524 gain their initial access to an organization is, at the time Mandiant's report was published, unknown. Once the group has gained access, they typically install a backdoor named QUIETEXIT on devices such as load balancers, SAN arrays, and wireless access point controllers. QUIETEXIT establishes an SSH connection to a C&C server, and once connected QUIETEXIT provides the functionality of an SSH server. It is also capable of setting up a SOCKS tunnel that allows the attackers to execute their tools on their local system thus leaving no traces of tools on the compromised systems. The C&C servers used by the group are a botnet of compromised IoT devices. The IoT devices are typically legacy conference room camera systems from a specific vendor. The IP addresses of the C&C servers are typically obtained using Dynamic DNS providers though an IP address and port can be specified in the command-line arguments used when executing QUIETEXIT. Further information is available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * For a list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.




# References

  * <https://www.mandiant.com/resources/unc3524-eye-spy-email>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Tactics and Techniques:**

 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1583 - Acquire Infrastructure  
T1583.003 - Virtual Private Server  
T1584 - Compromise Infrastructure  
T1608 - Stage Capabilities  
T1608.003 - Install Digital Certificate  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
T1059.001 - PowerShell  
T1059.003 - Windows Command Shell  
  
 **Persistence - TA0003**  
T1037 - Boot or Logon Initialization Scripts  
T1037.004 - RC Scripts  
T1098 - Account Manipulation  
T1098.001 - Additional Cloud Credentials  
T1505 - Server Software Component  
T1505.003 - Web Shell  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1027 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
  
 **Credential Access - TA0006**  
T1003 - OS Credential Dumping  
T1003.004 - LSA Secrets  
T1003.006 - DCSync  
T1111 - Two-Factor Authentication Interception  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1012 - Query Registry  
T1016 - System Network Configuration Discovery  
T1049 - System Network Connections Discovery  
T1057 - Process Discovery  
T1518 - Software Discovery  
  
 **Lateral Movement - TA0008**  
T1021 - Remote Services  
T1021.004 - SSH  
  
 **Collection - TA0009**  
T1114 - Email Collection  
T1114.002 - Remote Email Collection  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
T1090 - Proxy  
T1090.003 - Multi-hop Proxy  
T1095 - Non-Application Layer Protocol  
T1572 - Protocol Tunneling  
T1573 - Encrypted Channel  
T1573.002 - Asymmetric Cryptography  
  


 **Mitigations:**

 **M1015:** Active Directory Configuration - Configure Active Directory to prevent use of certain techniques; use SID Filtering, etc.  
 **M1017:** User Training - Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction.  
 **M1018:** User Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.  
 **M1020:** SSL/TLS Inspection - Break and inspect SSL/TLS sessions to look at encrypted web traffic for adversary activity.  
 **M1021:** Restrict Web-Based Content - Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc.  
 **M1022:** Restrict File and Directory Permissions - Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.  
 **M1024:** Restrict Registry Permissions - Restrict the ability to modify certain hives or keys in the Windows Registry.  
 **M1025:** Privileged Process Integrity - Protect processes with high privileges that can be used to interact with critical system components through use of protected process light, anti-process injection defenses, or other process integrity enforcement measures.  
 **M1026:** Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.  
 **M1027:** Password Policies - Set and enforce secure password policies for accounts.  
 **M1028:** Operating System Configuration - Make configuration changes related to the operating system or a common feature of the operating system that result in system hardening against techniques.  
 **M1030:** Network Segmentation - Architect sections of the network to isolate critical systems, functions, or resources. Use physical and logical segmentation to prevent access to potentially sensitive systems and information. Use a DMZ to contain any internet-facing services that should not be exposed from the internal network. Configure separate virtual private cloud (VPC) instances to isolate critical cloud systems.  
 **M1031:** Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  
 **M1032:** Multi-factor Authentication - Use two or more pieces of evidence to authenticate to a system; such as username and password in addition to a token from a physical smart card or token generator.  
 **M1033:** Limit Software Installation - Block users or groups from installing unapproved software.  
 **M1035:** Limit Access to Resource Over Network - Prevent access to file shares, remote access to systems, unnecessary services. Mechanisms to limit access may include use of network concentrators, RDP gateways, etc.  
 **M1037:** Filter Network Traffic - Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic.  
 **M1038:** Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
 **M1040:** Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
 **M1041:** Encrypt Sensitive Information - Protect sensitive information with strong encryption.  
 **M1042:** Disable or Remove Feature or Program - Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.  
 **M1043:** Credential Access Protection - Use capabilities to prevent successful credential access by adversaries; including blocking forms of credential dumping.  
 **M1045:** Code Signing - Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.  
 **M1047:** Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
 **M1048:** Application Isolation and Sandboxing - Restrict execution of code to a virtual environment on or in transit to an endpoint system.  
 **M1049:** Antivirus/Antimalware - Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software.  
 **M1056:** Pre-compromise - This category is used for any applicable mitigation activities that apply to techniques occurring before an adversary gains Initial Access, such as Reconnaissance and Resource Development techniques.

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: An Analysis of RedLine Stealer
RedLine Stealer is a widely-used piece of malware, the results of which are a large part of the information being sold on the dark web. Researchers at Recorded Future have published an in-depth analysis of the malware and its history.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Malware
  *  **Targets:** Unknown
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** RedLine Stealer
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Phishing
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Unknown



# Overview

RedLine Stealer is an infostealer malware that is currently the largest contributor of stolen information being sold on Russian-speaking sites on the dark web. Researchers from Insikt Group at Recorded Future have analyzed the malware and published a comprehensive report on the malware's capabilities. The infostealer has been distributed since early 2020 by a group known as "REDGlade" or "Glade". According to these actors, there are two subscription licenses available - a lifetime license for 800 dollars, or monthly service for 150 dollars. This malware is normally distributed via phishing emails, as well as over social media. It has also been found masquerading as legitimate programs, including as an installer for Telegram. Once installed, the malware can perform a wide array of functions. At its core, it can steal usernames, passwords, cookies, saved credentials, and credit card information from browsers. It can also gather files from cryptocurrency cold wallets and other locations. Beyond that, RedLine Stealer is capable of performing basic download and execute functions, meaning it can be used as a loader in a multi-stage attack. RedLine is being continually developed by a competent C# developer, and so new versions of this malware are being released regularly. The volume of advertisements for log information stolen by this malware has increased over the past year, which corresponds to the increase in interest across many dark web sources. Further information can be found in the article located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/64130400/An%20Analysis%20of%20RedLine%20Stealer%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1634311309492&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques and phishing emails (M1017).
  * Application control may be able to prevent the running of executables masquerading as other files (M1038).



# References

  * <https://go.recordedfuture.com/hubfs/reports/mtp-2021-1014.pdf>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1566 - Phishing  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1204 - User Execution  
  
 **Credential Access - TA0006**  
T1539 - Steal Web Session Cookie  
T1552 - Unsecured Credentials  
T1555 - Credentials from Password Stores  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1007 - System Service Discovery  
T1057 - Process Discovery  
T1087 - Account Discovery  
T1120 - Peripheral Device Discovery  
T1124 - System Time Discovery  
T1518 - Software Discovery  
T1614 - System Location Discovery  
  
 **Collection - TA0009**  
T1113 - Screen Capture  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0010**  
T1041 - Exfiltration Over C2 Channel  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1095 - Non-Application Layer Protocol  
T1571 - Non-Standard Port

An Analysis of RedLine Stealer
RedLine Stealer is a widely-used piece of malware, the results of which are a large part of the information being sold on the dark web. Researchers at Recorded Future have published an in-depth analysis of the malware and its history.
parsed_raw_data.xfe_report:
# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Malware
  *  **Targets:** Unknown
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** RedLine Stealer
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Phishing
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Unknown



# Overview

RedLine Stealer is an infostealer malware that is currently the largest contributor of stolen information being sold on Russian-speaking sites on the dark web. Researchers from Insikt Group at Recorded Future have analyzed the malware and published a comprehensive report on the malware's capabilities. The infostealer has been distributed since early 2020 by a group known as "REDGlade" or "Glade". According to these actors, there are two subscription licenses available - a lifetime license for 800 dollars, or monthly service for 150 dollars. This malware is normally distributed via phishing emails, as well as over social media. It has also been found masquerading as legitimate programs, including as an installer for Telegram. Once installed, the malware can perform a wide array of functions. At its core, it can steal usernames, passwords, cookies, saved credentials, and credit card information from browsers. It can also gather files from cryptocurrency cold wallets and other locations. Beyond that, RedLine Stealer is capable of performing basic download and execute functions, meaning it can be used as a loader in a multi-stage attack. RedLine is being continually developed by a competent C# developer, and so new versions of this malware are being released regularly. The volume of advertisements for log information stolen by this malware has increased over the past year, which corresponds to the increase in interest across many dark web sources. Further information can be found in the article located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/64130400/An%20Analysis%20of%20RedLine%20Stealer%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1634311309492&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques and phishing emails (M1017).
  * Application control may be able to prevent the running of executables masquerading as other files (M1038).



# References

  * <https://go.recordedfuture.com/hubfs/reports/mtp-2021-1014.pdf>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1566 - Phishing  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1204 - User Execution  
  
 **Credential Access - TA0006**  
T1539 - Steal Web Session Cookie  
T1552 - Unsecured Credentials  
T1555 - Credentials from Password Stores  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1007 - System Service Discovery  
T1057 - Process Discovery  
T1087 - Account Discovery  
T1120 - Peripheral Device Discovery  
T1124 - System Time Discovery  
T1518 - Software Discovery  
T1614 - System Location Discovery  
  
 **Collection - TA0009**  
T1113 - Screen Capture  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0010**  
T1041 - Exfiltration Over C2 Channel  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1095 - Non-Application Layer Protocol  
T1571 - Non-Standard Port

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: WarzoneRAT Using New Detection Evasion Tactics
The Uptycs Threat Research Team has been researching new techniques being used by WarzoneRAT. In this article, they discuss a detection evasion technique using process hollowing.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Remote Access Trojan
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Unknown
  *  **Associated Payloads:** WarzoneRAT (S0670)
  *  **Targets:** Unknown
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Malicious Excel Document
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Unknown
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

The Uptycs Threat Research team has been analyzing the techniques used by the WarzoneRAT malware. The malware tends to be delivered via a malicious Excel document, which uses javascript embedded in a macro to start the kill chain. This script downloads the payload from a remote server and sets up persistence using scheduled tasks. In this article, the researchers describe a defense evasion technique that is a recent development for Warzone RAT. The launching script downloads various payloads, which are injected into legitimate processes such as MSBuild.exe using process hollowing. The script also injects a payload, which performs UAC bypass via ComputerDefaults.exe, allowing the malware to run at a higher privilege level. For more information, please see the link in the reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.

# Recommendations

  * For a list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.




# References

  * <https://www.uptycs.com/blog/warzonerat-can-now-evade-with-process-hollowing>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1566.001 - Spearphishing Attachment  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
T1059.001 - PowerShell  
T1204.002 - Malicious File  
  
 **Persistence - TA0003**  
T1053.005 - Scheduled Task  
  
 **Privilege Escalation - TA0004**  
T1055.012 - Process Hollowing  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1055 - Process Injection  
  


#### Mitigations:

  
 **M1017:** User Training - Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction.  
 **M1018:** User Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.  
 **M1021:** Restrict Web-Based Content - Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc.  
 **M1022:** Restrict File and Directory Permissions - Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.  
 **M1026:** Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.  
 **M1028:** Operating System Configuration - Make configuration changes related to the operating system or a common feature of the operating system that result in system hardening against techniques.  
 **M1031:** Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  
 **M1033:** Limit Software Installation - Block users or groups from installing unapproved software.  
 **M1038:** Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
 **M1040:** Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
 **M1042:** Disable or Remove Feature or Program - Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.  
 **M1045:** Code Signing - Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.  
 **M1047:** Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
 **M1049:** Antivirus/Antimalware - Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software.  
 **M1054:** Software Configuration - Implement configuration changes to software (other than the operating system) to mitigate security risks associated to how the software operates.

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Webhards Used to Distribute UDP RAT
ASEC researchers have found malware named UDP RAT being distributed via webhards and torrents. The malware, disguised as an adult game, is distributed using Korean webhards and torrent sites, according to ASEC's blog post.
output:
# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Remote Access Trojan
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Non-specific
  *  **Associated Payloads:** UDP RAT
  *  **Targets:** Users of webhards and torrent sites who download adult games.
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Installation of Trojanized adult games.
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Connection to C2 for additional malware.
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See MITRE ATT&CK Framework below



# Overview

ASEC researchers, while observing malware sources from Korea, have found malware named UDP RAT, disguised as an adult video game. The attacker uses several different games containing the same compressed file and distributed using webhards and torrents. The compressed file contains a file called Game..exe which is not the game at all but is a malware launcher. A second Game.exe (differs from Game..exe) file is used to run the actual games. Once the process completes, Game..exe is automatically hidden. Further files are created including one that poses as an uninstaller but is actually another type of malware. Connections to a C2 server are used to obtain the URL of further malware to be downloaded. ASEC researchers were unable to obtain the download URL and therefore cannot speak to the operation of the malware. Further details can be found within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/68616424/Webhards%20Used%20to%20Distribute%20UDP%20RAT%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1635187872652&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Restrict Web-Based Content (M1021).



# References

  * <https://asec.ahnlab.com/en/27555/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1204 - User Execution  
T1204.002 - Malicious File  
  
 **Persistence - TA0003**  
T1547 - Boot or Logon Autostart Execution  
T1547.001 - Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1564 - Hide Artifacts  
T1564.001 - Hidden Files and Directories  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
T1071.001 - Web Protocols  
T1095 - Non-Application Layer Protocol  
T1102 - Web Service

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Accellion File Transfer Appliance FTA Exploited for Data Theft and Extortion Affecting Multiple Companies
Multiple organizations have had sensitive data stolen as a result of attackers exploiting zero day vulnerabilities of the Accellion File Transfer Appliance (FTA). Attacks began in mid-December 2020. Extortion emails received by victimized organizations started in late January 2021. Accellion's FTA is a 20 year old product, which Accellion has recommended customers move over to a different more secure offering.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware, Data Theft, Backdoor




# Overview

Beginning in mid-December 2020, multiple zero-day vulnerabilities in Accellion's legacy file transfer appliance (FTA) were exploited by malicious actors who installed a web shell that cybersecurity firm Mandiant has named DEWMODE. The threat actors exploited multiple vulnerabilities, which have since been patched. By late January 2021, multiple organizations who used FTA, received extortion emails from an actor claiming to be associated with the CLOP ransomware team, threatening to publish stolen data on a darkweb site that is monitored by many include media outlets. The web shell extracts files from a MySQL database and presents a list to the webshell user of those files and allows them to download them. The malicious actors behind the attack against Accellion FTA are being tracked as UNC2546 by Mandiant. Further information can be found in the article located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.



# Reference

  * <https://www.fireeye.com/blog/threat-research/2021/02/accellion-fta-exploited-for-data-theft-and-extortion.html>

  * <https://us-cert.cisa.gov/ncas/alerts/aa21-055a>
  * <https://www.guidepointsecurity.com/accellion-fta-targeted-by-file-downloading-web-shell/>
  * <https://www.accellion.com/company/press-releases/accellion-provides-update-to-recent-fta-security-incident/>
  * <https://www.bankinfosecurity.com/blogs/accellion-mess-what-went-wrong-p-2989>
  * <https://apnews.com/article/software-c4815b9f0c0092071bad97d9f6842fe6>
  * <https://www.cyberscoop.com/fireeye-ids-hacking-group-suspected-in-accellion-kroger-breach/>
  * <https://www.infosecurity-magazine.com/news/singtel-supply-chain-breach-traced/>
  * <https://www.infosecurity-magazine.com/news/new-zealands-central-bank-probes/>
  * <https://www.zdnet.com/article/transport-for-nsw-confirms-data-taken-in-accellion-data-breach/>
  * <https://sao.wa.gov/breach2021/>
  * <https://www.wsj.com/articles/hack-of-software-provider-accellion-sets-off-global-ripple-effects-11613730601>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: DDoS Attacks Targeting Ukrainian Websites Analyzed
A Distributed Denial of Service (DDoS) attack targeting Ukrainian government organizations and banks caused temporary outages from February 15-16th.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Malware
  *  **Targets:** Ukrainian Financial and Government Organizations
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** Katana bot (derivative of Mirai) 
  * **Initial Infection Vector:** Botnet 
  * **Post-Compromise Actions:** DDoS
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

Cado Security reports that between February 15-16th a number of Financial, Government, and Military websites fell victim to a Distributed Denial of Service (DDoS) attack. Network traffic to bank sites - Privat Bank and Oschad Bank - was seen spiking as the the attack commenced along with customer reports of the websites being unavailable. Some Privat Bank customers in the Ukraine received SMS messages crafted by adversaries warning that ATMs would not work on February 15th. In addition, a BGP hijack against the Privat Bank's IP space caused traffic routing issues for users. The report also mentions other components to the attack such as DDoS attacks against .gov.ua DNS servers. The news outlet, tsn.ua, named zsu.gov.ua and mil.gov.ua as specific Ukrainian government victims. The Ukrainian Ministry of Defense also confirmed the attack via Twitter. The report calls out Mirai and derivative Katana as likely botnets used to launch the attack. It goes on to name exploited Avtech network cameras as the launch point for the attacks. Overall, Cado Security's report calls these attacks moderately impactful. They were not particularly successful but the combination of methods suggests there is a base level of sophistication coordinated by the adversary. Further details can be found in the article located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/81133648/DDoS%20Attacks%20Targeting%20Ukrainian%20Websites%20Analyzed%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1645985381594&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root (M1026).
  * Filter Network Traffic - Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic (M1037).
  * Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking (M1038).
  * Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior (M1040).
  * Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses (M1047).
  * Antivirus/Antimalware - Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software (M1049).
  * Pre-compromise - This category is used for any applicable mitigation activities that apply to techniques occurring before an adversary gains Initial Access, such as Reconnaissance and Resource Development techniques (M1056).



# References

  * <https://www.cadosecurity.com/technical-analysis-of-the-ddos-attacks-against-ukrainian-websites/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Reconnaissance - TA0043**  
T1590 - Gather Victim Network Information  
  
 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1583 - Acquire Infrastructure  
T1583.005 - Botnet  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
T1059.004 - Unix Shell  
  
 **Impact - TA0040**  
T1498 - Network Denial of Service

A Distributed Denial of Service (DDoS) attack targeting Ukrainian government organizations and banks caused temporary outages from February 15-16th.

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/81133648/DDoS%20Attacks%20Targeting%20Ukrainian%20Websites%20Analyzed%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1645985381594&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root (M1026).
  * Filter Network Traffic - Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic (M1037).
  * Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking (M1038).
  * Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior (M1040).
  * Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses (M1047).
  * Antivirus/Antimalware - Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software (M1049).
  * Pre-compromise - This category is used for any applicable mitigation activities that apply to techniques occurring before an adversary gains Initial Access, such as Reconnaissance and Resource Development techniques (M1056).



# References

  * <https://www.cadosecurity.com/technical-analysis-of-the-ddos-attacks-against-ukrainian-websites/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Reconnaissance - TA0043**  
T1590 - Gather Victim Network Information  
  
 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1583 - Acquire Infrastructure  
T1583.005 - Botnet  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
T1059.004 - Unix Shell  
  
 **Impact - TA0040**  
T1498 - Network Denial of Service

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Magniber Ransomware Now Targeting Windows 11
360 Total Security researchers have been tracking the distribution of Magniber ransomware. They have observed an attack occurring on a Windows 11 system, and a large uptick in attack volumes, which has been described in an article.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Ransomware
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Unknown
  *  **Associated Payloads:** Magniber
  *  **Targets:** Unknown
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Fake Windows and Chrome updates, cracked software websites, fake pornographic websites.
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Data Encryption, Data Theft
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

360 Total Security researchers have reported seeing Magniber ransomware infections on Windows 11 machines. Previously, they reported Magniber ransomware being distributed as fake Windows 10 upgrade patch packages. The researchers also saw other .msi files with misleading names taking advantage of the pandemic to lure users into executing them. The volume of attacks using this method sharply increased in May 2022. Despite the large rise in volume, the malware actually hasn't evolved very much since before this campaign. The main difference in the latest variant is the ability to infect multiple Windows versions, including Windows 11. The malware uses RSA+AES encryption to encrypt files. The group uses the popular double-extortion method where they threaten to leak files as well as encrypting them for financial gain if the ransom isn't paid. For more information, please see the link in the references section.

# Indicators of Compromise

Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.

# Recommendations

  * For a list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.




# References

  * <https://blog.360totalsecurity.com/en/win11-users-beware-magniber-ransomware-has-been-upgraded-again-aiming-at-win11/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Tactics and Techniques:**

 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1587 - Develop Capabilities  
T1587.001 - Malware  
T1608 - Stage Capabilities  
T1608.001 - Upload Malware  
T1608.002 - Upload Tool  
T1608.005 - Link Target  
  
 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1189 - Drive-by Compromise  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1204 - User Execution  
T1204.002 - Malicious File  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1083 - File and Directory Discovery  
  
 **Collection - TA0009**  
T1005 - Data from Local System  
T1074 - Data Staged  
T1074.001 - Local Data Staging  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0010**  
T1041 - Exfiltration Over C2 Channel  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
T1071.001 - Web Protocols  
  
 **Impact - TA0040**  
T1486 - Data Encrypted for Impact  
  


 **Mitigations:**

 **M1017:** User Training - Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction.  
 **M1021:** Restrict Web-Based Content - Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc.  
 **M1031:** Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  
 **M1037:** Filter Network Traffic - Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic.  
 **M1038:** Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
 **M1040:** Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
 **M1045:** Code Signing - Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.  
 **M1047:** Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
 **M1048:** Application Isolation and Sandboxing - Restrict execution of code to a virtual environment on or in transit to an endpoint system.  
 **M1050:** Exploit Protection - Use capabilities to detect and block conditions that may lead to or be indicative of a software exploit occurring.  
 **M1051:** Update Software - Perform regular software updates to mitigate exploitation risk.  
 **M1053:** Data Backup - Take and store data backups from end user systems and critical servers. Ensure backup and storage systems are hardened and kept separate from the corporate network to prevent compromise.  
 **M1056:** Pre-compromise - This category is used for any applicable mitigation activities that apply to techniques occurring before an adversary gains Initial Access, such as Reconnaissance and Resource Development techniques.  
 **M1057:** Data Loss Prevention - Use a data loss prevention (DLP) strategy to categorize sensitive data, identify data formats indicative of personal identifiable information (PII), and restrict exfiltration of sensitive data.

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: New Mirai variant Named Mirai_ptea
A new Mirai variant that targets KGUARD DVR firmware was detected by Netlab 360 in the latter part of June. They named the new variant mirai_ptea.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Botnet, DDoS




# Overview

A new Mirai variant named mirai_ptea was detected by Netlab 360 in June. According to Netlab 360 who discovered and named the new variant, it targets a previously unknown vulnerability in KGUARD DVR firmware. Probing for this vulnerability began as early as March. A matter of days after the discovery of mirai_ptea, and another variant named mirai_aurora were detected exploiting the KGUARD vulnerability. Netlab 360's report notes that the vulnerability appears to have been addressed in versions of the KGUARD firmware. The vulnerability is due to the firmware listening on an unspecified port which will allows an attacker to execute system commands without any authentication. Command and control communications are handled by mirai_ptea connecting to a Tor server through a proxy node. The botnet is used to carry out DDoS attacks. Further information is available from the Netlab 360 report linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://blog.netlab.360.com/mirai_ptea-botnet-is-exploiting-undisclosed-kguard-dvr-vulnerability-en/>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Renewed SideWinder Activity in South Asia
SideWinder is an APT that targets South Asian government and military organizations with espionage campaigns, likely acting in Indian interests. DeepEnd Research reports on the most recent wave of activity from this threat group.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Renewed SideWinder Activity in South Asia
SideWinder is an APT that targets South Asian government and military organizations with espionage campaigns, likely acting in Indian interests. DeepEnd Research reports on the most recent wave of activity from this threat group.

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Phishing, Spyware, APT




# Overview

DeepEnd Research published a blog post analyzing the most recent wave of SideWinder APT activity. This specific campaign appears to target government entities in Nepal. Their research began with the discovery of a server hosting shell code. This shell code was determined to be the second stage payload, specifically a Meterpreter payload. Using this sample they were able to trace it back to a first stage payload likely delivered by HTA spear phishing email attachments. The HTA file downloads a spyware payload that steals logins from browsers and files from user folders to exfiltrate back to the C2 server. Additionally, the server hosted many credential phishing landing pages targeting various Nepalese government organizations. These pages leveraged the legitimate versions of login pages to load resources in order to make it appear more realistic. One of the most interesting pages was that created for a new target, the Election Commission of Nepal. This is noteworthy given recent news associated with the upcoming Nepalese elections. Finally, the researchers note the discovery of mobile malware being developed by the group, but it appears to be in the testing stage. For more information, see the Deep End Research blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <http://www.deependresearch.org/2021/03/renewed-sidewinder-activity-in-south.html>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: HEH Botnet
HEH is a new IoT P2P botnet discovered by 360 Netlab researchers. It spreads its reach by brute forcing Telnet services, regardless of the device type.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: HEH Botnet
HEH is a new IoT P2P botnet discovered by 360 Netlab researchers. It spreads its reach by brute forcing Telnet services, regardless of the device type.

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Botnet




# Overview

360 Netlab has published a blog post analyzing a new botnet malware, which they have named HEH. This malware is written in Go and does not target any specific architectures or end devices, it simply brute forces any discovered Telnet services. The payload is delivered to a system via a malicious shell script. Once executed on a victim system it launches three functional modules: a propagation module, local HTTP service module, and a P2P module. The propagation module works by randomly generating IP addresses, identifying whether Telnet is open on that IP address, and, if so, brute forcing the service with a hardcoded list of usernames and passwords. The HTTP module starts an HTTP server on port 80 through which the payload can be obtained. The P2P module is the module capable of interacting with other botnet peers and executing commands. It is able to perform pings to each member of the botnet and issue updates to the peer list. Its UDP service component is used to receive and execute commands received from other peers. Available commands include those for restarting the bot, executing shell commands, and self destructing the device by wiping disk contents. An attack command is also present but does not contain any code, likely indicating the malware is still in development. For more information, see the 360 Netlab blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.



# Reference

  * <https://blog.netlab.360.com/heh-an-iot-p2p-botnet/>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: MuddyWater - An Element of the Iranian Ministry of Intelligence and Security
The U.S. Cyber Command has published a report from its Cyber National Mission Force in which they identify a number of open-source tools that have been used by Iranian intelligence actors known as MuddyWater. Additionally, SentinelOne Labs has also published a report that provides details of recent incidents that correlate with the Cyber Command report.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Malware, Surveillance.
  *  **Targets:** Opponents of the Iranian government.
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** PowGoop, Mori Backdoor
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Various, including exploiting Exchange servers (CVE-2020-0688), Spearphishing.
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Surveillance, Data collection, and exfiltration.
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below for associated techniques.



# Overview

While the threat group commonly referred to as MuddyWater has been believed to be an Iranian state-sponsored group, a report from U.S. Cyber Command definitively ties MuddyWater to Iran, describing the group as an element of the Iranian Ministry of Intelligence and Security (MOIS). MuddyWater is also known as Dirtywater, Earth Vetala, Mercury, Seedworm, Static Kitten, T-APT-14, and TEMP.Zagros, and are tracked by IBM X-Force as ITG17. The report notes that MuddyWater has been reported to have targeted Middle Eastern nations as well as European and North American nations but reports its purpose as identifying and surveilling those opposed to the Iranian government, both domestically and abroad. The report provides IoCs for multiple variants of PowGoop, the Mori Backdoor, and some JavaScript samples, used by MuddyWater. 

Additionally, SentinelOne Labs has published a report that provides some details of recent incidents that correlate with the Cyber Command report. More information is provided on the malware associated with MuddyWater, their tunneling tools, and their attempts to exploit a Microsoft Exchange server vulnerability (CVE-2020-0688) on Exchange servers that belong to governmental organizations located in the Middle East.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/74056891/MuddyWater%20-%20An%20Element%20of%20the%20Iranian%20Ministry%20of%20Intelligence%20and%20Security%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1642051541494&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).



# References

  * <https://www.cybercom.mil/Media/News/Article/2897570/iranian-intel-cyber-suite-of-malware-uses-open-source-tools/>
  * <https://www.virustotal.com/gui/user/CYBERCOM_Malware_Alert>
