instruction:
I have encountered the following information: BT Missed Voice Message Phishing Lure
In a new campaign observed by Cofense, British Telecom users are being targeted with phishing emails claiming to be related to missed voice messages.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Phishing
  *  **Target:** British Telecom (BT) customers
  *  **Lure:** BT Landline missed voice message
  *  **Payload:** Link to fake BT login page
  *  **Compromised Data:** Account credentials



# Overview

Cofense published a blog post analyzing a phishing campaign targeting British Telecom (BT) users. The body of the email claims that the recipients BT landline has a new voice message that can be played via provided link. Both the landing page for this link and the email use BT branding in an attempt to trick the user. The landing page provides a login prompt requesting the user's email and password in order to play missed voice messages. Any entered credentials are exfiltrated to the attacker while the victim is redirected to the BT Landline help page. For more information, see the Cofense blog post in the References section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/68616512/BT%20Missed%20Voice%20Message%20Phishing%20Lure%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1635168039384&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Restrict Web-Based Content (M1021).
  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques and phishing emails (M1017).



# References

  * <https://cofense.com/blog/missed-voice-message-phish/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1566 - Phishing  
T1566.002 - Spearphishing Link  
  
 **Credential Access - TA0006**  
T1056 - Input Capture

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: OneDrive Cloud Service Abused for Phishing
A phishing campaign discovered by Cofense is abusing legitimate OneDrive cloud hosting services to bypass detection.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Phishing




# Overview

Cofense published a blog post analyzing a phishing campaign that is leveraging OneDrive to host their malicious content. The phishing email claims a file has been shared via OneDrive and provides a shortened OneDrive link to visit. Hosted on this OneDrive URL is a PDF containing hyperlinked text to a second-stage phishing page. If a user falls for this trick and visits the secondary page, they are presented with logon options for multiple email services combined with further OneDrive branding. Each login option provides a different fake login page; for example, one led to an Outlook login page while another presented a Box login. When a user provides credentials, the entered data is exfiltrated to the attacker while the victim is redirected to a benign research article. For more information, see the Cofense blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://cofense.com/blog/one-drive-malicious-links/>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Spearphishing Attacks Targeting Organizations in Ukraine
A report from Palo Alto's Unit 42 provides an analysis of a spearphishing attack and its payloads that occurred in early February and targeted organizations in Ukraine.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Spearphishing Attacks Targeting Organizations in Ukraine
A report from Palo Alto's Unit 42 provides an analysis of a spearphishing attack and its payloads that occurred in early February and targeted organizations in Ukraine.

# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Infostealers, Downloaders.
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** UAC-0056
  *  **Associated Payloads:** SaintBot, OutSteel.
  *  **Targets:** Organizations located in Ukraine.
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Malicious document attached to a spearphishing email.
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Collection and exfiltration of documents.
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

An analysis of a spearphishing attack that occurred in early February and targeted organizations in Ukraine has been published in a report from Palo Alto's Unit 42. The attack has been attributed to a threat group that Ukraine's CERT identifies as UAC-0056. The spearphishing email had a malicious Word document that contained JavaScript attached. The JavaScript was an initial loader that in turn executed PowerShell code to download and install two payloads, a downloader named SaintBot and a document stealer named OutSteel. The theme of the phishing email was that the recipient had allegedly committed a crime. Other attacks that targeted organizations in Ukraine that occurred in 2021 and have been attributed to UAC-0056 are also documented. Palo Alto believes the objective of the attacks is to obtain sensitive information that can provide situational awareness. Further information is available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/81133945/Spearphishing%20Attacks%20Targeting%20Organizations%20in%20Ukraine%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1646189448050&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.

parsed_raw_data.xfe_q:
Spearphishing Attacks Targeting Organizations in Ukraine
A report from Palo Alto's Unit 42 provides an analysis of a spearphishing attack and its payloads that occurred in early February and targeted organizations in Ukraine.
parsed_raw_data.xfe_report:
# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Infostealers, Downloaders.
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** UAC-0056
  *  **Associated Payloads:** SaintBot, OutSteel.
  *  **Targets:** Organizations located in Ukraine.
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Malicious document attached to a spearphishing email.
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Collection and exfiltration of documents.
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

An analysis of a spearphishing attack that occurred in early February and targeted organizations in Ukraine has been published in a report from Palo Alto's Unit 42. The attack has been attributed to a threat group that Ukraine's CERT identifies as UAC-0056. The spearphishing email had a malicious Word document that contained JavaScript attached. The JavaScript was an initial loader that in turn executed PowerShell code to download and install two payloads, a downloader named SaintBot and a document stealer named OutSteel. The theme of the phishing email was that the recipient had allegedly committed a crime. Other attacks that targeted organizations in Ukraine that occurred in 2021 and have been attributed to UAC-0056 are also documented. Palo Alto believes the objective of the attacks is to obtain sensitive information that can provide situational awareness. Further information is available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/81133945/Spearphishing%20Attacks%20Targeting%20Organizations%20in%20Ukraine%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1646189448050&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Restrict Web-Based Content (M1021).
  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques and phishing emails (M1017).



# References

  * <https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/ukraine-targeted-outsteel-saintbot/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Reconnaissance - TA0043**  
T1589 - Gather Victim Identity Information

T1588.002 - Tool

T1608.002 - Upload Tool  
T1608.005 - Link Target  
  
 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1566 - Phishing  
T1566.001 - Spearphishing Attachment  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
T1059.001 - PowerShell  
T1059.007 - JavaScript  
T1204 - User Execution  
T1204.001 - Malicious Link  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1027 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
T1027.002 - Software Packing  
T1055 - Process Injection  
T1070 - Indicator Removal on Host  
T1070.004 - File Deletion  
T1140 - Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information  
T1548 - Abuse Elevation Control Mechanism  
T1548.002 - Bypass User Account Control  
T1553 - Subvert Trust Controls  
T1553.002 - Code Signing  
T1562 - Impair Defenses  
T1562.001 - Disable or Modify Tools  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1083 - File and Directory Discovery

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Business Email Compromise Disruption via Cross-Domain Threat Data
Microsoft Defender researchers have reported on a business email compromise (BEC) campaign that they subsequently thwarted.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Phishing, Business Email Compromise




# Overview

An investigation by the Microsoft Defender team researchers has uncovered a BEC campaign in which attackers are conducting phishing and compromised mailboxes attacks. Using multiple web services, the attackers were able to operate under the radar. Different IPs and timeframes made for difficult for analysts to correlate activity that does not appear related. Microsoft 365 Defender's cross-domain feature was able to assist in the identification of this BEC campaign. A minimal footprint makes the cross-domain feature a necessary part of the identification process. Microsoft's Threat Intelligence Center (MSTIC) reported the activity to multiple cloud security teams and they, in turn, suspended the accounts used by threat actors thus eliminating the infrastructure. By employing multi-factor authentication (MFA), most of these types of attacks are thwarted since the attackers cannot log into those protected accounts. A phishing email sent to potential victims contained an HTML file as well as a voicemail lure. Shortly after these emails were sent, forwarding rules were created, presumably, by the threat actors. JavaScript within the HTML attachment showed an imitation of the Microsoft sign-in page. Upon entering a password, the user is shown animations and, after that, a "File not found" message. Credentials were sent to the attackers through a redirection to a cloud service provider not related to the attacker. Persistence was obtained via email forwarding rules. Further information can be found in the report located within the Reference section below.

# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.microsoft.com/security/blog/2021/06/14/behind-the-scenes-of-business-email-compromise-using-cross-domain-threat-data-to-disrupt-a-large-bec-infrastructure/>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: APT34 Using New Backdoor In Campaign Against Jordan Government
Malwarebytes has published an analysis of a brand new backdoor called Saitama. This is being actively used in a campaign against the Jordan government by the threat group APT34.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: APT34 Using New Backdoor In Campaign Against Jordan Government
Malwarebytes has published an analysis of a brand new backdoor called Saitama. This is being actively used in a campaign against the Jordan government by the threat group APT34.

# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Backdoor
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** APT34
  *  **Associated Payloads:** Saitama
  *  **Targets:** Jordan Government
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Phishing Attachment
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Data Collection



# Overview

Malwarebytes Labs have been tracking the threat group APT34. They have recently observed this group using a new backdoor in a campaign against the Jordanian government. This backdoor is being called Saitama. Initial access is gained through a malicious email containing an excel file, pretending to be from the Government of Jordan. If the victim enables macros, the excel file performs the necessary actions to drop the Saitama backdoor onto the victim machine. The backdoor uses DNS for C2 communications, as well as long sleep times and compression to disguise the malicious traffic. The backdoor can execute predefined commands, and custom commands from the C2 server, and manipulate files on disk. Some of the predefined commands contain internal IP and domain names, showing that this is a highly targeted attack and that the attackers had some knowledge of the victim's internal infrastructure. For more information, please see the link in the reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * For a full list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.




# References

  * <https://blog.malwarebytes.com/threat-intelligence/2022/05/apt34-targets-jordan-government-using-new-saitama-backdoor/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1566.001 - Spearphishing Attachment  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1204 - User Execution  
T1204.002 - Malicious File  
  
 **Persistence - TA0003**  
T1053.005 - Scheduled Task  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1564 - Hide Artifacts  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1033 - System Owner/User Discovery  
T1046 - Network Service Scanning  
T1049 - System Network Connections Discovery  
T1083 - File and Directory Discovery  
  
 **Collection - TA0009**  
T1560 - Archive Collected Data  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0010**  
T1041 - Exfiltration Over C2 Channel  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1071.004 - DNS  
  


#### Mitigations:

  
 **M1013:** Application Developer Guidance: This mitigation describes any guidance or training given to developers of applications to avoid introducing security weaknesses that an adversary may be able to take advantage of.  
 **M1017:** User Training - Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction.  
 **M1018:** User Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.  
 **M1021:** Restrict Web-Based Content - Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc.  
 **M1022:** Restrict File and Directory Permissions - Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.  
 **M1026:** Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.  
 **M1028:** Operating System Configuration - Make configuration changes related to the operating system or a common feature of the operating system that result in system hardening against techniques.  
 **M1030:** Network Segmentation - Architect sections of the network to isolate critical systems, functions, or resources. Use physical and logical segmentation to prevent access to potentially sensitive systems and information. Use a DMZ to contain any internet-facing services that should not be exposed from the internal network. Configure separate virtual private cloud (VPC) instances to isolate critical cloud systems.  
 **M1031:** Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  
 **M1037:** Filter Network Traffic - Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic.  
 **M1038:** Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
 **M1040:** Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
 **M1042:** Disable or Remove Feature or Program - Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.  
 **M1045:** Code Signing - Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.  
 **M1047:** Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
 **M1049:** Antivirus/Antimalware - Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software.  
 **M1054:** Software Configuration - Implement configuration changes to software (other than the operating system) to mitigate security risks associated to how the software operates.  
 **M1057:** Data Loss Prevention - Use a data loss prevention (DLP) strategy to categorize sensitive data, identify data formats indicative of personal identifiable information (PII), and restrict exfiltration of sensitive data.

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: More Malicious Word File Used to Target Korea
A report from AhnLab's ASEC team provides information on a malicious document being used to target Korean language speakers that AhnLab appears to attribute to Kimsuky.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Malware
  *  **Targets:** Personnel involved in diplomacy, defense, and politics.
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** Unspecified
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Malicious document attached to an email.
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Data disclosure, possibly other actions.
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

According to a report from AhnLab's ASEC team, malicious Word documents, probably arriving as email attachments, are being used to target Korean language speakers. These emails claim to have documents that provide information about North Korean diplomacy and defense. When opened, and if macros are enabled, the malicious documents download templates from a remote host and then execute them. The final payload was not observed as the URL for it was not valid when checked. The goal of the attacks appears to be, at the least, to obtain information about the victim system. While AhnLab does not specifically attribute the activity to Kimsuky, AhnLab's detection rule identifies the activity as "Downloader/DOC.Kimsuky". Kimsuky is also known by other names including Thallium and is tracked by IBM X-Force as ITG16. Kimsuky typically targets personnel involved in diplomacy, defense, and politics. Further information is available from the report linked in the Reference section below. 

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * For a list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.




# References

  * <https://asec.ahnlab.com/en/33894/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Tactics and Techniques:**

 **Reconnaissance - TA0043**  
T1589 - Gather Victim Identity Information  
T1589.002 - Email Addresses  
  
 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1584 - Compromise Infrastructure  
T1584.004 - Server  
T1608 - Stage Capabilities  
T1608.001 - Upload Malware  
T1608.005 - Link Target  
  
 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1566 - Phishing  
T1566.001 - Spearphishing Attachment  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1204 - User Execution  
T1204.002 - Malicious File  
  


 **Mitigations:**

 **M1017:** User Training - Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction.  
 **M1021:** Restrict Web-Based Content - Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc.  
 **M1031:** Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  
 **M1038:** Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
 **M1040:** Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
 **M1045:** Code Signing - Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.  
 **M1047:** Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
 **M1049:** Antivirus/Antimalware - Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software.  
 **M1054:** Software Configuration - Implement configuration changes to software (other than the operating system) to mitigate security risks associated to how the software operates.  
 **M1056:** Pre-compromise - This category is used for any applicable mitigation activities that apply to techniques occurring before an adversary gains Initial Access, such as Reconnaissance and Resource Development techniques.

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Phishing Campaign Targeting Predominantly Government Entities
A phishing campaign, active since late 2019, and targeting the education, energy, finance, government, and heath sectors in a number of geographies, has been reported by Recorded Future’s Insikt Group. The campaign has leveraged the open source phishing framework, FiercePhish.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Phishing Campaign Targeting Predominantly Government Entities
A phishing campaign, active since late 2019, and targeting the education, energy, finance, government, and heath sectors in a number of geographies, has been reported by Recorded Future’s Insikt Group. The campaign has leveraged the open source phishing framework, FiercePhish.

# Threat Type

  * Phishing




# Overview

Primarily targeting governmental entities, as well as the education, energy, finance, and heath sectors, Recorded Future’s Insikt Group has identified a phishing campaign that has been active since late 2019. The most targeted countries have been Canada, India, the United States, and Turkey. Other countries targeted include, Australia, India, Qatar, the Republic of Korea, Turkey, the United Arab Emirates, and the United Kingdom. The campaign has largely been using Russian domains (.ru) and Insikt believes the campaign has been coordinated through the site asherintartrading.com. The site has hosted the management portal for the the open source phishing framework, FiercePhish. A number of IP addresses, including more than thirty belonging to DigitalOcean, have also been used in the campaign, along with more than two hundred domains and URLs. The URLs follow a similar naming convention in most cases. In the email noted in the report, the victim was presented with a fake Gmail login page. In addition, if the victim clicked the unsubscribe link in the email, they were presented with a different phishing page, on a different domain. Further details are available from the report linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://go.recordedfuture.com/hubfs/reports/cta-2020-1027.pdf>

# Threat Type

  * Phishing




# Overview

Primarily targeting governmental entities, as well as the education, energy, finance, and heath sectors, Recorded Future’s Insikt Group has identified a phishing campaign that has been active since late 2019. The most targeted countries have been Canada, India, the United States, and Turkey. Other countries targeted include, Australia, India, Qatar, the Republic of Korea, Turkey, the United Arab Emirates, and the United Kingdom. The campaign has largely been using Russian domains (.ru) and Insikt believes the campaign has been coordinated through the site asherintartrading.com. The site has hosted the management portal for the the open source phishing framework, FiercePhish. A number of IP addresses, including more than thirty belonging to DigitalOcean, have also been used in the campaign, along with more than two hundred domains and URLs. The URLs follow a similar naming convention in most cases. In the email noted in the report, the victim was presented with a fake Gmail login page. In addition, if the victim clicked the unsubscribe link in the email, they were presented with a different phishing page, on a different domain. Further details are available from the report linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://go.recordedfuture.com/hubfs/reports/cta-2020-1027.pdf>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: New Linux Backdoor - B1txor20
Netlab 360 has discovered a new Linux backdoor that is being deployed through exploitation of the Log4J vulnerability.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Malware
  *  **Targets:** Linux systems.
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** B1txor20 backdoor.
  *  ** **Initial Infection Vector:**** Exploitation of the Log4J vulnerability.
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Various including uploading information. ****
  * **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

A new Linux backdoor that is being deployed through exploitation of the Log4J vulnerability has been discovered by Netlab 360. The backdoor has been named B1txor20 is likely still being developed as some features contained in the code are not used and some have bugs. B1txor20 is capable of providing a shell, executing arbitrary commands, uploading information, opening a SOCKS5 proxy, and installing a rootkit. B1txor20 communicates with its C&C servers using a DNS tunnel, information that needs to be sent to the C&C server is sent as DNS queries and the server query responses contain any commands or output from the server. The content of the queries and responses are encrypted. It appears from a list of scanner IP addresses in Netlab's report that the actor behind the malware actively scans for vulnerable systems. Further information is available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).



# References

  * <https://blog.netlab.360.com/b1txor20-use-of-dns-tunneling_en/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Reconnaissance - TA0043**  
T1595 - Active Scanning  
T1595.002 - Vulnerability Scanning  
  
 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1583 - Acquire Infrastructure  
T1583.001 - Domains  
T1583.004 - Server  
T1587 - Develop Capabilities  
T1587.001 - Malware  
T1588 - Obtain Capabilities  
T1588.005 - Exploits  
T1608 - Stage Capabilities  
T1608.001 - Upload Malware  
  
 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
  
 **Privilege Escalation - TA0004**  
T1543 - Create or Modify System Process  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1027 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
T1036 - Masquerading  
T1036.004 - Masquerade Task or Service  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1082 - System Information Discovery  
  
 **Collection - TA0009**  
T1005 - Data from Local System  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0010**  
T1041 - Exfiltration Over C2 Channel  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
T1071.004 - DNS  
T1090 - Proxy  
T1573 - Encrypted Channel  
T1573.001 - Symmetric Cryptography

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: ToxicEye RAT
The use of legitimate messaging services for C2 communication in order to bypass security systems is common among threat actors. A blog post from Check Point focuses on the use of Telegram for C2 by a new RAT dubbed "ToxicEye."
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware, RAT




# Overview

Check Point has published a blog analyzing ToxicEye, a new RAT that leverages Telegram for C2 communication. Abusing a legitimate messaging service, such as Telegram, allows malware traffic to bypass security detection systems. Telegram also allows the attackers to remain anonymous as it only requires a phone number for registration. ToxicEye is one example of a RAT using this technique for C2 communication. It spreads via phishing emails with a malicious attachment that downloads and executes the next stage payload. This payload is a configuration file with an embedded executable. The executable connects back to the attacker's C2 via a Telegram bot. It can then receive commands from the bot. Available commands include those that allow for data stealing, file operations, I/O hijacking, and ransomware functionality. ToxicEye along with many other similar RATs can be found hosted publicly on GitHub. For more information, see the Check Point blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://blog.checkpoint.com/2021/04/22/turning-telegram-toxic-new-toxiceye-rat-is-the-latest-to-use-telegram-for-command-control/>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: SAP Security Patch Day - May 2021
SAP has released its May 2021 security patches for a variety of products. Each product and a link to details on the vulnerability are listed below. In all, 6 security notes were released. Of these, 3 are rated high, 2 are rated as medium, and 1 is rated as low. Additionally, there 5 are updates to previously released patches. The potential impact from successful exploitation of the most serious vulnerability is code injection. In addition, information disclosure, malicious redirection, and other nefarious actions are possible.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: SAP Security Patch Day - May 2021
SAP has released its May 2021 security patches for a variety of products. Each product and a link to details on the vulnerability are listed below. In all, 6 security notes were released. Of these, 3 are rated high, 2 are rated as medium, and 1 is rated as low. Additionally, there 5 are updates to previously released patches. The potential impact from successful exploitation of the most serious vulnerability is code injection. In addition, information disclosure, malicious redirection, and other nefarious actions are possible.

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

 We recommend following the manufacturer's recommendations for remediation and patching as soon as possible. Further information can be found in the release located within the Reference section below.

  


  *  **Update to Security Note released on August 2018 Patch Day:**  
 **Security updates for the browser control Google Chromium delivered with SAP Business Client**  
Product - SAP Business Client, Version - 6.5 CVSSv3 Score: 10
  *  **Update to Security Note released on April 2021 Patch Day:**  
 **[CVE-2021-27602] Remote Code Execution vulnerability in Source Rules of SAP Commerce**  
Product - SAP Commerce, Versions - 1808, 1811, 1905, 2005, 2011 CVSSv3 Score: 9.9
  *  **Update to Security Note released on January 2021 Patch Day:**  
 **[CVE-2021-21466] Code Injection in SAP Business Warehouse and SAP BW/4HANA**  
Product - SAP Business Warehouse, Versions - 700, 701, 702, 711, 730, 731, 740, 750, 782   
Product - SAP BW4HANA, Versions - 100, 200 CVSSv3 Score: 9.9
  *  **[CVE-2021-27611] Code Injection vulnerability in SAP NetWeaver AS ABAP**  
Product - SAP NetWeaver AS ABAP, Versions - 700,701,702,730,731 CVSSv3 Score: 8.2
  *  **[CVE-2021-27616] Multiple vulnerabilities in SAP Business One, version for SAP HANA (Business-One-Hana-Chef-Cookbook)**  
Additional CVE - CVE-2021-27614  
Product - SAP Business One, version for SAP HANA (Cookbooks), Versions - 0.1.6, 0.1.7, 0.1.19 CVSSv3 Score: 7.8
  *  **[CVE-2021-27613] Information Disclosure in SAP Business One (Chef business-one-cookbook)**  
Product - SAP Business One (Cookbooks), Version - 0.1.9 CVSSv3 Score: 7.8
  *  **[CVE-2021-27619] Information Disclosure in SAP Commerce (Backoffice search)**  
Product - SAP Commerce (Backoffice Search), Versions - 1808, 1811, 1905, 2005, 2011 CVSSv3 Score: 6.5
  *  **[Multiple CVEs] Multiple vulnerabilities in SAP Process Integration (Integration Builder Framework)**  
CVEs - CVE-2021-27617, CVE-2021-27618  
Product - SAP Process Integration (Integration Builder Framework), Versions - 7.10, 7.11, 7.20, 7.30, 7.31, 7.40, 7.50 CVSSv3 Score: 4.9
  *  **Update to Security Note released on March 2021 Patch Day:**  
 **[CVE-2021-21491] Reverse TabNabbing vulnerability in SAP NetWeaver Application Server Java (Applications based on Web Dynpro Java)**  
Product - SAP NetWeaver Application Server Java (Applications based on Web Dynpro Java), Versions - 7.00, 7.10, 7.11, 7.20, 7.30, 731, 7.40, 7.50 CVSSv3 Score: 4.7
  *  **Update to Security Note released on April 2021 Patch Day:**  
 **[CVE-2021-27609] Missing Authorization check in SAP Focused RUN**  
Product - SAP Focused RUN, Versions - 200, 300 CVSSv3 Score: 4.6
  *  **[CVE-2021-27612] SAP GUI for Windows is vulnerable to redirect users to an untrusted website**  
Product - SAP GUI for Windows, Versions - 7.60, 7.70 CVSSv3 Score: 3.4



# CVEs

  * A complete list of CVEs can be found here: [SAPSecurityPatchDay-May2021-CVEs.txt](/download/attachments/49184990/SAPSecurityPatchDay-May2021-CVEs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1620846528524&api=v2)




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://wiki.scn.sap.com/wiki/pages/viewpage.action?pageId=576094655>

I have encountered the following information: APT34 Campaign IoCs
A tweet from the 360 Threat Intelligence Center provides IoCs believed to be associated with a campaign being conducted by APT34, aka OilRig. APT34 is tracked by IBM X-Force as ITG13.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Campaign, APT




# Overview

APT34 (aka Cobalt Gypsy, Helix Kitten, IRN2, and OilRig) is a threat group suspected to originate from Iran. APT34 is tracked by IBM X-Force as ITG13. APT34 has been operating since at least 2014 and targeted a variety of industries, including energy, chemical, financial, government, and telecommunications. Geographically, the group primarily targets the Middle East. The IoCs relate to malicious Excel files. While no information was provided on the delivery mechanism for the files, it is likely to be via spearphishing emails with the Excel files attached. It is mentioned in the tweet that an attack associated with the IoCs used DNS tunneling.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://twitter.com/360CoreSec/status/1408348476660797440>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: New Rocke Group Malware Variant
Rocke Group has been active since 2018 distributing cryptomining software to Linux-based cloud server. Intezer reports on the group's most recent malware variant being leveraged for spreading their infection.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Cryptomining




# Overview

Intezer has published a blog post analyzing Rocke Group's most recent malware variant. A dropper script is used to download a UPX-packed payload to a victim server. This payload is comprised for multiple modules that are extracted and executed. For persistence, the malware creates a scheduled task in crontab and bashrc files. Additionally, a startup service is created to execute the malware. To spread laterally, the malware first attempts to brute force SSH, Redis, and Jenkins passwords. As a backup, it is able to exploit Jenkins and ActiveMQ vulnerabilities. Library hijacking is used in order to evade detection by hiding its presence from system commands. Following Rocke Group's cryptomining goals, the malware also includes an XMRig miner as a payload. Other processes using a significant amount of CPU are killed prior to the execution of the miner. For more information, see the Intezer blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.



# Reference

  * <https://www.intezer.com/blog/cloud-security/rocke-group-actively-targeting-the-cloud-wants-your-ssh-keys/>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Ad Blocker Injecting Ads Into Legitimate Websites
Researchers at Imperva Research Labs have identified a false ad blocker extension that injects ads into legitimate pages. This extension is available on Chrome and Opera browsers.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

Summary
=======



Attack Details
==============

* **Threat Type:** Adware
* **Targets:** eCommerce
* **Malware Family/Families:**PBot, AllBlock
* **Initial Infection Vector:** Extension Download
* **Post-Compromise Actions:** Unknown

Overview
========

Imperva Research Labs recently uncovered a malicious browser extension that injects malicious adverts into links present on a web page. This particular extension is available on both Chrome and Opera browsers and is called AllBlock. This extension could be used to generate revenue for clicks, sabotage a competitor's site by making their website unusable, or redirect customers to a competitor's site. When a page is loaded, AllBlock sends a list of the links present to a remote server. This server then responds with a list of domains it wants to redirect the user to from those links. These links often have affiliate codes injected into them, allowing the attacker to earn money from the user's clicks. The extension also contains some anti-analysis techniques. Firstly, the extension contains a command to clear the debug console every 100 milliseconds. This conceals the communications between the extension and the remote server. AllBlock also has a built-in allowlist, to prevent it from replacing links from some major websites. This allowlist mainly contains search engines, with a focus on Russian engines. There is a sizeable impact to this kind of attack. It is estimated that 68% of shopping baskets are abandoned and a large part of this could be due to ad injection attempts. This extension has been traced back to another adware campaign known as PBot, which used some of the same back-end infrastructure. Further information can be found in the article located within the Reference section below.

Indicators of Compromise
========================

Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.

Recommendations
===============

* Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
* Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
* Set a browser extension allow or deny list as appropriate for your security policy (M1038).
* Only install browser extensions from trusted sources that can be verified. Browser extensions for some browsers can be controlled through Group Policy. Change settings to prevent the browser from installing extensions without sufficient permissions (M1033).
* Ensure extensions that are installed are the intended ones as many malicious extensions will masquerade as legitimate ones (M1047).

References
==========

* <https://www.imperva.com/blog/the-ad-blocker-that-injects-ads/>

MITRE ATT&CK Framework
======================

**Initial Access - TA0001**  
 T1189 - Drive-by Compromise  

**Persistence - TA0003**  
 T1176 - Browser Extensions  

**Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
 T1070 - Indicator Removal on Host  
   T1070.003 - Clear Command History  

**Command and Control - TA0011**  
 T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
   T1071.001 - Web Protocols

parsed_raw_data.xfe_q:
Ad Blocker Injecting Ads Into Legitimate Websites
Researchers at Imperva Research Labs have identified a false ad blocker extension that injects ads into legitimate pages. This extension is available on Chrome and Opera browsers.
parsed_raw_data.xfe_report:
Summary
=======



Attack Details
==============

* **Threat Type:** Adware
* **Targets:** eCommerce
* **Malware Family/Families:**PBot, AllBlock
* **Initial Infection Vector:** Extension Download
* **Post-Compromise Actions:** Unknown

Overview
========

Imperva Research Labs recently uncovered a malicious browser extension that injects malicious adverts into links present on a web page. This particular extension is available on both Chrome and Opera browsers and is called AllBlock. This extension could be used to generate revenue for clicks, sabotage a competitor's site by making their website unusable, or redirect customers to a competitor's site. When a page is loaded, AllBlock sends a list of the links present to a remote server. This server then responds with a list of domains it wants to redirect the user to from those links. These links often have affiliate codes injected into them, allowing the attacker to earn money from the user's clicks. The extension also contains some anti-analysis techniques. Firstly, the extension contains a command to clear the debug console every 100 milliseconds. This conceals the communications between the extension and the remote server. AllBlock also has a built-in allowlist, to prevent it from replacing links from some major websites. This allowlist mainly contains search engines, with a focus on Russian engines. There is a sizeable impact to this kind of attack. It is estimated that 68% of shopping baskets are abandoned and a large part of this could be due to ad injection attempts. This extension has been traced back to another adware campaign known as PBot, which used some of the same back-end infrastructure. Further information can be found in the article located within the Reference section below.

Indicators of Compromise
========================

Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.

Recommendations
===============

* Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
* Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
* Set a browser extension allow or deny list as appropriate for your security policy (M1038).
* Only install browser extensions from trusted sources that can be verified. Browser extensions for some browsers can be controlled through Group Policy. Change settings to prevent the browser from installing extensions without sufficient permissions (M1033).
* Ensure extensions that are installed are the intended ones as many malicious extensions will masquerade as legitimate ones (M1047).

References
==========

* <https://www.imperva.com/blog/the-ad-blocker-that-injects-ads/>

MITRE ATT&CK Framework
======================

**Initial Access - TA0001**  
 T1189 - Drive-by Compromise  

**Persistence - TA0003**  
 T1176 - Browser Extensions  

**Defense Evasion - TA0005**

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: BlackTech using new Gh0st RAT variant
The threat group BlackTech has been seen using a new variant of Gh0st RAT malware, which has been named Gh0stTimes by researchers at JPCERT. The researchers have seen this malware in use in attacks from 2020, and have analyzed it to understand the new functionality and impact it may have on victims.
output:
# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Malware
  *  **Associated Threat Actors** \- BlackTech (G0098), Hive0090
  *  **Targets:** Japanese Organisations, Technology
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** Gh0st RAT (S0032), Gh0stTimes
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Unknown
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Unknown



# Overview

The threat group BlackTech has been operating since 2018 in east Asia, intending to steal technology from their targets. BlackTech is being tracked by IBM as Hive0090. Recently, they have been observed using a new piece of malware, called Gh0stTimes. This malware has been analyzed by researchers at JPCERT who found that it was an updated version of the existing remote access tool known as Gh0st RAT. This new variant has been used since 2020. In this variant, many functions remain the same, but Gh0stTimes has improved communications, more commands, and a control panel for controlling infected machines. Just as in the original malware, Gh0stTimes communicates with C2 servers using a custom protocol to obfuscate what is sent. However, the malware now exchanges encryption keys with the C2 server that it then uses to encrypt all further communications. Once the encryption is set up, the malware communicates pertinent host information to the C2 server which can be viewed in the control panel GUI. The new variant also contains dummy code to inhibit static analysis, which the researchers stated was ineffective. Once the malware has been installed, it can perform file operations, act as a remote shell, change C2 servers and act as a proxy for further attacks. Further information can be found in the article located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/64129628/BlackTech%20using%20new%20Gh0st%20RAT%20variant%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1633530144534&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.

  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.

  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.

  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.

  * SSL/TLS inspection can be used to see the contents of encrypted sessions to look for network-based indicators of malware communication protocols (M1020).
  * Network intrusion detection and prevention systems that use network signatures to identify traffic for specific adversary malware can be used to mitigate activity at the network level. (M1031).
  * Some endpoint security solutions can be configured to block some types of process injection based on common sequences of behavior that occur during the injection process (M1040). 



# References

  * <https://blogs.jpcert.or.jp/en/2021/10/gh0sttimes.html>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
  
 **Persistence - TA0003**  
T1547.001 - Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder  
  
 **Privilege Escalation - TA0004**  
T1055 - Process Injection  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1112 - Modify Registry  
  
 **Collection - TA0009**  
T1113 - Screen Capture  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1095 - Non-Application Layer Protocol  
T1573 - Encrypted Channel  
T1573.001 - Symmetric Cryptography

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: An Analysis of the Buer Loader
A report from Trend Micro Research provides an analysis of the Buer Loader malware.
output:
# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Loader
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Multiple
  *  **Associated Payloads:** Ransomware, Cobalt Strike, other malware.
  *  **Targets:** Various
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Malicious documents or Exploit Kit
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Payload deployment
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

The Buer Loader was originally written in C has been around since at least late 2019. In the second quarter of 2021, a new variant was observed that has been rewritten in the Rust language. Buer is known to have been used to deliver a range of malware payloads including TrickBot and Ryuk. Buer's deployment options are configurable using its control panel. Since August 2019 and through to the second quarter of 2021, the majority of Buer detections have been in India (40%) and Israel (30%) with the most affected industry sectors being banking, healthcare, and telecommunications. Buer has typically been delivered through malicious documents attached to emails or via an exploit kit such as Fallout. To help avoid detection and make analysis more difficult, Buer uses multiple techniques including obfuscation, time-based evasion, dummy code loops, and checks for sandboxes and analysis tools. In 2021, the most commonly used theme in Buer campaigns was the ubiquitous COVID-19. Perhaps the most common payloads of Buer in 2021 were ransomware or Cobalt Strike. Further information is available from the report linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/70222342/An%20Analysis%20of%20the%20Buer%20Loader%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1636525038521&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques and phishing emails (M1017).



# References

  * <https://www.trendmicro.com/content/dam/trendmicro/global/en/research/21/k/a-review-and-analysis-of-2021-buer-loader-campaigns/TechnicalBrief-An-Analysis-of-Buer-Loader.pdf>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1566 - Phishing  
T1566.001 - Spearphishing Attachment  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1047 - Windows Management Instrumentation  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
T1059.001 - PowerShell  
  
 **Persistence - TA0003**  
T1547 - Boot or Logon Autostart Execution  
T1547.001 - Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder  
  
 **Privilege Escalation - TA0004**  
T1055 - Process Injection  
T1134 - Access Token Manipulation  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1027 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
T1027.002 - Software Packing  
T1140 - Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information  
T1497 - Virtualization/Sandbox Evasion  
T1497.001 - System Checks  
T1497.003 - Time Based Evasion  
T1553 - Subvert Trust Controls  
T1553.002 - Code Signing  
T1562 - Impair Defenses  
T1562.001 - Disable or Modify Tools  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1012 - Query Registry  
T1057 - Process Discovery  
T1082 - System Information Discovery  
T1124 - System Time Discovery  
T1518 - Software Discovery  
T1518.001 - Security Software Discovery

parsed_raw_data.xfe_q:
An Analysis of the Buer Loader
A report from Trend Micro Research provides an analysis of the Buer Loader malware.
parsed_raw_data.xfe_report:
# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Loader
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Multiple
  *  **Associated Payloads:** Ransomware, Cobalt Strike, other malware.
  *  **Targets:** Various
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Malicious documents or Exploit Kit
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Payload deployment
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

The Buer Loader was originally written in C has been around since at least late 2019. In the second quarter of 2021, a new variant was observed that has been rewritten in the Rust language. Buer is known to have been used to deliver a range of malware payloads including TrickBot and Ryuk. Buer's deployment options are configurable using its control panel. Since August 2019 and through to the second quarter of 2021, the majority of Buer detections have been in India (40%) and Israel (30%) with the most affected industry sectors being banking, healthcare, and telecommunications. Buer has typically been delivered through malicious documents attached to emails or via an exploit kit such as Fallout. To help avoid detection and make analysis more difficult, Buer uses multiple techniques including obfuscation, time-based evasion, dummy code loops, and checks for sandboxes and analysis tools. In 2021, the most commonly used theme in Buer campaigns was the ubiquitous COVID-19. Perhaps the most common payloads of Buer in 2021 were ransomware or Cobalt Strike. Further information is available from the report linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/70222342/An%20Analysis%20of%20the%20Buer%20Loader%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1636525038521&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques and phishing emails (M1017).



# References

  * <https://www.trendmicro.com/content/dam/trendmicro/global/en/research/21/k/a-review-and-analysis-of-2021-buer-loader-campaigns/TechnicalBrief-An-Analysis-of-Buer-Loader.pdf>

 **Privilege Escalation - TA0004**  
T1055 - Process Injection  
T1134 - Access Token Manipulation  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1027 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
T1027.002 - Software Packing  
T1140 - Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information  
T1497 - Virtualization/Sandbox Evasion  
T1497.001 - System Checks  
T1497.003 - Time Based Evasion  
T1553 - Subvert Trust Controls  
T1553.002 - Code Signing  
T1562 - Impair Defenses  
T1562.001 - Disable or Modify Tools  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Shadow Academy Targets Universities
RiskIQ have identified a series of attacks against some twenty universities that have occurred from July though to October. The attacks use TTPs similar to Silent Librarian. However, the indicators are not sufficient to attribute the attacks to Silent Librarian. RiskIQ has dubbed the threat actors, Shadow Academy.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Phishing, Espionage, Financial Theft




# Overview

The Mabna Institute (also known as Cobalt Dickens, Silent Librarian, TA407) is tracked by IBM-Force as Hive0082. Nine Iranians associated with the Mabna Institute were indicted by the U.S. Department of Justice in 2018 for a number of attacks on universities and companies, and the Mabna Institute was alleged to be a state sponsored operation. RiskIQ has identified a series of attacks against some twenty universities that occurred through the second half of this year. The TTPs used in the attacks are similar to those associated with the Mabna Institute attacks. RiskIQ notes that despite the similarities, they are insufficient to attribute the attacks to the Mabna Institute. RiskIQ has dubbed the actors behind the attacks as Shadow Academy. RiskIQ's investigation began when an attack against the Louisiana State University was identified. The attack consisted of a spoofed login page used by students. Domain shadowing, carried out by obtaining a domain's account credentials and using them to register subdomains, was used in the attack. In this case a subdomain was used to host the phishing pages. The objective of the attacks is to obtain sensitive information and conduct espionage operations. The universities targeted in the attacks were located in Afghanistan, Australia, the UK, and the USA. Other URLs used by Shadow Academy were aimed at credential and financial theft and targeted services such as online banking, Amazon, and Instagram. RiskIQ also identified another attack named Murrez who is believed to be associated with a group named W4coders, and may be a competitor to Shadow Academy. Further details are available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.riskiq.com/blog/external-threat-management/shadow-academy/>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: LinkedIn Phishing Using Google Forms
By using legitimate services to host malicious content, attackers can bypass detection. Armorblox observed a phishing campaign using this technique by hosting a fake login page on Google Forms.
output:
# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Phishing
  *  **Target:** LinkedIn Users
  *  **Lure:** LinkedIn security alert
  *  **Payload:** Link to a fake login page hosted on Google Forms
  *  **TTPs:** Email sent from a compromised account ([T1078](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1078/)), phishing link ([T1598.003](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1598/003/))
  *  **Compromised Data:** LinkedIn login credentials
  *  **Post-compromise Actions:** Unknown



# Overview

Armorblox published a blog post detailing a phishing campaign leveraging Google Forms to host its malicious content. The initial email spoofs LinkedIn but actually originates from a compromised email account, allowing it to bypass security email gateways. The email claims that the recipient's LinkedIn account has been locked due to unusual activity and requires verification to unlock. Visiting the provided link leads to a Google Form using LinkedIn branding on a fake login form. If a user falls victim, their credentials will be sent to the attacker. For more information, see the Armorblox blog post in the Reference section.

# Recommendations

  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.
  * Enable multi-factor authentication (MFA) where possible.



# References

  * <https://www.armorblox.com/blog/linkedin-phishing-using-google-forms/>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: An In-Depth Look At TA410 Tools And Techniques
ESET researchers have published a detailed profile of the threat group TA410. This report details the group's activities going back to 2019 and outlines the typical tools and techniques they employ.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: An In-Depth Look At TA410 Tools And Techniques
ESET researchers have published a detailed profile of the threat group TA410. This report details the group's activities going back to 2019 and outlines the typical tools and techniques they employ.

# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Backdoor, Rootkit
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** TA410
  *  **Associated Payloads:** FlowCloud, LookBack
  *  **Targets:** Government, Education
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Phishing, Exploitation of Public-Facing Infrastructure
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Data Theft, Espionage



# Overview

ESET researchers have been tracking the group TA410 since early 2019. The group targets organizations around the world with a focus on the governmental and education sectors. The researchers assert that the threat group consists of three teams, with overlapping targets and tools, but different infrastructures. The group is sophisticated, tailoring their techniques to their intended targets. For initial access, the group either uses spearphishing emails or the exploitation of public-facing infrastructure. They utilize sophisticated malware, called FlowCloud which is being continually developed. This malware can control microphones and camera devices, as well as monitor the file systems to steal files. The group also utilizes a rootkit to hide their activities on victim machines. For more detailed information, please see the report in the references section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * For a full list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.




# References

  * <https://www.welivesecurity.com/2022/04/27/lookback-ta410-umbrella-cyberespionage-ttps-activity/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1587.001 - Malware  
T1588.003 - Code Signing Certificates  
T1588.005 - Exploits  
  
 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application  
T1566.001 - Spearphishing Attachment  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1047 - Windows Management Instrumentation  
T1106 - Native API  
T1129 - Shared Modules  
T1203 - Exploitation for Client Execution  
T1559.001 - Component Object Model  
  
 **Persistence - TA0003**  
T1053.005 - Scheduled Task  
T1505.003 - Web Shell  
T1543.003 - Windows Service  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1014 - Rootkit  
T1027 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
T1036.004 - Masquerade Task or Service  
T1036.005 - Match Legitimate Name or Location  
T1055.003 - Thread Execution Hijacking  
T1055.012 - Process Hollowing  
T1070.004 - File Deletion  
T1070.006 - Timestomp  
T1134.002 - Create Process with Token  
T1140 - Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information  
T1497 - Virtualization/Sandbox Evasion  
T1574.002 - DLL Side-Loading  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1010 - Application Window Discovery  
T1012 - Query Registry  
T1016 - System Network Configuration Discovery  
T1057 - Process Discovery  
T1083 - File and Directory Discovery  
T1120 - Peripheral Device Discovery  
T1518 - Software Discovery  
  
 **Collection - TA0009**  
T1025 - Data from Removable Media  
T1056 - Input Capture  
T1056.001 - Keylogging  
T1074.001 - Local Data Staging  
T1113 - Screen Capture  
T1119 - Automated Collection  
T1123 - Audio Capture  
T1125 - Video Capture  
T1560.002 - Archive via Library  
T1560.003 - Archive via Custom Method  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0010**  
T1030 - Data Transfer Size Limits  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1071.001 - Web Protocols  
T1095 - Non-Application Layer Protocol  
T1132.001 - Standard Encoding  
T1132.002 - Non-Standard Encoding  
T1573.001 - Symmetric Cryptography  
  
 **Impact - TA0040**  
T1529 - System Shutdown/Reboot  
  


#### Mitigations:

  
 **M1013:** Application Developer Guidance: This mitigation describes any guidance or training given to developers of applications to avoid introducing security weaknesses that an adversary may be able to take advantage of.  
 **M1015:** Active Directory Configuration - Configure Active Directory to prevent use of certain techniques; use SID Filtering, etc.  
 **M1016:** Vulnerability Scanning - Vulnerability scanning is used to find potentially exploitable software vulnerabilities to remediate them.  
 **M1017:** User Training - Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction.  
 **M1018:** User Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.  
 **M1020:** SSL/TLS Inspection - Break and inspect SSL/TLS sessions to look at encrypted web traffic for adversary activity.  
 **M1021:** Restrict Web-Based Content - Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc.  
 **M1022:** Restrict File and Directory Permissions - Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.  
 **M1024:** Restrict Registry Permissions - Restrict the ability to modify certain hives or keys in the Windows Registry.  
 **M1026:** Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.  
 **M1028:** Operating System Configuration - Make configuration changes related to the operating system or a common feature of the operating system that result in system hardening against techniques.  
 **M1029:** Remote Data Storage - Use remote security log and sensitive file storage where access can be controlled better to prevent exposure of intrusion detection log data or sensitive information.  
 **M1030:** Network Segmentation - Architect sections of the network to isolate critical systems, functions, or resources. Use physical and logical segmentation to prevent access to potentially sensitive systems and information. Use a DMZ to contain any internet-facing services that should not be exposed from the internal network. Configure separate virtual private cloud (VPC) instances to isolate critical cloud systems.  
 **M1031:** Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  
 **M1033:** Limit Software Installation - Block users or groups from installing unapproved software.  
 **M1037:** Filter Network Traffic - Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic.  
 **M1038:** Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
 **M1039:** Environment Variable Permissions - Prevent modification of environment variables by unauthorized users and groups.  
 **M1040:** Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
 **M1041:** Encrypt Sensitive Information - Protect sensitive information with strong encryption.  
 **M1042:** Disable or Remove Feature or Program - Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.  
 **M1044:** Restrict Library Loading - Prevent abuse of library loading mechanisms in the operating system and software to load untrusted code by configuring appropriate library loading mechanisms and investigating potential vulnerable software.  
 **M1045:** Code Signing - Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.  
 **M1047:** Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
 **M1048:** Application Isolation and Sandboxing - Restrict execution of code to a virtual environment on or in transit to an endpoint system.  
 **M1049:** Antivirus/Antimalware - Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software.  
 **M1050:** Exploit Protection - Use capabilities to detect and block conditions that may lead to or be indicative of a software exploit occurring.  
 **M1051:** Update Software - Perform regular software updates to mitigate exploitation risk.  
 **M1052:** User Account Control - Configure Windows User Account Control to mitigate risk of adversaries obtaining elevated process access.  
 **M1054:** Software Configuration - Implement configuration changes to software (other than the operating system) to mitigate security risks associated to how the software operates.  
 **M1056:** Pre-compromise - This category is used for any applicable mitigation activities that apply to techniques occurring before an adversary gains Initial Access, such as Reconnaissance and Resource Development techniques.  
 **M1057:** Data Loss Prevention - Use a data loss prevention (DLP) strategy to categorize sensitive data, identify data formats indicative of personal identifiable information (PII), and restrict exfiltration of sensitive data.

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: New Version of BRATA Android RAT
BRATA has expanded its operations outside of the LATAM region into Italy. Cleafy reports on the tactics, techniques, and procedures (TTPs) involved in a recent campaign against Italian banking customers.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Android banking Trojan
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Unknown
  *  **Associated Payloads:** BRATA
  *  **Targets:** Italian bank customers
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Malicious link via SMS
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Data theft, financial fraud



# Overview

Cleafy published a blog post analyzing a new BRATA campaign targeting Italian banking customers. The infection chain begins with an SMS message containing a link to a website supposedly providing an anti-spam application. The message comes from a spoofed number appearing to be the victim's bank. A human operator will call users who download the app to walk them through the installation process, which involves granting intrusive permissions. With the permissions provided, the malware operator can intercept SMS messages to receive 2FA codes for use in fraudulent transactions. Additionally, the malware is capable of screen recording, uninstalling itself, disabling security defenses, displaying phishing pages, and more. The move from originally targeting Brazilian users to now targeting Italian users may be the result of the malware authors reselling their payloads, according to Cleafy. For more information, see the Cleafy blog post in the References section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/74055902/New%20Version%20of%20BRATA%20Android%20RAT%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1638980691655&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Install security updates (M1001).
  * Users should be encouraged to only install apps from authorized app stores, which are less likely to contain malicious repackaged apps (M1011).
  * Implement an enterprise mobility management (EMM), also known as mobile device management (MDM) (M1012).
  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques (M1017).
  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.



# References

  * <https://www.cleafy.com/cleafy-labs/mobile-banking-fraud-brata-strikes-again>

 **Credential Access - TA0031**  
T1411 - Input Prompt  
T1412 - Capture SMS Messages  
T1417 - Input Capture  
  
 **Collection - TA0035**  
T1412 - Capture SMS Messages

T1509 - Uncommonly Used Port

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: An Analysis of STEELCORGI
STEELCORGI is a tool from the arsenal of a threat actor known as TH-239 or UNC1945. A report from Yoroi provides an analysis of the tool.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: An Analysis of STEELCORGI
STEELCORGI is a tool from the arsenal of a threat actor known as TH-239 or UNC1945. A report from Yoroi provides an analysis of the tool.

# Threat Type

  * Malware




# Overview

A recently published report from Yoroi provides an analysis of a tool named STEELCORGI. The tool is part of the arsenal used by the threat actor known as TH-239 or UNC1945. The Yoroi report describes the tool as a "Swiss Army Knife" due to its capabilities as it can be used for reconnaissance and exploitation, and post exploitation activities such as brute forcing attacks and lateral movement. STEELCORGI is an ELF binary which is heavily protected to make analysis difficult. When the tool is executed, it searches for an environment variable which would have to have been set by the TH-239 actors. The environment variable contains the key required to decrypt the the tool so it can begin to execute the actual payload. The capabilities the tool provides are too numerous to list in a short summary. The report from Yoroi, linked in the Reference section below, provides information on how the tool was extracted from its protective layer for analysis, and the functions it provides.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://yoroi.company/research/opening-steelcorgi-a-sophisticated-apt-swiss-army-knife/>
