instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: New Version of APT-C-23 Android Spyware
APT-C-23 targeting Middle Eastern users with Android spyware. Sophos reports on recent updates to the group's payloads that enhance its evasiveness.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: New Version of APT-C-23 Android Spyware
APT-C-23 targeting Middle Eastern users with Android spyware. Sophos reports on recent updates to the group's payloads that enhance its evasiveness.

# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Android Spyware
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** APT-C-23
  *  **Associated Payloads:** APT-C-23 Spyware
  *  **Targets:** Middle East
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Side-loaded malicious APK
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Remote command execution, data theft



# Overview

Sophos published a blog post analyzing a recent version of APT-C-23's Android spyware. The group operates in the Middle East, primarily targeting victims in the Palestinian territories. The infection vector of the most recent payloads is unknown, although Sophos suspects that SMS text message links are the source of the malicious download. Upon installation, the device checks in with a hardcoded C2 address. A new addition to the code allows this C2 address to be updated by the operators as needed. After obtaining the permissions required to carry out its functionality, the app attempts to hide itself from the user by changing its logo and name to that of a legitimate application, such as Google Play, Youtube, Google, or Botim. Opening the app from this point forward will open the legitimate version of the application it is masquerading as. The malware will continue to wait for commands received via Firebase messaging. Command capabilities include data collection, taking pictures and screenshots, recording audio, reading notifications, and more. Any collected data is ZIP archived and later uploaded to the C2 server. For more information, see the Sophos blog post in the References section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/72155158/New%20Version%20of%20APT-C-23%20Android%20Spyware%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1637766335569&api=v2)

  * Install security updates (M1001).
  * Users should be encouraged to only install apps from authorized app stores, which are less likely to contain malicious repackaged apps (M1011).
  * Implement an enterprise mobility management (EMM), also known as mobile device management (MDM) (M1012).
  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques (M1017).
  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.



# References

  * <https://news.sophos.com/en-us/2021/11/23/android-apt-spyware-targeting-middle-east-victims-improves-its-capabilities/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Initial Access - TA0027**  
T1444 - Masquerade as Legitimate Application  
T1476 - Deliver Malicious App via Other Means  
  
 **Execution - TA0041**  
T1575 - Native Code  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0030**

 **Discovery - TA0032**  
T1418 - Application Discovery  
  
 **Collection - TA0035**

T1429 - Capture Audio

T1433 - Access Call Log

T1517 - Access Notifications

T1437 - Standard Application Layer Protocol

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Targeted HelloKitty Ransomware Attack
In the wake of a targeted attack against CD Projekt Red, SentinelOne has published a blog post analyzing the HelloKitty ransomware.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Targeted HelloKitty Ransomware Attack
In the wake of a targeted attack against CD Projekt Red, SentinelOne has published a blog post analyzing the HelloKitty ransomware.

# Threat Type

  * Ransomware




# Overview

SentinelOne has published a blog post analyzing the HelloKitty ransomware family, which was recently leveraged in a targeted attack against CD Projekt Red. HelloKitty appeared in late 2020 and is relatively rudimentary compared to other ransomware families. For example, when processes are being killed a CMD window is spawned in the foreground for each instance, alerting users to unexpected behavior. After processes are killed, encryption takes place using either an AES-256 and RSA-2048 combination or AES-128 and NTRU. Either way, no weaknesses in the encryption are known, making decryption without a key impossible. The ransom notes specifically reference the victim or their environment, indicating its targeted nature. Victims are directed to a support portal on TOR where they can pay a ransom in order to receive a decryption program and key. The portal address was not active at the time of publication of this article. For more information, see the SentinelOne blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://labs.sentinelone.com/hellokitty-ransomware-lacks-stealth-but-still-strikes-home/>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Delta Plus Ransomware
While investigating smaller ransomware actors, McAfee researchers uncovered an actor distributing a ransomware payload dubbed "Delta Plus."

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Ransomware
  *  **Targets:** Unknown
  *  **Ransomware Family:** Delta Plus
  *  **RaaS Operation:** No
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Fake application installers
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Data Encryption, Data Theft



# Overview

McAfee published a blog post analyzing the Delta Plus ransomware as a part of an investigation into small ransomware actors. The ransomware was discovered due to a hit on a Babuk payload signature. The reason it was detected as Babuk is because it was based on leaked Babuk source code. The Bitcoin address, actor email addresses, and ransomware name were edited for the actor's purpose, but the payload remained the same. McAfee notes that prior to leveraged leaked Babuk code, the actor attempted to write their own ransomware but it was simple and easy to analyze. Investigating domains contacted by the payload led to the discovery of an open directory containing additional tools, such as scripts for defense evasion and privilege escalation. Further pivoting on the network infrastructure led to what is likely the initial infection vector, fake Flash and AnyDesk installers, along with an exfiltration tool and other payloads. For more information, see the McAfee blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/64130649/Delta%20Plus%20Ransomware%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1634655653585&api=v2)

parsed_raw_data.xfe_q:
Delta Plus Ransomware
While investigating smaller ransomware actors, McAfee researchers uncovered an actor distributing a ransomware payload dubbed "Delta Plus."
parsed_raw_data.xfe_report:
# Threat Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Ransomware
  *  **Targets:** Unknown
  *  **Ransomware Family:** Delta Plus
  *  **RaaS Operation:** No
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Fake application installers
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Data Encryption, Data Theft



# Overview

McAfee published a blog post analyzing the Delta Plus ransomware as a part of an investigation into small ransomware actors. The ransomware was discovered due to a hit on a Babuk payload signature. The reason it was detected as Babuk is because it was based on leaked Babuk source code. The Bitcoin address, actor email addresses, and ransomware name were edited for the actor's purpose, but the payload remained the same. McAfee notes that prior to leveraged leaked Babuk code, the actor attempted to write their own ransomware but it was simple and easy to analyze. Investigating domains contacted by the payload led to the discovery of an open directory containing additional tools, such as scripts for defense evasion and privilege escalation. Further pivoting on the network infrastructure led to what is likely the initial infection vector, fake Flash and AnyDesk installers, along with an exfiltration tool and other payloads. For more information, see the McAfee blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Phishing Campaign Targeting Microsoft SSO Discovered
The Cofense Phishing Defense Center has published a report on a new phishing campaign they have discovered. This campaign is attempting to harvest victim's Microsoft SSO credentials.
output:
# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Credential Harvesting
  *  **Target:** Microsoft SSO
  *  **Lure:** Password Reset Email
  *  **Compromised Data:** Microsoft SSO Credentials
  *  **Post-compromise Actions:** Unknown



# Overview

The Cofense Phishing Defense Center has uncovered a new phishing campaign targeting consumers. The goal of this attack is to steal Microsoft Single Sign-on credentials, meaning one password can compromise many different systems. The phishing emails come from a compromised domain owned by a law firm and are spoofed to appear it is coming from a well-known fragrance company. The use of an established law firm that has been registered since 2015 means the email is more likely to get past email defenses, as it is more likely to be legitimate. The link in the email takes the user to a false Microsoft login page, where the credentials entered will be logged and used in other attacks or sold. This campaign has been seen in several environments that have email protections. Further information is available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/74057304/Phishing%20Campaign%20Targeting%20Microsoft%20SSO%20Discovered%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1642762617886&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques and phishing emails (M1017).



# References

  * <https://cofense.com/blog/cyber-gang-targets-users-with-password-expiration-scan/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1584 - Compromise Infrastructure  
T1584.001 - Domains  
  
 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1566 - Phishing  
T1566.002 - Spearphishing Link  
  
 **Credential Access - TA0006**  
T1056 - Input Capture  
T1056.003 - Web Portal Capture  
  
 **Collection - TA0009**  
T1056 - Input Capture  
T1056.003 - Web Portal Capture

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Telegram Utilized for Harvesting Credentials
Using legitimate services for malicious purposes is common as it helps attackers fly under the radar. In one such case, Cofense researchers discovered attackers using the Telegram API in a phishing campaign.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Phishing




# Overview

Cofense published a blog post analyzing the use of the Telegram API in a recent phishing campaign. The initial phishing email spoofs an internal support address and claims that there are emails that have been blocked and need to be manually reviewed. When a user clicks the link, they are redirected to a webmail phishing page customized based on the domain of the victim email address. The most interesting aspect of this campaign is that entering credentials leads to a POST request to the legitimate Telegram API. The attackers can then retrieve the email credentials from their Telegram account. After their credentials are exfiltrated, victims are redirected to the domain associated with their email. For more information, see the Cofense blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://cofense.com/blog/telegram-utilized-credentials>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: AnyDesk Bundled with Babuk Ransomware
A blog post from Quick Heal details an infection chain involving fake AnyDesk websites distributing the Babuk downloader and Allakore RAT.
output:
# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** RAT, Ransomware
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Unknown
  *  **Associated Payloads:** Allakore, Babuk
  *  **Targets:** Unknown
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Fake AnyDesk installer
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Data theft, data encryption



# Overview

Quick Heal uncovered fake AnyDesk websites being used to ultimately infect victims with the Babuk ransomware. These sites advertise a free AnyDesk installer that, if downloaded, is delivered to the system as a self-extracting archive. Upon execution, the archive runs the legitimate AnyDesk setup binary, presenting the installer application to the user. In the background, the Allakore RAT, Babuk downloader, and a .reg file are dropped into the Startup folder and subsequently executed using PowerShell. First, the .reg file is used to disable UAC and malware protection. Then the Babuk downloader is executed, which first launches the Allakore RAT to establish a C2 connection back to the attacker. After performing various defense evasion tactics, the downloader ultimately downloads and executes a BAT script and executable. The BAT script performs further defense evasion. The executable file is the final payload, the Babuk ransomware. Files are encrypted and data is stolen with a ransom being demanded in order to restore access and prevent data leak. For more information, see the Quick Heal blog post in the References section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [Anydesk Bundled with Babuk Ransomware IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/72155276/Anydesk%20Bundled%20with%20Babuk%20Ransomware%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1638206944295&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Restrict Web-Based Content (M1021).
  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques and phishing emails (M1017).
  * Set PowerShell execution policy to execute only signed scripts (M1045).



# References

  * <https://blogs.quickheal.com/anydesk-software-exploited-to-spread-babuk-ransomware/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1608 - Stage Capabilities  
T1608.001 - Upload Malware  
  
 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1566 - Phishing  
T1566.002 - Spearphishing Link  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
T1059.001 - PowerShell  
T1059.003 - Windows Command Shell  
T1204 - User Execution  
T1204.002 - Malicious File  
  
 **Persistence - TA0003**  
T1547 - Boot or Logon Autostart Execution  
T1547.001 - Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1027 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
T1027.002 - Software Packing  
T1548 - Abuse Elevation Control Mechanism  
T1548.002 - Bypass User Account Control  
T1562 - Impair Defenses  
T1562.001 - Disable or Modify Tools  
  
 **Impact - TA0040**  
T1486 - Data Encrypted for Impact  
T1490 - Inhibit System Recovery

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Vidar Now Using Social Media To Retrieve C2 Server Address
As malware grows more sophisticated, it develops new ways to communicate with the threat groups controlling it. In this article from ASEC Labs, the Vidar info-stealer can be seen using social media to create C2 servers.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Info-stealer
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Unknown **  
**
  * **Associated Payloads:** Vidar
  *  **Targets:** Unknown
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Unknown **  
**
  * **Post-Compromise Actions:** Data Theft



# Overview

The ASEC analysis team has seen the Vidar info-stealer using social media to update what C2 server it is currently using. Rather than having a list of C2 domains hard-coded in the malware, Vidar leverages the social media site Mastadon to dynamically update its C2 server. Upon installation, the malware reaches out to a certain account on this social media platform named "banda5ker". This page contains a string in the bio section which has the word "hello" followed by an IP address. The malware downloads this page and searches for the "hello" string, which it uses as a flag to download the IP address, which corresponds to the C2 server. instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: FBI Flash - Ranzy Locker Ransomware
The FBI has issued a Flash that provides information on the Ranzy Locker ransomware.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: FBI Flash - Ranzy Locker Ransomware
The FBI has issued a Flash that provides information on the Ranzy Locker ransomware.

# Threat Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Ransomware
  *  **Targets:** Construction, academia, information technology, and transportation sectors.
  *  **Ransomware Family:** Ranzy Locker
  *  **RaaS Operation:** Yes
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Brute-forcing RDP, Exploitation of Exchange server vulnerabilities, Phishing
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Lateral movement, Data collection, and exfiltration, Encryption of files.
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

The FBI reports that Ranzy, first appearing in late 2020, has since been used to target victims in the United States academia, construction, information technology, and transportation sectors. As of July 2021, Ranzy's victims number more than thirty. The attackers compromised the majority of the victims using brute-force attacks against the Remote Desktop Protocol (RDP). The more recent victims were compromised through phishing or exploitation of Microsoft Exchange Server vulnerabilities. As is typical of modern ransomware attacks, the attackers searched the victim systems for sensitive data to exfiltrate which they threaten to publish unless the victim pays the ransom. The FBI notes that in some cases, a second ransom was demanded to prevent the publication of the victim's data. Further information is available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/68616790/FBI%20Flash%20-%20Ranzy%20Locker%20Ransomware%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1635314644454&api=v2)



# Detection

  * A Yara rule can be found here: [ Yara Rule.txt](/download/attachments/68616790/FBI%20Flash%20-%20Ranzy%20Locker%20Ransomware%20Yara%20Rule.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1635314733931&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).

  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.

  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).

  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).

  * Restrict Web-Based Content (M1021).

  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques and phishing emails (M1017).

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: LemonDuck Leveraging ProxyLogon
New variants of the LemonDuck cryptominer malware are emerging as exploiting ProxyLogon continues to occur. Sophos reports on the latest variants.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: LemonDuck Leveraging ProxyLogon
New variants of the LemonDuck cryptominer malware are emerging as exploiting ProxyLogon continues to occur. Sophos reports on the latest variants.

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Cryptominer




# Overview

Common aspects of samples utilizing the ProxyLogon exploit have led to the conclusion these variants are part of the LemonDuck campaign. Some of the observed behaviors include deploying multiple copies of web shells dropped in attacks, installing the miner payload as a Windows service for persistence, lateral movement using Oracle WebLogic server exploits, using certutil to download LemonDuck (launched using PowerShell), creating a user account with RDP, evasion code updates to disable and remove security products, and, in one variant, a Cobalt Strike beacon is deployed. All of the variants exploited the IIS process (w3wp.exe) for command execution on the MSE server targeted. Most commonly, researchers observed similar attack vectors and code to previous instances of LemonDuck. Other attacks employed certutil to download a PowerShell script. There was even an attempt at a file-less attack using code in script-based exploits that are directly executed by cmd.exe. This script attempts to create a user and gain Remote Desktop access to servers. Variants of the China Chopper shells were observed in this campaign. Further details can be found in the report located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://news.sophos.com/en-us/2021/05/07/new-lemon-duck-variants-exploiting-microsoft-exchange-server/>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Android Security Bulletin - January 4th, 2021
Android published a security bulletin regarding vulnerabilities in their operating system and its components.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Android Security Bulletin - January 4th, 2021
Android published a security bulletin regarding vulnerabilities in their operating system and its components.

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

 In total they disclosed 41 vulnerabilities including remote code execution, privilege escalation, information disclosure, and denial of service issues. Four of the vulnerabilities were rated as "Critical" severity, thirty-six as "High" severity, and one as "Moderate" severity. The most severe potential impact is arbitrary code execution by a remote attacker. Along with those in the Android software itself, vulnerabilities in its components, such as MediaTek and Qualcomm, are also addressed in this advisory. Patches have been released to fix these issues. We recommend reviewing the advisories in the Reference section for patches and mitigation advice.

# CVEs

  * A complete list of CVEs can be found here: [ CVEs.txt](/download/attachments/35719477/Android%20Security%20Bulletin%20-%20January%204th%2C%202021%20CVEs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1609966411374&api=v2)




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  * <https://source.android.com/security/bulletin/2021-01-01>

Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Oracle CPU - January 2021
Oracle has released their quarterly Critical Patch Update (CPU) for October of 2020. Included are updates that fix 329 security vulnerabilities across the Oracle product line.

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

  
 The main CPU document provides details on affected products and the CVSS scoring details for each vulnerability addressed. A description of each vulnerability, and the CVSS vector string, are available from the risk matrices in the verbose version of the CPU. In addition, Oracle has also released its Solaris Third Party Bulletin which addresses vulnerabilities in third party software that is provided with Oracle Solaris. instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Silver Sparrow - macOS Malware With No Current Payload
An unusual piece of macOS malware has been reported by Red Canary. The malware is named Silver Sparrow, has infected almost 30,000 systems but, as of yet, has no actual payload.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware




# Overview

Silver Sparrow is macOS malware, two versions of which have been analysed by Red Canary. The first version surfaced in August 2020, the second version appearing a month later. Both versions contained Mach-O binaries. However, the Mach-O binary in the second version is compiled for the Intel x86_64 and M1 ARM64 architectures. Silver Sparrow has been distributed using malvertising with links that lead to malicious DMG or PKG installers. Between them, the two versions of Silver Sparrow are reported to have infected almost 30,000 systems. Once installed, Silver Sparrow contacts its C&C every hour. As of yet, no actual payload is known to have been delivered to the infected systems. Silver Sparrow can completely remove itself from infected systems. While the actual purpose of Silver Sparrow is unknown, and there is no current payload, the operators of Silver Sparrow could issue instructions to the malware at a time of their choosing. Further details are available from the report linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://redcanary.com/blog/clipping-silver-sparrows-wings/>

Silver Sparrow has been distributed using malvertising with links that lead to malicious DMG or PKG installers. Between them, the two versions of Silver Sparrow are reported to have infected almost 30,000 systems. Once installed, Silver Sparrow contacts its C&C every hour. As of yet, no actual payload is known to have been delivered to the infected systems. Silver Sparrow can completely remove itself from infected systems. While the actual purpose of Silver Sparrow is unknown, and there is no current payload, the operators of Silver Sparrow could issue instructions to the malware at a time of their choosing. Further details are available from the report linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://redcanary.com/blog/clipping-silver-sparrows-wings/>

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: More Apps On Google Play Infected with Cerberus
In keeping with the current state of the amount of malware on the Google Play store, another report on Cerberus and its infiltration on various apps within the store has been published. Bitdefender provides some insight and analysis on this threat.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware, Trojan




# Overview

Applications on the Google Play store have become targets for threat actors to implant their wares. Cerberus is a banking Trojan that has been found within numerous applications located on the store. Using machine learning algorithms, detection of these applications began as early as February 2020 with the most recent being found mere days ago. Popularity amongst these applications ranges from little to the most popular having more than 10,000 downloads. The applications in question usually contain at least part of the functionality expected. Behind the scenes, these applications communicate with C2 servers and, provided they meet prerequisites, download malicious APKs. In order to perform its intended actions, the application requests administrative rights from the victim. If approved, the application will install the payload and use the admin rights to enable the malicious actions. Several items of interest are communicated back to C2 servers including country, package name, build release, and build model. A token is sent to the app and is used for all future communication with the C2 server. The applications delivered are based on the parameters provided in the vetting process. This makes tracing the applications more difficult. Once the app is successfully installed and the subsequent payload downloaded, the first app is no longer used for malicious actions. Given that the apps have been given administrative permissions, they interact with malicious applications in the Cerberus family and perform the typical Cerberus actions. It is at this point that the malware has full control of the device, making it especially disconcerting to security professionals. At present, there are two different versions of the malware. The first is less obfuscated and uses Base64 encryption. Communication was simpler and lacked the registration process seen in version 2. The second version uses different obfuscation techniques and contains very little of the debugging information from version 1. Additionally, communication is more advanced, which allows for more precise control of the payload and its installation. Further hindering investigations is the use of several developer accounts with a vague pattern emerging in the email addresses. Droppers are mainly located in Europe and specifically Spain. The U.S. and Australia also contain servers for the droppers. Further information can be found in the blog post located within the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://labs.bitdefender.com/2020/09/apps-on-google-play-tainted-with-cerberus-banker-malware/>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Craigslist Mail Relay Abused for Phishing
Craigslist implements a mail relay to send notifications and messages while protecting a user's identity. Inky researchers observed this relay being used in a phishing campaign to evade detection and trick users.
output:
# Threat Details

  *  **Threat Type** : Malware
  *  **Target:** Craigslist users
  *  **Lure:** Craigslist violation warning
  *  **Payload:** Malicious document hosted on OneDrive
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Download additional payloads
  *  **Additional TTPs:** Abuse of Craigslist mail relay



# Overview

Inky published a blog post detailing a phishing campaign abusing the Craigslist mail relay to evade detection and trick users. The relay is used to allow users to send messages in response to posts while protecting their identity. In the campaign observed by Inky researchers, the threat actor sent messages to Craigslist users via this feature, resulting in an email that comes from the legitimate Craigslist domain. The content of the email claimed that the recipient's post violated a policy and a form must be filled out to prevent their account from being deleted. The link leads to a Word document hosted on Microsoft OneDrive with a download link for the supposed form. The downloaded file is a ZIP archive containing a macro-enabled spreadsheet using a Docusign theme. Analysis of the macro reveals attempts to download additional files, however, the files were not accessible at the time of analysis, so the final payload is unknown. For more information, see the Inky blog post in the References section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [Craiglist Mail Relay Abused for Phishing IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/68616751/Craiglist%20Mail%20Relay%20Abused%20for%20Phishing%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1635272571201&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Restrict Web-Based Content (M1021).
  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques and phishing emails (M1017).



# References

  * <https://www.inky.com/blog/urgency-mail-relay-serve-phishers-well-on-craigslist>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1566 - Phishing  
T1566.002 - Spearphishing Link  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1204 - User Execution  
T1204.001 - Malicious Link  
T1204.002 - Malicious File

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Further on CacheFlow
In December 2020, researchers from Avast published a report on what they named CacheFlow. They have now published a followup which provides further technical details.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Type

  * Malware




# Overview

Reported in December 2020, CacheFlow was a campaign that used a number of malicious browser extensions for the Chrome and Edge web browsers. The campaign was named CacheFlow by researchers from Avast. A new report from Avast provides further technical details on the campaign, which resulted in more than three million installs of the malicious plugins. The plugins were available through the Google and Microsoft stores, and were deleted from them in December. CacheFlow employed a number of techniques to avoid discovery and is thought to have operated since 2017. Once one of the malicious extensions was installed, the operators could gather information about the victim, redirect the victim to URLs of their choosing, and install other malware. Further information is available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://decoded.avast.io/janvojtesek/backdoored-browser-extensions-hid-malicious-traffic-in-analytics-requests/>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: The Ferocious Kitten APT Group
A report from Kaspersky provides some information on the TTPs associated with the Ferocious Kitten APT group.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: The Ferocious Kitten APT Group
A report from Kaspersky provides some information on the TTPs associated with the Ferocious Kitten APT group.

# Threat Type

  * Malware, APT




# Overview

The Ferocious Kitten is an APT group that, according to Kaspersky, has been operating since at least 2015. The primary targets of the group are those who speak Persian and are located in Iran. Kaspersky notes that two other APT groups, Domestic Kitten and Rampant Kitten, show similarities with Ferocious Kitten's TTPs and victims. Two malicious documents, both of which use the Persian language, were analyzed by Kaspersky. If macros are enabled, the documents display anti-Iranian regime messages. The documents also drop an executable file named "update.exe" onto the victim's system. The executable is copied to the Startup directory and renamed "svehost.exe" to achieve persistence. The use of weaponized documents appears to be a relatively new adoption for Ferocious Kitten, in the past, malicious executables were delivered directly to victims. Kaspersky has named the payload MarkiRAT. MarkiRAT is basically an information stealer and keylogger that provides its operators with the ability to search the victim system for files, upload and download files, and execute commands. Some variants of MarkiRAT have additional features, such as hijacking the Telegram messaging app and the Chrome browser. Further information is available from the Kaspersky report linked in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://securelist.com/ferocious-kitten-6-years-of-covert-surveillance-in-iran/102806/>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: BazarLoader Delivered via Compromised Installers and ISO Files
The BazarLoader actors leverage numerous techniques for delivering their payload to victims. Trend Micro reports on two of the newest BazarLoader delivery vectors: compromised installers and ISO files.
output:
# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Backdoor
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Unknown
  *  **Associated Payloads:** BazarLoader
  *  **Targets:** Unknown
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Compromised installers, ISO files
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Deploy additional malware



# Overview

Trend Micro published a blog post detailing BazarLoader's new use of compromised installers and ISO files as an initial delivery vector. The first method specifically involved compromised versions of VLC and TeamViewer packages. It is unknown how these packages are being distributed, but they are possibly part of a social engineering campaign. Once on the system, the installer drops and executes a BazarLoader executable. Notably, BazarLoader typically leverages DLLs, not executables. Upon execution, the BazarLoader payload connects to a C2 server and injects itself into an MS Edge process. In the case of the ISO file delivery vector, the ISO contains a LNK file that is responsible for running a BazarLoader DLL. As with the previous infection chain, BazarLoader then connects to its C2 and injects into MS Edge. Ultimately, BazarLoader is typically used to install a second-stage payload, such as Cobalt Strike or ransomware. For more information, see the Trend Micro blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/72155161/BazarLoader%20Delivered%20via%20Compromised%20Installers%20and%20ISO%20Files%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1637766458972&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Restrict Web-Based Content (M1021).
  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques and phishing emails (M1017).



# References

  * <https://www.trendmicro.com/en_us/research/21/k/bazarloader-adds-compromised-installers-iso-to-arrival-delivery-vectors.html>
  * <https://www.trendmicro.com/content/dam/trendmicro/global/en/research/21/k/bazarloader-adds-compromised-installers-iso-to-arrival-delivery-vectors/tb-bazarloader-looking-in-analyzing-the-infection-chains-stages-and-campaigns.pdf>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1587 - Develop Capabilities  
T1587.001 - Malware  
  
 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1566 - Phishing  
T1566.001 - Spearphishing Attachment  
T1566.002 - Spearphishing Link  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1204 - User Execution  
T1204.002 - Malicious File  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1055 - Process Injection  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
T1071.001 - Web Protocols

instruction:
I have encountered the following information: Phorpiex Botnet Now Running Without C2 Server
Phorpiex malware was briefly down this summer, but has since returned in a more sophisticated form, according to a report by Check Point Research. The new variant is able to run as a Peer-to-Peer network in the event of its C2 servers being shut down, increasing the botnet resiliency.

What can you tell me about it? I need overview, related mitre attack informations if exists, IoCs, recommandations and possible references.
output:
You are asking about a specific threat report. Below is the information I have about the given report

# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Cryptomining
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Unknown
  *  **Associated Payloads:** Phorpiex/Twizt
  *  **Targets:** Cryptocurrency Owners
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Unknown
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Crpyto-clipping, Malware Dropping



# Overview

Check Point Researchers have reported on a new variant of the old cryptominer known as Phorpiex. Earlier this year, the owners of this malware commented that they were shutting down operations and putting the source code up for sale. Less than two weeks after this statement, Phorpiex reappeared with some new functionality. It is unclear whether it was sold and redeveloped or if the original threat actors decided to continue development. The main difference was that this new variant was able to function without any C2 servers, operating in a peer-to-peer mode to communicate with other infected machines. The malware also appears to be more successful at using the crypto-stealing technique known as crypto-clipping. This technique replaces any copied cryptocurrency address with the attacker's wallet when pasted. Since the addresses are long and random, the victim doesn't notice the replacement and authorizes the payment to the victim's wallet. The total value of currency stolen this way is almost half a million dollars, with the largest single transaction totaling 26 Etherium. The malware also has a new method for communicating with the C2 server. It uses a custom, encrypted protocol which uses a hash value to guarantee message integrity, which is more sophisticated than the original malware used. This new variant is called 'Twizt' and is steadily increasing in prevalence with most infections occurring in African countries. There is some evidence the operators of this malware are Ukrainian, as the malware will not run on machines in Ukraine. Further information is available from the links in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/74056390/Phorpiex%20Botnet%20Now%20Running%20Without%20C2%20Server%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1640254355709&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking (M1038). 
  * Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior (M1040). 



# References

  * <https://research.checkpoint.com/2021/phorpiex-botnet-is-back-with-a-new-twizt-hijacking-hundreds-of-crypto-transactions/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1053 - Scheduled Task/Job  
T1129 - Shared Modules

parsed_raw_data.xfe_q:
Phorpiex Botnet Now Running Without C2 Server
Phorpiex malware was briefly down this summer, but has since returned in a more sophisticated form, according to a report by Check Point Research. The new variant is able to run as a Peer-to-Peer network in the event of its C2 servers being shut down, increasing the botnet resiliency.
parsed_raw_data.xfe_report:
# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Cryptomining
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Unknown
  *  **Associated Payloads:** Phorpiex/Twizt
  *  **Targets:** Cryptocurrency Owners
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Unknown
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Crpyto-clipping, Malware Dropping



# Overview

Check Point Researchers have reported on a new variant of the old cryptominer known as Phorpiex. Earlier this year, the owners of this malware commented that they were shutting down operations and putting the source code up for sale. Less than two weeks after this statement, Phorpiex reappeared with some new functionality. It is unclear whether it was sold and redeveloped or if the original threat actors decided to continue development. The main difference was that this new variant was able to function without any C2 servers, operating in a peer-to-peer mode to communicate with other infected machines. The malware also appears to be more successful at using the crypto-stealing technique known as crypto-clipping. This technique replaces any copied cryptocurrency address with the attacker's wallet when pasted. Since the addresses are long and random, the victim doesn't notice the replacement and authorizes the payment to the victim's wallet. The total value of currency stolen this way is almost half a million dollars, with the largest single transaction totaling 26 Etherium. The malware also has a new method for communicating with the C2 server. It uses a custom, encrypted protocol which uses a hash value to guarantee message integrity, which is more sophisticated than the original malware used. This new variant is called 'Twizt' and is steadily increasing in prevalence with most infections occurring in African countries. There is some evidence the operators of this malware are Ukrainian, as the malware will not run on machines in Ukraine. Further information is available from the links in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/74056390/Phorpiex%20Botnet%20Now%20Running%20Without%20C2%20Server%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1640254355709&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking (M1038). 
  * Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior (M1040). 



# References

  * <https://research.checkpoint.com/2021/phorpiex-botnet-is-back-with-a-new-twizt-hijacking-hundreds-of-crypto-transactions/>

T1053 - Scheduled Task/Job  
T1129 - Shared Modules

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Finding Threats and Threat-Groups Based on a Cookie
RiskIQ's second part in a series called "Adventures in Cookie Land" leverages cookies found to locate related threats and threat-groups.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware, Threat-Groups



# Overview

In part two of RiskIQ's "Adventures in Cookie Land" report, they used a malicious cookie to discover how many other threats and threat groups they could uncover. They found several different threat groups had used different variations of a similar backdoor in the past. Base64-encoded versions of the cookie they based this section on also led to activity associated with Goblin Panda, groups that used ICEFOG malware, a group behind what they tagged as "WATERFIGHT" campaign, as well as other active threat groups. In all, they found nine unique IP addresses linked to this modified indicator. One of the more interesting IP addresses belonged to a subsidiary of Choopa named Vultr. That IP had hosted a number of sites in December of 2019 that have been tied to threat activity. Domains associated with that IP led to three more connected IPs, one of which was owned by Digital Ocean that has been known to host malicious sites in the past. Continuing their pivoting, the researchers came across ICEFOG. They also identified indicators related to the APT9 and APT15 and additional IP addresses. For more details, please see the links in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/30769630/Finding%20Threats%20and%20Threat-Groups%20Based%20on%20a%20Cookie%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1600718007784&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://www.riskiq.com/blog/external-threat-management/cookie-land/>
  * <https://community.riskiq.com/article/5fe2da7f>
  * <https://community.riskiq.com/article/56fa1b2f>

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: ACTINIUM Targeting Ukraine
Microsoft has published a report on the activities of a threat actor they have named ACTINIUM that has been targeting organizations located in Ukraine.
output:
# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Malware, Espionage.
  *  **Targets:** Ukrainian government entities including the judiciary, law enforcement, and military as well as attacking non-profit organizations and NGOs.
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** DinoTrain, DesertDown, DilongTrash, ObfuBerry, ObfuMerry, PowerPunch, Pterodo (S0147), QuietSieve.
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Spearphishing emails with malicious documents attached.
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Lateral movement, collection, and exfiltration of information.
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

ACTINIUM is the name Microsoft has applied to a threat actor they previously tracked as DEV-0157 and is also known publicly as Gamaredon. ACTINIUM has been operating for close to 10 years. In the last 6 months, Microsoft has observed ACTINIUM targeting Ukrainian government entities including the judiciary, law enforcement, and military as well as attacking non-profit organizations and NGOs. The Ukrainian government has attributed ACTINIUM to the Russian Federal Security Service (FSB) and has been operating from Crimea. Microsoft reports that ACTINIUM's objectives are cyber espionage, maintaining and using their access to move laterally into related organizations. While a number of vectors may be used to compromise their targets. Microsoft notes one method in its report, that being the use of spearphishing emails with malicious documents attached that use remote template injection to begin the infection chain. The spearphishing emails and documents are typically themed to an organization that is familiar to the target. A number of payloads are deployed and these include DesertDown, DinoTrain, DilongTrash, ObfuBerry, ObfuMerry, PowerPunch, Pterodo, QuietSieve. In some cases, UltraVNC has been deployed to provide more interactive remote access. Further information is available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/74058528/ACTINIUM%20Targeting%20Ukraine%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1644546386402&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level (M1051).
  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques and phishing emails (M1017).
  * Restrict Web-Based Content (M1021).



# References

  * <https://www.microsoft.com/security/blog/2022/02/04/actinium-targets-ukrainian-organizations/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Reconnaissance - TA0043**  
T1589 - Gather Victim Identity Information  
T1591 - Gather Victim Org Information  
  
 **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1583 - Acquire Infrastructure  
T1583.001 - Domains  
T1583.004 - Server  
T1587 - Develop Capabilities  
T1587.001 - Malware  
T1588 - Obtain Capabilities  
T1588.002 - Tool  
T1608 - Stage Capabilities  
T1608.001 - Upload Malware  
T1608.002 - Upload Tool  
  
 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1199 - Trusted Relationship  
T1566 - Phishing  
T1566.001 - Spearphishing Attachment  
  
 **Execution - TA0002  
** T1053 - Scheduled Task/Job  
T1053.005 - Scheduled Task  
T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter  
T1059.005 - Visual Basic  
T1204 - User Execution  
T1204.002 - Malicious File

 **Persistence - TA0003**  
T1547 - Boot or Logon Autostart Execution  
T1547.001 - Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder

 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1027 - Obfuscated Files or Information  
T1070 - Indicator Removal on Host  
T1070.004 - File Deletion  
T1218 - Signed Binary Proxy Execution  
T1218.011 - Rundll32  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1083 - File and Directory Discovery  
  
 **Collection - TA0009**  
T1005 - Data from Local System  
T1074 - Data Staged  
T1074.001 - Local Data Staging  
T1113 - Screen Capture  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0010**  
T1041 - Exfiltration Over C2 Channel

 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
T1071.001 - Web Protocols  
T1105 - Ingress Tool Transfer

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Unexpected Sign-In Attempt Phishing
Several companies across the US, England, and Scotland are reporting a targeted phishing campaign attempting to obtain corporate email account credentials. Cofense reports on their analysis of this campaign.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Unexpected Sign-In Attempt Phishing
Several companies across the US, England, and Scotland are reporting a targeted phishing campaign attempting to obtain corporate email account credentials. Cofense reports on their analysis of this campaign.

# Threat Type

  * Phishing




# Overview

Cofense has published their analysis of a phishing campaign seen targeting organizations in English-speaking countries. The phishing emails are customized using the organization's name in various aspects to appear more legitimate. It is used in the "From" field as part of the sender address, the subject line and in various parts of the email body. The email claims that there was a sign in attempt from a suspicious location and points to an attached file that can be used to review that activity. Opening the attached HTML file leads to a fake sign in page for the company's mail portal, requesting their email address and password. Cofense notes that the images and CSS styles are pulled from a remote website. Entering the credentials results in a POST request to an attacker-controlled URL. For more information, see the Cofense blog post in the Reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.   




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.
  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.
  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.
  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.



# Reference

  * <https://cofense.com/101-credential-phishing-for-observant-employees/>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Adobe Security Updates April 2021
Adobe has released four security updates. The updates are for Photoshop, Digital Editions, Bridge, and RoboHelp. Three of the updates address at least one vulnerability rated by Adobe as Critical and one is rated Important.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Adobe Security Updates April 2021
Adobe has released four security updates. The updates are for Photoshop, Digital Editions, Bridge, and RoboHelp. Three of the updates address at least one vulnerability rated by Adobe as Critical and one is rated Important.

# Threat Type

  * Vulnerability




# Overview

 The potential impact of successful exploitation of the most serious vulnerabilities is the remote execution of arbitrary code. Further details are available from the links below.

 **APSB21-28 Security updates available for Adobe Photoshop**  
Adobe has released updates for Photoshop for Windows and macOS. These updates resolve multiple critical [vulnerabilities. Successful exploitation could lead to arbitrary code execution in the context of the current user.](https://helpx.adobe.com/security/products/framemaker/apsb21-14.html)  
<https://helpx.adobe.com/security/products/photoshop/apsb21-28.html>

 **APSB21-26 Security Updates Available for Adobe Digital Editions**  
Adobe has released a security update for Adobe Digital Editions. This update resolves a critical vulnerability that could result in arbitrary file system write.  
<https://helpx.adobe.com/security/products/Digital-Editions/apsb21-26.html>

 **APSB21-23 Security Updates Available for Adobe Bridge**  
Adobe has released a security update for Adobe Bridge. This update addresses critical and important vulnerabilities that could lead to arbitrary code execution in the context of the current user.   
<https://helpx.adobe.com/security/products/bridge/apsb21-23.html>

**APSB21-20 Security update available for RoboHelp  
** Adobe has released a security update for RoboHelp. This update resolves a vulnerability rated important. Successful exploitaton could lead to privilege escalation in the context of current user.  
<https://helpx.adobe.com/security/products/robohelp/apsb21-20.html> **  
**

# CVEs

  * A complete list of CVEs can be found here: [ CVEs.txt](/download/attachments/46072181/Adobe%20Security%20Updates%20April%202021%20CVEs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1618520349798&api=v2)




# Recommendations

  * Review the source article for full details.

  * Apply applicable patches, updates, or workarounds as necessary. 




# Reference

  *     * <https://helpx.adobe.com/security.html>

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: Malicious CHM Files Used to Target Korean Users
Ahnlab's ASEC team has published a report that provides an analysis of Windows Help Files (.chm) that are being used to distribute malware.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: Malicious CHM Files Used to Target Korean Users
Ahnlab's ASEC team has published a report that provides an analysis of Windows Help Files (.chm) that are being used to distribute malware.

# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Malware
  *  **Targets:** Korean users
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** Unspecified
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Malicious .chm files.
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Deployment of unspecified payloads.
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

Windows Help Files (.chm) are being used to target Korean users, according to a report from Ahnlab's ASEC team. While the delivery mechanism is not stated, the victim receives an archive file that contains multiple files, and in some cases an additional archive file. Some of the files within the archive are benign but the .chm files contain malicious code that results in the creation of a file that when executed uses PowerShell to download additional files. Persistence is achieved by creating an LNK file which is then executed on startup by a registry run key. The payloads that would be downloaded were not able to be obtained. Further information is available from the link in the Reference section below.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

  * For a list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.




# References

  * <https://asec.ahnlab.com/en/34313/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Tactics and Techniques:**

####  **Resource Development - TA0042**  
T1584 - Compromise Infrastructure  
T1584.004 - Server  
T1587 - Develop Capabilities  
T1587.001 - Malware  
T1608 - Stage Capabilities

Malicious CHM Files Used to Target Korean Users
Ahnlab's ASEC team has published a report that provides an analysis of Windows Help Files (.chm) that are being used to distribute malware.
parsed_raw_data.xfe_report:
# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Malware
  *  **Targets:** Korean users
  *  **Malware Family/Families:** Unspecified
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Malicious .chm files.
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Deployment of unspecified payloads.
  *  **Additional TTPs:** See the MITRE ATT&CK Framework below.



# Overview

Windows Help Files (.chm) are being used to target Korean users, according to a report from Ahnlab's ASEC team. While the delivery mechanism is not stated, the victim receives an archive file that contains multiple files, and in some cases an additional archive file. Some of the files within the archive are benign but the .chm files contain malicious code that results in the creation of a file that when executed uses PowerShell to download additional files. Persistence is achieved by creating an LNK file which is then executed on startup by a registry run key. The payloads that would be downloaded were not able to be obtained. Further information is available from the link in the Reference section below.

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report.

instruction:
Tell me about the following threat: New Cryptbot Has been Optimized and Upgraded
ASEC Labs have been tracking the distribution of the infostealer Cryptbot. This article describes the latest incarnation of this malware which is currently being distributed.

Provide threat type, overview, describe IoCs if exists, recommandations, related MITRE ATT&CK TTPs and references if exists.
output:
Sure! Here is the information I have about the threat: New Cryptbot Has been Optimized and Upgraded
ASEC Labs have been tracking the distribution of the infostealer Cryptbot. This article describes the latest incarnation of this malware which is currently being distributed.

# Threat Details

  *  **Malware Type:** Infostealer
  *  **Associated Threat Actors:** Unknown
  *  **Associated Payloads:** Cryptbot
  *  **Targets:** Unknown
  *  **Initial Infection Vector:** Fake Websites Advertising Cracked Software **  
**
  *  **Post-Compromise Actions:** Credential and Data Theft



# Overview

ASEC labs have analyzed the latest version of the Cryptbot infostealer. The infostealer is normally distributed on websites that claim to host cracked software and tools. The actors optimize these pages so they appear at the top of search results, increasing infection probability. The latest version of the malware removes several features for simplification. This includes the anti-sandbox routine and the use of multiple C2 addresses. The actors have also removed behavior that allows the malware to collect TXT files and take screenshots. The new version has been updated so it can steal from the latest version of Chrome. However, the biggest improvement is that previous versions of Cryptbot would fail if any data that the malware was targetting didn't exist. The bug has been fixed so the malware can run regardless of the success of the stealing behavior. For more information, please see the link in the reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * A complete list of IoCs can be found here: [ IoCs.txt](/download/attachments/74059279/New%20Cryptbot%20Has%20been%20Optimized%20and%20Upgraded%20IoCs.txt?version=1&modificationDate=1645615239169&api=v2)



# Recommendations

  * Use anti-virus software and ensure software and associated files are up to date (M1049).
  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs (M1031, M1035, M1037).
  * Train users to identify social engineering techniques and phishing emails (M1017).
  * Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing (M1045). 



# References

  * <https://asec.ahnlab.com/en/31802/>



# MITRE ATT&CK Framework

 **Initial Access - TA0001**  
T1566 - Phishing  
  
 **Execution - TA0002**  
T1204 - User Execution  
T1204.002 - Malicious File  
  
 **Persistence - TA0003**  
T1547.001 - Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder  
  
 **Privilege Escalation - TA0004**  
T1055 - Process Injection  
T1055.011 - Extra Window Memory Injection  
  
 **Defense Evasion - TA0005**  
T1055.009 - Proc Memory  
  
 **Credential Access - TA0006**  
T1003 - OS Credential Dumping  
  
 **Collection - TA0009**  
T1119 - Automated Collection  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0010**  
T1041 - Exfiltration Over C2 Channel

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Phishing Campaign Impersonates AhnLab To Infect Victim
ASEC Labs has written an analysis on a new phishing campaign impersonating AhnLab to infect the victim. The attack executed Windows Media Player and then downloaded and installed malware.
output:
# Attack Details

  *  **Threat Type:** Malware
  *  **Target:** Users In Korea
  *  **Lure:** Crypto-themed Word docs
  *  **Payload:** Downloaders
  *  **Post-compromise Actions:** Malware download and Install



# Overview

ASEC Labs has been reporting on a new phishing campaign. The latest documents found in this campaign are using text that impersonates AhnLab to trick users into opening the document and allowing macros to be run. Each document has a financial or cryptocurrency-themed title as a lure. When the file is opened, a Word macro file is downloaded and executed after the user grants permission. Upon execution, the macro is set to execute whenever the openState property of the Windows Meda Player object is changed. It then downloads and executes malicious programs. System information is sent to a hardcoded C2 address, although at the time of writing this address was not accessible. Persistence for the downloaded malware is gained through the registry. For more information, please see the link in the reference section.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * Associated indicators of compromise are provided alongside this report. 



# Recommendations

For a full list of mitigative recommendations, please see the MITRE ATT&CK Framework matrix below.

# References

  * <https://asec.ahnlab.com/en/33477/>

T1566 - Phishing  
T1566.001 - Spearphishing Attachment

T1059.005 - Visual Basic  
T1204.002 - Malicious File  
  
 **Persistence - TA0003**

 **Privilege Escalation - TA0004**  
T1548.002 - Bypass User Account Control  
  
 **Discovery - TA0007**  
T1049 - System Network Connections Discovery  
T1082 - System Information Discovery  
  
 **Collection - TA0009**  
T1005 - Data from Local System  
  
 **Exfiltration - TA0010**  
T1041 - Exfiltration Over C2 Channel  
  
 **Command and Control - TA0011**  
T1071 - Application Layer Protocol  
  


#### Mitigations:

  
 **M1013:** Application Developer Guidance: This mitigation describes any guidance or training given to developers of applications to avoid introducing security weaknesses that an adversary may be able to take advantage of.  
 **M1017:** User Training - Train users to be aware of access or manipulation attempts by an adversary to reduce the risk of successful spearphishing, social engineering, and other techniques that involve user interaction.  
 **M1018:** User Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to user accounts.  
 **M1021:** Restrict Web-Based Content - Restrict use of certain websites, block downloads/attachments, block Javascript, restrict browser extensions, etc.  
 **M1022:** Restrict File and Directory Permissions - Restrict access by setting directory and file permissions that are not specific to users or privileged accounts.  
 **M1024:** Restrict Registry Permissions - Restrict the ability to modify certain hives or keys in the Windows Registry.  
 **M1025:** Privileged Process Integrity - Protect processes with high privileges that can be used to interact with critical system components through use of protected process light, anti-process injection defenses, or other process integrity enforcement measures.  
 **M1026:** Privileged Account Management - Manage the creation, modification, use, and permissions associated to privileged accounts, including SYSTEM and root.  
 **M1028:** Operating System Configuration - Make configuration changes related to the operating system or a common feature of the operating system that result in system hardening against techniques.  
 **M1031:** Network Intrusion Prevention - Use intrusion detection signatures to block traffic at network boundaries.  
 **M1033:** Limit Software Installation - Block users or groups from installing unapproved software.  
 **M1037:** Filter Network Traffic - Use network appliances to filter ingress or egress traffic and perform protocol-based filtering. Configure software on endpoints to filter network traffic.  
 **M1038:** Execution Prevention - Block execution of code on a system through application control, and/or script blocking.  
 **M1040:** Behavior Prevention on Endpoint - Use capabilities to prevent suspicious behavior patterns from occurring on endpoint systems. This could include suspicious process, file, API call, etc. behavior.  
 **M1042:** Disable or Remove Feature or Program - Remove or deny access to unnecessary and potentially vulnerable software to prevent abuse by adversaries.  
 **M1043:** Credential Access Protection - Use capabilities to prevent successful credential access by adversaries; including blocking forms of credential dumping.  
 **M1044:** Restrict Library Loading - Prevent abuse of library loading mechanisms in the operating system and software to load untrusted code by configuring appropriate library loading mechanisms and investigating potential vulnerable software.  
 **M1045:** Code Signing - Enforce binary and application integrity with digital signature verification to prevent untrusted code from executing.  
 **M1047:** Audit - Perform audits or scans of systems, permissions, insecure software, insecure configurations, etc. to identify potential weaknesses.  
 **M1049:** Antivirus/Antimalware - Use signatures or heuristics to detect malicious software.  
 **M1051:** Update Software - Perform regular software updates to mitigate exploitation risk.  
 **M1052:** User Account Control - Configure Windows User Account Control to mitigate risk of adversaries obtaining elevated process access.  
 **M1054:** Software Configuration - Implement configuration changes to software (other than the operating system) to mitigate security risks associated to how the software operates.  
 **M1057:** Data Loss Prevention - Use a data loss prevention (DLP) strategy to categorize sensitive data, identify data formats indicative of personal identifiable information (PII), and restrict exfiltration of sensitive data.

instruction:
Tell me everything you know the following threat: Bitcoin Scam Leads To Millions For Threat Actors
ZDNet's investigation revealed a progressive Bitcoin campaign, leading to massive monetary gain for threat actors and a loss in money, data, and trust for its end-users.
output:
# Threat Type

  * Malware, Phishing




# Overview

  
ZDNet reported on a resurgence of Bitcoin attacks, as threat actors capitalize on vulnerabilities within Electrum's application backend infrastructure, allowing threat actors to create false servers, using them as bait for users of the original application. This simple, yet well-orchestrated scheme, combines human error and phishing tactics, enticing users of the application to install a malicious version of the original app. Users are then duped into providing a requested one-time passcode after receiving notification for an update. If threat actors are successful up to that point, there is a high chance users of Electrum's wallet application have given approval for the malicious wallet to transfer all of their funds to an attacker's account. Electrum, understands the impact of malicious servers and have applied preventative measures to reduce the tempo of attacks such as: a server blacklisting system and updates preventing servers from showing HTML formatted popups to end users.

# Indicators of Compromise

  * N/A




# Recommendations

  * Ensure anti-virus software and associated files are up to date.

  * Search for existing signs of the indicated IoCs in your environment.

  * Consider blocking and or setting up detection for all URL and IP based IoCs.

  * Keep applications and operating systems running at the current released patch level.

  * Exercise caution with attachments and links in emails.




# References

  * [https://www.zdnet.com/article/bitcoin-wallet-trick-has-netted-criminals-more-than-22-million/](https://www.zdnet.com/article/bitcoin-wallet-trick-has-netted-criminals-more-than-22-million/)
